site_title: Jawala IPO's public tranche 18.5 times subscribed
summary: Malaysian timber company Jawala's initial public offering closed with its public offer tranche subscribed 18.5 times, drawing 7.4 million shares. The placement tranche was fully allotted, with six parties receiving at least 5% of the shares. Jawala raised about S$3.2 million in net proceeds through the offering and will make its trading debut on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board on June 1.

site_title: First Aida
summary: The Singapore Lyric Opera is set to stage Verdi's classic opera Aida for the first time, with Nancy Yuen in the title role and Andrew Sinclair directing. The production, costing S$1 million, features over 100 singers, including Thomas Ruud as Radames and Martin Ng as Amonasro. The opera tells the tragic story of Aida, an Ethiopian princess who falls in love with Egypt's army commander Radames, despite the circumstances. Aida runs from June 1 to 6 at the Esplanade Theatre.

site_title: Qantas and Air New Zealand sign alliance as downunder tourism booms
summary: Qantas and Air New Zealand signed a codeshare deal covering 115 domestic routes, fueling record profits in the region. The agreement, made amid booming tourism, allows the airlines to leverage each other's strengths in their home markets. The deal comes as domestic revenues drive profits, dividends, and stock prices, with Qantas reaching a record profit in February and Air New Zealand set for its second-highest annual profit. The move marks a shift in airline alliances, with Qantas and Air New Zealand dropping or redrawing deals with Gulf carriers.

site_title: As Malaysia rebuilds, foreign relations may not be top focus
summary: Malaysia's newly installed government, led by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, is focusing on fulfilling election pledges and addressing the country's financial crisis. The government has scrapped the Goods and Services Tax (GST), offering a refund to citizens, and implemented fuel subsidies and reduced toll rates. Civil servants and pensioners will also receive bonuses. The government is reviewing and renegotiating big-ticket projects, including the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail, to rationalize expenditure and preserve fiscal discipline. This shift in focus may test relations with neighboring countries, particularly Singapore.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rally at open as Italy clinches deal
summary: European stocks rallied at the open on June 1, 2018, as Italy reached a new coalition deal, overshadowing trade war fears. The FTSE 100 index climbed 0.6%, the DAX 30 gained 0.6%, and the CAC 40 rose 0.8%. Milan's FTSE MIB opened up 2.5%. Investors looked ahead to US jobs data, brushing aside concerns about the ongoing trade tensions between the US and EU.

images.alt_text: European stock markets rallied at the open on Friday after Italy reached a new coalition deal, with investors brushing aside trade war fears and looked ahead to key US jobs data.

site_title: Malaysia timber firm Jawala pushes back trading debut to Friday, 2pm
summary: Malaysia-based sustainable timber company Jawala Inc has delayed its trading debut to Friday at 2pm due to an unexpected delay in filing the return of allotment, as May 31 was a public holiday. The company aims to raise S$3.15 million by offering 18 million shares at S$0.25 apiece. Incorporated in August 2017, Jawala holds a 100-year licence to manage a 11,043-hectare plantation in Sabah's Sapulut Forest Reserve.

site_title: Australia home prices post first annual fall in six years
summary: Australia's home prices have posted their first annual decline in six years, with a nationwide drop of 0.4% in May, according to CoreLogic. This decline is attributed to tighter lending standards at banks, which cooled demand in major cities like Sydney and Melbourne. However, regional markets continued to rise, leading to a 0.1% drop in combined capital cities' home prices. The decline marks the first annual drop since 2012, as prices slipped 0.4% for the year.

site_title: Crypto wallet that attracted US$35b wins IDG backing
summary: ImToken, a Chinese cryptocurrency wallet startup, has secured $10 million in funding from IDG Capital, valuing the company at an unspecified amount. The wallet has attracted 4 million users who have stored over $35 billion in crypto assets, surpassing major competitors like Coinbase. Founded in 2016, ImToken has focused on supporting Ethereum, becoming the world's largest Ethereum wallet provider. The company plans to expand beyond China, adding a new office in Singapore and increasing its headcount, with a focus on institutional investors.

site_title: Pandan Valley Chic
summary: Former architect Koon Wai Leong transformed a 1,700 sq ft apartment in Pandan Valley, Singapore, into a perfect family home for his family of four. He stripped the space bare and reconfigured the layout to suit his needs, knocking down non-load-bearing walls and adding a laundry room, play area, and study. The apartment now features a spacious kitchen, stylish living room, and children's bedrooms on the same level, connected by a play area. The couple, who previously lived in a rented apartment, chose a black and grey theme with brass accents for a timeless look, and took their time selecting furniture pieces.

images.alt_text: The split levels separate the private and the common areas.
The new dry kitchen overlooks the living room.
The play area which connects the children's bedrooms on both ends.
The study which has glass doors that allow natural light in.
The bathroom gets a stylish touch.
The cosy master bedroom.
''There is nothing else like this for a family that you can find at anywhere near this price.'' - Koon Wai Leong

site_title: Asia: Markets fluctuate as US tariffs spark fresh trade war fears
summary: US President Donald Trump imposed tariffs on European, Mexican, and Canadian steel and aluminum, sparking fears of a trade war. Markets in Asia fluctuated, with Hong Kong and Tokyo rising, while Shanghai fell. The European Union threatened countermeasures, and French President Emmanuel Macron labeled the move "illegal." Analysts warn the trade war could impact global growth and relations, and investors are watching US jobs data and a G7 finance ministers meeting for further guidance.

site_title: Trump plays down chances of quick breakthrough as North Koreans bring letter
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed skepticism about a quick breakthrough in negotiations with North Korea, despite receiving a letter from North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. A delegation from Pyongyang is set to meet with Trump at the White House, which may revive talks on denuclearization. Trump hopes for an unprecedented meeting with Kim on June 12 in Singapore, but acknowledges that deals often take time. North Korea has proposed a phased approach to denuclearization, which Trump has rejected. Diplomatic efforts have been ongoing to get the summit back on track.

site_title: Mattis, Modi in Singapore for security summit
summary: US Defence Secretary Jim Mattis is attending a security summit in Singapore to assure allies of America's commitment to the region and its aim of checking China's rise. Mattis aims to steer clear of speculation on a possible meeting between North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and President Donald Trump, instead focusing on Washington's backing of the Asia-Pacific region. The summit comes as China continues its military build-up in the South China Sea, prompting concerns about the effectiveness of US warnings.

site_title: Singapore's PropNex Realty preparing to launch IPO: sources
summary: PropNex Realty Pte, Singapore's largest property broker, is preparing to launch an initial public offering (IPO) seeking about S$40 million. The company aims for a market capitalization of up to S$250 million, with IPO shares to be marketed at 62-68 Singapore cents apiece. PropNex, which has nearly 7,000 agents, is considering the IPO as the local housing market recovers, with en bloc sales projected to reach S$12.8 billion this year, the highest in over a decade.

site_title: New Zealand's terms of trade fall in Q1 as weak dairy export prices weigh
summary: New Zealand's terms of trade fell 1.9% in Q1, marking the first decline in over a year, due to weaker dairy export prices. Dairy prices dropped 6.7% and export prices fell 2.2%, while imports edged down 0.3%. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand's cautious monetary policy remains intact, with interest rates at 1.75%. Economists expect a stronger outlook for exports, citing recent global milk price increases.

site_title: NWC recommends monthly wage hikes of S$50 to S$70 for those earning up to S$1,300
summary: The National Wages Council (NWC) of Singapore recommended monthly wage hikes of S$50 to S$70 for low-wage workers earning up to S$1,300, covering 24,000 more workers than last year. The guidelines also propose a special bonus of S$300 to S$600 for companies that achieved productivity improvements last year. Additionally, employers are encouraged to give raises and/or one-off lump sums to workers earning above S$1,300 based on their skills and productivity.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.05 points to 1,744.67 at 9:07am. The market saw 184.05 million lots traded worth RM84.06 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 155 to 119.

site_title: HSR cancellation was coalition policy from the start, says Mahathir
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad denied pre-empting the Cabinet when announcing the cancellation of the High-Speed Rail (HSR) line between Singapore and Kuala Lumpur. Mahathir stated that the decision was part of the coalition's policy from the start, citing the party's campaign on the issue during the May general elections. He emphasized that he would not go against the party's decision, despite not being able to form the Cabinet soon enough.

site_title: Australian shares end down, banks rattled by ANZ; NZ falls
summary: Australian shares ended down 0.4% on Friday, dropping 21.5 points to 5,990.4, as the banking sector was rattled by ANZ facing criminal charges. The index marked its third week in the red, amid trade tariffs and bank woes, following Italy's political turmoil earlier in the week. US trade tariffs against key trading partners also hurt sentiment.

site_title: Malaysia working with Singapore to recover lost 1MDB funds
summary: Malaysia is cooperating with Singapore to recover billions of dollars believed to have been embezzled from the state investment company 1MDB. Investigators are working together to map a money trail, collect evidence, and identify Singapore witnesses. This cooperation comes after Malaysia's new Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's administration pledged to cooperate with global probes into the scandal. Singapore has previously seized hundreds of millions of dollars in assets and jailed bankers linked to the scandal, and its authorities are now assisting Malaysian investigators in piecing together how funds were laundered through major financial centers.

site_title: Chemicals firm Anchun International reshuffles board, names new CEO
summary: Anchun International Holdings has appointed Zheng Zhi Zhong as executive director and chief executive, replacing Xie Ming. Zheng has 10 years of experience with the company, including roles in engineering design, project management, and production management. He takes over from Xie Ming, who has been redesignated as executive chairman. The reshuffle is the company's latest board move.

site_title: Moncler goes for monthly launches of its jackets
summary: Luxury fashion brand Moncler is launching a monthly production strategy, dubbed "Genius," aiming to offer new products for all of its down coat collections on a monthly basis. Under this plan, Moncler will partner with world-renowned designers to create limited-edition collections. The strategy aims to adapt to changing shopping habits and appeal to younger consumers influenced by social media. Moncler's CEO, Remo Ruffini, hopes to eventually expand the monthly launch to all of its collections, which account for 80% of its sales.

site_title: Why Wall Street traders aren't rejoicing over changes to Volcker rule
summary: The Federal Reserve and other agencies proposed changes to the Volcker Rule, which will likely make compliance cheaper and easier for smaller firms. The revised regime won't significantly ease a ban on risky trading or expand allowed activities. The biggest win for Wall Street is eliminating the intent test, which required trades to benefit clients, not bet the bank's money. The new proposal focuses on whether the bank has labeled the security a trading asset on its balance sheet, applying only to firms with more than $25 million in losses and profits in a three-month period.

site_title: Europe's biggest debt collector says Italian exposure 'very good'
summary: Europe's largest debt collector, Intrum AB, says the Italian government's political instability won't impact its business, citing the country's existing debt as a positive. Intrum stands by its deal with Intesa to service non-performing loans in Italy, despite concerns over the country's economic and political situation.

site_title: More than half of US drivers killed 'had drugs in system'
summary: A new report by the Governors Highway Safety Association finds that nearly two-thirds of drivers killed in highway crashes tested positive for opioids, marijuana, or a combination of both. The number of drivers testing positive for these substances has increased from 28% in 2006 to 43.6% in 2016. The report urges states to develop reliable roadside testing devices and provide better training for law enforcement to detect drivers under the influence of these substances, as more states move to legalize marijuana.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as trade war fears grow
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on June 1, 2018, due to growing fears of a global trade war. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.39% to 22,114.95, while the Topix index dropped 0.39% to 1,740.72. The decline was triggered by US announcements of steel and aluminium tariffs on the European Union, Canada, and Mexico, sparking concerns about trade tensions.

site_title: Singapore bank lending goes up 0.8% in April
summary: Singapore bank lending increased by 0.8% in April to S$667 billion, a slower pace than the 1.6% growth in March. Business lending rose 1.2% to S$402 billion, with loans to the building and construction sector growing 0.4%. Consumer lending increased 0.3% to S$265 billion, while housing loans gained 0.4%. Bank lending has risen 5.7% year-on-year, with forecasters expecting a 4% increase for the full year of 2018.

site_title: Gold prices rise on weaker US dollar, trade tension
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to $1,305.87 per ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar and concerns over US-China trade tensions. This is the second straight monthly decline, but gold is still up 1.4% for the year. The easing of US dollar highs and trade tensions supported gold prices, with US gold futures for June delivery up 0.3%.

images.alt_text: Gold prices have risen as the US dollar eases from six-and-a-half-month highs hit earlier this week, with prices further supported by concerns over US-China trade.

site_title: It's downhill for airline profits as fuel prices creep higher
summary: Airline profits are expected to decline significantly due to rising fuel costs, with IATA CEO Alexandre de Juniac stating that carriers will have to pass the burden onto passengers. Despite solid profits for 2018, fuel costs will "bite hard" if prices continue past $80 a barrel. European airlines have increased fuel hedging, while Norwegian Air Shuttle remains cautious, and analysts predict a reduction in potential earnings across Europe by up to $4.7 billion this year.

site_title: Trump says talks positive, expects letter from Kim
summary: US President Donald Trump said a North Korean delegation, led by former spy chief Kim Yong Chol, is likely to deliver a letter from North Korean leader Kim Jong Un to Washington on Friday, following talks between Trump's Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Kim Yong Chol in New York. The letter is seen as a positive step towards a potential summit between Trump and Kim, with the goal of denuclearization. Trump expressed optimism about the talks, stating that they are "going along very well" and that he is willing to stay for a longer period in Singapore if results are promising.

site_title: Malaysia vows to meet deficit target, plug RM21b tax hole
summary: Malaysia's finance minister, Lim Guan Eng, announced that the country will meet its 2018 budget deficit target despite a US$5 billion loss from the scrapped goods and services tax. The RM21 billion revenue shortfall will be offset by increased oil revenues, spending cuts, and higher dividends from government-linked firms. The projected fiscal deficit will increase to RM40.1 billion, maintaining a 2.8% of GDP. The government aims to maintain fiscal discipline and has no plans to revise economic growth forecasts or list state-owned Petronas for funding.

site_title: US and Brent crude part ways, leaving market flummoxed over oil prices
summary: US and Brent crude oil futures have diverged, with US crude trading as much as $11 below Brent, the deepest discount since 2015. This has left traders and investors confused, despite expectations that OPEC, led by Saudi Arabia, would increase global supplies as US sanctions on Iran reduce exports. The US oil glut, driven by record production, is threatening to swamp the global market, with light sweet crude from the US muscling into refineries worldwide.

images.alt_text: Global oil markets have been roiled by a surprising divergence between the world's major benchmarks, Brent crude and its US counterpart, which in recent days have traded at odds with one another, wrongfooting investors betting on the exact opposite.

site_title: China A-shares make MSCI debut
summary: China's A-shares, denominated in yuan and traded on the Shanghai and Shenzhen bourses, will make their debut on MSCI's indices on Friday, marking a milestone in Chinese securities development. The inclusion of over 200 A-share large-caps is expected to encourage foreign investment, although observers warn that gains may not be felt immediately due to low corporate transparency and volatility in the market. MSCI's inclusion is expected to put A-shares on the radar of foreign investors, potentially leading to passive fund inflows, but active fund inflows may be limited in the initial stage.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower on trade war fears, Dow -1.0%
summary: US stocks ended lower on Thursday, May 31, 2018, due to fears of a trade war following the Trump administration's announcement of tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from Europe, Canada, and Mexico. The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 1.0% to 24,416.33, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.7% and 0.3%, respectively. The decline was attributed to concerns over a potential trade war between the US and its major trading partners.

site_title: Stranger Things
summary: Theatre company The Finger Players has created a set of strange stories inspired by Chinese supernatural classic Liaozhai Zhiyi, titled "Citizen Dog". The play, performed in Mandarin with English surtitles, critiques contemporary society through supernatural elements. It explores the lives of ordinary people, featuring a middle-aged widower, a mysterious foreigner, and a fox spirit, raising questions about reality and illusion. "Citizen Dog" will be performed at the Victoria Theatre from June 8 to 10.

site_title: Grain Fed
summary: Grain, an online restaurant in Singapore, offers healthy, grain-based meals delivered to offices and homes. The company's in-house chefs create nutrient-dense recipes featuring ancient grains like quinoa, freekeh, and bulgur wheat. Popular dishes include Grilled Farm Fresh Chicken and chicken yakitori. Meals can be ordered up to five working days in advance and are available for delivery. Customers can order on the website grain.com.sg.

site_title: No takers for Air India; govt's terms too onerous
summary: The Indian government's plan to sell a 76% stake in Air India has failed to draw a single bid, despite easing some terms and extending the deadline. The airline has lucrative routes but also faces challenges, including a high employee-to-aircraft ratio. The government is unlikely to extend the deadline and expects bids to come in at the last minute. Selling Air India is crucial to meet the government's divestment target and keep the fiscal deficit at 3.3% of GDP, but the current market conditions may not be supportive for a sale.

site_title: STI dips 0.5% at 11th hour
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,428.18, down 15.77 points, or 0.5%, at the 11th hour on Thursday. This follows a sell-off the previous day, with the index failing to recover. The short-term bearish view prevails, with the local bourse being an outlier in the region, where most Asian markets logged gains.

site_title: Sembcorp buys UK distributed energy generator for £216m
summary: Sembcorp Industries acquired UK distributed energy generator UK Power Reserve for £216m (S$385.72m) in cash, expanding its presence in the UK's flexible distributed energy sector. The deal, part of Sembcorp's strategy to rebalance its energy portfolio towards developed markets, brings on board flexible assets and merchant energy capabilities. UKPR owns 533 megawatts of operational and under-development projects, providing small-scale, fast-ramping power generation and rapid response batteries to counter renewable power intermittency.

site_title: HDB's latest 12-year bond deal makes it the biggest issuer in 2018
summary: HDB, Singapore's public housing body, sold a S$500 million 12-year bond, making it the nation's largest issuer of Singapore dollar bonds this year. The bond, rated Aaa by Moody's, was issued under its S$32 billion multicurrency medium-term note programme. Despite poor market sentiment, HDB tapped into improved investor sentiment following dovish signals from the US Federal Reserve, catching a positive uplift in investor sentiment to access the market. This sale brings HDB's total bond issuance to S$1.615 billion this year.

site_title: US allies hit back at Washington's steel, aluminium tariffs
summary: The US imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from Canada, Mexico, and the European Union, sparking retaliation from its allies. The tariffs, announced by US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross, drew criticism from lawmakers and business groups, leading to a decline in financial markets. Canada and Mexico retaliated with tariffs on US goods, while the EU threatened to impose duties on Harley-Davidson motorcycles and bourbon. The move is seen as a hardening of the Trump administration's approach to trade negotiations, with potential consequences for the global economy and US allies.

site_title: Chinese WeWork rival said to seek fresh funding to expand
summary: KR SPACE Ltd, a Chinese co-working space provider competing with WeWork Cos, is seeking at least $200 million in fresh funding to support expansion. The Beijing-based startup aims for a post-money valuation of $1.3 billion and is also considering a merger with a rival. Competition in China's shared office space is intensifying, with WeWork acquiring a smaller local rival in April. KR SPACE has 40 locations with 300,000 square meters of floor space and over 20,000 individual members.

site_title: Singapore's Got Talent
summary: Singapore's Got Talent: The DesignSingapore Council is seeking the Next Generation Singapore Designer through a competition with Wallpaper*. The top prize includes exhibiting at Singapore Design Week 2019 and Milan Design Week 2019. Designers are required to submit portfolios and proposals for reimagining everyday objects. The deadline for entries is June 30. The winner will showcase their work at the Wallpaper* Handmade 2019 exhibition.

images.alt_text: Wallpaper.

site_title: CPFIS funds yield negative returns in Q1
summary: CPFIS funds in Singapore yielded negative returns of 1.65% on average in Q1 2018, with unit trusts down 1.75% and investment-linked insurance products down 1.6%. However, the one-year period ended March 2018 saw positive returns of 8.32% overall, with unit trusts up 8.79% and ILPs up 8.05%. The three-year period ended March 2018 saw average growth of 13.09%.

site_title: South Korea's May exports rebound sharply on robust global chip demand
summary: South Korea's exports rebounded sharply in May, growing 13.5% to $50.9 billion, exceeding forecasts. The strong rebound, after a 1.5% decline in April, is attributed to robust demand for memory chips and petrochemical products. The export growth is a relief for policymakers navigating economic challenges, including weak domestic consumption and global trade frictions. A trade surplus of $6.7 billion was also reported, with imports surging 12.6% in May.

site_title: Singapore's CBD hit by massive blackout on Friday afternoon
summary: A massive power outage affected the Central Business District in Singapore on Friday afternoon, leaving offices and businesses without light or functioning lifts. The outage also caused issues with traffic lights. The cause of the blackout is not specified in the article.

site_title: Blast From The Past
summary: IWC Schaffhausen's Tribute to Pallweber Edition '150 Years' won the Watch of the Year Award at the Temporis Gala Awards 2018. The timepiece features a unique digital display format, inspired by IWC's 1884 pocket watch designs. It's available in pocket watch and three wristwatch versions, powered by the IWC-manufactured 94200 calibre movement. This edition pays homage to the pioneering feat of IWC's early pocket watch production, marking a 150-year milestone in the brand's history.

site_title: BoA joins Citi in pivot to S&P 500 safety amid global turmoil
summary: Bank of America (BoA) has joined Citigroup in recommending US stocks as a safe investment option amid global turmoil, citing better earnings revisions, stronger growth, and a solid valuation. The US equity market, which was at the center of a global selloff in February, is now considered one of the safest places to invest, with the S&P 500 up 2.6% in May, outpacing the rest of the world. Strategists attribute the shift to heightened political risk in Europe and economic slowdowns in emerging markets, making the US market a higher quality option.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall on trade tensions, Deutsche troubles
summary: European shares fell on Thursday as trade tensions and concerns over Deutsche Bank weighed on the market. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index declined 0.6%, with Germany's DAX down 1.4% and Italy's FTSE MIB limiting losses to 0.1%. US tariffs on aluminum and steel imports, including from the EU, reignited fears of a global trade war, with shares in steelmakers and pipe maker Tenaris falling. Deutsche Bank plummeted to a record low after a US Federal Reserve report deemed its US operations "troubled."

site_title: Malaysia timber firm Jawala makes Catalist debut
summary: Malaysian timber firm Jawala Inc made its trading debut on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange, opening at 26.5 Singapore cents and closing at 26 cents. The initial public offering was subscribed 18.5 times, with its market capitalization at about S$30 million. This brings the total number of companies listed on Catalist to 206, with a combined market capitalization of about S$12 billion.

site_title: Thai May headline CPI accelerates to 1.49%, beats forecast
summary: Thailand's annual headline inflation rate in May rose 1.49%, beating forecasts and its highest level in 16 months. The increase was driven by higher fuel prices. The core CPI, excluding raw food and energy prices, also rose 0.80%. The Bank of Thailand's policy interest rate remained unchanged at 1.50%. This marks the second consecutive month the rate falls within the 1-4% target range. The central bank is expected to keep the rate unchanged until at least mid-2026.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Perennial, Enviro-Hub, Sunpower, MSCI revisions
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings acquired Sanctuary City Pte Ltd for US$15.6 million, gaining a 60% stake in PT Bhakti Bangun Harmoni. Enviro-Hub Holdings reported three consecutive years' losses and filed a notice. Sunpower Group secured a S$22 million contract with Xinjiang Xinte. The Singapore Exchange announced revisions to the MSCI, impacting five additional SGX-listed stocks.

site_title: Tata Consultancy CEO sets sights even higher after US$32b rally
summary: Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) CEO Rajesh Gopinathan is optimistic about the company's future, despite challenges in the Indian technology-services industry. He believes the industry's opportunities are bigger than ever, citing the largest technology talent pool in the world, with 400,000 employees. TCS has seen a 50% increase in stock value under Gopinathan's leadership, adding $32 billion to its market value. Gopinathan aims to achieve double-digit growth, with a focus on acquiring the right assets to boost revenue.

images.alt_text: TCS CEO Gopinathan says industry peers are not thinking creatively enough and are wallowing in doom and gloom instead.

site_title: Andre Fu
summary: Andre Fu, founder of AFSO, designed the Waldorf Astoria Bangkok, which opened in the third quarter of 2018. The hotel's 171 guest rooms and suites were designed to reflect the city's richness in Thai culture without replicating it. The top three floors feature distinct dining outlets by AvroKO. Fu's design philosophy has shifted from "relaxed luxury" to "modern reflections," considering the past and present to create a personal connection with guests. Fu's studio has worked on various notable projects, including the Upper House hotel in Hong Kong and the Shangri-La Hotel in Tokyo.

site_title: Real Madrid stunned as Zidane quits at the top
summary: Real Madrid coach Zinedine Zidane quit the Spanish giants on May 31, 2018, just days after winning the Champions League for a record third year in a row. Zidane, 45, cited a need for change, both for himself and the club, and expressed uncertainty about his ability to maintain his winning record. He denied any involvement with other clubs and stated he's eyeing no other position, with many speculating about potential replacements, including Mauricio Pochettino and Arsene Wenger.

site_title: Samsonite CEO resigns as short seller jolts luggage maker
summary: Samsonite International SA's CEO, Ramesh Tainwala, resigned after a short seller, Blue Orca Capital LLC, accused him of accounting lapses and poor corporate governance, including falsifying educational credentials. The company's shares jumped 15% in Hong Kong as trading resumed. Samsonite released a detailed response to the allegations, repeating that the report is "one-sided and misleading." Kyle Francis Gendreau, the CFO, succeeds Tainwala as CEO.

site_title: Second Coming
summary: Singer-songwriter Linying returns with her new single "Tall Order", featuring her signature blend of electronic-folk pop and trip-hop. Her 2016 single "Sticky Leaves" gained global attention, earning over five million streams on Spotify and a feature on Netflix's Terrace House. Linying's music has previously been spun by top DJs at festivals like Coachella and Lollapalooza, solidifying her reputation as a cult favourite in Singapore's music scene.

site_title: Amazon blocks Australia from global sites over tax
summary: Amazon blocks Australian shoppers from its international websites due to new tax laws requiring 10% GST on overseas online purchases, starting July 1. The retailer will direct Australian customers to its smaller Australian site, offering less for sale, and compensate by opening a "global store" with an additional 4 million items. The new tax rules aim to "level the playing field" for Australian businesses, according to Treasurer Scott Morrison.

images.alt_text: Australian shoppers wanting to use Amazon's global platforms will be directed to its smaller Australian site, which offers much less for sale.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,427.32, down 0.03%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Friday afternoon, with the Straits Times Index falling 0.86 points or 0.03% to 3,427.32. Losers edged out gainers, with 176 stocks down and 161 up, as 1.10 billion shares worth S$738.4 million changed hands. Notable movers included YZJ Shipbuilding, Allied Tech, and Ezion, while active index stocks Venture and DBS also declined.

site_title: Nordic countries oppose EU plans for digital tax on firms' turnover
summary: Finance ministers from the Nordic countries (Sweden, Denmark, and Finland) have urged the European Union to shelve a proposed digital tax on firms' turnover, citing concerns it could damage the European economy. They argue the tax deviates from income taxation principles and could lead to international retaliation. The Nordic countries instead advocate for a global approach to reforming the digital tax system through the OECD, echoing requests from other EU states.

images.alt_text: "A digital services tax deviates from fundamental principles of income taxation by applying the tax on gross income, i.e. without regard to whether the taxpayer is making a profit or not," Swedish Finance Minister Magdalena Andersson, and her counterparts from Denmark and Finland, Kristian Jensen and Petteri Orpo, said in a joint statement on Friday.

site_title: Geylang Serai
summary: Geylang Serai, a small settlement in Singapore, was named after the lemongrass factory in the area, which dated back to the 19th Century. After the lemongrass industry failed, the area shifted to coconut and rubber farming, and later became a hub for light industry and shopping complexes. The government established the Malay Village in the 1980s to preserve the area's cultural heritage, featuring a replica of a kampong and promoting traditional Malay activities, including the annual Ramadan Bazaar. The area has undergone significant redevelopment since the 1960s.

site_title: Young talents light up Magic Square
summary: A one-year pop-up restaurant, Magic Square, has kicked off with three young chefs under 30 creating original nine-course menus. Chef Desmond Shen's dishes showcase his technical skills and creativity, including a fermented miso and a modernized fish soup. However, the communal setting and emphasis on technical skill over heart may detract from the dining experience. Despite some inconsistencies, the project's potential for sustainability and growth is promising, with a rating of 7 out of 10.

site_title: Keen bidding expected for Dairy Farm GLS site
summary: A 99-year leasehold site at Dairy Farm Road, launched under Singapore's government land sales (GLS) programme, is expected to attract keen interest from developers due to its proximity to Hillview MRT station and major expressways, as well as strong rental demand from expatriates. The site, which can yield around 500 units, is also expected to set a benchmark price for GLS land parcels in the locality. Meanwhile, two Reserve List sites - one at Sims Drive and the other at Tampines Avenue 10 - are also expected to be triggered for sale, drawing competition from developers for the executive condominium (EC) site in Tampines, which could potentially fetch up to S$600 psf ppr.

images.alt_text: The Dairy Farm Road plot's most attractive attributes are its proximity to the Bukit Timah Nature Reserve and partial unblocked views over the landed residential plots.

site_title: Tesla denies autopilot feature engaged in Brussels car crash
summary: Tesla has denied reports that its autopilot feature was engaged in a car crash in Brussels, where a Model S vehicle crashed into five parked cars on May 29. The driver, who was reportedly outside the vehicle with the engine running, claimed he was in control without using Autopilot. Police confirmed the incident but did not intervene, instead handling it through insurance companies. Tesla stated that the customer was driving and operating the car himself, without using Autopilot, and that drivers must keep their hands on the wheel and eyes on the road at all times while using the feature.

site_title: Green Shopping
summary: Three eco-conscious stores in Singapore are promoting sustainable living: The Social Space, The Sustainability Project, and Unpackt. The Social Space offers refill stations and sells eco-friendly products, while The Sustainability Project and Unpackt focus on zero-waste shopping and selling reusable products. These stores aim to reduce waste, promote sustainable living, and encourage consumers to adopt a greener lifestyle. By offering practical yet stylish products, these businesses are making sustainable living more accessible and affordable for everyone.

site_title: SoftBank joins GM in self-driving car race; GM shares soar
summary: General Motors has secured a $2.25 billion investment from SoftBank's Vision Fund in its autonomous vehicle unit Cruise, valuing the company at $11.5 billion. The deal, one of the largest in self-driving technology, follows SoftBank's investments in Uber and other mobility companies. GM shares rose 13% after the announcement, with CEO Mary Barra stating the company may explore other opportunities with SoftBank-backed companies. The partnership solidifies GM's leadership in self-driving cars, with Cruise operating in conjunction with Waymo and other companies.

site_title: ANZ Bank faces criminal cartel charges over 2015 share sale
summary: ANZ Bank faces Australian criminal charges over alleged cartel conduct during a 2015 A$2.5 billion share sale. The bank and its group treasurer, Rick Moscati, are accused of failing to disclose the joint lead managers' share holdings. The charges add to the banking industry's woes, following a litany of misconduct discoveries, including rigging benchmark interest rates and taking bribes. The Australian competition regulator may also charge two other companies and individuals. ANZ Bank intends to defend itself and settle the allegations.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Friday on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with a positive note, rising 0.26% to 30,548.78, following Italy's agreement to form a coalition government. However, gains were tempered by concerns over fresh trade war fears. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.35% and 0.41% respectively.

images.alt_text: angpanasonic -  Jake Hirose, Panasonic’s Managing Director for Consumer Appliances Marketing, Asia Pacific,##########angpanasonic##########Panasonic

site_title: Italy needs to work harder, be less corrupt: Juncker
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker has urged Italy to work harder, reduce corruption, and take responsibility for its poor south. Juncker's comments, made during a conference in Brussels, were met with criticism from Italian politicians, including President Antonio Tajani, who warned the comments would be "unacceptable" if true. Juncker also stated that nations should prioritize their own problems before seeking EU help, saying "Nations first, Europe second." The comments sparked a heated debate in Italy, with far-right leader Matteo Salvini condemning them as "shameful and racist".

images.alt_text: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker has said Italians need to work harder, be less corrupt and stop blaming the EU for the problems of the country's poor south.

site_title: Cybersecurity risk assessment essential to any audit: Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants
summary: Auditors should consider cybersecurity risks in every audit, even for companies with no online presence, according to a new report by the Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants. The report warns that breaches may have occurred undetected, and auditors should be aware of this possibility. Auditors should also involve subject matter specialists when cybersecurity issues are identified as a key business risk. Cybersecurity risks are becoming increasingly important, and auditors should consider their impact on financial statement audits. This guidance is believed to be the first in South-east Asia to address cybersecurity risk considerations in financial statements audits.

site_title: Atari co-founder Ted Dabney dead at age 81: reports
summary: Atari co-founder Samuel "Ted" Dabney, who helped create the hit video game "Pong", has died at 81. Dabney died on May 26 from cancer, according to his wife. He co-founded Atari in 1972 with Nolan Bushnell, and "Pong" became a sensation in arcades and paved the way for the multi-billion dollar video game industry. Dabney's legacy will be remembered, with industry icon Jonathan Seamus Blackley praising his design genius behind "Computer Space" and "Pong".

images.alt_text: Atari co-founder Samuel "Ted" Dabney, who helped create hit video game "Pong", has died at the age of 81 at his Northern California home, according to reports.

site_title: Telegram messaging says Apple has prevented its updates since April
summary: Apple has prevented Telegram from updating globally since Russia banned the service in April, citing the need for technical updates to comply with the latest iPhone operating system and European data privacy law. Telegram's CEO, Pavel Durov, claims Apple's control over the App Store restricts updates, despite the app being available for download. The situation has sparked concerns about internet censorship and Apple's role in policing content, with digital rights groups calling for greater transparency from the company.

site_title: Savour World Cup action for free at Sports Hub
summary: The Singapore Sports Hub is hosting the Festival of Football, a free event showcasing World Cup 2018 matches on a 66 square-metre screen from June 14 to July 30. The festival will feature group stage matches, knockout matches, including the grand final, and ticket promotions for the ICC and Singapore Premier League. It will also include meet-and-greet opportunities with football players, live entertainment, and daily prizes. The event aims to celebrate the World Cup and provide a fun experience for football fans.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won rise as exports growth supports sentiment
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index and won rose on Friday, driven by robust economic exports data showing growth. The KOSPI increased 0.66% and the won gained 0.3%, its largest weekly percentage gain since May 11. The won also rose against the US dollar, while US stocks ended the previous session with losses, and Japanese stocks weakened. Despite a 0.9% weekly decline, the market sentiment improved, and foreigners were net buyers of shares worth 233 billion won.

site_title: Thai May headline CPI accelerates to 1.49%, beats forecast
summary: Thailand's annual headline inflation rate in May rose 1.49%, beating forecasts and its highest level in 16 months, driven by higher fuel prices. The core CPI, excluding raw food and energy prices, increased 0.80% from a year earlier, within the Bank of Thailand's target range. The central bank left its policy interest rate unchanged at 1.50%, near record lows, as analysts expect no policy change throughout 2018.

site_title: Europe needs to take a chill pill over the euro
summary: The European Union is urged to reevaluate its euro project due to rising populist threats and economic instability. The EU's structure, which has failed to converge European economies, is seen as a primary cause of the issue. A controlled unwinding of the common currency could alleviate economic problems and reduce the influence of radical parties. The EU should consider the economic realities of its member states and design solutions that lessen the pain of economic divergence, rather than relying on threats and hysteria.

site_title: Wrap It Up
summary: Pan Pacific Singapore's Hai Tien Lo restaurant is offering unique Dragon Boat Festival treats, including a bolster-shaped dumpling with braised pork knuckle and a brown rice version with salted egg and corn. The restaurant also packs premium dumpling sets with three flavors and homemade sauces. The sets are priced at S$68.90 or S$88.90. To learn more or place an order, call 6826-8240 or visit www.pacificmarketplace.sg.

site_title: Rosneft testing oil production increase ahead of Opec talks
summary: Rosneft, Russia's largest oil company, has successfully tested its ability to increase oil production by 70,000 barrels per day ahead of OPEC talks on June 22. The test, conducted in Siberia, demonstrates the company's capacity to bring back production cut under a deal between Moscow and OPEC. Rosneft's spare production capacity is estimated at 120,000-150,000 barrels per day, and the company's output is expected to support its second-quarter results. Saudi Arabia has also lifted its oil production, further contributing to the potential increase in global oil supplies.

site_title: Canada hits US with billions in retaliatory tariffs in steel row
summary: Canada has imposed retaliatory tariffs of up to C$16.6 billion on US imports in response to the US' 25% steel and 10% aluminum tariffs. The Canadian tariffs will be applied from July 1, affecting consumer products such as yogurt, coffee, and sailboats. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau called the US tariffs "totally unacceptable" and vowed to challenge the US measures under the North American Free Trade Agreement and the World Trade Organization. The move comes after nine months of stalled negotiations between Canada, Mexico, and the US on revamping the Nafta agreement.

site_title: Bonding with your kids over a video game
summary: A father, struggling to connect with his twin sons, turned to playing Clash of Clans to bond with them. Initially, the game helped him understand their obsession and they reciprocated, but as they lost interest and moved on to other games, the father became fixated on the game himself. Despite his sons' disinterest, the father continued to play, even installing the Fortnite app on his phone to gauge their reaction. The sons' renewed interest in playing with their father led to a moment of high connection, and he eventually dabbled in Fortnite.

site_title: Italy's anti-establishment leaders revive governing coalition
summary: Italy's anti-establishment parties, the 5-Star Movement and the League, revived their governing coalition, ending three months of political turmoil. The deal promises to increase spending, challenge European Union fiscal rules, and crack down on immigration. The coalition, led by Giuseppe Conte, will focus on improving the quality of life for Italians, while also reviewing the EU's fiscal rules. The agreement removes the risk of repeat elections and has sparked relief in global financial markets, which had been tumbling due to concerns over Italy's future in the euro zone.

images.alt_text: Italy's anti-establishment parties revived coalition plans on Thursday, ending three months of political turmoil by announcing a government that promises to increase spending, challenge European Union fiscal rules and crack down on immigration.

site_title: Asean and India set to enhance cooperation in digital connectivity
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is set to enhance digital connectivity with Southeast Asia during his visit to Singapore, where he will participate in the Shangri-La Dialogue. Modi aims to promote India's Digital India initiative, which has already linked remote villages to e-services. Asean member states, such as Singapore, have expressed interest in India's digital developments, including the Aadhaar initiative. Asean has also established its own Smart Cities Network, which could boost bilateral trade and investment between India and Asean. The two regions have a mismatch in ICT infrastructure and usage, but cooperation could unlock the true potential of the global digital economy.

site_title: Mainstream brokerages enter en bloc fray
summary: Mainstream real estate brokerages such as ERA Realty, Huttons Asia, and PropNex are expanding their involvement in collective sales, alongside property consultancies. These brokerages leverage their strong ties with home owners to market sites, with some even helping sellers find replacement homes. While consultancies dominate the market in terms of total collective sales deals, brokerages can offer an edge due to their on-the-ground connections. Industry players note that marketing a site can take years, and a careful balance of risk and reward is required, with costs ranging from tens of thousands to hundreds of thousands of dollars for complex deals.

site_title: Bag It
summary: Mulberry's new 'It' bag, The Leighton, is part of its Autumn/Winter 2018 collection, featuring soft supple leather and two sizes in demure and dynamic shades. The design incorporates a slouch for casualness without compromising structure. The Leighton is available in Dark Clay, Coral Rose, Purple Heather, and Deep Amber colors.

site_title: Sydney Airport targets India as next key market
summary: Sydney Airport is targeting India as its next major international growth market, following the success of its non-stop services to China. The airport has only one direct link to India, an Air India service, despite being the eighth-largest source country for Australian travelers. Sydney Airport CEO Geoff Culbert is seeking to add services to cities like Mumbai and Bangalore, offering financial incentives to airlines. Indian airlines are examining widebody jet orders to compete on longer routes, including to Australia, as the Australian economy shifts towards services like tourism and education.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Willas-Array Electronics reported a 17.3% increase in revenue to HK$4.56 billion for the year ended March 31, with net profit more than tripling to HK$111.96 million. Innopac Holdings is seeking shareholder approval for a S$5 million stock placement, which could result in private investor Jack Lim becoming a controlling shareholder. Meanwhile, Magnus Energy received a letter of demand from its former managing director, Charles Madhavan, alleging wrongful termination and against the directors. Sunpower secured a 105.2 million yuan contract with Xinjiang Xinte.

site_title: Niche Drinks
summary: Singapore's drinking scene is evolving with a growing interest in niche wines and liqueurs, reflecting a more discerning and sophisticated crowd. Tapas bars are offering signature Spanish cava and rare sherries, while gastro-wine bars feature exclusive vintage ports. Italian-centric hotel bars are showcasing amari, a botanically infused liqueur. Luxury wine bars, such as The NCO Club, serve premium wines and champagnes, including Cristal. As a result, demand for premium drinks is increasing, and bars are adapting to cater to the changing tastes of Singapore's drinking crowd.

site_title: Last batch of Jayer Burgundies could fetch up to US$13 million at auction
summary: Henri Jayer's last batch of Burgundies, including rare wines, will be auctioned off in Geneva on June 17, with 1,064 bottles valued up to $13 million. The collection, from 1970 to 2001, includes Cros-Parantoux Vosne-Romanee Premier Cru, one of the world's most expensive wines. The auction is expected to fetch between $6.7 million and $13 million, with buyers likely including Asian, American, and European collectors. The sale is seen as a rare opportunity for wine enthusiasts to own a piece of the legendary winemaker's legacy.

site_title: Malaysia vows to meet deficit target, plug RM21b tax hole
summary: Malaysia's finance minister, Lim Guan Eng, says the country can meet its 2018 budget deficit target despite a US$5 billion loss in revenue from the scrapped goods and services tax. The RM21 billion deficit will be offset by rising oil revenues, spending cuts, and increased dividends from government-linked firms. The government projects a 2.8% GDP deficit and maintains current economic growth forecasts. Higher dividends from Petronas and sovereign wealth funds are expected to deliver an extra RM5 billion this year.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings, a Myanmar-based company, reported a 26% year-on-year decline in FY18 net profit due to lower profit contributions from its real estate business. However, its non-real estate businesses showed strong revenue growth of 33% y-o-y. Analysts remain positive on the group's prospects, citing potential catalysts such as a recovery in Myanmar's property market and non-real estate businesses turning profitable. Yoma's target price is lowered to S$0.58 from S$0.75, maintaining a Buy rating.

site_title: Euro rallies as Italy political crisis abates
summary: The euro rallied by half a percent to a three-day high of $1.1725 on Thursday, following Italian Prime Minister-designate Carlo Cottarelli's comments that possibilities had emerged for a political government. The euro had fallen 3.5% this month due to concerns over a potential eurosceptic government in Italy. A degree of calm has returned, easing fears of a snap election that could impact Italy's euro membership. However, analysts remain cautious, noting that the situation remains murky and the euro's recovery is far from certain.

site_title: Asean and India set to enhance ICT cooperation
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is set to enhance ICT cooperation with ASEAN during his visit to Singapore, focusing on digital connectivity and economic development. Modi proposed launching digital villages in Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, and Vietnam to exchange technology and telecommunication insights. ASEAN member states have expressed interest in India's digital developments, and both sides have made progress in establishing digital payment frameworks and smart cities initiatives. Long-term cooperation requires enhancing ICT infrastructure before cross-border collaborations can be boosted, with the potential to boost bilateral trade and investment between ASEAN and India.

site_title: Italy's bond yields drop on fresh bid to form government
summary: Italy's bond yields dropped on Thursday as investors bid on a fresh attempt to form a government, easing fears of an early election. The 2-year government bond yield fell as much as 102 basis points to 0.98%, while the 10-year bond yield dropped 29 basis points to 2.76%. Polls showed most Italians want to stay in the euro, countering concerns about eurosceptic parties. Analysts warn that short-term stability may prevail but predict the situation remains unpredictable.

site_title: Arabian Escape
summary: Oman, a lesser-known Arab country, is gaining attention for its stunning landscape and unique cultural attractions. Maintaining diplomatic neutrality since the 1970s, Oman has avoided conflicts and war, resulting in a multi-sectarian population that coexists peacefully. The country is now focusing on tourism, with a goal of attracting five million visitors by 2040. Popular destinations include Muscat, the capital city, which features the stunning Sultan Qaboos Grand Mosque, the Royal Opera House, and the Mutrah Souq. The country's interior offers breathtaking mountain scenery, ancient forts, and the highest luxury hotel in the Middle East, the Anantara Al Jabal Al Akhdar resort. Desert safaris and Bedouin camps also offer an authentic Arabian experience, with opportunities for hiking, rock-climbing, and stargazing.

site_title: Pencil Art
summary: Faber-Castell is hosting an art exhibition in Singapore, "Colour To Life", which combines traditional colouring with augmented reality technology. The event features art sculptures made from the brand's pencils by international artists, as well as hands-on classes teaching various drawing techniques. Visitors can also scan their finished colouring pages into a free app to bring their artwork to life. The exhibition runs from May 31 to June 3 at Marina Square Central Atrium.

site_title: Consumer spending posts biggest gain in five months
summary: US consumer spending increased 0.6% in April, the largest gain in five months, according to the Commerce Department. This rise in spending, which accounts for over two-thirds of the US economy, suggests economic growth is regaining momentum. Meanwhile, inflation continued to rise steadily.

site_title: Mapletree Investments' Patmi up 39% at S$1.96b for FY17/18
summary: Mapletree Investments reported a profit after tax and minority interests (Patmi) of S$1.96 billion for FY17/18, up 39% from a year ago. Revenue rose 37% to S$3.19 billion, while recurring Patmi gained 6% to S$685 million. Assets under management (AUM) grew 17% to S$46.3 billion, driven by market expansion and development projects. The group's CEO expressed confidence in delivering a sustainable high-margin real estate business, with positive signs for future profitability.

site_title: Uber, Waymo in talks on tie-up over self-driving vehicles
summary: Uber is in talks with Alphabet's self-driving unit Waymo about integrating Waymo's technology into Uber's ride-hailing app. This development signals a possible thaw in relations between the companies, following a $245 million settlement in a trade secrets dispute. Uber CEO Dara Khosrowshahi expressed optimism about the potential partnership, stating that Waymo's technology would be a good addition to Uber's network. Uber plans to restart its self-driving car operation in the coming months, following a fatal crash in Arizona.

images.alt_text: Uber chief Dara Khosrowshahi believes autonomous-driving technology will be shared.

site_title: Italy factory activity growth weakest in May since Nov 2016
summary: Italy's manufacturing activity growth weakened in May, falling to its lowest rate in 18 months, according to a survey. The Markit/ADACI Purchasing Managers Index dropped to 52.7, below the 50 mark separating growth from contraction. This suggests a potential slowdown in the euro zone's third-largest economy, which has been in political limbo since an inconclusive election. The sub-index for new orders, output, and employment also weakened, with export orders posting their lowest reading since August 2016.

site_title: More people have lost money trading on unregulated platforms
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) have warned the public about unregulated online trading platforms, where investors are losing millions of dollars. In 2017, 142 reports were received, with a total loss of S$7.8 million, compared to 40 reports in 2016. These platforms often operate overseas, making it difficult to verify their credibility and recover losses. The MAS advises consumers to exercise extreme caution and 'ASK, CHECK, CONFIRM' before investing, as many of these platforms are likely scams.

images.alt_text: More people are losing money trading on unregulated online platforms.

site_title: Royal Material
summary: Loro Piana's "The Gift of Kings" wool is a rare and exceptional merino wool, measuring only 12 microns, finer than cashmere and light as vicuña. Only a few thousand sheep in Australia and New Zealand produce this wool, which is harvested in small quantities. The brand's efforts to master the art of 12-micron wool production have led to a significant decrease in the gold standard of 17 microns. The luxurious wool is used to create high-end products, including a water-repellent jacket priced at S$14,020 and a shawl costing S$4,030.

site_title: Italy's crisis unlikely to get out of hand
summary: Italy may face new elections in autumn 2018 or early 2019, potentially shaping the EU's and euro's rules. A radical government could plunge Italy into a crisis with financial and economic spillovers to neighbors. However, the EU has tools to contain contagion risks, including the European Stability Mechanism and the Outright Monetary Transactions program. A repeat of the 2011-12 euro crisis is unlikely, but a potential Italian crisis could still have significant consequences for the euro zone. The EU and euro are more resilient than previously thought, and Italy's exit would likely strengthen pro-EU sentiment.

site_title: India and Singapore move to deepen economic cooperation in startups and innovation
summary: India and Singapore have strengthened their economic ties, focusing on startups and innovation. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi called for deeper cooperation, stating that the two countries should "step into the future together." Singapore's Minister-in-Charge of Trade Relations, S Iswaran, highlighted opportunities for collaboration in the startup sector, with Singapore's Enterprise Singapore launching the Singapore-India Incubation Programme to support Indian startups. Trade between the countries jumped 14.6% last year, with Singapore's investments in India reaching S$36.3 billion in 2016.

site_title: OUE executive chairman Stephen Riady to be SIAS patron
summary: Stephen Riady, executive chairman of OUE, has been appointed as a patron of the Securities Investors Association Singapore (SIAS) with effect from June 1. The appointment is honorary and reflects Riady's support for SIAS's investor education programs and promotion of knowledge in the investor community. Riady praised SIAS for its role in advocating for positive engagement between listed companies and retail investors, and promoting fair corporate governance practices.

site_title: Price war, proxy war make for one messy telco war
summary: A price war is brewing in the telco sector, with new network operator TPG Telecom's two-year free plan for seniors and Circles.Life's "zero-dollar flexi plan" sparking a price slashing salvos. This could put an end to the brief market honeymoon of mobile virtual network operators (MVNOs), which have been seen as a threat to core business revenues. Incumbents, such as M1, have been tapping MVNOs to cushion the blow, but a price war could lead to a proxy war, with incumbents competing in enterprise arms rather than the mobile consumer market.

site_title: US levies steel, aluminum tariffs on allies, risks trade war
summary: The US imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from the European Union, Canada, and Mexico, effective from midnight, escalating the risk of a trade war. The 25% tariff on steel and 10% tariff on aluminum imports aim to boost US steel and aluminum industries. The move has sparked concerns about retaliation from the EU, which has threatened to impose tariffs on US exports, including Harley Davidson motorcycles and bourbon. The US has given permanent tariff exemptions to several countries, including Australia, Argentina, and South Korea, but set import quotas.

site_title: Healthway Medical's interim CEO steps down; Dr Khor Chin Kee appointed CEO from June 1
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation announced that Dr. Dominic Er Kong Kiong, its interim CEO, stepped down on May 31, 2018. Dr. Khor Chin Kee, 56, will take over as CEO from June 1. Dr. Khor will oversee the company's operations and drive business optimisation strategy to enhance operational efficiency. This comes after the company's shares finished 2.1% down on the day of the announcement.

site_title: Modern-Day Armour
summary: This article discusses modern blazers, featuring various styles such as the belted blazer, double-breasted blazer, and oversized blazer. It highlights how different accessories and colors can be used to create a unique and flattering silhouette. The article showcases blazers from popular brands like Michael Kors, Boss, Hermès, Tom Ford, and Victoria Beckham, providing tips on how to style them for different occasions. The blazers are paired with a range of items, from Bermuda shorts to pastel-colored suits, demonstrating the versatility of modern blazers.

site_title: Magnus Energy's former MD sends demand letter over 'wrongful termination'
summary: Magnus Energy Group has received a letter of demand from the lawyers representing its former managing director Charles Madhavan, claiming wrongful termination. Madhavan was terminated on May 26, 2018, due to differences with management and board. The company is reviewing the allegations made in the letter and has sought independent legal advice. No legal proceedings have been commenced against the company at this stage. The company will provide material developments as necessary.

site_title: Young, rich and keen on doing good while investing
summary: A survey by Standard Chartered Private Bank found that young, rich Singaporeans are keen on sustainable investing, with 31% of respondents demonstrating a good understanding of the concept and 64% motivated to do good while earning a profit. Chinese investors are leading the way, with an expected allocation of 23% of their portfolios to sustainable investments by 2021. The survey also found that over 90% of investment portfolios with a sustainable investment concept have the same or better returns than a normal investment portfolio, challenging the misconception that returns must be sacrificed.

site_title: New Lakeside ex-CFO pleads guilty; fined S$80,000, gets 3-year directorship ban
summary: Former New Lakeside Holdings CFO Oh Gim Teck pleaded guilty to breaching Singapore Exchange's disclosure rules, fined S$80,000 and banned from directorship for 3 years. He failed to inform independent directors about unit loans, despite knowing of the liability as early as 2008. The breach occurred when unit NLX defaulted on loans, which would have made the company insolvent if not disclosed. Oh's actions led to a delay in announcing the issue to SGX, breaching Rule 703 of the SGX listing manual.

site_title: Google launches second China-specific app; aims to woo biggest smartphone market
summary: Google has launched a China-specific app, "Files Go", a storage management tool for smartphones, as part of its efforts to expand operations in the country. The app is available on third-party Chinese app stores and marks the second China-specific app released by Google since its flagship services were banned in 2010. The move aims to woo the world's biggest smartphone market, where Google's products remain unavailable due to censorship regulations. This is part of Google's recent efforts to re-engage with China, with CEO Sundar Pichai visiting the country and speaking at government forums.

site_title: Chong Kee Hiong to step down as CEO and executive director of OUE H-Reit's manager
summary: Chong Kee Hiong is stepping down as CEO and executive director of OUE H-Reit's manager and OUE Hospitality Trust's trustee-manager on July 15, 2018. He will pursue other professional interests after overseeing the growth of OUE Hospitality Trust's portfolio to S$2.2 billion since 2013. Isaac Chen Yi-Chung, current deputy CEO, will take over as acting CEO, subject to regulatory approval.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on renewed trade war concerns
summary: US stocks opened lower on May 31, 2018, due to concerns over a looming trade war with the European Union. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.19% and the S&P 500 dropped 0.11%. Despite renewed efforts in Italy to form a government, worries about US-EU tariffs outweighed optimism, causing the Nasdaq Composite to decline 0.09%.

site_title: Fall in earnings drags Singapore's May market cap
summary: Singapore's stock market experienced a 1.5% decline in May, with the benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) falling 2.9% to S$579.3 billion. The three local banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, led the losses, while CapitaLand and City Developments also declined due to earnings reports. The month was marked by geopolitical events, including the Malaysian election results and US-China trade talks, which caused market volatility. However, sectors such as commerce, hotels, and service providers saw gains, including ComfortDelGro and Singapore Airlines.

images.alt_text: All three banks had reported double-digit improvements in their respective first-quarter net profits in May, but were hit by external factors.

site_title: Hafary Holdings' financial controller resigns
summary: Hafary Holdings announced the resignation of its financial controller, Wu Pei Cong, effective May 31. Wu, who held the role since August 2015, will be replaced by finance manager Mandy Lee Yee Fei starting June 1. Lee, who joined the company in 2015, will oversee finance and corporate functions, including financial reporting, treasury, and regulatory compliance.

site_title: Trouble dieting? Scientists discover how to make sugar taste vile
summary: Scientists have discovered a way to manipulate the brain to make sweet things taste vile and bitter ones nice in mice, potentially leading to new strategies for treating eating disorders and obesity. Researchers used laser light stimulation to "switch" parts of the brain's amygdala, turning sweetness into an aversive taste and bitterness into a desirable one. The method has yet to be tested in humans, but could provide a new approach to understanding and treating eating disorders.

site_title: The smart way to use Artificial Intelligence and make sense of it
summary: Artificial Intelligence (AI) has the potential to replicate numerous developments in various areas of business and personal lives, but its hype is often exaggerated. While AI has been around for years, its capabilities are often specialized and not general. Developing AI requires tedious work, including selecting the right algorithm and presenting the problem correctly. The success of AI depends on the quality of the data, and its impact will be more beneficial than detrimental, leading to new job opportunities and augmenting human work.

site_title: SGX raps Jason Holdings founder and former CEO
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reprimanded Jason Holdings Limited and its former CEO, Jason Sim Chon Ang, for breaching Catalist rules. The group materially overstated its revenue in its half-year financial results for the period ended June 30, 2015. Sim authorized the inclusion of undelivered materials in progress claim billings and submitted falsified documents to obtain trade financing facilities. The bourse views Sim's actions as a breach of fiduciary duties and a failure to act in the interests of shareholders. The case has been referred to the authorities.

site_title: Denmark bans Islamic full-face veil in public spaces
summary: Denmark has banned the Islamic full-face veil in public spaces, with a fine of 1,000 kroner (S$210) for wearing a burqa or niqab. The ban, which took effect on August 1, targets not only the full-face veils but also other accessories that hide the face. Human rights campaigners have condemned the law as a "violation of women's rights", while supporters argue it enables better integration of Muslim immigrants into Danish society.

site_title: Facebook users make appearance in Cambridge Analytica bankruptcy
summary: Cambridge Analytica, the UK firm at the center of a US presidential election data scandal, is facing a group of Facebook users in its bankruptcy. "Data Breach Plaintiffs" filed a notice to appear in the company's New York bankruptcy, seeking class-action status for claims that 87 million Facebook users had their personal information taken without permission. The group is represented by Lowenstein Sandler LLP in two lawsuits against Facebook and Cambridge Analytica, alleging invasion of privacy, negligence, and unlawful interception of communications. The cases were brought in Delaware District Court.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: US President Trump's 50% copper import tariff is expected to impact global markets. Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weigh market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. European stocks fell due to bank and healthcare sector drag, with US-EU tariffs in focus. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potentially lower H2 revenue and similar operating losses. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for its £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: US President Trump has announced a 50% copper import tariff, affecting refined metal. Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weigh market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In Singapore, NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, and Wall Street opened lower after Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Companies such as Creative Technology also warned of potential revenue and operating loss issues due to the economic uncertainty.

site_title: China's factory gauge beats estimates on global trade resilience
summary: China's manufacturing purchasing managers index (PMI) rose to an eight-month high of 51.9 in May, beating estimates, signaling resilience in the global economy despite external risks such as trade tensions and debt curbs. The non-manufacturing PMI also rose for a third straight month to 54.9, indicating improvement. However, a third consecutive month of tight funding conditions for companies and higher input prices remain concerns. Despite this, economists expect China's growth to slow in the second half, with forecasts ranging from 6.5% to 7% this year.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas buys 25% stake in LNG Canada project
summary: Malaysia's state-owned oil and gas company Petronas has agreed to buy a 25% stake in LNG Canada, a liquefied natural gas export project in British Columbia, Canada. The project, led by Royal Dutch Shell, will consist of two LNG production facilities exporting 13 million tonnes per year. Petronas joins existing partners Shell, PetroChina, Mitsubishi, and Korea Gas, following the cancellation of its own planned terminal in 2017. The purchase is expected to close in the next few months and is seen as a positive development for Petronas, with analysts expecting the global LNG market to tighten post-2022.

site_title: Make time to stand and stare
summary: A writer advocates for the practice of taking time to stand and stare after dinner, citing the decline of serving dessert wines as a loss for physical and mental health. He recommends Madeira, a fortified wine, as a relaxing choice, noting its long lifespan and ability to reduce mental illness symptoms. A study at Stanford University supports the benefits of taking a nature walk, highlighting the need for stillness and quiet reflection in a fast-paced life. The writer encourages readers to prioritize relaxation and take time to appreciate the world around them.

site_title: India's annual growth slows to 6.7%, Q4 picks up
summary: India's GDP growth accelerated to 7.7% in Q4 of the financial year, exceeding economists' expectations of 7.4%. The improvement in growth rate reinforces India's status as one of the world's fastest-growing economies. This marks a recovery from disruptions caused by various economic initiatives.

site_title: Khor Un Hun, CEO of trustee-manager of Keppel Infrastructure Trust, to step down on June 30
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust's CEO, Khor Un Hun, will step down on June 30 to pursue other interests. Matthew Pollard, with 28 years of experience in investment banking and entrepreneurship, will succeed him as CEO from July 1. Pollard brings expertise in the energy, power, renewable, and infrastructure sectors. Keppel Infrastructure Trust's chairman, Koh Ban Heng, expressed confidence in Pollard's ability to lead the trust's growth and deliver sustainable returns for unitholders.

site_title: Enviro-Hub Holdings files notice of 3 years' losses; 6-month market cap still above SGX watch-list threshold
summary: Singapore-listed Enviro-Hub Holdings reported three consecutive years of losses, with a pre-tax loss for the year to Dec 31, 2017. The company's market capitalization averaged S$42.14 million over six months, above the SGX watch-list threshold of S$40 million. Enviro-Hub shares closed at S$0.03 on May 31, unchanged from the previous session. The company's financial results trigger a review by the Singapore Exchange, which will assess whether to add Enviro-Hub to the watch list in June.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 21.34 points to 1,740.62 on Thursday, driven by gains. Volume reached 4.6 billion lots worth RM9.3 billion, with 581 gainers and 409 losers.

site_title: Malaysia vows to meet deficit target, plug US$5b tax hole
summary: Malaysia's finance minister, Lim Guan Eng, says the country will meet its 2018 budget deficit target despite a US$5 billion hole from scrapping a goods and services tax. The government will offset the lost revenue with increased oil-related income, spending cuts, and new taxes. The projected fiscal deficit will increase to 2.8% of GDP, but economic growth forecasts remain unchanged. The government also plans to introduce a new sales tax in September and explore ways to raise funds, including higher dividends from government-linked entities.

site_title: Trump says North Korea talks positive, expects letter from Kim Jong Un
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that talks with North Korea in New York have been "very positive," and he expects a delegation from Pyongyang to deliver a letter from leader Kim Jong Un to the White House on Friday. Trump expressed optimism about a potential deal, saying "I think it will be very positive." This would be the first visit by high-level North Korean officials to the White House since 2000.

site_title: Australia: Shares track up as Italy turmoil eases; NZ higher
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 6010.5, driven by a global equities rally as Italy's political turmoil eased. Materials stocks led the gain. The S&P/ASX 200 index is set for a monthly gain despite a 0.5% loss on Wednesday. The easing of Italy's turmoil is seen as a positive factor, reversing losses in Asian markets.

site_title: Perennial buys Sanctuary City for US$15.6m; to develop site in Sentul City into residential development
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings acquired Sanctuary City Pte Ltd for US$15.6 million, gaining a 60% stake in PT Bhakti Bangun Harmoni, a 246,982 sq m land parcel in Sentul City, Indonesia. The site will be jointly developed with PT Cipta Harmoni Lestari into a residential development with 1,700 units. The project's total development cost is estimated at S$153.4 million, funded through sales, borrowings, and internal funds. The site is accessible by highway to Jakarta and near the Sentul City Light Rail Transit station, attracting middle- to high-income residents.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas buys 25% stake in LNG Canada project
summary: Malaysia's state-owned oil and gas company Petronas is buying a 25% stake in the LNG Canada project, a liquefied natural gas export project in British Columbia, Canada. The project, led by Royal Dutch Shell, will consist of two LNG production facilities exporting 13 million tonnes per year. The acquisition, valued at C$40 billion (S$41.5 billion), comes after Petronas scrapped plans to build a US$36 billion LNG terminal due to market concerns. The deal is seen as a positive development for Petronas, with analysts expecting the global LNG market to tighten post-2022.

site_title: Australia's building activity slows in April, a bad omen for economy
