summary: Australia's housing activity slowed in April, with dwelling approvals down 5% and non-residential permits also declining. This marks a slowdown in the four-year-old home building boom, which has supported the country's economy. Economists expect home prices to ease further, with a possible 5-10% decline this year and next, posing a downside risk to the Australian economy. The Reserve Bank of Australia is likely to keep interest rates at a record low, and a weakening consumer is a significant concern.

site_title: Trump slaps steel tariffs on closest allies as trade tensions rise
summary: The Trump administration imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imported from the European Union, Canada, and Mexico, sparking retaliation from America's closest allies. The move, announced just hours before temporary exemptions expired, marks the Trump administration's most aggressive trade action against major US trading partners. The decision is likely to trigger significant trade tensions and has significant implications for global trade and economies.

site_title: Sunpower secures manufacturing contract worth 105m yuan
summary: Sunpower Group secured a 105.2 million yuan (S$22 million) manufacturing contract with Xinjiang Xinte, its second within a month, bringing the total contract value to 185.2 million yuan. The contract involves delivering raw material towers and cold-hydraulic heat exchangers for Xinjiang Xinte's high-purity polysilicon plant upgrade by the end of 2018. The deal is expected to have a positive impact on Sunpower's results for the current financial year, pushing its order book to a new record.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's administration is cooperating with global probes into state investment company 1MDB, meeting with Singapore investigators. Sembcorp acquired UK's largest flexible distributed energy generator for £216m. The Urban Redevelopment Authority and Housing & Development Board released three residential sites for sale in Singapore. CPFIS funds yielded a 1.65% negative return in Q1, and the National Wages Council recommended monthly wage hikes of $50-$70 for low-wage workers. Singapore shares fell 0.5% lower on Thursday, while the US tariffs on Vietnam and the Asian garment industry were announced.

site_title: MSCI changes to take effect from Friday; 5 SGX stocks affected by revisions
summary: MSCI changes will take effect from Friday, impacting five Singapore Exchange-listed stocks. Venture Corp will be added to the MSCI Singapore Index, while Dairy Farm International and Top Glove Corp will be added to the MSCI Hong Kong and Malaysia Index, respectively. Hutchison Port Holdings Trust and StarHub will be removed from the MSCI Singapore Index and added to the MSCI Singapore Small Cap Index. The changes reflect the stocks' performance in 2018, with Venture, Dairy Farm, and Top Glove posting significant total returns.

site_title: Young rich Singaporeans keen on sustainable investing: survey
summary: A survey by Standard Chartered Private Bank found that young, wealthy Singaporeans are keen on sustainable investing, with 64% motivated to do good and earn a profit. Investors in Singapore have the strongest understanding of sustainable investing, with 31% demonstrating a good grasp of the concept. In contrast, Chinese investors aim to increase their sustainable investment allocation to 23% by 2021, driven by better returns. The survey highlights the growing interest in sustainable investing in Asia, with over 90% of investment portfolios with sustainable investment concepts having the same or better returns than normal portfolios.

site_title: NWC recommends monthly wage hikes of $50-$70 for workers earning up to $1,300
summary: The National Wages Council (NWC) in Singapore has recommended monthly wage hikes of $50-$70 for workers earning up to $1,300, affecting 150,000 full-time workers. This increase is higher than last year's recommendation of $45-$60 for workers earning up to $1,200. Additionally, companies that achieved productivity improvements will be required to give their low-wage workers a special bonus of $300-$600. The guidelines aim to recognize the improvement in general business conditions and encourage employers to share productivity gains with workers.

site_title: US consumer spending accelerates; weekly jobless claims fall
summary: US consumer spending increased 0.6% in April, the largest gain in five months, following a 0.5% increase in March. Weekly jobless claims also fell, down more than expected. This data bolsters expectations for a Federal Reserve interest rate hike next month. Moderately rising inflation and a tightening labor market also support rate increases. Consumer spending accounts for over two-thirds of the US economy, indicating economic growth is regaining momentum.

site_title: More people have lost money trading on unregulated online platforms: SPF, MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) of the Singapore Police Force have warned the public about unregulated online trading platforms, where investors have lost a total of S$7.8 million in 2017. These platforms often pose a high risk of fraud, with investors facing difficulties in recovering their money and being exposed to unauthorized transactions. The MAS advises consumers to exercise extreme caution and "ASK, CHECK, CONFIRM" before committing to an investment, and to report any suspicious activities to the authorities.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks recover from sharp losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks rebounded on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.37% to 30,468.56, following a sell-off the previous day. The gains were driven by reduced fears over Italian politics and upbeat Chinese factory activity data. The Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indexes also rose, with the Shanghai Composite Index advancing 1.78% to 3,095.47. The rally was largely unaffected by recent US-EU trade tensions, with investors focusing on economic data instead.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won rise as Italy woes ease; North Korea-US talks in focus
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 0.58% to 2,423.01, while the won strengthened 0.3% to 1,077.7 per dollar, as concerns over Italy eased and US-North Korea talks gained focus. The benchmark stock index fell 3.7% for the month, its largest monthly drop in three months. MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan rose 0.72%, while the US dollar rose 0.96% against the won this year.

site_title: Faster customs clearance for goods exported by Singapore firms to Australia
summary: Singapore Customs and the Australian Border Force have signed a Mutual Recognition Arrangement (MRA) to facilitate faster customs clearance for goods exported between the two countries. Certified firms in both countries will enjoy reduced documentary and cargo inspections, and faster clearance processes. This agreement, signed under the Comprehensive Strategic Partnership between Singapore and Australia in 2015, aims to elevate bilateral trade ties and maintain supply chain security. The move is expected to benefit businesses and boost trade between the two countries.

site_title: HDB's S$500m bond deal last week makes it the biggest issuer in SGD market
summary: HDB, Singapore's public housing body, successfully sold a S$500 million, 12-year bond last week, marking the largest issuance in the SGD market this year. The bond, rated Aaa by Moody's, was sold despite poor market sentiment, with OCBC Bank handling the deal. This is HDB's third bond issue this year, following two previous sales in January and March. The sale brings HDB's total SGD bond issuance to S$1.615 billion this year, making it the biggest issuer in the local market.

site_title: Escalating trade battle embroils G-7 finance meet
summary: The G7 finance ministers' meeting in Canada is being overshadowed by escalating US trade tensions with Europe, particularly with regards to metal and auto imports. US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross rejected EU exemption extensions for steel and aluminum tariffs, which will take effect on Friday, sparking frustration in Europe. The US is also expected to impose tariffs on auto imports, a move that could disrupt the global economy and strain relations with traditional allies.

images.alt_text: Amid threats of imminent tariffs on metals and auto imports, escalating trade tensions between Europe and the United States were casting a shadow over a meeting of finance ministers from the world's top economies.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on bargain-hunting
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.83% on Thursday, driven by bargain-hunting after a rally on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 22,201.82, while the Topix index rose 0.65%. The gains followed a decline the previous day due to concerns over Italian politics. The rebound was fueled by a rebound on Wall Street, where stocks rallied despite worries over US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.5% lower on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.46% to 3,428.18 on Thursday, despite a 15.77-point drop in the morning, as the market recovered from Wednesday's losses. The index bucked regional trends, closing higher, amid renewed efforts to form a government in Italy and upbeat manufacturing data from China. Investors expect the European Central Bank's next meeting to be influenced by the preliminary eurozone May CPI data release, which could support proposals for ending quantitative easing.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge up as Italy tries to solve political crisis
summary: European shares opened slightly up on May 31, 2018, as investors awaited Italy's resolution of its political crisis. Milan's bourse rose, while Germany's DAX declined due to car maker losses. The pan-European STOXX 600 index rose 0.1%, while Italy's banking index gained 1% after a 5% decline. US market concerns weighed on German automakers, with Volkswagen and Daimler losing 1.3% and 0.9% respectively. The outcome of US-EU trade talks also impacted markets.

site_title: Last of the Jayer wine to go on sale in Geneva
summary: The last remaining bottles of late legendary winemaker Henri Jayer's Burgundies, including some of the world's most expensive wines, will go on auction in Geneva next month. 1,064 bottles, including Cros-Parantoux Vosne-Romanee Premier Cru, will be sold at Baghera Wines auction, with prices expected to reach up to $13 million. Jayer's daughters aim to ensure the wines are enjoyed, not just collected, and will be present at the auction to oversee the dispersal of their inheritance.

site_title: Mapletree Investments' PATMI up 39% to S$1.96b for FY17/18
summary: Mapletree Investments reported a profit after tax and minority interests (PATMI) of S$1.96 billion for FY17/18, up 39% from a year ago. Revenue rose 37% to S$3.19 billion, and recurring PATMI gained 6% to S$685 million. Assets under management (AUM) grew 17% to S$46.3 billion. The group attributed its success to growth in student accommodation, office and data centers, and development projects. Looking ahead, Mapletree plans to expand its capital management business and seed logistics platforms in the US and Europe.

site_title: US trade envoy Ross says up to EU whether there is escalation on tariffs -Le Figaro
summary: US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross stated that the US does not want a trade war with the EU, but the decision on import tariffs on EU steel and aluminium will be made on Thursday. The EU's decision on retaliatory measures will determine the escalation, with Ross suggesting that Trump's reaction will be influenced by the EU's decision. Ross emphasized that the US is open to negotiations and does not want to escalate tensions.

site_title: Hot stock: StarHub share price hits 9-year low
summary: StarHub's share price plummeted to an almost 9-year low after the telco lost its deal to screen Discovery brand content due to negotiations impasse. The stock closed at S$0.07 lower, with 91.3 million shares traded. StarHub was also removed from the MSCI Singapore Index and replaced with the MSCI Singapore Small Cap Index. Discovery channels, including Animal Planet and TLC, may be pulled from StarHub's offerings after June 30, affecting subscribers. The telco is in renewal negotiations with Discovery and acquiring replacement content.

site_title: OUE executive chairman Stephen Riady to be SIAS patron
summary: Stephen Riady, executive chairman of OUE, has been appointed as a patron of the Securities Investors Association Singapore (SIAS) starting June 1. This is an honorary appointment with no executive functions. Riady has expressed his support for SIAS's investor education programs and the group's advocacy for positive engagement between listed companies and retail investors. The appointment comes after Tony Tan Keng Yam, the former president of Singapore, was the first chief patron of SIAS in 2017.

site_title: South Korean prosecutors raid Korean Air headquarters: Yonhap
summary: South Korean prosecutors raided Korean Air Lines' headquarters on May 31, 2018, over suspected embezzlement and breach of trust by members of its owning family. An investigative team was present at the headquarters, but no immediate comment was available from a prosecution spokesman. The raid is related to allegations of wrongdoing by the Koo family, who own Korean Air, but no further details were provided.

images.alt_text: South Korean prosecutors raided Korean Air Lines' headquarters over suspected embezzlement and breach of trust by members of its owning family, Yonhap News Agency reported on Thursday.

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant said to raise funding to over US$12b
summary: Billionaire Jack Ma's Ant Financial has raised its fundraising target to over $12 billion by bringing in existing Chinese shareholders in a yuan-denominated financing round. The company is seeking at least $2 billion in additional funding, on top of a recent $10 billion round that valued Ant Financial at $150 billion. The capital infusion aims to aid Ant's expansion and help the company weather regulatory clampdowns. With a valuation of $150 billion, Ant Financial would become the world's largest fintech firm, and its Alipay service handles over $2.4 trillion in mobile payments every three months.

images.alt_text: Billionaire Jack Ma's Ant Financial is lifting its fundraising target to more than US$12 billion by bringing in existing Chinese shareholders in a yuan-denominated financing round, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Asia: Markets recover with euro as Italy fears ease
summary: Asian markets recovered from the previous day's decline, with the euro holding steady, as concerns over Italy's populist government eased following conciliatory noises from the country's two largest parties. The euro surged after German inflation data showed a surprise increase, and markets in Tokyo, Sydney, and other Asian cities also rose. Oil prices fell slightly but remained stable, and investors are now awaiting US jobs figures for more insight into the Federal Reserve's interest rate plans.

site_title: Malaysia investigators said to meet Singapore on 1MDB probe
summary: Malaysian investigators are meeting with Singaporean officials to discuss the 1MDB probe, a scandal-plagued state investment company. The meetings come as Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's administration cooperates with global probes, following criticism from US and European investigators under the previous administration. Singapore has seized hundreds of millions of dollars in assets and jailed bankers over 1MDB transactions, and cooperation with Malaysia could help piece together billions of dollars allegedly embezzled and laundered globally. The meetings signal a shift towards international cooperation on the probe.

site_title: Prosecutors to raid Kobe Steel for data tampering: media
summary: Tokyo District Public Prosecutors Office and Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department plan to raid Kobe Steel Ltd's headquarters and production facilities in relation to a data tampering scandal. The company admitted in March that data fraud has been ongoing nearly five decades and revealed new cases of cheating. The CEO will step down to take responsibility, and the company is under investigation by the US Justice Department.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Thursday, tracking recoveries in the US and Europe as fears of a political crisis in Italy abated. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.72% to 30,274.18, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.67% and 0.72% respectively. The recoveries were attributed to reduced concerns about a political crisis in Italy and ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: New Zealand plans to invest in more recycling plants as it deals with China waste ban
summary: New Zealand plans to invest in more recycling plants to cope with China's waste ban, which has left 15 million kgs of paper and plastics piling up annually. The country's associate environment minister, Eugenie Sage, said the ban has had a greater impact than expected and requires a coordinated response from the government and waste sectors. The government will use its existing waste levy to fund onshore recycling plants and explore other options, such as expanding the waste levy and implementing product stewardship measures.

site_title: Australian shares end higher as Italy turmoil eases; NZ posts bumper month
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to close at 6,011.9, driven by gains in materials stocks, while global markets recovered from Italy's political turmoil. The S&P/ASX 200 index marked a 0.5% monthly gain. However, healthcare stocks declined 0.5% due to US President Donald Trump's comments on reducing drug prices, affecting companies like CSL and Cochlear. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.1% for its best month since December 2017.

site_title: S Jayakumar not surprised Malaysia withdrew Pedra Branca cases
summary: Former Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister S Jayakumar is not surprised that Malaysia withdrew its applications to the International Court of Justice regarding Pedra Branca, citing "very weak legal basis" for its cases. The cases, filed in 2017 and 2018, aimed to revise a 2008 ICJ judgment awarding sovereignty of Pedra Branca to Singapore. The ICJ will remove the cases from its list after Malaysia informed it of its decision to discontinue proceedings, with Singapore agreeing.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon trading at 3,452.9, up 0.3% on day
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% to 3,452.9 at 1pm on Thursday, driven by gains in YZJ Shipbuilding and DBS. Accrelist was the most actively traded counter by volume, while 194 gainers outnumbered 135 losers. Total shares traded were 963.7 million worth S$711.6 million.

site_title: Keppel sets new pledge to cut carbon emissions by 28.8% from 2010 levels by 2030
summary: Keppel Corp has set a new goal to cut its carbon emissions intensity by 28.8% from 2010 levels by 2030, surpassing its previous 2014 target of a 16% improvement. The company is on track to achieve the target, having already reduced its emissions intensity by 27.7% in its Singapore operations. Keppel has also become a signatory to the United Nations Global Compact and is working to include overseas facilities in its emissions monitoring.

site_title: New Lakeside ex-CFO pleads guilty; judge slaps S$80,000 fine, 3-year directorship ban
summary: Former New Lakeside Holdings CFO Oh Gim Teck pleaded guilty to breaching Singapore Exchange's disclosure rules, fined S$80,000 and banned from directorship for 3 years. The breaches occurred due to the company's failure to disclose its subsidiary's loan defaults and subsequent liabilities, which led to the company's insolvency. The guilty plea was made before District Judge Jasvender Kaur, following a case where New Lakeside was in the business of producing and selling apple juice concentrate.

site_title: Compliance professional to become new Innopac controlling shareholder with proposed placement
summary: A compliance professional, Jack Lim, is set to become Innopac Holdings' new controlling shareholder after a proposed S$5 million stock placement. Lim will take 2.5 billion shares at the offer price of 0.1 Singapore cent per share, securing a 26.42% stake in the company. The proceeds will be used for new business investments, existing investment business development, working capital, and placement expenses. The company will seek shareholder approval for the placement and transfer of controlling interest at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Addvalue Tech posts US$11.1m full-year loss on lower revenue, higher expenses
summary: Addvalue Tech posted a full-year net loss of US$11.11 million, its fourth consecutive year in the red, due to lower sales and higher expenses. Revenue fell 62.3% to US$4.09 million, mainly attributed to depressed economic conditions and shifting market demand. Operating expenses rose to US$8.4 million, and no dividend has been declared. Despite this, the group is in discussions with customers on US$10 million projects and expects to "significantly outperform" next year. The company aims to reward shareholders through a possible distribution-in-specie exercise.

site_title: Singapore bank lending up 0.8% in April
summary: Singapore bank lending rose 0.8% in April, with loans reaching S$667 billion. This growth is slower than the 1.6% increase in March. Business lending grew 1.2% and consumer lending increased 0.3%. Year-on-year, bank lending rose 5.7%, a slight improvement from the 5.4% increase in March.

site_title: Chinese industrial provinces face summer electricity crunch
summary: Chinese industrial provinces Guangdong and Shandong are facing potential power shortages this summer due to rising temperatures and weak hydro power output. Guangdong is already curbing power supplies to industrial users, while Shandong expects a 5-gigawatt shortage. The peak power grid load is estimated at 79 GW, a 4-GW increase from last year. The two provinces are among China's largest in terms of population and economic growth, with Guangdong being the top province by total gross domestic product. Authorities are concerned about the impact of the power shortages on industrial production.

site_title: High-level US-North Korea nuclear talks get underway in New York
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and North Korean official Kim Yong Chol met in New York for dinner, marking the first of two days of talks on the future of Pyongyang's nuclear program and a possible summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. The two men discussed the complete, verifiable, and irreversible denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula, but no progress was made. The White House left open the possibility of a Trump-Kim summit on June 12 in Singapore, despite Trump's previous cancellation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 15.45 points to 1,734.73. Volume was 72.6 million lots worth RM49.84 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 192 to 80.

site_title: URA, HDB release sale sites at Dairy Farm Road, Sims Drive and Tampines Avenue 10
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and Housing & Development Board (HDB) have released three sites for sale in Singapore, including one Confirmed List site at Dairy Farm Road and two Reserve List sites at Sims Drive and Tampines Avenue 10. The sites have a combined site area of approximately 38,192.8 square meters, with a total permissible gross floor area of 129,916 square meters. The sites are expected to yield around 1,880 residential units, with project completion periods ranging from five to 60 months. Tender bids for the sites will close by September 4.

site_title: Willas-Array full-year profit triples on strong industrial, home appliance and automotive sales
summary: Willas-Array Electronics reported a tripled full-year net profit of HK$111.96 million (S$19.1 million) on 17.3% revenue growth. The company's industrial, home appliance, and automotive segments drove the increase, with earnings per share rising to HK$1.47. A final dividend of HK$0.42 per share and a bonus issue of one new share for every 10 existing shares were proposed. The company expects strong domestic demand and export market growth, particularly in its automotive and home appliance segments.

site_title: Stocks to watch: KSH Holdings, Willas-Array, Courts Asia
summary: KSH Holdings saw a 28.1% fall in net profit to S$29.5 million, while Willas-Array Electronics' full-year net profit more than tripled to HK$111.96 million. Courts Asia reported a net loss of S$3.02 million for its fourth quarter, reversing from a profit a year ago.

site_title: CPFIS funds yield negative returns in Q1
summary: CPFIS funds yielded negative returns of 1.65% on average in Q1 2018, with unit trusts down 1.75% and investment-linked insurance products down 1.6%. However, one-year returns were positive, with unit trusts up 8.79% and ILPs up 8.05%. Equities outperformed other asset classes, growing 10.75%, while bonds posted 1.05% returns. The three-year period showed equities up 15.97% and bonds up 5.12%. Experts attribute the downturn to global market volatility and inflation concerns.

site_title: China shunned Australia's minister during recent visit: diplomat
summary: China rejected a request for a meeting with Australia's Trade Minister Steven Ciobo during his visit in May, according to a senior diplomat. The visit was seen as a sign of warming bilateral relations, but tensions escalated after Australian wine company Treasury Wine Estates Ltd faced delays getting products through Chinese customs. China's top diplomat Wang Yi said Australia must "abandon traditional thinking" and "take off its coloured glasses" to improve relations, amid a diplomatic rift fueled by Australia's moves to limit foreign influence and reject Chinese investment bids.

site_title: US to impose steel, aluminum tariffs on EU: report
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to impose steep steel and aluminum tariffs on European Union imports, starting on Friday, despite failed talks to reach a compromise. The 25% tariff on steel and 10% on aluminum was initially aimed at China but affects US allies. The EU has vowed to retaliate with tariffs on American goods, including iconic items like Harley-Davidson motorbikes and bourbon whiskey. This move is part of Trump's multi-sided trade confrontation, which has already hit Canada, Mexico, South Korea, and China.

site_title: India's e-commerce wars to be reshaped by private label brands
summary: India's e-commerce market is shifting towards private label brands as online retailers, such as Flipkart and Amazon, struggle to make profits through discounted sales. Private labels offer affordable alternatives to global brands, appealing to price-sensitive Indian shoppers. Analysts predict that private labels will create loyalty, higher margins, and help retailers control costs. Walmart's acquisition of Flipkart aims to bolster private labels, with plans to expand to other countries and tap into the Indian diaspora. This pivot is seen as a key strategy to make money in the Indian e-commerce market, forecasted to reach $200 billion in a decade.

site_title: Sembcorp buys UK's largest flexible distributed energy generator for £216m
summary: Sembcorp Industries acquired UK Power Reserve (UKPR), the UK's largest flexible distributed energy generator, for £216m (S$385.72m) in cash. The deal brings flexible assets and merchant energy capabilities, expanding Sembcorp's presence in the UK's flexible distributed energy sector. UKPR owns 533MW of operational assets and 480MW under development, with a focus on small-scale, fast-ramping power generation and rapid response batteries. The acquisition is part of Sembcorp's strategy to rebalance its energy portfolio towards developed markets.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Industries' wind turbines in India. Sembcorp has acquired distributed energy generator UK Power Reserve for £216 million (S$385.72 million) in cash, giving the conglomerate a foothold in the UK's flexible distributed energy sector.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher despite caution over Italy
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on May 31, 2018, driven by rallies on Wall Street, despite concerns over Italian political uncertainty. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.63% and the Topix index increased 0.58%. Investors took a cautious view of the Italian crisis, with shares rebounding from Tuesday's falls. Oil companies JXTG and Inpex rallied, while exporters such as Olympus, Canon, and Toyota also rose. Japan's factory output picked up 0.3% in April, lower than expected.

images.alt_text: People gather along the promenade near the Merlion statue at Marina Bay in Singapore on December 25, 2020. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)##########abtourism##########

site_title: Jason Holdings founder and CEO leaves roles in company
summary: Jason Sim Chon Ang, founder and CEO of Jason Holdings Limited, has stepped down as group CEO and non-executive director, effective May 28, 2018. The company's wholly owned subsidiary, Jason Parquet Specialist (Singapore) Pte Ltd, was liquidated in 2016. Jason Holdings is now exploring new businesses for acquisition and is actively seeking to inject new business into the group. The company is considering a resumption proposal to the Singapore Exchange to restart trading in its shares.

site_title: Oil climbs over 2%, shrugs off API's US crude build
summary: Oil prices surged over 2% on Wednesday, defying expectations of a decline in US crude stockpiles, after Russia's central bank expressed caution on plans to boost oil supply. Brent settled at $77.50 a barrel, up 2.8%, while US crude rose 2.2% to $68.21. The surprise stock build was attributed to an unexpected increase of 1 million barrels, contrary to analyst expectations of a 525,000-barrel decline. The news comes as reports suggest OPEC and Russia may ease output cuts, putting pressure on oil prices.

site_title: US firms upbeat despite trade uncertainties: Federal Reserve
summary: US businesses remain largely upbeat despite ongoing trade uncertainties and a growing labour shortage, according to the Federal Reserve's "beige book" survey. Labour shortages are prompting firms to raise wages and take extraordinary measures, including turning away business. The Fed notes concerns about the uncertainty of international trade policy, particularly with China and the European Union. Despite this, economic activity expanded moderately in late April and early May, and businesses are generally optimistic about growth in the near term. The Fed is expected to raise its benchmark lending rate in mid-June to guide the economy towards continued growth without inflation acceleration.

site_title: Social media furor hits oil giant as fuel costs squeeze Thailand
summary: Thailand joins the global energy cost anxiety with a social media furor over fuel prices, prompting state-run oil refiner PTT Pcl to defend itself. The military government has rolled out fuel subsides for diesel and cooking gas, but the economy remains vulnerable to rising crude oil costs. Inflation in Thailand's economy is expected to accelerate to a 15-month high, with agriculture accounting for 8% of GDP and a third of total employment. Thais are calling for a boycott of PTT gas stations, with some accusing the firm of price-gouging.

images.alt_text: Thailand has joined the global wave of anxiety over climbing energy costs.

site_title: Buffett said to have offered Uber US$3b but talks crumbled
summary: Warren Buffett proposed investing $3 billion in Uber Technologies, but talks fell apart due to disagreements over terms and size of the deal. The proposed agreement would have provided a convertible loan to Uber, protecting Buffett's investment and offering significant upside if the company continued to grow in value. Uber's cash position remains strong, with $6.3 billion in cash at the end of the first quarter, but the discussions show the company's continued appetite for capital. The talks ended after Uber proposed decreasing the deal size to $2 billion, which Buffett refused.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.8% on Thursday, driven by gains in the Straits Times Index, despite ongoing political turmoil in Italy affecting Asian sentiment. The index reached 3,473.13 points at 9:01am. About 56 million shares changed hands, with 101 gainers outnumbering 27 losers. The rally follows a 5-day winning streak ahead of GDP data, with no major news impacting the market.

site_title: Smartphone market to stay cool this year: forecast
summary: International Data Corporation forecasts global smartphone sales to decline 0.2% to 1.462 billion this year, with China's market expected to drop 7.1% and India's to continue growing on low-priced handsets. However, the market is predicted to rebound in 2022, growing 3% to 1.654 billion, driven by new 5G networks and premium flagship devices. Average smartphone price is expected to rise 10% to $345, with Android dominating the market at 85%. Apple's iPhone sales are forecast to grow 2.6% to 221 million this year.

site_title: China official factory PMI rises to 51.9 in May, well above forecasts
summary: China's manufacturing sector grew at its fastest pace in eight months, with the official PMI rising to 51.9 in May, exceeding forecasts. This marks the 22nd consecutive month of growth, defying concerns about a slowdown in the world's second-largest economy. The rise in PMI suggests China's economy is resilient, but the country's policymakers still face challenges, including debt risks and a heated trade row with the US.

images.alt_text: China's manufacturing sector grew at the fastest pace in eight months in May, easing concerns about a slowdown in the world's second-biggest economy.

site_title: In nod to India, US military renames its Pacific Command
summary: The US military is renaming its Pacific Command to the Indo-Pacific Command in a nod to India's growing importance in US strategic thinking. The name change, announced by Defence Secretary Jim Mattis, reflects the increasing connectivity between the Indian and Pacific Oceans and the US focus on the region in the face of China's growing influence. The change is part of efforts to counter China's regional leadership, but critics say President Trump has ceded considerable influence in the Asia-Pacific domain.

site_title: US: Stocks rebound from prior session selloff
summary: US stocks rebounded on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 1.3% to close at 24,667.78. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also advanced 1.3% and 0.9%, respectively. Investors took a more optimistic stance on the Italian political crisis, bidding up bank shares. The crisis, however, remains unresolved, with anti-establishment leader Luigi Di Maio seeking a compromise. US economic data showed a 2.2% growth rate in the first quarter, and private sector added 178,000 jobs in May.

site_title: Social media furor hits oil giant as fuel costs squeeze Thailand
summary: Thailand joins the global energy cost anxiety wave as fuel prices rise, prompting a social media furor over pump prices. The military government has rolled out fuel subsidies, but the economy remains vulnerable to the increase in crude oil. Inflation in Thailand's economy is expected to accelerate to a 15-month high of 1.3% in May. The government has threatened to take legal action against false claims made against state-run oil refiner PTT Pcl, which is Asia's biggest oil and gas firm. Rising living costs and elevated household debt raise concerns over military rule.

site_title: Malaysia's CIMB posts best quarterly profit in 5 years
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Group Holdings Bhd posted its highest quarterly profit in five years, driven by lower costs and provisions, as well as a one-off gain from a stake disposal in its brokerage business. The results are expected to ease investor worries about economic growth and its impact on bank profits. CIMB's strong performance comes after a promising quarter from Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank).

site_title: Transit-Mixed Concrete names acting CEO
summary: Transit-Mixed Concrete has appointed Liu Kien Fang, a 61-year-old with over 20 years of experience in the construction industry, as acting CEO, effective June 1. Liu holds a diploma in business management from the Singapore Institute of Management and previously served as operation adviser at Myanmar firm High Tech Concrete Co.

site_title: Europe: Italian stocks stage comeback in recovering market
summary: Italian stocks staged a comeback, rising 2.1% on Wednesday, as investors recovered from the previous day's sharp selloff and digested the possibility of a new Italian election in July. The FTSE MIB index still fell 2.7% for the week, but Italian banks rebounded, with Intesa Sanpaolo and Unicredit delivering significant gains. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index ended the day up 0.3%, while Germany's DAX jumped 0.9%. A new election could impact the euro, but analysts say the sell-off looks smaller than previous euro zone crises.

site_title: Thailand becoming dumping ground for world's high-tech trash
summary: Thailand has become a dumping ground for the world's high-tech trash due to China's import ban on overseas rubbish. The country has seen a surge in shipments of electronic waste, including discarded electronics and hazardous materials, from Hong Kong, Singapore, and Japan. Police have filed charges against three recycling and waste processing companies, and Thailand's Prime Minister has vowed to step up nationwide inspections to combat illegal electronic waste. Environmentalists call for new laws to prevent illegal imports, citing the limitations of the Basel Convention, which Thailand ratified in 1997.

site_title: Indonesian group buys 2 floors at Singapore's Octagon for S$30.3 million
summary: Indonesian conglomerate Central Cipta Murdaya (CCM) has acquired two floors at Singapore's Octagon for S$30.3 million, paying S$2,450 per square foot. The 20th floor of Springleaf Tower in Anson Road has also changed hands for S$25 million, with CBRE brokered the deal. These whole-floor deals mark a gradual recovery in the strata office market, with foreigners, especially from South-east Asia, Hong Kong, and China, driving the demand.

site_title: StarHub faces pay-TV price spat
summary: Discovery cable provider has threatened to pull its 11 English-language channels from StarHub's pay-TV service due to an "impasse" in new price talks. Discovery claims StarHub is not paying "fair value" for its channels, including Animal Planet and Eurosport. The move could see seven channels leave StarHub's offerings in June and four more in August. StarHub is in renewal negotiations with Discovery and plans to launch new channels to maintain content for customers. The dispute may impact StarHub's pay-TV revenue, which accounted for 14.5% of its FY2017 revenue.

site_title: Toyota supplier says hello to chips, goodbye to cars
summary: NSK Ltd, a 102-year-old Japanese manufacturer, is shifting its focus from supplying components for cars to those critical to digital products and services. The company's sales of components for chip-making machines and robot parts have fueled earnings growth, with operating profit from industrial products expected to rise 34% this fiscal year. Demand for industrial components has surged, driven by the growth of the global data market and the increasing need for automation in manufacturing.

site_title: Hawks take hold in India as RBI policy looks set to tighten
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is expected to tighten monetary policy in its June 6 meeting to combat inflation and stabilize the rupee. Interest-rate cycle indicators, such as bond yields and swap markets, suggest a 25-75 basis point hike. The gap between the 10-year government bond yield and the RBI's benchmark repurchase rate has widened to 175 basis points, its most since 2013. This indicates a turn in the interest-rate cycle, with the RBI expected to raise borrowing costs to contain inflation and volatility.

site_title: Singapore to gain faster access to India's startup ecosystem
summary: Singapore and India have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to establish a Singapore-India incubation programme, aiming to foster collaboration between Singapore and Indian startups through networking events, workshops, and mentorship sessions. The programme will connect over 4,750 Indian startups with Singaporean ones, focusing on fintech, e-services, and deeptech. The move is expected to introduce ideas and concepts between the two ecosystems, promoting innovation and collaboration between companies in both markets.

site_title: Malaysia starting sales tax in Sept to shore up Budget
summary: Malaysia will implement a 10% sales and services tax in September to replace the consumption levy, aiming to shore up its budget. The government has canceled a proposed high-speed railway link to Singapore and a mass rapid transit line in Kuala Lumpur, citing financial concerns. New Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad is seeking to fulfill election pledges, including fuel subsidies and reducing living costs, while also addressing contingent debt and liabilities exceeding $336 billion. The government will review major projects, including the Bandar Malaysia property project, and reassess bilateral projects with Singapore.

site_title: Singapore on track to being go-to city for innovative global solutions
summary: A thousand young people from over 110 countries are in Singapore for Unleash Lab 2018, a conference that aims to develop innovative solutions to the planet's sustainability challenges. The event, which runs from May 30 to June 6, brings together participants from diverse backgrounds to co-create solutions to the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) by 2030. The initiative, which has already seen inspiring ideas and serious investment, seeks to establish Singapore as a hub for incubating and growing solutions to global sustainability challenges, positioning it as a go-to city for innovative global solutions.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Valuetronics Holdings reported FY3/18 core net profit of HK$201 million, exceeding Bloomberg's consensus forecasts, driven by higher sales from consumer electronics and industrial & commercial electronics. The company expects double-digit growth in its ICE segment and increasing product penetration for consumer lifestyle products. However, near-term uncertainty arises from short order visibility for smart lighting. GS-CIMB Research cut its target price to S$0.95, while MM2 Asia maintained an "Add" rating with a target price of S$0.70.

site_title: Germany still clinging to diesel as first driving bans take effect
summary: Germany has implemented its first driving ban on older diesel vehicles, starting with a 1,600-meter stretch of highway and a 580-meter section of a major road in Hamburg. The ban is in response to a court ruling that cities can reduce air pollution below EU health thresholds. The move comes as public confidence in diesel technology dwindles, following the "dieselgate" scandal in 2015. Other cities, including Stuttgart and Kiel, are considering similar restrictions, while the federal government has offered longer-term measures to reduce emissions.

site_title: STI falls 2% on Italy woes, trade tensions
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore fell 2.12% to 3,443.95 on Wednesday, amid concerns over Italy's political crisis and US-China trade tensions. The crisis in Italy, which could lead to a referendum on the country's membership in the European Union, has raised fears of a wider euro-area crisis. US President Donald Trump also announced plans to release a list of planned US$50 billion tariffs on Chinese imports by mid-June, further exacerbating market jitters.

site_title: Keppel Corp pledges to further reduce carbon emission
summary: Keppel Corp, a Singaporean conglomerate, has pledged to reduce its carbon emissions intensity by 28.8% by 2030, aligning with Singapore's target of a 36% reduction by 2030. The company has already achieved a 16% reduction in carbon emissions from 2020 business-as-usual levels. Keppel's sustainability efforts include energy efficiency initiatives, such as Green Mark-certified developments, resulting in cost savings and carbon dioxide emission avoidance. The company has also implemented a supplier code of conduct to integrate sustainability principles across its supply chain.

site_title: UOB launches digital clinics for small businesses
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has launched digital clinics for small businesses in Singapore, providing one-on-one guidance on digital solutions and practical advice on how to improve processes. The clinics, costing S$90 per session, are offered to U SME members on a complimentary basis. The clinics aim to address the common challenge faced by SMEs in taking the first step towards digitalisation, with 2 in 3 businesses expressing a desire for a more customised approach. The initiative is part of UOB's efforts to support Singapore's small businesses in adopting digital solutions.

site_title: Where the merits of golf extend beyond the course
summary: Golf is being used in Singapore as a tool for building and maintaining relationships between businesses, politicians, and partners. The BT Golf League provides a platform for corporate events, where deals are often sealed and partnerships are cemented. Singapore's founding prime minister Lee Kuan Yew used golf to discuss bilateral relations with Malaysian leaders, while his successor Goh Chok Tong met with US President Bill Clinton. The league's editor believes that the best business deals are often done on the golf course, and sponsors see benefits in the event, citing it as a way to foster friendship, teamwork, and partnership among corporate teams.

site_title: Long hot summer awaits Italy and eurozone ahead of polls
summary: Italy's long hot summer ahead of polls is expected to impact the eurozone, with investors shunning European markets due to uncertainty over Italian politics and Brexit negotiations. Italian stocks and bonds staged a brief rally, but the yield on 10-year Italian bonds fell slightly. Economists debate whether Italy will exit the eurozone, with some predicting a financial crisis in Europe and others suggesting a surge in domestic demand and an export boom. The Italian government, led by Carlo Cottarelli, aims to form a stop-gap government, but markets fear that President Sergio Mattarella's rejection of euro sceptic Paolo Savona as finance minister may lead to a more radical government.

site_title: Euro bounces off 10-month lows
summary: The euro recovered from 10-month lows after Italy's largest party announced a renewed attempt to form a coalition government, potentially ending months of political turmoil and a referendum on the euro. The euro rose 0.7% to $1.1624 on Wednesday, settling below multi-year highs. Analysts say the euro remains at risk and may not rise much above $1.15 or $1.16 until the Italian crisis is resolved.

site_title: Why robots will not eat the banker's lunch
summary: A recent report by Opimas LLC predicts that over 200,000 jobs in banks will be made redundant by 2025, including 24,000 in private banking and wealth management, primarily due to Artificial Intelligence. However, private bankers bring a holistic approach to complex relationship management, making robots less likely to replace them. JP Morgan Chase & Co is testing an AI system called LOXM, which is being applied to real-time trades, but the bank claims it is not intended to replace human bankers. This suggests that AI may augment banking services rather than replace human staff.

site_title: Indonesian group buys 2 floors at Octagon for S$30.3 million
summary: A Singapore-incorporated company owned by the Murdaya family has bought two floors at The Octagon in Cecil Street for S$30.3 million, or S$2,450 per square foot. The 12,378 sq ft space, mostly vacant, will be leased out. Meanwhile, the 20th floor of Springleaf Tower in Anson Road has changed hands for S$25 million, or S$2,419 psf. These deals indicate a gradual recovery in the strata office market, with rising office rents and increased demand from foreign investors, particularly from South-east Asia and Hong Kong.

site_title: Q1 GDP growth revised downwards
summary: US economic growth in the first quarter was revised downwards to a 2.2% annual rate, slower than the initially reported 2.3% pace. This was attributed to downward revisions in inventory investment and consumer spending. However, income tax cuts are expected to boost economic activity this year.

site_title: Trade war risk stalks global economic upturn: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) warned that a trade war could threaten the global economic upturn, which is on track for a 40-year low in unemployment. Global growth is expected to increase from 3.8% to 3.9% in 2019. The OECD's forecast comes as tensions between countries rise, including the ongoing trade tensions between the US and Vietnam, and the potential for higher US tariffs on the Asian garment industry. This could slow China's GDP growth, adding pressure on policymakers.

site_title: 'Big Brother' surveillance takes spotlight at Beijing security fair
summary: China's police forces showcased cutting-edge surveillance gadgets at a recent security fair in Beijing, highlighting the country's extensive use of technology to monitor and punish behavior that runs counter to the Communist Party. The fair featured products such as smartphone scanners, robots, drones, facial-recognition cameras, and DNA database software, sparking concerns from human rights groups about the development of a nationwide surveillance system. Chinese firms are rushing to meet demand from security services, fuelling a surveillance tech arms race, with Western companies also participating in the market.

images.alt_text: A scanner made by Hisign Technology that can extract data from mobile phone apps, and analyse user social network connections, on display at the China International Exhibition on Police Equipment.

site_title: Federal Reserve moves to ease post-crisis rule on risky bank trading
summary: The Federal Reserve has taken its first step to ease a post-crisis rule limiting high-risk trading by banks. The rule, enacted after the 2008 financial crisis, aimed to prevent banks from engaging in certain trading activities that could pose systemic risk. The Fed's proposed changes were met with criticism from progressive lawmakers and groups, who warned the changes could lead to another crisis. The Fed is the first of five agencies to approve any change, and its decision will set the stage for potential modifications to the Volcker rule.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve took a first step on Wednesday to soften a key rule enacted after the 2008 financial crisis to limit high-risk trading by banks.

site_title: Delays on Dreamliner engine checks to worsen
summary: Rolls-Royce Holdings expects a sharp increase in Boeing 787 Dreamliner planes to be grounded due to engine faults, with 50 planes potentially parked by June 9. About 80% of Package C engines have undergone initial checks for cracking or wear, with just under a third failing the initial checks. The company is tripling engine service capacity and accelerating blade redesign to mitigate the issue. Despite the expected disruption, Rolls-Royce does not expect the stepped-up inspections to have a financial impact.

site_title: Why Singapore summit could still surprise
summary: US-North Korea summit may still materialize, with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov's visit to Pyongyang signaling a possible resumption. However, expectations surrounding the June 12 summit in Singapore remain high, and a significant gap between US and North Korean goals has emerged. The White House should downplay expectations, as the summit may not yield significant agreements, despite potential for a "good start" in a sustained strategic dialogue. The US lacks a clear, coherent strategy for the talks, with differing interpretations of "denuclearization" and complex issues surrounding US alliances and the non-proliferation regime.

site_title: Kim's quest to make North Korea normal again
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is set to meet with US President Donald Trump in Singapore next month, but the summit's outcome remains uncertain. Kim wants to ease sanctions in exchange for economic prosperity, but he is unwilling to give up his nuclear weapons until he feels safe enough to retain power without them. Kim's recent diplomatic efforts, including meetings with Chinese President Xi Jinping and South Korean President Moon Jae-in, have shown a more nuanced and diplomatic side to the leader, but his concerns about regime security remain a major obstacle to a deal.

site_title: SIAS withdraws Most Transparent Company Award from Midas
summary: The Securities Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) has withdrawn its Most Transparent Company Award from Midas Holdings, a Chinese railway parts maker, due to concerns over the reliability of its audited financial statements. The move comes after Mazars LLP, Midas's auditors, publicly disclosed that their reports for 2012-2016 cannot be relied upon. Midas is currently being investigated in Singapore and China for fraud, and its shares have been suspended since February. The withdrawal is seen as unprecedented and reflects SIAS's commitment to transparency and good corporate governance.

site_title: It's goodbye promising 'India Connect', and hello arbitration
summary: Singapore Exchange Ltd's "India Connect" stock connect between India and Singapore is facing arbitration after India's National Stock Exchange of India Ltd objected to the replication of the popular SGX Nifty 50 derivative contract. The dispute stems from the use of publicly available settlement prices and an 18-year-old licensing agreement. The arbitrator aims to find a solution by June 16, but Singapore's central bank expressed disappointment, citing reduced financial instrument options for investors. The move has also drawn criticism from MSCI Inc.

images.alt_text: A stock connect between India and Singapore, modelled on the popular Shanghai-Hong Kong link, died before it could be born.

site_title: Data subjects, reclaim the power of knowing the fate of your data
summary: The European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) applies to "data subjects" worldwide, not just European residents, and not just those physically in Europe. These data subjects are individuals whose personal data is used by controllers or processors, regardless of their physical location. The law aims to regulate companies operating globally, making them comply with stricter EU rules, and granting data subjects the right to move their information, know how it's used, and contest decisions made by algorithms. This law seeks to restore personal sovereignty and power to individuals, recognizing that data is currency and a key factor in global power dynamics.

site_title: Investors should be wary of yield curve inversion - a key signal of recession
summary: The US bond market has seen significant volatility this year, with the 10-year Treasury yield reaching a four-year high of 3.115% in May. A flattening yield curve is expected as the US Federal Reserve tightens, but a rare phenomenon known as yield curve inversion, where short rates exceed long rates, could precede a recession. Historically, yield curve inversions have preceded recessions, such as the 2007 sub-prime crisis. Analysts warn investors to be cautious if the yield curve inverts, as it could signal economic downturn.

site_title: Committal hearings begin for 2013 penny stock crash case
summary: A committal hearing began in Singapore's Supreme Court for the 2013 penny stock crash case, where Malaysian businessman John Soh Chee Wen and former IPCO International CEO Quah Su-Ling are accused of manipulating stock prices, resulting in an $8 billion loss in shareholder value. The prosecution, led by Deputy Public Prosecutor Peter Koy, will call 13 witnesses over the course of the hearing, which is expected to last until Friday. The accused are represented by top law firms, and the outcome of the hearing will determine if there is sufficient evidence to proceed to trial.

site_title: Yoma Strategic Q4 profit falls 86% to S$3.5m
summary: Yoma Strategic Holding's Q4 profit fell 86% to S$3.5 million, with revenue dropping 48.2% to S$25.1 million. The decline was mainly due to reduced income from the sale of residences and land development rights. The company has declared a final cash dividend of 0.25 Singapore cent per ordinary share and plans to scale up its business pillars and expand into financial services in Myanmar.

site_title: TV show Roseanne axed after star's racist tweet sparks outrage
summary: ABC cancelled its popular TV show "Roseanne" after star Roseanne Barr compared a former Obama administration official to an ape in a tweet, sparking outrage. The show's cancellation follows a similar 2013 incident where Barr made a racist comment. Barr apologized, but her tweet was swiftly deleted and she was dropped by her talent agency. The cancellation also led to the removal of reruns from other cable networks, including Hulu.

site_title: Thailand is new dumping ground for world's high-tech trash: police
summary: Thailand has become a dumping ground for the world's high-tech trash, as China's import ban on overseas rubbish has led to the re-routing of waste to South-east Asia. Police have seized seven shipping containers packed with discarded electronics, including crushed game consoles and computer boards, from Hong Kong, Singapore, and Japan. Environmentalists say new laws are needed to prevent illegal imports, and Thailand's Prime Minister has vowed to step up nationwide inspections.

site_title: Crisis flashbacks hit traders hard and fast
summary: Financial markets are experiencing turbulence in 2018, with pundits drawing comparisons to past crises such as the dot-com bubble, emerging-market chaos, and euro area debt scare. Despite less extreme fluctuations, investors are on edge due to the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes, which are affecting US Treasury yields and asset valuations. While some experts, including George Soros, warn of a potential major financial crisis, others, like Hao Hong, advise investors to take less risk and wait for events to unfold.

site_title: Sats posts 1.8% decline in Q4 net profit, final dividend up 1 cent to 12 cents
summary: Sats, a groundhandler, reported a 1.8% decline in Q4 net profit to S$65.4 million, with underlying net profit remaining flat at S$51.5 million. Revenue dipped 0.5% to S$423.5 million, driven by a 2.4% decline in food solutions business turnover. Operating profit rose 0.7% year-over-year to S$46.1 million. Sats will pay a final dividend of 12 cents per share, up one cent from last year. The company expects growth opportunities in passenger and cargo traffic, and plans to expand its airport network and digitize operations.

site_title: Savour an Omani getaway in the Weekend magazine
summary: Oman, a lesser-known country at the Arabian Peninsula's southeastern end, is featured in the Weekend magazine. The article highlights the country's stunning coastline, mountain ranges, warm locals, and safe streets. It also showcases four eco-conscious retailers and growing bars focusing on niche drinks. Additionally, it mentions various lifestyle topics such as mod-Indian cuisine and corporate purpose. The article aims to encourage readers to explore Oman and incorporate sustainable living into their daily lives.

site_title: More in private sector earned more in 2017 than in 2016
summary: The Ministry of Manpower in Singapore reported that more private sector workers received higher pay cheques in 2017 than in 2016, with real wages growing at 3.2% and 78% of employees polled receiving a salary increase. However, this was the slowest growth since 2013, due to rising costs of living and inflation. The survey also found that nearly two-thirds of low-wage workers received wage increases, with most receiving at least S$50.

site_title: Brewing up a Bettr future
summary: Bettr Barista, a social enterprise founded by Pamela Chng, provides gainful employment to marginalized women and at-risk youth through a four-month training program in coffee-related skills. The company, which operates coffee shops and mobile brew bars, has trained over 80 beneficiaries and achieved annual revenue of over $1 million. Bettr Barista's approach focuses on sustainability and profitability, hiring less productive workers who require more time and training. The company has broken even and was named Social Enterprise of the Year in 2017, with plans to expand to other regional countries and open new locations.

images.alt_text: "It is not enough to just train somebody on something. We need to give them a much broader set of skills to cope with their life and work challenges, so that they don't give up." - Pamela Chng (right, in black), founder of Bettr Barista.

Bettr Barista (above), runs a social programme training marginalised women and youth at risk. It earns its keep mainly by conducting coffee-related workshops, imparting brewing, barista and sensorial skills.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Manulife US Reit has opened a preferential offering of new units, priced at US$0.865 apiece, to raise about US$197.2 million. The funds will partially fund acquisitions of two office buildings in Washington DC and Atlanta. Meanwhile, Roxy-Pacific Holdings acquired a freehold residential site in Singapore for S$106 million, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding repurchased 5 million shares for S$4.5 million to boost its share price.

site_title: Deutsche Bank staff to learn about their fates by July, says CEO
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO Christian Sewing announced that staff will learn about their fates by July, with the bank aiming to reduce its workforce by over 7,000 by the end of 2019. The bank has already cut 600 jobs in its corporate and investment bank division since the start of the year. Sewing also plans to cut costs by moving offices out of city centers and reducing payments to IT vendors. The bank's share price has fallen nearly 5% due to the ongoing decline in revenue and market sell-off.

site_title: AirAsia shares plummet as probe imperils plans for India unit's IPO
summary: AirAsia shares plummeted 10.6% as Indian authorities filed a corruption case against the airline, its CEO Tony Fernandes, and unit AirAsia India. The probe accuses the airline of violating foreign direct investment rules and bribing officials to fly international routes. The case threatens to delay AirAsia India's IPO plans and international expansion, with analysts warning of potential losses and capital injections. The airline's shares have shed 20% since the Malaysian general election, valuing the company at around $2.5 billion.

site_title: Italian crisis and US-China trade rift roil Asian markets
summary: Asian markets plummeted 1.5% on Wednesday due to fears of an Italian euro zone existential crisis and escalating US-China trade tensions. The euro plunged to a 10-month low, and Italy's borrowing costs rose as a no-confidence motion against its premier built up. US President Donald Trump announced a list of $50 billion in tariffs on Chinese imports, further spooking markets. The Philippine peso hit a 12-year low, while the Singapore dollar depreciated against the US dollar. Analysts predict a protracted uncertainty period and potential impact on Asia's corporates with European operations.

site_title: Courts Asia in the red for Q4, dragged down by Malaysian business
summary: Courts Asia reported a Q4 net loss of S$3.02 million due to poor business performance in Malaysia, reversing from a profit a year ago. Revenue dropped 9.5% to S$163.3 million, and loss per share stood at 0.59 Singapore cents. The company attributed the decline to weak Malaysian sales and increased credit costs. Despite a strong Singapore performance, the business remains cautiously optimistic about Malaysia's outlook and plans for long-term sustainability. The full-year net profit dived 66% to S$8.1 million.

site_title: SIA to restart direct flights to New York in October
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will resume direct flights to New York in October, operating the ultra-long-range A350-900 jet. The flights will depart Singapore three times a week initially, with daily operations starting on October 18. The airline has seven A350-900ULRs on order, with all deliveries expected by the end of the year. The route is expected to boost connectivity to and through the Singapore hub, offering a faster and more comfortable option for business travelers.

site_title: ARA to raise US$1b for new pan-Asian infrastructure fund
summary: ARA Asset Management, backed by Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing, is launching a new pan-Asian infrastructure fund to raise US$1 billion in equity. The fund, ARA Infrastructure, aims to generate "mid-teens" returns through a mix of mid-stage developments and brownfield projects in the region. The company, which currently manages over 90 properties in the Asia-Pacific, aims to expand globally and reach US$100 billion in assets under management within five years.

site_title: Underground power station to supply Labrador area by 2025, as Singapore digs deeper
summary: Singapore plans to build its largest underground power station, set to supply the Labrador area by 2025. The 230kV station will be located underground, freeing up 3ha of land and reducing the risk of blackouts and burst pipelines during construction. The project is part of a nationwide push to utilize subterranean space and will not involve residential homes. Experts believe the benefits of underground infrastructure, such as freeing up land for parks and social amenities, outweigh the increased construction costs. A 3D underground masterplan will be unveiled next year, showcasing pilot areas and their potential uses.

site_title: BI raises key rate again, flags chance of more hikes
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, raised its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 4.75% for the second time in two weeks, signaling potential further hikes to bolster the rupiah and contain capital outflows amid an emerging market sell-off. Governor Perry Warjiyo prioritized rupiah stability, citing a need for "measured" rate hikes. The rupiah barely moved following the announcement, trading at about 13,985 per dollar.

site_title: ST Engineering announces rebranding of subsidiaries, corporate brands
summary: ST Engineering to adopt single brand approach, harmonizing corporate brands using "ST Engineering" as a masterbrand. The group's subsidiaries, including ST Aerospace, ST Electronics, ST Kinetics, and ST Marine, will have their corporate brands changed to start with "ST Engineering". The brand harmonization and company legal name change will take effect from June 1 in a phased approach, aiming to drive higher brand visibility and position the group for greater commercial impact. This move is expected to enhance competitiveness and cement the group's reputation as a global technology, defense, and engineering group.

site_title: Petronas Q1 profit jumps 26%
summary: Malaysia's state energy firm Petronas reported a 26% increase in first-quarter profit to RM13 billion, driven by higher oil prices. Revenue rose 2.5% to RM57.9 billion. The company expects a "satisfactory" year-end performance, subject to oil price volatility. Petronas' total oil production volume rose to 2,461 tboe/day, and its Refinery and Petrochemical Integrated Development project is on track for a 2019 start-up, with 90% completion at the end of April.

images.alt_text: Petronas expects overall year-end performance to be "satisfactory" subject to the volatility of oil prices and forex rates.

site_title: Surf's up for upmarket seaside project as Nigeria's economy rebounds
summary: Nigeria's economy is rebounding, allowing the construction of Eko Atlantic City, a high-end seaside development, to progress. The project, expected to be fully operational in five years, will reclaim 10 sq km of land from the Atlantic Ocean and feature luxury apartments, roads, and infrastructure. The development is being built on a 6.5 sq km stretch of land already reclaimed, with plans to attract corporate headquarters and foreign investment. With Nigeria's gross domestic product forecast to grow to 2.1% this year, Eko Atlantic City aims to cater to the growing middle class and foreign buyers.

images.alt_text: Nigeria's gross domestic product has expanded for four straight quarters. The IMF forecasts growth will accelerate to 2.1 per cent this year from 0.8 per cent in 2017.

site_title: Italian imbroglio may trigger new global crisis
summary: US President Donald Trump's decision to heighten trade tensions with Europe may trigger a global economic disaster on the scale of the 2008 financial crisis. Italy, the euro area's third-largest economy, is at the center of the turmoil, with its economy being 10 times larger than Greece' and playing a crucial role in the single currency's survival. Ignoring Italy's systemic importance, Trump's actions may sow confusion in the markets and have severe economic consequences, potentially destabilizing the global economy.

site_title: Electric vehicles on road set to triple in 2 years
summary: The global fleet of electric vehicles is expected to more than triple to 13 million by the end of the decade, with sales soaring 24% annually on average through 2030. The International Energy Agency (IEA) attributes this growth to dynamic policy developments and investments in battery production, facilitating cost reductions. Major automakers, including Tesla and Nissan, have announced dozens of battery-powered versions of their models. The IEA estimates that EVs will displace 380,000 barrels of demand per day by the end of the next decade, with China expected to make up half of the world's demand.

site_title: First Sponsor unit selling part of Chengdu project for S$97.5m
summary: First Sponsor Group's unit, Chengdu Gaeronic Real Estate Co, is selling parts of the mixed-use project Chengdu Cityspring for 465 million yuan (S$97.5 million). The sale includes a commercial building, retail space, and 318 basement car park lots. The property is owned under a leasehold, set to expire in 2049, and the sale price exceeds the net book value by 102.9 million yuan. The proceeds will be used to fund existing operations in China, strengthening the company's balance sheet.

site_title: Anti-bias training doesn't work - it may make the problem worse
summary: A viral video of two African-American men being arrested at a Starbucks in Philadelphia sparked calls for boycotts and an apology from CEO Kevin Johnson. In response, Starbucks closed 8,000 US stores for anti-bias training, but experts say this approach may not solve the problem. Research suggests that implicit bias training often fails to alter racial biases and behaviors, and can even backfire. Instead, companies should focus on measures that truly address inequality, such as increasing racial integration and diversity in leadership positions, and implementing college recruitment programs.

site_title: Opec, non-Opec sticking to oil pact but may raise output if needed - Gulf source
summary: OPEC and non-OPEC countries, including Saudi Arabia, aim to maintain a global oil supply reduction pact until the end of 2018, but are prepared to adjust output if a shortage occurs. The deal, which began in 2017, has driven down inventories and pushed up prices, but the group is not yet ready to fully lift controls. If a shortage takes place, producers will coordinate closely and adjust output levels in a gradual and deliberate manner, with Saudi Arabia favoring a gradual approach to increase output if needed.

site_title: JTC releases 2 sites at Braddell, Tampines
summary: JTC has released two industrial sites in Braddell and Tampines for tender, along with a reserve list site in Corporation Drive. The confirmed list sites include a 0.97-hectare site at Braddell Road with a 30-year tenure and a 0.47-hectare site at Tampines Industrial Drive with a 20-year tenure. The tender for the Braddell Road site closes on July 11, while the Tampines site closes on July 25.

site_title: Australia's building activity slows in April, bad omen for economy
summary: Australia's housing activity slowed in April, with dwelling approvals down 5% and non-residential permits also decreasing. This marks an ominous sign for broader economic growth, as the country's four-year-old home building boom is losing momentum. Analysts expect home prices in major cities to ease another 5% this year, with further declines likely next year, constraining consumer spending and posing a downside risk to the Australian economy.

site_title: Jason Marine FY net profit falls 89% on continued challenging market conditions
summary: Jason Marine Holdings reported a 88.9% drop in net profit to S$45,000 in FY2018, from S$406,000 in FY2017, due to a 4.6% decline in revenue. The company attributed the decline to a drop in airtime revenue. Despite this, net asset value per share rose to 44.24 cents. Jason Marine expects challenging market conditions to persist and plans to focus on strengthening its existing business and expanding its portfolio of integrated communications solutions. The company proposed a first and final tax-exempt dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent per share.

site_title: PM Lee: Cabinet changes among my most difficult responsibilities as PM
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said Cabinet changes are one of his most difficult but important responsibilities, requiring a balance between avoiding abrupt discontinuities and not keeping the status quo for too long. He praised the retirement of three ministers, Lim Swee Say, Yaacob Ibrahim, and Lim Hng Kiang, who brought 70 years of solid experience to the table, and highlighted their contributions to Singapore's success. Lee emphasized the need for leadership renewal, citing the growing age of the current ministers and the need to prepare for their eventual departure.

site_title: Gilstead Mansion en bloc bid targets S$68m
summary: The owners of Gilstead Mansion in Singapore have put the 24-unit freehold site up for collective sale by public tender with an expected price of at least S$68 million. The tender will close on July 3, and the site can be developed into 22 cluster terrace houses or maintained as apartments. Consent has been received from 330 out of 410 unit owners, short of the 80% approval required for a collective sale to proceed. The sale price works out to about S$1,564.50 per sq ft per plot ratio, similar to nearby sales.

site_title: Walmart says it will pay for its workers to earn college degrees
summary: Walmart is launching a college tuition subsidy program for its 1.4 million US workers, offering to pay for tuition in exchange for a $1 daily contribution. The program will cover courses at three universities: University of Florida, Brandman University, and Bellevue University. Full- and part-time workers can enroll in associate's and bachelor's degrees in supply chain management or business. The goal is to help employees obtain a degree without taking out loans, with no upfront costs and no penalty for leaving the company before completing studies.

site_title: Cooperation between Singapore, China authorities vital to regulating S-chips
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has engaged with the Chinese Embassy in Singapore to discuss strengthened supervision and accountability of Chinese companies listed on the exchange. This move aims to boost investor confidence in S-chips, which have faced scandals and financial misreporting. Chinese authorities must abide by Singapore's disclosure-based regime to build investor trust. Securing state-owned enterprise (SOE) or mainland cornerstone investors can help minority shareholders take regulatory action against offenders in China, but detailed guidelines need to be worked out to implement the proposal.

site_title: Look out for Saudis' July official selling prices for key to oil outlook
summary: Saudi Aramco is set to release its official selling prices (OSPs) for July-loading crude oil cargoes, which will likely influence global crude oil prices. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) meeting in July is seen as key to the outlook for crude oil prices. Saudi Aramco's OSPs set the prices for much of the Middle East's exports, and investors closely monitor these prices for guidance on future market trends. The release of OSPs is expected to provide a strong indication of the direction of crude oil prices in the coming months.

site_title: UOB launches digital clinics targeted at small businesses
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) launched digital clinics targeting small businesses to aid in digitalisation. The clinics, held monthly, provide one-on-one guidance from digitalisation experts on implementing digital solutions. Experts from UOB partners SAP, HReasily, and Enterpryze will lead the sessions. This initiative aims to help small businesses improve processes and leverage technology.

site_title: China slams US for 'sudden flip-flops' in trade policy
summary: China has strongly criticized the US for "sudden flip-flops" in trade policy, following President Donald Trump's announcement that the US is finalizing trade sanctions against China. The US had previously announced a truce in trade hostilities, but now threatens tariffs on Chinese goods. China's foreign ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying urged the US to abandon trade wars and back off imposing tariffs, warning that China will take "firm and forceful measures" if necessary. The US has proposed $50 billion in tariffs on Chinese tech goods, with the final list to be announced June 15.

site_title: Yangzijiang buys back 5m shares, readies cash for more share buybacks
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has repurchased 5 million shares for S$4.5 million, amid the weak performance of its shares. The share price declined 13% to a 15-month low. The company has 5.6 billion Chinese yuan (S$1.2 billion) in cash and is ready to conduct more share buybacks to bolster its share price.

site_title: 2013 penny stock crash case enters committal hearing
summary: A committal hearing began at the Supreme Court to determine if there's enough evidence for the 2013 penny stock crash case to proceed to trial. Malaysian businessman John Soh Chee Wen and former IPCO International CEO Quah Su-Ling are accused of manipulating stock prices, resulting in an $8 billion loss on the Singapore Exchange within three days in October 2013. The prosecution, led by Deputy Public Prosecutor Peter Koy, will call 13 witnesses over the course of the hearing.

site_title: Navarro rebukes Mnuchin over trade truce before China talks
