This marks the third consecutive month of growth, following a 4% increase in March and a 3% increase in February. Norway remains the world's top salmon producer, with Chile following closely.

site_title: Alibaba, Tencent join big names betting on Hon Hai arm's IPO
summary: China's largest tech corporations, including Alibaba and Tencent, are investing in Foxconn Industrial Internet Co.'s (FII) Shanghai listing, which aims to raise 27.1 billion yuan for smart manufacturing and 5G projects. Strategic investors include Baidu, Apple assembler Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., and other major Chinese companies. The lockup period is set at three years. The IPO has attracted significant investment from China's top internet companies, further solidifying FII's position as a key player in the smart factory sector.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.67% on Monday, driven by hopes for a successful summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. The Hang Seng Index increased to 30,792.26, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices eased slightly. The positive move was seen as a relief to investors amid US-EU trade tensions and tariff threats.

site_title: Australian shares end lower on weaker commodities; NZ up
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% on Monday as mining and oil stocks declined due to weaker commodity prices, while banks dropped amid the Royal Commission inquiry's resumption. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6004, extending its 0.1% loss from Friday.

site_title: In Britain, austerity Is changing everything
summary: Austerity measures in Britain, introduced in 2010, have drastically reduced local government budgets, with the borough of Knowsley experiencing a roughly 50% cut and Liverpool a nearly 66% reduction. This has led to the closure of public facilities, including libraries, leisure centers, and police stations, and the potential sale of community spaces like Browns Field. Experts argue that austerity has created destitution, harming vulnerable populations, and has made Britain less like Western Europe and more like the US, where millions lack healthcare and job loss can lead to severe financial struggles.

images.alt_text: As austerity bites, many fire stations including this one, which was mentioned in the Beatles song "Penny Lane", have closed in Liverpool, England.

site_title: Indonesia seeks to tame market contagion as bets grow on Wednesday rate hike
summary: Indonesia's central bank is expected to raise interest rates for the second time in two weeks to combat market contagion and relieve pressure on the country's financial markets. Governor Perry Warjiyo has downplayed the meeting as non-emergency, but the rupiah has surged to a two-week high. The move comes as emerging markets face outflows of funds due to rising US interest rates. Indonesia's economy has been affected by the global market fluctuations, with investors seeking safer assets.

images.alt_text: Perry Warjiyo, sworn in as governor last week, said on Monday that it was not an "emergency meeting", but the rupiah jumped to a two-week high on hopes central bank actions will relieve persistent pressure on the country's financial markets.

site_title: Cheers! Coca-Cola launches first boozy drink in Japan
summary: Coca-Cola launched its first alcoholic drink, "Lemon-Do", in Japan, offering three, five, and seven percent alcohol content. The fizzy, lemon-flavored drinks are part of a pilot project in the southern Kyushu region and are available in 350-milliliter cans for 150 yen (S$1.87). The company aims to capitalize on Japan's growing "chuhai" alcopop market, which is popular among young women. The drinks will not be launched outside of Japan, and the recipe remains a secret. This move marks Coca-Cola's first foray into the Japanese alcohol market in its 125-year history.

site_title: Italian president's powers limited but key in a crisis
summary: Italian President Sergio Mattarella has limited powers but exercised them to refuse appointing a eurosceptic finance minister, backed by the majority of parliamentarians, as chosen by Prime Minister-designate. This decision, based on Article 92 of the Italian constitution, enraged far-right League of Matteo Salvini and anti-establishment Five Star Movement of Luigi Di Maio, who accused the president of meddling by Brussels or financial lobbyists. The president's decision has sparked the possibility of impeaching Mattarella for treason, a move that would require an absolute majority in parliament.

site_title: New Bank Indonesia Governor is wasting no time on rate hikes
summary: Indonesia's new central bank Governor Perry Warjiyo has called an early policy meeting, setting the stage for a potential second interest rate hike in two weeks, amid a currency rout triggered by rising US interest rates. The meeting, scheduled for Wednesday, aims to boost the currency and address investor concerns. Economists expect a 25 basis point rate hike, while others anticipate macro-prudential measures to maintain stability. The move follows a net US$2.1 billion of Indonesian sovereign bonds being dumped by global funds, pushing the rupiah to a fresh low.

site_title: Grab hungers to be Asean consumers' daily staple as it unveils food delivery service
summary: Grab unveiled a food delivery service, GrabFood, in Singapore, aiming to become the "everyday app" for South-east Asian consumers. The service, available in six countries, allows consumers to order food on demand without minimum order requirements. Delivery partners can work on their own schedule and cash out earnings immediately. GrabFood is the result of Grab's acquisition of Uber's food delivery business, UberEATS, and marks a significant milestone in its expansion.

images.alt_text: LIA president Khoo Kah Siang cited two key areas of focus for the industry for the year ahead: keeping a lid on rising healthcare costs and looking at issues surrounding digitalisation.
Grab announced an islandwide beta version of GrabFood in Singapore, through which consumers can order food on demand from "thousands of merchants", without any minimum order requirement.

Delivery-partners of GrabFood, meanwhile, can work "whenever they want" without having to pre-book their delivery slots, and cash out all their earnings for the day on the same day, "without any delay".

site_title: Veolia CEO sees opportunities in China from Beijing's waste crackdown
summary: Veolia Environnement SA, a French water and waste services firm, sees opportunities in China due to Beijing's crackdown on waste imports. CEO Antoine Frerot stated that the company has nine hazardous waste treatment plants in China and plans to open a ship dismantling plant in Guangdong in a few months. This move is a positive response to the Chinese government's efforts to reduce waste imports and increase recycling.

site_title: Mother of 'nut rage' Korean Air heiress questioned
summary: Seoul police questioned 69-year-old Lee Myung-hee, the matriarch of the Korean Air dynasty, over allegations of assaulting household staff, construction workers, and employees at her home and a Korean Air-affiliated hotel. Lee's two daughters, who held management positions at Korean Air, sparked "nut rage" scandals in 2014 and 2017. Lee apologized for causing trouble and faces charges of cursing, screaming, kicking, slapping, and throwing objects at employees. Authorities have launched probes into worker abuse, smuggling, and immigration law violations, and hundreds of Korean Air workers have protested demanding the ouster of the Cho clan from the airline.

site_title: Oil slumps as Saudis and Russia say reviving output on the table
summary: Oil prices slumped to their longest run of losses in almost four months as Saudi Arabia and Russia discussed reviving output to ease consumer anxiety, following a surge in prices to levels not seen since 2014. Brent futures fell near $75, while crude in New York dropped 3.1%, with opposition from several producers making a consensus uncertain. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) and Russia are likely to revive oil output in the second half of the year, but no decision has been made, and demand concerns remain.

images.alt_text: Oil headed for its longest run of losses in almost four months as Saudi Arabia and Russia said they are discussing reviving output to ease consumer anxiety after prices jumped to levels last seen in 2014.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei inches up as North Korea fears ease
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index rose 0.13% to close at 22,481.09 on Monday, driven by easing geopolitical concerns after US and North Korean officials met to prepare for a summit. The broader Topix index fell 0.07%. The move comes as US President Trump threatens to extend tariffs, but traders seem to be brushing off the threat. The Nikkei's gain was seen as a positive sign for the market, despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Average cost of hiring an expatriate in Singapore fell in 2017: poll
summary: The average cost of employing an expatriate in Singapore dropped by over US$12,000 in 2017, to US$223,095, making it one of the most dramatic falls in Asia. Despite this, Singapore remains one of the 20 most expensive countries for expatriate staff. Malaysia saw a bigger drop, with an average expatriate pay package of US$150,868, making it the least expensive city in the rankings. In contrast, Hong Kong's expatriate pay package rose to US$268,514, while China's dropped to US$276,387 due to exchange rate movements.

site_title: Macau will struggle to kick its gambling addiction
summary: Macau aims to reduce its reliance on gambling revenue by diversifying its tourism offerings, targeting 40% of revenue from non-gaming activities like conferences, nightlife, and family-friendly fun. Currently, casinos generate just 12% of revenue. To achieve this goal, casino operators are investing in new facilities and attractions, but local authorities are hindered by inadequate infrastructure, branding, and bureaucracy. Macau needs to improve its transportation links, streamline regulatory processes, and promote itself beyond China's perception as a gambling hub to secure its future.

site_title: Diesel cars to die out in Tesla-like future, EU regulator says
summary: European Union regulators predict that diesel cars will largely disappear in the next few years, driven by a technological revolution in road transport. The EU's industrial-policy chief, Elzbieta Bienkowska, says diesel cars are "finished" due to the scandal involving Volkswagen AG's software cheating on emissions tests. The EU is seeking to boost electric-vehicle sales, aiming for 5% of new registrations by 2021 and 20% by 2025, with incentives and stricter rules to encourage the shift.

images.alt_text: European Union consumers may do as much as regulators to propel the the region's car sector into the electricity-powered age foreseen by Tesla Inc., according to the EU's industrial-policy chief.

site_title: Jordan's veteran musicians revive Arab song
summary: A group of veteran musicians in Jordan, some over 80 years old, revive the golden age of Arab song through free concerts at the Al Hussein Cultural Center. Founded by Sakher Hattar in 2008, Beit al-Ruwwad celebrates classic Arab music and Jordanian folklore, with performances featuring oud, flute, drums, and accordion. The group's fans, including those from across Jordanian society, praise the concerts for providing a comfortable space for original art and artists, and for transporting them back to a beautiful time.

site_title: New Bank Indonesia Governor is wasting no time on rate hikes
summary: Bank Indonesia, Indonesia's central bank, has announced an early policy meeting, exceeding expectations, and is set to increase the benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points from 4.5% to 4.75%. The move aims to stem a global rout triggered by rising US interest rates and a stronger dollar, boosting the rupiah 1% against the dollar. Governor Perry Warjiyo has pledged to act early and be ahead of the curve, following a similar strategy employed by central banks in emerging markets.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday trading at 3,524.98, up 0.33% on the day
summary: Singapore stocks opened Monday at 3,524.98, up 0.33% or 11.75 points, with 667.7 million shares worth S$391.8 million traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 172 to 146, with Ezion Holdings and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings declining 3.3% and 2.6% respectively. Winners included DBS Group Holdings and SingTel, up 0.6% and 0.3% respectively.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp Industries, AEM, Mencast
summary: Sembcorp Industries has hired Graham Cockroft as its new group CFO, effective September 3. AEM Holdings received verdicts in favor in two Chinese lawsuits involving its subsidiary AEM Microtronics. Mencast plans to release land, divest properties, and generate cash to pare down loans.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as North Korea fears ease
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on May 28, 2018, as geopolitical worries eased following a US and North Korean meeting on Sunday to resume summit preparations. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.15% to 22,484.56, while the Topix index increased 0.03% to 1,772.18. The positive market sentiment was attributed to the resumption of diplomatic efforts between the US and North Korea.

site_title: Completed condo, private apartment prices slip 0.3% in April from March: NUS index
summary: Singapore's completed private apartment and condominium prices dropped 0.3% in April from March, according to the National University of Singapore's (NUS) flash estimates. The decline was mainly driven by a 0.8% drop in central region prices, excluding small units. This comes after a 1% month-on-month rise in March. Overall, prices are 7.9% higher year-on-year, with a 9.1% increase in central region apartments and a 7% rise in non-central locations.

site_title: Malaysia's Maybank posts highest-ever Q1 profit on lower expenses
summary: Malaysia's largest lender, Maybank, reported its highest-ever first-quarter profit of RM1.9 billion ($638.8 million), up 10% from last year, driven by lower expenses and declining impairment losses. Revenue increased 2% to RM11.5 billion, while the bank's cost-to-income ratio improved to 47.6%. Maybank's loans grew 6.7% in Malaysia, 5.5% in Singapore, and 2.9% in Indonesia. The bank's chairwoman attributed the positive results to a positive outlook in the region and Malaysia, despite uncertainties.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 14.98 points to 1,793.45. The market saw 78.39 million lots traded worth RM44.03 million, with 126 gainers and 117 losers.

site_title: Chinese battery firms join Responsible Cobalt Initiative
summary: Chinese battery maker Contemporary Amperex Technology Co Ltd (CATL) and battery recycler GEM Co Ltd have joined the Responsible Cobalt Initiative (RCI), a group tackling cobalt supply chain risks. The RCI, with 31 members including Apple, HP, and BMW, aims to promote responsible sourcing of cobalt. The move is seen as a step towards addressing concerns over the use of cobalt in lithium-ion batteries, particularly in the electric vehicle sector. The RCI's membership expansion underscores the industry's commitment to transparency and sustainability in the cobalt supply chain.

site_title: MoMA sees a problem in a cafe's name. The cafe sees none.
summary: The Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) in New York has filed a trademark infringement lawsuit against MoMaCha, a cafe and exhibition space that opened on the Bowery in April. MoMa claims the cafe's name and logo are too similar to its own, targeting visitors and seeking free publicity. MoMaCha's lawyers argue the name is a combination of "more" and "matcha" and not meant to confuse with MoMA. The cafe has changed its formatting and announced its disassociation from MoMA, but the lawsuit remains pending.

site_title: Blackstone bids US$2.38b for office tower fund Investa
summary: Blackstone Group LP has offered A$3.14 billion (S$3.19 billion) to acquire Investa Office Fund, a real estate investment trust in Australia, for A$5.25 in cash per share, a 13% increase from the previous closing price. The deal would give Blackstone 37 properties across Australia, and Investa's directors plan to recommend the deal to investors unless a better offer is received. This is the latest attempt by a suitor, following previous offers from Dexus Property Group and Cromwell Property Group, which were rejected by investors.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index adding 0.56% to 30,759.84, following US President Donald Trump's comments suggesting a resumption of his summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. The Shanghai Composite Index was flat, while the Shenzhen Composite Index decreased 0.11%. The gains came despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and concerns about global economic growth.

site_title: Gaylin Q4 loss widens to S$44m on hefty provisions, but now net cash positive
summary: Gaylin Holdings reported a widened fourth-quarter net loss of S$44.4 million, or 6.13 Singapore cents per share, due to a S$35.5 million provision for slow-moving inventory. Revenue declined 28.1% to S$15.5 million. Despite the loss, the company strengthened its cash position, becoming net cash positive for the first time since 2012, with S$57.8 million in cash and cash equivalents. Gaylin expressed increasing optimism in the global oilfield services market amid rising oil prices.

site_title: China to host Iran to avoid project disruption amid nuclear deal doubt
summary: China will host Iranian President Hassan Rouhani in June to discuss joint projects and avoid disruption amid doubt over the Iran nuclear deal. The summit, part of the China and Russia-led Shanghai Cooperation Organisation, aims to promote bilateral cooperation. China has supported the 2015 deal and is one of its signatories, while the US has withdrawn, leading European states to scramble to ensure Iran receives economic benefits to stay in the deal. China's Deputy Foreign Minister Zhang Hanhui hopes for close consultation between the two countries on the deal and joint efforts to prevent major disruption of joint projects.

images.alt_text: China will host Iranian President Hassan Rouhani next month at a regional summit aimed at avoiding disruption of joint projects, its foreign ministry said on Monday, as major powers scramble to save Iran's nuclear deal after the United States pulled out.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won gain on revived North Korea-US summit hopes
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 0.67% to 2,477.18 on May 28, 2018, following US President Donald Trump's announcement that a US team had arrived in North Korea to prepare for a proposed summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. The won gained 0.37% to 1,074 per dollar, while bond yields remained unchanged. Construction and railway shares surged, including Hyundai Engineering & Construction, which jumped 28%. The KOSPI is up 0.41% in the past 30 days, but down 0.3% this year.

site_title: Europe's largest wooden building awaits salvation off Istanbul
summary: Europe's largest wooden building, the Prinkipo Greek Orthodox orphanage, built in 1898 on an island off Istanbul, is at risk of collapse due to dilapidation and lack of maintenance. Once a luxury casino hotel, the building was converted into an orphanage in 1903 and closed in 1964. Cultural heritage NGO Europa Nostra has listed it as one of Europe's seven most endangered sites, and experts will assess the damage this summer to determine the cost of restoration, estimated to be around $50 million. The orphanage's former residents and the Turkish government are determined to save the building, which they consider a cultural treasure.

images.alt_text: Built at the end of the 19th century on an island off Istanbul, this unique six-storey structure once served as a home for Greek Orthodox orphans until it was shut down in the early 1960s.And more than five decades later, the now dilapidated Prinkipo Greek Orthodox orphanage is at risk of collapse.

site_title: Australia orders recall of further 1.1 million cars fitted with Takata air bags
summary: Australia has ordered a recall of an additional 1.1 million cars fitted with Takata air bags, increasing the total affected vehicles to nearly 3 million. The recall, which must be completed by December 31, 2020, is due to the air bags' potential to rupture and cause injuries. Manufacturers face fines of A$1.1 million if they fail to meet the deadline. The move follows pressure on global manufacturers to meet recall timetables, with the US auto safety agency seeking to meet with 12 major automakers that missed a December 2017 deadline.

site_title: German carmakers morally obliged to refit dirty diesels: minister
summary: German Environment Minister Svenja Schulze says carmakers have a moral obligation to refit heavily polluting diesel vehicles, but lacks legal power to enforce the move. The proposed refits could be targeted at cities with high pollution levels, costing around low single-digit billions. This comes amid revelations that nitrogen oxide emissions from diesel cars are higher than previously thought, leading to fines and enforcement action by the European Commission. The plan aims to boost consumer confidence and avoid taxpayer costs.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.18% to 3,519.71
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.18% to 3,519.71 at the start of the week, with 28.5 million shares worth S$46.1 million traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 63 to 31. DBS Group Holdings and Singtel led the gains, while Ezion Holdings and Sembcorp Marine slipped. The rally came ahead of trading holidays observed globally, with US-EU tariffs and other market events expected to influence the market.

site_title: MAS affirms commitment to BIS Foreign Exchange Global Code
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) reaffirmed its commitment to the Foreign Exchange Global Code, developed by the Bank for International Settlements (BIS). The MAS will adhere to the Code's principles, promoting a robust and transparent foreign exchange market. The central bank encourages Singaporean wholesale forex market participants to demonstrate adherence to the Code, aiming to maintain market integrity.

site_title: Keppel eyes S$114m gain in US$298m sale of stake in Beijing commercial project
summary: Keppel Corp is set to book a S$114 million gain after selling a 51% stake in a Beijing commercial project for US$297.9 million. The stake was sold to CBD Aether Center through an option agreement. If the deal is completed within 120 days, Keppel will receive the full consideration price, including an option fee. The sale would have increased Keppel's net tangible asset per share and earnings per share in 2017 if completed on Jan 1, 2017.

site_title: Brazil cuts fuel prices after strike leaves food, fuel scarce
summary: Brazil's President Michel Temer has cut diesel fuel prices by 0.46 reais a liter, effective for 60 days, following a week-long national truckers' strike that led to fuel and food shortages. The strike, which paralyzed much of the country's economic infrastructure, resulted in estimated losses of $2.8 billion to the economy. Temer also agreed to four other demands made by the truckers, including abolishing a tax on diesel and implementing subsidies to maintain a temporary 10% fuel price reduction. The move aims to ease the problems and suffering caused by the strike.

images.alt_text: Brazil's President Michel Temer, under pressure from a week-long national truckers' strike which led to fuel and food shortages, ceded to protesters' demands Sunday and slashed the cost of diesel.

site_title: Grab hungers to be Asean consumers' daily staple as it unveils food delivery service
summary: Grab, a ride-hailing startup, unveiled a food delivery service called GrabFood in Singapore, aiming to become the "everyday app" for South-east Asian consumers. The service, available islandwide, allows consumers to order food on demand from thousands of merchants without minimum order requirements. GrabFood will be launched in six South-east Asian countries, including Singapore, Indonesia, Thailand, Vietnam, Malaysia, and the Philippines, within the quarter. This move follows Grab's acquisition of Uber's operations in South-east Asia, including UberEATS, and is part of its efforts to create a seamless experience for customers.

images.alt_text: Grab announced an islandwide beta version of GrabFood in Singapore, through which consumers can order food on demand from "thousands of merchants", without any minimum order requirement.

Delivery-partners of GrabFood, meanwhile, can work "whenever they want" without having to pre-book their delivery slots, and cash out all their earnings for the day on the same day, "without any delay".

site_title: Australia: Shares track lower on weaker commodity prices; NZ falls
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% on Monday, weighed down by weaker commodity prices and the resumption of the Royal Commission inquiry into financial services. Mining stocks, including Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton, declined as London aluminium and nickel prices dropped. Energy stocks also fell, with oil prices off due to global economic slowdown fears. Meanwhile, banks lost 0.1% and retail conglomerate Wesfarmers dragged the benchmark down after announcing plans to sell its pubs and liquor business.

site_title: South Korean president might join Trump, Kim in Singapore for 3-way summit: Official
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae In may join US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in a three-way summit in Singapore next month, depending on the outcome of ongoing US-North Korea talks. The summit, first proposed by Moon and Kim in April, aims to provide a security guarantee for North Korea in exchange for its denuclearisation. If successful, a three-way summit could mark a significant step towards formally ending the Korean War. The outcome of US-North Korea talks will determine whether Moon's trip to Singapore will proceed.

site_title: St Thomas Walk property owned by sole family in District 9 up for sale with S$68m asking price
summary: A freehold residential redevelopment site in St Thomas Walk, District 9, has been put up for sale with an asking price of S$68 million. The site, with a land area of 1,190 sq m, can be redeveloped into a 36-storey high-rise boutique project. The sale is expected to attract interest from developers due to the current market sentiments, with recent sales in the vicinity showing brisk take-ups. The tender exercise for the site will close on July 3.

site_title: China warns US vessels to leave disputed waters
summary: China has despatched warships to challenge two US Navy vessels that sailed through disputed waters in the South China Sea. The US Higgins destroyer and Antietam cruiser passed within 12 nautical miles of the Paracel Islands, prompting China to warn the US vessels to leave. The encounter occurred amid rising tensions between the US and China, with China accusing the US of violating its sovereignty. The US Navy conducted "freedom of navigation operations," exercising its rights under international law, but China claims the islands as its own.

site_title: The airline geek trying to build a media giant with no reporters
summary: A Japanese startup, JX Press Corp, founded by 29-year-old Katsuhiro Yoneshige, has been making headlines for its innovative approach to news reporting. The company, which has no journalists or international bureaus, uses a combination of social media and artificial intelligence to find breaking news and write reports. Its tool, Fast Alert, scours social media and overseas media to detect news, and its free mobile app, NewsDigest, ranks 8th in Japan's news app category. JX Press has gained interest from major broadcasters and hedge funds, and aims to list its shares by 2021.

site_title: US despatches army of envoys to salvage talks
summary: The US has dispatched a team of envoys to North Korea to revive talks between the two leaders, aiming for a summit meeting by June 12. US diplomats met with their North Korean counterparts in the Demilitarized Zone, seeking commitments on the regime's nuclear program. US President Donald Trump expressed optimism about the meeting, tweeting that North Korea has "brilliant potential" and will be a "great economic and financial Nation one day." Simultaneous negotiations in the DMZ and Singapore are underway to finalize preparations for the meeting.

site_title: CareShield Life: What you need to know
summary: Singapore's CareShield Life, a mandatory long-term savings plan, provides additional premium support for those struggling to pay premiums. The transitional subsidy offers up to S$250 for Singaporeans in the first five years. The payout increases annually until age 67 or a claim is made, whichever comes first.

site_title: US set to go hog-wild as supply soars and prices plunge
summary: A record-sized US hog herd has led to a surge in pork supply, causing prices to plummet and hedge funds to become the most bearish on the market's outlook since 2013. Wholesale pork prices have fallen 18% and ribs are at their cheapest since 2009, with some stores offering buy-one-get-two discounts. The US Department of Agriculture reports a 6% increase in stockpiles of ribs and nearly 73 million hogs and pigs in the US, a record for the time of year.

site_title: Watchdogs go after tech companies as Europe's data law kicks in
summary: The European Union has implemented a sweeping overhaul of digital privacy laws, known as GDPR, giving users the right to demand data deletion and object to new data collection forms. This move makes the EU the most powerful regulator of Silicon Valley, creating a global standard for tech companies. The new law aims to protect customers' data and creates new headaches for US tech companies, while providing new protections for Americans.

site_title: Sembcorp hires Contact Energy CFO; current CFO Koh to head regional utilities business
summary: Sembcorp Industries has hired Graham Cockroft, former CFO of Contact Energy, as its new group CFO, effective September 3, 2018. Current CFO Koh Chiap Khiong will lead the group's utilities business in Singapore, South-east Asia, and China. Cockroft brings 20 years of experience from BG Group and Contact Energy, and was chosen after a global search by CEO Neil McGregor. McGregor praised Koh's contributions as CFO and expressed confidence in Cockroft's ability to deliver performance and growth in a dynamic environment.

site_title: Saudi-Russia oil policy shift sets stage for tense Opec meeting
summary: Saudi Arabia and Russia have announced a plan to revive oil production, raising output to make up for losses from other OPEC members, particularly Venezuela and Iran. The proposal, which does not involve consultation with most OPEC partners, could lead to a contentious meeting in Vienna next month. If the plan is implemented, Saudi Arabia could go ahead with the increase alone, potentially causing a significant impact on the market. The success of the 24-nation alliance that agreed to supply cuts seems valuable to Saudi Arabia, but it may prefer a diplomatic route to seek consensus.

site_title: 'Solo: A Star Wars Story' struggles to take off in opening weekend
summary: "Solo: A Star Wars Story" underperformed in its opening weekend, earning an estimated US$101 million in the US, far below predicted US$130-150 million. The film, directed by Ron Howard and starring Alden Ehrenreich as young Han Solo, struggled in North America and abroad, with a predicted global take of US$300 million falling short. It took second spot behind "Deadpool 2" and third behind "Avengers: Infinity War."

images.alt_text: "Solo: A Star Wars Story," the latest prequel in the hugely popular film franchise, struggled to achieve escape velocity this holiday weekend, with an estimated US$101 million four-day take falling far below expectations.

site_title: Republicans up in arms over bank curbs on gun sales
summary: US Republicans are pressing regulators to stop banks from restricting financing for gun sellers, citing concerns over infringement of the Second Amendment. Major banks have taken steps to prevent guns from falling into the wrong hands, including restricting credit and lending to gun retailers and manufacturers. Gun advocates view these moves as a direct assault on the industry, while lawmakers weigh in on the issue, with some expressing reluctance to interfere in the financial sector. The banking industry's efforts to curb gun sales have created a rift between Republicans and the financial industry, which has been a major contributor to the party.

site_title: Bombardier to build two new luxury aircraft amid growing demand
summary: Bombardier Inc. plans to build two new luxury aircraft, the Global 5500 and Global 6500, in response to growing demand for large-cabin business jets. The models will feature redesigned cabins, optimized wings, and all-new Rolls-Royce engines, offering increased range and fuel efficiency. The Global 5500 will have a range of 5,700 nautical miles and a list price of $46 million, while the Global 6500 will have a range of 6,600 nautical miles and a list price of $56 million, both expected to enter service in 2019.

images.alt_text: Bombardier Inc. will build two new private planes in response to growing demand for large-cabin business jets.

site_title: US ex-president George H. W. Bush hospitalised again
summary: Former US President George H.W. Bush, 93, was re-admitted to hospital in Maine with low blood pressure and fatigue, just over three weeks after his release from a Texas hospital. He contracted an infection that spread to his blood during his previous hospitalization, following the funeral of his wife Barbara Bush. Bush, who suffers from Parkinson's disease and is wheelchair-bound, will remain at the hospital for observation for a few days. This is his latest hospitalization, following previous instances in recent years.

images.alt_text: A little more than three weeks after he was released from hospital, former US president George H. W. Bush was re-admitted on Sunday with low blood pressure and fatigue, his spokesman said.

site_title: Gold bulls puzzled why metal hasn't performed amid tensions
summary: Gold prices have failed to perform amid rising tensions, with experts attributing this to the stronger US dollar and rising US Treasury bond yields. The US dollar's strength has historically weakened gold, and the rising yields have underpinned the dollar, contributing to gold's disappointing performance. Despite geopolitical uncertainty and a surging oil price, physical demand from emerging markets such as China and India remains strong, and central banks continue to diversify their reserves by buying gold. Experts predict that gold demand will increase in the long run, driven by economic growth and wealth creation in massive population nations.

site_title: Mencast looks to free up space, raise cash
summary: Mencast, an offshore and marine (O&M) business, is undergoing a transformation to free up space, raise cash, and improve its sustainability. CEO Glenndle Sim is leveraging digital twin technology to optimize operations, reduce inventory storage, and divest existing properties. This will generate cash to pare down bank loans. The company has also seen increased customer orders, including a $5.6 million contract with Penguin International, despite the sector's downturn. By adopting long-term customer focus, collaborative work style, and continual innovation, Mencast aims to emerge stronger and beat the odds.

site_title: EMS Energy inks non-binding agreement with new investor Qian Investment Holding
summary: EMS Energy Limited has entered into a non-binding agreement with Qian Investment Holding to allot and issue 5 billion new shares at 0.15 Singapore cents or S$7.5 million. The deal includes the acquisition of Qian Investment's international sales and marketing of lubricant additives business. Following the completion, EMS Energy plans to undertake a rights issue of up to 6.173 billion new shares and issue up to 1.65 billion new shares to Alternative Advisors Pte Ltd. Qian Investment is expected to hold a 70% stake in EMS Energy after the transactions.

site_title: Italy plunges into political crisis after government talks collapse
summary: Italy is plunged into a political crisis after Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte gave up his bid to form a government following talks with President Sergio Mattarella collapsing over the inclusion of an eurosceptic economy minister. Conte, a lawyer and novice politician, had been tasked with forming a coalition government with the Five Star Movement and far-right League. With the talks ending in failure, Conte has stepped aside, leaving Italy with a temporary technical government and the strong possibility of new elections in the autumn.

site_title: Malaysian playboy financier Jho Low in cross-hairs after poll upset
summary: Malaysian financier Jho Low, a key figure in the 1MDB mega-scandal, is under threat of being brought to justice by the new government. The new administration, led by Mahathir Mohamad, has reopened probes into the sophisticated fraud and vowed to arrest Low, who allegedly stole huge sums from the fund. Low, 36, has been linked to celebrities and spent vast sums on luxury items, but denies any wrongdoing. The new government's move aims to pressure Low, who is currently unclear whereabouts, and recover the allegedly stolen funds.

site_title: Trump sees 'brilliant potential' for North Korea as summit prep continues
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed "brilliant potential" for North Korea as summit preparations continue, despite a recent cancellation. Trump's change of heart followed a flurry of diplomacy led by South Korea, which appears to have put the June 12 summit back on track. The US and North Korean officials met at a border truce village, with the US delegation led by Sung Kim, and analysts are increasingly confident that the historic meeting will take place. However, differences in expectations between the US and North Korea remain, with the US seeking North Korea's nuclear disarmament in exchange for sanctions relief.

site_title: Director acquisitions surge; buyback momentum continues
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) has generated a 5.5% total return for the 2018 year through May 24, outperforming regional benchmarks. Dividend distributions contributed to the STI's lead. Share buybacks continued, totaling S$41.1 million, with CapitaLand leading the tally. Director and substantial shareholder transactions also increased, with notable acquisitions by Yanlord Perennial Investment, Best World International, and Sino Grandness Food Industry Group. These transactions highlight the ongoing momentum in the Singaporean stock market.

site_title: China's April industrial profit growth rebounds to 6-month high
summary: China's industrial profits rose 21.9% year-over-year in April, the fastest pace in six months, driven by higher prices and strong demand. The rebound was led by the steel, chemicals, and automobile industries. Despite concerns about slowing momentum, the data suggests China's industrial sector remains solidly growing. However, profit growth has softened from last year's strong pace, and debt growth for Chinese companies has slowed to the lowest rate in over a decade, with profit margins squeezed to their lowest level in two years.

site_title: Qualcomm to meet China regulators to clear US$44b NXP deal
summary: Qualcomm is set to meet with Chinese regulators in Beijing to finalize the clearance for its US$44 billion acquisition of NXP Semiconductors. The deal has received approval from eight global regulators, with Chinese clearance the only remaining hurdle. Approval would depend on the progress of broader US-China trade talks. The acquisition has been impacted by rising tensions between the two countries.

site_title: Hold your breath for jam-packed week ahead
summary: US Treasury Secretary's "trade war with China is on hold" statement contradicts President Trump's dissatisfaction with bilateral talks. Trump cancels planned North Korea summit, calling it a "geopolitical bombshell." US imposes 50% copper import tariff, causing market fluctuations. Global risk is on the rise, with investors weighing market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions.

site_title: Bringing home Africa's plundered art
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron has pledged to return African artefacts to their countries of origin within five years, sparking speculation that European museums may be pressured to follow suit. The move comes as hundreds of thousands of colonial-era items are held in European museums, many of which were plundered by French troops and other colonial powers. African officials and heritage experts say the objects should be returned to their rightful owners, boosting national pride and attracting tourists. The initiative has raised hopes that European curators may be forced to re-examine their collections and consider restitution.

site_title: Boeing sends troubleshooter to Rolls-Royce amid 787 woes
summary: Boeing has sent a troubleshooter, Keith Leverkuhn, to Rolls-Royce to address engine problems affecting 787 Dreamliners, grounding around 34 planes. The issue, related to potential cracking of Trent 1000 engine blades, could worsen as more planes are re-routed for inspections. Boeing aims to minimize disruption to airline customers ahead of the summer travel season. The company is working closely with Rolls to retrofit the affected engines, which could take four years to complete.

site_title: Qatar bans goods from 4 states as embargo anniversary approaches
summary: Qatar has banned products originating from the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, and Bahrain, effective immediately, due to an impending embargo anniversary. The ban aims to protect consumer safety and combat improper trafficking of goods. Qatar, which had previously relied on imports from the four countries, has since found new suppliers and developed alternative shipping routes. The ban is the latest move in the ongoing diplomatic row between Qatar and its neighboring states, which imposed an embargo on Qatar in June 2017.

site_title: Prudential Singapore to pay at least S$2.2m to all customers hit by wrong GIRO deductions
summary: Prudential Singapore is paying at least S$2.2 million to 22,000 customers affected by incorrect GIRO deductions, which occurred due to a "technical glitch" that caused deductions to be 100 times the actual premiums. The insurer will credit S$100 to each customer's account and refund the excess amount. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched an investigation into the incident and will take follow-up supervisory measures if necessary. Prudential Singapore has apologized for the inconvenience and anxiety caused by the error.

site_title: Moon steps in when Trump and Kim fall out
summary: US President Donald Trump abruptly cancelled a planned summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, prompting South Korean President Moon Jae-in to intervene and secure a meeting between the two leaders. The summit's cancellation was followed by a series of diplomatic efforts, including the restart of inter-Korean talks and a Red Cross meeting to reunite families separated by the war. Moon's actions have allowed him to maintain his role as a neutral middleman, but may make it harder for Trump to enforce his "maximum pressure" campaign if talks break down again.

images.alt_text: Mr Moon's (right) surprise meeting with Mr Kim on Saturday shows he's willing to do what it takes to keep diplomacy on track and avoid a return to threats of war over North Korea's nuclear programme.

site_title: Prudential to pay S$100 to all customers whose GIRO deduction fell on May 24
summary: Prudential Singapore is paying S$100 to customers whose GIRO deduction date for monthly insurance premiums fell on May 24 due to an error. This includes customers not affected by the issue. The payment is a result of the bank's efforts to rectify the mistake and provide compensation to those impacted.

images.alt_text: Prudential Singapore on Saturday said it would pay S$100 to every customer whose GIRO deduction date for their monthly insurance premiums fell on Thursday.

site_title: Acra looking into Mazars' role in Midas auditing
summary: Singapore's Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) is investigating Mazars' role in auditing scandal-hit Midas Holdings. Mazars said its auditors' reports for 2012-2016 can no longer be relied upon due to the company's financial misrepresentations. Midas, a Chinese railway parts maker, is being investigated in Singapore and China for fraud. The investigation follows the discovery of significant cash discrepancies, with Midas' cash holdings now standing at S$700,000 compared to the one billion yuan reflected in its audited results for 2016.

site_title: Alexa, No! Amazon explains how an Echo shared a couple's private conversation
summary: A woman in Portland, Oregon, reported that her Amazon Echo device shared her private conversation with her husband's employee, despite having the volume set to 7/10. Amazon stated that the device mistakenly heard a series of requests to send the recording, which it interpreted as a "send message" request. The family disconnected the device and contacted Amazon, prompting an investigation. The incident highlights concerns over digital assistants' ability to share private conversations without consent.

site_title: Scares ahead in global trade and markets, but little danger of zombie apocalypse
summary: Stock markets experienced slight declines last week due to ongoing tensions between the US, North Korea, and China, but a rebound is expected as negotiations between the parties gain momentum. US President Donald Trump's recent comments on trade and tariffs have added to market volatility, but experts believe a major trade war is unlikely, likening it to a "zombie apocalypse." Meanwhile, oil prices have plummeted, and emerging markets are experiencing currency fluctuations, but economists expect the US economy to continue growing, particularly in the second quarter.

site_title: Malaysian playboy financier in cross-hairs after poll upset
summary: Malaysian financier Jho Low, at the center of the 1MDB mega-scandal, may face justice under the new government, which has vowed to bring him to justice. Low, a 36-year-old playboy, is suspected of being a key figure in the scandal and has led a high-rolling lifestyle, spending millions on luxury items and gifts to celebrities. The new government has reopened probes into the sophisticated fraud, and tax authorities have been instructed to probe Low and his family. Low has denied any wrongdoing, but Abdul Razak Idris, a former senior officer, believes he is the mastermind and should be arrested and brought back to Malaysia to face justice.

site_title: CareShield Life to replace ElderShield in 2020
summary: Singapore will launch CareShield Life, a national long-term care insurance scheme, in 2020, replacing ElderShield for people aged 30-40. The scheme offers wider coverage and will be compulsory, with premiums starting at S$206 for men and S$253 for women. Payouts of at least S$600 a month will be provided for care needs, with potential increases in future years. The government aims to ensure affordability through Medisave and permanent premium subsidies. The scheme is part of Singapore's efforts to address its ageing population.

images.alt_text: Salma Khalik

site_title: US dollar ends week stronger against peers
summary: The US dollar rose 0.44% against a basket of peers, its strongest level since mid-November, due to a slump in oil prices and concerns over the euro. The dollar index was up 0.6% for the week. Oil prices fell $2 on Friday as Saudi Arabia and Russia discussed easing supply curbs. The euro weakened, with investors selling Italian assets due to rising bond yields and political instability in Spain. Sterling traded near a five-month low due to Brexit worries.

site_title: Qualcomm executives to get severance if they're fired after sale
summary: Qualcomm's top executives will be eligible to receive severance payments if they're fired after a change in control, reversing a previous policy. Executives will receive 1.5 times their salary and bonus, plus health benefits for a period, and any unvested equity awards. The policy aims to ensure continued dedication of top executives, mirroring a plan adopted for lower-ranking employees during a hostile takeover attempt. This move aims to deter potential acquirers from making sweeping changes.

site_title: Gold price actions showing signs of indecision in market
summary: Gold prices show signs of indecision, breaking below the key support level at US$1,300 due to the recent strength in the US dollar index. However, the lack of bearish follow-through suggests a possible false breakout scenario. After consolidating within a US$12 range, gold broke below a crucial uptrend line on May 21, but bulls defended the line and formed a bullish hammer, indicating a possible reversal higher. This price action mirrors the 2017 false bearish breakout scenario, and gold is expected to re-target the US$1,350-US$1,365 resistance area next.

site_title: New blockchain kid on Brooklyn block
summary: A Brooklyn-based company, Meridio, is experimenting with blockchain technology to transform the New York housing market. The company has partnered with a building owner to introduce cryptocurrency tokens and a secure database, allowing for efficient and secure online transactions. While proponents claim it can reduce fraud and increase accessibility, critics argue that the technology is still in its early stages and lacks regulation, potentially leading to volatility and gentrification. The experiment aims to make real estate investments more accessible to a broader pool of people, but its impact remains uncertain.

site_title: Startup of UAE's nuclear reactor to be delayed
summary: The startup of the UAE's Barakah Nuclear Energy Plant has been delayed, with operations expected to begin between the end of 2019 and early 2020. The plant, valued at $24.4 billion, is the world's largest nuclear project under construction and will be the first in the Arab world. A training delay and necessary regulatory approvals were cited as reasons for the delay, with the first of four reactors expected to start operations in the UAE, marking the country's first nuclear power acquisition in over two decades.

site_title: US warships sail near South China Sea islands claimed by Beijing
summary: US warships sailed near South China Sea islands claimed by China on Sunday, in a move likely to anger Beijing amid strained US-China ties. The operation, planned months in advance, involved a guided-missile destroyer and a guided-missile cruiser, which came within 12 nautical miles of the Paracel Islands. The US aims to counter China's efforts to limit freedom of navigation in the strategic waters, amid a trade dispute between the world's two largest economies.

site_title: Singapore start-ups look to a changing France for growth
summary: Singapore start-ups are looking to France as a potential hub for growth and partnerships, drawn by the country's efforts to boost its tech ecosystem under President Emmanuel Macron's agenda. The French government has established a 10 billion euro fund to finance innovation and research, and Station F, the world's largest start-up incubator, is a key private effort to boost the ecosystem. About 20-25% of start-ups at Station F come from outside France, including Singapore, and the country is attracting interest from traditional French corporates. Several Singapore companies, including healthcare tech startup Jaga-Me and robotics and AI start-up H3 Dynamics, are exploring opportunities in France, citing the country's strong aerospace engineering ecosystem and business links with Singapore.

images.alt_text: Homegrown robotics and AI start-up H3 Dynamics is keen on opportunities in France. Seen here are founder and chief executive officer Taras Wankewycz (front), who is French, with his colleagues.

Matralix is a Singaporean start-up looking to break into the French market. From left: Loke Siew Keong, head of manufacturing; Soo Kit Ying, head of quality and automation; Saif A Khan, CTO; and Renuga Gopal, CEO.

site_title: Daimler in talks with German authorities over diesel issues
summary: Daimler is in talks with German authorities over potential emissions irregularities in Mercedes-Benz cars, with the possibility of recalling over 600,000 diesel vehicles due to illegal engine setups. The luxury carmaker denies the allegations, stating it is cooperating with the regulator. The investigation is part of a broader global scrutiny following Volkswagen's emissions-cheating scandal, with Daimler facing ongoing investigations by German and US authorities.

site_title: ECB board race countdown prompts diversity call to Euro members
summary: European Central Bank Executive Board member Benoit Coeure is calling for greater diversity among the institution's leaders, particularly women, to improve public trust. Currently, only one of the six policy makers on the Executive Board is female, and only two women are members of the Governing Council. Coeure's comments come as euro-region leaders prepare to appoint successors to President Mario Draghi, with opportunities to increase female representation in the coming year.

images.alt_text: Mr Coeure's intervention, 18 months before a successor to Draghi takes office, adds the institution's voice to a call for diversity in its top echelon.

site_title: Iran sanctions cast pall over smaller German banks
summary: Germany's smaller banks are taking advantage of the nuclear deal with Iran, which was rejected by Donald Trump, to do business with the country. Despite looming US sanctions, some firms, such as the KCI, are continuing to serve clients in Iran. German exports to Iran have grown to almost 2.6 billion euros last year, but are still a fraction of the country's exports to the US. The KCI will wait and see how sanctions develop before turning away from Iran, while larger banks like Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank avoid the country due to past penalties.

site_title: Apple sees steep increase in US national security requests
summary: Apple's transparency report reveals a 20% increase in US national security-related requests in the second half of 2017, reaching 16,249 requests affecting 8,249 accounts. This represents a 2.5 times increase from the comparable period in 2016. The report also shows a 36% rise in national security requests at Google and a near doubling of such requests at Facebook. Apple will now report app takedown requests from governments starting July 1.

site_title: DBS to partner Carousell to build startup's mobile wallet CarouPay
summary: DBS Bank, Singapore's largest bank, is partnering with online classifieds platform Carousell to build and implement CarouPay, a mobile wallet within the Carousell app. The integrated payment system will allow buyers to make payments without using third-party fund transfer platforms or meet-ups. CarouPay is set to launch in June and will initially be used only within the Carousell platform, with plans to expand in the future. The partnership aims to make the checkout process more seamless and provide convenience and assurance for users.

site_title: Starbucks' bid to curb racism draws support and scepticism
summary: Starbucks will close over 8,000 US stores on Tuesday for an unprecedented four-hour training exercise aimed at curbing racism. The move comes after the arrest of two black men at a Philadelphia Starbucks store, sparking outrage and protests. The training will focus on understanding racial bias and the history of public accommodations in the US, with future sessions addressing all aspects of bias and experiences. While some welcome the initiative, others express skepticism, with some experts questioning whether it will lead to lasting change.

site_title: Tesla seeks to dismiss securities fraud lawsuit
summary: Tesla has asked a court to dismiss a securities fraud lawsuit by shareholders who claim the company gave false public statements about the progress of its Model 3 sedan. The lawsuit, filed last October, seeks class action status for shareholders who bought Tesla stock between 2016 and 2017. Tesla claims its statements about production challenges were "frank and in plain language," including repeated disclosures by CEO Elon Musk. A hearing is scheduled for August.

site_title: Kylie Minogue turns 50 and the world still can't get her out of its head
summary: Kylie Minogue turns 50, celebrating a three-decade career marked by 80 million record sales, surviving breast cancer, and becoming a gay icon. Born in Melbourne in 1968, she rose to fame as a teenager on the soap opera Neighbours and went on to become one of Australia's biggest cultural exports and an international sex symbol. With a career spanning hits like "I Should Be So Lucky" and "Can't Get You Out Of My Head," Minogue has defied critics and established herself as a star and ambassador for universal love.

site_title: Beyond paper credentials
summary: Business leaders from various industries share their views on ditching academic qualifications as an indicator of cognitive ability and potential in hiring executive staff. Most agree that academic credentials are not the only factor, and that other qualities such as attitude, experience, skills, and soft skills are equally important. Some companies, like Qian Hu Corporation and Ernst & Young, use a combination of academic credentials and experiences to assess potential hires. Others, like Terrific Mentors International and Singapore International Chamber of Commerce, focus on competency-based recruitment, valuing character, values, and potential over academic qualifications.

site_title: Audi CEO says diesel crisis not over and vows to stay on - report
summary: Audi CEO Rupert Stadler stated that the diesel emissions crisis is not over, despite previous recalls. He assured that he would remain at the helm, saying he feels responsibility for solving the issue. Stadler also mentioned the possibility of further vehicle recalls and told regulators about ongoing issues. The comments came after Audi discovered emissions problems in an additional 60,000 cars, dealing a fresh blow to parent company Volkswagen.

site_title: Disney slashes forecast for "Solo" as early ticket sales sag
summary: Disney lowered its opening-weekend forecast for "Solo: A Star Wars Story" to $105-115 million, down from a previous estimate of $150 million. Early ticket sales are disappointing, with US$11.4 million from 43 international markets and an estimated $10 million in China. The movie's poor performance signals a weak public response, particularly considering its estimated budget of over $250 million and marketing costs. This marks a sharp cut from Disney's strong box office performance so far this year, led by Marvel films like "Black Panther" and "Avengers".

site_title: Under pressure from Trump, Saudis put brakes on oil's rally
summary: Saudi Arabia, under pressure from US President Donald Trump, has shifted its policy stance on oil prices, indicating a potential increase in production to boost supply and curb the rally. The move comes after Trump criticized OPEC for artificially high prices, sparking a diplomatic wrangle with other OPEC members. The change in policy has led to a decline in oil prices, with crude falling below $67 a barrel. OPEC officials are set to meet on June 22 to hammer out a deal, with possible output increases ranging from 300,000 to 800,000 barrels a day.

images.alt_text: The world's largest oil exporter just made quite a policy swerve. Within six weeks, Saudi Arabia has gone from advocating higher prices to trying to stop the rally at US$80 a barrel.

site_title: Daimler 'facing scrutiny over 120,000 Vito, C-Class diesel vehicles'
summary: Daimler faces an investigation over 120,000 diesel Vito vans and 80,000 C-Class cars for possible illicit software that allowed vehicles to emit excess pollution. The company has submitted a software update for regulatory approval. A recall order for 6,300 Vito vans has been issued by the German motor authority KBA, with Daimler planning to appeal the decision. German transport minister Andreas Scheuer is set to meet with Daimler CEO Dieter Zetsche to discuss the issue. Daimler faces a broader recall order for over 600,000 diesel-engine vehicles, following Volkswagen's 2015 emissions cheating scandal.

site_title: Oil drop below US$80 vindicates cautious investors trimming bets
summary: Oil prices fell below $80 a barrel, vindicating cautious investors who trimmed their bets. Hedge funds reduced their net-long position in Brent crude by 8.6% in the week ended May 22, the largest decline since June 2017. The drop followed comments from Saudi and Russian energy ministers suggesting that OPEC and its allies may boost oil output in the second half of the year to alleviate consumer anxiety about higher prices.

site_title: Suzhou court rules in favour of AEM Holdings' subsidiary
summary: AEM Holdings' subsidiary, AEM Microtronics (Suzhou) Co (AMSZ), has won two legal cases in favor of the company. AMSZ was formed after AEM Holdings divested its plating business to Yunyi Electric Co for 6.63 million yuan. AMSZ was established to take over the non-plating business of AEM (Suzhou) Co (ASZ), and the court has ruled that ASZ will bear the costs of the suits, totaling one million yuan for non-payment of property and 2.7 million yuan in salaries and purchases.

site_title: Cheap pork means more ribs on US grills as meat output expands
summary: A record US hog herd has led to a surge in pork supply, resulting in cheap prices and increased meat output. Wholesale pork prices have fallen 18% and ribs have dropped 10% from last year, making it a buyer's market. Hedge funds are taking notice, with a net-short position of 10,053 contracts, the most bearish since 2013. Despite this, consumer demand for pork remains strong, particularly for summer favorites like ribs and chops, with nearly three-quarters of American grill owners firing up their grills on Memorial Day.

site_title: Valuetronics posts higher profit of HK$204.73 million for FY2018
summary: Valuetronics reported a 25.4% year-over-year increase in revenue to HK$2.85 billion for FY2018, driven by higher revenue from industrial and consumer electronics segments. The company's net profit rose 33% to HK$204.73 million, with gross profit increasing 21.3% to HK$414.6 million. Despite operating in a challenging macroeconomic environment, Valuetronics expects to remain profitable in FY2019. The board recommended a final dividend of 15 HK cents per share and a special dividend of five HK cents per share for FY2018.

site_title: South Korea welcomes prospect of 'reignited' US-North Korea talks
summary: South Korea has welcomed the renewed prospect of a US-North Korea summit, following President Trump's cancellation and subsequent suggestion that the talks may still take place. The summit, originally scheduled for June 12, aims to achieve full denuclearization of North Korea. South Korean President Moon Jae In had scrambled his national security team after Trump's initial cancellation, but the US president later indicated the meeting could still happen. The development has been seen as a positive step in calming tensions on the Korean Peninsula.

images.alt_text: South Korea on Saturday welcomed the renewed prospect of a summit between the United States and North Korea after President Trump cancelled talks with Kim Jong Un only to suggest they might still take place.

site_title: Indonesian tycoon buys 2 Bt Pasoh shophouses
summary: Indonesian tycoon Prajogo Pangestu's family office has purchased two adjoining freehold shophouses in Teo Hong Road, Bukit Pasoh Conservation Area, for nearly S$22 million. The properties are near Outram MRT Station. One of the shophouses was sold by Lim Chun Shuang, son of Lim Hock San, president and CEO of United Industrial Corporation. The deal marks a significant investment in Singapore's prime property market.

site_title: Lagarde says protectionism Is darkest cloud over world economy
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde warns that protectionism is the "darkest cloud" over the global economy, despite a solid upswing. The threat of trade protectionism poses a significant concern, as it could disrupt decades of trade relationships. Lagarde expressed optimism about the global economy, citing a decade of difficult times followed by a current economic boom.

site_title: Beyond paper credentials
summary: Many experts believe that academic qualifications are not the sole indicator of cognitive ability and potential in a candidate. Instead, employers should consider a combination of skills, experiences, and personal qualities. Some companies, like Singapore International Chamber of Commerce, focus on competency-based recruitment, assessing character, values, and skills rather than academic credentials. Others, like FairPrice, prioritize experience, track record, and a "can do" attitude. Experts emphasize the importance of EQ (emotional intelligence) over IQ (intelligence quotient), and some companies, like P&G, evaluate candidates on emotional intelligence and learning agility.

site_title: Singapore's 3rd derivatives exchange kicks off trading with palm oil futures
summary: Singapore's Asia Pacific Exchange (Apex) launched its third derivatives exchange, starting trading of US dollar-denominated palm oil futures. The exchange aims to provide an alternative to benchmark ringgit-denominated contracts, targeting Chinese buyers and South-east Asian sellers. The contracts, which opened at US$635 a tonne, showed initial interest, but its sustainability remains to be seen. Apex plans to offer other futures and options on various commodities and financial instruments, complementing existing exchanges in the region.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange's latest report provides insights into the tanker and dry bulk market, with rates firming in the Mediterranean and Black Sea. VLCC rates increased to around WS 47.5 for 270,000mt to China, while Suezmax rates reached WS 97.5 for 135,000mt from Black Sea to Mediterranean. Aframax rates also gained 25 points to WS 145 for 80,000mt, with Panamax rates remaining steady at WS 105 for 55,000mt. The LR2 market for 75,000mt from ME Gulf to Japan has gained 7.5 points to WS 90s. In contrast, Capesize rates eased across the board due to the lack of Brazil cargo, with owners preferring to stay in the East.

site_title: Kushner Cos exits Philadelphia with sale of property stake
summary: Kushner Cos has sold its Philadelphia property stake, Schmidt's Commons, to Post Brothers for $44.1 million. The 10-building complex, featuring 500 rental apartments and 130,000 square feet of retail space, was acquired by Kushner Cos and Oaktree Capital Management in 2013. Post Brothers will manage the property, which includes a party-ready courtyard and plans to upgrade amenities and attract a more mature tenant base. The sale marks Kushner Cos' exit from Philadelphia, with Oaktree's stake remaining unchanged.

site_title: EU privacy law enters into force, activist takes aim
summary: The European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) went into effect on May 25, 2018, requiring companies to handle customer data more attentively. Major US media outlets were forced to shut down their websites in parts of Europe due to GDPR. A privacy activist, Max Schrems, filed complaints against US tech giants for allegedly acting illegally by forcing users to accept intrusive terms of service. The GDPR imposes fines of up to 4% of global revenue or 20 million euros for breaking privacy laws, and regulators signaled they would enforce the new rules.

site_title: Trump says China's ZTE to pay US$1.3b fine to re-open
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a deal allowing Chinese telecommunications company ZTE Corp to remain in business after paying a $1.3 billion fine, with conditions including hiring American compliance officers and providing "high-level security guarantees." The decision comes as the US and China engage in high-stakes talks on steel trade and intellectual property rights, and may ease tensions between the White House and Congress over trade policy.

site_title: Xiaomi said to seek June 7 listing hearing for US$10b IPO
summary: Xiaomi is set to seek formal Hong Kong stock exchange approval on June 7 for a potential $10 billion initial public offering (IPO). The company aims to price the share sale late next month if its application is approved, with a potential valuation of $60-70 billion. This would make it one of the largest first-time share sales since 2014, minting dozens of new millionaires from early employees. The IPO is part of Xiaomi's expansion plans, including opening its first store in Paris and planning more shops in Europe.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi, led by serial entrepreneur Lei Jun, is one of the most anticipated deals in what's expected to be a banner year for Hong Kong IPOs.

site_title: Energy pathfinder
summary: Engie CEO Isabelle Kocher emphasizes the importance of defining a company's purpose and selecting the right leaders in driving transformation. Under her leadership, the French energy firm has successfully completed an ambitious transformation plan, exceeding expectations. Kocher notes that this transformation does not mark the end of change for the company, as she looks to continue driving growth and innovation.

site_title: Q & A with Ernie Els
summary: Ernie Els recently opened his latest golf course, Royal Green Golf & Country Club, in Saudi Arabia. The four-time Major winner shares insights on what it takes to win at the US and British Open. Els emphasizes the importance of mental preparation and strategy in golf, stating that a strong mental game is just as crucial as physical skills. He also notes that the US Open and British Open courses require different approaches, with the former demanding a more aggressive strategy and the latter requiring a more strategic and precise approach.

site_title: Platinum hedge fund co-founder pleads guilty in corruption case
summary: Platinum Partners co-founder Murray Huberfeld pleaded guilty to a criminal conspiracy charge six months after a mistrial in a corruption case. He agreed to a 6- to 12-month prison term and did not require cooperation with prosecutors in their case against former labour leader Norman Seabrook, who faces a retrial. The plea followed allegations that Huberfeld paid a $60,000 kickback to Seabrook in exchange for steering union money to invest with Platinum. Huberfeld's guilty plea resolves a major corruption case involving the hedge fund and its founder.

site_title: Golf quartet receive Asian Games boost
summary: Singapore's golf team received a boost for the Asian Games with two nominees scoring regional triumphs. The victories have increased the country's chances of participating in the men's golf event at the Asian Games.

site_title: Jury asks judge to slap cancer warning on baby powder
summary: A California jury awarded $4 million in punitive damages to a 68-year-old woman who claimed her mesothelioma was caused by asbestos in Johnson & Johnson's baby powder. The jury also found J&J 67% responsible for her cancer. The jurors asked the judge if they could force the company to warn consumers about the potential asbestos contamination, but the judge said it was not a remedy that could be ordered. J&J plans to appeal the verdict, which is part of thousands of lawsuits alleging the company's talc products are connected to cancer.

images.alt_text: A California jury weighing J&J's punishment over its handling of its iconic baby powder asked a judge May 24 if they could force the company to warn consumers that its Johnson's Baby Powder could be contaminated with asbestos, according to the law firm that won the case against the health-care giant.

site_title: Indonesian tycoon buys 2 Singapore Bukit Pasoh shophouses
summary: Indonesian tycoon Prajogo Pangestu's family office has purchased two adjoining freehold shophouses in Singapore's Bukit Pasoh Conservation Area for nearly S$22 million. The properties, spanning 11,000 sq ft, will be refurbished and rented out as offices with F&B on the ground floor. The deal was brokered by JLL, and renovations are expected to begin around year-end. The purchase is part of ANB Investment's expansion in Singapore, which also owns four three-storey shophouses at Amoy Street and a 30,000 sq ft residential building near Newton MRT Station.

site_title: Singapore-listed Malaysian healthcare group IHH Healthcare's Q1 profit falls 88%
summary: IHH Healthcare, a Malaysian healthcare group, reported a 88% drop in Q1 profit to RM57.24 million due to one-off gains and higher depreciation costs. Revenue increased 6% to RM2.85 billion, driven by organic growth and new hospitals in Hong Kong and Turkey. The group is confident in future growth, citing the performance of Gleneagles Hong Kong and upcoming hospital openings. IHH extended its offer to Fortis Healthcare's board until June 30, seeking a 40 billion rupee investment.

site_title: US: S&P, Dow fall as oil drop hurts energy; chipmakers boost Nasdaq
summary: US stocks fell on Friday, with the S&P 500 and Dow easing after oil prices dropped 4% to their lowest since 2014. The decline in energy stocks was offset by gains in chipmakers and retail stocks. The Nasdaq Composite rose 0.13%, driven by Broadcom and Intel's 2.7% and 1.3% gains, respectively. Despite the losses, the Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq posted weekly gains, with the Nasdaq up 1.1%.

images.alt_text: Stock markets this week also have been roiled by trade tensions with China, a US threat of imposing tariffs on imported cars and uncertainty over a US-North Korea summit.

site_title: Hyflux woes not a sign that loans to power companies are riskier: Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service says Hyflux's restructuring is credit-negative but not indicative of riskier bank exposures to Singapore power generation firms. The company is seeking court protection to restructure its S$1.5 billion in debt and skip a coupon on its S$500 million perpetual securities. Moody's notes that most large power generation companies in Singapore have strong shareholders with diversified portfolios, and their debt loads are more manageable. The agency also suggests that some banks, such as DBS and Maybank, may suffer losses on their Hyflux exposures, but their exposure is largely secured.

site_title: Tried & Tested
summary: Laguna Golf Bintan is offering limited-time annual full golf memberships for S$695 (down from S$1,500), providing a discounted rate for golf enthusiasts.

site_title: Bayer's Monsanto takeover less lucrative than expected
summary: Bayer's planned takeover of Monsanto is expected to yield $1.2 billion in annual savings from 2022, lower than the initially predicted $1.5 billion. The deal's savings are reduced due to the loss of overlapping activities in seeds and pesticides, worth 7.6 billion euros, to rival BASF. Bayer needs to find 44 billion euros in new funding to complete the $62.5-billion acquisition, which may lead to increased debt. The merger still faces approval from the US Department of Justice before a June 14 deadline.

images.alt_text: Bayer has been forced by competition authorities including the European Commission to sacrifice existing activities in seeds and pesticides worth 7.6 billion euros (S$11.9 billion) to home-grown rival BASF in exchange for approval of the Monsanto deal.

site_title: Japan's Nomura, Line seal agreement for net-based securities brokerage
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc and Line Corp have agreed to set up an internet-focused securities brokerage, Line Securities Corporation, with Nomura owning 49% and Line holding 51%. The venture aims to leverage Line's 75 million monthly active users to recruit a younger generation of clients. The companies plan to offer brokerage services and investment advice through the messaging platform, with an initial capital of 10 billion yen. The joint venture is part of Nomura's efforts to tap a new generation of customers as its client base ages.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Trek 2000 chairman Henn Tan has stepped down and will serve as consultant for three years. First Ship Lease Trust raised US$7 million from convertible bonds, repaying US$10 million of its loan. SBI Offshore has appointed KordaMentha for an audit into a 3.63 million yuan write-off. Meanwhile, US copper import tariffs may cover refined metal, causing market fluctuations.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Keppel Corp's revised launch schedules in China have led to a 8-14% decrease in earnings for 2018-19, but will lift earnings by 30% in 2020. The company's Vietnamese property market is expected to offset weakness in China. Meanwhile, Bukit Sembawang Estates reported a 66% increase in FY18 net profit, driven by a higher profit margin, and has a good mix of projects to ride the recovering housing market. Analysts maintain a BUY recommendation for both companies.

site_title: Leonie Gardens goes en bloc with S$800m reserve price
summary: Leonie Gardens, a 99-year leasehold condo in Singapore, is going en bloc with a reserve price of S$800 million. The site has 71 years remaining on its lease and can be developed into around 544 condominium units. A 10% balcony space can be added, increasing the area, but a development charge of S$44 million will be levied. This follows another en bloc sale by Lakeside Apartments, which has a reserve price of S$240 million.

site_title: With recipes, the key to making millions is not about the food
summary: A recipe's value lies not in its ingredients or techniques, but in its reputation and brand. Chefs and food companies can attempt to monetize recipes through trademarks, patents, and litigation, but these methods have limitations. In the US, most recipes are not protected by copyright due to their utilitarian nature. However, trademarks and patents can be used to protect brand identities and unique formulations. Successful recipes often rely on their reputation, marketing, and the value of the brand behind them, rather than the recipe itself.

site_title: Metro's Q4 bottom line turns red due to losses from associates
summary: Metro Holdings posted a Q4 net loss of S$1.9 million due to losses from associates, reversing the net profit of S$34.2 million from the same period last year. Revenue rose 1.8% to S$34.3 million, while gross profit fell 18.5% to S$2.3 million. The group's share of associate results was hurt by a fall in Top Spring International Holdings' results, resulting in a loss of S$24.3 million. Despite this, the full-year net profit jumped 93.9% to S$156 million, driven by a divestment gain of S$159 million.

site_title: April factory output surge stumps economists
