summary: Singapore's factory output surged in April, defying expectations of a slowdown. Despite electronics exports contracting, the sector's momentum continued, driven by expanding electronics production. Economists still anticipate a easing of growth pace in the coming quarters due to moderating global semiconductor demand and a high base from last year.

site_title: Over RM114 million in cash, 400-plus luxury bags seized in 1MDB probe
summary: Malaysian police seized RM114 million in cash and over 400 luxury handbags from several properties linked to former Prime Minister Najib Razak as part of an anti-graft probe into the 1MDB fund. Najib's home, apartments of his son and daughter, and an empty apartment were searched. The cash was found in 26 currencies, with the largest amounts in ringgit and Singapore dollars. Experts are valuing the seized luxury items, including jewelry and watches. The new government has pledged to honour all payments on debt arising from 1MDB, estimated to be RM38 billion.

site_title: Wire-to-wire victory
summary: Thailand's Varanyu Rattanaphiboonkij won his first professional golf tournament, the Singha Laguna Phuket Open, with a wire-to-wire victory. He finished with an even-par 70 in the final round, securing a six-shot win. Rattanaphiboonkij achieved his first professional victory in front of his family, marking a significant milestone in his career.

site_title: How to take stock of a hotel's value?
summary: Hotel investors should focus on income and not price appreciation, as traditional metrics like price-to-earnings ratio can be misleading due to the business's high capital intensity. Hotels generate low asset turnover, with a median of 0.2, but can be profitable when rooms are rented out. The median return on equity is 5%, and the enterprise multiple (EV/EBITDA) provides a more accurate valuation at 19. Investing in hotels can be an income play, with the current price-to-book ratio at 1.4, and investors may be paying S$100 for around S$3.30 of free cash flow.

site_title: Geopolitics, trade fears drag STI 0.5% lower for the week
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 0.44% to 3,513.23, marking its second consecutive weekly decline, due to geopolitical tensions and trade fears. The US-North Korea summit's cancellation and President Trump's threat of high US tariffs on imported cars contributed to the market's downturn. Despite robust factory output and business receipts, concerns over protectionism and structural headwinds stifled economic recovery. Losses were led by Jardine stocks and banking stalwarts, while Top Glove and Creative Technology saw significant gains.

site_title: IHH Healthcare's Q1 profit falls 88% to RM57.24m
summary: IHH Healthcare Berhad's first-quarter profit plummeted 88% to RM57.24 million due to higher depreciation, finance costs, and foreign exchange losses. The absence of a one-off gain from a 2017 divestment of Apollo Hospitals contributed to the decline. The company's profit after tax and minority interests was 40% lower. IHH extended its offer acceptance period for the Fortis board to June 30.

site_title: Midas Holdings under probe by China, HK authorities
summary: Midas Holdings, a Singapore-listed railway-parts maker, is under investigation by Chinese, Hong Kong, and Singapore authorities. Investigations into the scandal-hit company have widened after trading was suspended in February due to litigations, enforcement orders, and court documents. Midas has defaulted on US$1.05 million in interest payment and hired a lawyer in a dispute with its former CEO, who is demanding repayment of nearly S$3.3 million. The company's former executive chairman has also issued a lawyer's letter refuting an announcement stating he was not suitable to continue as an executive director.

site_title: The 'wow' factor at Apple's new campus
summary: Apple's new campus, Apple Park Visitor Center, has opened to the public offering a unique experience. The two-storey, 20,135 sq ft building features a rooftop terrace with stunning views of the campus, including "The Spaceship" headquarters. The visitor center offers an interactive, augmented reality (AR) tour of the campus, allowing visitors to explore Apple Park in 3D. The building also boasts a cafe, retail space, and exclusive merchandise. The design is minimalist and beautiful, showcasing Apple's consistent branding and values.

site_title: Yoma Strategic, Pernod Ricard joint venture eyes Myanmar's whisky industry
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings and Pernod Ricard are forming a joint venture to produce and distribute whisky in Myanmar. Upon completion, Pernod Ricard will become the largest shareholder and bring an internationally experienced management team. The remaining equity will be split among Yoma Strategic, Delta Capital Myanmar, and Win Brothers. This partnership represents Pernod Ricard's first formal presence in Myanmar and will see the company take the lead in managing production facilities, distribution networks, and brand portfolios. Completion is expected in 2019, subject to customary conditions.

site_title: '4G ministers have to work more closely together'
summary: Singapore's 4th-generation ministers must work more closely together due to complex growth strategies involving multiple government agencies. Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations S Iswaran emphasized the need for collaboration, saying it's an evolution rather than a revolutionary process. As issues cut across various ministries, ministers will need to learn to rely on each other's judgment, with Iswaran noting this will be an important part of their evolution. The transition to larger roles and responsibilities should not be hastened, and a natural course should be allowed to unfold.

site_title: Warren golf & country club reaches a milestone
summary: The Warren Golf & Country Club in the US has reached a milestone by completing a decade of staging one of the best amateur tournaments for aspiring youngsters, marking its dedication to providing a platform for young golfers to develop their skills.

site_title: Disrupters don't stand a chance against car companies
summary: Self-driving car technology continues to improve, but its commercial success is hindered by a lack of a viable business model. Despite significant investment, companies like Google and Amazon have struggled to replicate the success of Google Fiber, a high-speed internet service that was initially met with excitement but ultimately failed to turn a profit. In contrast, established car companies like General Motors and Toyota are more likely to succeed in the self-driving car market, as they have the resources and infrastructure to support widespread adoption.

images.alt_text: Robotic arms assembling Tesla's Model S sedans at a factory in Fremont, California. The company has struggled with financing concerns, investor relations and mass-producing vehicles at scale. Tesla, Uber and Lyft are not profitable and have not yet survived an economic downturn.

site_title: For easy playability
summary: Masashi Sannomiya, a 20-year veteran of luxury golf brand Honma, has been promoted to overseas Southeast Asia team manager in the international division. Despite having no official handicap, Sannomiya can consistently shoot in the 80s.

site_title: 22,000 Prudential customers hit by excess GIRO debits
summary: Approximately 22,000 Prudential customers in Singapore were affected by a technical glitch that led to excess deductions of monthly insurance premiums, with some deductions reaching tens of thousands of dollars. The error occurred due to a misplaced decimal point, resulting in GIRO deductions of hundreds of dollars being incorrectly debited from customers' accounts. All transactions were reversed within 24 hours, and the insurer is reimbursing interest and charges incurred. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is investigating the root cause of the incident.

site_title: Frasers Property buys warehouse in the Netherlands for 25m euros
summary: Frasers Property has acquired a 31,600 square meter logistics warehouse in the Netherlands for 25 million euros. The warehouse, located in the industrial estate Noord II, is leased to a dairy industry company on a long-term basis. The acquisition, funded from internal resources, is not expected to impact the group's earnings per share and net tangible asset value. Frasers Property's indirect subsidiary will hold the freehold interest in the property.

site_title: Deutsche Bank job cuts being felt from Britain to Australia
summary: Deutsche Bank is cutting at least 7,000 jobs globally, including 25% of its equities business in London and New York. The bank has already laid off 600 staff since CEO Christian Sewing took over last month, with more job cuts expected in Asia. In the UK, a team of 10 investment bankers focused on emerging markets is being eliminated, and in Australia, corporate finance specialists have been let go. The cuts aim to refocus the bank on Europe and its home market after three consecutive years of losses, with employees awaiting details on the impacted roles.

images.alt_text: Christian Sewing, new CEO of Germany's Deutsche Bank, attends the bank's annual meeting in Frankfurt, Germany, May 24, 2018. Germany's biggest bank is cutting a team of 10 investment bankers in the British capital focused on deals in emerging markets, a person familiar with the matter said on Friday.

site_title: Vivo X21's future-proof fingerprinting
summary: The Vivo X21 is a bezel-less phone featuring a 6.28-inch screen with a 90% screen-to-body ratio. The device boasts a large, bright, and crisp display, making it suitable for movies and games. Notably, the phone's fingerprint scanner is embedded inside the screen, a world-first innovation by Chinese manufacturer Vivo. This feature allows for a more seamless user experience and increased screen real estate.

site_title: Dealing with failure, freezing up and fraud
summary: A leadership expert shares advice on how to handle difficult situations, including dealing with failure, freezing up, and fraud. Key takeaways include: staying calm and thinking clearly, asking for time to consider accusations, and avoiding confrontations. The expert suggests that making an example of someone for a mistake can be effective in certain situations, but is often a sign of weakness. Additionally, kindness and helping those who have committed fraud through the court process can be a more effective approach. Overcoming fear of failure requires time, effort, and role-playing exercises, leading to increased confidence and boldness.

site_title: Reits
summary: US President Trump's 50% copper import tariff is said to cover refined metal, affecting global markets. In Singapore, the Q3 condo launch wave will test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents reached another record, with more increases expected. UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high, while Goldman Sachs acquired a large hotel and retail asset portfolio in Seoul. New World Group is selling China property assets after a loan deal. US mortgage rates climbed for the first time in five weeks.

site_title: Creative awarded fresh damages in Huawei lawsuit
summary: Creative Technology has won a court case against Huawei International, securing S$2.3 million in damages. The court also dismissed Huawei's appeal, awarding costs to Creative and its QMax Communications subsidiary. The damages will result in US$32 million in income for the company's Q4. The counter surged to an intra-day high of S$6.25 before settling at S$6.01, with a 3.44% gain.

site_title: European leaders back speedy ratification of EU-Singapore FTA: Iswaran
summary: European leaders support speedy ratification of the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA), with French and German ministers expressing strong backing. The goal is to have the pact come into force before the EU's mandate expires in 2019. Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations, S Iswaran, stated that key European leaders are keen to finalize the deal as soon as possible.

images.alt_text: Mr Iswaran said there is scope for Singapore and France in developing global connections and "to see how both sides can plug in to each other's activities".

site_title: Is your advisor doing enough to protect your confidentiality?
summary: A recent trend of data breaches has raised concerns about companies' handling of customer data. Investment professionals must protect client confidentiality to establish investment policies and make tailored recommendations. However, this process can reveal sensitive information, highlighting the need for robust data safeguarding measures. As the investment industry continues to evolve, protecting client data will become increasingly crucial.

site_title: ComfortDelGro-Uber deal is off
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp and ride-hailing firm Uber have dissolved their strategic agreement to acquire a 51% stake in Uber's car rental subsidiary in Singapore, Lion City Holdings. The deal, valued at S$642 million, was cancelled due to Uber's exit from the South-east Asian market. ComfortDelGro will withdraw an application to the Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore, and CEO Yang Ban Seng stated the company remains committed to entering the private-hire vehicle space, despite the change in operating environment.

site_title: Singapore's 3rd derivatives exchange kicks off trading with palm oil futures
summary: Singapore's third derivatives exchange, the Asia Pacific Exchange (Apex), launched palm oil futures trading on May 25, 2018, offering US dollar-denominated contracts to give traders another option. The contracts are expected to provide access to Chinese buyers, with the exchange's CEO citing arbitrage opportunities and increased volumes. The September palm olein futures contract opened at US$635 a tonne, while the November contract was up 1.7%. Apex plans to offer other futures and options on commodities and interest rates, with major shareholders including Chinese conglomerate CEFC China Energy.

site_title: US business spending on equipment gaining momentum
summary: US business spending on equipment gained momentum in April, with new orders for key capital goods increasing 1.0% and shipments rebounding after a slowdown in the first quarter. This data, combined with strong consumer spending, bolsters expectations for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates next month. The US central bank has already increased borrowing costs in March and forecasts at least two more rate hikes for this year.

site_title: JTC enters new industrial revolution with 3 key commitments
summary: JTC, a Singapore government agency and industrial landlord, has announced three key commitments to navigate the new industrial revolution. It will continue to pursue "ambitious visions," build partnerships with counterpart agencies and businesses, and adhere to Singapore's development model. To mark its 50th anniversary, JTC has launched a microsite tracing Singapore's industrialization journey and will install a time capsule at its first permanent headquarters, set to be opened in its 75th year.

images.alt_text: From right: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, JTC chief executive Ng Lang, JTC chairman Loo Choon Yong, Senior Parliamentary Secretary for Trade & Industry Tan Wu Meng (hidden) and the architect of the original Jurong Town Hall, Lim Chong Keat viewing the objects that were placed in the time capsule.
In his address at the JTC dinner on Friday, Prime Minister Lee lauded JTC for focusing its resources on areas where the private sector is unable or unwilling to get involved.

site_title: Are you always saying 'thank you'? Oh, please...
summary: A new study found that people rarely express gratitude in everyday, informal interactions, with verbal thanks occurring in only about 1 in 20 occasions. Researchers attribute this to the "default mode" of reciprocity, where cooperation is the norm, and individuals rarely expect or receive thanks. The study, which analyzed interactions in eight languages, suggests that the cultural ideology of politeness in Western European cultures may contribute to the infrequent use of "thank you" phrases, but this does not necessarily mean that people are ungrateful.

site_title: Staying hydrated in the humidity
summary: Kao Corp's Curel hydrating products claim to end dry skin, a mission the author, a lifelong dry skin sufferer, finds believable. The author, who needs to moisturize daily, praises Curel for hydrating skin without leaving it feeling sticky or icky. Curel's products are particularly helpful in humid climates like Singapore, where dry skin often flakes and itches. The author suggests Curel as a potential solution for others struggling with dry skin, particularly in tropical environments.

site_title: Trump pivots again on Kim summit, says it 'could' happen June 12
summary: President Donald Trump has shifted his stance on a planned summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, stating it "could" happen on the originally scheduled June 12 date. Trump cited "very nice statements" from North Korea as a reason for the potential resumption of talks. North Korean officials expressed a desire to pursue peace and reiterated their willingness to negotiate with the US. Trump's initial cancellation of the summit was sparked by North Korea's "tremendous anger" and "open hostility" in recent statements.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump pivoted from his abrupt cancellation of a planned summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, saying it may still happen on the originally scheduled June 12 date.

site_title: Shanghai Turbo updates on legal tussle
summary: Shanghai Turbo has filed an appeal with the Court of Appeal against the High Court's decision allowing the jurisdictional challenge by former executive director Liu Ming. The appeal was filed on May 18, 2018, related to the court's previous decision that Liu's lawsuit should be heard by Chinese courts. Meanwhile, Zhang Ping and Lin Chuan Jun have filed a fresh action to restrain Shanghai Turbo from issuing new shares until an extraordinary general meeting is held. The court has adjourned a hearing to June 18, 2018.

site_title: No wonder the ultra-wealthy are now flocking to Sydney
summary: Sydney is attracting an increasing number of high-net-worth individuals, with more immigrating to the city than any other location globally. By 2026, the city's high-net-worth population is expected to increase 70%, while ultra-wealthy residents (those with $50 million+) are expected to rise 37% in the next five years. The city's appeal is likely due to its desirable climate, beaches, and harbour.

site_title: ECB resolve to end bond buys this year remains firm -sources
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) remains committed to ending its €2.55 trillion bond-buying scheme later this year, despite sluggish growth and political uncertainty in Italy. Recent indicators suggest growth is leveling off, but core inflation projections will not change significantly. Higher headline inflation, starting in the summer, could support the end of bond buys, but the focus remains on core inflation. The ECB is more cautious about signaling interest rate hikes, with markets expecting a rate hike roughly six months after the bond-buying scheme ends, which could be delayed if growth weakens further.

images.alt_text: Sluggish growth has not weakened the European Central Bank's resolve to end a bond-buying scheme later this year but could make it more cautious about signalling interest rate hikes, conversations with four sources close to the matter indicate.

site_title: Investors unsettled as Singapore and India fight over futures
summary: Singapore Exchange Ltd and National Stock Exchange of India Ltd are locked in a dispute over derivatives contracts, threatening to end a popular way for international investors to hedge Indian shares. India is trying to discourage offshore trading and promote a tax-free trading zone, but this move has unsettled investors. The dispute, which went to court in Mumbai, has left traders scrambling to find new ways to manage their exposure to the US$2.3 trillion Indian market. If the National Stock Exchange wins, investors may pull out of the country or lower their exposure, according to market participants.

site_title: Leverage in Asia buyout loans is edging back to 2007 levels
summary: Asian buyout loans are edging back to 2007 levels, with lenders taking on higher risk to secure yield. Leverage ratios are rising, with senior debt multiples of 4.5 to 5.5 becoming more common. At least $9.2 billion of financing is in the pipeline, with S&P Global Ratings warning that the trend reflects late-cycle behavior and increasing risks. Despite this, leverage remains lower than in the US, and private equity firms are raising significant capital to target Asia-focused investments, driving the trend.

images.alt_text: "Rising leverage in the Asia-Pacific region reflects the more aggressive behaviour of lenders and is adding to risks as we approach the latter parts of the current credit cycle." - Paul Draffin, analyst at S&P Global Ratings

site_title: US Fed's Powell defends central bank independence
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell emphasized the importance of central bank independence in maintaining monetary policy and financial regulation. He warned that a lack of independence can lead to episodes of runaway inflation and economic contractions. Powell stressed the need for transparency and dialogue to enhance public trust and strengthen democratic legitimacy. He also highlighted the benefits of instrument independence, allowing central banks to choose the means to achieve legislatively-assigned goals, and the importance of regulatory independence in maintaining the stability of the banking system.

site_title: Leonie Gardens in District 9 goes en bloc with S$800m reserve price; Lakeside Apartments at S$240m
summary: Huttons Asia has launched en bloc tenders for Leonie Gardens in District 9 with a reserve price of S$800 million, and Lakeside Apartments in Jurong Lake District with a reserve price of S$240 million. Both properties have 71 years remaining on their 99-year leasehold and can be developed into condominium units. The tenders will close on June 21 and July 17, respectively, with the potential for additional balcony space to be added at a development charge.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stocks closed higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 21.74 points to 1,797.40. The market saw 2.2 billion lots traded worth RM2.95 billion, with 506 gainers outnumbering 397 losers.

site_title: Saudi Oil Minister says Aramco IPO Is 'most likely' in 2019
summary: Saudi Oil Minister Khalid Al-Falih confirmed that the initial public offering (IPO) of Saudi Aramco is "most likely" to happen in 2019, citing market readiness rather than the company's or Saudi Arabia's readiness. The IPO, which would value the company at over $2 trillion, aims to raise $100 billion and is expected to be the world's largest ever share sale. This marks a delay from the previously announced second-half 2018 timeline, which was pushed back by Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's plan to modernize the economy.

site_title: Trek 2000's Henn Tan steps down as chairman, becomes the group's consultant
summary: Trek 2000's chairman, Henn Tan, has stepped down effective immediately, becoming the group's consultant for a three-year period. Tan will advise on strategic and business planning, stakeholder management, and administration. He will assume the role of chairman emeritus. Khor Peng Soon has taken over as independent non-executive chairman. Foo Kok Wah has resigned as president of operations, sales, and customised solutions division. The company's counter ended the day at 15.5 Singapore cents, down 0.64%.

site_title: Managing drawdowns in Asian equities
summary: The Eastspring Asian Low Volatility Equity fund has shown success in navigating sharp drawdowns in Asian equities. Historically, Asian equities experience large intra-year declines, but such drawdowns often produce buying opportunities, resulting in positive year-end returns 20 out of 30 times over the past 30 years. The fund targets a 4% yield, focusing on above-average dividend yields and quality stocks, and has delivered a positive return since inception. Its low-volatility approach, based on a quantitative model, has proven effective in managing drawdowns and is likely to weather a return to normalcy in Asian equities.

site_title: All eyes on Kiev
summary: The UEFA Champions League final pits Real Madrid against Liverpool in Kiev, with the two historic clubs seeking their 17th title between them. Liverpool's manager Jurgen Klopp believes his team can level the experience gap with "desire, attitude, work-rate," while Real Madrid captain Sergio Ramos says his team is hungry for a 13th title. The match promises an attractive brand of attacking football, with both teams known for their high-pressing style of play and charismatic leaders. Liverpool has scored a tournament-best 40 goals en route to the final, while Real Madrid has relied on experience and luck to reach the final.

images.alt_text: Liverpool's Egyptian winger Mohamed Salah (top) and Real Madrid's Portuguese forward Cristiano Ronaldo are the key players for their respective clubs.

site_title: Adoption of digital solutions slows among family businesses: survey
summary: A survey by the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce & Industry (SCCCI) found that digital adoption among family businesses in Singapore is slow, despite 86% planning to be part of the digital economy. Only 34.7% have included digitalisation and innovation in their strategic plans, and nearly 11% have an online extension, with 5% having an e-commerce arm. The main obstacles cited were lack of experience, resources, and talent, as well as financial costs. The survey suggests that family businesses need non-family professionals to lead digital transformation, and that the next generation may not have the necessary skills to take over.

site_title: Eurosports Global narrows full-year net loss to S$3.9m
summary: EUROSPORTS Global, the Lamborghini agent, narrowed its full-year net loss by 51% to S$3.91 million, with a loss per share of 1.47 Singapore cents. Revenue rose 18.5% to S$62.08 million, driven by increased sales of new Lamborghini automobiles.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.4% lower on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.44% lower on Friday, finishing at 3,513.23 points, after US-China trade tensions and geopolitical concerns overshadowed encouraging domestic macro data. The week-on-week loss was 16 points, or 0.5%, following a 5-day rally. Turnover was 1.5 billion shares worth S$1.03 billion.

site_title: Movie producer Weinstein charged with rape, sex abuse
summary: Film producer Harvey Weinstein has been charged with rape, sexual misconduct, sex abuse, and a criminal sex act against two women. His bail was set at $1 million cash, and he was ordered to wear a GPS monitor. The charges follow a months-long investigation by the Manhattan district attorney's office. Weinstein, 66, denies having non-consensual sex with anyone and has been accused by over 70 women, including some allegations dating back decades, leading to the #MeToo movement.

site_title: JTC spells out 3 key commitments in face of new industrial revolution at 50th anniversary
summary: JTC, a government agency and industrial landlord, has outlined three key commitments for the new industrial revolution. It will continue to pursue ambitious projects, build partnerships with economic agencies and businesses, and adopt the "Singapore model of development" with a long-term view. To mark its 50th anniversary, JTC will install a time capsule at its headquarters, reflecting on its industrialization journey and future plans. The agency's chairman, Loo Choon Yong, emphasized the importance of collaboration and experimentation in the face of uncertainty.

site_title: Trump welcomes 'warm' North Korea statement as 'very good news'
summary: US President Donald Trump welcomed a conciliatory statement from North Korea, calling it "warm and productive." The statement, from North Korea's First Vice Foreign Minister Kim Kye Gwan, expressed willingness to meet with Trump, contradicting recent statements from North Korea. Trump canceled a planned summit with Kim Jong Un in June, citing "tremendous anger and open hostility." The US and North Korea will likely engage in renewed diplomatic efforts, with some experts warning of rising tensions and military options.

site_title: IHH Healthcare Q1 profit slides 88% on absence of one-off gain; extends acceptance period for Fortis offer to June 30
summary: Malaysia's IHH Healthcare reported a 88% drop in Q1 profit to RM57.24 million due to absence of a one-off gain and higher depreciation, amortization, and finance costs from new hospitals. Revenue increased 6% to RM2.85 billion. The group is confident new hospitals will drive future growth. IHH has extended its offer for India's Fortis Healthcare to June 30, after a second extension. The company's largest subsidiary, Parkway Pantai, saw a 4% increase in revenue.

site_title: Oscar winner Danny Boyle to direct next Bond film
summary: Danny Boyle, an Academy Award winner, has been chosen to direct the next James Bond film, with Daniel Craig set to reprise his role as 007. Production will begin in December 2018 at Pinewood Studios, with a release in autumn 2019. Boyle, known for films like "Slumdog Millionaire" and "Trainspotting," was described by producers as "exceptionally talented."

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish week with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed the week with losses, falling 0.56% to 30,588.04, due to lingering China-US trade worries and Donald Trump's decision to call off his North Korea summit. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the latter dropping 0.93%. The losses were attributed to traders' concerns over global economic uncertainty and trade tensions.

site_title: Australian shares slip, weighed by materials, energy firms; NZ rises on a2 Milk
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.1% on Friday, weighed down by declines in materials and energy stocks, with global miner BHP falling 2.5% and Woodside Petroleum Ltd hitting a two-week low. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark rose 0.6% on a strong performance from dairy firm a2 Milk Company Ltd, which rose 2.6%. The Australian S&P/ASX 200 index fell 4.3 points to 6,032.8, its biggest weekly decline since March.

site_title: China issues revised guidelines for banks' liquidity risk management
summary: China's banking and insurance regulator has issued revised guidelines for commercial banks' liquidity risk management, aiming for a high-quality liquidity asset adequacy ratio of 80% by end-2018 and 100% by end-2019. The revised guidelines, effective July 1, 2018, are part of efforts to improve supervision and risk control in the country's financial sector. The move is expected to enhance the stability and resilience of China's financial system.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won shrug off cancellation of Trump-Kim summit
summary: South Korean stocks ended slightly lower on Friday, closing 0.2% down at 2,460.80 points, despite US President Donald Trump's cancellation of a summit with North Korea. The won rose 0.2% to 1,078.0 against the dollar. Despite the cancellation, many investors remain hopeful for a summit, and offshore investors were net buyers. North Korea-linked stocks took a hit, with Hyundai Elevator and Hyundai Rotem down 16.8% and 19.2%, respectively.

site_title: SIAS to organise meetings between retail investors and Hyflux in due course
summary: Hyflux, a beleaguered water treatment firm, has agreed to meet with its stakeholders, including retail investors, at town hall meetings organized by the Securities Investors Association (SIAS) in due course. The meetings aim to address Hyflux's debt woes and reorganize its business. SIAS called on retail investors to give the company time to achieve this outcome, as it is "doing its best" to maintain value for investors.

site_title: Opec, Russia prepared to raise oil output under US pressure
summary: Saudi Arabia and Russia are discussing raising Opec and non-Opec oil production by 1 million barrels a day, amid US pressure over high oil prices. The move aims to ease 17 months of strict supply cuts, following a complaint from US President Donald Trump. Energy ministers from both countries said any easing would be gradual to avoid shocking the market. This move could ease concerns about supply adequacy and calm consumer worries, following oil hitting its highest price since late 2014 at $80.50 a barrel.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Hyflux's restructuring may lead to financial losses for creditors, according to Moody's Investors Service. Midas Holdings is under investigation by Chinese and Hong Kong authorities. Singapore's factory output increased 9.1% in April, while the service sector saw a 8.5% increase in business receipts. Prudential policy holders affected by Giro deductions were refunded. ComfortDelGro terminated its stake in Uber's Lion City and withdrew its application to the Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore. The Straits Times Index closed 0.4% lower on Friday.

images.alt_text: Hyflux's restructuring, which may include a combination of haircuts, debt maturity extension, or interest rates adjustments, could lead to financial losses for creditors, Moody's Investors Service said in a research report released on Friday.

site_title: Malaysian police says cash worth RM114m found in apartment raid
summary: Malaysian police discovered RM114 million in cash during a raid on three apartments as part of an investigation into state fund 1MDB. The cash was found in 35 bags, and 37 other bags containing jewelry and watches were also seized. The value of the jewelry and watches has not been calculated yet. The raid is part of an ongoing anti-corruption investigation into 1MDB.

site_title: Cortina Q4 profit more than doubles to S$7.8m on better sales margin, retail network expansion
summary: Cortina Holdings reported a fiscal fourth-quarter profit of S$7.83 million, more than doubling from the previous period, driven by a 25.3% increase in revenue to S$132.92 million. The company's sales margin rose to 23.6% and earnings per share almost doubled to 13.5 Singapore cents. Cortina declared a special cash dividend and a final cash dividend, and expects to remain profitable. The company's revenue grew 19% to S$466.29 million for the fiscal year, with profit attributable to company owners rising 89%.

site_title: ComfortDelGro terminates stake in Uber's Lion City, forges ahead with private hire plans
summary: ComfortDelGro has terminated its 51% stake in Uber's Lion City Holdings, a subsidiary valued at S$642 million, due to changing operating conditions. The termination of the sale and purchase agreement (SPA) will not impact ComfortDelGro's net tangible assets or earnings per share. Despite exiting the partnership, ComfortDelGro remains committed to entering the private hire vehicle space, citing the convergence of private hire vehicles and taxis in the personalised mobility market.

site_title: SBI Offshore appoints independent reviewer to look into unauthorised funds write-off
summary: SBI Offshore has appointed independent reviewer KordaMentha to investigate the unauthorized write-off of S$3.63 million from its 2015 accounts, which occurred at its China-incorporated subsidiary. The write-off was not authorized by the board and may have been due to lapses in internal control. The independent review will examine the circumstances and make recommendations, with updates to be shared with shareholders.

site_title: Eight shophouses in Jalan Besar to be conserved, another 24 under consideration by URA
summary: Eight shophouses in Jalan Besar, Singapore, will be conserved by the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) as part of the city's conservation efforts. The buildings, located on Serangoon Road, Race Course Road, and Balestier Road, date back to pre-World War II and feature the "Art Deco" architectural style. The conservation of these eight shophouses complements a cluster of heritage buildings in the area, which was first gazetted as a conservation area in 1991. Another 24 shophouses nearby are under consideration for conservation.

site_title: Malaysia's tax office to investigate Jho Low over 1MDB
summary: Malaysia's finance minister, Lim Guan Eng, has ordered an investigation into financier Jho Low and his family in relation to 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB), a state fund at the center of a massive anti-corruption probe. The investigation follows a relaunched probe into the disappearance of billions of dollars from 1MDB. Low has previously denied any wrongdoing, but his whereabouts are currently unknown. This move comes as the new government seeks to hold those responsible accountable for the scandal.

site_title: US : Wall St opens marginally lower on oil slump
summary: US stocks opened slightly lower on Friday due to a steep drop in oil prices and disappointing corporate results. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.12% to 24,781.29, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The decline comes amid concerns over North Korea and trade tensions with China.

images.alt_text: US stocks opened slightly lower on Friday following a steep drop in oil prices and disappointing corporate results that soured sentiment at the end of a week dominated by concerns over North Korea and trade tensions with China.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close mixed after Trump cans NoKorea summit
summary: Tokyo stocks closed flat on Friday, up 0.06% due to bargain hunting after US President Trump canceled a planned summit with North Korea. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 13.78 points to 22,450.79, while the Topix index fell 3.95 points to 1,771.70. The cancellation alleviated concerns and boosted investor sentiment.

site_title: All Prudential policy holders hit by excess deductions refunded by Friday afternoon
summary: Prudential Singapore has refunded all policy holders affected by excess deductions from their Giro accounts, with the refunds completed by Friday afternoon. The insurer blamed a "technical glitch" for the issue, which resulted in some deductions exceeding bank balances. Prudential confirmed that customer policies were not affected and offered to refund any interest lost. Affected policy holders can contact Prudential's customer hotline for further assistance.

site_title: Singapore competition watchdog provisionally rules against proposed merger of maritime products suppliers
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has provisionally ruled against the proposed merger of maritime products suppliers Wilhelmsen Maritime Services AS (WMS) and Drew Marine's technical solutions, fire, safety and rescue businesses. The CCCS found that WMS's control over Drew Marine's businesses would result in a substantial lessening of competition in the market for marine water treatment chemicals in Singapore, violating the Competition Act. The companies have 10 working days to make representations and may offer commitments to address concerns. A final decision will be made after consideration of their representations.

site_title: Metro slips into the red for Q4, posts S$1.9m loss
summary: Metro Holdings posted a Q4 net loss of S$1.9 million, reversing a year-ago net profit of S$34.2 million. Revenue rose 1.8% to S$34.3 million, driven by higher retail sales. However, gross profit fell 18.5% to S$2.3 million. The group received S$15.8 million from the sale of an associate and a gain of S$3.6 million on disposal of available-for-sale-investments.

site_title: Two men set off bomb in restaurant in Canada; 15 wounded
summary: Two unidentified men set off a bomb at a restaurant in Mississauga, Canada, wounding 15 people, including three with critical injuries. The blast occurred on May 24, 2018, and the suspects fled the scene. Police have released images of the suspects and are investigating the motive behind the attack, which comes a month after a similar incident in Toronto.

site_title: Europe: Equities rise at open
summary: European stocks rose at the open on Friday, rebounding from losses sparked by US President Donald Trump's decision to axe a summit with North Korea. The FTSE 100 index rose 0.4% to 7,744.40 points, while the Paris CAC 40 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 gained 0.4% and 0.5% respectively. Asian markets fell the previous day, but analysts hope the talks can be rekindled, tempering losses.

site_title: Singapore's April factory output up 9.1%; sees expansion across all clusters
summary: Singapore's factory output increased 9.1% in April, beating economist expectations and surpassing March's revised growth of 6.1%. All manufacturing clusters saw expansion, with electronics output growing 11.3% and chemicals production rising 12.4%. The aerospace and land transport segments drove transport engineering growth, while biomedical manufacturing output rose 8.2%. The economy had expanded 4.4% in Q1, with the manufacturing sector growing 9.8%.

site_title: Singapore the preferred location of future Asian LNG trading hub: Deloitte
summary: Singapore has emerged as the preferred location for a future Asian liquefied natural gas (LNG) trading hub, according to a Deloitte survey of 80 senior energy industry leaders. 74% of respondents predicted Singapore would attain the position by 2023, citing its world-class trading infrastructure, low geopolitical risk, and attractive tax and regulatory regime. The survey also found that the Platts Japan/Korea Marker (JKM) would be the most widely chosen pricing benchmark for spot trades in 2023, and that China, Japan, and South Korea are expected to be the top three LNG importers in Asia by 2023.

site_title: Selfie app loved by millions is a big loser for investors
summary: Meitu Inc., a Chinese photo-retouching app company, has struggled to turn a profit despite its blockbuster Hong Kong IPO in 2016. The company's inability to monetize its free apps has led to investor concerns about high valuations and intense competition. Despite its 500 million active users, Meitu's revenue is mostly generated from selling branded cellphones, and its advertising and e-commerce business is still in its early stages. The company's stock has lost over half its value since March 2017, with some investors cutting their holdings, but key insiders have been buying shares, lifting their combined stake to 40%.

site_title: World's most profitable banks can be found in India
summary: India's state-run banks face challenges due to unprecedented frauds and surging bad debt, but new private lenders offer high returns. Private Indian banks, such as AU Small Finance Bank Ltd and Bandhan Bank Ltd, have become the world's most expensive, with AU Small Finance Bank's return-on-equity reaching 56%. The government's recapitalization efforts may not be enough to meet regulatory capital ratios, and credit challenges faced by wholesale banks have led to a large market for retail banks to make gains.

site_title: Indonesia's parliament approves tougher anti-terror laws
summary: Indonesia's parliament approved tougher anti-terrorism laws in response to a surge in homegrown Islamist militancy. The revised law allows police to preemptively detain suspects for longer and prosecute those who join or recruit for militant groups. The move comes after a series of deadly bombings in Indonesia, including the Surabaya attacks that killed over 30 people. The revised law aims to combat the threat posed by extremist groups and improve national security.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's parliament approved on Friday tougher anti-terrorism laws as it seeks to combat a surge in homegrown Islamist militancy, days after suicide bombings claimed by Islamic State killed more than 30 people in the city of Surabaya.

site_title: Singapore's service sector takings up 8.5% in Q1
summary: Singapore's service sector experienced a strong Q1 with business receipts rising 8.5% year-over-year, driven by the financial and insurance sector's 14.2% growth. Health and social services also saw double-digit growth of 13.2%. On a quarter-on-quarter basis, takings rose 0.1% from the previous quarter. However, some sectors, such as transport and storage, business services, and information and communications, saw declines. The figures exclude wholesale and retail trade, and accommodation and food services.

site_title: Creative-Huawei lawsuit: Appeals court grants Creative S$2.3m in extra damages
summary: Creative Technology has won a court appeal, with the Court of Appeal granting an additional S$2.3 million in damages against Huawei International. The decision is final and orders Huawei to pay Creative and its QMax Communications subsidiary costs. The original judgment from 2017 awarded S$36 million to Creative, including interest. Creative expects to recognize US$32 million in income from the proceedings. The lawsuit was over a contract for a wireless broadband project, with Creative seeking to recover S$30 million and Huawei counter-suing for outstanding payments.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon trading at 3,526.33, down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Friday at 3,526.33, down 0.1% from the previous day. Losers outnumbered gainers 157 to 137, with 831.6 million shares worth S$484.2 million changing hands. ISR Capital rose 66.7% to 0.5 Singapore cent, while YZJ Shipbuilding SG fell 7.9% to S$0.995. The Straits Times Index retreated 2.59 points to its current level.

site_title: Taiwan air force scrambles as Chinese bombers fly round island
summary: Taiwan's air force scrambled aircraft on May 25, 2018, as Chinese bombers flew around the island, sparking tensions between the two nations. The Chinese bombers, two H-6 bombers, passed through the Bashi Channel and rounded Taiwan via Japan's Miyako Strait, but the Taiwanese air force monitored the aircraft and ensured the island's security. This incident comes after Taiwan lost its second diplomatic ally in less than a month due to Chinese pressure, with Burkina Faso cutting ties with the island.

site_title: Apple blocks Steam's plan to extend its video games to iPhones
summary: Apple has blocked Steam's plan to extend its video games to iPhones, citing "business conflicts with app guidelines". The move is seen as a sign that Apple is protecting its ability to take a cut of digital purchases made inside games on its mobile devices. Steam had planned to release a free mobile app, Steam Link, allowing gamers to continue playing on their mobile phones while away from their desktop machines. The rejection could hurt Steam with users between 18 and 24 years old, who are more likely to have iPhones.

site_title: Malaysia will pay all obligations on 1MDB debt: finmin
summary: Malaysia's finance minister, Lim Guan Eng, announced that the country will honor all payments on 1MDB debt, totaling RM38 billion, despite the new government's dissatisfaction with missing funds. This move aims to reassure markets about the government's commitment to its international obligations. The government is currently investigating the disappearance of billions of dollars from the fund, with anti-graft agents questioning former Prime Minister Najib Razak, who set up 1MDB a decade ago.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 13.16 points to 1,788.82. Volume reached 36.88 million lots worth RM25.79 million, with 91 gainers outnumbering 69 losers.

site_title: Asia: Stocks hit as Trump drops Kim summit but losses tempered
summary: Asian markets fell on Friday as US President Donald Trump pulled out of the June 12 summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, despite hopes the talks can be rekindled. The news sparked concerns about the future of a rapprochement on the divided peninsula. Despite this, losses were tempered by expectations that the talks can be revived.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with losses on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Friday, May 25, 2018, due to concerns over the cancellation of a summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.31%, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.20%. The market decline followed a week of gains, as investors reacted to the Trump-Kim summit cancellation.

site_title: Malaysia's defeated UMNO party asks for its money back
summary: Malaysia's defeated UMNO party has asked police to return millions of dollars seized from properties linked to former Prime Minister Najib Razak. The funds, estimated to be worth millions, were seized during raids on Najib's home and other properties following his defeat in the May 9 election. UMNO claims the money was campaign contributions and party funding, and requests its return to aid in the party's rebuilding efforts after its first loss in six decades.

site_title: Hyflux restructuring negative for creditors: Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service warns that Hyflux's restructuring, which may include debt maturity extension or interest rate adjustments, could lead to financial losses for its creditors, including about 30 financial institutions. The company's secured debt is dominated by banks, with Maybank Singapore being a key secured creditor. Moody's analysts believe potential losses to Maybank should be limited, as most of its exposure is secured by the Tuaspring project. The company's problems are attributed to large debt and excess capacity in Singapore's power generation sector, but Moody's does not view Hyflux's issues as symptomatic of an industry-wide deterioration.

images.alt_text: Hyflux's restructuring, which may include a combination of haircuts, debt maturity extension, or interest rates adjustments, could lead to financial losses for creditors, Moody's Investors Service said in a research report released on Friday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after US-North Korea summit cancelled
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday after the US cancelled a planned summit with North Korea, causing pessimism. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.27% and the Topix index declined 0.33%. The cancellation led to a decline in global markets, with the US stock market also experiencing a downturn. Despite this, other markets, such as Singapore, remained bullish, with stocks rallying for a fifth consecutive day.

site_title: Yoma Strategic, Pernod Ricard joint venture eyes Myanmar's whisky industry
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings, a Singapore-listed company, has formed a joint venture with Pernod Ricard to produce and distribute whisky in Myanmar. The partnership will see Pernod Ricard become the largest shareholder, with Yoma Strategic, Delta Capital Myanmar, and Win Brothers also participating. The joint venture aims to tap into Myanmar's growing whisky market, with Pernod Ricard bringing international management expertise and a portfolio of leading brands. Completion of the deal is expected in 2019, subject to customary conditions.

site_title: Midas Holdings under probe by China, Hong Kong authorities: SGX RegCo
summary: The Singapore Exchange's regulation unit, SGX RegCo, has been engaging with Chinese and Hong Kong authorities regarding Midas Holdings, a scandal-hit railway-parts maker. The company is under investigation by Singapore authorities, including the Commercial Affairs Department, and has defaulted on interest payments. Trading in Midas shares has been suspended since February. Relevant authorities in China, Hong Kong, and Singapore are investigating the case, and SGX RegCo is cooperating fully.

site_title: Oregon family finds Amazon's Alexa has a mind of her own
summary: A Portland, Oregon, family discovered that Amazon's Alexa can misinterpret conversation, sending an audio recording to one of their contacts. The incident occurred when Alexa, triggered by a background conversation about hardwood floors, was mistaken for a "send message" request. The company acknowledged the issue and is evaluating options to prevent similar incidents. Experts note that faulty hearing can cause Alexa to misinterpret sounds, and millions of Amazon customers use the device daily, making this a rare but concerning example of Alexa's limitations.

site_title: Japan's 2017 external assets fall, still biggest creditor nation
summary: Japan's net external assets fell 2.3% to 328 trillion yen in 2017, marking the third consecutive year of decline, despite being the world's largest creditor nation for the 27th year. Gross external assets rose 2.7% to a record 1,012 trillion yen, driven by increased Japanese direct investment overseas. Japan's overall external debt grew 5.2% to 684 trillion yen, largely due to foreign investors buying Japanese bonds and rising stock prices. The dollar lost 3.8% in value, while the euro rose 9.4%.

site_title: Singapore's 3rd derivatives exchange kicks off trading with palm oil contract
summary: Singapore's third derivatives exchange, APEX, launched palm oil futures trading on May 25, 2018, offering US dollar-denominated contracts alongside benchmark ringgit-denominated contracts from Malaysia. The September palm olein futures contract opened at US$635 a tonne, while the November contract rose 1.7% after opening at US$650 a tonne. This move aims to provide traders with another option beyond existing contracts, giving APEX a foothold in the Asia Pacific region's energy and commodities market.

site_title: Stocks to watch: RHT Health Trust, SingHaiyi, Singapore Shipping Corp, Bukit Sembawang Estates
summary: RHT Health Trust recorded a 5.4% decrease in distribution per unit to 1.06 Singapore cents in its fiscal fourth quarter, attributed to increased borrowings and interest expenses. SingHaiyi Group's profit fell 70.7% to S$6.5 million due to higher cost of sales and absence of a one-off gain. Singapore Shipping Corp's net profit rose 59.5% to US$2.57 million on higher revenue and operating profit. Bukit Sembawang Estates reported a substantial increase in quarterly net income, with net profit after tax rising to S$21.5 million.

site_title: Australia: Shares dip on materials and energy; a2 Milk boosts NZ
summary: Australian shares fell 0.1% on Friday, led by a decline in materials and energy stocks, as copper prices dropped. BHP and Rio Tinto fell 1.8% and 0.4% respectively. In contrast, Aristocrat Leisure surged 4.7% after reporting strong profit growth, while a2 Milk Company rose 2.8% on news of China's handling of customs processes for Australian wine imports. In New Zealand, the benchmark index rose 0.6%.

images.alt_text: Kim Jones, the new artistic director for women’s wear at Fendi, at its store on Rue Saint-Honoré in Paris, Jan. 22, 2021. Jones is not the first designer to make the jump from men’s to women’s wear but given that Fendi surpassed a billion euros in revenue in 2017 (about $1.2 billion) to become one of the more important brands in the LVMH stable, a lot is riding on his success. (Dmitry Kostyukov/The New York Times)##########pqkim27##########

site_title: North Korea says still open to talks with US
summary: North Korea stated its willingness to talk to the US despite President Donald Trump's cancellation of a planned summit. The decision was described as "extremely regrettable" by North Korea's First Vice-Foreign Minister Kim Kye Gwan. The summit, set for June 12 in Singapore, was cancelled due to "open hostility" from the North Korean regime. North Korea had previously declared it had dismantled its nuclear test site, a move seen as a goodwill gesture ahead of the summit. The US and North Korea remain open to talks, with the US willing to meet at any time in any form.

site_title: There are more good rosés than ever
summary: There's a surge in popularity for rosé, leading to an increase in the number of rosé wines available in the market. This week's recommendations include a delicious Early Mountain Rosé from Virginia, a Rhone to the Bone rosé from France, and other wines from Patagonia, Argentina, and Spain, including a pinot noir, an obscure white from the French Alps, and a Spanish Albarino.

site_title: As Singapore and India fight over futures, investor worries grow
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) and National Stock Exchange of India (NSE) are at odds over derivatives contracts, threatening to end a popular way to hedge Indian shares. NSE cancelled licensing agreements with overseas bourses, including SGX, in an effort to discourage offshore trading and promote a tax-free trading zone. The dispute has raised concerns among international investors, who may pull out of the country or lower their exposure. A court hearing is set for Saturday, with SGX prepared to launch the contracts on June 4, despite NSE's claims they are "unlicensed products".

images.alt_text: Singapore's exchange has readied the SGX India Futures for launch on June 4, and has said the contracts will use publicly available data.

site_title: The Gentleman
summary: Naeem Kapadia, a consultant lawyer, is driven by success and living life to the fullest. He values unique experiences, such as bespoke tailoring and attending cultural events, and is inspired by creativity and individualism. Kapadia enjoys running, attending plays and museum exhibitions, and has a passion for travel and trying new cuisines.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday, STI down 0.3% to 3,518.88
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.3% to 3,518.88 on Friday, as the Straits Times Index retreated 10.04 points. The decline came amid a volatile US market, where stocks recovered from overnight losses after US President Donald Trump cancelled a planned summit with North Korea. Gainers outnumbered losers 55 to 43, with QT Vascular rising 5.9% and DBS falling 0.8%.

site_title: Chinese buyers pump luxe property bubble in Phnom Penh
summary: Chinese investors have fueled a luxury property boom in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, with 22,828 high-end apartments expected to be completed by the end of 2018, more than doubling the current number. Many of these units are sold to absent Chinese landlords, raising concerns about affordability for locals. The surge in investment echoes China's own metropolitan hubs, and developers are now facing an oversupply of units, with weak resale demand expected due to high prices and limited local buyers.

site_title: Malaysian timber firm Jawala to raise S$3.15m ahead of SGX listing
summary: Malaysian timber firm Jawala Inc is raising S$3.15 million ahead of a listing on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board. The company, which harvests and supplies timber, has made a net profit of RM2.5 million in the last financial year and plans to use listing proceeds to develop its plantation site and invest in research efforts. Jawala's 100-year licence agreement to manage a 11,043-hectare plantation in Sabah's Sapulut Forest Reserve is also a key factor in its decision to list as a public company.

site_title: Google tries to ease tensions on eve of new EU privacy law
summary: Google is seeking to ease concerns among online publishers about the impact of the European Union's new data privacy law, the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which takes effect on Friday. The law requires organizations to have transparent justification for processing personal data, and Google has promised to release additional tools to assist publishers in June and August. Despite this, publishers and advertisers are scrambling to comply, with some expressing concerns about the lack of guidance from regulators and the potential for significant fines. Google has said its GDPR strategy is in line with guidance from European authorities, but has indicated it may revise its policies if necessary.

site_title: US: Trump's North Korea move sees Wall Street slide
summary: US stocks declined 0.3-0.2% on Wall Street, closing at 24,811.76 and 2,727.76 respectively, after President Donald Trump canceled a June summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, citing Pyongyang's "open hostility." The Dow rebounded from its lows, but trade jitters and a national security investigation into auto imports contributed to the negative finish. Financial stocks fell, with Goldman Sachs and JP Morgan Chase down 0.7% and 1.1%, while US automakers rose on the news.

site_title: Malaysia's commercial crime chief set to give statement on 1MDB
summary: Malaysia's commercial crime chief is set to hold a press conference on Friday regarding 1MDB, a state fund at the center of corruption allegations. The press conference comes a day after former premier Najib Razak concluded a statement to anti-graft agents, denying any wrongdoing. Najib, barred from leaving the country, has faced raids on his properties linked to his family. The event marks a significant development in the ongoing investigation into 1MDB, with the commercial crime chief expected to provide updates on the case.

images.alt_text: Malaysian police's head of commercial crime was set to hold a press conference on Friday related to 1Malaysia Development Berhad, a day after former premier Najib Razak concluded a statement to anti-graft agents investigating the state fund.

site_title: FSL Trust uses proceeds from bond issue as partial repayment for loan
summary: FSL Trust Management announced the issuance of redeemable 7% convertible bonds, raising US$7 million in net proceeds. US$6.68 million was used to repay an existing syndicated loan, reducing the outstanding amount to US$109.94 million. A supplemental agreement was entered into to amend the bond terms, requiring prior unitholder approval for sales, transfers, or assignments of the bonds. This move aims to enhance the trust's financial flexibility and protect its interests.

site_title: Europe: Shares led lower by autos stocks, Deutsche Bank
summary: European stocks fell 0.5% as US President Donald Trump cancelled a meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, causing global equities to come under pressure. German carmakers Daimler, BMW, and Volkswagen dropped 1.7-2.8% after the US launched a national security investigation into car and truck imports. Deutsche Bank fell 4.8% after announcing thousands of job cuts, its lowest level since September 2016. Italy's FTSE MIB index also fell 0.7% due to uncertainty over the make-up of the Italian government.

site_title: Trump-Kim 'breakup' sparks Twitter mirth over commemorative coins
summary: US President Donald Trump cancelled a summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, citing Pyongyang's "open hostility," prompting derisive comments on Twitter about a commemorative coin pre-minted for the event. The coin, selling for $19.95, was cut in price after Trump's letter. Social media users mocked the "breakup" tone of the letter and the premature coins, with many speculating about the fate of the coins and potential Nobel Peace Prize winnings for Trump. The summit, originally set for June 12 in Singapore, will not take place.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump's letter to North Korean leader Kim Jong Un cancelling their summit next month prompted a deluge of derisory comments on Twitter on Thursday, including many about the now discounted commemorative coin pre-minted for the occasion.

site_title: MLT sells S$220m of units at S$1.197 apiece to cover rich end of price talk
summary: MAPLETREE Logistics Trust (MLT) has priced an S$220 million unit placement at S$1.197 apiece, a discount of 2.25% from its counter price. The deal, launched on Thursday, was 5.2 times covered, with 93.3% of proceeds going towards funding a 50% interest in 11 Chinese logistics properties. Trading of new units is expected to start on June 5, subject to SGX-ST approval.

site_title: UK households less confident as economy worries grow: survey
summary: UK households have become less confident in the economy due to Brexit uncertainty, with the consumer confidence index falling to 108.4 in May, down 1.4 points from April. This reflects concerns about second-quarter growth prospects. Despite household finances improving for the fifth month in a row, job security expectations fell to 109.5, its largest monthly drop since 2013. The economy's slowdown in January-March was attributed to heavy snowfall and high inflation. The UK's inflation rate has fallen, while wage growth has picked up, but economic prospects remain a concern.

site_title: Frasers Property acquires owner of new logistics warehouse in Netherlands for 25m euros
summary: Frasers Property Ltd acquired a logistics warehouse in the Netherlands for 25 million euros, with the property having a gross lettable area of 31,600 square meters. The acquisition, completed through an indirect subsidiary, does not expect to impact earnings per share or net tangible asset value per share for the current financial year. The warehouse is leased to a leading dairy company on a long-term basis.

site_title: Singapore's full-year NODX growth forecast untouched by low Q1 showing
summary: Singapore's full-year non-oil domestic export (NODX) growth forecast remains unchanged at 1-3% despite a lower-than-expected 1.1% year-over-year growth in the first quarter. The government's earlier projection, made in February, is still intact. Total merchandise trade is forecast to expand 3-5% in 2018, with non-oil exports and services growth moderating from the previous year. The lower-than-expected NODX growth may be attributed to a shorter working month in February and a high base effect in March.

site_title: Morgan Freeman apologises after sexual harassment claims
summary: Morgan Freeman has apologized for sexual harassment claims made by 16 women, including eight victims, who described troubling behavior on production sets or promotional tours. The allegations include unwanted touching, comments about appearance, and requests for women to twirl. Freeman stated that his intention was never to offend or make anyone feel uneasy, but acknowledged that his actions were unacceptable. The allegations come as part of the #MeToo movement, following similar accusations against other high-profile figures, including Harvey Weinstein.

site_title: Facebook, Twitter tighten rules for political ads
summary: Social media platforms Twitter and Facebook have implemented new policies to label and verify identities of those paying for political messages. Twitter will require "election labels" for US candidate ads and notarised forms to verify advertisers' US identities. Facebook will verify the identity of advertisers and clearly label election-related and issue ads, starting with the US. The goal is to prevent interference and misinformation in elections, following criticism over their role in the 2016 US election.

site_title: Oil slips further below US$80/barrel on talk Opec may lift output
summary: Oil prices fell about $1 on Thursday, with Brent crude futures settling at $78.79 a barrel and US WTI crude futures at $70.71 a barrel, a 1.27% and 1.57% loss respectively. Expectations build that Opec may lift output in June to make up for reduced supplies from Venezuela and Iran, which could ease production cuts. A weaker US dollar also supported crude prices.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell about US$1 on Thursday, with expectations building that reduced supplies from Venezuela and Iran could prompt Opec to wind down output cuts in place since the start of 2017.

site_title: Saving An Endangered Language
summary: A grassroots initiative in Singapore aims to revive the endangered Kristang language, a creole of Portuguese and Malay spoken by the Portuguese-Eurasians. Kevin Martens Wong's Kodrah Kristang classes have grown from 14 participants in 2016 to hundreds today, with a 30-year master plan to produce language textbooks, novels, and media. The language is spoken by fewer than 150 people in Singapore and a few thousands more in Malaysia, with most fluent speakers over 50. To ensure its survival, young people must learn and use the language, with Wong hoping to see hundreds of families in Singapore interact daily in Kristang.

site_title: Models, actresses, employees: the women speaking out against Weinstein
summary: Dozens of women, including actresses and models, have accused veteran producer Harvey Weinstein of harassment, abuse, and rape dating back to the 1990s. The accusations surfaced after a New York Times exposé in October 2017, with subsequent investigations by The New Yorker and other media outlets revealing more cases of misconduct. Weinstein is expected to surrender to authorities in New York to face possible criminal charges, with many of his accusers, including Asia Argento and Rose McGowan, speaking out against him and calling for change in the entertainment industry.

site_title: Trump signs Dodd-Frank rollback as deregulation push continues
summary: US President Donald Trump signed the first major rollback of post-crisis banking regulations, known as Dodd-Frank, into law. The law reduces regulatory scrutiny for small- and medium-sized banks, freeing them from stress testing. Critics, including Democrats, warn this move could lead to the return of reckless financial conduct that caused the 2008 global financial crisis. Despite this, the US banking sector reported its most profitable quarter ever, with profits rising 27.5% to $56 billion, driven by community banks' 17.7% increase in net income.

site_title: Jury orders Samsung to pay Apple US$533m in iPhone case
summary: A US federal court jury ordered Samsung to pay Apple $533 million for copying iPhone design features, including a black screen with rounded edges and "bounce-back" and "tap-to-zoom" functions. The verdict, a split between Apple's request for $1 billion and Samsung's $28 million, was seen as a victory for Apple, which argued that design was essential to the iPhone. The case dates back seven years and was revisited after a Supreme Court decision overturned an earlier $400 million damage award.

site_title: Singapore's Q1 GDP growth at 4.4%; MTI revises full-year figure to 2.5-3.5%
summary: Singapore's Q1 GDP growth reached 4.4%, exceeding expectations, with full-year growth forecasted at 2.5-3.5%. The growth was primarily driven by manufacturing, finance, and insurance, and wholesale trade sectors. However, economists expect momentum to slow in the coming quarters due to moderating manufacturing and softening external demand. The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) revised its full-year forecast, citing a slightly improved external demand outlook and robust performance of the Singapore economy in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: Daniel Tarullo, who announced his resignation on Friday - nearly five years before the end of the term he was appointed to by former President Barack Obama - was an architect of efforts to shore up capital held by banks to help them weather financial storms.

Singapore's gross domestic product (GDP) grew 4.4 per cent in the first three months of 2018, with full-year growth expected to come in at "2.5 to 3.5 per cent" this year, said the Ministry of Trade and Industry on Thursday.

site_title: Cathay Pacific revamps loyalty programme with focus on customer spend
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways has overhauled its loyalty programme, Asia Miles, to focus on customer spend rather than distance flown. The new award chart considers airfare type, travel class, and distance, with 80% of tickets earning more miles. The airline aims to increase revenue and cut costs as part of a three-year transformation programme. Asia Miles has 10 million members and plans to increase award seats by 20% or more, following a trend seen in other airlines such as Qantas. The changes aim to make the programme more efficient and competitive in the market.

site_title: QT Vascular sells IP rights for its coronary products to US firm
summary: QT Vascular, a Singaporean medtech firm, has sold its intellectual property rights for non-drug coated coronary products, including Chocolate XD and Glider, to US firm Teleflex for S$98.4 million in cash. The deal also gives Teleflex an option to purchase the drug coated coronary balloon catheter, Chocolate Heart. Proceeds from the sale will strengthen QT Vascular's balance sheet and enable further product development, including Chocolate Touch, which is on track for FDA approval.

site_title: Accounting advisory services to grow amid tech disruption
summary: Accounting advisory services are expected to grow amid tech disruption, driven by the need for businesses to adapt to changing trends and dynamics. A survey by ACCA found that audit & assurance, tax advisory & compliance, and IT advisory services will be in high demand for the next three years. The report also highlights the importance of providing high-quality, relevant advice and deepening knowledge of the industry and client circumstances. To capitalize on this growth, accounting firms will need to diversify their services, regionalize, and harness technology, while also upgrading their skills to be future-ready.

site_title: When dollars and cents become bits and bytes, in BT Weekend
summary: Singaporeans' adoption of digital payments remains slow, despite being tech-savvy. A recent article in BT Weekend explores the complications of transitioning to digital dollars. Meanwhile, Engie CEO Isabelle Kocher discusses transforming her company for its employees' full potential. Other topics include a review of the Eastspring Asian Low Volatility Equity fund, ethics in financial advising, and a preview of the UEFA Champions League final between Real Madrid and Liverpool. The article highlights the need for companies to have corporate purpose and the importance of financial literacy, particularly for women.

site_title: Creative Ideas
summary: Design student David Jonathan Ui has created Scoville, a kitchen tool designed to easily remove chilli seeds. Scoville is one of 20 finalists at the inaugural Singapore Creative Awards, which will announce winners on May 30. The tool features a curved blade and prongs, addressing the pain of deseeding chillies. The public can view the finalists' works at the Singapore Book Fair 2018 and vote for their favorite design until May 27 to win a massage chair.

site_title: Lenovo posts US$189m loss on one-time write-off
summary: Lenovo reported a US$189 million net loss for its full fiscal year due to a one-time US$400 million non-cash write-off charge. The company's fourth-quarter profit declined 69% to US$33 million, while revenue increased 11% year-over-year to US$10.6 billion. Lenovo plans to overhaul its business by combining its PC, mobile, and smart devices groups into an "intelligent devices group." The company's shares rose initially but later declined, and its stock will be removed from Hong Kong's benchmark index next month.

site_title: Boustead buys entire WhiteRock medical group for S$19m
summary: Boustead Singapore has entered into a sale-and-purchase agreement to acquire WhiteRock Medical Company for S$19.02 million. The acquisition includes 16 healthcare corporations operating in Singapore, China, Hong Kong, Malaysia, and Thailand, with a team of 71 employees. Boustead believes the acquisition is of a "reasonable valuation" for the healthcare industry and will fill an underserved gap in the market. The deal is dependent on a successful restructuring of WhiteRock MedCo's global business and shareholder approval.

site_title: Oil falls on shock US stock builds, Opec supply worries
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday after a surprise build in US crude and petrol inventories, despite strong demand. US crude inventories rose 5.8 million barrels and petrol stocks increased by 1.9 million barrels, with analysts attributing the unexpected build to reduced exports and rising imports. The increase came as Opec may consider raising oil output due to supply shortfalls from Iran and Venezuela, and rising geopolitical tensions. Oil prices have gained nearly 20% this year, driven by coordinated supply cuts and rising tensions.

site_title: Norwegian firm in S'pore seeks exemption from US solar tariffs
summary: Norwegian solar-energy firm REC Group has submitted a request to the US Trade Representative to be excluded from the US tariffs on solar panel imports. The tariffs, announced by President Donald Trump in January, cover both solar cells and modules, and are expected to raise the cost of solar power and its deployment. Experts have expressed concerns about the impact on the US solar industry, and REC Group has stated that its "TwinPeak" solar panels have unique performance attributes that are highly prized by US customers, making an exemption request.

site_title: Funds from land deal used to pay 1MDB dues
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's administration used funds from land deals and a sovereign wealth fund to pay off debts of 1MDB, a state fund under money laundering investigations. About $500 million from a land sale and $300 million from the sale of Khazanah Nasional shares were used to settle a $1.2 billion debt owed to Abu Dhabi state fund IPIC. The new Malaysian administration has opened investigations into 1MDB's financial dealings, and Najib is being questioned by the anti-graft agency.

site_title: US new home sales fall less than forecast in April
summary: US new home sales fell 1.5% in April to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 662,000 units, less than forecast. Despite rising mortgage rates, sales rose 11.6% from a year ago, with transactions in the South and Northeast increasing. Economists attribute the drop to a shortage of lower-end homes, not higher interest rates. The median new house price rose 0.4% to $312,400, and it would take 5.4 months to clear the supply of houses on the market.

site_title: Indonesia's Go-Jek going into Singapore, Vietnam, Thailand, Philippines
summary: Indonesia's ride-hailing startup Go-Jek is expanding into four new markets: Singapore, Vietnam, Thailand, and the Philippines, investing US$500 million over the next four months. This move will compete with Singapore-based Grab, which already operates in Indonesia. Go-Jek aims to replicate its services, including food delivery and grocery shopping, in the new markets. The expansion follows a US$1.5 billion fundraising round led by Temasek, Google, and other investors. Go-Jek's CEO, Nadiem Makarim, expects the move to provide welcome competition and become the go-to lifestyle app in the region.

site_title: Chinese buyers pump luxe property bubble in Phnom Penh
summary: Chinese buyers are fueling a luxury property bubble in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, with many units sold to absent landlords. The city is set to have over 22,828 luxury apartments by the end of 2018, with an estimated 30,000 units by 2020. This has raised concerns about affordability for locals, with many units priced at over $1,000 per month. Chinese developers, including Guangzhou Yuetai Group and Prince Real Estate, are leading the surge in high-end real estate investment, with some buyers purchasing units without ever visiting the country.

site_title: US launches probe into auto imports
summary: The US has launched a national security investigation into car and truck imports under Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962, potentially leading to new tariffs on imported vehicles and parts.
