The Stoxx 600 index extended Monday's gains, despite concerns over the formation of an Italian government and its potential impact on spending plans.

site_title: MAS to simplify rules for market operators and speed up launch of new products
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) proposes to simplify rules for market operators and speed up the launch of new derivatives products. MAS aims to create a new multi-tier regime with three tiers (RMO Tier 1, Tier 2, and Tier 3) to accommodate emerging business models and lower regulatory requirements. The new regime will allow market operators to serve retail investors and launch products more quickly, with RMO Tier 1 operators meeting additional requirements for retail investor protection. The public consultation ends on June 22, 2018.

site_title: Macly Group purchases 5 terrace houses in Guillemard area
summary: MACLY Group acquired five terrace houses in the Guillemard area for nearly S$20.55 million, with an average price of around S$700 per square foot per plot ratio. The properties are on 12,839 sq ft of freehold land, zoned for residential use. Macly plans to redevelop the site into a 47-apartment project and expects to begin construction in the first half of next year.

site_title: Saks offers facial workouts, threaded brows in cosmetics redo
summary: Saks Fifth Avenue has renovated its flagship store in midtown Manhattan, moving its beauty section to the second floor with 15 treatment cabins and a concierge service. The luxury retailer aims to elevate the cosmetics shopping experience, offering high-end services such as face workouts, slimming massages, and free services like express facials and brow threading. The move is part of a $250 million renovation, as Saks seeks to rekindle interest in brick-and-mortar shopping and compete with online retailers like Ulta Beauty and Sephora.

site_title: How to avoid the risk of taking phishing bait
summary: Cybersecurity experts warn that spear phishing, a targeted email-spoofing attack, poses a significant threat to organizations, with 48% of respondents citing it as their primary concern. Spear phishing attacks are becoming increasingly sophisticated, using personalized information to trick victims into installing malware or providing sensitive information. To prevent these attacks, experts recommend educating employees about the risks, using email security technology, and implementing advanced solutions such as machine learning and artificial intelligence (AI) components. These measures can help deter spear phishing attacks and protect sensitive company information.

site_title: As bitcoin world wobbles, mining rig company Canaan plans US$2b IPO
summary: Canaan Inc., a leading cryptocurrency mining rig supplier, plans to raise up to $2 billion in the world's largest bitcoin-focused initial public offering (IPO). Despite a 60% decline in bitcoin mining profitability and fewer customers, Canaan is presenting itself as a chip designer focused on artificial intelligence and blockchain. The company's profits rose seven-fold last year, driven by a surge in demand for its products during bitcoin's soaring price. The IPO, scheduled for July, is seen as a rare opportunity for investors to buy into a cryptocurrency supply company.

site_title: Chinese vase, left in attic, worth at least half a million euros: Sotheby's
summary: A Chinese vase discovered in a French attic is set to be auctioned off by Sotheby's on June 12, with a guide price of 500,000 euros. The vase, made for the 18th century Qing dynasty Emperor Qianlong, is an exquisite porcelain vessel featuring an idyllic landscape with deer and cranes. Experts consider it a major work of art, the only known example in the world bearing such detail, and a rare example of Qing imperial porcelain.

site_title: Iran tells European powers to step up and save nuclear deal
summary: Iran has urged European powers to step up and save the international nuclear deal, after the US threatened "the strongest sanctions in history" if Iran fails to make sweeping changes. Iranian officials have vowed to resist US pressure, while European powers, including Germany, have signaled their limited ability to shield companies from US sanctions. German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas plans to discuss the deal with US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, but the EU's ability to persuade its firms to stay in Iran is seen as limited.

site_title: 'I'm sorry', Facebook boss tells European lawmakers
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg apologized to European lawmakers, acknowledging the company's failure to prevent the misuse of user data in the Cambridge Analytica scandal. He pledged to invest in data protection and prevent similar breaches, while also welcoming the EU's new personal data protection rules. Zuckerberg admitted that Facebook had been "too slow" to identify Russian interference in the 2016 US presidential election and committed to making significant investments to keep users safe, despite potential impacts on profits.

site_title: Manchester United named most valuable football team
summary: Manchester United has been named the most valuable football team, with an estimated overall value of over 3.2 billion euros, surpassing Real Madrid and FC Barcelona. This increase is attributed to the club's strong brand, advertising contracts, and social media reach. The total financial value of the 32 European clubs has risen by 9% to 32.5 billion euros, with Bayern Munich coming in fourth and Juventus ninth. Financial fair play regulations limit Paris Saint-Germain's growth, despite its estimated value of 1.14 billion euros.

site_title: Airport infrastructure is the vital link in helping Asean nations fly high
summary: Asean nations face significant economic growth opportunities through infrastructure development, particularly airport infrastructure. The region's large workforce and growing economy make it an attractive market for investment. However, Asean is lagging behind in airport infrastructure, with only one-third of the number of airports as the US. To meet growing air transport demand, Asean countries need to develop their airport infrastructure, including runways and terminal buildings. The Asean Single Aviation Market policy aims to promote air connectivity and liberalization within the region. China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) and Japan's Official Development Assistance program also provide financing options for infrastructure development. Asean countries must prioritize airport infrastructure development and adopt supportive and collaborative policies to maximize connectivity and drive economic growth.

site_title: US slaps steep import duties on Chinese steel shipped from Vietnam
summary: The US Commerce Department has imposed steep import duties on Chinese steel shipped from Vietnam, with duties of 199.76% on anti-dumping and 256.44% on countervailing duties. The decision comes after finding that up to 90% of the steel originated from China, evading US anti-dumping and anti-subsidy orders. This marks a victory for US steelmakers, who had argued that Chinese products were being diverted to other countries to circumvent duties. The decision aims to protect the US steel industry from unfair trade practices.

site_title: NSE-SGX rift deepens with India bourse filing injunction in Bombay
summary: The National Stock Exchange of India (NSE) has filed an injunction in the Bombay High Court to block the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) launch of three new India equity derivative products on June 4. The products are alternatives to the NSE's Nifty 50 contracts, which are set to be delisted in August. The SGX claims to have regulatory approvals and will launch the products as planned, despite the NSE's attempt to block them. The move deepens the rift between the two exchanges, which have been competing for market share.

site_title: Here's a new idea: Investing in N Korea
summary: North Korea is being wooed by foreign investors as peace on the Korean peninsula appears to be within grasp. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has stated that the US would allow American companies to invest in North Korea's energy, infrastructure, and agriculture sectors if the regime agrees to fully dismantle its nuclear weapons program. Several Western and Asian companies are already keen to invest in the impoverished nation, with South Korean President Moon Jae-in's "Korean Peninsula New Economic Initiative" outlining joint economic projects to be started if relations improve.

site_title: As smart-beta spreads, former fan wonders if it's actually dumb
summary: Former smart-beta ETF fan Vincent Deluard created a "DUMB" portfolio that outperformed a combined version of five popular smart-beta ETFs by over 2% since 2016. Deluard's experiment tested the effectiveness of factor-based strategies, concluding that combining factors without a guiding principal can lead to factor dilution and reduced market-beating potential. Experts caution that short-term performance does not indicate success, and that smart-beta products serve multiple strategic outcomes, including improving returns, reducing risk, and increasing income.

site_title: Beware the VIX, prepare for a more volatile bull market
summary: The VIX, a measure of expected US stock market volatility, has declined to a near-four-month low despite a 9% peak-to-trough decline in global stocks this year. This reflects concerns over an economic upswing ending due to higher inflation, rising interest rates, and a US-China trade dispute. Experts warn of a more volatile bull market, with potential implications for investors and the global economy.

images.alt_text: The return of volatility does not mean that it is time to sell. On the contrary, global growth is still good, earnings growth is strong, and equity market valuations remain appealing relative to cash and fixed income.

site_title: Troubled firms wait too long to restructure and bounce back: lawyer
summary: A top Singaporean lawyer, Patrick Ang, says Asian companies often wait too long to seek help with restructuring due to a cultural fear of failure. This delay can hurt companies' chances of a successful restructuring, as they may attempt to stave off creditors or wait for problems to resolve on their own. Ang advises troubled companies to deliver bad news all at once and demonstrate commitment to cutting costs to gain stakeholder buy-in. He believes restructuring can lead to a fresh start and notes that Singapore is poised to become a regional debt restructuring hub.

images.alt_text: Mr Ang's advice to beleaguered firms is to bite the bullet and deliver all the bad news at once. By coming clean quickly with stakeholders, firms can then work on moving upwards.

site_title: Uber wins approval for taxi-hailing pilot programme in remote Japanese island
summary: Uber has received government approval for a taxi-hailing pilot programme in Awaji, a remote Japanese island with 120,000 residents. The pilot, set to start this summer, will connect local drivers and passengers, marking Uber's first foray into Japan after years of being sidelined by laws against ride-sharing.

site_title: Banks adopt military playbook against cybercrime
summary: Banks are adopting a military-like approach to combat cybercrime, with former government cyberspies, soldiers, and counter-intelligence officials leading security teams. At least a dozen banks, including Mastercard and Visa, have established "fusion centres" modeled after the Department of Homeland Security's counterterrorism hubs. These centers track and analyze threats, conduct combat-style exercises, and simulate real-world attacks to test defenses. The goal is to detect patterns and vulnerabilities, and to develop strategies to prevent massive data breaches like the one that hit Equifax last year.

site_title: US slaps steep import duties on Chinese steel shipped from Vietnam
summary: The US Commerce Department imposed steep import duties on Chinese steel shipped from Vietnam, with duties ranging from 199.76% to 256.44% on imports of cold-rolled steel and 199.43% to 39.05% on corrosion-resistant steel. The decision follows a European Union finding that Vietnamese steel shipments circumvented tariffs and comes after US steelmakers successfully argued that Chinese products were being diverted to Vietnam to evade duties. The move is part of the ongoing trade tensions between the US and China, and is expected to further impact the global steel industry.

site_title: UAE raises the stakes to woo foreigners to stay on in Dubai
summary: The UAE is introducing new rules allowing expatriates to fully own businesses in Dubai or Abu Dhabi without a local partner, effective by year-end. This move aims to increase foreign investment and talent in the country, as it competes with neighboring Gulf states for economic growth and talent. The new rules include 10-year residency permits for professionals in certain fields and no local partner requirement outside of free zones. The UAE seeks to boost its competitiveness and stay ahead in attracting investors, amid a global shift away from fossil fuels.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore-listed plantation companies under UOB Kay Hian's coverage reported weaker-than-expected Q1 2018 results due to lower-than-expected production and sales volumes. Despite expected production recovery in the second half, sector performance will be dragged down by a weaker crude palm oil average selling price. Analysts expect a range of US$600 to US$650 a tonne for crude palm oil prices in the second quarter. Meanwhile, Keppel Corporation and Japan Foods Holding are recommended as "add" and "buy" stocks, respectively, with potential upside catalysts in FY2019 driven by organic growth and joint ventures.

site_title: US dollar rally falters as Treasury yields dip
summary: The US dollar's rally against a basket of six major currencies faltered on Tuesday as Treasury yields dipped, prompting traders to cash in on bullish bets. The dollar's index fell to 93.414, down from a five-month high of 94.058. The euro rebounded from a 4 1/2-month low of US$1.1717, while US Treasury yields pulled back from seven-year highs. Profit-taking and easing US-China trade tensions contributed to the dollar's decline, which was its biggest daily loss in two weeks.

site_title: Asset managers plan new ETFs on their own
summary: Asset managers are planning to launch new exchange-traded funds (ETFs) without relying on third-party expert issuers, a trend expected to gain momentum with new regulations set to simplify the approval process. The removal of "exemptive relief" requirements is expected to reduce the time and cost associated with launching an ETF, allowing smaller issuers to enter the $3.6 trillion US market. Experts believe that having in-house expertise is now a key differentiator, with marketing and public relations capabilities also playing a crucial role in standing out.

site_title: Humans fight back against robots mining personal finance data
summary: The European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is set to take effect on May 25, imposing human oversight and consumer protection on robots mining personal finance data. The rules require firms to get consent from people when their data is used to automate certain decisions, and clients have the right to demand a human review and details about automated processes. This may hinder companies developing sophisticated algorithms, potentially hindering the EU's financial industry in competing with US and Asian rivals.

site_title: At a glance
summary: Stocks in Europe and the US fell due to bank and healthcare issues, with US-EU tariffs in focus. The US stock market opened lower, amid Trump's fresh tariff threats on Canada. Meanwhile, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Companies like Creative Technology and OCBC warned of potential revenue and operating loss issues. Indonesia detained an employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case, and London's Heathrow considered raising airport fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Hyflux CEO Olivia Lum's letter to stakeholders
summary: Hyflux, a global leader in water infrastructure solutions, has announced a court-supervised liabilities reorganisation exercise to restructure its business and debt. The move comes after the company faced losses in 2017 due to depressed electricity prices in Singapore. CEO Olivia Lum has appointed financial and legal advisers to guide the process, which aims to protect viable core businesses and position the company for long-term sustainable growth. The reorganisation exercise will provide space and time for the company to focus on strategic discussions, operational optimisation, and project completion.

site_title: Ng Chee Meng steps up as labour chief, takes over from Chan Chun Sing
summary: Ng Chee Meng has been officially appointed as the new Labour Chief, taking over from Chan Chun Sing, who stepped down after a month as Minister of Trade and Industry. Ng, who joined the labour movement in April, was unanimously elected by the NTUC central committee to lead the organization. Chan expressed his commitment to supporting the labour movement and ensuring good jobs for workers, as he transitions to his new role in the government.

site_title: Buxani Group buys 117-room hotel in Glasgow
summary: Buxani Group, a Singapore-based property investment firm, has purchased a 117-room hotel in Glasgow, Scotland for £10 million (S$18 million). This marks the group's first UK property acquisition, with plans to expand to more 3- and 4-star hotels in the UK and Europe. CEO Kishore Buxani is optimistic about the global travel and tourism industry, citing growth in Asian tourists and tech-savvy travelers.

images.alt_text: The 117-room GoGlasgow Urban Hotel is near Ibrox Stadium in Paisley Road West in Glasgow. Following the completion of the acquisition on May 16, Thailand-based Compass Hospitality has taken over the hotel's management.

site_title: Circles.Life to offer zero-dollar price plan
summary: Circles.Life, a Singapore-based mobile virtual network operator (MVNO), has launched a zero-dollar price plan, offering 1GB of data, half an hour of voice calls, and 10 text messages. Analysts predict intense competition in the market, with the plan posing a threat to incumbent mobile network operators (MNOs). While a price war is unlikely, the move may lead to further price-slashing by MNOs, and Circles.Life's willingness to pay for market share may impact industry profitability.

site_title: Hatten Land in JV to launch new platform
summary: Hatten Land, a CATALIST-listed property developer in Singapore, has formed an 85:15 joint venture with proptech startup FundPlaces to launch StayCay, South-east Asia's first hospitality blockchain platform for hotels and malls. The platform aims to boost brand loyalty and hotel occupancy, with the goal of managing US$1 billion in assets by expanding to other third-party hotels and retail merchants in the region. StayCay will use blockchain technology to issue "hotel tokens" that can be exchanged for discounted packages and rewards points.

site_title: Don't forget the fishing industry
summary: The world's fishing fleet, estimated to be around 4.5 million vessels, operates with minimal regulation, posing problems for insurers and workers alike. Despite the International Labour Organization's Work in Fishing Convention, 2007, many crews face atrocious conditions, including overwork, non-payment of wages, forced labor, and human trafficking. The convention aims to improve occupational safety, health, and medical care, as well as social security protection for fishers. However, the industry's lack of regulation makes it challenging to enforce these rights, with some owners operating outside of authorities' sight and mind.

site_title: Public education drive urges Swedes: 'Prep for war'
summary: Sweden is launching a public education drive urging citizens to prepare for war, amid concerns over Russia's military exercises and geopolitical tensions. The "total defence" campaign, aimed at increasing war and crisis-readiness, will distribute a 20-page leaflet to 4.8 million households, featuring fighter jets and tanks in a peaceful landscape. Experts estimate it would take a week to mobilize the Swedish military, and the government is expanding its network of shelters to accommodate up to two-thirds of the population. The campaign is seen as a response to Russia's military actions and a shift away from the country's post-Cold War focus on peace-time emergencies.

images.alt_text: This is a screenshot of the leaflet to be issued by Sweden's government to its citizens. Sweden has not gone to war for more than 200 years, so today's generations of Swedes - members of one of the world's richest nations - will get it spelled out for them on how life is going to become tough in a crisis.

site_title: An SIA-SilkAir merger makes for a better way to fly
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is set to merge regional carrier SilkAir, effectively ending the SilkAir brand. The move aims to consolidate operations, focusing on two distinct brands: SIA for premium services and Scoot for budget markets. A US$100 million fleet upgrade will modernize SilkAir's aircraft, including new lie-flat seats and inflight entertainment systems, ensuring consistency across SIA's network. The merger is expected to enhance strategic and operational focus in the competitive airline industry.

site_title: Airport infrastructure is the vital link in helping Asean nations fly high
summary: Asean nations face significant growth opportunities with increased connectivity, driven by digital technology and urbanization. Airport infrastructure development is critical to propel economic growth, with Asean countries needing to address infrastructure gaps to meet growing demand. The region's population of 639 million and young workforce will drive economic growth, but airport infrastructure development is often overlooked. Key obstacles include securing finance, managing bureaucracy, and addressing corruption. Multilateral development institutions and China's Belt and Road Initiative can help bridge the financing gap. Asean's aviation industry is booming, with air travel expected to double to 7.8 billion passengers annually by 2030, and connectivity among Asean countries is crucial to meet this demand. The region needs to accelerate airport infrastructure development and liberalize market policies to maximize connectivity and support economic growth.

site_title: Moya launches one-for-two rights issue
summary: Singapore water treatment company Moya Holdings Asia has launched a one-for-two rights issue, offering up to 1.4 billion new shares at S$0.095 each. The issue is primarily to repay an existing loan facility and finance expansion plans, including acquiring more capacity in Indonesia. The company's largest shareholder, Tamaris Infrastructure, has agreed to fully subscribe for its entitlement, while other shareholders may not subscribe due to the lower market price. If no other shareholder subscribes, Moya will raise at least S$90.7 million.

site_title: UK economy will bounce back from weak start to 2018 says Carney
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said the UK economy will bounce back from a weak start to 2018 due to temporary and idiosyncratic factors. Despite expectations of higher interest rates, the central bank kept rates at 0.5% in May, citing uncertainty from Brexit. Carney denied confusing investors and households, saying surveys showed most expected a rate hike in 2018. Monetary Policy Committee member Gertjan Vlieghe also backed publishing interest rate forecasts, but most MPC members oppose the idea, citing risks of being interpreted as a promise.

site_title: Global economic recovery drives record public asset growth
summary: Global economic recovery drove record public asset growth in 2017, with assets increasing by US$2.5 trillion, a 7.3% rise, the largest ever, according to an OMFIF report. Public pension, central bank, and sovereign fund assets now total US$36.2 trillion, accounting for 45% of the world's GDP. Asia-Pacific assets grew 7%, while Europe's assets increased 12%, with sustainable investments gaining traction amid climate change concerns.

site_title: Australia investigators defend MH370 out-of-control scenario
summary: Australian investigators defended their findings that missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 was out of control when it crashed into the ocean in 2014. The Boeing 777, carrying 239 passengers, vanished en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing. Despite an extensive search, the plane has not been found. Investigators rejected theories that a rogue pilot intentionally ditched the plane, citing a lack of evidence. The search remains ongoing, with private searches continuing in the southern Indian Ocean.

site_title: EU fears offer to US not enough to end trade row
summary: The European Union's trade commissioner, Cecilia Malmstrom, warned that the bloc's offer to the US to waive tariffs on steel and aluminum imports in exchange for a similar exemption for China was not enough to end the trade row. EU trade ministers will discuss a limited trade deal with the US, which could include exemptions for European imports of US natural gas. The EU has threatened to retaliate with tariffs on US goods, including Harley-Davidson motorbikes and bourbon whiskey, unless the US agrees to a permanent exemption.

site_title: Making it their business to give back
summary: Business leaders emphasize the importance of corporate social responsibility (CSR) in creating a better world and achieving long-term success. CSR improves productivity, attracts talent, and positively impacts the community. Companies like The Ritz-Carlton, Alpha, and CapitaLand engage in volunteerism, skills-based volunteering, and philanthropic efforts, which enhance their brand reputation and contribute to the well-being of their stakeholders. To encourage other firms to give back, companies should indoctrinate their people into a giving culture, start small, and focus on strategic philanthropic efforts that resonate with their business and expertise.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group (SEG) has agreed to buy a 7.52% stake in Spackman Media Group (SMG) for US$6.9 million, increasing SEG's interest in SMG to 41.28%. SEG will issue new shares worth US$6.9 million to existing SMG shareholders at S$0.09 each.

site_title: Europe prepares for populists taking power in Italy
summary: Italy's two populist parties, the Five Star movement and the far-right League, have signed a pact to form a coalition government. The deal, which must be approved by both parties, comes after a dozen weeks of negotiations following Italy's inconclusive March election. The coalition, which won more than half the vote, poses a significant threat to the euro zone's future due to Italy's high debt load and banking sector stress. The new administration is expected to push for structural reforms, but its stability and ability to implement them remain uncertain, raising concerns about the country's future and the potential for political paralysis.

site_title: Sony buys EMI Music Publishing in US$1.9b deal
summary: Sony has acquired EMI Music Publishing in a $1.9 billion deal, giving the Japanese firm an indirect stake of approximately 90% in the music publishing company. The deal, signed with Abu Dhabi-based investment firm Mubadala, values EMI at $4.75 billion. Sony boss Kenichiro Yoshida said the acquisition will allow the company to maintain its No 1 position in the music publishing industry, driven by a resurgence in the music business due to subscription-based streaming services. The deal is subject to regulatory approvals and closing conditions.

site_title: An egg a day may keep the doctor away
summary: A study of half a million Chinese adults found that eating an egg a day may lower the risk of heart disease and stroke. The study, published in the journal Heart, found daily egg consumption was associated with a 26% lower risk of hemorrhagic stroke and an 18% lower risk of death from cardiovascular disease. However, specialists cautioned that the results do not prove that eating eggs directly lowers CVD risk, citing factors such as the study's affluent participants and the complexity of diet.

site_title: Most earnings meet forecasts, but ratio for those off-mark worsens
summary: Most corporate earnings in Singapore met forecasts for the March quarter, with a 2-1 ratio of misses to beats, a deterioration from the previous quarter. The commodities/consumer sector and Reits were particularly disappointing, while banks and tech manufacturing services stocks were more resilient. Despite the mixed results, Citi Research still expects earnings growth of 9% for the year, driven by a synchronized global recovery. Notable performers included Genting Singapore and Singapore Airlines, which reported higher-than-expected profits.

site_title: Is O&M still relevant to Keppel Corp's new vision?
summary: Keppel Corp's new vision seeks to reposition itself as a solutions provider for sustainable urbanization, moving away from its traditional offshore and marine (O&M) business. The conglomerate has created a new platform, Keppel Urban Solutions, to pursue smart city developments. However, the fate of its O&M unit remains uncertain, with some questioning the value-add of near-shore structures and potential job losses. Despite losing out on several key field development projects, Keppel O&M won a rig-building order, and the company's shareholders acknowledge the need to groom new toplines. A merger between Keppel O&M and SembMarine has been suggested, but Keppel Corp has not ruled out the possibility.

site_title: China to cut car import duty to 15%
summary: China will cut the import duty on passenger cars to 15% effective July 1, a move aimed at boosting car makers such as BMW and Ford Motor Co. The reduction follows a truce between the US and China to defuse trade tensions and follows previous tariff cuts on consumer products. The move will benefit European and Asian manufacturers, including luxury car brands like Audi and Toyota's Lexus, which will see a reduction in import duty from 25% to 6%. The change is part of China's efforts to open its economy and demonstrate its commitment to trade cooperation.

site_title: German economists oppose 'high risk' Macron euro zone reform plan
summary: German economists, including former ECB board member Juergen Stark and Ifo think tank head Hans-Werner Sinn, oppose French President Emmanuel Macron's euro zone reform proposals, calling them "high risk." They argue that creating a separate euro zone budget and appointing a finance minister would weaken incentives for banks to sort out bad loans and undermine the ECB's monetary policy. The economists instead suggest focusing on structural reforms and implementing an "orderly insolvency procedure" for countries and an "orderly exit procedure" for those that fail to reform.

site_title: Losers abound in muted Tuesday trade
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 5.05 points, or 0.14%, to 3,543.18 on Tuesday, with losers outperforming gainers 230 to 157. Weak liquidity and a lack of strong leads contributed to the muted trade. Bourse operators and property developers, such as Singapore Exchange and City Developments, were among the losers. Analysts attributed the decline to the fading optimism from US-China trade talks and the potential for increased oil prices due to the deteriorating situation in Venezuela.

site_title: GIC in joint venture to acquire office portfolio in California's 'Silicon Beach'
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, GIC, has formed a joint venture with Rockwood Capital to acquire a portfolio of Class A office assets in Playa Vista, California. The portfolio includes Water's Edge and Playa Jefferson, totaling 510,000 sq ft. Construction on the second phase of Water's Edge is underway, with completion expected in 2020. GIC expects the market to remain supply-constrained, benefiting the growing technology and creative industries in the area, dubbed 'Silicon Beach'.

site_title: Malaysian anti-graft chief: 'I was sent a bullet to my house'
summary: Malaysia's anti-graft chief, Mohd Shukri Abdull, revealed that a 2015 probe into ex-premier Najib Razak's suspicious activities was shut down after witnesses disappeared and officers were intimidated. Abdull claimed that his home was targeted with a bullet, and he was restored to the agency by the new government following Najib's election defeat. The probe was allegedly aimed at charging Najib for siphoning funds from a state fund, but the agency was effectively silenced to prevent the charges from moving forward.

site_title: BOE's Carney says economy will bounce back
summary: BOE governor Mark Carney said Britain's economy will bounce back from a weak start to the year, despite heavy snowstorms, and interest rates may still rise. The BOE kept rates at 0.5% in May, contrary to market expectations. Carney stated that the economy's weakness was temporary and idiosyncratic, rather than a change in circumstances. He also emphasized that households and firms expect a rate hike in 2018, but at a slow pace.

site_title: Polyester, nylon clothes may be caught in UK curbs on plastics
summary: The UK Treasury plans to announce a package of new taxes to combat plastic waste, including taxes on synthetic microfibres from polyester and nylon clothes, in its November budget statement. The move aims to address the issue of microfibres polluting the world's oceans and harming marine life. The proposed tax is seen as a way to encourage clothing manufacturers and retailers to use more sustainable materials and reduce shedding. The Treasury has received over 100,000 responses to a consultation on the issue, and Prime Minister Theresa May's government aims to eliminate plastic waste by 2042.

site_title: Citic Envirotech CEO to step down, succeeded by exec chairman
summary: Citic Envirotech's CEO Lin Yucheng will step down on June 1, 2018, and be succeeded by executive chairman Hao Weibao. Lin, who founded the company in 2003, will become a non-executive director and adviser, citing a desire to step aside from daily operations. Hao Weibao thanked Lin for his 15 years of leadership, describing his performance as "outstanding." The company's stock ended trading at S$0.68 on the day, down 1.45%.

site_title: Sovereign investor flows to global markets turn net positive in Q1
summary: Sovereign wealth fund investor flows to global markets turned net positive in Q1 for the first time since 2014, with a net US$4.3 billion placed with external asset managers. Allocations to non-US passive equity strategies drove the change, with European and emerging markets equities attracting US$5.6 billion and US$4.2 billion, respectively. This is the first positive net inflow since 2014, but only 38.8% of products reported net inflows, with global equity and fixed income experiencing net outflows.

site_title: Hyflux seeks court protection to reorganise business, debt
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-based water treatment company, has filed for court protection to reorganize its business and address its debt pile. The company has applied for a 30-day moratorium against creditors and may seek an additional six-month extension. This move comes after the company's power business suffered from sustained hits from Singapore's electricity market weakness. Hyflux aims to protect its core businesses, focus on growth, and complete projects to generate steady cash flow. The company has a net loss of S$22.21 million and S$1.3 billion of net borrowings.

site_title: China, US near deal on ZTE reprieve; Beijing cuts auto tariffs
summary: US and China near a deal to lift the seven-year ban on ZTE Corp, a Chinese telecoms gear maker, in exchange for China removing tariffs on US agricultural products and buying more American farm goods. Beijing also announced cuts to auto tariffs, easing trade tensions between the two nations. The agreement comes after talks last week, with the US setting aside demands for China to revamp its industrial policy in exchange for buying more farm products.

site_title: Microsoft will share data, tools to speed Chinese AI development
summary: Microsoft will establish an open platform with four Chinese universities to share AI data and tools, accelerating development in the country. The platform aims to democratize AI and compete with local giants like Baidu and Alibaba. Microsoft showcased its AI chip system, Project Brainwave, and digital assistant, XiaoIce, in Beijing. The move follows Microsoft's global focus on AI, with 8,000 employees working on AI products and tools. The partnership seeks to capitalize on China's growing AI market, which is dominated by local players, and gain clients from Amazon and Alphabet.

site_title: US: Wall Street rises at open as US-China trade talks progress
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Tuesday, boosted by tech gains as US-China trade talks progressed. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.14%, the S&P 500 gained 0.20%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.36%. The positive momentum followed a record-breaking session the previous day, despite ongoing trade tensions and tariff threats.

images.alt_text: Wall Street opened higher for the second straight day on Tuesday, boosted by gains in tech stocks as trade talks between the United States and China gained momentum.

site_title: Iran tells Europe to step up and save nuclear deal
summary: Iran has criticized US threats of "strongest sanctions in history" and urged European powers to step up and save the international nuclear deal. Iran's military and political leaders have issued defiant statements, warning that the US will face a strong response. European powers, including Germany, are under pressure to defend the deal, with German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas planning to meet with US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. European companies are worried about US sanctions, and some have already started pulling out. To salvage the deal, European signatories must show strength in the face of American pressure, according to an Iranian parliament official.

site_title: Cordlife slumps 7.4%, queried by SGX on unusual price moves
summary: Cordlife Group shares plummet 7.4% to S$0.88 after the private cord-blood banker received a Singapore Exchange (SGX) query on unusual price movements. The counter had risen 28% the previous day, prompting the query. Cordlife attributed the price spike to its Q3 results, which showed a net profit of S$843,000 and a 24.5% increase in revenue. The company is in talks on corporate development opportunities, but no definitive agreements have been reached.

site_title: Raffles Education partners CFLD International to set up educational hubs in S-E Asia
summary: Raffles Education Corporation has partnered with CFLD International to establish educational hubs across South-east Asia. The first hub will be built in Indonesia's Tangerang New City, featuring a Raffles-owned college and pre-school, along with third-party providers for enrichment classes and tuition centers. This marks Raffles' expansion into the region, with CFLD International serving as the master planner and operator of the "New Industry Cities."

site_title: A$ at one-month high, kiwi snaps losing streak
summary: The Australian dollar reached a one-month high of US$0.7600, boosted by rising oil prices and conciliatory talks on trade between the US and China. Meanwhile, the New Zealand dollar broke a five-session losing streak after a strong session. The Aussie's surge above key chart resistance was seen as a positive sign for the country's economy. The news comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: This rally in the Aussie dollar may fade as high household debt and low wage growth can weigh on domestic consumption and broader economic activity, says AxiTrader's Greg McKenna.

site_title: Technics to transfer listing status to Insonotech
summary: TECHNICS Oil and Gas has agreed to transfer its listing status on the Singapore Exchange to privately-owned Insonotech for S$5 million. Insonotech will issue new shares to creditors and shareholders. The transfer will result in Technics O&G's delisting and Insonotech's listing on the Catalist. The proposed transfer is subject to shareholder and creditor approvals.

site_title: MAS to simplify rules to improve flexibility for market operators and speed to market for new products
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to simplify rules for market operators to improve flexibility and speed to market for new products. MAS proposes a new multi-tier regime for market operators, including Recognised Market Operators (RMO) Tier 1, Tier 2, and Tier 3, to better match regulatory requirements to risks posed by different types of operators. The new regime aims to facilitate innovation in financial services while safeguarding investors' interests, with the goal of allowing market operators to serve retail investors and launch new products more quickly.

site_title: Govt will adjust pace of public-sector projects to facilitate transformation
summary: Singapore's Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat announced the government will adjust the pace of public-sector projects to facilitate transformation, with a focus on quality over price competition. The government will also review tender evaluation frameworks to prioritize firms with consistent good performance. This is part of a broader effort to tap research, innovation, and enterprise capabilities to help local companies innovate and stay competitive in a rapidly urbanizing and technologically driven Asia.

site_title: In fresh blow to Nobels, Swedish court blocks plans for new centre
summary: A Swedish court blocked plans for a new Nobel Centre in Stockholm, citing damage to a cultural heritage site, inconvenience to neighboring properties, and inadequate traffic solutions. The centre, intended to host exhibitions and ceremonies, was financially backed by Swedish icons, but its construction was opposed by the National Museum, King Carl XVI Gustaf, and businessman Fredrik Lundberg. The Stockholm City Council plans to appeal the ruling, which comes at a tumultuous time for the Nobel Prize, following a sexual misconduct scandal that led to the Swedish Academy's decision not to award the literature prize this year.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's stocks closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.55 points to 1,845.03. The decline was attributed to a higher number of losers (624) compared to gainers (356) in trading volume of 2.34 billion shares worth RM2.74 billion.

site_title: Conservationists fight to save animals as mass extinction looms
summary: Conservationists are fighting to save animal species threatened by mass extinction. Species are vanishing at an accelerating pace worldwide, with some populations dwindling to just a few individuals. Efforts include captive breeding, habitat restoration, and removal of predators. Examples include the Mauritius kestrel, reduced from 4 individuals in 1974, and nursing baby pandas and orangutans. Conservationists are using various methods, from shaming multinationals to protecting endangered species, to give them a second chance.

site_title: Raffles Education partners CFLD International to set up educational hubs across South-east Asia
summary: Raffles Education Corporation has partnered with CFLD International to establish educational hubs across South-east Asia. The first hub will be built in Indonesia's Tangerang New City, featuring a Raffles-owned college and pre-school, along with third-party providers offering enrichment classes. This marks the beginning of a strategic partnership to develop educational infrastructure in the region.

site_title: Consumers are repaying cell-phone debt before making car payment
summary: US consumers are prioritizing mobile phone payments over car loans, a shift driven by the increasing importance of mobile devices in daily life. This trend is reflected in the growing market for asset-backed securities (ABS) backed by mobile phone loans, with Verizon Communications Inc issuing $7.7 billion in bonds since 2016. Experts say the shift in consumer behavior is driven by technological change and the decreasing importance of cars as a central asset, making mobile phone payments a high priority for consumers.

site_title: Global Yellow Pages units enter into New Zealand land acquisition, property sales
summary: Global Yellow Pages has entered into a conditional agreement to purchase a 1.9905-hectare plot of land in Pauanui, New Zealand for NZ$6 million. The company plans to build holiday accommodation on the site. GYP also entered into agreements to sell six units of its Remarkables Residences development in Queenstown and has a separate agreement to purchase a nearby property through its investment vehicle Global Media Holdings. GYP's CEO and his daughters have abstained from board deliberations due to potential conflicts of interest.

site_title: Malaysia's foreign stock inflows for 2018 just got wiped out
summary: Foreign investors have pulled out of Malaysia's stock market, wiping out $937.8 million in inflows from 2018. This follows a 11-day sell-off of $949 million worth of stocks, with the benchmark FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index falling 0.5%. Experts, including Sat Duhra, attribute this to concerns over the new coalition government led by 92-year-old Mahathir Mohamad, citing fiscal indiscipline and risk of economic growth. Local investors, however, have continued to buy stocks, driving the index to 16.1 times its 12-month forward earnings.

site_title: YuuZoo's former chairman provides bond, gets passport back
summary: Former YuuZoo chairman Thomas Zilliacus has provided a bond to report back to the Singapore Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) on June 4 to assist in the investigation into the company's potential breach of the Securities and Futures Act. Zilliacus also provided a complete chronological summary of YuuZoo's financial announcements from 2015-2017. His passport has been returned, allowing him to travel overseas. The company has also taken action regarding a notice of compliance from the Singapore Exchange, reducing its "other income" and impairing a significant portion of its assets.

site_title: TLV in equity deal to enter China retail market
summary: TLV Holdings, a Singapore-based jeweller, has acquired a 49% equity stake in Shimao Jewellery from Maoming Liutao Zhubao Chuangyi Chanye Co Ltd for 1.96 million yuan (S$411,000). The acquisition will fund the entry of TLV into China's jewellery retail market, eliminating the need for a joint venture. Despite a 48% increase in net profit to S$3.2 million, TLV's revenue dipped 1.7% to S$111.81 million. The move is seen as a strategic expansion into China's growing retail market.

site_title: Samurai 2K Aerosol expects 'significantly higher' profit, revenue for FY2018
summary: Samurai 2K Aerosol, a Catalist-listed company, expects "significantly higher" revenue and profit for FY2018 due to stronger demand for its aerosol paint products, particularly in the Indonesian market. The company attributes this growth to enhanced marketing initiatives. The company's counter ended trading up 2.08% following the announcement, with its unaudited FY2018 results to be released by May 30.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia's restructuring of Xinfei unit progresses
summary: Hong Leong Asia announced progress in restructuring its consumer products unit, Xinfei, which ceased manufacturing in November 2017 due to a challenging market environment in China. The company obtained approval from the majority of Xinfei's creditors to proceed with a restructuring plan. The plan involves transferring equity holdings to a new China-incorporated investor through a tender process, with creditors owed small amounts to be paid in full. The repayment of other creditors will depend on the proceeds from the sale.

site_title: Bitcoin a shadowy new realm as US weighs security clearances
summary: The US government is weighing the security clearance of individuals who invest or trade in Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies. The Pentagon is struggling to define the currencies, with some seeing them as new investments and payment methods, while others worry they provide potential vehicles for illegal activities. The debate matters for the national security apparatus, which has to track over 4 million people with security clearances. Experts say a clear policy is needed to avoid hampering the Pentagon's efforts to expand its operations in cyberspace and to prevent a "huge negative impact" on the growing market.

site_title: The Hour Glass clocks moderate 2% FY18 profit rise; expects to remain profitable
summary: The Hour Glass, a luxury watch retailer, reported a 2% profit rise in FY18 to S$49.82 million, despite a 1% decline in revenue to S$691.65 million. A one-time relocation expense in Australia contributed to higher operating expenses. The company declared a final dividend of 2 Singapore cents per share and expects to remain profitable. It plans to maintain its 38 boutiques in 10 cities and improve its retail network and customer engagement.

site_title: Europe: Autos, banks fuel shares as Italy recovers
summary: European shares rose to a two-month high, driven by gains in autos and bank stocks. Italian shares recovered from Monday's dip, with Fiat Chrysler and Volkswagen leading the gains. Asian stocks fell due to surging oil prices and inflation concerns. Investors await the final details of Italy's new government, and smaller companies like Halfords warned on profits.

site_title: Sick UAE property market seen propped up by longer visas
summary: The UAE's property market, which has been stagnant since oil prices collapsed in 2014, is expected to be boosted by the government's decision to extend visas to 10 years for certain professionals. This move aims to attract more foreign buyers and stimulate demand for residential and commercial properties. Shares in several property companies in Dubai and Abu Dhabi have jumped on the news, and developers are offering incentives to attract buyers, including luxury cars and apartments. However, critics argue that permanent residency is still needed to encourage expatriates to buy property.

site_title: Amazon eyes Latam expansion, opens Argentina office
summary: Amazon is expanding its cloud computing operations in Latin America, opening an office in Buenos Aires, Argentina, and increasing its presence in countries such as Brazil, Chile, Colombia, and Mexico. Amazon Web Services (AWS) vice president Teresa Carlson stated that the company aims to be a partner in Latin America, leveraging opportunities and talent. The move follows discussions between Amazon and Argentina's President Mauricio Macri about installing a data center in the country. This expansion is part of Amazon's growing web services unit, which contributed to the company's $1.6 billion profit last quarter.

site_title: EU agrees to start trade talks with Australia, New Zealand
summary: The European Union has agreed to start trade talks with Australia and New Zealand, aiming to forge new alliances amid rising US trade tensions. The talks, set to begin later this year, will focus on comprehensive agreements, with caveats on opening EU markets to farm produce. EU exports to the two countries are forecast to increase by a third if trade agreements are struck, and the bloc is seeking ambitious deals. European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker aims to conclude the talks within the next two years, ahead of Britain's potential trade negotiations with the two countries.

images.alt_text: European Union countries cleared the way on Tuesday for the bloc to begin free trade talks with Australia and New Zealand in a drive to forge new alliances as trade tensions with the United States increase.

site_title: Deutsche Bank's chairman to face tough questions at annual meeting
summary: Deutsche Bank's chairman Paul Achleitner and CEO Christian Sewing will face tough questions at the annual meeting, with investors calling for quicker results amid a loss-making streak and dwindling revenue. The bank plans to scale back its investment bank and focus on retail banking and asset management. A vocal faction may vote to oust Achleitner, while shareholders urge Sewing to deliver quickly and effectively, amid concerns the bank can't afford more restructuring years. The meeting will provide an opportunity for investors to vent after years of management changes and strategy shifts.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) faces an interim injunction on its new India equity derivative products, with its counter falling. Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, GIC, forms a joint venture to acquire a California office portfolio. The Housing Board launched 3,970 BTO flats in Sengkang, Yishun, Toa Payoh, and Tampines. Malaysia will review the implementation of a high-speed rail project to Singapore and a $14 billion east coast rail project. Hyflux considers seeking court protection for creditor talks, while SembMarine completes topsides for France's Total. Singapore shares close down 0.14% on Tuesday.

site_title: Australia investigators defend MH370 out-of-control scenario
summary: Australian investigators defended their findings that missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 was out of control when it crashed into the ocean, contrary to theories that a rogue pilot deliberately ditched the plane. The investigation, led by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau, concluded that the jet was making a high-speed out-of-control descent when it hit the water. Key evidence, including the right outboard flap configuration, suggests the plane was not being controlled successfully at the end. Analysis of the last transmission also points to fuel exhaustion as the likely cause.

site_title: Oil rises towards US$80 as supply concerns mount
summary: Oil prices rose towards US$80 a barrel on Tuesday, driven by concerns over falling Venezuelan crude output and potential Iranian export drops. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries plus Russia and other non-members have implemented a supply-cutting deal, while strong global demand supports prices. Brent crude, the global benchmark, reached US$79.85 a barrel, its highest since November 2014.

site_title: "I was sent a bullet" probing 1MDB, says Malaysian anti-graft chief
summary: Malaysia's anti-graft chief, Shukri Abdull, accused former Prime Minister Najib Razak of trying to silence him and his agency after they attempted to charge him with siphoning funds from 1MDB in 2015. Abdull said he was sent a bullet and received police protection after he tried to record a statement from Najib. The new Malaysian government has reopened investigations into 1MDB and set up a task force to recover the stolen funds, with the US Department of Justice also continuing to pursue the case.

site_title: Off colour: Pollution turns India's white marble Taj Mahal green
summary: India's Taj Mahal, a 17th-century white marble mausoleum, is turning yellow and green due to pollution from the city of Agra. The monument, one of the world's seven wonders, is exposed to filthy air, sewage, and dust from vehicles, resulting in the growth of tiny insects that stain the marble. The Indian Supreme Court has criticized the government for not taking sufficient measures to preserve the monument. Restorers are using a clay mineral paste to clean the marble, and activists are concerned about the weakening of the wooden foundations due to the falling water table.

site_title: Singapore CEOs optimistic about growth; cyberthreats cited as top risk: KPMG poll
summary: Singapore CEOs are optimistic about the global economy over the next three years, with 77% confident about the global economy and 92% about their firms' prospects. However, they cite cyberthreats as the top risk, with 55% expecting less than 2% top-line growth. The top risks in Singapore include cybersecurity, operational risk, and environmental risks. Despite this, 73% of Singapore CEOs plan to collaborate with innovative startups, and 62% will increase investment in disruption detection.

site_title: Harry Kane named England's World Cup captain
summary: England's Football Association announced that Tottenham striker Harry Kane will be the country's captain at the 2018 World Cup in Russia. Manager Gareth Southgate has chosen Kane, 24, who has scored 12 goals in 23 international appearances, to lead the team. Kane was previously handed the armband for the qualifier against Scotland last June and has skippered the side on three further occasions. The decision was made after a team meeting, with Southgate praising Kane's outstanding personal qualities and leadership.

site_title: China cutting car import duty, say sources
summary: China has cut the import duty on passenger cars to 15%, boosting carmakers such as BMW and Ford, amid a truce between US President Donald Trump's administration and Chinese officials to defuse trade war tensions. The move reduces the levy from 25% and will benefit European and Asian manufacturers. Luxury sales leader Audi, part of Volkswagen, and Tesla will also benefit, while Chinese carmakers will experience less impact due to the reduced tariff. The decision is seen as a conciliatory stance from China, following recent steps to ease trade tensions.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon trading at 3,552.41, up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading with the Straits Times Index rising 4.18 points, or 0.1%, to 3,552.41 at 1:01pm on Tuesday. Losers outnumbered gainers 156 to 135, with 527.3 million shares worth S$388.7 million changing hands. Active stocks included Magnus Energy and Ezion, with Venture Corp falling 1.9% and Genting Singapore rising 0.8%.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.18% to 22,960.34 on Tuesday, snapping a three-day winning streak, as investors locked in profits ahead of North Korea-related events. The broader Topix index also declined 0.23%. This move came after a series of political events surrounding North Korea, which led to profit-taking.

site_title: Adobe buys Magento for US$1.68b to target e-commerce
summary: Adobe Systems Inc. agreed to buy e-commerce company Magento for US$1.68 billion, aiming to capture a bigger slice of the digital-commerce industry. Magento offers software to build and run web stores, handle online purchases, and competes with Shopify Inc. The deal is Adobe's third-biggest acquisition and is expected to close in the third quarter of Adobe's fiscal year. The purchase will see Adobe battle cloud-based commerce services Salesforce, Oracle, and SAP SE, and is part of its Experience Cloud, which generates less revenue than its creative software offerings.

site_title: Thai protesters confront police, anti-government march blocked
summary: Anti-government protesters in Thailand confronted police on Tuesday as they attempted to march from a university to Government House, demanding a general election by November. The march was blocked by police barriers and a row of officers, with some protesters fainting. The military government has repeatedly delayed the election, sparking a public perception crisis. Despite the confrontation, protesters claimed to have planned a peaceful march, with one organizer stating they had no intention of using violence. The government has warned protesters of arrest and imprisonment if they continue their march.

site_title: Singapore shares close down 0.14% on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed down 0.14% on Tuesday, ending at 3,543.18 points, after a lackluster session with 1.06 billion shares changing hands for S$894.9 million. Losers outperformed gainers 230-157, with thin liquidity contributing to the decline.

site_title: UDG Healthcare disappoints on weaker Sharp business
summary: UDG Healthcare reported a weaker-than-expected first-half performance at its Sharp division, with revenue falling 4.4% to US$118.6 million due to weaker demand for bottling services. Operating profit declined 1.6% due to lower demand. The company lowered its outlook for Sharp, resulting in a 6% drop in shares. The decline was attributed to a decline in bottling services at the US business, which is Sharp's largest contributor to revenue.

site_title: Trump retreats from China tariffs amid White House trade discord
summary: President Donald Trump has retreated from imposing tariffs on Chinese goods due to White House discord over trade strategy and concerns about North Korea negotiations. The decision was made after farm-state Republicans lobbied the White House to resolve trade differences with China. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said the administration's plan to impose tariffs had been suspended, with China agreeing to purchase unspecified amounts of American farm products. However, critics, including former chief strategist Steven Bannon, have criticized the deal as a capitulation, and divisions within the administration remain raw.

site_title: Five dead, dozens quarantined as virus fears spread in India
summary: At least five people have died in southern India from the Nipah virus, a deadly disease carried by fruit bats, with over 90 people in quarantine. The virus, fatal in 70% of cases, has killed more than 260 people in Malaysia, Bangladesh, and India since 1998. Authorities have ordered emergency measures to control the outbreak, and a nursing assistant who died after treating patients has been hailed as a hero. The World Health Organization has named Nipah as one of the eight priority diseases that could cause an epidemic.

site_title: Singapore telco Circles.Life rolls out free mobile plan with a catch
summary: Circles.Life, a Singaporean telco, launched a free mobile plan with 1GB of data, 30 minutes of talk-time, and 10 SMS per month, but with a catch. Consumers must buy something every three months to keep their line, such as a 1GB data add-on for S$8 or a 2GB add-on for S$12. The plan aims to empower elderly users and those who need a backup line, with no strings attached, according to Circles.Life's co-founder.

site_title: Malaysia's embattled Najib questioned by anti-corruption agency
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak was questioned by the country's anti-corruption agency about a suspicious transfer of $10.6 million into his bank account. The funds are a fraction of billions allegedly siphoned from state fund 1MDB. Najib has denied wrongdoing, but the new government has reopened investigations and vowed to recover money from the fund. The US Department of Justice has also committed to pursuing investigations into 1MDB and plans to work with Malaysian authorities to recover assets.

site_title: Intel finds another chip exploit, says fix already in place
summary: Intel has found another chip exploit, related to the Spectre and Meltdown vulnerabilities, but says a fix is already in place. The company claims no evidence of the vulnerability being used to hack computers and notes that browser-based mitigations are available to safeguard systems. The new variant could potentially be exploited via code run inside a web browser, but Intel says fixes for the original issues should have already closed off this avenue. The use of patches may slow down computers by 2-8%.

site_title: Hatten Land partners FundPlaces to launch blockchain platform for malls and hotels
summary: Hatten Land, a CATALIST-listed property developer, partners with proptech startup FundPlaces to launch a blockchain platform called StayCay for hotels and malls in Southeast Asia. The platform allows for "hotel tokens" to be exchanged for discounted packages and operates a rewards program. The platform aims to boost brand loyalty and expand to include third-party hotels and retail merchants. It is expected to go live by December 2018 and will utilize more than 3,400 hotel rooms and 5,000 retail outlets.

site_title: US, China nearing deal to remove US sales ban against ZTE: sources
summary: US and China are nearing a deal to lift a US ban on supplying telecommunications firm ZTE Corp, according to sources. In exchange, China may remove tariffs on US agricultural products and increase imports. The deal is part of ongoing trade negotiations between the two countries.

site_title: Hot stock: Cordlife down 9.5%
summary: Cordlife Group shares fell 9.5% to S$0.86 apiece after announcing talks on corporate development opportunities in response to unusual price movements. The company reported a net profit of S$843,000 for the three months ended March 31, reversing a net loss in the previous year. Revenue rose 24.5% to S$17.71 million, driven by contributions from its Hong Kong cord-blood bank acquisition. No dividends were declared for the current financial period.

site_title: Gold prices slip as investors eye riskier assets
summary: Gold prices slipped slightly on Tuesday, hovering near a 2018 low, as a firm dollar and optimism in global markets reduced appetite for the precious metal. Spot gold eased 0.1% to $1,290.66 per ounce, its lowest since Dec. 27. The dip came despite a previous day's surge after US President Trump announced fresh tariffs on Canada. The dollar's near five-month highs also contributed to the decline.

site_title: SGX faces interim injunction on its new India equity derivative products; counter falls
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has faced an interim injunction on its new India equity derivative products following an application by the National Stock Exchange of India in the Bombay High Court. As a result, SGX shares fell 2.09% to S$7.48. The new products were set to be listed in June, but the halt in trading has halted these plans.

site_title: Indonesia's most active volcano rumbles, public ordered to stay away
summary: Indonesia's most active volcano, Mount Merapi, has shown danger signs with a series of small eruptions, prompting authorities to order villagers to leave and hikers to stay clear within a 3 km radius. The 2010 eruptions killed over 350 people, and authorities are taking no chances. Hiking is also temporarily prohibited. The national disaster mitigation agency has issued the warning after plumes of smoke and ash billowed into the sky late on Monday.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's most active volcano, Mount Merapi on densely populated Java island, has shown danger signs with a series of small eruptions, and authorities have ordered villagers living on its slopes to leave and hikers to stay clear.

site_title: French public sector, rail workers go on strike
summary: French public sector staff and rail workers are going on strike Tuesday to protest proposed reforms by President Emmanuel Macron, who aims to reduce public spending and jobs. The strike, which will affect schools, flights, and energy infrastructure, is the third since Macron's election in 2017 and is backed by all unions representing civil servants. Macron's centrist government plans to cut 120,000 jobs by 2022 and scrap special status for civil servants, sparking widespread protests. The strike is expected to cause major disruption and has sparked accusations that Macron wants to destroy public services.

site_title: Polyester, nylon clothes may be caught in UK curbs on plastics
summary: UK Chancellor Philip Hammond is urged to tax polyester and nylon clothes to curb plastic waste in oceans. The Treasury plans to announce a package of new taxes in its budget statement in November, following a consultation that attracted over 100,000 responses. Synthetic microfibre pollution is 5 times more prevalent than plastic microbeads and bags, and a tax on these materials could reduce shedding and encourage sustainable materials. The UK aims to eliminate plastic waste by 2042, with current policies covering half of the plastic waste in oceans.

site_title: Malaysia's finance minister takes office as budget doubts linger
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has sworn in Lim Guan Eng, 57, as the country's first ethnic Chinese finance minister in over four decades. Lim's priorities include finding new income sources, reintroducing fuel subsidies, and boosting minimum wages to address rising living standards. Mahathir's administration is also focused on controlling debt levels, with a reported 1 trillion ringgit debt. Lim, who was sworn in with 13 other cabinet ministers, faces the challenge of replacing the lost revenue from the scrapped 6% goods-and-services tax.

site_title: China blames Australia for strained relations as trade suffers
summary: China has issued a rebuke to Australia, blaming the country for strained relations, which have led to difficulties in trade. Foreign Minister Wang Yi said Australia's traditional thinking and approach to China need to change. The spat began in December when Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull introduced anti-foreign interference laws, which China views as a threat. The US, Japan, and South-east Asian countries are watching the situation closely, with some analysts warning that the relationship may continue to cool off. China is concerned about the impact on trade, including stalled beef exports and delayed shipments.

images.alt_text: China has issued a fresh rebuke to Australia as tensions between the two nations continued to simmer, with Foreign Minister Wang Yi blaming its trading partner for the spat and saying it was up to Australia to get their relationship back on track.

site_title: Malaysia says to review rail project to Singapore, east coast
summary: Malaysia's new Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced plans to review several mega projects, including the high-speed rail line to Singapore and the RM55 billion East Coast Rail Line. The review aims to ensure transparency and avoid direct deals, following criticism of previous administrations' projects. The government will also assess the implementation of other projects, including the rail line to Singapore and a US$14 billion east-coast rail project. The review is part of Mahathir's efforts to revamp the country's infrastructure and economic policies.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda says major central banks cautious of issuing digital currencies
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that US and most European central banks are "extremely cautious" about issuing digital currencies as substitutes for cash. In contrast, Sweden is an exception due to its low cash usage, prompting the central bank to consider digital currencies. The BOJ itself has no plans to issue digital currencies for public use, with Kuroda emphasizing caution over the concept.

site_title: Brazil truck drivers block soy roads to protest fuel price increases
summary: Brazilian truck drivers blocked major highways in 18 states to protest fuel price increases, which have surged nearly 50% in less than a year. The demonstrations added pressure on the federal government to provide relief, with some drivers allowing passenger vehicles to pass through. The government is considering a tax cut to reduce fuel prices, but analysts warn of worsening Brazil's large fiscal deficit. The protests, led by grain exporters and oilseeds crushers, have not significantly disrupted agricultural goods transport.

site_title: SembMarine completes 3 fixed platform topsides for France's Total
summary: SembCorp Marine has completed three integrated fixed platform topsides for Total's Culzean gas field in the UK North Sea. The 30,000-tonne topsides, built over 32 months, will handle 500 million standard cubic feet of gas and 25,000 barrels of condensate per day. The successful completion strengthens SembCorp Marine's track record of delivering safe and reliable engineering solutions for demanding oil and gas field projects.

site_title: Turkey's lira trades near record lows against US dollar
summary: Turkey's lira traded near record lows against the US dollar, dipping to 4.5860 at 0518 GMT, amid concerns over double-digit inflation and the central bank's inability to control it. The lira has lost around 17% this year, following a weakest-ever level of 4.5995 on Monday. Investors are worried about the impact of inflation on the country's economy and the central bank's ability to address it.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly higher on Tuesday, STI up 0.1% to 3,550.4
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% to 3,550.4 on Tuesday, driven by a US trade war truce between China and the US. The Straits Times Index gained 2.17 points, with gainers outnumbering losers 80 to 40. DBS rose 0.3% to S$29.50, while Singtel fell 0.3% to S$3.40. The market saw 46.5 million shares worth S$59.6 million change hands.

site_title: Sony buys EMI Music Publishing in US$1.9b deal
summary: Sony has acquired EMI Music Publishing in a US$1.9 billion deal, giving the Japanese entertainment giant an indirect stake of approximately 90% in the music publishing firm and record label. The acquisition values EMI at US$4.75 billion and includes rights to 2.1 million pieces of music. Sony boss Kenichiro Yoshida said the deal is a move to maintain its number-one position in the music publishing industry, driven by the resurgence of the music business due to subscription-based streaming services. The deal is subject to regulatory approvals.

site_title: GIC in venture to acquire and develop office portfolio in California's 'Silicon Beach'
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has formed a joint venture with Rockwood Capital to acquire and develop a portfolio of Class A office assets in Playa Vista, California's 'Silicon Beach'. The portfolio includes two existing properties, Water's Edge and Playa Jefferson, with a new 160,000 sq ft office building, WE3, currently under construction. The venture aims to capitalize on the growing technology and creative industries in the Los Angeles market, where GIC expects continued growth and expansion.

site_title: HDB puts on sale 3,970 BTO flats in Sengkang, Yishun, Toa Payoh and Tampines
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched 3,970 Build-To-Order (BTO) flats across four projects in Sengkang, Yishun, Toa Payoh, and Tampines, marking the second BTO exercise this year. Prices range from S$76,000 for a two-room flat to over S$422,000 for a five-room flat. The exercise also marks the first time measures announced at the Ministry of National Development's budget debate will take effect, including a revised proximity condition for the Married Child Priority Scheme. Applications can be submitted online from May 22 to May 27.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as trade deal euphoria abates
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed day on Tuesday, as investors tempered their optimism over the China-US trade deal, citing a lack of details and concerns over intellectual property. Oil prices rose after the US unveiled harsh sanctions on Iran and Venezuela. Despite initial fears of a trade war, markets fizzled out, with some analysts describing the agreement as a "ceasefire" rather than a "peace treaty."

images.alt_text: Out of the 1,400 jobs on offer at the career fair in Our Tampines Hub, 280 were for professional, manager, executive and technician (PMET) roles.
