site_title: Microsoft to share data, tools to speed Chinese AI development
summary: Microsoft has established an open platform with four Chinese universities to share its data and tools on artificial intelligence (AI) to accelerate development in the Chinese market. The company demonstrated its AI chip system, Project Brainwave, and showcased its digital assistant, XiaoIce, which can emulate human voices and converse with humans. This move aims to win clients from local giants Baidu, Alibaba, and Tencent, and to democratize AI globally. Microsoft's efforts come as the global AI market continues to evolve, with the company investing heavily in AI products and advances.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Moya, Spackman, Cordlife, Tiong Seng
summary: Moya Holdings Asia launched a rights issue to raise up to S$132.5 million, with Tamaris Infrastructure fully subscribing for its entitlement. Spackman Entertainment Group agreed to buy a 7.52% stake in Spackman Media Group for US$6.9 million, increasing its interest to 41.28%.

site_title: Why Google supports a strong Asean Community
summary: Google supports a strong Asean Community by recognizing the region's incredible digital potential and its economic opportunity for every South-east Asian country. The digital sector is forecasted to have a US$200 billion Internet economy by 2025, with an annual growth rate of 27%. To maintain competitiveness, Asean must develop a robust digital strategy, harmonizing national regulations and streamlining reporting requirements. Google supports greater digital literacy and has launched initiatives such as Go Global to train small and medium enterprises on digital export capabilities, aiming to get 2,500 SMEs digital- and export-ready by 2019.

site_title: Strong prospects in Asean, but firms face hurdles to regional expansion: survey
summary: Companies in Asean are keen to expand, but face hurdles such as regulatory barriers, finding suitable business partners, and hiring talent. A survey of 129 leaders and business owners found that 4 in 5 have plans to expand in Asean over the next 3-5 years. Despite the region's strong growth prospects, respondents cited challenges including local rules, connectivity issues, and manpower constraints. The survey also highlighted the need for improved integration among Asean economies and more coordination at the government level.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 0.71 points to 1,854.29. Gainers outnumbered losers 130 to 66, with a total trading volume of 51.17 million lots worth RM23.95 million.

site_title: The Business Times-Standard Chartered Leaders' Survey 2018: Prospects & Challenges in Asean
summary: The Business Times reports on key economic developments in ASEAN. Vietnam reacts to the US tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. Malaysia's industrial production rises 0.3%, below forecast. The country also prepares to seize assets worth RM3 billion from Daim Zainuddin. GoTo shares are expected to rebound after a US$2.2 billion sell-off. Foreign investors return to Vietnam's stock market due to sweetened trade terms. The Malaysian central bank signals a rate cut to shield the economy from tariff threats, amid concerns of growth jitters.

site_title: As bitcoin world wobbles, mining rig company plans US$2b IPO
summary: Canaan Inc., a leading cryptocurrency mining rig supplier, plans to raise up to $2 billion in the world's largest bitcoin-focused IPO, despite the declining profitability of bitcoin mining. The company will present itself as a chip designer focused on artificial intelligence and blockchain, diversifying its business beyond bitcoin. This move comes as bitcoin's value has dropped to less than half of its December value and mining profitability has decreased by 60% compared to 2017.

site_title: Hyflux said to mull seeking court protection for creditor talks
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore water treatment firm, is considering seeking court protection to facilitate negotiations with creditors. The company may file an application for a 30-day moratorium to prevent creditors from taking actions that could hurt its financial position. Hyflux has been working with an adviser to manage its debt load and has been in talks to sell a stake in its Tuaspring project and negotiate a potential divestment of the Tianjin Dagang desalination plant. The move comes after the company reported a widened net loss of S$22.2 million in the three months ended March 31.

images.alt_text: Hyflux, the Singapore water treatment firm, is considering seeking a form of court protection to facilitate negotiations with creditors, people with knowledge of the matter said.

site_title: Protest greets fourth year of Thai junta rule
summary: Protesters in Bangkok marked the fourth year of Thailand's junta rule, with around 200 protesters camping out at Thammasat University. Despite Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha's promise of elections in February, protesters are growing impatient, citing broken promises and lack of guarantees. The protesters, a mix of student activists and former "Red Shirts," plan to march to Government House, citing concerns about the junta's grip on power and the potential for violent crackdowns. The protests come as Thailand's government has banned political gatherings and silenced criticism with legal charges and tight monitoring of activists.

images.alt_text: Mossack and Fonseca (above) were indicted on charges of money-laundering; they were detained because of the risk they might try to flee the country.

Scores of Thai police ringed a Bangkok university early Tuesday as protesters prepared to march to Government House to mark four years of junta rule, one of the largest acts of dissent since the military grabbed power.

site_title: US slaps heavy duties on Chinese steel shipped from Vietnam
summary: The US Commerce Department has imposed heavy duties on Chinese steel shipped from Vietnam, marking a victory for US steelmakers. The duties range from 199.76% to 256.44% on imports of cold-rolled and corrosion-resistant steel, respectively, after finding that up to 90% of the product's value originated from China. The move aims to curb Chinese steel producers from diverting shipments to Vietnam to circumvent US duties. The decision follows a similar EU finding and a surge in US imports of Vietnamese steel after US duties were imposed on Chinese steel in 2015.

site_title: Improved aviation infrastructure needed to spur growth in Asean, says Liew Mun Leong
summary: Economic growth in Asean countries can be accelerated with improved aviation infrastructure, according to Liew Mun Leong. The region is "grossly deficit" in infrastructure facilities, hindering global connectivity. Securing finance, addressing corruption, and political instability are major challenges. With increasing demand from China and urbanization, air connectivity is crucial. 52% of top 100 Asian airports need terminal capacity, and 69% need runway capacity by 2030. Asean countries must commit to developing infrastructure to maximize regional competitiveness.

site_title: Ocean Sky International proposes rights cum warrants issue to boost financials
summary: Ocean Sky International proposes a rights cum warrants issue to boost its financials, offering up to 162.5 million new shares and detachable warrants. Shareholders can subscribe for one rights share for every two existing shares, priced at S$0.062 each. The issue is non-underwritten and controlled by Ang Boon Cheow Edward, who owns 57.07% of the company. The group aims to strengthen its financial position, with net proceeds of up to S$20.9 million from the maximum subscription scenario.

site_title: China: Shanghai edges down in opening trade
summary: Chinese stocks opened lower on May 22, 2018, after a previous day's rally fueled by news of averted US-China trade war. The Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.08%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index was marginally down. The Hong Kong market was closed for a public holiday. The moves came despite US President Trump's new tariff threats.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on May 22, 2018, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.11% to 23,026.93, while the Topix index fell 0.08%. Market sentiment was influenced by easing US-China trade concerns and profit-taking from recent gains.

site_title: The lucky 56: Xiaomi IPO to make dozens of workers millionaires
summary: Xiaomi Corp, a successful smartphone maker, is set to go public with an initial public offering (IPO). Eight years ago, 56 of the company's earliest employees invested $11 million, now worth $36 million each, making them the "Lucky 56." This initial investment helped Xiaomi grow into one of the world's top smartphone makers. The company's IPO is expected to be a blockbuster, with the employees' stakes potentially worth $1 billion to $3 billion.

images.alt_text: Eight years ago, before China's Xiaomi Corp had sold a single smartphone, 56 of the earliest employees pulled together $11 million to invest in the startup. Rank-and-file workers dipped into savings and borrowed from parents. One receptionist tapped her dowry.

site_title: Tesla Model 3 rebuffed by consumer reports on slow braking
summary: Consumer Reports has withheld its recommendation for Tesla's Model 3 due to its long stopping distances and difficult-to-use controls, with a 96.6kmh stopping distance of 46.3m being "far worse" than contemporary cars. Despite this, the magazine praised the car's battery range, handling, and acceleration. Tesla CEO Elon Musk has vowed to address the issue, and the company's shares were affected by the news. The Model 3's production delays and manufacturing bottlenecks have been ongoing, but Tesla expects to improve production rates soon.

site_title: Moya launches one-for-two rights issue
summary: Moya Holdings Asia has launched a one-for-two rights issue, issuing up to 1.4 billion new shares at S$0.095 each. The largest shareholder, Tamaris Infrastructure, has agreed to fully subscribe for its entitlement. If other shareholders do not subscribe, Moya will raise a minimum of S$90.7 million, primarily to repay an existing loan facility and fund expansion through acquisitions and working capital. Analysts note that the rights issue is dilutive, but issuing shares at the current market price is more dilutive.

site_title: Top US court to examine India power plant complaint
summary: The US Supreme Court will examine a complaint by Indian villagers alleging pollution caused by a coal power plant funded by the International Finance Corporation (IFC). The plant, owned by Tata Group in Gujarat, uses advanced technology to reduce emissions but the villagers claim it still causes damage to marine fauna and soil pollution. The IFC is accused of failing to comply with its charter, which makes funding conditional on environmental standards. The case will be argued in the next Supreme Court session starting in October.

site_title: British lawmakers say dirty Russian money is still flowing to London
summary: A British parliamentary committee has found that dirty Russian money continues to flow into London despite the government's rhetoric on the issue. The report warns of "inaction or lethargy" in addressing money laundering from Moscow, with wealthy Russians hiding assets through London's financial sector. The committee criticizes the government for not doing enough to prevent the flow of corrupt money, citing examples of Russian oligarchs investing in luxury properties and soccer teams. The report also expresses concerns about "Tier 1" visas and the government's failure to follow through on its own sanctions and anti-money laundering rules.

site_title: Re-elected, Venezuela's Maduro faces global criticism, US sanctions
summary: Venezuela's President Nicolas Maduro was re-elected with 68% of the vote, but his main challenger alleged irregularities and refused to recognize the result. The US imposed new sanctions on the country, restricting Venezuela's ability to liquidate state assets and debt in the US. The US, along with several other countries, criticized the election as a "sham" and called for democracy, free and fair elections, and the release of political prisoners. Maduro's re-election has sparked global criticism and economic concerns, with the country's economy in a state of crisis.

site_title: The old capitalism returns
summary: The article "The old capitalism returns" states that the current economic situation is reminiscent of the past, with periods of upheaval leading to long-term benefits. The article highlights various factors contributing to this, including the internet, budget deficits, high debt levels, globalization, income and wealth inequality, and immigration. The author notes that these changes are part of a natural cycle of economic growth and destruction, and that companies and governments must adapt to these changes to thrive.

site_title: Uber hit with harassment suit following policy shift
summary: Uber has been hit with a lawsuit alleging sexual harassment and discrimination against female employees, following the company's shift away from arbitration for such claims. Former employee Ingrid Avendano claims a toxic work culture and condoned harassment by managers, despite raising concerns. Uber scrapped a policy requiring arbitration of sexual misconduct claims, citing a move towards "safety and transparency." Avendano opted out of a $10 million settlement to pursue her claim individually in court.

site_title: Barack and Michelle Obama sign Netflix production deal
summary: Barack and Michelle Obama have signed a multi-year production deal with Netflix, launching Higher Ground Productions to produce films, series, and documentaries. The former first couple aims to promote empathy and understanding through storytelling, with a focus on inspiring and educating audiences. The deal does not disclose financial terms, but the Obamas have already earned significant income from book deals and their large social media presence. Netflix CEO Ted Sarandos described the Obamas as "uniquely positioned to discover and highlight stories of people who make a difference."

images.alt_text: Barack and Michelle Obama have entered into a multi-year agreement to produce films and series with Netflix, the world's leading internet entertainment service announced on Monday.

site_title: Palestinian president Abbas suffering from pneumonia, condition improving: officials
summary: Palestinian President Mahmud Abbas is suffering from pneumonia, but his condition is improving, according to officials. Abbas, 83, was admitted to the hospital on Sunday with complications following an ear operation and chest pains. He has been treated with antibiotics and is expected to spend several more days in the hospital. Abbas's health has been a subject of speculation, with no clear successor identified, and has been a point of contention among Palestinians. Officials have attempted to calm rumors about his condition by releasing photos of him walking and reading a newspaper.

site_title: Oil closes in on US$72 as US, China reach trade truce
summary: Oil prices rose near US$72 a barrel as a trade truce between the US and China eased concerns of a trade war, boosting investor sentiment. The agreement to substantially reduce the US trade deficit in goods with China and Beijing's promise to increase purchases of US goods and services alleviated worries about a trade war. Meanwhile, explorers in the US oil market kept drilling at 844 rigs, halting a six-week gaining streak. A meeting between Saudi Arabia and Russia is expected to discuss oil prices and market stability.

site_title: Spackman to issue shares worth US$6.9m to raise stake in associate by 7.52%
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group (SEG) has agreed to purchase a 7.52% stake in Spackman Media Group (SMG) for US$6.9 million. The acquisition will increase SEG's interest in SMG to 41.28%. SEG will issue new shares worth US$6.9 million to existing SMG shareholders to fund the purchase. The deal is expected to further solidify SEG's position in the entertainment industry.

site_title: Cordlife says in talks on corporate development opportunities after SGX query on share surge
summary: Cordlife Group, a private cord blood banker, is in talks on corporate development opportunities following a 28% surge in its shares on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) due to a query on the unusual price movement. The company cited its third-quarter unaudited financial statements, which showed a net profit of S$843,000, as a possible explanation for the share price increase. Cordlife stated that no definitive agreements have been reached and there is no certainty that any of the opportunities will materialize. The company is in compliance with SGX listing rules.

site_title: Oil rallies to multi-year highs on Venezuela worries
summary: US crude oil prices surged to multi-year highs, reaching $72.24 a barrel, amid concerns that Venezuela's oil output could decline further due to the country's presidential election and potential sanctions. Venezuela's socialist President Nicolas Maduro faced international condemnation after his re-election, and the US is considering oil sanctions on the country. Geopolitical concerns, including US sanctions on Iran and a possible trade war with China, have also contributed to the price increase.

site_title: Protest greets fourth year of Thai junta rule
summary: Protesters in Bangkok gathered to mark four years of junta rule in Thailand, with thousands expected to march to Government House. Discontent with the military regime has been simmering, despite a ban on gatherings since 2014. Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha suggested elections would be held in February 2019, but the junta's grip on power remains. The protest is one of the largest acts of dissent since the military took control in 2014.

images.alt_text: Scores of Thai police ringed a Bangkok university early Tuesday as protesters prepared to march to Government House to mark four years of junta rule, one of the largest acts of dissent since the military grabbed power.

site_title: Singha Estate eyes Thai hotel assets to ride tourism boom
summary: Thai firm Singha Estate plans to invest in hospitality assets, including hotels and airports, to capitalize on the country's tourism boom. The company aims to boost its income from recurring businesses, such as hospitality and office properties, and expects to achieve this by 2019 after listing its hospitality business, S Hotels and Resorts. Investments will focus on locations like Bangkok, Pattaya, and Bali, with a total estimated investment of US$680 million in the Maldives project.

site_title: Going digital a necessity, not a choice, for SMEs
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are increasingly recognizing the necessity of digitalization to stay competitive. Industry leaders emphasize that digitalization can improve productivity, scalability, and internationalization. Despite initial challenges, SMEs can overcome these by leveraging government support, such as the Productivity Solutions Grant, and investing in employee upskilling. Employers must also adopt a long-term view and redesign job roles to support the digitalization journey. Ultimately, digitalization is no longer a choice, but a necessity for SMEs to remain relevant in the market.

site_title: Wan Azizah leads Cabinet in swearing-in ceremony
summary: Malaysia's new government, led by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, held a swearing-in ceremony where Deputy Prime Minister Wan Azizah Wan Ismail took the oath of office, becoming the country's first female deputy prime minister. The ceremony was attended by 13 Cabinet ministers, including those from various parties, who took their oath and signed the official instrument of appointment. Despite the historic moment, women's representation in policymaking positions remains a concern, with activists calling for at least 30% of policymakers to be women, a pledge made by the Pakatan Harapan coalition during the campaign.

site_title: US: Wall Street forges higher on China-US trade truce cheer
summary: US stocks surged on Monday, driven by relief over a potential trade war truce between the US and China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.2% to close at 25,013.36, as investors breathed a sigh of relief. The Trump administration pledged to "put its trade dispute with China on hold" after both sides reached a consensus to reduce tensions. However, details of the agreement were unclear. The rally lifted other markets, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, which edged to fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Under pressure from Trump, FBI and Justice agree to expanded Russia probe
summary: The US Justice Department agreed to expand its Russia probe to include "any irregularities" in FBI tactics involving President Trump's campaign, following pressure from Trump. The investigation will now examine "any irregularities with the Federal Bureau of Investigation's or the Department of Justice's tactics concerning the Trump Campaign." The decision was made after a meeting between Trump, Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, and Federal Bureau of Investigation Director Christopher Wray.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on easing trade worries; Italy stocks slide
summary: European shares rose on Monday as trade war worries eased, lifting the dollar and supporting exporters. The Stoxx 600 index closed up 0.3%, while the FTSE 100 hit a new record high. Italian stocks, however, slid under pressure as markets awaited developments in the creation of a new government. A weaker pound also boosted the blue chips, with analysts citing a "feel-good factor" from the trade war truce.

site_title: 'Deadpool 2' topples 'Avengers: Infinity War' at box office
summary: "Deadpool 2" surpassed "Avengers: Infinity War" at the box office, earning US$174.9 million abroad and US$125.5 million domestically, with a total of US$300.4 million. The film, starring Ryan Reynolds and Josh Brolin, features an R-rated title and the biggest foreign debut for an R-rated title. "Avengers: Infinity War" took US$29.5 million in North American theaters, pushing its global total past US$1.8 billion.

site_title: Shrinking valuations cast shadow over smaller Chinese bank IPOs
summary: China's crackdown on shadow banking is casting a shadow over smaller banks' IPOs. Smaller banks' shares have slipped relative to larger peers, due to their involvement in the shadow banking sector. Analysts predict lower pricing prospects for the 18 regional lenders planning to list shares, as the deleveraging campaign squeezes their margins and weakens their capital strength. Despite recent price declines, some smaller banks are still considered overvalued, and investors remain lukewarm to upcoming IPOs. The outlook for smaller Chinese banks' listings appears dim.

site_title: Rising prices, rates test strength of US market
summary: US home sales near expansion highs despite lean inventory and accelerating prices, driven by demand from Americans eager to buy before prices rise further. Despite 39% of respondents in the University of Michigan survey saying selling conditions are optimal due to favorable prices, new listings have not increased, and homes are being quickly sold. Mortgage rates have risen to a seven-year high, making housing affordability more challenging, particularly for first-time buyers.

site_title: Starbucks: You don't have to buy coffee to sit in our cafes or use our restrooms
summary: Starbucks has introduced a new policy allowing customers to use its restrooms and sit in its cafes and patios without making a purchase. The move comes after a 2018 incident where two black men were asked to leave a Philadelphia store for not buying anything, sparking accusations of racial profiling. The company has also announced plans to close over 8,000 stores to train employees on racial-bias education and has committed to being part of the solution to prevent future discrimination.

site_title: Grab partners Maybank to promote GrabPay in Malaysia
summary: Grab has partnered Maybank to promote GrabPay in Malaysia, expanding its mobile wallet service to its second country after Singapore. The partnership aims to drive the acceptance and usage of GrabPay across Malaysia. Grab plans to roll out the GrabPay service across all eight countries in South-east Asia this year.

site_title: Tat Hong to delist as buyout offer crosses 90% threshold
summary: CRANE supplier Tat Hong will soon be delisted from the Singapore Exchange after a buyout offer by CEO Roland Ng and Standard Chartered's private equity arm crossed the 90% threshold. The offer, for 55 Singapore cents per share, is unconditional and has been extended to June 4. Shareholders who don't accept the offer will be left with illiquid shares. Tat Hong's profit warning in May cited weak revenues and unrealised foreign exchange losses, with the company expecting to report losses. The buyout aims to provide more managerial flexibility and reduce compliance costs.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Airlines' broker UOB Kay Hian raises its target price to S$12.60, citing increased fuel prices alleviating competitive pressure and improving forward bookings. They expect FY2019 net profit to hit S$1 billion, a 73% increase from previous estimates. Phillip Securities maintains an "equal weight" view on industrial Reits, while RHB Securities remains "overweight" on the retail sector, citing a pick-up in demand and innovative shopping experiences.

site_title: Jakarta to step up intervention as rupiah, bonds slide
summary: Bank Indonesia pledged to intervene in the currency and bond markets to ease volatility, citing the rupiah's slump to a 31-month low. The central bank will hold three forex swap auctions to boost liquidity, following a net $2.3 billion withdrawal of Indonesian sovereign bonds by global funds. The benchmark bond yield surged to its highest in 14 months, while the benchmark stock index declined over 9% this year. External factors and a stronger dollar index are cited as the main causes of the rupiah's weakness.

site_title: Strong prospects in Asean, but firms face hurdles to regional expansion: survey
summary: A survey by The Business Times and Standard Chartered Bank found that 80% of companies in Asean have plans to expand in the region over the next three to five years, despite facing hurdles such as regulatory barriers, finding suitable business partners, and talent constraints. The majority of respondents (92%) have a presence in Singapore, with Indonesia being the top priority for expansion. Companies cited growing domestic demand and customer requests as key reasons for expansion, but also highlighted the need for better connectivity and coordination among Asean economies.

images.alt_text: Almost all respondents (92 per cent) have a presence in Singapore.

site_title: L'Oreal banks on Cannes gloss to drive sales in social-media savvy China
summary: L'Oreal is leveraging its Cannes presence to drive sales in China, where its flagship brand L'Oreal Paris has seen booming makeup sales thanks to partnerships with social media influencers and beauty bloggers. The company's efforts include a live talk show with film stars, a Mandarin edition of the event, and a dedicated video studio on the Cannes beach. L'Oreal aims to combine accessibility, direct contact with consumers, and the aspirational nature of cinema to drive sales, as the Chinese market undergoes a shift to e-commerce and online sales.

images.alt_text: In the flurry of videos L'Oreal produced during the Cannes film festival, red-carpet struts were interspersed with product demos and interviews with the brand's ambassadors. The combination of staging elaborate events, publicising them via social media and easing the path to points of sale is reaping rewards.

site_title: London slump deepens as Brexit slows UK property
summary: London's housing market continues to slump due to Brexit uncertainty, with a 0.2% annual price decline reported by Rightmove and a 2.5% drop in April by Acadata. National price growth stands at 1% compared to a 9% high in 2016. The uncertainty surrounding the UK's exit from the EU has particularly affected London, with a shortage of properties for sale and stretched affordability contributing to a slow market. Sales are down 5.4% nationwide this year, with only Wales showing annual price increases.

site_title: Markets perk up on US-China trade talks
summary: US-China trade talks sparked a brief rally in local stocks with Chinese exposure, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.54% to 3,548.23. Winners included Venture Corporation, while losers outnumbered gainers 201-193. However, analysts warn of continued risk ahead due to ongoing tit-for-tat tariffs. The market rebound was short-lived, and shares ultimately ended the day down.

site_title: Commodities that may win big from a US-China trade truce
summary: A US-China trade truce has led to a potential boost in commodities, particularly US agricultural products and liquefied natural gas. China agreed to import more American goods, including soybeans, cotton, sorghum, and ethanol, which could benefit US exports. The country's planned tariffs on US exports were put on hold, allowing for increased imports of these commodities. Additionally, China's growing demand for liquefied natural gas could lead to increased imports from the US, with Bloomberg forecasting 82 million tons of imports by 2030.

site_title: Bank of Singapore inks MOU with SMBC Trust Bank
summary: Bank of Singapore has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with SMBC Trust Bank to provide Japanese ultra-high and high net worth individuals with global investment opportunities. The MOU aims to diversify portfolios and increase assets under management, with private wealth in Japan expected to grow from $14.9 trillion in 2016 to $16.2 trillion in 2021. This move is in line with Japanese investors' trend of expanding and diversifying portfolios beyond domestic assets.

site_title: Why Singapore remains a role model for managing national savings
summary: Singapore's national savings model remains a role model for managing sovereign wealth, with the country boasting the largest official reserves per capita and well-established sovereign wealth vehicles. Founded in the 1970s, institutions like Temasek and Government Investment Corporation have successfully navigated long-term investments. The key to Singapore's success lies in the coordination of four state institutions, including the Monetary Authority, Temasek, GIC, and Central Provident Fund, which work together to manage assets and liabilities effectively. This holistic approach has implications for emerging markets and developing countries accumulating significant reserves.

site_title: Ryanair posts record annual profit; stays cautious about year ahead
summary: Ryanair posted a record annual profit of €1.9 billion, despite a rostering issue that led to the cancellation of 20,000 flights in September. The airline attributed the profit to cost-cutting measures and strong demand. However, it warned that profits would fall in the coming year due to higher costs and stagnant fares. Ryanair's CEO remained cautious about the year ahead, citing increased competition and rising fuel prices. The airline's focus on operational efficiency and cost management will be crucial in maintaining its growth trajectory.

site_title: Deep understanding of Asean is key to seizing opportunities: panellists
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasizes the importance of deep understanding of Asean for seizing opportunities, particularly in non-infrastructure projects. He notes that China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) can be a partner for Singapore to enter the region if played correctly. Chan highlights that Singapore's system of rules and laws attracts Chinese investments, and the city-state can partner with China to invest in Asean markets. To effectively capture opportunities, securing talent, especially in technology, is key, and Singapore must live and work in Asean countries to gain a deep understanding of the region.

images.alt_text: THE BUSINESS TIMES LEADERS' FORUM 2018: (L-R): The panel discussion with Mr Lee U-Wen, Deputy News Editor, The Business Times (moderator); Mr Alexis Lanternier, CEO of Lazada Singapore; Mr Liew Mun Leong, Chairman of Surbana Jurong Private Limited and Chairman of Changi Airport Group; keynote speaker Mr Chan Chun Sing, Minister for Trade and Industry and Ho Meng Kit, CEO of the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) and Mr Tan Soon Kim, Assistant CEO of Enterprise Singapore.##########vipanel22##########Yen Meng Jiin

Mr Chan highlighted that China is also looking to invest in non-infrastructure projects.

site_title: Why Google supports a strong Asean Community
summary: Google supports a strong Asean Community by recognizing the region's digital economy as a significant growth engine, with a forecasted US$200 billion Internet economy by 2025. The company advocates for a more digitally connected Asean, where countries approach the digital economy as one community, rather than fragmented ones. Google also supports greater digital literacy and initiatives like Go Global, which trains small and medium-sized enterprises on how to export goods and services using the Internet, aiming to get 2,500 SMEs digital- and export-ready by 2019.

site_title: Transforming for a more secure future
summary: Ademco Security Group, a pioneer in Singapore's security sector, has undergone significant transformations over the past four decades. The firm, which launched a 24-hour central monitoring system in 1985 and introduced the country's first internet protocol-based alarm transmission system in 2003, has continued to innovate. In 2010, Ademco adopted a fully digital system, moving away from hard-copy reports, and in 2018, it brought in an autonomous security robot. The company's expansion into new markets, including Malaysia, Indonesia, and Vietnam, aims to secure more than half of annual revenue by 2020.

site_title: Porsche sales in Singapore kick into high gear
summary: Porsche reported strong sales in Singapore, with over 200 orders in the first quarter, surpassing 600 units delivered last year, valued at over S$186 million. Globally, the company delivered over 246,400 units, with China leading the way. Porsche is shifting its focus to digitalization and new services, aiming to clock a double-digit percentage of its business through digital services. The company is also investing in electric vehicles, with plans to double its investments in electromobility to six billion euros by 2022.

site_title: The known unknowns of US sanctions against Iran
summary: US President Donald Trump's reinstatement of sanctions against Iran raises questions about the impact on global safety and the Middle East. Experts argue that sanctions may not be effective in limiting nuclear weapons and could destabilize the region. The sanctions' effect on oil prices is uncertain, with some speculators already pricing in the increase, and analysts predicting a smaller impact on global oil supplies than expected. The US-Iran confrontation may lead to lower oil prices due to the strong political incentive for Trump and Saudi allies to resist further price increases, potentially benefiting Trump's re-election prospects.

site_title: Is there a method to Trump's madness?
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a reversal of a ban on Chinese telecommunications company ZTE, averting a potential trade war. The move followed a tweet from Trump stating that the restrictions on ZTE were costing "too many jobs in China." The White House claims the decision was part of a larger deal with China, which would include increased US exports to China to reduce the trade deficit. The deal may also have influenced North Korea's decision to potentially cancel a meeting with Trump, with Beijing reportedly using the threat of cancellation as leverage.

site_title: Malaysia has a few ways to make good revenue shortfall from zero GST
summary: Malaysia's new government has decided to zero-rate the Goods and Services Tax (GST), which brings in RM40 billion in revenue, to balance the budget and reduce national debt. However, this move has raised concerns among financial markets, with ratings agencies expressing displeasure. The Malaysian Ministry of Finance has acknowledged the need for fiscal reformation and announced plans to reintroduce the Sales and Services Tax (SST) to fill the gap. Favorable global market conditions, recovering commodity prices, and efficient economic management are expected to offset the shortfall, and Prime Minister Mahathir's market-friendly reputation is seen as a positive factor.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: US President Trump has imposed a 50% copper import tariff, targeting refined metal. The move is part of his efforts to protect domestic industries. Global markets reacted with oil prices rising over 2% amid concerns about market outlook and tariffs. US stocks edged down from records due to tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for its £10b upgrade.

site_title: Foreigners sell US$625m of Malaysian stocks in a week
summary: Foreign investors sold a record US$625 million of Malaysian stocks in a week, the highest since August 2013, according to Bursa Malaysia data. This comes despite a 0.4% gain in the benchmark index following the election of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamed. Overseas inflows into the market have dwindled to just US$10.3 million, and some strategists remain unconvinced by the market gains, citing concerns over the country's economic prospects.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust to buy 7 more Hyderabad office buildings
summary: Ascendas India Trust has entered into agreements to acquire two buildings, aVance 5 and 6, in Hyderabad's HITEC City for a combined leasable area of 1.8 million square feet. The buildings will be acquired at a price not exceeding S$270 million, with construction funding provided through inter-corporate deposits and debentures. This addition is expected to raise Ascendas India Trust's portfolio by 13% to 16 million sq ft, taking advantage of Hyderabad's robust rental growth driven by global IT companies.

site_title: Abuses pushed Malaysia's debt to over 1 trillion ringgit: Mahathir
summary: Malaysia's debt has exceeded 1 trillion ringgit (S$340 billion) under the new government led by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, who blames the previous government led by former Prime Minister Najib Razak for the debt. Mahathir says the debt had never exceeded 300 billion ringgit during his governance. He has announced plans to replace the GST with a sales and services tax, while also reintroducing fuel subsidies, despite warnings from Moody's that these measures could widen the fiscal deficit. Mahathir's government is working to restore the country's finances and reputation.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sembcorp Marine signed a contract with Shell Offshore Inc to build and integrate a floating production unit in the Mississippi Canyon, while Singapore Airlines won the "Best Air Cargo Carrier for Asia" award. Thakral Corp acquired an office property in Singapore for S$30 million, and Tiong Seng Holdings secured a contract to build a polyclinic and long-term care facility. SK Jewellery unveiled its flagship Shanghai bridal jewellery store.

site_title: Crowdfunded startup Ossic shuts down; backers to seek redress
summary: Ossic, a crowdfunded startup aiming to bring 3D headphone technology to the mass market, has shut down after taking thousands of orders for its Ossic X headphones. Despite raising $5.9 million, the company was unable to secure sufficient funding to ramp up mass production, citing slow adoption of virtual reality and the failure of other crowdfunded hardware companies. Over 1,200 backers are seeking redress, with some threatening a class action lawsuit. The company's shutdown leaves its ambitious plans for 3D audio headphones unfulfilled.

site_title: Singapore adopts national e-invoice system
summary: Singapore has adopted a national e-invoice system based on the Pan European Public Procurement On-Line (PEPPOL) standard, making it the first country outside Europe and the first in Asia to do so. The system aims to speed up business transactions, minimize disputes, and reduce operating costs for local businesses. The implementation is part of the government's efforts to accelerate the adoption of digital technologies and support the country's digital economy.

site_title: At US$78,000, Tesla pushes Model 3 beyond reach of the masses
summary: Tesla's Model 3, once priced at $35,000, has increased to $78,000, making it unaffordable for many consumers. The new, faster, and more powerful version features a top speed of 155mph, a 310-mile range, and 3.5-second acceleration from 0-60mph. The company's CEO, Elon Musk, believes the Model 3's increasing price is necessary to generate cash for mass production and eventually affordable vehicles for a broader market. This strategy may lead to the Model 3 becoming a luxury car, rather than a mass-market electric vehicle.

site_title: The dyeing art of Damascus silk
summary: In Syria's capital, Damascus, artisan Mohammad al-Rihawi struggles to maintain the traditional dyeing art of Damascus silk due to the ongoing civil war. The trade, famous for its luminous brocade, has nearly died out, with only a few skilled artisans remaining. The conflict has disrupted silkworm farming, forcing the industry to rely on imports from India and China. Rihawi and his 15-year-old son work tirelessly to preserve the craft, but demand is low, and the future of Damascus silk hangs in the balance.

site_title: Japan's Nippon Steel says solid demand mutes impact of US import duties
summary: Nippon Steel, Japan's top steelmaker, says strong global demand has cushioned the impact of US import duties, with 90% of its customers continuing to buy its specialized products. Despite this, the company remains concerned about the potential for a glut in the Asian market if US steel is redirected there. Nippon Steel plans to boost crude steel output and improve margins by increasing prices to absorb rising costs. The company is also optimistic about winning the bidding for Essar Steel, a bankrupt Indian firm, and its potential partnership with ArcelorMittal.

site_title: Deadpool sequel surges to box office lead
summary: Deadpool 2 surpassed box office expectations, earning $125 million in North America and $176 million abroad, the largest foreign debut for an R-rated title. The film's success marks another US$100-million-plus superhero opening, following Avengers: Infinity War. Other top-grossing films include Avengers, Book Club, and Life of the Party, with RBG, a documentary about Ruth Bader Ginsburg, experiencing strong ticket sales despite being a documentary.

site_title: Europe's luxe hotel group Kempinski to run Perennial's hotel at Capitol Singapore
summary: Kempinski Hotels SA has been appointed to operate The Capitol Kempinski Hotel Singapore in Singapore's downtown Civic District. The 157-room luxury hotel is part of the Capitol Singapore integrated development, which also features shopping, dining, and entertainment options. The hotel will be fully operational by the end of the year and will be positioned as a luxury destination. This marks Kempinski's expansion into Asia, with Vice-chairman Bernold O Schroeder stating that Singapore is an ideal location for the group's growth.

site_title: SPH, logistics firms to be part of locker network
summary: The Info-communications Media Development Authority (IMDA) has signed memoranda of intent with 15 logistics firms, including Singapore Press Holdings, to participate in a nationwide locker network. The network, which will begin in October, will allow users to pick up parcels from 59 SPH Buzz Convenience Stores and 100 condominium precincts. The goal is to ease last-mile delivery challenges and provide cost savings for merchants and logistics firms. IMDA will oversee the Federated Lockers Network and Collection Points Programme, which aims to increase convenience and efficiency in parcel delivery.

site_title: Strengthening US$ puts heat on emerging market currencies
summary: The US dollar's strength is putting pressure on emerging market currencies, with the MSCI Emerging Markets Currency Index closing below its 200-day moving average for the first time in over a year. Not a single developing-nation currency rose last week, with the US dollar advancing and US 10-year yields closing above 3%. The negative correlation between the US dollar and emerging markets is deepening, with many countries now more exposed to US dollar appreciation than in 2009. Central banks are expected to hold rates steady or make minimal changes, amid signs of slowing growth in developing economies.

site_title: ESR's expansion plans extend beyond Singapore's shores
summary: ESR, a pan-Asian logistics group, has announced its expansion plans with a series of recent acquisitions. The company's Reit, ESR-Reit, is poised for growth following a proposed merger with Viva Industrial Trust, valued at S$937 million. ESR's parent, Warburg Pincus, has a history of acquiring and consolidating Reits, and the company's next target could be from a list of potential Reits. ESR's expansion strategy also includes Australia, where it has acquired stakes in Propertylink and Centuria, and may be working to acquire these companies' industrial assets.

site_title: Iswaran in Paris to deepen France, Singapore innovation and tech links
summary: Minister-in-Charge of Trade Relations S Iswaran is visiting Paris from May 22 to 25 as part of the France-Singapore Year of Innovation 2018, aiming to deepen innovation and tech links between the two countries. He will meet with French officials, attend a tech and innovation festival, and reaffirm Singapore's commitment to the European Union-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA). Iswaran will also participate in a joint dialogue with France's Minister of Higher Education, Research and Innovation and deliver a keynote speech on Singapore's role as an artificial intelligence hub.

images.alt_text: Mr Iswaran will meet French government officials to reaffirm Singapore's commitment towards the smooth and swift ratification of EUSFTA.

site_title: Malaysia brings back old graft-busters for 1MDB task force
summary: Malaysia has brought back former graft-busters Abdul Gani Patail and Abu Kassim Mohamed to lead a task force focused on investigating and recovering assets lost due to wrongdoing at 1MDB, a state investment company. The task force, set to meet on Tuesday, aims to track down embezzlement of 1MDB funds and prosecute individuals involved in wrongdoing. The move is part of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's efforts to root out corruption in his administration, following his election less than two weeks ago.

site_title: 3 Fortis Healthcare directors quit amid takeover tussle
summary: Three Fortis Healthcare directors, Harpal Singh, Tejinder Singh Shergill, and Sabina Vaisoha, quit amid a takeover battle, citing personal reasons. The move comes ahead of a shareholder vote on Tuesday to decide their future. The vote follows a prolonged takeover battle involving five suitors, including Hero Enterprise Investment Office and Burman Family Office. Fortis Healthcare operates 45 healthcare facilities in India and abroad, and the takeover battle has been fueled by rising private healthcare spending in India and the government's plan to implement a healthcare programme.

site_title: Going digital has improved efficiency of Ademco staff
summary: Ademco, a security firm, has seen improvements in efficiency since adopting digital systems. In 2010, the company began using handheld tablets for service reports, allowing for automatic receipt and reducing lost paperwork. The cloud-based software also enables customer service staff to easily access information and field questions from customers, reducing phone calls. Additionally, the system's history log helps identify recurring problems early. This shift has made the job easier for service technicians and customer service staff, who now have access to precise and clear fault calls.

site_title: Ex-Googler turns mum's money into a billion dollars on Amazon
summary: An ex-Googler, Steven Yang, turned his mother's pharmaceutical investment of 3.9 billion yuan into a billion-dollar online consumer electronics enterprise, Anker, with 56% revenue growth in 2017 and 9.9% profit growth. Yang initially considered venture capital but opted to use his mother's money to fund his business idea.

site_title: Thai Airways finds new CEO after 2-year search
summary: Thai Airways International has selected Sumeth Damrongchaitham, 53, as its new CEO after a two-year search. Damrongchaitham will replace the former head, who retired in 2016, and take control of the airline struggling with high fuel costs and competition from low-cost carriers. The selection is seen as a positive move after investors and analysts expressed concerns about the airline's lack of independence due to its board comprising civil servants and former air force members. Damrongchaitham's appointment is expected to bring much-needed stability to the airline.

site_title: The Business Times-Standard Chartered Leaders' Survey 2018: Prospects and Challenges
summary: Standard Chartered's 2018 Leaders' Survey revealed prospects and challenges for businesses in Southeast Asia. Vietnam was caught off guard by a US tariff announcement and sought a lower rate. Meanwhile, Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3%, below forecast, and Daim Zainuddin's assets may be seized for about RM3 billion. GoTo shares are expected to rebound after a US$2.2 billion sell-off, and foreign investors returned to Vietnam's stocks due to sweetened US trade terms. SMCCI and Maybank also signed a memorandum of understanding to support Malay or Muslim-owned enterprises in Singapore and Malaysia.

site_title: Bridging the gap in data skills through citizen data scientists
summary: A global shortage of data scientists is hindering companies in Asia from leveraging data analytics, with 82% of companies anticipating its significant influence on decision-making in five years. The main hurdle is the lack of a digital culture and necessary skills, prompting the need for citizen data scientists to bridge the gap. This can be achieved through smart data discovery tools that empower every worker, enabling them to contribute to data-driven decision-making processes.

site_title: Anwar reassures ethnic Malays who fear losing benefits
summary: Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim reassured ethnic Malays who fear losing benefits, stating that the nation's security would be upheld. This comes after Anwar previously called for the dismantling of affirmative action policies favoring ethnic Malays. Anwar, expected to replace Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad in a year or two, aims to alleviate concerns among Malaysia's largest racial group.

site_title: China relieved, US business ambivalent over easing of trade tensions
summary: China has expressed relief over the easing of trade tensions with the US, with both nations agreeing to drop tariff threats while working on a wider trade agreement. The US Treasury Secretary said the trade war was "on hold," and US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross will travel to China next week to finalize the agreement. China has pledged to import more US energy and agricultural commodities to narrow the US$335 billion annual trade deficit. However, US business leaders have mixed reactions, with some expressing disappointment over the lack of concessions from China.

site_title: Improved aviation infrastructure needed to spur growth in Asean, says Liew Mun Leong
summary: Liew Mun Leong, chairman of Surbana Jurong Private Ltd and Changi Airport Group, emphasizes the need for improved aviation infrastructure in Asean to spur economic growth. The region is "grossly deficit" in infrastructure facilities, hindering global connectivity. Current challenges include securing finance, political instability, and corruption. Liew notes that airports in Asean capital cities face capacity constraints, with 52% of top 100 Asian airports needing more terminal capacity and 69% needing more runway capacity by 2030. He advocates for Asean countries to commit to infrastructure development to create value and maximize the region's comparative advantage.

site_title: Carving out a co-working niche
summary: Singapore's co-working space market is rapidly expanding, with over 100 purpose-built office spaces in the Central Business District. The market grew by 55% in 2017, with around half of new additions opening in the last two years. To stand out, some co-working spaces are creating strong niches, catering to specific values and needs of occupants. As a result, the industry is becoming increasingly competitive, with entrepreneurs and SME owners seeking unique and collaborative environments to thrive.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as trade war put 'on hold'
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday after the US and China put a potential trade war "on hold". The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 167.97 points, or 0.68%, to 24,883.06. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with gains of 12.98 points and 52.00 points, respectively. The news followed a series of US-China trade talks, with no new agreements announced.

site_title: US top court backs companies over worker class-action claims
summary: The US Supreme Court ruled 5-4 in favor of companies, allowing them to require employees to sign arbitration agreements waiving their right to bring class-action claims. This decision affects approximately 25 million employees, overriding a National Labor Relations Board decision invalidating such agreements. The ruling, written by Justice Neil Gorsuch, prioritizes federal arbitration law over labor statutes. The decision is seen as a blow to workers' rights, with Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg calling it "egregiously wrong."

site_title: Blackstone to buy LaSalle Hotel in US$4.8b agreement
summary: Blackstone Group LP agreed to acquire luxury hotel owner LaSalle Hotel Properties in an all-cash transaction valued at US$4.8 billion, including debt. The deal prevents a proposed merger between LaSalle and Pebblebrook Hotel Trust, which would have combined to create a portfolio of upscale hotels. LaSalle's board deemed the Blackstone offer a significant premium with immediate and certain cash value, exceeding a median premium of 14.7% in US REIT transactions over the past five years.

site_title: Insurers cash in on new European data privacy rules
summary: Europe's new General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) has boosted the European cyber insurance market, as companies become more aware of the risks caused by customer information breaches. The law, which took effect on Friday, aims to give EU citizens more rights over their online information and threatens fines of up to 4% of a company's annual revenue for serious infringements. Insurers say the directive, combined with major cyber attacks, is driving demand for cyber insurance, with premiums expected to reach over $2 billion annually by 2020.

site_title: British court dismisses charges against Barclays over 2008 Qatar deal
summary: A British court has dismissed charges brought by the Serious Fraud Office (SFO) against Barclays over its 2008 capital raising, suspending regulatory sanctions on the bank's operations. The SFO had alleged that a US$3 billion loan to Qatar helped Barclays avoid a British government rescue, but Barclays denied the claims. The dismissal removes the biggest remaining legal headache for Barclays, and the SFO plans to seek reinstatement of the charges.

site_title: Tiong Seng bags S$47.68m MOH contract to build 10-storey polyclinic and care facility
summary: Construction company Tiong Seng Holdings secured a S$47.68 million contract from the Ministry of Health to build a 10-storey polyclinic and care facility in Singapore. Construction will begin in June 2018, utilizing the company's prefabricated pre-finished volumetric construction (PPVC) techniques. The project is expected to boost Tiong Seng's order book to S$641.7 million by 2020, positioning the company as a market leader in the construction sector.

site_title: Renewal of bilateral swap arrangement between Japan and Singapore
summary: The Bank of Japan and Monetary Authority of Singapore have renewed their bilateral swap arrangement, allowing for the exchange of local currencies for US dollars in times of need. The arrangement enables Japan to swap Japanese yen for up to US$1 billion and Singapore to swap Singapore dollars for up to US$3 billion or its equivalent in Japanese yen. The renewal aims to promote financial stability, bilateral economic ties, and the use of local currency in the region. The agreement is seen as a key step in strengthening financial cooperation between the two countries.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.92 points to 1,853.58. Trading volume was 2.8 billion lots worth RM3 billion. Gainers narrowly outnumbered losers 493 to 476.

site_title: Greenback surges to five-month highs
summary: The US dollar surged to a five-month high on Monday, driven by relief over the fading risks of a China-US trade war. Investors cut their short positions against the greenback for the fourth consecutive week, reducing the net outstanding short positions to $11 billion. The dollar rose 0.4% against a basket of peers, its highest level since late December 2017. The rally has taken currency markets by surprise, with the euro and sterling also falling as markets await data on the European economy and potential interest rate hikes.

site_title: Aston Martin gears up for more growth ahead of possible flotation
summary: Aston Martin reported a pretax profit of £2.8 million in the first quarter of 2018, down from the previous year due to a weaker dollar. The company is considering a potential stock market listing, valued at £4 billion, but finance chief Mark Wilson emphasized that the decision is up to shareholders. Investment in new models increased by nearly a half to £68 million, and the company plans to launch hybrid and electric vehicles to meet emissions rules. A ban on petrol and diesel cars from 2040 in Britain is expected to impact the industry, but Wilson downplayed its potential impact.

site_title: Carlyle is said to poach Credit Suisse's top Indonesia dealmaker
summary: Carlyle Group LP has hired Robby Winarta, Credit Suisse's Indonesia investment-banking head, who has resigned from the Swiss bank. Winarta, who led Credit Suisse's top adviser on Indonesian mergers and acquisitions, plans to join Carlyle soon. This move follows Credit Suisse's loss of Malaysia coverage head Jefferi Hashim to CIMB Group Holdings Bhd. last year.

site_title: Deep understanding of Asean is key to seizing opportunities: panellists
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the importance of deep understanding of Asean to seize opportunities, particularly with China's Belt and Road Initiative. He noted that Singapore is a gateway to Asean and can partner with China for non-infrastructure projects. The panellists highlighted the need for talent, especially in technology, and the importance of understanding regional markets to add value. Chan also assured that Singapore will work with the Malaysian government on economic relations, including the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore high-speed rail project.

images.alt_text: (From left) The panel discussion with Lee U-Wen, deputy news editor, The Business Times (moderator); Alexis Lanternier, CEO of Lazada Singapore; Liew Mun Leong, chairman of Surbana Jurong Private Limited and chairman of Changi Airport Group; keynote speaker Chan Chun Sing, Minister for Trade and Industry; Ho Meng Kit, CEO of the Singapore Business Federation (SBF); and Tan Soon Kim, assistant CEO of Enterprise Singapore.
Mr Chan highlighted that China is also looking to invest in non-infrastructure projects.

site_title: Meghan and Harry release official photos of their UK royal wedding
summary: Prince Harry and Meghan, now the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, released official photos from their UK royal wedding at Windsor Castle on May 21, 2018. The couple thanked those involved in their wedding and expressed gratitude for those who watched the ceremony worldwide. The official portraits, taken by Alexi Lubomirski, feature the couple with key figures, including Queen Elizabeth, Prince Charles, and their children. The photos were released after the couple's heartfelt statement thanking everyone for celebrating their special day.

images.alt_text: A picture released by Kensington Palace on behalf of The Duke and Duchess of Sussex on May 21, 2018 shows Britain's Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex, (CL) and his wife Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, (CR) posing for an official wedding photograph.

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust completes acquisition of hotel in South Korea, master lease agreement inked
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust has completed the acquisition of a majority stake in KY-Heritage Hotel Dongdaemun in South Korea for 72.1 billion won. The hotel will be renamed The Splaisir Seoul Dongdaemun under a 20-year master lease agreement with Sotetsu International Korea Co. The acquisition is part of a sale and purchase agreement announced last month.

site_title: Japan's new law on room rentals a double-edged sword
summary: Japan's new law on room rentals will legalize short-term rentals on June 15, clearing up a legal grey area, but introduces fresh restrictions, including a limit of 180 overnight stays per year and registration with authorities. The new law aims to balance the needs of tourists and local residents, with potential hosts facing challenges such as opposition from neighbors and competition from other platforms. Experts predict a surge in demand for short-term rentals ahead of the 2020 Olympics, but warn that the new law may hamper business in the short term.

images.alt_text: Yasuhiro Kamiyama, CEO of house rental company Hyakusenrenma, showing off the company's rental house in Tokyo. Despite the new restrictions, there is a huge potential market for short-term rentals as Japan gears up for Tokyo 2020 and the 2019 Rugby World Cup.

site_title: London housing slump deepens as Brexit slows UK property
summary: London's housing market continues to decline, with a 0.2% annual price drop in May, according to Rightmove. The only region showing an annual fall, London's price decline contrasts with a 1% national growth rate. Brexit uncertainty and affordability issues have hit London hardest, leading to slower sales and hesitant buyers and sellers. Nationally, sales are down 5.4% year-on-year, and home prices reached a record high of £308,075 in May.

site_title: You don't have to buy coffee to sit in our cafes or use our restrooms
summary: Starbucks has implemented a new policy allowing customers to use its restrooms and sit in cafes without making a purchase, effective immediately. The change comes after a manager at a Philadelphia store called the police on two young black men who had not made a purchase before using the restroom, sparking accusations of racial profiling. The company plans to close over 8,000 US stores to train employees on racial-bias education, and those who become a safety threat can be banned from the store.

site_title: Iswaran visits Paris to deepen France-Singapore innovation and technology links
summary: Singapore Minister-In-Charge of Trade Relations S Iswaran is visiting Paris from May 22 to 25 as part of the France-Singapore Year of Innovation 2018. He will meet with French government officials, attend an innovation and technology festival, and deliver a keynote speech on Singapore's role as an AI hub. The visit aims to deepen innovation and research linkages between the two countries, with a focus on strengthening ties in research and development and promoting trade and investment.

site_title: Coordinated bombs rock 'peace progress' claims in Thai south
summary: Coordinated bombs were detonated in Thailand's southern border provinces, undermining the junta's claims of peace talks progress with Muslim insurgents. The attacks, which targeted 14 ATM booths and other public spaces, were the most sweeping in recent months, killing no one but causing chaos. Analysts believe the violence is a challenge to the junta's efforts and a reminder that the rebels are not part of the peace process. The attacks occurred during Ramadan, a period when violence is common in the region.

site_title: BreadTalk unit in joint venture to bring popular Chinese tea brands to Singapore
summary: A BreadTalk unit has entered into a joint venture with Shenzhen Pindao Food & Beverage Management to bring popular Chinese tea brands Nayuki and Tai Gai to Singapore and the region. Together Inc will hold a 90% stake in the JV, while Pindao holds 10%. The JV aims to capitalize on the growing demand for novelty tea beverages among young consumers, with Nayuki set to open in central Singapore and Tai Gai offering unique milk tea brews. The investment is expected to have no financial impact on BreadTalk for the 2018 financial year.

site_title: SK Jewellery opens flagship Shanghai store to tap burgeoning Chinese demand
summary: SK Jewellery, a Catalist-listed company, has unveiled its flagship Shanghai bridal jewellery store, Love & Co, to capitalize on growing demand for wedding jewellery in China. The store is the company's second outlet in China and serves as a "solid anchor" for expansion in the country. Located in Hong Kong Plaza, the store offers bespoke bridal jewellery under the Love & Co brand, marking the jeweller's entry into the lucrative Chinese market.

site_title: 'God help Turkey,' says brokerage as lira goes into meltdown
summary: Istanbul-based broker Alnus Yatirim warns that Turkey's central bank is failing to address the country's currency crisis, saying "God help Turkey" due to double-digit inflation and a 16% decline in the lira against the dollar in 2018. The currency is expected to reach 4.58 and 4.75 per dollar by the end of the week and next week, respectively, if no intervention occurs. The broker cites concerns about the impact of the lira's depreciation on Turkey's $222 billion in overseas debt.

site_title: BreadTalk unit in joint venture to bring popular Chinese tea brands to Singapore and the region
summary: BreadTalk has entered a joint venture with Shenzhen Pindao Food & Beverage Management to bring popular Chinese tea brands Nayuki and Tai Gai to Singapore and the region. Together Inc, a wholly owned BreadTalk subsidiary, will take a 90% stake in the JV, with Pindao holding 10%. The JV will operate Nayuki and Tai Gai in Singapore and Thailand, with a right of first refusal to operate in Malaysia, Indonesia, and the Philippines. The joint venture aims to capitalize on the growing demand for novelty tea beverages among young consumers in the region.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei closes up on weak yen
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index rose 0.31% to close at 23,002.37, driven by a weaker yen amid easing trade war concerns. The broader Topix index fell 0.08%. The gains followed a decline in the US dollar, which is linked to the yen.

site_title: Philippines' Ayala looks to sell big stake in coal unit, turn to renewables
summary: AC Energy Inc, a unit of Philippine conglomerate Ayala Corp, is exploring the sale of up to 50% stake in its coal-fired energy unit, AC Thermal, to fund its renewable energy business in Southeast Asia. The company is in talks with potential partners and expects to make a final decision within the year. AC Energy aims to expand its overall energy capacity to over 5,000 megawatts by 2025 and reach a 50-50 mix of thermal and renewable energy sources. The sale could raise up to US$1 billion, according to reports.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Malaysia's debt exceeds RM1 trillion, with Prime Minister Mahathir blaming the previous government led by Najib Razak. Perennial Real Estate Holdings has appointed Kempinski to operate The Capitol Kempinski Hotel Singapore. Tat Hong has crossed the 90% threshold for valid acceptances in its buyout offer. Crowdfunded headphones startup Ossic has shut down, and Bank of Singapore has signed a MOU with SMBC Trust Bank. ASEAN is at an inflexion point, according to Minister Chan Chun Sing, amid mounting pressure on its open and rules-based multilateral trading system.

site_title: Left behind: why boomtown New Zealand has a homelessness crisis
summary: New Zealand, known for its thriving economy, faces a homelessness crisis with the highest rate among 35 high-income OECD countries. Despite a booming dairy sector and rising prosperity, tens of thousands of residents are forced into homelessness due to unaffordable rents and property prices. The government has allocated NZ$3.8 billion to build social infrastructure and increase affordable housing supply, but experts say the plan may not be enough to address the crisis, which has worsened since 2015.

site_title: Grab partners Maybank to promote GrabPay in Malaysia
summary: Grab has partnered Maybank to promote GrabPay in Malaysia, bringing its mobile wallet to the country. The partnership aims to drive acceptance and usage of GrabPay in Malaysia, following Singapore. Grab secured its e-money licence in December and plans to roll out GrabPay across all eight South-east Asian countries this year. A beta version of GrabPay is set to launch in Malaysia in the coming weeks.

site_title: Oil gains near US$72 as world's top economies reach trade truce
summary: US oil futures rose 0.9% near US$72 a barrel as a trade truce between the US and China eased fears of a trade war, boosting oil prices. The truce, announced by US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, aims to balance trade. Saudi Arabia and Russia, top oil producers, are set to meet to discuss oil prices and global inventories. Oil has gained for a third month due to geopolitical tensions and US sanctions on Iran's oil exports.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon trading at 3,559.81, up 0.9%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Monday, with the Straits Times Index advancing 30.54 points, or 0.9%, to 3,559.81. The index saw 716.8 million shares change hands, with gains outnumbering losses 177 to 156. Notable movers included Venture Corp (up 3.1%) and DBS (up 1.8%).

site_title: Anwar reassures Malays who fear losing racial advantage
summary: Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim reassured ethnic Malays that their security would be upheld if he becomes prime minister, after previously calling for dismantling affirmative action policies. Anwar said he would honor guarantees for ethnic Malays and protect their opportunities, but not enrich them. He also focused on correcting economic inequality, worsened by the previous government. Anwar's ideological shift signals a more coherent coalition, and he aims to promote unity by rooting out corruption, which he believes would save billions of dollars a year.

images.alt_text: Anwar Ibrahim has a simple message for ethnic Malays who fear losing benefits they enjoyed under the previous government's six-decade rule: Don't worry.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise as US-China trade war fears ease
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.6% on Monday, May 21, 2018, after US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said the US-China trade war was put "on hold", easing trade tensions. The Hang Seng index rose to 31,234.35 points, while the China Enterprises Index remained unchanged. This easing of trade tensions boosted risk appetite and led to increased trading volume of 1.65 billion shares.

site_title: Singapore shares close up by 0.54% on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 18.96 points, or 0.54%, to 3,548.23 on Monday, driven by a thaw in US-China trade tensions. Wilmar International and Hi-P International saw gains, while Tokyo, Seoul, and Hong Kong also rose. The region's markets were lifted by the US-China trade talks, with the US stock market near record highs despite tariff concerns.

site_title: Indonesia central bank steps up FX swap auctions to support liquidity
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, will conduct three foreign exchange swap auctions this week to boost rupiah liquidity following a 25 basis point interest rate hike. The move aims to provide liquidity to banks before the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan and Eid al-Fitr celebrations. The auctions increase the frequency of BI's FX swap auctions, which were previously conducted twice a week. The rupiah has been under pressure due to rising US Treasury yields and the dollar's rally.

site_title: Philippines' Ayala looks to sell big stake in coal unit, turn to renewables
summary: Philippine conglomerate Ayala Corp's subsidiary AC Energy Inc plans to sell up to 50% stake in its coal-fired energy unit, AC Thermal, to boost its renewables business in Southeast Asia. The sale is expected to raise up to $1 billion, and the company is in talks with potential partners. AC Energy aims to expand its overall energy capacity to over 5,000 megawatts by 2025, with a 50-50 mix of thermal and renewable energy. The company has nearly doubled its net profit in the first quarter of this year, driven by robust contributions from its Indonesia investment and coal and renewable platforms.

site_title: Thai Q1 GDP grows at fastest pace in 5 years, government raises 2018 growth forecast
summary: Thailand's economy experienced its fastest growth in five years in the first quarter, with a 2.0% seasonally adjusted GDP growth rate. The National Economic and Social Development Board raised its 2018 growth forecast to 4.2-4.7%, citing strong exports and tourism. Private consumption and investment also showed signs of improvement, but the government expects growth to slow due to a high base effect.

site_title: Europe: Shares inch up as trade war concerns ease
summary: European stocks rose 0.3% in early trading on Monday, driven by easing trade war concerns and a strong dollar that supported exporters. The FTSE 100 hit a new record high, while the pan-European STOXX 600 index hovered near its highest level in over 3 months. However, budget airline Ryanair was weighed down by a disappointing outlook, and Italy's FTSE MIB fell 1.7% due to stocks going ex-dividend, including Intesa Sanpaolo.

site_title: Malaysia brings back old corruption fighters for new 1MDB task force
summary: Malaysia is reviving its 1MDB probe with a new task force led by former Attorney-General Abdul Gani Patail and former anti-graft agency chief commissioner Abu Kassim Mohamed. The team will focus on tracking down embezzlement of funds and prosecuting individuals involved in wrongdoing. The task force includes representatives from the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission, Attorney-General's Chambers, Royal Malaysia Police, and Bank Negara Malaysia. The move comes as Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad seeks to root out corruption in his administration, following his election just two weeks ago.

site_title: Ryanair posts record annual profit, pessimistic on year ahead
summary: Ryanair posted a record annual profit of 1.45 billion euros, up 10% from the previous year. Despite a record 20,000 cancelled flights in September, the airline expects to grow traffic by 7% to 139 million passengers in the coming year. However, unit costs are expected to rise by 9% due to higher staff and oil prices, leading to a pessimistic outlook for the year ahead. The airline's Chief Executive Michael O'Leary warned that forward bookings are strong but pricing remains soft, with fares expected to be broadly flat.

site_title: China's wealth gap: Teslas for the rich, footpaths for the poor
summary: China's wealth gap is vast, with residents in Shanghai and Beijing enjoying average incomes similar to those in Switzerland, while rural areas struggle with limited access to basic services. The country's economic disparities are driven by urbanization and government policies favoring coastal cities. Despite efforts to narrow the gap, with household incomes converging at a fast pace, the disparity remains significant, with some regions ranking among the poorest in the world. China's anti-poverty campaign aims to address this issue, with policymakers seeking to rebalance regional development and ensure sustainable economic growth.

site_title: At US$78,000, Tesla moves mass-market Model 3 beyond masses
summary: Elon Musk's Tesla Model 3 has surpassed its initial mass-market price point, now costing $78,000, with the latest performance model. This is a deliberate move by Musk to increase profit margins, as the company operates at a loss and has negative cash flow. The Model 3's production rate is expected to reach 5,000 units a week, allowing Tesla to eventually offer a base model priced at $35,000, but for now, the car is priced out of reach for many consumers.

site_title: Manpower Ministry to conduct labour force survey on 33,000 Singapore households
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore will conduct a labour force survey on 33,000 households from May 21 to July 31, collecting personal and labour-related information to compile manpower statistics. Households will be notified by post, and those who don't participate can be contacted by MOM interviewers. The survey aims to inform policy and program formulation, and the information collected will be safeguarded under the Statistics Act.

site_title: Australian shares end flat as financials and materials weigh; NZ falls
summary: Australian shares closed flat on Monday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index falling 2.90 points to 6,084.5, despite a rise in the healthcare index to a record high. Banking stocks declined, while materials stocks fell due to China's Dalian iron ore futures dropping 3%. Global miner BHP and Rio Tinto slid 0.4% and 0.9%, respectively. In contrast, biotherapeutics developer CSL Ltd rose to its highest level ever after raising its annual profit outlook.

site_title: SPH ties up with Parcel Santa to expand footprint in e-commerce, last-mile delivery
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has partnered with Parcel Santa to expand its e-commerce delivery footprint, using SPH's 3,000 vendors and 59 Buzz Convenience Stores to deliver parcels to secured lockers in condominiums. The partnership aims to create a nationwide common parcel locker system, with the first pilot in Bukit Panjang and Punggol in October. Recipients will receive an SMS notification and can collect their parcels within 24 hours or reschedule for a later time. The delivery process is monitored by Parcel Santa's proprietary system, providing a secure and efficient last-mile delivery solution.

site_title: Shorter, hotter, earlier: Shrinking spring slashes Pakistani harvests
