site_title: UBS said to target topline acceleration at investment bank
summary: UBS plans to focus on growing its merger and IPO advisory business to offset declining trading revenue. The investment bank aims to increase revenue by several hundred million Swiss francs annually over the next three to four years, while keeping costs in check. This strategy is part of the bank's regular review and is expected to remain unchanged, with a focus on profit over top-line growth. The corporate client solutions unit, which advises on dealmaking, is critical to serving wealthy clients from the private bank.

site_title: Economic crime reported in Singapore 'at record high'
summary: A PwC survey found that 35% of Singapore organizations reported suffering fraud in the last two years, the highest rate since 2005. This mirrors a global increase of 13 percentage points in reported economic crime. The most common types of fraud were asset misappropriation (44%) and business misconduct (41%). Companies reported losses of US$1 million or more in 32% of cases, and only 39% of respondents have specific policies addressing bribery and corruption risks.

site_title: Understanding hearing loss
summary: Untreated hearing loss can lead to dementia, social isolation, and mental health issues. There are two main types of hearing loss: conductive and sensorineural. Conductive hearing loss is caused by problems with the outer ear, eardrum, or ear bones, while sensorineural hearing loss is caused by issues with the inner ear structures and nerves. Treatable causes include impacted earwax, infections, skin conditions, and benign bony growths. In severe cases, hearing aids, surgery, or hearing implants may be necessary. Early treatment and diagnosis can prevent progressive hearing loss and improve quality of life.

site_title: A royal wedding and anniversary of the brutal beheading of Anne Boleyn
summary: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's wedding on May 19, 2018, coincidentally falls on the anniversary of King Henry VIII's execution of Anne Boleyn. The couple's wedding date was chosen without consideration for its historical significance, with some historians speculating that the royal family may have deliberately avoided the date to avoid bad luck. site_title: Japan reserves right to take counter measures against US steel tariffs
summary: Japan has notified the World Trade Organisation (WTO) that it reserves the right to take counter measures against US tariffs on steel and aluminium imports. Tokyo will wait for further US steps before deciding on implementing "rebalancing" measures, which could impact Japanese companies. The decision aims to protect Japanese businesses from the US tariffs, but no specific actions have been announced at this time.

site_title: 4G leaders will listen to people's views and launch discussion series, says Heng
summary: Singapore's 4G leaders vow to listen to citizens' views and launch discussion series, promising to partner all Singaporeans regardless of age, occupation, or interests. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for humility, respect, and open-mindedness in decision-making, with a focus on harnessing the strengths of every Singaporean to address complex challenges. The Government will communicate its thinking clearly and give everyone a role in turning good ideas into concrete action, according to Heng.

images.alt_text: Mr Heng urges the people to be open to change, and to actively engage with it and seek their place in the world.

site_title: A*Star: Efforts to spur local firms to innovate are working
summary: Singapore's Research, Innovation and Enterprise (RIE) 2020 plan is yielding positive results, with businesses responding well to collaborations with A*Star for research and development (R&D) projects. summary: A proposed merger between ESR-Reit and Viva Industrial Trust (VIT) could lead to more industrial Reit deals in Singapore. site_title: China's CEFC threatens to sue Czech firm amid debt debacle
summary: Chinese energy group CEFC has threatened to sue Czech firm J&T Private Investments over taking over its Prague-based unit due to unpaid debts of 450 million euros. site_title: China denies offering a US$200b package to slash US trade gap
summary: China has denied offering a US$200 billion package to slash the US trade deficit, contradicting US officials who said China was proposing trade concessions and increased purchases of American goods. Chinese Vice Premier Liu He met with US officials in Washington for talks aimed at heading off a trade war. site_title: Higher interest rates mean bonds and leverage don't mix
summary: Higher interest rates will negatively impact bonds and leverage, causing investors to lose money. Investors should factor in rising interest rates when building a diversified portfolio, keeping maturities shorter to minimize losses. Historically, central banks have tightened monetary policy until the economy slows, indicating interest rates will continue to rise. As a result, long-dated bonds are underperforming cash and are likely to continue doing so for the next decade, making it crucial for investors to avoid leveraging bond portfolios.

site_title: Indonesian rate hike may slow, not stop, outflow of foreign funds
summary: Bank Indonesia's first interest-rate hike since 2014 failed to curb the decline of the rupiah, which fell 0.8% to its weakest since October 2015. The central bank may need to raise rates again to slow outflows of foreign funds, with analysts predicting a 25-basis point hike in the second half. The country has seen a net $2.3 billion withdrawal from sovereign bonds and $1.2 billion from shares since March, with the benchmark 10-year bond yield trading near its highest in 14 months.

site_title: Tax me if you can
summary: The British government has imposed various taxes on everyday items, such as windows, soaps, and pastries, throughout history. The window tax, introduced in 1696, led to houses being boarded up to avoid paying the tax, resulting in reduced daylight. The soap tax, introduced in the 18th century, was eventually abolished due to its regressive nature and criticism from the public. The "pasty tax" in 2012 sparked public outcry, but was eventually amended to exempt freshly baked pastries. These examples highlight the power of public opinion and the importance of considering the impact of taxes on citizens' daily lives.

site_title: AstraZeneca's Q1 profit hit by falling Crestor sales
summary: AstraZeneca's Q1 profit fell 46% to $896 million due to generic competition to Crestor and higher costs. Crestor sales dropped 38% in Europe and Japan as cheaper versions stole market share. Despite the decline, the company expects a better second half and remains on track for a return to sales growth in 2018.

site_title: Pacific Radiance spells out details of restructuring plan
summary: Pacific Radiance, an offshore marine operator, has proposed a restructuring plan to attract US$120 million in investment through the subscription of new ordinary shares. The plan, if implemented, would re-profile existing financial obligations, forgiving US$100 million and repaying US$100 million over three years. The existing mortgage loan will be repaid based on its existing schedule. Pacific Radiance's Board believes the plan will ensure business sustainability and positioning for sector recovery. site_title: Guilt-tripped at work? Pause before saying 'yes'
summary: A highly competent employee, Esther, was guilt-tripped into taking on excessive work responsibilities, ultimately leading to burnout and her departure from the company. The power of guilt often drives workers to say "yes" to requests, even when they can't handle the workload. To avoid this, Esther learned to say "no" and set boundaries by offering alternatives, such as delegating tasks or providing background information. Practicing assertive communication, including being polite yet firm, and setting priorities can help individuals draw clear boundaries and prioritize their well-being.

site_title: Indebted Kushner Tower gets a Qatar-linked lifeline
summary: The Kushner Cos, controlled by Jared Kushner's family, is close to receiving a bailout of its troubled flagship building, 666 Fifth Ave, through a partnership with Brookfield Asset Management, a company with ties to the Qatari government. site_title: How to accept a compliment
summary: A writer, inspired by Dove Chocolate's advice, decided to accept compliments without self-deprecation or distraction. Initially responding with a mix of acknowledgment and deflection, they attempted a simple "Thank you" after receiving a compliment on their hair. This shift in response restored order and allowed them to fully appreciate the compliment. By accepting praise without hesitation, they gained confidence and a more positive attitude towards receiving compliments.

site_title: Pacific Radiance spells out restructuring plan for new US$120m capital injection
summary: Pacific Radiance, an offshore marine operator, has proposed a restructuring plan to receive a US$120 million capital injection from investors. site_title: The big battery boom hits another roadblock: fire-fearing cities
summary: US city planners are concerned about the risk of fires from large batteries used in energy storage, following electric-car crashes across America and Europe. Experts warn that improper handling of these batteries can lead to fatalities, highlighting the need for improved safety standards and emergency response protocols.

images.alt_text: The new era of big batteries has already drawn scrutiny after fiery electric-car crashes across America and Europe. Now, US city planners are worried about the same risk of hard-to-control blazes as these power-storage units make their way into basements and onto rooftops.

site_title: A bottle of Macallan whisky just sold for a record HK$7.96m
summary: A 60-year-old bottle of Macallan whisky sold for a record HK$7.96 million (S$1.36 million) at Bonhams Hong Kong, surpassing the previous auction record of HK$4.9 million set in 2014. summary: MAINBOARD-listed Oxley Holdings has sold an 80% stake in its subsidiary, Oxley Batam, to Catalist-listed Rich Capital Holdings for S$10.39 million. site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon trading at 3,526.03, down 0.3% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Friday, with the Straits Times Index falling 10.73 points to 3,526.03, down 0.3%. Losers outnumbered gainers 180 to 123, with 819.8 million shares changing hands. Notable movers included Falcon Energy rising 6.8% and Venture Corp gaining 3.2%. OCBC Bank fell 1.5%.

site_title: Thai snails kept 'happy' and healthy for their cosmetic slime
summary: Thai farmers are breeding giant African snails for their cosmetic slime, which is used in face serums and moisturizers. The snails are kept in a stress-free environment with organic food, resulting in high-quality mucus. The slime is extracted and sold to companies in South Korea, the US, and China, with some cosmetics brands paying up to five times Thailand's minimum monthly wage. The snail farming industry is minimal, with snails only being extracted once a month, and some farms even give them a break from slime extraction for four months a year.

site_title: Cambridge Analytica files for US bankruptcy after Facebook data scandal
summary: Cambridge Analytica, a UK-based political consulting firm, has filed for bankruptcy in New York, citing estimated liabilities of $1 million to $10 million. The company, which harvested Facebook data to influence the 2016 US election, has already ceased operations in the UK. The US bankruptcy proceeding may provide insight into the company's relationships and finances, as US legal proceedings are more transparent. This comes after the company faced intense scrutiny and criticism following the Facebook data scandal.

site_title: China drops anti-dumping probe of US sorghum imports
summary: China's Commerce Ministry halted its anti-dumping investigation into US sorghum imports, citing measures that would affect consumers and not align with public interest. This move comes as Chinese Vice Premier Liu He is in Washington for talks on resolving trade tensions between the US and China. China had imposed hefty anti-dumping deposits on US sorghum imports in April. The decision is seen as a step towards easing trade tensions between the two nations.

site_title: Asia: Energy firms soar with oil prices, dealers eye trade talks
summary: Oil prices surged, with Brent crude breaking the $80 mark for the first time in three-and-a-half years, driving energy firms higher. Global energy giants are expected to see fatter profits, with Hong Kong-listed PetroChina and CNOOC among the big gainers. Rising oil prices also increase inflation concerns, and the US Federal Reserve's interest rate-raising cycle is spooking investors. Meanwhile, high-level China-US trade talks are ongoing, with markets hoping for a deal to avoid a trade war.

site_title: Chinatown Plaza sold en bloc for S$260m
summary: Chinatown Plaza, a 33,953 sq ft site zoned for commercial and residential use, has been sold en bloc for S$260 million to RGE, a Singapore-based property unit. The sale translates to a land rate of S$1,915 psf ppr. Apartment owners can expect between S$3.44 million to S$4.79 million per unit, while shop owners can expect between S$1.64 million to S$10.62 million per unit. The sale is seen as a rare freehold mixed-use site in the city centre, allowing for long-term investment.

site_title: OCBC launches hybrid unit trust, combining fixed maturity product with call option strategy
summary: OCBC Bank and Lion Global Investors have launched the Lion-OCBC Global Income 2021 Fund, a hybrid unit trust that combines a fixed maturity product with a call option strategy to provide potential capital gains. The fund invests in a diversified portfolio of global bonds with an average investment-grade rating and targets a 9% payout, broken down into 3.5% per annum for the first two years and a variable distribution in the third year. The annual management fee is 1.2% in Year 1, decreasing to 0.4% in Year 3.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish week with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week with gains, driven by rising oil prices, as the Hang Seng Index rose 0.34% to 31,047.91. The Shanghai Composite Index climbed 1.24% to 3193.30, while the Shenzhen Composite Index advanced 0.33% to 1828.79. Investors are monitoring high-level China-US trade talks, but the market has largely brushed off recent US tariff threats, extending its rally.

site_title: Bank of Japan inflation target recedes as consumers resist price rises
summary: Japan's core consumer price growth slowed in April for the second straight month, reaching 0.7% from a year earlier, below the Bank of Japan's 2% inflation target. The slowdown is unwelcome for the central bank, which had hoped companies would hike prices at the start of the new business year. Analysts expect GDP growth to slow this year, suggesting capacity shortages won't intensify further, and inflation will likely hover below 1% in the coming months.

site_title: Australia: Shares hurt by materials losses, CSL shines on profit upgrade; NZ gain
summary: Australian shares fell 0.19% to 6,083, hurt by weak commodity prices and a pullback in the healthcare sector. However, CSL Ltd rose 5.6% to a record high after upgrading its full-year profit forecast, driven by a severe influenza season in the northern hemisphere. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.25% to 8,624.91, driven by Ryman Healthcare's 14% jump in full-year profit and Goodman Property Trust's 2.5% gain to a 10-year high.

site_title: Thailand's junta targets opposition for criticising election delays
summary: Thailand's military government has charged opposition members of the Puea Thai Party with violating a ban on political activity, sedition, and computer crimes after criticizing the delay of general elections. The charges follow a news conference by the party, which was founded by ousted former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra. The junta, which has ruled since 2014, has repeatedly delayed elections, sparking protests in Bangkok seeking a quick return to democracy. The charges are seen as an attempt to silence critics and maintain public perception of the junta's legitimacy.

site_title: Taiwan's Tsai under mid-term pressure over economic woes
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen faces mid-term pressure as her approval rating plummets to 26% due to economic stagnation and pension cuts. Thousands of military veterans and civil servants protest against the cuts, which Ms. Tsai has labelled "painful but necessary" to prevent public-sector pension schemes from collapsing. The protests have seen physical attacks on journalists and the death of a retired colonel. Despite criticism, Ms. Tsai remains committed to reforms, arguing that the public will see benefits over time, and her government faces a major test in the November local elections.

site_title: Europe: Shares set to extend winning streak on oil surge, weak euro
summary: European shares are set to extend their winning streak, supported by a surge in oil prices and a weaker euro, despite concerns over Italy's government and potential fiscal discipline. The pan-European STOXX 600 index fell 0.3% but remains near its highest level in three months, with energy shares and the FTSE MIB leading the gains.

images.alt_text: European shares dipped in morning trading on Friday but were on course for eight straight weeks of gains, supported by a rally in energy shares and a weaker euro, which helped investors shrug off worries over political risk in Italy.

site_title: Singapore's 3rd derivatives exchange Apex to start trading on May 25
summary: Singapore's third derivatives exchange, Asia Pacific Exchange Pte (Apex), will start trading on May 25, offering dollar-denominated palm olein futures that can be physically delivered. Apex, backed by industry veteran Eugene Zhu, is privately funded and has over 60 employees. The exchange aims to become the Asian pricing benchmark for palm oil, following China's efforts to integrate into the global financial system. This move is part of China's push to expand its derivatives markets overseas, with stakes in markets in Bangladesh and Pakistan, and a joint venture with Deutsche Boerse AG in Frankfurt.

site_title: US, China tariffs have had 'limited' direct effect on Singapore economy so far: Chan Chun Sing
summary: The US and China tariffs have had a limited direct impact on Singapore's economy, with a 0.09% estimated impact on exports. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing stated this in Parliament, replying to questions on the protectionist measures taken by the US and China. The tariffs primarily affect a small percentage of Singapore's exports, suggesting a relatively minimal economic impact so far.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, CCT, Hyphens Pharma
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is merging SilkAir into its flagship brand, investing over S$100 million to upgrade SilkAir's fleet with new seats and in-flight entertainment systems. CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) priced an upsized S$217.9 million unit placement at S$1.676 apiece. Hyphens Pharma International received strong interest for its IPO, with 4,800 valid applications and S$118.5 million in application monies.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.09 points to 1,859.53 on Friday, driven by a higher opening. Volume was 79.59 million lots worth RM29 million, with 118 gainers and 48 losers.

site_title: Prince Charles to walk Meghan Markle down the aisle: palace
summary: Prince Charles will walk Meghan Markle down the aisle during her wedding to Prince Harry after her father, Thomas Markle, pulled out due to health reasons. Meghan had requested Prince Charles to accompany her, and he has agreed, welcoming her to the royal family.

images.alt_text: Prince Charles will walk Meghan Markle down the aisle during her marriage to his son Prince Harry after her father pulled out of the ceremony for health reasons, Kensington Palace announced Friday.

site_title: Toyota plans to roll into China's EV market in GAC Motor vehicle
summary: Toyota is partnering with GAC Motor to sell an electric vehicle in China, the GAC Toyota ix4, without its logo. The car is based on GAC's Trumpchi GS4 and will feature the label of GAC Motor. Toyota aims to meet China's 10% electric vehicle quota by 2019 and will start selling the ix4 by the end of the year. This partnership shows Toyota's shift towards electric vehicles, as the company previously planned to focus on hydrogen fuel-cell technology. The move is seen as a creative solution to meet the strict production quotas for electric cars in China.

site_title: Shanghai stock exchange cracks down on share-backed loans by controlling stakeholders: media
summary: The Shanghai stock exchange has cracked down on controlling shareholders who pledge high percentages of their shares as collateral for financing, citing concerns over market instability. The exchange has asked 150 firms' controlling shareholders to disclose loans and take measures to avoid a credit crisis. In some cases, the exchange assisted investors in safe share disposals. New disclosure requirements on share pledges are also being finalized, requiring publication of associated credit arrangements. The move aims to mitigate risks associated with share-backed loans and stabilize the market.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks, won edge up amid caution on US-China trade talks
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index and the Korean won rose on Friday, driven by a 8% jump in shares of Samsung BioLogics after Biogen exercised its call option. Investors remain cautious amid US-China trade talks and developments in US-North Korea negotiations. The Kospi index was up 10.94 points or 0.45% at 2,459.39, while the won was quoted at 1,079.6 per dollar, 0.15% firmer than its previous close.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday, STI down 0.3% to 3,526.94
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index falling 0.3% to 3,526.94. The decline followed US stocks' overnight drop due to President Donald Trump's comments on trade talks with China. The market saw an even split of gainers and losers, with 52.9 million shares changing hands worth S$51 million.

site_title: Hyphens Pharma rises on trading debut
summary: Hyphens Pharma International, a specialty pharmaceutical and consumer healthcare group, made its trading debut on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board, rising 15.4% to 28.5 Singapore cents on its first day of trading. The company raised approximately S$118.5 million from its IPO, with cornerstone investors subscribing for 30.4 million shares. Hyphens Pharma plans to use the funds for business expansion, acquisitions, and product development. The company's post-IPO market capitalisation is S$78.0 million.

site_title: ESR-Reit, Viva Industrial Trust to merge; VIT stapled securityholders to receive S$0.96 per unit
summary: ESR-Reit and Viva Industrial Trust (VIT) announced a proposed merger to create Singapore's fourth-largest industrial Reit with a combined S$3 billion in assets. The deal will be completed through a trust scheme of arrangement, with ESR-Reit acquiring all of VIT's stapled securities and issuing new units to stapled security holders. VIT stapled securityholders will receive S$0.96 per unit, and the merger is deemed value-accretive for VIT and distribution-accretive for ESR-Reit. The merger is expected to be completed by the third quarter this year, subject to regulatory approvals.

site_title: The Royal Wedding Quiz
summary: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's historic wedding took place on May 19, 2018. They met through a mutual friend in London, with their third date being a safari adventure in Botswana. Meghan's wedding dress designer remains a secret, but the lemon elderflower cake was designed by Claire Ptak of Violet Bakery. The couple's honeymoon plans were not announced, and they hope to start a family soon. Harry's best man was Prince William, and Meghan has reportedly no relationship with her half-siblings.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as yen falls
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on May 18, 2018, as a weaker yen boosted exporter shares. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.24% and the Topix index rose 0.16%. This was largely due to the cheaper yen, which supported Japanese exporters.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly higher on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.30% to 31,033.97. The gains came amid crucial talks between China and the US aimed at averting a trade war. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.10% and the Shenzhen Composite Index edged down 0.13%. The small gains in Hong Kong stocks were seen as a positive sign, despite ongoing trade tensions between the US and China.

site_title: China offering Trump package to slash US trade deficit, officials say
summary: China has offered the US a package of trade concessions and increased purchases of American goods to cut the US trade deficit with China by up to $200 billion a year, according to US officials. The proposal includes eliminating Chinese tariffs on US farm products and Boeing aircraft sales. The US and China are engaged in ongoing trade discussions, with the US seeking a fair trading relationship and China reportedly asking for the US to set aside tariff threats and relax export controls.

images.alt_text: China is offering US President Donald Trump a package of trade concessions and increased purchases of American goods aimed at cutting the US trade deficit with China by up to US$200 billion a year, US officials familiar with the proposal said.

site_title: Walmart online sales surge, earnings beat expectations
summary: Walmart reported quarterly profits down $905 million, but earnings per share beat expectations at $1.14. Net sales rose 4.4% to $121.6 billion, driven by a 33% surge in US online sales. The company aims to grow online sales by 40% this year, focusing on affluent millennials and grocery delivery. International sales jumped 4.5%, and shares closed down 1.9% despite a strong performance.

site_title: Inheriting slowing Malaysian economy, Mahathir makes tax changes
summary: Malaysia's annual economic growth slowed to 5.4% in the first quarter of 2018, marking the second consecutive quarter of deceleration. The new government, led by 92-year-old Mahathir Mohamad, is facing the challenge of turning around the economy. Domestic demand is expected to help growth stay favourable, despite the slowdown. The change in administration has introduced tax changes, aiming to boost economic growth.

site_title: Australian dollar near 3-1/2-month highs against kiwi, boosted by oil
summary: The Australian dollar has reached a 3-1/2-month high against the New Zealand dollar, boosted by a surge in oil prices and a subtle divergence in monetary policy stances between the two countries. The commodity-driven currency has held at US$1.0903 on the kiwi, with oil prices reaching 3-1/2 year highs due to strong demand and supply cuts. The Aussie is on track for a sixth consecutive winning week, while the kiwi is on track for its fifth straight weekly loss.

site_title: ESR-Reit, VIT halt trading amid talk of possible merger announcement
summary: ESR-Reit and Viva Industrial Trust (VIT) halted trading on Friday amid speculation of a possible merger announcement. ESR-Reit's proposed acquisition of VIT's stapled securities could make it the fourth largest industrial S-Reit, with a combined portfolio of S$3 billion. The merger would be the first in Singapore Reits history, and analysts expect VIT to be ESR-Reit's next target. The period of exclusivity for discussions on the proposed merger has been extended to May 31.

site_title: YouTube revamps streaming music service
summary: YouTube is launching a revamped streaming music service, YouTube Music, as part of its effort to compete with Spotify and Apple Music. The service will be available in the US, Australia, New Zealand, Mexico, and South Korea, with a free, ad-supported version and an ad-free subscription at $9.99/month. The premium service, priced at $11.99/month, will include ad-free music and be available as a standalone option or with YouTube Premium. The move aims to separate YouTube's paid video plan from the music service.

site_title: Acra rejects China Environment's request to push back AGM, filing of financial statements
summary: China Environment's request to push back its annual general meeting (AGM) to June 30 was rejected by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) due to the company's failure to restate and re-audit its FY13 and FY14 financial statements and produce its financial statements for FY15 and FY16. The company had sought another extension, but Acra required the financial statements to be refiled first. As a result, the audited financial statements for FY15 and FY16 will be deferred. The company's subsidiaries have been subject to enforcement orders, and the company has stated it will not pay off civil suit liabilities.

site_title: Cuscaden Road GLS site to be developed into luxury residence
summary: A luxury residential project will be developed on a 5,722.5 sq m Government Land Sales (GLS) site at Cuscaden Road, Singapore, after it was awarded to a consortium for S$410 million, setting a new record for GLS sites. The project will focus on arts and culture, and the consortium, comprising SC Global, New World Development, and Far East Consortium International, has been praised for delivering original residences that raise the bar in luxury living.

site_title: CCT sells S$217.9m of units at S$1.676 to cover rich end of price talk
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) has priced an S$217.9 million private placement of units at S$1.676 apiece to cover the rich end of initial price talk. The issue price represents a 3.2% discount to the counter's volume weighted average price. The deal was 3.1 times covered, drawing strong demand from institutional and accredited investors. The proceeds will be used to partially finance the acquisition of a prime Frankfurt property and cover placement-related expenses and working capital, with listing expected to commence on May 28.

site_title: Uber chief product officer Jeff Holden leaving company
summary: Uber Technologies Inc chief product officer Jeff Holden is leaving the ride-hailing company, effective Thursday, according to an Uber spokesman. Holden, who oversaw Uber Elevate, the company's flying car operation, will be replaced by Eric Allison. Holden previously spent nine years at Amazon.com Inc and was hired by former Uber CEO Travis Kalanick from Groupon Inc. The departure comes after Holden told colleagues that Thursday was his last day, contradicting earlier plans to deploy flying taxi services in 2020.

site_title: No Ordinary Hero
summary: Deadpool 2, the sequel to the 2016 original, has returned to cinemas, with Ryan Reynolds reprising his role as the titular character. The film pits Deadpool against Cable, a time-travelling super soldier, played by Josh Brolin. Test screenings showed high audience scores, even surpassing the original film's global earnings of over S$1 billion. The movie is expected to live up to its hype, offering a humorous take on the superhero genre, with Deadpool forced to confront friendship, family, and saving the world.

site_title: Global economy to grow faster than expected in 2018-19, at 3.2%: UN
summary: The United Nations predicts a faster-than-expected global economic growth of 3.2% in 2018 and 2019, surpassing previous expectations. This growth is attributed to strong expansion in developed countries and favorable investment conditions. The report also warns that a shift away from multilateralism and increased trade barriers could threaten global growth, particularly for developing economies, and highlights concerns over high inequality and rising carbon emissions.

site_title: Validus, Lighthouse Canton launch S$20m SME financing fund
summary: Validus Capital and Lighthouse Canton Group launched a S$20 million SME financing fund, the LCV Trade Finance Fund, to support small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore. The fund, which aims to grow to S$200 million in three years, will invest in loans originating from Validus' peer-to-peer lending platform. This partnership is expected to provide much-needed financing relief to Singapore SMEs and benefit thousands of businesses.

site_title: Cash-filled designer handbags seized in raids on Malaysia's Najib
summary: Malaysian police seized 72 designer handbags, including Hermes, Birkin, and Louis Vuitton, stuffed with cash, jewelry, and other valuables, in raids linked to former premier Najib Razak. The haul was found in luxury condominiums in Kuala Lumpur, and its value is estimated to be impossible to calculate. The seizures follow Najib's fall from power after his ruling coalition was defeated in national elections, and he is now barred from leaving the country. Charges against Najib are expected, with the new government led by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad pressing forward with its pledge to bring Najib to justice.

site_title: Saudi high-speed rail line to start operating in September
summary: A high-speed railway linking Mecca and Medina in Saudi Arabia will start operating in September, with an initial four trains per week. The project, initially scheduled for 2016, had a cost overrun of 210 million euros. Saudi Arabia agreed to pay the overrun. The 444-kilometer track will provide daily service by September 2019 and can move 166,000 passengers per day. The project's challenges, including sandstorms in the Arabian Desert, were resolved after a visit by Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman to Spain.

site_title: Extending leases for older HDB flats 'will have serious trade-offs'
summary: Singapore's Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong has stated that extending leases for older HDB flats will involve serious trade-offs, including space constraints and costly maintenance. He emphasized that the issue is not straightforward and requires careful consideration of the ramifications. Wong assured residents that the government will study the matter and make responsible decisions, prioritizing the needs of future generations. The government is also exploring options, such as lease buyback schemes, to help homeowners unlock the value of their flats for retirement.

site_title: Japan inflation slows in April to 0.7%
summary: Japan's consumer prices rose 0.7% in April, below the 2% inflation target and weaker than in previous months. The core inflation rate, excluding volatile fresh food prices, also fell to 0.7%. This data comes as Japan's economy contracted 0.2% quarter-on-quarter in the January-March period, ending a series of eight consecutive quarters of growth. The Bank of Japan has signaled no plans to drop its ultra-loose monetary policy, despite its limited impact on deflation.

site_title: Europe: Oil stocks and Ocado buoy equities
summary: European shares rose to a 3-1/2 month high on Thursday, driven by oil stocks and online supermarket Ocado's surge after signing a deal with US retailer Kroger Co. The Stoxx 600 index gained 0.7% and Italy's benchmark index rose 0.3% despite concerns over the new Italian government's fiscal discipline. Oil prices climbed above $80 a barrel, while Ocado's shares surged 44% to an all-time high.

site_title: Bhutan Retreat
summary: Bhutan's annual yoga retreat, Como Uma Bhutan, is set to take place from August 12 to 18, offering daily yoga sessions and guided excursions through the country's valleys, including Taktsang Tiger's Nest Monastery and Punakha Dzong. Participants can enjoy foraging for Matsutake mushrooms and stay in twin-sharing rooms at US$4,480 per person. Email singapore@comoshambhala.com to book.

site_title: Oil steady after retreating from 2014 highs on dollar strength
summary: Oil prices rose above $80 a barrel for the first time since November 2014, before retreating due to a stronger dollar and increased US output. The US dollar hit a four-month high, making oil more expensive for importing nations. Global inventories have dropped sharply due to robust demand and Opec-led production cuts. Despite record US domestic output, prices remain elevated due to concerns over Venezuelan production and potential US sanctions.

site_title: SIA to merge SilkAir into flagship carrier; CEO cites connectivity within plane fleet
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) plans to merge SilkAir into its flagship carrier, improving connectivity across its fleet. The move aims to enhance passenger experience with upgraded cabins, including new lie-flat seats and in-flight entertainment systems. SIA will invest over S$100 million in SilkAir's fleet upgrades, starting from 2020. The merger is expected to boost connectivity within SIA's wide- and narrow-body planes.

site_title: Study finds more isn't better for Roche breast cancer drug
summary: A new study finds that women with HER-2 positive breast cancer can safely take Roche's Herceptin for 6 months, just as likely to be cancer-free after 4 years, as those taking the drug for 12 months. This reduced treatment duration also cuts in half the number of women who must stop the drug early due to heart side effects. The research suggests that a personalized approach to treatment, tailoring duration to individual patients, could be more effective and cost-efficient.

images.alt_text: Herceptin was a lifesaving breakthrough for women with aggressive and fast-growing HER-2 positive cancer when it was approved in 1998.

site_title: Aid groups warn of growing risks as Paris migrant camps swell
summary: Aid groups in Paris are warning of deteriorating conditions at two large migrant camps, citing security and health risks. The camps, housing around 2,200 people from Sudan, Eritrea, and Afghanistan, have seen makeshift shelters and tent cities form. Authorities have been urged to address the issue, which aid groups say could lead to further tensions. The camps have been established since 2015, following a surge in migrant arrivals in Europe.

site_title: US: Stocks dip amid rising trade, political anxiety
summary: US stocks closed in the red on Thursday, dipping 0.2% as investors reacted to President Trump's skepticism on trade talks with China and rising oil prices. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq fell 0.2% to 24,713.98 and 7,382.47, respectively. However, the Russell 2000 index of small-cap stocks reached an all-time high, suggesting investors are seeking safe harbor amid global uncertainty. Trump's comments and concerns over Iranian sanctions also weighed on oil prices, but ended flat.

site_title: Preventing knee pain in Singapore
summary: Orthopaedic surgeon Henry Chan of HC Orthopaedic Surgery emphasizes the importance of preventing knee pain in Singapore, particularly among high-achieving professionals engaging in extreme sports. Chan notes that five to 10% of his patients are at risk of knee injuries due to overexertion and inadequate training. He recommends non-invasive options such as bracing and physiotherapy, and surgery only after exhausting these alternatives. Chan also highlights technological advancements in computer navigation and robotic surgery, which offer precision in knee replacements and minimizes risks.

site_title: Miss Julie revisited
summary: Miss Julie, a strong-willed woman from August Strindberg's 1888 play, is being reinterpreted by Nine Years Theatre in Singapore as "Pissed Julie". The play, which explores gender conventions, features three actors performing each character on stage, with Mandarin, Cantonese, and English surtitles. The production, which runs until May 20 at the KC Arts Centre, questions whether societal expectations have changed enough to allow women full expression of their desires and ambitions. This bold interpretation challenges traditional notions of femininity and gender roles.

images.alt_text: Pissed Julie.

site_title: PayPal agrees to buy Sweden's iZettle in US$2.2b deal
summary: PayPal has agreed to acquire Sweden's iZettle for $2.2 billion, expanding its presence in in-store payments globally. iZettle, a financial technology startup, offers small businesses a mini credit card reader and lending services. The deal will enable PayPal to accelerate its international expansion, including to the US. iZettle CEO Jacob de Greer will continue to lead the business, which expects to process $6 billion in payments in 2018 and have gross revenues of $165 million. The acquisition marks PayPal's largest-ever deal.

site_title: Royal wedding brings new energy to monarchy
summary: Prince Harry and American actress Meghan Markle are set to marry on Saturday, combining UK royalty and US show business. The wedding is expected to boost the popularity of the monarchy, with Harry's brother Prince William and his wife Kate already having high approval ratings. The couple's marriage may also increase Harry's popularity, and Markle's humanitarian work may make her a popular figure in the UK. The royal family has largely recovered from its 1990s troubles, but Charles, the heir to the throne, has lower popularity ratings, raising uncertainties about the monarchy's future.

site_title: CDL, Distrii join hands in smart building apps
summary: City Developments (CDL) has formed a tech joint venture with Chinese co-working operator Distrii, aiming to develop smart office and building apps in Southeast Asia. The partnership will enable tenants and residents to access various services, including parking, meeting rooms, and payment of bills, through a mobile app. The apps will pilot at CDL's Republic Plaza co-working space by 2019 and eventually be rolled out to all CDL properties. This move is part of CDL's strategy to increase stickiness of tenants and residents, with innovation expected to be a major third leg of the company's business.

site_title: Uniqlo makes designer bid with Tomas Maier for one-off resort collection
summary: Uniqlo has collaborated with designer Tomas Maier on a one-time-only resort-focused collection, marking a departure from the brand's usual approach of working with established designers. The collection, which features 15 men's and 36 women's pieces, showcases Maier's minimalist aesthetic and warm-weather credibility. The collaboration aims to bring Uniqlo's intellectual approach to a more casual, resort-focused market. The collection will be available online and in stores starting May 24, with prices ranging from $9.90 to $99.90.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries subsidiary divests division
summary: Sembcorp Industries' subsidiary, SEMBCORP Environment, has sold its Singapore medical waste division to TEE Medical Services for S$20 million, resulting in a net gain of around S$15 million for the group. The division specializes in treating and disposing of biohazardous and pharmaceutical waste. The sale is part of Sembcorp's strategic efforts to improve performance and strengthen its balance sheet. The company's shares ended trading at S$3.07 apiece, up 0.66%.

site_title: Trump dampens chances of trade deal with China
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed skepticism about reaching a successful trade deal with China, stating he "tends to doubt it" due to China's perceived entitlement to favorable trade agreements. Trump's comments came ahead of a meeting with China's top trade negotiator Liu He, as the two nations seek to avoid a trade war. Trump's remarks were seen as a significant setback for the ongoing talks, which aim to address growing economic tensions between the two economic powers.

site_title: Taking on the big boys, in BT Weekend
summary: Minority shareholders in Singapore are increasingly taking on major companies, demanding better returns, disclosures, and accountability. This trend is driven by the growing awareness of corporate governance among small investors. Futurist Ben Pring warns that this shift could pose significant challenges for executives at large businesses. Meanwhile, other sections explore topics such as the impact of higher interest rates on property stocks, the importance of self-awareness at work, and the history of England's bizarre fiscal penalties.

site_title: ISS tells Facebook shareholders to withhold support for management
summary: ISS recommends that Facebook investors withhold support for 5 directors, including Mark Zuckerberg, citing concerns over board nomination procedures and lack of transparency. The advisory firm suggests creating a formal committee to nominate board candidates to ensure accountability. Investors are also advised to vote in favor of shareholder proposals aimed at improving the company's response to issues like election interference and harassment. Facebook will hold its annual general meeting on May 31 to vote on these proposals.

site_title: New govt confronts slower 5.4% growth in Q1
summary: Malaysia's economy slowed to 5.4% growth in the first quarter of 2018, below a median forecast of 5.5%. Despite this, the central bank expects GDP growth to remain favourable due to continued strength in domestic and global demand. The new government, led by 92-year-old Mahathir Mohamad, has announced plans to scrap a goods and services tax and review previous projects, which may impact inflation and economic growth. The central bank projects 2-3% inflation and accommodative monetary policy.

site_title: Return Flight
summary: Pangdemonium's immigration drama 'Dragonflies' is returning to the Victoria Theatre for a three-week run, featuring a star-studded cast including Adrian Pang and Tan Kheng Hua. The play, set in a near-future Singapore, tells the story of a family torn apart by climate change, populist politics, and shifting immigration laws. Directed by Tracie Pang, 'Dragonflies' is a topical and intelligent drama that feels like a story ripped from the headlines, potentially sparking division. The production runs from May 18 to June 3.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Viva Industrial Trust (VIT) Q1 results met expectations, with a positive growth outlook for its assets. The company's fair value is down to S$0.90 due to management fees. SIA Engineering's forward price earnings and price to book ratios are below standard deviation levels, making it a buy-in opportunity. The company expects double-digit rental reversions for UE Bizhub leases and a growing fleet size in Asia Pacific. SIA Engineering's target price is S$3.92, driven by an upswing in the engine MRO cycle and potential JV/associate income.

site_title: What Tesla can learn from BMW: Ditch the bots, employ real people
summary: BMW's production system, which employs human workers, is seen as a key factor in its success in producing high-quality cars. In contrast to Tesla, which has struggled with producing its Model 3, BMW's approach allows for flexibility and attention to detail, enabling it to consistently churn out elite cars. BMW's electric rollout will start with a battery-powered Mini in 2019 and will serve as a template for upgrading its major plants by 2021, with a focus on flexibility and minimizing inefficiencies.

site_title: CCT to buy majority stake in Frankfurt property for 343m euros
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) will acquire a majority stake in a 38-storey office building in Frankfurt's central business district for 342.7 million euros (S$548 million). The acquisition, partially funded by an equity placement and bank borrowings, is expected to be completed in June and will be CCT's maiden property acquisition outside Asia. The trust will hold a 94.9% stake in the property and plans to allocate 10-20% of its deposited properties for overseas investments.

site_title: How do you move a shark? Very carefully
summary: A team of animal keepers, divers, and a marine biologist carefully relocated eight sharks, including a 2.5m sand tiger named Otis, from a temporary enclosure to their new permanent home at the New York Aquarium. The delicate operation involved using cranes, trucks, and canvas slings to transport the sharks, with the help of red plastic breaker boards for protection. The relocation was part of the $146 million renovation project, which will feature a 5,342 sq m exhibit called "Ocean Wonders: Sharks!" opening to the public on June 30.

site_title: Six slapped with prohibition orders for 'mis-selling'
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued prohibition orders against six insurance agents and a relationship manager for mis-selling insurance and investment products. The individuals, from AIA, Prudential, and Citi, were found to have misled 29 clients, 48 insurance policies, and one structured note. The offences, which occurred between 2009 and 2015, involved vulnerable clients and improper switching. The orders range from two to seven years, and the individuals are barred from providing financial advisory services. MAS emphasized that representatives have a duty of care to customers and will take stern action against those who betray that trust.

site_title: Growing Art
summary: National Gallery Singapore's latest exhibition "(Re)collect: The Making Of Our Art Collection" showcases the growth of the gallery's collection from 110 works in 1960 to over 8,600 today. The show features a diverse range of artworks, including pieces by Malaysian painter-poet Latiff Mohidin, Indonesian father of modern art S Sudjojono, and Singaporean artists Cheo Chai Hiang and Kim Lim. The exhibition highlights the collection's evolution, including the acquisition of new works and the story behind each piece. The show runs until August 19, 2018.

site_title: Metro Holdings buys 35% of JV that's acquiring Shanghai mixed-use building
summary: Metro Holdings Limited has acquired a 35% stake in a joint venture acquiring Shanghai Plaza, a mixed-use building in Shanghai worth 2.9 billion yuan (S$613 million). The joint venture, Shanghai Yi Zhou Property Management Co Ltd, has already acquired 90% of the building, with plans to complete the acquisition by 2020. The move aims to tap Metro's retail expertise and network in Shanghai, a key gateway city and financial hub of China, where the company plans to further expand its presence.

site_title: 56 business services now use MyInfo, after bank trial: GovTech
summary: Singapore's MyInfo platform, a digital government vault, has seen 56 business services tie up with the system, joining 100 public services, after a pilot scheme in the banking sector. The platform automates electronic applications for services such as public housing, using personal data from 3.3 million SingPass holders. More than 150 companies have expressed interest, with telco M1 and real estate website SRX integrating MyInfo authentication and loan platforms. The government aims to link 160 public services by the end of the year, paving the way for a national digital identity service by 2020.

site_title: Chancery Court brings YTD tally to S$8.8b, topping 2017 figure
summary: The collective sales market in Singapore has seen a significant surge, with the first half of 2018 already surpassing the total collective sale figure for 2017, reaching S$8.81 billion. The sale of Chancery Court, a 99-year leasehold site, has topped the asking price, with a land price of about S$1,610 per square foot per plot ratio. Analysts expect the full-year total to reach a new record, surpassing 2007's S$11.4 billion, driven by the en bloc momentum and sustained interest among developers.

images.alt_text: It is barely halfway through the year, but with the sale of ex-HUDC Chancery Court on May 17, the collective sales market has busted the total collective sale figure for the whole of 2017.

site_title: Tencent shares rise after Q1 profit beats estimates
summary: Tencent Holdings reported a 61% jump in net profit and a 48% rise in revenue for its first quarter, beating consensus estimates. Shares rose 7% in Hong Kong after the results, with Credit Suisse and Jefferies lowering their target prices due to higher gross profit margins. However, Jefferies warned of structural business mix changes affecting margins. Tencent's shares have fluctuated this year, losing US$117 billion in market value between its peak and low. As of Thursday, its shares were up 3.3% to HK$409, giving it a market capitalisation of US$496 billion.

site_title: SIA's S$181.8m Q4 net profit surpasses expectations
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a net profit of S$181.8 million in Q4, surpassing expectations, driven by stronger passenger and cargo revenues. The airline's full-year net profit soared to S$892.9 million, with revenue increasing 6.3% to S$15.81 billion. Despite competition and cost pressures, SIA's operating profit for the full year crossed the billion-dollar mark at over S$1.05 billion. The airline group has recommended a final dividend of 30 Singapore cents per share, and plans to add 5% capacity in FY18/19.

site_title: Singtel Q4 earnings slip on lower regional contributions
summary: Singtel reported a 19% decline in Q4 net profit to S$781 million, driven by lower regional contributions from associates Bharti Airtel and Telkomsel. Despite this, the telco expects to pay a final dividend of 10.7 Singapore cents a share and maintains its annual payout of 17.5 Singapore cents a share until FY2020. Singtel attributes the decline to competition in India and Indonesia, but expects improved results in the mid-term.

site_title: Malaysian stock market takes regime change in its stride
summary: The Malaysian stock market has defied expectations after the country's general election, with the benchmark FBM KLCI index holding up well despite fears of a panic sell-down. The index has closed marginally in the red for two days but is up 0.4% this week, outperforming Asian bourses such as Singapore. Despite foreign investors being net sellers of Malaysian equities, the market's resilience is attributed to the new government's smooth transition and articulation of its policies. Analysts now suggest a "buy the dip" approach, citing the potential return of flight capital to Malaysia.

site_title: Zuckerberg agrees to closed-door talks with MEPs
summary: Mark Zuckerberg has agreed to closed-door talks with European Members of Parliament (MEPs) to address the Cambridge Analytica scandal. The meeting, set to take place next week, comes after the EU introduces new data protection rules, with 2.7 million EU citizens affected by the data breach. Facebook has welcomed the opportunity for dialogue and promised to show steps taken to protect people's privacy, amid criticism from lawmakers who want a public hearing.

site_title: Citi fined HK$57m for failings as Real Gold IPO sponsor
summary: Citi's Asian business was fined HK$57 million by Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission for failings as the sponsor of Real Gold Mining Ltd's 2009 IPO. The SFC found Citi failed to conduct adequate due diligence on customers and didn't properly supervise staff. This is the second disciplinary action against a bank for IPO misconduct in Hong Kong. Citi cooperated with the SFC's investigation and took action to ensure compliance with regulations.

site_title: Is an audit report reliable nowadays?
summary: The reliability of audit reports has been questioned, sparking concerns about the independence of auditors. Historically, auditors were expected to be impartial and possess extensive knowledge of the company's business. The audit profession relied on experienced auditors who had built their expertise through apprenticeships and constant tuition. However, the increasing complexity of financial statements and the pressure to deliver results have led to concerns about the integrity of the audit process.

site_title: Only Onigiri
summary: Singaporean izakaya owner Miho Takahashi has introduced her own version of onigiri at her decade-old Inaho's Kitchen Bar. The restaurant offers freshly made rice balls with standard and unusual fillings such as spicy prawn and pork curry, priced from S$9.90 per set meal. Available only during lunch, the onigiri is made with Hokkaido rice and comes with miso soup, egg pieces, and fried chicken. Inaho's Kitchen Bar is located at 60A Duxton Road and can be reserved by calling 62220852.

site_title: Old trades, new trends
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

In Singapore, three businesses - Hock Siong & Co, Dish the Fish, and Tiong Hoe Specialty Coffee - are embracing modern trends while preserving traditional industries. Hock Siong & Co, a second-hand furniture retailer, has modernized its operations with a cloud POS system and social media presence, while Dish the Fish, a fishmonger, uses technology to track sales and customer preferences. Tiong Hoe Specialty Coffee, a specialty coffee roaster, sources high-quality beans directly from coffee farms and filters water to ensure the best brew. These businesses are adapting to changing times while staying true to their core values.

site_title: PE and VC deals into South-east Asia hit record US$23.5b in 2017: report
summary: Private equity and venture capital investments into South-east Asia reached a record US$23.5 billion in 2017, driven by "mega-deals" for valuable companies. The top three deals included investments by Didi Chuxing, Google, Meituan-Dianping, Tencent, and Alibaba in companies like Grab, Go-Jek, and Tokopedia. The investments were largely made by Chinese corporates looking to expand into the region, with companies like Alibaba choosing to buy competitors rather than setting up shop. The trend is expected to continue, with South-east Asia remaining an attractive investment destination due to rapid smartphone adoption and growing technology sector.

site_title: Royal Treatment
summary: Prince Harry's wedding, held on May 19, 2018, has inspired The Langham hotel in London to offer the "Royal Season" experience from May 19 to Oct 12, 2018. Guests can book luxurious rooms and enjoy exclusive access to bespoke tailoring, perfumery, and limited-edition boots. The package includes visits to Royal Warrant holders Gieves & Hawkes, Floris London, and Langham Pink Hunter, as well as a bespoke suit from Gieves & Hawkes in the opulent Infinite Suite. The experience costs between £595 and £15,000 per night.

site_title: Ancient myth of 'good fences' is pretty much a myth
summary: The concept of "good fences" as a means to foster good neighbors is largely a myth, according to the article. In reality, fences have historically been used to define identity, exclude others, and perpetuate biases and prejudices. From ancient Greece to modern times, fences have separated Greeks from foreigners, women from men, and Easterners from Westerners, often leading to the suppression of marginalized groups and the stunting of cultural development. The article suggests that the regeneration of culture occurs when fences of prejudice are breached, allowing encounters between different people, traditions, and ideas.

site_title: Europe car sales speed up in April
summary: Europe's passenger car market experienced a 9.6% growth in April, rebounding from a decline in March. The Spanish market grew the fastest at 12.3%, followed by the UK at 10.4%. Over 1.3 million new cars were registered in April, with Volkswagen seeing a 13.8% surge in sales despite the dieselgate scandal. The European market grew 2.7% from January to April, with only the UK recording a drop of -8.8%.

site_title: When en bloc fever distorts 'lease decay' principle of leasehold property
summary: A recovery in private home prices in Singapore is being driven by unexpectedly strong collective sale fever, where owners of 99-year leasehold properties are enjoying huge windfalls. This has distorted the traditional "lease decay" principle, where the value of older leasehold properties decreases. En bloc sales have allowed owners to extract higher prices, despite shorter remaining leases, as developers can intensify land use. This divergence in prices poses challenges for policymakers, particularly for public housing, where aging HDB flats are a concern.

site_title: Bridal Bling
summary: Graff, a luxury jeweller, is hosting its first pop-up exhibition in Singapore featuring its bridal range, including show-stopping tiaras and engagement rings. The exhibition, running until May 20 at ION Orchard, showcases Graff's exquisite pieces hand-selected by a family member, including the Paragon, Flame, and Laurence Graff signature settings.

images.alt_text: Graff Bridal Jewellery Exhibition.

site_title: Opec may raise oil production despite falling demand
summary: Brent crude oil prices have reached US$80 a barrel, prompting Opec to consider increasing oil production despite falling global demand. The International Energy Agency estimates that demand will grow but has downgraded its forecast due to higher prices. Opec's total crude output rose in April, and the cartel may assess production at its upcoming June 22 meeting. The US and Canada are currently filling the supply gap, but speculative activity is high due to concerns about Iran and a potential conflict between Israel and Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Game Not Over
summary: A 40-year-old games designer, KJ Poh, shares his experience of building his own arcade machines, inspired by his childhood days at arcades. He started making machines two years ago and now sells them for S$300, teaching workshops on how to assemble a Retrocade Kit, a self-contained arcade machine that can run games from various consoles. Participants can take home a ready-to-play machine after a three-hour workshop, which costs S$380. Poh's workshop aims to relive childhood gaming memories and provide a fun, interactive experience.

site_title: HK spends HK$9.5b defending currency overnight
summary: Hong Kong's central bank, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), intervened overnight to defend its currency peg for a second day, buying HK$9.5 billion of local dollars to keep the Hong Kong dollar within its trading band. This is the third-largest intervention since the defense began last month. The move aims to counter the attractiveness of the Hong Kong dollar due to lower US interest rates, which has led to a significant increase in liquidity and tightening of borrowing costs.

site_title: Aurum Land buys all units in Balmoral Gardens for almost S$83m
summary: Aurum Land, the boutique development arm of Woh Hup group, has purchased all eight units in Balmoral Gardens for nearly S$83 million. The property is expected to be combined with the next-door site of 11 Balmoral Road, which Aurum acquired last year, to build a 12-storey condo with approximately 100 units. The combined site will have about 67,000 sq ft.

site_title: Euro falls towards 5-month lows on US bond yield rise
summary: The euro fell to a 5-month low against the US dollar, slipping 0.2% to US$1.1787, due to rising US Treasury bond yields and concerns over Italy's populist government. Investors are betting on further US interest rate hikes to curb inflation, driving the dollar higher. The euro's decline is also attributed to reports of Italy potentially asking the European Central Bank to forgive €250 billion of debt. The dollar rose to its strongest against the Japanese yen since January 23, while other commodity-linked currencies, such as the Australian dollar, also gained ground.

site_title: A toast to sake and natural wines
summary: A new alcohol distributor is introducing high-end sake and biodynamic wines to the market, offering a unique twist on traditional food and beverage pairings. The distributor is partnering with forward-thinking gastrobars to showcase these premium beverages. The high-end sake, particularly from Kokuryu brewery, is highly sought after and can be expensive due to its limited availability. This new development aims to make these premium drinks more accessible to consumers.

site_title: UK slashes maximum stake on gambling machines to £2
summary: The UK government has reduced the maximum stake on fixed-odds betting terminals (FOBTs) to £2 per spin, cutting the current maximum of £100. This move aims to protect vulnerable individuals from excessive losses. The decision follows a government review and comes after opposition MPs and religious leaders called for the maximum stake to be lowered. The government also announced measures to tighten online betting protections, raise awareness about potential harm, and launch a probe into the public health impact of betting.

site_title: MAS to raise insurance coverage for Sing-dollar deposits
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to increase insurance coverage for Singapore-dollar deposits to S$75,000 per depositor, starting April 1, 2019, and extend coverage to private-hire car owners and people working from home offices under the Policy Owners' Protection Scheme. The changes aim to protect depositors and insurance policy owners from insurer collapse. The fund build-up period will be extended to 2028, and premium rates will be increased to support the increased coverage.

site_title: Emerging-market malaise poised to linger
summary: Emerging-market currencies are experiencing their fifth major weakening trend since 2011, attributed to rising US Treasury yields, sluggish equity markets, and risk aversion. Unlike previous episodes, which were largely confidence events, this downturn is expected to persist unless a recession occurs. The sensitivity of EM currencies to higher rates is striking, and a reversal of US yield rise is unlikely, suggesting the pressure will continue unless a recession occurs. This poses a challenge for policymakers and investors in emerging markets.

site_title: US housing starts, building permits fall sharply in April, reversing March's rise
summary: US housing starts declined 3.7% in April to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.287 million units, reversing March's rise. Building permits also dropped sharply, suggesting the housing market continues to struggle due to shortages of land and skilled labor. The decline reverses a previous month's increase, leaving the market "treading water."

images.alt_text: Single-family homebuilding, which accounts for the largest share of the housing market, edged up 0.1 per cent to a rate of 894,000 units last month.

site_title: Two bottles of rare 60-year-old Macallan whisky to lead Hong Kong auction
summary: A rare 60-year-old Macallan whisky is set to be auctioned off in Hong Kong, with two bottles estimated to fetch HK$3.6 million to HK$4.5 million each. The sale is expected to surpass the 2014 auction record of HK$4.9 million, with prices for whiskies soaring globally due to growing demand from Asian buyers. The rare bottles, from 1926, are among the oldest and most valuable in the world, with only 24 bottles in existence. The auction is part of a growing trend of whisky as an alternative investment, with prices doubling over the past 12 months.

site_title: EU sets CO2 reduction target for trucks by 2030
summary: The European Union has proposed a 30% reduction in CO2 emissions from new large trucks by 2030 compared to 2019 levels, as part of the bloc's efforts to meet climate commitments under the Paris Agreement. This is the EU's first-ever CO2 standards for trucks, following new draft rules on CO2 standards for cars. The proposal must be approved by EU governments and the European Parliament before becoming law. The move aims to reduce road transport emissions, which currently account for a quarter of all emissions in the EU.

site_title: Corporate Cool
summary: Three British fashion brands, Joseph, Victoria Beckham, and Jil Sander, are featured for their chic and minimalist workwear staples. Joseph is known for its boxy and severe pieces, while Victoria Beckham offers pencil skirts, midi dresses, and structured shoulder bags. Jil Sander has reclaimed its clout under the helm of husband-and-wife team Luke and Lucie Meier, infusing its signature clean silhouettes with contemporary feminism. These brands are recognized for their attention to detail and character-driven pieces, offering a unique interpretation of workwear.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: AA Reit to spend S$48.2 million to redevelop its 3 Tuas Avenue 2 property, expected to be completed in 2nd half of 2019. IHH Healthcare seeks clarity on Fortis Healthcare's bid process, while SinoCloud Group's subsidiary to acquire an internet data centre in Lianyungang, China. Manipal Hospitals has revised its offer for Fortis Healthcare to 180 rupees a share.

site_title: SMEs should take do-it-yourself approach: Inderjit Singh
summary: Former MP Inderjit Singh advises SMEs to take a DIY approach to tackle business costs, manpower shortages, and rental pressures by sharing services, seeking alternative financing sources, and exploring cooperative banking options. Experts also emphasized the importance of adopting entrepreneurial thinking, focusing on growth rather than cost-cutting, and leveraging local partners for reliable business information.

site_title: Colin Goh
summary: Colin Goh, CEO of The Rice Company Limited, recalls his early days as a young arts producer in 1991, where a small crowd of 80 people attended a rock concert. This experience led him to understand the need for more Singaporean support for homegrown arts. In 2014, Goh founded RICE Company Limited, a not-for-profit organisation providing free arts training to socially disadvantaged children. Despite initial funding from supporters and a Budding Artists Fund, the organisation has expanded to multiple arts centres, showcasing Goh's success in promoting arts in Singapore.

site_title: Will peace ever come to the Promised Land?
summary: Israel and the Palestinians failed to achieve lasting peace 25 years after the 1993 Oslo Accord, which aimed to create a "Singapore of the Middle East" in the Gaza Strip. Instead, the Gaza Strip remains under Hamas control and is plagued by poverty, violence, and power outages. The Israeli government has shifted its focus to building Jewish settlements and has received strong backing from US President Donald Trump, who recognized Jerusalem as Israel's capital. The lack of progress in the peace process has led to growing criticism of Israel's policies towards the Palestinians, threatening its democratic values and traditional support in the US.

site_title: Silvaner: lovely yet unloved spring wine seeks friends
summary: Silvaner, a German white grape, is often overlooked in favor of more popular varieties. However, it offers a perfect blend of lightness, fragrance, and dryness, making it ideal for spring. With its herbal and floral notes, silvaner is a classic choice for lunchtime wine. Despite its origins as a widely planted grape in Germany, silvaner has fallen to fifth place in popularity, largely due to the abundance of low-quality wines. Advocates, such as André Ostertag, argue that the grape's popularity has declined due to a lack of serious winemaking and marketing. Fortunately, there are still excellent expressions of silvaner available, including wines from Alsace, Alto Adige, and Germany, that showcase the grape's unique qualities.

site_title: De Beers is said to edge up gem prices again amid record demand
summary: De Beers increased diamond prices by nearly 1% for the third consecutive time at its latest invitation-only sale, amidst record demand. The total sales are expected to be $530-$550 million. The price gains were more significant for high-quality stones over 1 carat, while smaller, lower-quality stones saw price cuts. This increase comes after De Beers announced a record $82 billion in diamond jewelry demand globally in 2017, with a 2% increase from the previous year.

site_title: China launches first rocket designed by a private company
summary: China successfully launched its first privately developed rocket, the Chongqing Liangjiang Star, from a launchpad in north-western China on May 17, 2018. Developed by OneSpace Technology, a Beijing-based private firm, the rocket marks the first time a non-state Chinese rocket has entered orbit. The OS-XO rocket can place a 100 kg load into orbit 800 km from the earth and uses energy-saving technology to lower fuel costs by 30%. The launch is part of China's ambitious space exploration program, with the goal of sending a permanent manned space station into orbit by 2022.

site_title: The omnichannel customer is here
summary: The rise of the omnichannel customer, who shops both online and in physical stores, is expected to be more loyal. With the increasing demand for instant gratification, companies must balance the need for speed with the challenges of integrating online and offline channels. To compete, traditional retailers need to learn to compete on differentiators, such as staff availability and knowledge, and may need to partner with established e-commerce platforms. Technology can improve customer engagement and loyalty, leveraging data and analytics to create personalized experiences. Omnichannel platforms, which integrate online and offline channels, are shown to increase customer satisfaction, loyalty, and spending.

site_title: Merck's lung cancer drugs show promise in early-stage trials
summary: Merck's experimental lung cancer drugs showed promising results in early-stage trials, with one of its treatments shrinking tumors in 41% of patients. The company, seeking to reduce development costs due to expected declining profits, is looking for partners to share further development costs. This marks a promising development in Merck's pipeline, which has seen a resurgence in several years.

site_title: Economists flag headwinds ahead for 'Goldilocks' economy
summary: Economists warn that the global economy's "Goldilocks" combination of robust growth and low inflation may not last, citing rising oil prices and faster-than-expected interest rate hikes. Oil prices have surged over 70% in the past year due to geopolitical uncertainties and supply restrictions. The US's plan to impose sanctions on Iran could lead to shortages, further increasing oil prices. Economists also express concern about faster interest rate hikes in the US, which could destabilize financial markets in the region and impact Singapore's household debt to income ratio.

site_title: Singapore market stuck in limbo
summary: The Singapore stock market remains stagnant amid uncertainty over rising US 10-year treasury bond yields and trade, geopolitical issues. The yield on the US 10-year treasury note reached 3.07%, its highest since 2011, and Pyongyang's potential withdrawal from the June summit with US President Donald Trump. The Straits Times Index ended 3.71 points up, or 0.11%, despite the negative market sentiment. Key players like Singtel reported a 19% fall in fourth-quarter net profit, while DBS Group Research maintained its "buy" call with a target price of S$3.85.

site_title: Goodwill shopping
summary: Three Singaporean retailers, Nordgreen, Freedom Cups, and xhundredfold, are giving back to charity through their business models. Nordgreen donates to charities such as education, health, and environment through its Giving Back Programme. Freedom Cups gives away reusable menstrual cups to women in underdeveloped countries, reducing waste and providing access to sanitary products. xhundredfold donates to causes such as education, dementia care, and zero-waste initiatives, with customers able to track the impact of their purchases.

site_title: Mahathir warns many figures on Malaysia's financial position are false
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad stated that many financial figures for the country are false, but did not provide evidence or specify which data he was referring to. This comment was made in response to a request for a forecast on Malaysia's economic growth. Mahathir emphasized the need to determine the accuracy of the inaccurate figures, but did not offer further clarification.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: US President Trump's 50% copper import tariff is expected to cover refined metal. Global stock markets declined, with US stocks edging down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, citing operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Swede Treat
summary: Swedish filmmaker Ingmar Bergman, who passed away in 2007, would have turned 100 this year. A Bergman Centenary celebration is underway, featuring a retrospective of his films, including Wild Strawberries, Persona, and Fanny & Alexander, at The Projector in Singapore. The selection, curated by local filmmaker Kirsten Tan, includes some of Bergman's most moving works, showcasing his diverse career in cinema, television, and stage productions. Screenings take place every weekend from May 20 to June 3.

site_title: MAS to tighten rules on cyber resilience in financial industry
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to issue a public consultation on tightening rules on cyber resilience in the financial industry, requiring financial institutions to implement fundamental controls and conduct independent reviews to ensure compliance. The regulator aims to promote cyber hygiene practices such as strong authentication and proper patch management to protect sensitive information and customer data. This move comes as the financial industry prepares for a growing market of digital payments, with Visa estimating over half of Asia-Pacific transactions are still in cash.

site_title: World's hottest luxury-property market is a sleepy Canadian city
summary: Victoria, British Columbia, has become the world's hottest luxury real estate market, according to Christie's International Real Estate. The city saw a 29% increase in sales volume and a 32-day average time to find a buyer in 2017, outpacing other major cities. Victoria's luxury sales were driven by Chinese and US buyers, with prices averaging $1.2 million, up 6% from 2016. Despite efforts to cool the market with foreign property taxes, Christie's expects Victoria to remain a top destination for luxury buyers, with the typical sale price significantly lower than in other major cities.

site_title: Forbidden Duck runs afowl
summary: Forbidden Duck, the Singapore debut of "demon chef" Alvin Leung, has received lukewarm reviews. Despite high expectations, the restaurant's innovative dishes, including edible condoms and spherified xiao long bao, failed to impress. Leung spent decades convincing people of his unique cooking style, but his Singapore venture has fallen short of expectations. The restaurant's opening has been met with disappointment, leaving many to wonder if Leung's innovative approach has lost its luster.

site_title: Extending leases of older HDB flats involves serious trade-offs and ramifications to consider, says Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's government is considering lease extensions for older HDB flats, but Minister Lawrence Wong notes that it involves "serious trade-offs and ramifications." The country faces space constraints, and extending leases would be costly for residents. Wong emphasizes that not everyone wants lease extensions and that the issue is complex, requiring careful consideration of the impact on future generations.
