The government aims to ensure affordable and quality housing for every generation, and it will study the matter before making a decision.

site_title: Commodity trading hits new high of S$28b in 2017
summary: Commodity trading in Singapore reached a new high of S$28 billion in 2017, with over 15,000 professionals employed, representing a 2.7% compounded annual growth rate over five years. The sector generated close to US$1.2 trillion in turnover, driven by strong demand from Asia. Enterprise Singapore attributes the growth to a sustained global economy and demand from key markets such as natural gas, nickel, and copper. The agency plans to work with traders to improve productivity, promote innovation, and develop standards for interoperability and security across digital platforms.

images.alt_text: Singapore currently houses more than 400 global, regional and local commodities players across the entire value chain, trading a wide spectrum of commodities under its Global Trader Programme.

site_title: US : Wall St opens lower as Cisco drags, bond yields climb
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 16.53 points, or 0.07%, to 24,752.40, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. Cisco's disappointing forecast pressured the markets, while concerns over rising US Treasury yields and looming trade talks persisted.

site_title: Walmart's US e-commerce growth rebounds, shares rise
summary: Walmart's US e-commerce sales rebounded 33% in the first quarter, beating expectations, and the company lifted its shares. This growth reverses a sharp slowdown during the holiday quarter, which had sent its shares down 10% and wiped out $31 billion from its market capitalization. Walmart's total revenue increased 4.4% to $122.7 billion, beating analyst estimates. The retailer expects to increase US e-commerce sales by 40% for the full year, driven by online grocery sales and new brands, including a partnership with Lord and Taylor.

site_title: EU vows to block blow of US Iran sanctions
summary: The European Union has vowed to block the effects of US sanctions on Iran, starting a process to neutralize extraterritorial US sanctions in the EU. This move comes as EU leaders pledged to keep a united front against US President Donald Trump's decision to pull out of the 2015 nuclear deal with Iran. The "blocking statute" regulation, created to circumvent US sanctions on Cuba, will be used to protect European companies from US sanctions. China and Russia have also increased their economic influence in Iran, further straining the transatlantic rift.

site_title: Dubai Aerospace in talks to place huge order for 400 jets
summary: Dubai Aerospace Enterprise (DAE), a major aircraft lessor, is in talks to buy 400 jets from Airbus and Boeing, worth over $40 billion. The deal, if finalized, would give DAE a long-term pipeline of aircraft on par with rivals. DAE CEO Firoz Tarapore expressed dissatisfaction with the price, and the company is prepared to expand its fleet through acquisition if talks fall through. Deliveries may take several years due to manufacturers' high demand.

site_title: Raffles United's directors provide bonds to CAD over potential breaches
summary: Raffles United Holdings' directors have provided bonds to the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) regarding potential breaches of the Securities and Futures Act. Managing director Teo Teng Beng, executive director Teo Xian-Hui Amanda Marie, and CFO Ho Hui Min have agreed to report back to CAD on May 31. This move allows their passports to be released for overseas travel, as part of the investigations. The provision of bonds aims to assist CAD in its inquiries, but no further details on the breaches or investigations have been disclosed.

site_title: Pharma gives Singapore NODX a shot in the arm, but it'll wear off, say economists
summary: Singapore's exports recovered in April after shrinking for two months, driven by a rebound in pharmaceutical shipments. However, economists predict this surge will be short-lived due to slowing electronics momentum and trade tensions. The electronics sector's slowdown, combined with US tariffs on Asian goods, is expected to weigh on the export outlook.

site_title: Trump plans to meet with China's top economic envoy
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to meet with China's top economic envoy at the White House, as part of talks to rebalance US-China economic ties. The meetings, which will last from Thursday to Friday, aim to ease the US-China trade conflict. Senior economic adviser Larry Kudlow described the negotiations as "difficult" and said the sides will exchange new proposals during the talks. Trump is "involved in every decision" and will lead the discussions, which are seen as a continuation of previous talks held in Beijing.

site_title: 'Strong investor demand' for Hyphens Pharma; public offer 152 times subscribed
summary: Hyphens Pharma International received strong investor interest for its initial public offering (IPO), with 4,800 valid applications for 3 million shares, translating to a 152 times subscribed public offer. The company received indications of interest for 324.7 million placement shares worth S$84.4 million. Proceeds from the IPO will be used for potential acquisitions, joint ventures, and product development. The shares will commence trading on May 18 on the Catalist, following a successful cornerstone subscription by three investors.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries subsidiary divests medical waste division for S$20m
summary: Sembcorp Industries has divested its Singapore medical waste division to TEE Medical Services for S$20 million, resulting in an expected net gain of around S$15 million. The division, which specializes in treating and disposing of biohazardous and pharmaceutical waste, was sold to a 50:50 joint venture between TEE Infrastructure and Asia Enviro Services. The divestment is part of Sembcorp's strategic efforts to improve performance and strengthen its balance sheet.

site_title: Maersk warns on trade risks as disappointing Q1 earnings hit share price
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container shipper, reported disappointing Q1 earnings, missing forecasts by 21% to $669 million. CEO Soren Skou attributed the result to "relatively sluggish underlying volume growth" and rising shipping costs. He warned of increased uncertainties due to geopolitical risks and trade tensions, particularly with the US-China trade talks. Maersk's shares fell 12% after the results, near 18-month lows, despite topping analysts' forecasts for quarterly revenue. Skou expects Ebitda for the year at $4-5 billion and plans to implement short-term initiatives to improve profitability.

site_title: Prospects for India's mega refinery project grow dimmer
summary: India's planned $44 billion refinery project, a joint venture between Saudi Aramco and an Indian consortium, is facing significant challenges due to land acquisition issues. Thousands of farmers in Ratnagiri district oppose the project, fearing it could harm the region's agricultural and fishing industries. Despite the government's efforts to ease land acquisition rules, the project's prospects are growing dimmer, with the state government unable to secure even a single acre of the 15,000 acres needed. The project's deadline is likely to be pushed back due to delays in land acquisition, which could impact its overall viability.

site_title: Former Cambridge Analytica boss to appear before British lawmakers on June 6
summary: Former Cambridge Analytica boss Alexander Nix is set to appear before British lawmakers on June 6. Nix had previously declined a summons but has now accepted, amid an investigation into the role of Cambridge Analytica in the 2016 Brexit vote and US presidential elections. The committee is addressing inconsistencies in Nix's previous testimony and will also examine the campaign's use of data. Cambridge Analytica denies doing paid work on the Brexit campaign and claims its work on the Trump campaign did not use the data at the centre of a Facebook scandal involving 87 million users.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.82 points to 1,854.44. The market saw a volume of 3.2 billion lots worth RM3.6 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 570 to 438.

site_title: Anwar says Najib likely headed to jail
summary: Malaysian politician Anwar Ibrahim expects former Prime Minister Najib Razak to be jailed over multi-billion-dollar graft claims, following his own release from custody. Anwar, who walked free on Wednesday after serving 2 years, said Najib faces an "arduous" legal battle and predicted he would likely be charged and imprisoned. Najib and his 1MDB fund deny wrongdoing, but Anwar believes it will be difficult for him to escape prison. Anwar plans to return to parliament and may not seek a cabinet position initially, while Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has pledged to hand power to Anwar within two years.

site_title: Private equity, venture capital investments into South-east Asia hit record US$23.5b in 2017: SVCA report
summary: Private equity and venture capital investments in South-east Asia reached a record $23.5 billion in 2017, surpassing Europe, according to a report by the Singapore Venture Capital & Private Equity Association. This marked the first year that Asia surpassed Europe in terms of PE and VC investments. The report highlights the growing investment in the region, driven by increasing demand for growth capital.

site_title: Chinese private firm launches first space rocket
summary: China's private firm OneSpace successfully launched its first space rocket, the Chongqing Liangjiang Star, reaching an altitude of 273 km before falling back to Earth. The suborbital rocket demonstrated an early working model of the company's OS-X series, designed for research linked to suborbital flights. OneSpace plans to build 20 OS-X rockets by the end of the decade, capable of placing a 100-kilo payload into an orbit 800 km from Earth. The company also develops the M-series rocket to compete in the microsatellite sector, a growing market dominated by Chinese aerospace start-ups.

site_title: SinoCloud unit signs letter of intent to buy Internet data centre in Jiangsu, China
summary: SinoCloud's subsidiary, Guiyang Zhongdian Gaoxin Digital Technologies Limited, has signed a letter of intent to acquire an Internet data centre in Lianyungang, Jiangsu, China. The deal involves the acquisition of two units, with Guiyang Zhongdian paying a 34.95 million yuan refundable deposit. The exclusivity period for discussions will end on December 31. The acquisition aims to expand SinoCloud's presence in the Chinese data centre market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Hang Seng falls as China-US trade talks resume; Tencent gains
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng index fell 0.5% to 30,942.15, despite a 0.4% gain for Tencent Holdings, as US-China trade talks resumed in Washington. Investors became cautious amid concerns of a damaging tariff war, with the White House's China critic relegated to a supporting role.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports rose 11.8% in April after two months of contraction, driven by a surge in non-electronic exports. Private equity and venture capital investments in South-east Asia reached a record $23.5 billion in 2017. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to raise requirements for cyber resilience in the financial sector. A Chancery Court site in Singapore sold for $401.78 million, while six individuals were banned from providing financial advisory services for mis-selling investment products. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended up 0.11% due to geopolitical concerns and rising bond yields.

site_title: Geopolitics, rising bond yields put lid on Singapore shares
summary: Singapore shares ended Thursday at 3,536.76, up 0.11% or 3.71 points from Wednesday's close, despite uncertainties over geopolitical meetings and rising US 10-year Treasury yields. Over 1.47 billion shares changed hands, with 174 gainers to 225 losers. The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) had opened at 3,545.90 and hit 3,550.62 before closing.

site_title: CDL, Distrii open Singapore's single largest and tech-driven co-working facility
summary: CDL and Distrii have opened Singapore's largest and tech-driven co-working facility, spanning 62,000 square feet across six floors. The 900-workstation space features proprietary collaboration tools, a 200-person hall, and a German burger chain cafe. The facility has secured over 60% occupancy rate, with members including blockchain incubator BitTemple. Membership starts from S$550 per month, and the space offers access to Distrii's managed offices in China. A joint venture with CDL aims to develop smart office and smart building applications for buildings.

site_title: Takeda CEO prescribes surgical R&D cuts after US$62b Shire deal
summary: Takeda Pharmaceutical's CEO Christophe Weber has outlined a plan to cut costs and streamline R&D after the $62 billion acquisition of Shire, aiming to reduce the company's debt and maintain innovation. Weber plans to dispose of or spin off experimental drugs that don't meet medical innovation standards, with a focus on gastroenterology, neuroscience, and rare diseases. The deal, set to close in the first half of 2019, is expected to result in at least $1.4 billion in annual cost synergies, including $600 million in R&D costs. Weber hopes to secure investor support and bring in strategic investors to alleviate concerns about the deal's financial implications.

site_title: Commodity trading hits new S$28b high in local business spending
summary: Commodity trading in Singapore reached a new high of S$28 billion in local business spending, with a 2.7% compounded annual growth rate over the past five years. The sector generated close to US$1.2 trillion in turnover last year, driven by strong demand growth from key markets. Enterprise Singapore attributes the growth to a sustained global economy and demand from Asia, and plans to foster more collaborations, promote digital trade, and help traders upgrade and globalize their business. The sector faces disruption from digital technologies, but Enterprise Singapore aims to stay ahead by acquiring the right technologies and talent.

site_title: Oil hits US$80 a barrel on concerns about Iran supply
summary: Oil prices reached a 4-year high, hitting US$80 a barrel, due to concerns about reduced Iranian exports, which could decrease global supply in a tightening market. This is the first time US$80 a barrel has been reached since November 2014.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise as Italian stocks recover, Ocado soars
summary: European stocks rose in early trading on Thursday, with Italy's benchmark climbing over 1% and the pan-European Stoxx 600 reaching 3-1/2 month highs. Shares in Ocado surged 40% after signing a partnership deal with US retailer Kroger Co. Energy stocks and miners also rose, while British bookmakers fell after the UK government cut the top stake on fixed-odds betting terminals. The Stoxx 600 held at its high despite a rise in sterling.

site_title: Grab partners Maybank to promote GrabPay in Malaysia
summary: Grab has partnered Maybank to promote GrabPay in Malaysia, driving the acceptance and usage of its mobile wallet in the country. GrabPay will be available in Malaysia after securing its e-money licence from Bank Negara Malaysia last year. Maybank customers will be able to use GrabPay to pay for services and top up their wallets from their bank accounts, with exclusive benefits and rewards. The partnership aims to expand GrabPay's presence in Southeast Asia, with plans to roll out the service across all eight countries this year.

site_title: IHH Healthcare extends acceptance period for its offer for India's Fortis to May 29
summary: IHH Healthcare has extended its acceptance period for its offer to acquire India's Fortis Healthcare to May 29, following Manipal Hospitals' revised offer of 180 rupees a share. The new offer values Fortis at 94.03 billion rupees, significantly better than previous bids. IHH Healthcare has requested clarity on whether a new bid process will be initiated by Fortis' board, which had accepted a 40 billion rupee investment offer from Hero Enterprise Investment Office and Burman Family Office.

site_title: Slowing Malaysian economy poses challenge for Mahathir government
summary: Malaysia's annual economic growth slowed to 5.4% in the first quarter of 2018, its second consecutive quarter of deceleration. The country's new government, led by 92-year-old Mahathir Mohamad, faces the challenge of turning around the economy. The slowdown comes amid uncertainty over economic policies, including plans to scrap a goods and services tax and reintroduce a sales tax. Despite this, the central bank projects favorable growth driven by domestic and global demand, with inflation expected to average 2-3% in 2018.

site_title: SIA swings into the black with Q4 net profit of S$181.8 million
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a net profit of S$181.8 million for the fourth quarter, swinging out of the red. Revenue expanded 8.2% year-on-year to S$4.02 billion, while operating profit rose to S$214.5 million. The airline's full-year net profit surged to S$892.9 million, driven by stronger passenger and cargo revenues. SIA also announced a final dividend of 30 Singapore cents per share, up from 11 cents previously. The airline attributed the improvement to its three-year transformation programme, which aims to enhance the customer experience, revenue growth, and operational efficiency.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rise on bargain-hunting
summary: Tokyo stocks rose moderately on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index increasing 0.53% to 22,838.37, following two days of losses. Investors bought on dips, supported by gains on Wall Street and a weak yen. The dollar traded at 110.28 yen, while US stocks rose on upbeat data and positive corporate results. Some investors may wait ahead of US-China trade talks, but overall buying sentiment remained strong, with banks and carmakers leading the gains.

site_title: Australia shares end at over 1-week low, Treasury Wine slides; NZ up
summary: Australian shares ended at a 1-week low, falling 0.2% to 6,094.30, due to Westpac's 3.7% decline and Treasury Wine Estates' 6.2% drop. The mining sector, however, helped limit losses with BHP posting its highest close in 3.5 years and Rio Tinto rising 2.4%. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.6% to 8,603.38, while the country's newly elected Labour party unveiled its first budget with billions in funding for housing, health, and education.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won edge down on foreign selling, North Korea-US summit doubts
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index and currency declined on foreign selling, with the won weakening to 1,081.2 per dollar, down 0.33% from the previous day. The KOSPI fell 0.46% to 2,448.45, while Samsung Biologics and Samsung Electronics declined 3.9% and 1%, respectively. Lingering doubts about a US-North Korea summit also weighed on sentiment, with local bond yields dropping. Foreigners were net sellers of 270,449 million won worth of shares.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 5.08 points to 1,863.34. The index saw 97.66 million lots traded worth RM62.05 million, with 176 gainers outnumbering 68 losers.

site_title: Slowing Malaysian economy poses challenge for Mahathir government
summary: Malaysia's economy slowed to 5.4% growth in the first quarter of 2018, down from a median forecast of 5.5%. The country's new government, led by 92-year-old Mahathir Mohamad, is facing a challenge to turn around the economy, which has decelerated for two consecutive quarters. Mahathir has announced plans to scrap a goods and services tax, reintroduce a sales tax, and review projects signed off by the previous government, sparking concerns about populist policies and economic growth.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon trading at 3,536.15, up 3.1 points
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading Thursday afternoon at 3,536.15, up 3.1 points or 0.09% from the previous day. Trading volume was 858 million shares worth S$484 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 161 to 156, with stocks like Singtel and DBS down 0.6% and 0.3% respectively. The Straits Times Index closed at 3,536.15.

site_title: Hackers steal 300m pesos from Mexico financial system
summary: Hackers targeted Mexico's interbank payment system, making off with approximately $15 million (300 million pesos). The incident occurred over several weeks, but commercial bank customers' accounts were not at risk. An investigation is underway, with the suspected hackers' nationality unknown. The attacks were detected, and banks switched to a slower but more secure method. The incident highlights the vulnerability of Mexico's financial system to cyber threats.

site_title: Private equity, venture capital investments into S-E Asia hit record US$23.5b in 2017: SVCA report
summary: Private equity and venture capital investments in South-east Asia reached a record US$23.5 billion in 2017, surpassing Europe for the first time, according to the South-east Asia PE & VC: Investment Activity report. This marks a significant milestone for the region, with last year's investments exceeding those in Europe. The report, released by the Singapore Venture Capital & Private Equity Association (SVCA), highlights the growing interest in the region from investors.

site_title: Insurance policy protection for private-hire drivers, higher deposit safeguards to be in place from April 2019
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to increase insurance coverage for Singapore-dollar deposits under the Deposit Insurance Scheme to S$75,000 per depositor, effective April 1, 2019. Private-hire drivers will also be protected against insurer collapse under the Policy Owners' Protection Scheme. The fund backing the deposit insurance will be increased by 0.5 to 1 basis point to support the higher coverage limit, and a cap will be set on property damage claims to keep premiums affordable. The changes require parliamentary approval.

site_title: MyInfo digital ID service signs on its first telco
summary: MyInfo, Singapore's digital identity service, has partnered with M1 telco to integrate its authentication system into the company's mobile remittance service, M1 Remit. This move eliminates the need for users to physically register with the service. The integration is the first of its kind for Singapore's money remittance process, backed by MyInfo. The partnership aims to simplify the remittance process for customers, and M1 joins Singtel in offering mobile-based money remittance services.

site_title: Metro takes 35% stake in joint venture to acquire mixed-use building in Shanghai
summary: Metro Holdings Limited has acquired a 35% stake in a joint venture to invest in Shanghai Plaza, a 2.9 billion yuan (S$613 million) mixed-use building in Shanghai. The joint venture aims to acquire the remaining 10% by 2020. This investment aligns with Metro's strategy to grow its presence in China, particularly in high-growth cities like Shanghai. The property is located near popular shopping districts and major transportation hubs, and Metro Holdings chairman Winston Choo sees this as an opportunity to tap into retail expertise and network.

site_title: Chancery Court at Dunearn Road sells en bloc for S$401.78m, 6% higher than reserve price
summary: The Chancery Court at Dunearn Road sold en bloc for S$401.78 million, 6% higher than its reserve price. The site, with a land price of S$1,610 per square foot per plot ratio, will be redeveloped to a gross plot ratio of 1.4 and have its lease upgraded to 99 years. The buyer's identity was not disclosed, and the sale price translates to a premium of S$182.4 million.

site_title: Asia: Traders cautious with trade talks, geopolitics in mind
summary: Asian traders remain cautious ahead of high-level China-US trade talks, despite a positive start to the day from Wall Street. The US indexes finished in the green zone, but traders are wary of rising inflation and higher borrowing costs. Geopolitical concerns, including US tariffs on Europe, also weigh on markets. The region's stocks are expected to be influenced by the outcome of the trade talks, which could impact global trade and economic growth.

site_title: South Korea to play "mediator" to resolve North Korea-US summit doubts: official
summary: South Korea plans to mediate between the US and North Korea to resolve doubts over an upcoming summit between Kim Jong Un and President Donald Trump on June 12 in Singapore. North Korea threatened to pull out if the US continues to demand unilateral nuclear disarmament. The US reportedly demanded North Korea ship nuclear warheads and materials overseas within six months, prompting the North Korean threat. South Korea's involvement aims to find a compromise and secure the summit's success.

site_title: Singapore's commodity trading hits new S$28b high in local business spending
summary: Singapore's commodity trading reached a new high of S$28 billion in 2018, driven by strong demand growth from natural gas, nickel, and copper. The sector generated close to US$1.2 trillion in turnover, with 15,000 professionals hired, representing a 2.7% compounded annual growth rate over the past five years.

site_title: US: Stocks rebound on solid economic data, corporate results
summary: US stocks rebounded strongly on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.25% and the S&P 500 rising 0.41%. Positive corporate results, including a 11% surge in Macy's same-store sales, offset weak housing data and inflation concerns. Industrial production jumped 0.7% in April, while oil prices rose, but investors seemed unfazed by trade and geopolitical concerns.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports surge 11.8% in April after 2 months of contraction; electronics shipments continue to slide
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports surged 11.8% in April, ending two months of contraction, driven by a 19.6% increase in non-electronic exports. Electronics shipments declined 6.9%, primarily due to a decrease in personal computer parts. Non-oil re-exports also grew, with China, the EU, and the US being the largest contributors to growth. The rebound in non-oil exports is seen as a positive sign for the country's economy.

site_title: AA Reit: Redevelopment at 3 Tuas Ave 2 to cost S$48.2m
summary: AA Reit announced a redevelopment project at 3 Tuas Ave 2, expected to cost S$48.2 million, with a completion date in the second half of 2019. The project will transform the site into a modern industrial facility, increasing the property's value to S$51.0 million and gross floor area to 24,890 square meters. The redevelopment is expected to have minimal impact on AA Reit's revenue, with the property contributing less than 1% of gross rental income in FY2018.

site_title: Six individuals get prohition orders for mis-selling investment products: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued prohibition orders against six individuals for mis-selling investment products. The individuals, who worked for Prudential, AIA, and Citibank, were found to have committed various types of misconduct, including forgery, making false statements, and improper switching. The penalties range from two to seven years, with those targeting vulnerable clients facing longer durations. The MAS emphasized that representatives mis-selling to vulnerable clients will face stiffer action, with Mr. Hiah and Ms. Heng receiving the longest bans of seven and four years, respectively.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at open
summary: Hong Kong shares opened flat on May 17, 2018, as a strong lead from Wall Street was tempered by concerns over Federal Reserve interest rates. The Hang Seng Index eased 1.61 points to 31,108.59, while the Shanghai Composite Index barely moved, inching up 0.44 points to 3,170.01. High-level trade talks between China and the US began in Washington, adding to market uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia Q1 current account surplus rises to RM15b
summary: Malaysia's current account surplus increased to RM15.0 billion in Q1 2018, from RM13.9 billion in the previous quarter. Portfolio investment saw a net outflow of RM2.6 billion, while foreign direct investment rose to RM12 billion. These developments suggest a strengthening economy, with foreign investment and exports contributing to the surplus.

site_title: Japan plans retaliatory tariffs against US: NHK
summary: Japan is planning retaliatory tariffs of $409 million against US exports in response to US steel and aluminum import tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump. The government will notify the World Trade Organization of the plan, which is part of efforts to have Washington add Japan to a list of countries exempted from the US tariffs.

site_title: Oil gains after report shows larger than expected US stock draws
summary: Oil prices rose after a US inventory report showed crude and petrol stocks fell more than expected, with Brent crude futures gaining 85 cents to $79.28 a barrel and US crude futures gaining 18 cents to $71.49 a barrel. The US Energy Information Administration reported a 1.4 million barrel decrease in crude inventories and a 3.79 million barrel decline in petrol stocks, exceeding analyst expectations. The stronger dollar made it more expensive to buy dollar-denominated commodities, but concerns about supply from Iran and Venezuela and a healthy demand for US crude supported price gains.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC downgrades Viva Industrial Trust to 'hold'
summary: OCBC Investment Research downgraded Viva Industrial Trust (VIT) from "buy" to "hold" due to management fees being paid in cash, decreasing its fair value estimate from S$0.93 to S$0.90. Despite revenue growth, distributable income dropped 9.2% year-on-year, mainly due to the payment of management fees. The trust's growth outlook remains positive, with flat to positive revenue growth for most assets, and a merger with ESR-Reit is pending final regulatory approvals.

site_title: Big proxy adviser ISS does not support Facebook's Zuckerberg in proxy vote
summary: Top proxy adviser Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) recommended Facebook investors withhold support from five directors, including CEO Mark Zuckerberg, and vote in favor of shareholder proposals aimed at improving the company's response to data privacy issues. ISS expressed concerns over Facebook's handling of customer data and recommended creating a formal committee to nominate board candidates. The company will hold its annual meeting on May 31 to vote on the proposals.

site_title: Tenders for sites on Cuscaden Road, Mattar Road and Silat Avenue go to highest bidders
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority of Singapore (URA) announced that tenders for sites on Cuscaden Road, Mattar Road, and Silat Avenue have been awarded to the highest bidders. The site on Cuscaden Road was sold for S$409.99 million (S$25,588.22 per square metre), the site on Mattar Road for S$223 million (S$11,931.89 per square metre), and the site on Silat Avenue for S$1.035 billion (S$12,244.68 per square metre) with 1,125 units. The tenders closed on April 26, 2018, and the land parcels were offered for 99-year lease terms.

site_title: Tencent shares rise after Q1 profit beats estimates
summary: Tencent Holdings reported a 61% jump in net profit and a 48% rise in revenue for its first quarter, beating consensus estimates. The company's shares rose 7% in Hong Kong. However, analysts lowered their target prices for the stock to HK$523, citing concerns about the company's growth prospects. Despite this, the strong Q1 results are seen as a positive sign for Tencent's future performance.

site_title: Japan March core machinery orders fall 3.9% month-on-month
summary: Japan's core machinery orders fell 3.9% month-on-month in March, the first decline in three months, according to Cabinet Office data. This was lower than the 3.0% decline expected by economists. Core orders declined 2.4% compared to the previous year. Despite this, manufacturers forecast a 7.1% rise in core orders for April-June, after a 3.3% increase in the previous quarter.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, CapitaLand Commercial Trust, AusNet
summary: Singtel reported a 19% decline in net profit to S$781 million for its fourth quarter, citing adverse currency movements and lower profits at Telkomsel and Airtel. CapitaLand Commercial Trust acquired a majority stake in a Frankfurt property for S$542.5 million, while AusNet Services will invest A$141 million in a power transmission line in Victoria, Australia.

site_title: Raffles United's directors provide bonds to report to CAD on potential breaches of Securities and Futures Act
summary: Raffles United Holdings' directors have provided bonds to report to the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) regarding potential breaches of the Securities and Futures Act. Managing Director Teo Teng Beng, Executive Director Teo Xian-Hui Amanda Marie, and CFO Ho Hui Min have made the commitments. The passports of the three individuals were released by the CAD for overseas travel. The move is part of the CAD's ongoing investigations.

site_title: Police search scandal-tainted Malaysian ex-premier's home
summary: Malaysian police searched the home of former premier Najib Razak, amid a probe into a massive graft scandal. The search, which lasted over six hours, yielded no arrests, but officers did seize some personal items. Najib's wife, Rosmah Mansor, was also targeted, as the new government vows to investigate allegations of looting a sovereign wealth fund. The search comes as the new government, led by Mahathir Mohamad, takes steps to address public anger over the scandal, which has plagued Najib's rule for years.

site_title: Two Sherpa climbers set new summit records on Everest
summary: Kami Rita Sherpa, a 48-year-old Nepali climber, set a new record for the most visits to Mount Everest's summit with his 22nd ascent. He was accompanied by 13 other climbers, including clients, via the South-east Ridge route. Kami surpassed two fellow Sherpas to hold the record. Meanwhile, 44-year-old Lhakpa Sherpa, a US-based climber, broke her own record for most summits by a woman, reaching the top for the ninth time. Both climbers successfully completed their ascents, with Kami expected to return to base camp by the weekend.

images.alt_text: A Nepali mountaineer climbed Mount Everest on Wednesday for a 22nd time while a female climber made it to the top for the ninth time, each setting a new record on the world's highest mountain, officials said.

site_title: Europe: Political risk hits Milan bourse, weak euro backs shares
summary: Italy's two anti-system parties' formation of a coalition has sparked concerns among investors, hitting the Milan bourse with a 2.3% decline, its worst fall since March. A weak euro provided support to the broader European market, with the Stoxx 600 index rising 0.2%. Italian banks fell 3.68% due to government bond holdings, and the country's debt pile is expected to worsen with tax cuts and welfare payments. The market's performance contrasts with the recent outperformance of European peers despite the tenuous political situation.

site_title: MAS to raise requirements on cyber resilience in Singapore's financial sector
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to raise requirements on cyber resilience in the financial sector, proposing a public consultation on cyber hygiene practices. Financial institutions in Singapore will be required to adopt controls such as strong authentication, controlled use of administrative privileges, and proper patch management to protect system, sensitive information, and customer data. This move aims to enhance overall cyber resilience and provide a strong foundation in security, addressing the growing threat of cyber attacks in the financial industry.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday, STI up 0.5% to 3,549.68
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Thursday, advancing 16.63 points, or 0.5%, to 3,549.68. The rebound was driven by upbeat US industry and corporate results, offsetting inflation jitters. Gainers outnumbered losers 87 to 41, with UOB and DBS leading the gainers, up 0.8% and 0.7%, respectively. The Straits Times Index reached its highest level since May 14.

site_title: Facebook's Zuckerberg agrees closed-door talks with European Parliament members
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has agreed to closed-door talks with European Parliament members to answer questions about the Cambridge Analytica scandal. The meeting, set to take place next week, comes amid EU's new data protection rules and follows Zuckerberg's 10-hour US Congress interrogation. Lawmakers had hoped for a public hearing, but Zuckerberg's representatives say the meeting will provide an opportunity for dialogue and explanation. Facebook has welcomed the chance to meet MEPs and comply with the EU's General Data Protection Regulation, which aims to give users more control over their personal data.

site_title: SRX launches home loan platform
summary: SRX, a Singaporean real estate services provider, has launched a home loan platform called myHome Finance, which utilizes the Singapore government's MyInfo service to automatically complete loan application forms. The platform also features an artificial intelligence engine to identify preferred loan options and best rates from partner banks. This move aims to simplify the loan application process for borrowers, reducing the need to manually fill out forms.

site_title: Mexico central bank estimates hackers hit about 300m pesos
summary: Mexico's central bank reported a cyberattack affecting five companies, including banks and brokerages, resulting in an estimated 300 million pesos (S$20.5 million) of irregular transactions. The attack, which occurred at the end of April, targeted connections to a domestic payments system. The central bank is investigating the incident and has not specified which companies were targeted.

site_title: Singtel Q4 profit shrinks 19% to S$781m on forex effects, lower associates' contributions
summary: Singtel reported a 19% decline in net profit to S$781 million for its Q4 2018, due to negative currency movements and lower associates' contributions. Revenue grew 0.4% to S$4.326 billion. The telco attributed the decline to Telkomsel's 22.1% drop in post-tax profit contribution and data revenue growth not keeping up with traditional services. Despite this, Singtel expects a recovery after Lebaran and is confident in its digital transformation strategy, with free cash flow rising 12.8% to S$3.61 billion for the full year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wall Street gain, weak yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by gains on Wall Street and a weak yen. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.44% to 22,817.60, while the Topix index gained 0.38%. The uptrend is attributed to rises in US stocks and a firm dollar. However, some investors may wait-and-see ahead of US-China trade talks, which may impact the market.

site_title: Births plunge to record lows in United States
summary: US births have plummeted to record lows, with 3.85 million births in 2017, the fewest since 1987. The overall fertility rate fell to 1.76 births per woman, down three percent from 2016. Experts attribute the decline to American women delaying childbearing, citing factors such as education and career pursuits. While this trend is concerning for the economy, the US still has a higher fertility rate than several European countries, including Italy, Germany, and Japan. Experts suggest economic incentives, paid parental leave, and immigration policies could help boost the birth rate.

site_title: Cambridge Analytica shared data with Russia: whistleblower
summary: A whistleblower, Christopher Wylie, testified to a congressional hearing that Cambridge Analytica, a political consulting firm, shared data with Russian researchers and companies linked to Russian intelligence. Wylie stated that Russian security services had access to data harvested by Cambridge Analytica, and the firm used Russian researchers to gather data. Cambridge Analytica used the data for "rumour campaigns" and "attitudinal inoculation" with companies and executives linked to the Russian intelligence agency FSB, and its CEO, Alexander Nix, was suspended after bragging about winning campaigns through blackmail and honey traps.

site_title: CCT to buy prime Frankfurt property for 343m euros, raise at least S$212m via private placement
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) is buying a majority stake in a prime Frankfurt property, Gallileo, for 342.7 million euros (S$548.3 million), partially funded through a private placement of at least $212 million. CCT will hold 94.9% stake, with CapitaLand holding the remaining 5.1%. The acquisition is expected to be completed in June and is expected to increase CCT's Q1 distribution per unit by 1.4% to 2.15 cents. This marks CCT's strategic expansion into Germany and geographical diversification.

site_title: Frasers Property, GIC, JustCo invest US$177m in co-working space platform
summary: Frasers Property, GIC, and JustCo have invested US$177 million in a co-working space platform, enabling JustCo to expand into Asian markets such as China, Japan, and Australia. JustCo currently has a presence in Singapore, Indonesia, and Thailand, and this investment will support its growth. The platform aims to provide co-working space across Asia, further establishing JustCo as a major player in the region's co-working industry.

site_title: Four years after coup, Thais tire of corruption and democratic delays
summary: Thailand's military government is facing a public perception crisis four years after a bloodless coup, with corruption remaining endemic and democratic delays fueling anti-government protests. Despite promising to tackle corruption and return the country to democratic rule within two years, the junta has passed 298 laws and issued over 500 orders, but corruption cases remain unaddressed. Protests have intensified, with the government facing criticism for delaying the general election and prioritizing other sectors over the agricultural sector, which has been particularly hard-hit. Analysts say the military's grip on power remains strong, with leaders weary of more bloodshed if they take to the streets.

site_title: Keppel unit selling 5 rigs to Borr Drilling for US$745m
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) has sold five jack-up rigs to Borr Drilling for approximately US$745 million, at an average price of US$149 million per rig. The deal excludes down payments made by the original owners and includes a payment schedule over five years. The sale is seen as a 30-35% discount to the rigs' historical construction cost, with delivery of the rigs scheduled from Q4 2019 to Q4 2020.

site_title: Dispute on policy picks up steam at top of US Fed
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's top deputies are debating whether the economy has shifted into a higher gear, giving the Fed room for more interest rate hikes. San Francisco Fed President John Williams argues that the neutral rate, a speed limit on interest rate hikes, is much lower than in the past, while Fed Vice-Chair Randal Quarles suggests the Fed has more room to raise rates without braking the economy. The debate may shape the pace of interest rate hikes and the Fed's approach to combating future recessions.

site_title: Malaysia's new government scraps 6% consumption tax
summary: Malaysia's new government has scrapped the 6% consumption tax, known as the Goods and Services Tax (GST), effective June 1. This decision fulfills a campaign promise by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad and will have a significant impact on the government's revenue, with economists warning of a widening budget deficit. However, some analysts believe that the move may help spur consumer spending and ease inflation in the booming economy, and that the government will take compensating measures to offset the loss.

images.alt_text: Malaysia scrapped a 6 per cent rate on the goods and services tax (GST), fulfilling a campaign promise by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad that gave him an unexpected win in last week's election.

site_title: Asean stands to gain from Belt and Road Initiative despite challenges
summary: The Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) is expected to benefit the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) despite challenges. Asean countries, particularly Malaysia and the Philippines, are well-positioned to reap significant benefits from the initiative, which aims to connect countries via a combination of land-based and ocean-crossing infrastructure projects. China is providing financing and technical expertise, and projects worth billions of dollars are already underway in the region. However, concerns over job creation, geopolitical risks, and execution problems have raised questions about the viability of the long-term projects. Despite these challenges, Asean is encouraged by China's efforts to improve the perception of the BRI and its evolving approach to accommodate the growth strategies of recipient countries.

site_title: Twitter uses new approach to step up fight against trolls
summary: Twitter is stepping up its fight against online trolls by analyzing "behavioral signals" in addition to tweet content. The new approach aims to identify and mute bullies and trolls, even if their tweets don't violate Twitter policy. The platform will use AI and machine learning to focus on user actions, such as multiple accounts or repetitive tweeting, to distort conversations. The goal is to encourage free and open conversation while reducing the ability to game and skew systems.

site_title: Rio Tinto CEO calls for 'United Nations' of the mining world
summary: Rio Tinto CEO Jean-Sebastien Jacques calls for the creation of a "United Nations" of the mining industry to address rising resource nationalism and cost inflation. He believes partnerships can help mitigate these challenges.

site_title: With friends like Trump, who needs enemies: EU chief
summary: EU President Donald Tusk criticized US President Donald Trump, calling him "capricious assertiveness" and saying the US acted like an enemy rather than a friend. Tusk urged EU leaders to form a united front against Trump's withdrawal from the Iranian nuclear deal and his imposition of trade tariffs on Europe. The EU agreed to support the Iran deal if Tehran abides by it and to protect European companies affected by the US decision. The EU also presented a united front on trade, stating it would not negotiate with a gun at its head, but some member states are open to tolerating limited quotas from the US.

images.alt_text: The European Union's top official launched a stinging attack Wednesday on President Donald Trump, slamming his "capricious assertiveness" and saying the US leader acted more like an enemy than a friend.

site_title: Firms should take initiative instead of relying on government: Inderjit Singh
summary: Former MP Inderjit Singh suggests that firms, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), should take the initiative to address their needs instead of relying on government policies. He recommends exploring shared services, technological solutions, and alternative financing sources to help themselves and each other. Singh also proposes setting up a cooperative SME bank, which could benefit Singapore's SMEs.

images.alt_text: Instead of holding out for government policies to change in their favour, firms should do what they can on their own, said former member of parliament and co-president of the World Entrepreneurship Forum Inderjit Singh, at the Mitigating Business Uncertainties seminar on Thursday morning.

site_title: Didi revamps car pooling safety
summary: Didi Chuxing, a Chinese ride-hailing company, has revamped its car pooling safety measures after a female customer was allegedly murdered by a driver using its Hitch service in China. The company will delete personalized tags, make driver facial recognition compulsory, and halt Hitch service from 10pm to 6am daily. Didi also announced measures to improve safety across its other services, including facial recognition for all platforms, a redesigned emergency help button, and voice recordings of every ride. These changes aim to enhance user safety and will be implemented before the car pooling business resumes service.

site_title: US-China spat a matter of concern for EU: official
summary: The European Union is concerned about potential "collateral damage" from the US-China trade spat, with EU Agriculture Commissioner Phil Hogan warning that the bloc may suffer from flooded foreign steel imports. Hogan criticized Washington for breaking a years-long push to force Beijing to cut steel and aluminum exports. He urged the US to work with the EU to address prolonged trade issues with China, citing concerns that the dispute could escalate into other areas, affecting the EU market and international companies.

site_title: Indonesian market rout worsens ahead of central bank rate decision
summary: Indonesian stocks and the rupiah plummeted for a third day, with the currency reaching a 31-month low due to foreign investors' asset dump amid rising US yields and a strong dollar. The rupiah fell to 14,110 to a US dollar, while the Jakarta Composite Index dropped 1.6%. Bank Indonesia is expected to raise interest rates on Thursday to stem the sell-off, amid lingering trade, growth, and geopolitical worries. A series of terror attacks in Indonesia further eroded investor sentiment, with analysts predicting no positive catalyst to reverse the trend.

site_title: PM Lee to meet Mahathir on Saturday
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will meet Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir on Saturday, highlighting the strong ties between the two countries. Despite the recent election outcome in Malaysia, Lee expressed his commitment to maintaining good relations with neighboring countries, regardless of political cycles or election outcomes.

site_title: US data fuelling greenback, but outlook lacks consensus
summary: The US dollar is experiencing a rally, but its outlook remains uncertain. Forex strategists believe it may be a good time to buy battered currencies like the Aussie, sterling, and euro due to improving economic data. The US stock market edged down from records amid tariff threats, while European stocks were dragged down by bank and healthcare sectors. US-EU trade talks are also in focus, with traders brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports surge 11.8% in April after 2 months of contraction; electronics shipments continue to slide
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports surged 11.8% in April, reversing a two-month contraction. This was driven by a rise in non-electronic exports, which outweighed a decline in electronics shipments. The growth beats economist estimates of a 7.3% increase. This follows a 3.2% decline in March and a 6% fall in February. The improvement in non-oil exports suggests a recovery in the Singaporean economy.

images.alt_text: After shrinking for two straight months, Singapore's non-oil domestic exports returned to growth in April as rising non-electronic exports outweighed a slide in electronics shipments.

site_title: Four years after coup, Thais tire of corruption and democratic delays
summary: Thailand's ruling military junta, four years after a bloodless coup, faces a public perception crisis due to endemic corruption and delayed democratic reforms. Despite promising to tackle corruption and restore democratic rule, the junta has passed 298 laws and issued over 500 orders, but corruption remains widespread. Protests have increased, with demonstrators demanding an election and better living standards. Analysts say the junta has done more to battle corruption than any other government in Thai history, but popular dissatisfaction is unlikely to dislodge the regime, with leaders of the main opposition group weary of more bloodshed.

site_title: Moderate-growth forecast not cause for worry: PM
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong reassured Singaporeans that the country's moderate growth forecast of 2-4% is "quite good for a mature economy". Despite concerns, South Korea and Taiwan are growing at a comparable rate, while Japan's growth is slower. Lee emphasized the importance of young leaders coming together as much as identifying the next PM.

site_title: Surbana Jurong, CAI clinch projects in India's Pune Metropolitan Region
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Singaporean company, has clinched a project to provide a masterplan for the Pune Metropolitan Region in Maharashtra, India. Changi Airports International (CAI) will also provide advisory services for the proposed new Pune Airport. The project was awarded following a joint committee meeting between Singapore and India, which agreed to collaborate on urban infrastructure, port and logistics, and manufacturing sectors. The master plan is expected to be delivered in 10 months, guiding the physical development of the region and providing a sustainability framework.

site_title: Ash cloud from Hawaii volcano sparks red alert for aviation
summary: A red alert for aviation has been issued due to an ash cloud from Hawaii's Kilauea volcano, triggered by intense explosions that spewed ash and volcanic smog into the air. The US Geological Survey warned that the eruption could become more violent, producing ballistic projectiles and increasing ash production. The ash, not poisonous but irritating, has affected roads and air quality, prompting an "unhealthy air" advisory in the community. The eruption has also impacted the island's tourism industry, with hotel bookings dropping by nearly half.

site_title: CAD, MAS ready to extend further help on 1MDB transactions
summary: Singapore authorities are prepared to provide further assistance to Malaysia in investigating 1MDB transactions, following new Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's promise to charge former PM Najib Razak over graft claims. Singapore has cooperated with Malaysia on past requests for information and has taken action against financial institutions and individuals involved in 1MDB-related fund flows. The alleged mastermind, Jho Low, is believed to be in China or Thailand. Some $4.5 billion is alleged to have been misappropriated from 1MDB, with funds possibly going to Najib's personal bank accounts.

site_title: China's refined wine palates thirst for more
summary: China's wine consumption is rapidly growing, with over 1.46 billion liters consumed annually, ranking fifth globally. The country is expected to become the world's second-largest wine consumer by 2021, with a 18.5% increase in consumption. A recent international wine tasting competition in Beijing showcased China's emerging wine connoisseurs, with many seeking out domestic and international wines for taste, pleasure, and experience. The growing passion for wine has led to an increase in imports, with 750 million liters of foreign wine entering China in 2017, and Chinese wine producers responding by improving quality and training overseas.

site_title: Deliveroo employees to receive shares totalling £10m
summary: Deliveroo, a British food courier company, will give its nearly 2,000 permanent employees shares worth nearly £10 million, making them shareholders. This move aims to recognize their hard work and commitment. However, the program does not extend to its 15,000 self-employed riders. The company's valuation is around $2 billion, and its founder, Will Shu, wants to reward employees for their contributions to the company's success.

site_title: WHO's new leadership on the wrong track
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is facing criticism for its ineffective leadership and lack of focus on core issues, particularly strengthening national health systems and coordinating defenses against transnational disease outbreaks. The WHO's tendency to do poorly has led to criticism of its response to the 2014 Ebola crisis and its handling of global health threats. Funding issues, with only 5.7% of its budget allocated to disease outbreaks, have also contributed to the organization's problems. The WHO's new leadership, led by Director-General Tedros Adhanom, is under scrutiny for its inability to unite nations around practical solutions and for prioritizing non-core topics such as intellectual property protections.

site_title: US still hopeful over N Korea summit; Trump ready to meet
summary: US President Donald Trump is still hopeful for a summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, despite North Korea's recent comments that may reconsider the meeting if the US insists on unilateral nuclear disarmament. White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders stated that the US remains hopeful, but prepared for tough negotiations, and will continue the maximum pressure campaign if the meeting doesn't happen. The summit is scheduled for June 12 in Singapore.

site_title: Manulife US Reit to raise US$197.2m from 22-for-100 preferential offering
summary: Manulife US Reit has announced a preferential offering of 22 new units for every 100 held at US$0.865 per unit, aiming to raise US$197.2 million. The deal includes 228 million new non-renounceable units and is underwritten by DBS Bank and CLSA Singapore. The funds will be used to partially fund two office building acquisitions and for expenses related to the offering and working capital. The books closure date is May 24.

site_title: Brazil keeps interest rate at 6.5% in surprise move
summary: Brazil's Central Bank maintained the key Selic rate at 6.5% in a surprise move, ending 12 consecutive interest rate cuts. Analysts had expected a further cut to 6.25%. The decision reflects "volatility" during Brazil's weak economic recovery from its worst recession on record. The bank has been slashing interest rates since October 2016 to stimulate the economy.

site_title: Old trades, new trends, in the Weekend magazine
summary: Singaporean business owners are reviving traditional trades, such as karang guni collecting, fishmongering, and coffee powder selling, with modern twists. Brillyn Teoh's family rag-and-bone business now sells second-hand furniture, while Jeffrey Tan turned buying fish into a hipster shopping experience. Jacob Tan modernized his coffee-roasting business by sourcing specialty coffee. Meanwhile, Colin Goh's RICE company demonstrates a sustainable business model without government handouts. These entrepreneurs showcase innovative approaches to preserving heritage trades while appealing to new customers.

site_title: China spots problems with US cars, pork as trade talks get under way
summary: China has stepped up inspections of key US imports, including pork and automobiles, amid high-level trade talks with the US. The move comes after China found problems with American pork and US car imports were found to be of poor quality. Vice-Premier Liu He and other high-ranking Chinese officials visited Washington for negotiations, while US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross expressed a "wide" gap between the two countries. The US is seeking a trade deal with China, with US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin working to reach an agreement, but tariffs remain a major point of contention.

images.alt_text: China said on Wednesday it had stepped up inspections of key US imports such as pork and automobiles, just as a high-level delegation visits Washington for key trade negotiations.

site_title: Boustead's chairman puts trust in Falcon Energy MD
summary: Boustead chairman Wong Fong Fui has invested S$2 million in Falcon Energy Group, taking an 8% stake, citing trust in managing director P T Tan. Wong aims to gain an early-mover advantage in the slowly recovering offshore and marine sector. FEG's low debt and planned divestment of its CH Offshore shareholding are seen as positives. The company has incurred a loss of US$19.7 million for the nine months ended March 31, 2018.

site_title: Euro falls to lowest since late December on Italy debt worries
summary: The euro fell to its lowest level since late December, plummeting to US$1.1783, following reports that Italy's 5-Star Movement and far-right League plan to ask the ECB for debt forgiveness of 250 billion euros. The dollar's resurgence, reaching a five-month high, also contributed to the euro's decline. This move reverses the euro's performance in 2018, which was initially expected to strengthen due to the US' trade and budget deficits.

site_title: Starbucks unveils ambitious China plan
summary: Starbucks plans to more than triple its revenue in China over the next five years, aiming for 6,000 stores on the mainland by 2022. The company aims to compete with KFC and other foreign food chains by opening a new store every 15 hours. Starbucks is also expanding its product offerings, including a $7.2 billion deal with Nestle to introduce packaged coffee products in Chinese supermarkets and restaurants. The company expects to more than double its operating profit in China by 2022 and create 10,000 jobs annually.

site_title: Airbnb sets its sights on surfing
summary: Airbnb has introduced over 75 surfing-related activities in its Experiences category, available in 20 destinations worldwide. The new experiences were launched in partnership with the World Surf League, with prices ranging from $50 to $100. This marks Airbnb's first official partnership with a sports organization for its Experiences platform. The move aims to expand the company's offerings and provide travelers with unique experiences.

site_title: Singapore shares fall for third straight day
summary: Singapore shares fell for the third consecutive day, with the Straits Times Index down 0.2% to 3,533.05, amidst heightened market volatility. The US dollar strengthened as concerns over US interest rate increases resurfaced. Other Asian markets, including Japan, Hong Kong, and Shanghai, also declined. The US yield spiked, and North Korea threatened to pull out of a US summit, contributing to the market downturn.

site_title: Hong Kong's land record smashed by Sun Hung Kai's HK$25.2b buy
summary: Hong Kong's land record was shattered by Sun Hung Kai Properties' HK$25.2 billion purchase of a residential land plot near Hong Kong's former airport, surpassing the previous record of HK$17.3 billion set in November 2017. The land has a maximum gross floor area of 131,495 square meters. The purchase signals a continued rise in Hong Kong's residential property market, with higher land prices likely leading to higher home prices. The Kai Tak area in Kowloon has become a hotspot for investors, with Chinese conglomerate HNA Group selling three land parcels for more than they paid.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group's Q1 2018 financials were disappointing due to the absence of profits from blockbuster movie Master and underperformance of Golden Slumber. RHB Research cuts target price to S$0.10, maintaining a "buy" rating, citing yield-accretive acquisitions and potential hit Sovereign Default. Best World International's Q1 net profit fell 9.2% due to delayed recognition of China takings, with revenue down 30% year-on-year. Both analysts remain cautious but positive on the companies' outlook for future recovery.

site_title: Data analytics and e-platforms changing the commodity sector
summary: Data analytics and electronic platforms are transforming the Singapore commodity-trading sector, enhancing the country's value proposition for firms. The use of data analytics is becoming increasingly important for companies to make informed decisions, with many firms hiring data scientists. E-platforms, such as online marketplaces and portals, are also emerging, enabling companies to "exchange information, negotiate contracts, and conclude business" more efficiently and securely. These innovations are expected to drive growth in the sector, with over 60% of commodity-trading companies believing that big data and data analytics will transform the sector.

site_title: OKP group MD, employees charged for worksite accident
summary: OKP Holdings' subsidiary and managing director Or Toh Wat, along with employees Allen Yee and Wong Kiew Hai, have been charged for alleged breaches of the Building Control Act and Workplace Safety and Health Act following a work-site accident in July 2017 that killed one worker and injured 10 others. The accident occurred during the construction of a road viaduct under the Pan Island Expressway. The company is seeking legal advice on the matter.

site_title: Tesla manufacturing woes, fatal crashes combine to sink shares
summary: Tesla's shares plummeted 2.7% to $284.18 after a fatal crash in southern Switzerland and a bearish report from Morgan Stanley analyst Adam Jonas, who slashed his price target by 23% due to "structural" issues with the Model 3 sedan. The analyst cited vehicle design, manufacturing process, and automation levels as key concerns. Elon Musk criticized analysts and media for their coverage of the incidents, and Tesla has temporarily halted Model 3 production to make assembly line fixes. The company's energy unit has also lost two leaders, adding to departures at the electric-car maker.

site_title: Industrial production up 0.7% in April on strong mining activity
summary: US industrial production rose 0.7% in April, driven by strong mining activity and a solid performance by manufacturing firms. Cold weather and a decline in car and vehicle parts production were the only factors to dampen the first quarter's strong start. This data contradicts previous concerns about a potential economic slowdown, offering a positive note for the US economy.

site_title: Cavenagh Gardens, Flynn Park, Rosalia Park join bandwagon
summary: JLL launches five freehold residential sites in Singapore with a total value of over S$1.2 billion. The sites include Cavenagh Gardens, Flynn Park, Rosalia Park, La Ville, and three single-storey detached houses at Lorong H Telok Kurau. The minimum prices range from S$36-38 million to S$480 million, with a price per square foot of S$1,640. Regional director Tan Hong Boon expects "keen interest" from local and foreign developers and investors, citing strong demand for residential land and recent sales of S$8.33 billion in the past four-and-a-half months.

site_title: Japan's economy shrinks after two years of growth
summary: Japan's economy contracted by 0.2% quarter-over-quarter in the January-March period, marking its first reversal in two years due to sluggish consumption and a winter cold snap. This growth reversal is expected to be short-lived, with analysts predicting a rebound. The contraction was compared to 0.1% growth at the end of 2017, according to the Cabinet Office.

site_title: US Justice Department and FBI probing Cambridge Analytica
summary: The US Justice Department and FBI are investigating Cambridge Analytica, a British marketing firm at the center of the Facebook data scandal. Officials have interviewed a former employee, Christopher Wylie, who claimed the company obtained data from up to 87 million Facebook users for Donald Trump's presidential campaign. Cambridge Analytica denies exploiting the data, citing it deleted the data obtained in breach of Facebook's terms. The probe appears to focus on the company's finances and data handling practices, and its connection to the broader investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election is unclear.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: 3Cnergy, a CATALIST-listed company, has entered into a subscription agreement with Catpital Private, which will subscribe for 101.64 million new shares at S$0.022 per share. This deal will raise net proceeds of nearly S$2.24 million for the company. The price is a discount of 7.56% from the weighted average price of S$0.0238 on May 14.

site_title: Venture, recent IPOs among stock changes in MSCI, FTSE indices
summary: Venture Corp, a Singaporean electronics manufacturer, has been added to the MSCI Singapore Index and FTSE Value-Stocks Asean Index, while being dropped from the MSCI Singapore Small Cap Index. Other companies, such as Cromwell European Reit and Keppel KBS US Reit, have been added to the MSCI Singapore Small Cap Index, while Hutchison Port Trust and StarHub have been removed from the MSCI Singapore Index. The changes are effective as of May 31 and May 21, respectively.

site_title: Asean stands to gain from Belt and Road Initiative despite challenges
summary: The Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) has significant win-win implications for both China and the more than 80 countries and international organisations that have joined. The BRI aims to connect countries via a combination of land-based and ocean-crossing routes, with Asean being well-positioned to reap benefits. Projects worth $53.3 billion are underway in Asean-5 countries, with Malaysia and the Philippines expected to be the biggest beneficiaries. However, challenges and risks, such as public backlash and geopolitical risks, need to be addressed to materialise the large long-term benefits of the BRI.

site_title: Bankruptcy jeopardises RCom's US$3.7b deal; shares plummet
summary: Reliance Communications Ltd's shares plummeted 21% after an Indian tribunal ordered the company into insolvency proceedings, jeopardizing its US$3.7 billion asset sale to Reliance Jio Infocomm Ltd. The tribunal accepted a petition from Ericsson AB to recover 11.6 billion rupees in unpaid dues. The order sets back RCom's planned sale of airwaves, towers, and fibre assets. RCom can appeal the verdict with a tribunal in New Delhi.

site_title: Burberry beats forecasts as market awaits Tisci's designs
summary: Burberry reported a 2% rise in full-year adjusted profit to £467 million, beating market forecasts. The luxury group's revenue declined 1% to £2.73 billion, but comparable same-store sales rose 3%, in line with forecasts. New designer Riccardo Tisci's designs are key to repositioning the brand in a higher luxury segment. Burberry's chief executive Marco Gobbetti expressed optimism about the year ahead, citing promising early signs of transformation and a strong leadership team in place.

site_title: Tom Wolfe kept a close, comical and astonished eye
summary: Tom Wolfe, a renowned writer and caricaturist, died at 88, leaving behind a legacy of innovative journalism. Known for his distinctive style, Wolfe helped create the New Journalism movement, which emphasized immersive reporting and attention-grabbing prose. His work, including "The Right Stuff" and "The Bonfire of the Vanities," captivated readers with its unique blend of satire and social commentary. Wolfe's writing often tackled American society's complexities, vices, and follies, earning him both praise and criticism from peers like Norman Mailer and John Updike.

images.alt_text: Every morning, Tom Wolfe dressed in one of his signature outfits - silk jacket, double-breasted white vest, shirt, tie, pleated pants, red-and-white socks and white shoes - and sat down at his typewriter.

site_title: China's leading private firms toe Party line
summary: China's private firms, including Alibaba, Haier, and Dalian Wanda, have pledged to help reduce the country's income gap, a key objective of the Communist Party's Socialism with Chinese Characteristics (SCC) policy. President Xi Jinping has emphasized the importance of reading party literature and has encouraged entrepreneurs to study and adapt to the party's vision. The private sector is expected to play a larger role in achieving China's future goals, including lifting 55 million people out of extreme poverty by 2020.

site_title: Singapore AI health startup UCARE.AI raises S$8.2m in funding
summary: Singapore-based AI healthcare startup UCARE.AI has raised S$8.2 million in funding, primarily in Series A funding. Investors include Walden International, Great Eastern, Peter Lim, and WPGrowth Ventures. The funds will be used for talent acquisition and market expansion in South-east Asia. UCARE.AI uses AI to optimize healthcare resources and reduce costs by prioritizing healthcare resources and identifying the risk of rehospitalization. The startup plans to work with companies like Parkway Shenton to provide personalized health risk assessments and timely interventions.

site_title: China coal traders bet on shortages as spring temperatures soar
summary: China's thermal coal futures rose to a six-week high on May 16, 2018, as traders anticipated a supply crunch due to lower hydro power output and forecasts of a summer heat wave. Demand is expected to rise as households crank up air conditioners in cities like Beijing and Shanghai. Coal prices have rallied 16% since mid-April, with futures reaching 643 yuan (S$135) per tonne, the highest since February 28. Utilities are shoring up supplies, but the pace of stockpiling is expected to accelerate in late May, with prices potentially reaching 690 yuan per tonne in June.

site_title: Can McDonalds and Starbucks help solve the global retirement problem?
summary: A proposal suggests that McDonald's and Starbucks can help solve the global retirement problem by making saving and investing easier and more convenient. The author proposes that these companies use their existing electronic payment systems to deduct retirement savings from customers' accounts, similar to how they deduct purchases. This would make saving and investing as easy as spending, potentially leading to significant increases in automatic retirement savings. Additionally, the author recommends simplifying investment products to focus on target return and maximum drawdown, eliminating unnecessary jargon and benchmarks, to make investing more accessible and transparent.

images.alt_text: Despite the knowledge of the excess spending dilemma, our whole environment (not least the financial industry) is geared to spending.

site_title: HSBC's Saudi unit to buy RBS venture in US$5b stock deal
summary: HSBC's Saudi Arabia unit, Saudi British Bank (SABB), has agreed to pay a 29% premium to acquire Royal Bank of Scotland's (RBS) local venture, Alawwal Bank, in a $5 billion stock deal. The deal values Alawwal's existing share capital at $6.7 billion, and would be Saudi Arabia's first bank combination in nearly 20 years. The merger would make SABB the kingdom's third-largest lender, with assets of $73 billion.

site_title: China's new home prices pick up in April with broad-based gains
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.5% in April, marking the 36th consecutive month of gains, with 58 of 70 major cities reporting higher prices. On an annual basis, home prices increased 4.7%, slowing from a 4.9% gain in March. Despite government measures to prevent speculative investment, broader market strength suggests momentum persists, particularly in smaller cities. Authorities have introduced curbs in over 100 cities to reduce bubble risks and ensure a soft landing.

site_title: More than 100 SMEs gain from group-based upgrading solutions
summary: More than 100 small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore have benefited from 22 group-based upgrading projects implemented by SME Centres in the past year. The centres aim to expand this initiative to another 200 SMEs by year's end, with the goal of improving sales, productivity, and customer service levels.

site_title: Are venture capitalists value destroyers?
summary: Venture capitalists are funding companies at a significant loss, with many selling products and services at a price lower than production costs. These losses are being sustained through investments, which are driven by the promise of future growth rather than current profitability. Companies like Uber and Amazon have burnt through billions of dollars in losses, with Uber's nine-year losses totaling over $10.7 billion. This "value destruction" is being fueled by venture capitalists who stake their fortunes on the companies' ability to multiply valuation over time.

site_title: TCS enters big league but does its growth justify its valuation?
summary: Tata Consultancy Services (TCS), India's largest IT company, has reached a market capitalization of over $100 billion, making it the country's most valuable company and breaking into the global big league. However, analysts question whether its growth justifies its valuation, citing a 6.7% revenue growth in the fiscal year 2018, lower than the industry average. The company's "Business 4.0" plan aims to drive large-scale transformation across sectors, but experts argue that its shares may be riding on hope rather than substance, with valuations deemed expensive by some analysts.

site_title: Far East bags coveted Holland site for S$1.2b
summary: Far East Organization has secured a coveted commercial and residential site in Holland Road, Singapore, for S$1.213 billion. The consortium, led by Far East, will develop a mixed-use project with 400+ apartments for sale, serviced apartments, offices, retail space, and dual office/residential units. The total development cost is estimated to be around S$1.8 billion. The URA praised the winning proposal's design concept and planning of public spaces, which will enhance the existing Holland Village character. This is Far East's first S$1 billion acquisition in seven years, marking a significant victory for the property giant.

site_title: Germany's booming construction sector raises 2018 sales forecast
summary: Germany's construction sector is experiencing a boom, driven by soaring demand for real estate, increased investments, and higher state spending on infrastructure. The HDB Construction Industry Association raised its sales forecast to 6% nominal growth, up from 4% in January. Real sales are expected to grow by 2% due to higher construction prices. The sector's growth is being fueled by the European Central Bank's ultra-low interest rates, a growing urban population, and high immigration. The construction boom is also contributing to overall economic growth, with investments in construction being a key driver of GDP expansion.

site_title: Pacific Radiance to embark on schemes of arrangement
summary: Pacific Radiance, a Singapore-based offshore marine operator, plans to pursue restructuring through schemes of arrangement to avoid legal proceedings. The company's unit, Pacific Crest Pte Ltd, has made applications to the court for interim protection against winding up proceedings and enforcement of security over its property. This move aims to provide stability for day-to-day operations and allow time to pursue restructuring and investment. The applications are in response to winding up proceedings filed by Alliance Catering, seeking payment of US$1.07 million and S$76,900.

site_title: US regulators fine China's ICBC US$6.1m for oversight failures
summary: US regulators have fined China's Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) US$6.1 million for oversight failures related to anti-money laundering systems.
