The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA) and the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) charged ICBC with inadequate monitoring and reporting of suspicious transactions, including the clearance of 33 billion penny stock shares. The bank has agreed to pay US$5.3 million to FINRA and US$860,000 to the SEC. Analysts say the actions may slow China's banks' growth into overseas markets.

site_title: Will CCT divest Twenty Anson?
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) may divest its 20-storey office tower, Twenty Anson, after receiving unsolicited interest from a few parties. CCT retained Cushman & Wakefield to gather interest, with potential buyers offering S$2,500 per square foot, valued at S$515 million. The building, which has a 94.3% occupancy rate, may be sold to repay debts or boost future distributions to unitholders, as its net property income fell 16% in the first quarter of this year.

site_title: Shrinking the Fed's large balance sheet
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised the target range of the Fed funds rate to 1.5-1.75% in March 2018, with officials projecting further rate increases. The Fed's balance sheet, which grew to $4.3 trillion since 2008, is shrinking as part of its plan to normalize policy. The balance sheet reduction is expected to lead to higher short-term rates and may have an easing effect on markets. Analysts expect the Fed to raise rates a total of four times this year, with some arguing that the unwinding of quantitative easing may dampen interest rates in the long term.

site_title: Tencent beats estimates as WeChat, mobile games drive growth
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd posted a 61% jump in quarterly net income to 23.3 billion yuan, driven by mobile game blockbusters like PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds and WeChat's 1.04 billion monthly active users. Revenue rose 48% to 73.5 billion yuan, surpassing estimates, but adjusted earnings per share missed the mark. The company's gaming segment grew 68% and value-added services revenue rose 34%. Tencent continues to focus on gaming and advertising growth, while investing in new businesses to sustain growth and expand its user base.

site_title: What returns would you give up for doing good?
summary: Investors are increasingly allocating money to environmentally, socially, and governance (ESG) funds, with assets growing 37% last year. However, there is a risk of "mission creep" as funds take on social responsibility beyond their fiduciary duty. Norway's sovereign wealth fund is considering banning ownership of gambling stocks, while Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund plans to increase ESG-classified assets. Experts argue that sacrificing potential gains for ESG considerations is necessary, but the extent of the impact on returns is uncertain.

site_title: Rupert Murdoch's son Lachlan to become Fox CEO after Disney deal
summary: Rupert Murdoch's son Lachlan will become the CEO of 21st Century Fox after the company's TV and film assets are acquired by Walt Disney Co in a $52.4 billion deal. Lachlan and his father will serve as co-chairmen, with John Nallen taking on the role of chief operating officer. The new Fox will retain assets such as Fox News and sports cable networks, but the company has declined to comment on reports of a rival offer from Comcast Corp. The deal is expected to be approved by shareholders this summer.

site_title: All resolutions passed at Yuuzoo's special general meeting
summary: Yuuzoo Corporation's special general meeting was held on May 16, 2018, resulting in the passage of all resolutions. The resolutions included discontinuing operations in Bermuda, continuing operations in the British Virgin Islands, changing the company's name to Yuuzoo Networks Group Corporation, and adopting new capital structure and memorandum and articles of association.

site_title: TT International's Big Box in Jurong East put up for sale by receivers
summary: Singapore's Big Box warehouse retail mall, owned by TT International, has been put up for sale by its receivers and managers. The eight-storey building in Jurong East has a gross floor area of over 1.4 million square feet and is located within the Jurong Gateway locale. The sale, conducted via an expression of interest, will close on June 14, offering logistics players and e-commerce companies a rare opportunity to acquire the facility. The property has a balance of 19 years on its 30-year lease tenure and is approved for "Business 1" use with a gross plot ratio of up to 2.5.

site_title: Indonesian market rout worsens ahead of central bank rate decision
summary: Indonesian stocks and the rupiah plummeted for a third day ahead of the central bank's rate decision, with the currency hitting a 31-month low due to foreign investors' asset dumping amid rising US yields and a strong dollar. The rupiah fell to 14,110 to the US dollar, while the Jakarta Composite Index dropped 1.6%. Bank Indonesia is expected to raise interest rates to stem the sell-off, which has made Indonesia's currency and stocks among the worst performers in Asia amidst ongoing trade, growth, and geopolitical concerns.

site_title: SPH ties up with China's Focus Media in JV
summary: SPH and China's Focus Media Holding have formed a joint venture (JV) company, Target Media Culcreative Pte Ltd, to develop a smart in-lift media delivery platform in Singapore. The JV will leverage SPH's news and lifestyle content, Focus Media's expertise in in-lift media technologies, and their respective systems support and product development guidance. The platform aims to improve audience engagement efforts and will be launched later. The JV company will be owned by the two largest shareholders, SPH and Focus Media, with 30% and 21% stakes respectively.

site_title: Malaysia's new govt scraps 6% consumption tax
summary: Malaysia's new government has scrapped a 6% consumption tax, known as the Goods and Services Tax (GST), which was introduced in 2015. The tax rate will be set at zero per cent from June 1, fulfilling Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's campaign promise. Economists warn the move could cut government income and widen the budget deficit, but analysts suggest the government may offset losses with other revenue-raising measures and boost consumer spending.

site_title: PM Lee to meet Mahathir in Malaysia on Saturday
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong is set to meet Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad on Saturday, amid a period of uncertainty and global economic changes. Lee emphasized the importance of maintaining good relations with Malaysia, his closest neighbor, and expressed hopes for a stable and prosperous Malaysia. He also acknowledged the challenges posed by trade tensions between the US and China, which he believes threaten global prosperity, particularly for smaller countries like Singapore.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares barely changed amid N Korea, trade worries
summary: Hong Kong stocks barely changed on Wednesday, ending 0.1% down at 31,110.20, amid renewed worries over North Korea and surging US bond yields. Investors awaited news from US-China trade talks in Washington. The Hang Seng index was unchanged at 12,440.12 points.

site_title: Declassified report on Malaysia's 1MDB shows funding anomalies
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB scandal-plagued state fund has been found to have funding anomalies, with auditors expressing widespread concern over the lack of corporate governance and internal controls. A newly-declassified report shows that 1MDB officers took investment actions without full knowledge of the board of directors and provided inaccurate information. The audit also found that the fund used government funds to pay interest on its debt, contrary to its original purpose. The report's release comes as Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad seeks to tighten the net around former premier Najib Razak, who has been barred from leaving Malaysia.

site_title: Pacific Radiance to pursue schemes of arrangement
summary: Pacific Radiance, an offshore marine operator, is planning to pursue restructuring through schemes of arrangement to avoid looming legal proceedings. The company's unit, Pacific Crest Pte Ltd, has applied to the Court for an interim protection against legal proceedings, seeking to fend off receiver or manager appointments and enforcement of security over its properties. The application, filed on May 16, provides stability for day-to-day operations and allows time to pursue restructuring and investment, pending court decision on June 8.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed 7.18 points, or 0.2%, at 3,533.05 on Wednesday, with 2 billion shares worth S$1.4 billion traded. Losers outpaced gainers 257 to 162.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat as gains in retail stocks offset losses in energy shares
summary: US stocks opened flat on Wednesday, with gains in retail stocks offsetting losses in energy shares. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.06% to 24,722.32, while the S&P 500 opened 0.04% higher at 2,712.62. The Nasdaq Composite gained 0.06% to 7,356.22. Gains in retail stocks, led by Macy's, countered losses in energy and financial shares.

site_title: Natural Cool and former chief corporate officer reach 'confidential settlement'
summary: Natural Cool has reached a confidential settlement with former CCO Ng Quek Peng over alleged wrongful termination, following a letter of demand in 2017 seeking damages exceeding S$2.5 million. Ng was terminated in February 2017 after the company's new board took over, citing no merits to his claim. The company had sought formal legal advice at the time. The terms of the settlement have not been disclosed.

site_title: Mind the gap, and stem the class divide
summary: Singapore's government acknowledges the country's growing inequality issue, with Education Minister Ong Ye Kung stating it's a "national priority today." The government has identified four areas to address: income gap, social mobility, social mixing, and social stratification. While Singapore is a middle-income society, social mobility is at risk of becoming entrenched, and the country's social stratification is a concern. To tackle inequality, the government and citizens must work together, with ceaseless striving and seizing opportunities to move up in life.

site_title: Far East Organization-led consortium clinches plum Holland Road site
summary: A consortium led by Far East Organization has won the 99-year leasehold site in Holland Road with a winning bid of S$1.213 billion, or nearly S$1,888 per square foot per plot ratio. The consortium's fellow members are Sekisui House and Sino Group. The winning bid surpassed the next highest bid of S$1.055 billion by a consortium comprising Perennial Real Estate Holdings and Qingjian Realty. The site's concept proposal was deemed "compelling" by the Urban Redevelopment Authority, with plans to maintain the site's human-scale environment and create unique street experiences.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.06 points to 1,858.26 on Wednesday, with a trading volume of 3.002 billion lots worth RM2.911 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 492 to 486.

site_title: Two more District 9 sites launched for collective sale
summary: Two freehold developments in Singapore's District 9, Cairnhill Astoria and Trendale Tower, have been launched for collective sale through public tender. The reserve prices are S$196 million and S$163.52 million, respectively. This marks a shift in collective sale interest towards prime sites, with prices rising by 5.5% in Q1 2018. The sales are expected to surpass last year's S$8.1 billion, with 26 residential collective sales worth S$8.3 billion already transacted in Districts 9 and 10.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: JLL launches five freehold residential sites worth over S$1.2 billion. Venture Corp is added to two stock indices and removed from one after mid-year reviews by MSCI and FTSE. The landmark TT International building in Jurong East is put up for sale by receivers, while Cairnhill Astoria in District 9 is set for collective sale for S$196 million. Boustead chairman Wong Fong Fui buys an 8% stake in Falcon Energy for S$2 million. Frasers Property, GIC, and JustCo invest US$177 million to develop a co-working space platform across Asia.

site_title: IEA cuts outlook for global oil demand as crude nears US$80 a barrel
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) has cut its forecast for global oil demand growth to 1.4 million barrels per day for 2018, citing a moderate outlook due to crude oil prices near $80 a barrel and reduced fuel subsidies in key importing nations. This reduction is attributed to 51% price increase in the last year, driven by coordinated supply cuts and US sanctions on Iran. Oil inventories in major nations have fallen 1 million barrels below the five-year average, prompting the IEA to monitor developments closely and be prepared to act if necessary.

site_title: US manufacturing output rises; past months revised lower
summary: US factory output rose 0.5% in April, exceeding economists' expectations. However, revised estimates showed less growth in prior months, casting doubt on the economic outlook. Overall industrial output expanded 0.7% in April, with machinery production contributing to the gain. The report follows a slowdown in US factory activity, with manufacturers citing rising commodity prices due to tariffs. Industrial capacity utilization rose 0.4 percentage points to 78.0% in April, a signal for further economic growth before sparking inflation.

site_title: Europe: Shares open higher
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Wednesday, supported by mining stocks and solid earnings updates, while Italian banks fell 0.8% due to fresh political worries. Top gainers included Micro Focus International and Alstom, while Elior fell 15% following a profit warning. The STOXX 600 index hovered around its highest level since early February.

site_title: AusNet invests A$140m to build transmission lines for Victoria wind farm
summary: AusNet Services is investing A$140 million to build a 70km, 132kV transmission line for the 530 MW Stockyard Hill Wind Farm in Victoria, Australia. The construction is scheduled to start in July 2018 and will be completed by the end of 2019, connecting the wind farm to a terminal station in Haunted Gully. The project is a key part of the wind farm's integration into the national power grid.

site_title: Japanese property firm CRE to invest US$6.2m in Sembcorp Infra Services
summary: Japanese property firm CRE Inc has agreed to invest US$6.2 million in Sembcorp Infra Services through a share subscription agreement. Sembcorp Infra Services will issue 20.51 million new shares, with CRE holding 30% of the enlarged capital. The investment is expected to be finalized by end-July 2018 in cash.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks flat; won skids on renewed North Korea tensions
summary: South Korea's stocks remained flat amid renewed tensions with North Korea, with the won falling 0.35% against the dollar. North Korea threatened to cancel a summit with the US and scrap inter-Korea talks, casting doubt on its pledge to denuclearize the peninsula. Tech shares, including Samsung and LG Electronics, rose, while steelmakers like POSCO and Hyundai Steel declined. The Kospi index remained unchanged at 2,459.82.

site_title: Owners of Trendale Tower in prime Cairnhill enclave asking for S$163.5m in collective sale
summary: Trendale Tower, a 20-storey residential development in Singapore's prime Cairnhill enclave, is being put up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$163.52 million. The site has a land rate of S$2,250 per square foot per plot ratio and is zoned for residential use with a gross plot ratio of 2.8. The sale is seen as an attractive offering for developers, with interest building up in the high-end residential segment. The tender will close on June 25.

site_title: Singapore's PM Lee to meet Mahathir in Malaysia on Saturday
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong plans to meet Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad in Malaysia on Saturday to discuss their relationship and potential cooperation. Lee emphasized the importance of a stable and prosperous Malaysia, citing their previous cooperation on projects such as the Second Link at Tuas. The meeting comes as Singapore faces uncertain global economic conditions, with rising trade tensions between the US and China. Lee reassured the public that Singapore's economic growth forecast of 2-4% is a good rate for a mature economy, and that the country will continue to push ahead with its economic upgrading efforts.

site_title: Malaysia says GST to be effectively scrapped from June 1
summary: Malaysia's new government, led by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, has announced that the country's 6% goods and services tax (GST) will be effectively abolished from June 1. This move aims to address the rising cost of living and stimulate spending in the Southeast Asian nation. The GST was introduced in 2015 by the previous government, led by Najib Razak. The decision is expected to put pressure on Malaysia's fiscal position, but is likely to boost the economy.

site_title: Australian stores limit baby formula as China demand hits stocks
summary: Australian supermarket chain Coles is limiting baby formula sales in some stores due to high demand from China, where the product is being resold for more than double the original price. The move comes after customers cleared shelves and sold the product online in China. Coles is restricting sales to two tins per customer and working with suppliers to improve availability. Similar restrictions are being implemented by Woolworths, with some stores moving the product behind counters. The move aims to protect local supply and ensure that customers with genuine needs have access to the product.

site_title: Straits Trading's Q1 profit down 53.6%
summary: Straits Trading Co's Q1 net profit dropped 53.6% to S$9.69 million, mainly due to lower revenue from tin mining and smelting. Total revenue decreased 7.2% to S$123.9 million. Earnings per share fell to 2.4 Singapore cents from 5.1 cents previously. The company plans to grow its Japan residential rental properties and redeploy capital into attractive investments in regional markets, including China and Australia.

site_title: Australia shares end higher on banks, miners; A2 Milk weighs on NZ
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 6,107, driven by bank stocks and miners, including BHP's 1.4% gain. New Zealand shares fell 1.8% to their lowest in over a week, weighed down by a2 Milk's 13.7% drop after missing revenue forecasts. Myer Holdings rose 16% despite posting a sales decline, and Westpac Banking advanced 0.7%. The decline in a2 Milk shares also hurt Synlait Milk Ltd, which closed 4.2% lower.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 2.51 points to 1,850.71. The index saw 93.13 million lots traded worth RM39.15 million, with 123 gainers outnumbering 88 losers.

site_title: Keppel Singmarine bags pair of newbuild dredgers from Van Oord
summary: Keppel Singmarine has secured newbuild contracts from Van Oord for the construction of two high-value dredgers. The dredgers, equipped with dual-fuel systems, are scheduled for delivery in Q4 2020 and Q2 2021. Keppel Singmarine will also be given an option to build a third dredger for Van Oord. The contracts are part of Van Oord's efforts to strengthen its mid-class dredger fleet and presence in the region, while Keppel Corp benefits from the diversification of its order book.

site_title: Malaysia stocks get no love from foreigners after election shock
summary: Malaysia's stocks have been negatively impacted by foreign investors following Mahathir Mohamad's surprise election win, with a 0.4% gain in the FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index this week. Foreign investors have sold US$375.6 million of stocks in two days, halving this year's foreign inflows. Despite this, local institution funds and retail investors remain positive on the market, citing the potential for the new administration to implement restructuring and improve the economy.

site_title: TT International's Big Box in Jurong East put up for sale by receivers
summary: TT International's Big Box in Jurong East, a 51% subsidiary, has been put up for sale by receivers. The eight-storey warehouse retail mall has a gross floor area of over 1.4 million sq ft and is located in a prime Jurong Gateway locale. The sale will be conducted via an expression of interest, closing on June 14. The property has a 19-year lease tenure and is approved for "Business 1" use, with potential for additional GFA conversion. The sale is seen as a compelling opportunity for logistics and e-commerce companies.

site_title: Hong Kong land record smashed by Sun Hung Kai's HK25.2b buy
summary: Hong Kong's property market has reached a record high with Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd paying HK$25.2 billion for a plot of residential land near Hong Kong's former airport, beating previous records. The purchase, which exceeds the previous record by almost one-and-a-half times, signals higher home prices in the world's least affordable real estate market. The Kai Tak area in Kowloon has become a hot property market, with Chinese conglomerate HNA Group Co selling land sites for more money than it paid. The sale is expected to total HK$40 billion.

site_title: Venture, recent IPOs among changes to MSCI, FTSE indices
summary: Venture Corp, an electronics manufacturer, has been added to the MSCI Singapore Index and the FTSE Value-Stocks Asean Index, but removed from the MSCI Singapore Small Cap Index. Other stocks have also been added or removed from various indices. Despite a recent decline in its share price due to rumors of struggling sales, analysts remain optimistic about the company's growth driven by other products.

site_title: White House: US still hopeful for North Korea summit
summary: The US remains hopeful for a summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, despite recent doubts. White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders stated that the US is prepared for tough negotiations. North Korea threatened to reconsider the summit if the US insists on unilateral nuclear disarmament. The meeting's fate remains uncertain, but the US continues to pursue diplomatic progress.

images.alt_text: The United States is still hopeful about a planned summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un but President Donald Trump is prepared for a tough negotiation process.

site_title: JLL launches five freehold residential sites worth over S$1.2b
summary: JLL has launched five freehold residential sites in Singapore worth over S$1.2 billion, attracting keen interest from local and foreign developers and investors. The sites include Cavenagh Gardens, Flynn Park, and three single-storey detached houses in Lorong H Telok Kurau. Tan Hong Boon, regional director at JLL, expects strong demand for residential lands due to the recent price upswing in private properties, with 26 sites worth S$8.33 billion sold in the past four-and-a-half months.

site_title: Surbana Jurong to provide masterplan for India's Maharashtra state
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Temasek-owned company, has been awarded a masterplan project for Pune Metropolitan Region in Maharashtra, India. The project involves reviewing existing regional plans and providing recommendations for future developments, including land use, infrastructure, and transportation. The planning process will be a joint effort with the Pune Metropolitan Regional Development Authority and other related authorities, with a 10-month delivery timeline. The project follows a framework agreement between Singapore and India to facilitate investments and collaboration opportunities in sectors such as aviation, urban infrastructure, and port and logistics.

site_title: Indonesia police shoot man after "sharp weapon" used in attack
summary: Indonesian police shot a man after he attacked them with a "sharp weapon" at Riau police headquarters in Pekanbaru, Sumatra, wounding two officers. A car rammed into the police headquarters, and a masked passenger got out, attacking officers. The man was shot and killed in the incident.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday trading at 3,531.83, down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday, falling 8.4 points, or 0.2%, to 3,531.83. Losers outnumbered gainers 210 to 128, with about 906.9 million shares changing hands. Ezion was the most actively traded counter, rising 5.2% to 12.1 Singapore cents. Other active index stocks included Venture Corp, down 3.6%, and Genting Singapore, falling 2.3%.

site_title: China's home prices rise 0.5% in April from March
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.5% in April from March, with a 4.7% year-over-year increase. This slowdown marks a continuation of property cooling measures implemented since 2016. The country aims to contain property bubbles while ensuring a soft landing in the economy.

site_title: Boustead's Wong Fong Fui buys 8% stake in Falcon Energy for S$2m
summary: Boustead chairman and CEO Wong Fong Fui acquired an 8% stake in Falcon Energy through a private placement, buying 70 million shares at 2.8 Singapore cents per share. The placement price was a 3.704% premium to the stock's volume-weighted average price of 2.7 Singapore cents on May 7 and 8.

site_title: HSBC, RBS Saudi Bank ventures reach initial deal on merger terms
summary: HSBC Holdings and Royal Bank of Scotland Group's Saudi banking affiliates reached a preliminary agreement on a potential merger between Alawwal Bank and Saudi British Bank. Alawwal shareholders will receive 0.485 SABB shares for each Alawwal share, valuing the bank at approximately 18.6 billion riyals. The deal, if successful, would create an entity with $73 billion in assets and mark Saudi Arabia's first bank merger in nearly 20 years, amid the country's diversification and privatization plans.

site_title: Frasers Property, GIC, JustCo invest US$177m to develop co-working space platform across Asia
summary: Frasers Property, GIC, and JustCo are investing US$177 million to develop a co-working space platform across Asia, with a focus on expanding into China, Japan, Australia, and other markets. The investment will support JustCo's technology solutions and enhance its service offerings. Frasers Property and GIC believe the co-working sector has growth potential, with opportunities for consolidation. The partnership aims to accelerate JustCo's expansion, leveraging international scale and technological services.

site_title: Asia: Markets fall, dollar rises as US rate fears return
summary: Asian markets declined, mirroring Wall Street, as the dollar strengthened amid US interest rate concerns. Solid retail sales data fueled inflation fears, boosting expectations for three more Federal Reserve rate hikes this year. Benchmark 10-year Treasury yields hit a seven-year high. Geopolitical issues and US-EU tariff tensions also kept investors cautious.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end down after Japan GDP shrinks
summary: Tokyo shares ended down on May 16, 2018, following a decline on Wall Street and Japan's first contraction in two years in GDP. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.44% to 22,717.23 and the Topix index dropped 0.27% to 1,800.35. The contraction was attributed to weaker-than-expected economic growth and a decline in consumer spending. The market reaction was largely in line with global trends, with US stocks also experiencing losses due to uncertainty over trade policies.

site_title: South Korea says North's decision to suspend inter-Korean talks 'regrettable'
summary: South Korea's unification ministry stated that North Korea's decision to suspend inter-Korean talks is regrettable and not in line with the Panmunjom Declaration. The talks were set to discuss a ministerial-level meeting, but North Korea cited a joint US-South Korea air drill as the reason for the postponement. The ministry urged North Korea to swiftly return to the talks, with an official statement to be sent to the North.

site_title: STX Entertainment: A Hollywood star may be born in Hong Kong
summary: STX Entertainment, a young Hollywood studio, is set to make its stock market debut in Hong Kong with a valuation of at least $2.5 billion. Backed by investors such as China's Tencent and Hong Kong-listed media company PCCW, the studio aims to capitalize on its local connections to produce movies that appeal in China. Despite being unprofitable, STX's top line is growing quickly, and investors may be drawn to its scarcity value in a consolidated industry. Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan are joint sponsors of the initial public offering.

site_title: Duterte says China's Xi won't allow his removal from office
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte said Chinese President Xi Jinping has assured him that Beijing won't allow his removal from office, despite the country's constitution limiting presidents to one six-year term. Duterte, nearing the end of his second term, has repeatedly rejected calls to seek another term. The assurance was reportedly made during a meeting between the two leaders in April. Duterte has been criticized for his reliance on Chinese loans and his reluctance to criticize Beijing's actions in the South China Sea.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday, STI down 0.2% to 3,533.9
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Wednesday, retreating 6.33 points, or 0.2%, to 3,533.9. The decline followed US stocks' overnight falls, as fears of inflation returned to the market. Losers outnumbered gainers 78 to 45, with DBS and Singtel falling 0.7% and 0.6%, respectively. Japan's Topix index also fell 0.2%, while Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index rose 0.1%.

site_title: Starbucks says aims to triple China revenue by 2022
summary: Starbucks aims to triple its China revenue by 2022, targeting 6,000 stores in the country by the end of 2022. The US coffee chain seeks to more than double its operating income in China, with current revenue at $3.24 billion. A global coffee alliance with Nestle will help extend Starbucks' reach in China. Despite increased competition, Starbucks dominates China's coffee scene and plans to leverage the partnership to provide more at-home options to Chinese consumers.

images.alt_text: Starbucks Corp is looking to more than triple its revenue and almost double its store count in China over the next five years, doubling down on the market as traffic growth comes under pressure in the United States.

site_title: Malaysia's jailed leader Anwar Ibrahim freed after royal pardon
summary: Malaysia's former deputy prime minister Anwar Ibrahim was released from prison on a royal pardon from the King on May 16, 2018. He had been serving a second prison term for sodomy since 2014. Anwar maintained the charges against him were part of a conspiracy to end his political career. Following his release, crowds of supporters cheered and chanted "Reformasi!" in celebration, marking a significant milestone in his long-standing fight for justice and reform. Anwar is now a free man after receiving the royal pardon.

site_title: Ex-French leader Sarkozy faces ruling on campaign finance trial
summary: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy faces a ruling on whether to stand trial on charges of illicit financing of his 2012 presidential campaign. Prosecutors claim he spent nearly 43 million euros via fake invoices, while Sarkozy's defense team argues he was sanctioned for campaign overspending in 2013. An appeals court's decision could delay a trial, which could result in up to a year in prison if convicted. Sarkozy has denied any wrongdoing and claims he was unaware of the alleged fraud.

site_title: Japan Q1 GDP contracts annualised 0.6%: government
summary: Japan's economy contracted at an annualised rate of 0.6% in Q1, marking the first decline in nine quarters. Private consumption and capital expenditure slowed, leading to the contraction. This ended the longest sequence of growth since 1986-1989, during Japan's asset-inflated bubble economy. The Q1 GDP shrinkage was slightly higher than the median estimate of a 0.2% annualised contraction.

site_title: Noble independent director to take over as chairman of audit committee from June 1
summary: Noble Group's independent director Andrew Herd will take over as chairman of its audit committee from Paul Brough on June 1. Brough steps down but remains a member. The commodities group reported a first quarter net loss of US$71.5 million, down from US$129.3 million in the previous year, with revenue slumping 39% to US$1.21 billion.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Frasers Property, Keppel, Aspen
summary: Frasers Property is investing $177 million with GIC and JustCo to develop a co-working space platform across Asia. Keppel Offshore & Marine sold five jackup rigs to Borr Drilling for $745 million. Aspen Group Holdings reported a 156.5% increase in net profit to RM13.1 million, with revenue rising 170% to RM102.7 million.

site_title: Australian consumer sentiment falls again in May
summary: Australian consumer sentiment decreased by 0.6% in May, according to a Melbourne Institute and Westpac Bank survey, falling for the second consecutive month. Despite a voter-friendly budget unveiled earlier in the month, consumers remained cautious about their family finances. The index, which measures optimism and pessimism, was still up 3.9% from the same period last year. Westpac Chief Economist Bill Evans described the result as a "disappointing update," suggesting the budget may not have had the desired impact on consumer sentiment.

site_title: Google worker rebellion against military project grows
summary: A growing petition among 4,000 Google employees urges the company to cancel its collaboration with the US military on a project using artificial intelligence to enhance drone capabilities. The project, referred to as Project Maven, has raised concerns about the potential for automated targeting systems on armed drones. The Electronic Frontier Foundation and the International Committee for Robot Arms Control have expressed support for the petition, warning that the technology could pave the way for autonomous drones to kill without human supervision. Google has not commented on the petition.

site_title: Ash cloud from Hawaii volcano sparks red alert for aviation
summary: A red alert for aviation has been issued in Hawaii due to an ash cloud from Kilauea volcano, which rose to 3,657m above the crater. Explosions intensified on Tuesday, spewing ash and triggering an "unhealthy air" advisory in the community of Pahala. The US Geological Survey (USGS) classifies this as an aviation red alert, indicating a volcanic eruption that could spew ash along aircraft routes.

site_title: Singapore prepared to extend further help to Malaysia on 1MDB-related transactions: CAD, MAS
summary: Singapore authorities are prepared to extend further assistance to Malaysia on 1MDB-related transactions, following a joint statement from the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). Singapore has cooperated extensively with Malaysian counterparts, fined eight banks S$29.1 million, and shut down Swiss private banks BSI and Falcon. The move comes as Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad expects prosecutors to soon charge former Prime Minister Najib Razak over graft claims, with allegedly $4.5 billion misappropriated from the state fund 1MDB.

images.alt_text: Singapore's authorities are fully prepared to extend further assistance to their Malaysian counterparts on 1MDB-related transactions, the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said in a statement on Wednesday morning.

site_title: Cairnhill Astoria in District 9 to be put up for collective sale for S$196m
summary: The freehold development Cairnhill Astoria in District 9 is set to be launched for collective sale at a reserve price of S$196 million, reflecting a land rate of S$1,964 per square foot per plot ratio. The site, built in 1983, comprises 36 apartments and has a gross plot ratio of 2.8 under the Master Plan 2014. This is comparable to recent sales in the area, and the collective sale is expected to attract buyers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend losses at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.44% at open, tracking US interest rate concerns. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 31,014.72, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.37% to 3,180.23. Investors worried about a possible sharp rise in US interest rates, which led to losses on Wall Street.

site_title: US investigating Cambridge Analytica: NYT
summary: The US Justice Department and FBI are investigating Cambridge Analytica, a now-defunct political data firm, over its handling of Facebook user information. The investigation focuses on the company's financial dealings and acquisition of personal data from Facebook and other sources. Cambridge Analytica was hired by President Donald Trump's 2016 US election campaign and harvested data from 87 million Facebook users, prompting multiple investigations in the US and Europe. Prosecutors have sought to question former employees and banks that handled the company's business.

site_title: Australia's Q1 wages growth disappoints, bolsters lower-for-longer rates view
summary: Australian wages rose 0.5% in Q1, below expectations, and private-sector growth remained near historic lows. This data supports the view that the Reserve Bank of Australia will hold interest rates at 1.50% for a prolonged period, awaiting a revival in consumer prices. Annual wage growth is just above consumer price inflation, and private sector wages remain stagnant at 1.9%. The data suggests the RBA may not see core inflation reaching its 2-3% target band until mid-2020.

site_title: US states sue OxyContin maker over opioid crisis
summary: US states sue OxyContin maker Purdue Pharma for alleged deceptive trade practices related to the opioid painkiller, which is linked to thousands of lives lost annually. The lawsuit, filed by six states, claims Purdue Pharma knowingly marketed OxyContin as a safe alternative to heroin despite its addictive nature. Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton stated, "My office is holding Purdue Pharma accountable for fueling the nation's opioid epidemic." The lawsuits are part of a wave of similar actions taken by states and municipalities nationwide.

site_title: US moving ahead with North Korea summit preparation: State Department
summary: The US is moving ahead with preparations for a summit between President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, scheduled for June 12. Despite North Korea's recent doubts, the State Department confirmed plans would continue, citing no notification of a position change. The annual Max Thunder joint military exercises, which North Korea has questioned, will proceed as scheduled. The US Pentagon defended the exercises as defensive and aimed at enhancing the alliance's ability to defend South Korea.

site_title: Airbnb sets its sights on surfing
summary: Airbnb has introduced over 75 surfing-related activities in its Experiences category, partnering with the World Surf League to offer surfing lessons, tours, and adventures in 20 destinations worldwide. The activities cost an average of $50 to $100 and are available in locations such as South Africa, Japan, and Hawaii. The move follows a 54% increase in guest arrivals in surfing communities in 2017, with surfers preferring to stay in homes rather than hotels. The partnership aims to capitalize on the growing interest in surfing among travelers, with several hotels also introducing surfing experiences for guests.

site_title: Airbus ruling may strain trade ties with Europe
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has ruled that the European Union (EU) illegally subsidised Airbus, allowing the US to potentially impose billions of dollars in retaliatory sanctions on EU imports. The US claims Airbus received 22 billion euros in financial support, resulting in commercial damages worth $7-10 billion for Boeing. The ruling could further strain trans-Atlantic trade relations, but a negotiated settlement remains possible. The US trade representative has warned that countermeasures could take months to decide, and the EU must take action to stop breaking WTO rules.

site_title: 3Cnergy to place out 101.6m new shares to Peter Lim-backed Catpital Private for S$2.24m
summary: 3Cnergy, a CATALIST-listed company, has entered into a subscription agreement with Catpital Private, backed by billionaire investor Peter Lim, to subscribe for 101.64 million new shares at S$0.022 per share. This is a discount of 7.56% from the weighted average price of S$0.0238 on May 14. The deal will raise nearly S$2.24 million in net proceeds, mainly for repaying term loans and working capital. The new shares will represent 3.31% of 3Cnergy's enlarged share capital.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down after Wall St drop
summary: Tokyo stocks opened down 0.36% on May 16, 2018, following a drop on Wall Street and Japan's economy contracting for the first time in two years, according to official data. The Nikkei 225 index fell 82.92 points to 22,735.10, while the Topix index declined 3.57 points to 1,801.58.

site_title: Singapore AI health startup UCARE.AI raises S$8.2m in funding
summary: Singapore-based AI health startup UCARE.AI has raised S$8.2 million in funding, primarily through Series A and seed funding rounds. The investors include Walden International, Great Eastern, Peter Lim, and WPGrowth Ventures. The funds will be used for talent acquisition and market expansion into South-east Asia. UCARE.AI uses AI to optimize healthcare resources and reduce costs, boasting a predictive capability to identify rehospitalization risk for Singaporeans. The startup aims to provide continuous monitoring and disease management to corporate patients through personalized health risk assessments and timely interventions.

site_title: Football field-sized asteroid to shave by Earth
summary: A football field-sized asteroid, 2010 WC9, is set to make a close approach to Earth on Tuesday, passing at a safe distance about halfway between the Earth and Moon. The asteroid, approximately 60-120 meters across, will be no closer than 193,000 kilometers to Earth's surface at its closest approach. This will be the closest the asteroid will come to Earth for at least two centuries. The asteroid will then make a distant flyby of Earth in 2019.

site_title: Europe: Shares buoyed by oil stocks
summary: European shares rose 0.1% on Tuesday, buoyed by oil stocks reaching their highest level since September 2014 due to concerns over US sanctions on Iran. The Stoxx 600 index, led by oil majors BP and Royal Dutch Shell, rose 0.9%, despite weak data from China and Germany. The financial sector also supported the market, with Raiffeisen and Commerzbank rising 4.6% and 3.9% respectively. Telecoms, however, fell 2% due to weak earnings from Vodafone and Eutelsat.

site_title: A Chinese town's deep bonds with Japan bring wealth and hatred
summary: In Fangzheng, China, a remote town near the border with Japan, a memorial garden honors the 5,000 Japanese who died in World War II. The Friendship Garden, built after Japan's defeat, symbolizes the close ties between Fangzheng and Japan. The town's residents have maintained strong economic and cultural bonds with Japan, despite the country's wartime aggression. The garden serves as a poignant reminder of the town's complex history, where deep relationships and shared memories coexist with feelings of hatred and resentment.

images.alt_text: At the end of a narrow road in Fangzheng, a remote town in north-eastern China, next to a hushed forest of birch and pine trees, stands the locked iron gate of the Sino-Japanese Friendship Garden.

site_title: Long legs turn women's heads, arm length immaterial: study
summary: In a study of over 800 American women, researchers found that men with legs slightly longer than average, but not too long, were deemed most attractive. The preferred leg length was just above average, with a good shin-to-thigh ratio. In contrast, arm length had no effect on attractiveness. The study suggests that long legs may be a reliable signal of good nutrition and health, and adds to the growing evidence that limb variation influences various aspects of human well-being, including mate choice and employment prospects.

site_title: Flush with Nestle cash, Starbucks wants to triple China revenue
summary: Starbucks plans to triple its China revenue by 2022 by opening 600 new stores annually, reaching 6,000 stores on the mainland. CEO Kevin Johnson said this is an ideal time to accelerate growth due to China's long runway of opportunity. The company aims to maintain store quality while expanding, despite the potential to open more locations due to demand.

site_title: Storms slam US Northeast, snarling transport and causing power outages
summary: Powerful storms with high winds, rain, and hail hit the US Northeast, causing widespread power outages and disrupting transport. A severe thunderstorm warning was issued for Maryland to New Hampshire, with nearly 50 reports of hail in several states. Nearly 600,000 customers lost power, and nearly 400 flights were canceled at New York airports. The storms also prompted tornado warnings in Connecticut and New York, but no damage was reported. The National Weather Service warned of flash flooding and severe weather across southern New England and the northern Mid-Atlantic states.

images.alt_text: Powerful storms packing high winds, torrential rain and hail slammed heavily populated parts of the US Northeast on Tuesday, snarling transport and causing widespread power outages in an area home to tens of millions of people.

site_title: Keppel inks deal to sell five existing rigs for US$745m
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) has signed a master agreement to sell five existing jackup rigs to Borr Drilling for approximately US$745 million. The sale price excludes down payments, with Borr Drilling paying US$288 million upfront and the remaining amounts within five years. The rigs are scheduled for delivery from Q4 2019 to Q4 2020, with one rig delivered next year and four in 2020. The deal is seen as a win-win for both parties, allowing Keppel O&M to improve cash flow and Borr Drilling to expand its fleet of jackup rigs.

site_title: Oil eases in late trading on US stockpile concerns
summary: Oil prices rose slightly after retreating from multi-year highs due to concerns about US sanctions on Iran restricting crude exports. Brent crude oil settled at $78.43 a barrel, up 20 cents, while US light crude closed at $71.31 a barrel, up 35 cents. However, prices pulled back after a trade group reported unexpectedly high US crude stockpiles, which rose nearly 5 million barrels. The US is set to impose sanctions on Iran, raising fears of a tightening market and potential shortages later this year.

site_title: Euro stuck near US$1.19 after weaker German growth
summary: The euro remained near four-month lows on Tuesday after weaker-than-expected German economic growth and a rise in US Treasury yields boosted the US dollar. The euro slipped 0.1% to US$1.1919, while the US dollar's index rose 0.2% to 92.764. Weaker-than-expected US inflation numbers halted a US dollar rally, but the greenback's strength was sustained by rising US Treasury yields and easing trade tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Bank Indonesia could raise key rate on Thursday to defend rupiah
summary: Bank Indonesia is set to raise its key interest rate on Thursday to support the rupiah and stabilize domestic markets, according to a majority of economists polled by Reuters. The rate hike is expected to be 25 basis points to 4.5% to defend the rupiah, which has lost over 5% against the dollar since late January. The move aims to address concerns about capital outflows and financial stability, despite Indonesia's inflation target of 2.5-4.5% being met in April.

site_title: Malaysia poll win offers hope: Anwar
summary: Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim hailed his country's election victory as a "golden era" offering hope for democracy, despite cautioning that "one election does not a democracy make." Anwar, who was jailed for sodomy and abuse of power, joined forces with former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad to oust scandal-tainted Prime Minister Najib Razak. Anwar is set to be released and may take over as prime minister in a year, with Mahathir saying he will step down after two years. The historic win marks a shift in power, ending six decades of Barisan Nasional's rule.

images.alt_text: Jailed Malaysian leader Anwar Ibrahim on Wednesday said his country was on the verge of a new "golden era", with the toppling of a corruption-riddled regime offering hope to people "clamouring for freedom" everywhere.

site_title: Sias urges Vard directors to say how they are independent
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) has urged Vard Holdings directors to disclose their independence in relation to a delisting offer from majority shareholder Fincantieri. Sias also called on Fincantieri to increase its delisting offer to minority shareholders, who have expressed concerns over the deal. The investor advocacy group has welcomed a decision by the Singapore Exchange Regulation to require Vard to hold another EGM to correct irregularities in its delisting circular.

site_title: Number of EU workers in UK falls for first time since 2010, employers concerned
summary: The number of European Union nationals working in the UK fell 1.2% to 2.292 million in the first three months of 2018, marking the first decline since 2010. The drop was largely attributed to workers from the eight eastern European countries that joined the EU in 2004, whose numbers decreased by 9.1% over the past year. Meanwhile, the number of Romanians and Bulgarians continued to rise sharply, increasing by 19.8%. This decline may have significant implications for the UK economy, particularly in low-skilled sectors such as food manufacturing and social care.

site_title: Manulife US Reit to raise US$197.2m from 22-for-100 preferential offering
summary: Manulife US Reit has announced a US$197.2 million preferential offering, issuing 228 million new non-renounceable units at US$0.865 per unit, a 7.9% discount to its market price. The deal is underwritten by DBS Bank and CLSA Singapore, and will be used to partially fund two office building acquisitions in the US. About 96.9% of the gross proceeds will be allocated to acquisitions, with the remaining balance used for expenses and working capital, with a books closure date set for May 24.

site_title: Twitter tweak steps up fight against trolls
summary: Twitter is stepping up its fight against online trolls by analyzing "behavioral signals" to identify and mute offenders, even if their tweets don't violate Twitter policy. The new approach considers patterns of user behavior in addition to tweet content. Twitter aims to filter out offensive speech while maintaining an open platform, allowing users to still engage in discussions while minimizing troll activity. This is the latest "safety" initiative by Twitter to address online harassment.

site_title: China's April output grows; investment, domestic demand soften
summary: China's industrial output grew 7% in April, beating expectations, while investment and domestic demand softened due to government tightening. Retail sales grew 9.4% and investment cooled to 7.4% in the first four months of the year. The slowdown in headline investment growth is attributed to weaker public investment and tightened financial regulations. Real estate investment and property sales also eased, with fixed-asset investment growth cooling to 8.4%. Analysts expect the economy to continue losing momentum, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: How can we have trade war when US-China 'trade deficit' is disappearing?
summary: The US-China trade deficit is decreasing, contradicting the notion of a trade war. Despite this, tensions are escalating, driven by income inequality and non-tariff barriers to trade. China's emergence has led to a significant increase in income disparities, with the top 1% of earners in the US doubling their share of national income since the 1950s. To address this, China needs to liberalize its trade policies, and the US and China should engage in reciprocal trade and intellectual property agreements. The US and South Korea have agreed on a new trade agreement, and China has agreed to liberalize its financial sector and increase protection of intellectual property.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: First Resources' Q1 2018 results were lower than expected due to an inventory build-up of 37,000 tonnes of crude palm oil. Despite this, downstream margins reversed into the red at negative 0.6% due to lower selling prices and sales volumes. However, downstream forecasts remain positive, assuming margins of 3-4% going forward. The company's share price closed at S$1.56, with a target price of S$1.75.

site_title: Gas giants swap roles as biggest buyer turns Aussie saviour
summary: Australia is set to become the world's largest exporter of liquefied natural gas, prompting the country to import gas from Japan to ease a domestic supply crunch. Australian Industrial Energy plans to build an import terminal in New South Wales, seeking help from Japan's Jera Co, which is capitalizing on a global oversupply to transform Japan's role from largest buyer to a budding trader. This shift is a reversal of Japan's typical role as a major LNG buyer, and Australia's move is seen as a response to the growing export industry.

site_title: Pulling back the cost curtain of automation
summary: Business leaders focus on reducing operational costs to improve bottom lines, but many lack visibility into their margins. Organising processes and documenting standard operating procedures (SOPs) helps improve service delivery consistency, customer satisfaction, and resource allocation. This leads to more accurate cost estimates and the ability to identify areas of waste and inefficiency. A granular, process-based approach enables businesses to measure inefficiency, identify high performers, and match tasks with the right talent, ultimately laying the foundation for successful automation implementation and increased profitability.

site_title: Family business values - beyond legal structures
summary: A successful family business owner prioritizes values beyond legal structures to ensure a smooth transition from one generation to another. Effective succession planning, including governance structures such as family offices and councils, helps lift the burden from the founding generation. The Princely Family of Liechtenstein, known for transferring wealth over 30 generations, shares their insights on using family governance structures to manage family issues and decision-making. By investing time and patience, families can develop the next generation's skills and values to become successful leaders and owners of family businesses.

site_title: Modigliani sells for US$157.2m in New York
summary: Amedeo Modigliani's painting "Nu couche" sold for US$157.2 million in New York, becoming the fourth most expensive work of art sold at auction. Painted a century ago, the nearly 58-inch-wide masterpiece is the largest painting produced by Modigliani, who reinvented the nude for the modern era. The sale follows Modigliani's ranking as the third highest-selling artist at auction, after Leonardo da Vinci and Pablo Picasso. The painting was acquired in 2003 for US$26.9 million and sold with a buyer's premium, generating a healthy profit for its seller.

site_title: BI could raise key rate on Thursday to defend rupiah
summary: Bank Indonesia is expected to raise its key interest rate on Thursday to support the rupiah and stabilize domestic markets, according to a Reuters poll of 21 economists. The rate is predicted to be hiked by 25 basis points to 4.5% to combat capital outflows and inflation, which has risen to 3.41% in April. The move aims to stabilize the rupiah, which has lost over 5% against the dollar since late January, and mitigate concerns about a widening current account deficit.

site_title: How to be a wise passion investor
summary: Investing in art can be a high-risk, high-reward endeavor. To avoid buying worthless art, follow these tips: don't buy art solely for investment, enlist an unbiased art advisor, and focus on emerging trends and under-valued artists. Avoid brand-name artists, as their works can fluctuate in value, and be cautious of "art investment" companies that promise guaranteed returns. Be patient, hold onto art for at least five years, and build rapport within the art community. Additionally, subscribe to art databases, buy art with a proven secondary market, and carefully evaluate the risks and potential returns before making a purchase.

site_title: Apple supplier Foxconn's Q1 profit dives below estimates
summary: Taiwan's Foxconn, Apple's largest contract electronics maker, reported a 14.5% decline in Q1 net profit to NT$24.08 billion, missing analyst estimates. Shares fell 3% despite a pledge to boost shareholder returns with a US$1.2 billion capital reduction. Analysts attribute the decline to a stronger local dollar and higher marketing costs, which squeezed the company's operating profit margin to 2.4%. Foxconn's CEO Terry Gou has been diversifying the company's business, but investors remain concerned about its reliance on Apple.

site_title: Hong Kong's US$10 billion deals offer punters an IPO for any mood
summary: Hong Kong's China Tower is filing for a $10 billion initial public offering, joining Xiaomi's predicted $10 billion offering. The deals come as investors seek alternative options due to recent slumps in Chinese tech shares. China Tower's IPO has attractive bond-like properties, including low volatility and potential for higher dividends. This follows a busy year for new listings in Hong Kong, with some recent IPOs experiencing significant declines, including China Literature and Razer.

site_title: Vodafone CEO to leave in October after a decade
summary: Vittorio Colao, Vodafone's CEO, will step down in October after a decade at the helm, marking the end of a period of significant change for the company. Colao's departure follows a major purchase of cable assets in Europe and a shift towards a more European-focused strategy. Nick Read, current CFO, will take over as CEO, while Margherita Della Valle will succeed Read as CFO. The move is seen as a smooth transition, with Read bringing a familiar face to the role.

site_title: User Experience: Much sought-after X factor
summary: Businesses can significantly boost growth by investing in user experience (UX) design, which involves creating a pleasurable and engaging experience for customers. This approach has become crucial in the digital economy, where the relationship between a business and its audience occurs solely online. By conducting user research, designers can identify ways to delight users and build a "habit loop" that leads to repeat business. Effective UX design can lead to increased customer satisfaction, positive word-of-mouth, and ultimately, business growth. Companies in the financial services industry, such as fintech startups, are particularly benefiting from UX design, which helps to simplify complex products and services and create a more user-friendly experience.

site_title: Social stratification is starting to become entrenched: Ye Kung
summary: Singapore's Education Minister Ong Ye Kung stated that universal welfare is not the solution to inequality, as it could lead to lower motivation among low-income groups. Instead, the government will continue to provide assistance to the disadvantaged, prioritizing self-reliance over handouts, in order to maintain dignity.

site_title: Curbs on new pre-sales reduced in some Chinese cities
summary: China's local authorities in cities like Shanghai, Hangzhou, and Nanjing have eased restrictions on pre-sales of new apartment buildings, allowing developers to slightly increase prices. This move is expected to boost cash flow and housing supply in top cities, but is unlikely to have a significant nationwide impact. The relaxation of curbs highlights a balance between the central government's efforts to control prices and local authorities' desire to boost revenue through property sales and taxes.

site_title: Margot Kidder, of Lois Lane fame, dies at 69
summary: Margot Kidder, the actress known for her role as Lois Lane in the 1978 film Superman, has died at 69. Kidder appeared in over 130 films and TV shows, including The Amityville Horror, and was diagnosed with bipolar disorder in 1996. She had a long history of involvement with liberal causes and was arrested in 2011 while protesting the Keystone XL Pipeline. Kidder's death was confirmed by her manager, Camilla Fluxman Pines, who did not specify a cause.

site_title: China giants tackle tough Indonesian e-commerce
summary: Chinese tech giants JD.com, Tencent, and Alibaba's Lazada are competing in Indonesia's e-commerce market, which is forecast to grow from $7 billion to $63 billion by 2027. The companies are investing heavily, with Alibaba doubling its investment in Lazada to $4 billion, and opening warehouses across the country to cut costs. Local companies like Blibli are also competing, but experts say Indonesia's e-commerce market is unique and requires adaptation. The market's growth is driven by Indonesia's young population and improving transportation and communications, but logistical costs remain a significant challenge.

site_title: SMEs seeing productivity gains after tech, innovation push
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are seeing productivity gains after adopting over 50 ready-to-go technology solutions through Tech Depot since April 2017. More than 1,300 firms have benefited from these solutions, with an average 25% productivity improvement. The government is encouraging SMEs to collaborate with research institutes like A*Star to enhance business competitiveness and position Singapore as a "global Asia node of technology, innovation and enterprise".

site_title: Noble's red streak continues in Q1
summary: Noble Group reported a net loss of $71.5 million in its first quarter, down from a net loss of $129.3 million in the previous year, due to constraints on liquidity and trade finance. Revenue fell 39% to $1.21 billion, and the company's operating loss was exacerbated by a deeper net loss on supply chain assets. However, a jump in share of profits from joint ventures helped offset the losses, with a $133.8 million increase from the previous year. The company is in the process of restructuring, with a special general meeting scheduled for shareholders to vote on the matter.

site_title: Golden Agri-Resources Q1 net profit down 68%
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a 68% decline in net profit to US$11.9 million for its Q1 2018, down from US$37.6 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 11.3% to US$1.82 billion, mainly due to decreased palm production and CPO prices.

site_title: US: Wall Street closes lower amid renewed inflation worries
summary: Wall Street closed lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 0.78% to 24,706.41, its first loss in nine days. The decline followed a rise in 10-year US Treasury notes above 3% and higher oil prices, eroding investor optimism. The losses affected all sectors, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also edging to fresh records despite tariff concerns.

site_title: SIAEC posts higher Q4 profit on divestment gain
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) reported a net profit of S$55 million for the fourth quarter ended March 31, up 20% year-on-year, driven by a S$14.3 million gain from divesting its 24.5% stake in Asian Compressor Technology Services Company (ACTS) for US$60 million.

site_title: Global markets have come down; what's cheap to buy and where?
summary: Global stock markets have declined for the first time in two years, with the UK and Japan experiencing significant losses. Emerging markets, however, have returned around 40% in US dollar terms since 2016. Valuations are now looking less extended, suggesting a more favorable environment for long-term investors. The US market remains expensive, while Europe appears fairly valued. The UK's high dividend yield has its appeal, but investors should be cautious due to the strain on companies to pay out high dividends. A diversified portfolio, rather than focusing on a single market, is recommended.

site_title: Zeti to announce Malaysia's GST strategy in 100 days
summary: Malaysia's new Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad plans to announce a strategy to remove the goods and services tax (GST) within 100 days. The move is expected to maintain fiscal balance despite cancelling the consumption tax, reintroducing fuel subsidies, and reviewing Chinese investment deals. The outgoing government had set a revenue target of 43.8 billion ringgit, 18% of total revenue. The decision is seen as a response to concerns over the country's fiscal strength following Trump's tariff announcement.

site_title: Tech stocks searching for mojo amid mediocre Q1 earnings
summary: Tech manufacturing services stocks are struggling to regain momentum after mediocre Q1 earnings. Thinner margins, currency volatility, and poor orders visibility are recurring themes, causing shares to fall. Funds are shifting away from the sector, instead focusing on industrials and consumer sectors. Companies like Creative Technology are warning of potential revenue shortfalls and operating losses. The sector's recovery efforts are ongoing, but investors remain cautious amid broader market uncertainty.

site_title: Artificial Intelligence - investing in the future
summary: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is becoming mainstream due to advancements in data, computing power, and algorithms. AI enables machines to simulate human intelligence, performing tasks like visual perception, decision-making, and translation. It has profound implications across sectors, including healthcare, finance, and education. Global GDP is estimated to increase by 14% in 2030, driven by AI adoption, resulting in a $15 trillion boost. AI is a disruptive technology with far-reaching consequences, transforming various aspects of life and industries.

site_title: SIA Engg board chairman to retire
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) board chairman Stephen Lee Ching Yen will retire at the end of July 2018, after a 13-year tenure. He will be succeeded by deputy chairman Tang Kin Fei. Lee expressed gratitude to board members and staff, but will remain a special adviser to the board for its transformation project. Tang thanked Lee for his exceptional leadership and valued contributions to the company.

site_title: Key themes when investing in Chinese equities in 2018
summary: Chinese equities are expected to perform well in 2018, driven by growth in new economy sectors such as IT/e-commerce, healthcare, and consumer staples. Despite a slowdown in traditional economy sectors like infrastructure and real estate, the government's efforts to reduce debt and promote financial de-leveraging are expected to support banks and large corporations. Key sectors to watch include IT/e-commerce, banks, healthcare, insurance, and consumer staples, while the property sector is expected to remain neutral.

site_title: 70% of apartments released in New Futura Phase 2 sold
summary: Luxe Leonie Hill condo, New Futura, has seen 21 of 30 units released in its North Tower sold at an average S$3,500 per square foot, with a majority of buyers being permanent residents and foreigners. The South Tower has also seen robust demand, with 62 of 64 apartments sold at an average S$3,350 per square foot. The majority of buyers are from Asia, with 72% being foreigners and permanent residents.

site_title: A closer walk with philanthropy today
summary: Philanthropy has evolved, shifting from spontaneous charity-giving to a more purpose-driven approach, leveraging successful business models to address global challenges. Impact investment, venture philanthropy, and strategic philanthropy are new forms of philanthropy that require risk-taking, strategy, and commitment. These approaches involve philanthropists actively investing in businesses or organizations to generate income, with the returns going to charity. The article highlights the importance of transparency, accountability, and long-lasting outcomes in sustainable development. To achieve transformational impact, governments and individuals must work together, aligning their interests and promoting philanthropic accountability, data collection, and community engagement.

site_title: Zeti to announce Malaysia's GST strategy in 100 days
summary: Malaysia's new Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has vowed to cancel the goods and services tax (GST) within 100 days, with senior adviser Zeti Akhthar Aziz assuring investors that fiscal balance can be maintained. The government plans to collect 43.8 billion ringgit in 2018, but Zeti said fiscal deficit will improve by controlling expenditure, re-prioritizing projects, and reducing public sector wastage. The move has been met with positive reactions from Malaysian markets, with the stock market up 0.4% and the ringgit stronger.

site_title: US bond market may be signalling negative growth
summary: The US bond market may be signaling negative economic growth, despite the economy being in its ninth year of expansion. The gap between short-term and long-term interest rates has narrowed, a phenomenon known as flattening, which can be a warning sign of a recession. Investors are not expecting sustained growth of 3% and are not looking for inflation to break out. While most economists agree that a recession is not imminent, the flattening yield curve suggests that the economy may be weaker than it appears, with some experts warning of a potential downturn in the future.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singapore Medical Group reported a net profit of S$3.42 million for its first quarter, more than double the previous year's S$1.43 million. Banyan Tree Holdings posted a 17-fold increase in net profit to S$20.2 million. Cosco Shipping International reported a fiscal first-quarter profit of S$2.83 million, reversing a previous quarter's loss. ESR Cayman Limited received a US$306 million investment from JD.com, creating an alliance for logistics services. Fragrance Group's first quarter net profit rose 57.7% to S$8.5 million, while UOB-Kay Hian Holdings' net profit jumped 30.3% to S$25.7 million.

site_title: What Walmart-Flipkart deal could mean for e-commerce in India
summary: Walmart has acquired a 77% stake in Flipkart, India's largest online retail platform, for $16 billion. The deal gives Walmart access to over 1 million Flipkart customers and positions it as a major player in India's e-commerce market. The acquisition marks a significant shift in the competitive landscape of India's e-commerce industry, with Walmart competing directly with Amazon, which had also been eyeing Flipkart. The deal is seen as a strategic move by Walmart to expand its presence in India's retail market, which has been challenging for the company.

images.alt_text: Flipkart (above, its online services HQ in Bengaluru) started out in 2008, selling just books. Its buyout by Walmart gives the US retail giant access to more than a million of its customers and casts Walmart as a key player in India's e-commerce.

site_title: Earnings at Allianz's asset management unit soar on increased inflows
summary: Allianz's asset management unit saw a 16.3% increase in operating profit in the first quarter, driven by increased inflows of 21 billion euros. This is the second consecutive year of strong inflows, following 150 billion euros last year. The rise in inflows is attributed to customer confidence and the ability of active managers to profit from market volatility. Meanwhile, the insurance side of Allianz reported strong internal growth of 4.9% in the first quarter, driven by increased demand for property and casualty policies following natural disasters in the US and California.

site_title: Have Chatbot, will serve
summary: HHWT, an online platform for Muslim travelers, has introduced a chatbot named Sofia, powered by the Azure Bot Service, to help users find halal-friendly options, prayer spaces, and accommodations. Sofia was created to address the high volume of customer inquiries, which were previously handled by email. The chatbot has a success rate of 85% and serves up to 8,000 users a day, providing users with information in a native, conversational format. Sofia's custom machine learning algorithm allows her to learn from interactions and improve her answers over time, enabling HHWT to better serve its customers and potentially expand into a marketplace in the future.

site_title: A post-Korea summit poser: Will US remain in East Asia?
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to meet with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un on June 12, following the release of three American citizens held by North Korea. However, officials caution that a swift resolution to the issues dividing the two sides is unlikely, particularly regarding the "denuclearisation" of the Korean Peninsula. The recent summit between Kim and South Korean President Moon Jae In has created a sense of an historic turning point, with the possibility of a peace agreement and reunification of the Korean Peninsula after a 70-year break-up.

site_title: Singapore market slides, in line with region
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index slid 22.23 points or 0.62% to 3,540.23, its second straight session of losses. This follows the region's worst performance, led by the Jakarta Composite Index, which sank 1.8% and is down 8.1% for the year. Stocks with Indonesia-sourced revenues or assets suffered, including First Resources, Bumitama Agri, and Sinarmas Land. Investors are cautious due to concerns over rising rates, Middle East tensions, and trade frictions, with Bank of Singapore's head of investment strategy citing a risk-off mood in the bond market.

site_title: Botswana President wants more jobs for Africans in new deal with De Beers
summary: Botswana President Mokgweetsi Masisi is seeking a new long-term diamond sales pact with De Beers, which will expire in 2020. He wants more jobs created in the industry and for diamonds to be processed locally. The deal is crucial for Botswana, which relies on diamonds for almost a fifth of its GDP, and De Beers, which gets about two-thirds of its gems from the southern African nation. Masisi aims to create skilled jobs and diversify the economy, while De Beers' Indian billionaire Anil Agarwal has expressed interest in investing more in Africa.

site_title: SIA could surprise with stronger-than-expected results
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is expected to surprise with stronger-than-expected results in its fourth quarter and full-year earnings, driven by a rebound in the cargo sector and its budget unit Scoot. Analysts estimate a full-year net profit of S$666-780 million, with some predicting a higher profit of S$765 million. A final dividend of 17 Singapore cents per share could materialise, up from 11 cents previously. However, sharply climbing fuel prices and interest rates could act as headwinds, with the airline group having put in place fuel hedges to cushion the impact.

site_title: How wealthy S'poreans are preparing to live to 100
summary: Wealthy Singaporeans expect to live to 100, despite the country's average life expectancy of 83.1 years. A UBS survey of nearly 5,000 millionaires found that 415 believed they could live to 100, with 92% prioritizing health investments over wealth growth. Many plan to allocate 30% of their wealth to healthcare costs and are willing to sacrifice wealth for better health. The survey also revealed that many wealthy Singaporeans are taking steps to maintain a healthy work-life balance and are planning to adjust their investment and retirement plans to accommodate longer lifespans.

images.alt_text: Masazo Nonaka of Japan, aged 112, receiving a certificate for the Guinness World Records' oldest male person living title on April 10. According to WHO, Singapore is second in the world in terms of healthy life expectancy at 73.9 years. Japan is top at 74.9 years.
Hartmut Issel

site_title: Retail sales gain points to healthier Q2
summary: US retail sales rose 0.3% in April, matching the median forecast, driven by bigger after-tax pay cheques that compensated for rising fuel costs. This marks the second consecutive month of sales growth, suggesting a strong start to Q2. The 0.3% increase follows a 0.8% advance in March, which was stronger than initially reported.

site_title: Saxo Bank unfazed by fintech shake-up as it thrives on tech
summary: Saxo Bank, a Danish investment bank, remains unaffected by the fintech industry's changes, focusing on technology to drive growth. The bank has expanded its Hong Kong office and appointed a new Greater China CEO, solidifying its presence in the region. Following its success in introducing forex trading platforms in 1998, Saxo Bank aims to continue its expansion in China, leveraging technology to thrive in the market.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda shifts into lower gear on stimulus policy
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda has shifted his focus to incremental policy shifts, moving away from the "shock and awe" stimulus approach of his predecessor Masaaki Shirakawa. Policymakers are brainstorming ways to raise bond yields from near-zero levels as a first step towards ending crisis-mode policy. The move aims to address the pain prolonged easing is inflicting on banks' profits and give the Bank of Japan more flexibility on monetary policy. Normalisation will be gradual, with nuanced signals to avoid disrupting markets, and is seen as a step towards achieving the 2% inflation target.

site_title: DBS banking on platforms instead of pipelines
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, is shifting its focus from traditional pipelines to embedding its services in "ecosystems" and partnering with retail marketplaces. The bank launched a S$30 million branding campaign with a "live more, bank less" approach and has invested in retail marketplace Carousell, raising US$85 million in total. CEO Piyush Gupta believes the future of banking lies in this ecosystem approach, rather than the traditional pipeline business.

site_title: A relook at alternative investments
summary: HSBC advises investors to consider alternative investments to manage risk in volatile markets, despite misconceptions surrounding their purpose and performance. Effective alternative investments can reduce risk and drive higher returns, but require careful selection of a manager and fund. Hedge funds, private equity, and private credit can offer benefits, but often come with long-term lock-up periods and higher risk. Investors should weigh the trade-offs and consider their individual circumstances before making a decision.

site_title: Fraud-hit PNB suffers biggest ever quarterly loss for an Indian bank
