summary: Hong Leong Asia reported a net loss of S$5.5 million for the first quarter, an improvement from S$9.9 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 9.2% to S$1.02 billion, mainly due to declines in its Diesel Engines Unit and consumer products unit. Despite this, the company's net asset value per share edged up to 165.13 Singapore cents. Hong Leong Asia shares finished 5.2% up at S$1.02 on Friday.

site_title: UOL Group's Q1 profit dips 8%
summary: UOL Group's Q1 profit fell 8% to S$73.82 million, primarily due to amortisation and depreciation of fair value uplifts. Revenue surged 89% to S$661 million, driven by higher contributions from its core business segments. The company's interest in UIC rose to 49.85% and its marketing and distribution expenses increased 34%. UOL expects the hospitality sector in Asia-Pacific to benefit from the improving global economic outlook, with its freehold project Amber45 launching this weekend.

site_title: Auditors uncover possible misappropriation of funds at China Environment subsidiary
summary: Auditors at China Environment subsidiary Anhui Dongyuan Environmental Protection Co have uncovered possible misappropriation of rental income monies. The company requested management hand over company seals, but they refused, escorting Singapore management off the premises. The issue is being resolved, but the incident highlights potential financial irregularities within the company.

site_title: Hyphens Pharma prices Catalist IPO at S$0.26 a share to raise S$13.5m
summary: Hyphens Pharma International priced its Catalist IPO at S$0.26 per share, raising S$13.5 million in net proceeds. The company is offering 29.6 million shares, with a public offer comprising 3 million shares opening on Friday and closing next Wednesday. Trading is expected to commence the following Friday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore retail sales dropped 1.5% in March due to a slump in car sales, reversing the 8.6% gain in February. Former Genting Singapore VP Kunye Tagi admitted to insider trading and paid a civil penalty of S$50,000. Malaysia's king agreed to pardon jailed opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim. The Straits Times Index rose 0.9% to 3,570.17, driven by a US stock rally.

images.alt_text: Sales of apparel and footwear, medical goods and toiletries, and department stores industries also saw increases of between 2.7 per cent and 6.8 per cent.

site_title: Record-breaking US$646.1m sales at Rockefeller auction
summary: Christie's auction of Peggy and David Rockefeller's art collection in New York has achieved record-breaking sales, surpassing the low estimate of US$484 million with a total of US$646.1 million. All 44 lots sold, with notable sales including a 1905 Pablo Picasso painting for US$115 million, a Venetian landscape by Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot for US$9 million, and a Claude Monet painting for US$84.7 million. The sale exceeded expectations, with many artworks setting new artist records, and the proceeds will benefit 12 institutions selected by the Rockefellers.

site_title: UMS Holdings Q1 net profit inches up 2% to S$11.4 million
summary: UMS Holdings reported a Q1 net profit of S$11.4 million, a 2% increase from the same period last year. Revenue decreased by 10% to S$37.5 million, with a 9% decline in revenue from its semiconductor business.

site_title: 1MDB bonds take a hit as Malaysia vote puts focus on future
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB fund came under pressure in the bond market after the nation's landmark election ousted Prime Minister Najib Razak, who faced public anger over a money laundering scandal. The fund's dollar bonds due 2023 fell to 80 cents on the dollar after a 11.7 cent slide following the election. New Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said he would recover most funds and that Najib would face consequences if found guilty. The fund's future is uncertain, with speculation growing that its closure could be more certain than previously thought.

site_title: CityNeon Q1 net profit up 80.4% to S$4m
summary: CityNeon Holdings reported a 80.4% increase in net profit to S$4m in Q1 2018, driven by a 38.4% rise in revenue to S$23.5m. The increase in revenue was mainly attributed to its intellectual properties experience (IPE) segment, which contributed 62.2% of the company's topline. Earnings per share increased to 1.6 Singapore cents, and net asset value per share rose to 25.8 Singapore cents. CityNeon shares ended 2.9% higher at S$1.07 on the day of the announcement.

site_title: Peak Court sold en bloc for S$118.88 million
summary: Peak Court, a 35-year-old freehold residential site at Thomson Road, has been sold en bloc for S$118.88 million to Rich Capital Holdings and Tuan Sing Holdings. The site can be redeveloped into 106 units of one, two and three-bedroom apartments. Rich Capital will hold 30% and Tuan Sing 70% of the stake. The acquisition marks Rich Capital's maiden foray into the Singapore residential property sector. The redevelopment is expected to be funded through a combination of internal resources and bank borrowings.

site_title: China April new loans rise to 1.18t yuan
summary: China's banks extended 1.18 trillion yuan (S$248.7 billion) in net new loans in April, slightly higher than expected, as policymakers aim to support the economy amid US trade threats. The first four months of the year saw a 13.5% increase in new loans to 6.04 trillion yuan. Corporate loans rose to 572.6 billion yuan, while household loans, mostly mortgages, fell to 528.4 billion yuan. Despite a stronger-than-expected first quarter growth, analysts expect China's economic growth to slow to around 6.5% this year due to rising borrowing costs and trade tensions.

site_title: Cordlife Group reports Q3 net profit of S$843,000 on new HK unit, better margins
summary: Cordlife Group, a private cord blood bank, reported a net profit of S$843,000 in Q3 2018, reversing a net loss of S$401,000 in the same period last year. Revenue grew 24.5% to S$17.71 million, driven by a newly acquired Hong Kong unit, Healthbaby Biotech. The group expects to report a full-year net profit for 2018, barring unforeseen circumstances. Cordlife plans to grow its non-invasive diagnostics services and explore acquisition opportunities, citing a growing market for stem cell banking in Asia.

site_title: Mewah posts Q1 profit increase of 22% to S$4.8m
summary: Mewah International reported a 22.2% increase in net profit to S$4.85 million in Q1, driven by a 15% increase in revenue to US$836.9 million. The bulk segment saw a 20.9% revenue increase, while the consumer pack segment recorded a 1.9% increase. Net asset value per share edged up to 35.3 Singapore cents. The company's shares finished unchanged at S$0.27.

site_title: Silver Lake agrees to buy property portal ZPG for £2.2b
summary: Silver Lake agreed to buy UK property platform ZPG Plc for £2.2 billion, with ZPG shareholders receiving 490 pence in cash per share. The deal has secured support from Daily Mail & General Trust Plc, the largest shareholder, with over 30% of ZPG shareholders backing the bid. The acquisition aims to grow Silver Lake's presence in the UK real-estate market, following previous deals with EDR and Money.co.uk. Shares in ZPG jumped 30% following the announcement.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks jump as high-tech shares rally
summary: Tokyo stocks surged on Friday, led by a 1.16% gain in the Nikkei 225 index, with high-tech shares driving the rally. US shares in the sector rose overnight, and investors are optimistic about corporate results season, which is nearing its end. Despite concerns over geopolitical risks, including the US embassy move to Jerusalem, the market is buoyed by strong performances in semiconductor equipment and industrial robot makers.

site_title: China again flies bombers around Taiwan
summary: China conducted encirclement drills around Taiwan with H-6K bombers and Su-35 fighter jets, escalating tensions between the two. This is the latest in a series of frequent military exercises, designed to deter Taiwan's potential independence. China claims Taiwan as its sacred territory and has been modernizing its armed forces, including stealth fighters and advanced missiles. The balance of power has shifted decisively in China's favor, with military experts warning Taiwan could be overwhelmed unless US forces intervene. This move has rattled nerves in the region and Washington.

site_title: Europe: Shares head for longest winning streak in three years
summary: European stocks are set for their longest winning streak in over three years, with the STOXX 600 index up 0.1% and on track for a seventh straight week of gains. M&A news drove early trading, with shares in Sika and Daily Mail and General Trust rising 11% and 9% respectively. The deal-making momentum is expected to continue as fresh earnings season comes to a close.

images.alt_text: European stocks edged higher in early trading on Friday, set to seal their longest winning streak in over three years as fresh deal-making stole the spotlight from the tail-end of a busy earnings season.

site_title: Barclays CEO fined £642,430 over whistleblower affair
summary: British regulators have fined Barclays CEO Jes Staley £642,430 for breaching rules by trying to uncover a whistleblower. Staley accepted the fines from the Financial Conduct Authority and the Bank of England's Prudential Regulation Authority, which amount to 10% of his annual salary, bonus, and pension. The incident occurred in 2016, after an anonymous letter raised concerns about a senior employee. Barclays confirmed it would also reduce Staley's compensation by £500,000, following a year-long investigation.

site_title: Wee Hur posts Q1 profit of S$11.1m, up 3.5 times
summary: Wee Hur Holdings reported a Q1 profit of S$11.1 million, a 3.5-fold increase from the previous year. Revenue grew almost five-fold to S$159.6 million, driven by the recognition of revenue from its industrial development property, Mega@Woodlands. Despite a foreign exchange loss, the company's net asset value per share edged up to 0.39 Singapore cent. Wee Hur shares rose 2.2% to S$0.23 following the announcement.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end week with five straight gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.02% on Friday, marking the fifth consecutive day of gains, as investors tracked a positive lead from Wall Street following a soft inflation reading. The Hang Seng Index closed at 31,122.06. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.35% and the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 1.02%. The gains were attributed to investor confidence in the US economy despite concerns about rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks clocked up five straight days of gains on Friday as investors tracked another positive lead from Wall Street after a soft inflation reading soothed concerns about rising US interest rates.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open up, head for fifth straight gain
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for the fifth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 1.11% to 31,151.80. The gains were attributed to a positive lead from Wall Street, with investors tracking the market's performance. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, adding 0.17% and 0.10% respectively. The market's rally is seen as a result of investors' confidence despite recent US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: 1MDB bonds take a hit as Najib's ouster puts focus on future
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB state-owned investment fund faced pressure in the bond market after the nation's landmark election ousted Prime Minister Najib Razak, who faced public anger over a money laundering scandal. The fund's dollar bonds due 2023 fell to about 80 cents on the dollar, a 11.7 cent slide, amid speculation its closure could be more certain. New Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad vowed to recover funds and hold Najib accountable if wrongdoing is found. The fund's future is uncertain, with more investigations likely to come to light under Mahathir's leadership.

site_title: China's President Xi Jinping may also travel to Singapore when Trump meets Kim: report
summary: China's President Xi Jinping may attend a summit in Singapore alongside US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, according to a Japanese newspaper report. The meeting is scheduled for June 12 in Singapore, where Trump and Kim will discuss denuclearization. A senior US negotiator stated that there's a possibility of a third country leader, likely Xi, joining the summit. This would be the first time leaders of the three signatories to the 1953 armistice would meet in the same country.

site_title: Law Ministry invites proposals to pilot business models for moneylending
summary: The Ministry of Law in Singapore has invited proposals to pilot business models for moneylending, aiming to better protect borrowers. Proposals must meet specific criteria, including higher standards than current legal requirements, and be submitted by companies with at least S$1 million paid-up capital. The pilot, expected to begin in 2019, will assess proposals based on credit policies and cost of credit. Successful applicants may be granted licenses to implement their models in up to four locations for up to two years.

site_title: Former Midas Holdings CEO claims S$3.3 million in unpaid salaries, loans
summary: Former Midas Holdings CEO Patrick Chew Hwa Kwang claims the company owes him S$3.3 million in unpaid salaries, allowances, and loans. Chew alleges the company's conduct forced him to resign, with no payment received from December 2017 until his resignation in March 2018. Chew also lent the company S$2.9 million in November 2017, which remains unpaid. Midas Holdings is studying the claim and will respond in due time.

site_title: Former Genting Singapore VP admits to insider trading
summary: Genting Singapore's former vice president of finance, Kunye Tagi, admitted to insider trading and paid a S$50,000 civil penalty to the Monetary Authority of Singapore without a court action. Tagi sold 175,000 shares on April 14 and 24, 2015, using non-public price-sensitive information about the company's financial results. The sale avoided a potential loss of S$13,625, and the MAS agreed to the penalty under the Securities and Futures Act.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won edge up on weaker-than-expected US inflation
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index and the won rose on softer-than-expected US inflation, with the KOSPI up 13.53 points or 0.55% at 2,477.69. The won gained 0.7% for the week, its largest weekly gain in three weeks. US stocks also rose, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific index up 0.78%. The won was quoted at 1,069.3 per dollar, while the KOSPI's current price-to-earnings ratio is 12.10. Foreigners were net buyers of 200,246 million won worth of shares.

site_title: Worked to the bone: South Korea's elderly
summary: South Korea's elderly are forced to work past retirement age due to weak social safety nets. Over 45% of elderly South Koreans live in poverty, with many unable to access pension benefits. Park Jae Yeol, a 71-year-old, works three days a week as a deliveryman to make ends meet, earning about $500 a month. The country's rapidly aging population, dubbed the "silver tsunami," is expected to make up 25% of the population by 2030. South Korea's pension system is inadequate, with many missing out on benefits, leaving them to rely on low welfare payments.

site_title: Australian shares rise for 6th straight week; NZ at record high
summary: Australian shares rose for the sixth consecutive week, closing 0.9% higher, despite a flat finish on Friday. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 6,116.2, driven by gains in materials and consumer discretionary stocks, including BHP and Rio Tinto. In contrast, financial stocks and AMP Ltd weighed on the index. New Zealand shares reached a record high, gaining 1.5% for the week, led by healthcare stocks.

site_title: 5-year project to upgrade MRT power supply may require train service hours to be shortened: Khaw
summary: Singapore's 5-year project to upgrade the North-South and East-West Lines' power supply system may require shortened train service hours, costing nearly S$900 million. Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan said the upgrade will boost reliability, but may inconvenience commuters. The project, which started later this year, aims to replace aging assets and install a new power system that can handle increased train frequencies. Full-day tests during passenger service have been smooth, and daily tests are planned for the June school holidays.

site_title: Why Singapore for the Trump-Kim summit?
summary: US President Donald Trump confirmed a historic first meeting between the US and North Korean leaders will take place in Singapore on June 12. Singapore was chosen for the summit due to its unique location bridging the East and West, modern infrastructure, and security. Trump described the meeting as a "very special moment for World Peace." The summit marks a significant moment in the unpredictable relationship between the US and North Korea, with Trump expressing optimism for a positive outcome.

site_title: Nestle falls behind as millennials warm up to frozen meals
summary: Nestle's frozen food business is struggling to meet demand from young, health-conscious adults, resulting in lost market share to rivals. Despite revamping its menu with healthier options, the company's supply chain wasn't ready to meet the surge in demand, leading to a missed opportunity. Frozen food sales rose 1.4% in the US last year, driven by young adults, but Nestle's volumes declined 5% in January. The company is increasing capacity and adding new lines to catch up, but investors question its ability to compete with high-growth businesses.

site_title: Malaysia timber company Jawala lodges preliminary documents for Catalist IPO
summary: Malaysia-based timber company Jawala has lodged a preliminary prospectus for a planned initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board. The IPO aims to raise funds for developing the company's 11,043-hectare plantation site and working capital. Jawala posted a net profit of RM1.7 million in 2017, with plans to pay out at least 20% of profit as dividends to shareholders. Terms for the IPO, including pricing and timing, have yet to be set. UOB Kay Hian is the sponsor and issue manager for the deal.

site_title: New compulsory training and proficiency test for corporate service providers, starting Nov 15
summary: Singapore's Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) will require corporate service providers to complete a mandatory training and proficiency test starting November 15, 2018. The test aims to boost professional standards and combat illicit activities like money laundering and terrorism financing. Existing providers have until April 2019 to complete the training, while new applicants will need to pass the test to register as filing agents. ACRA will also publish the names of suspended or cancelled providers due to severe breaches.

site_title: Malaysia elections: PM-in-waiting Anwar watches Mahathir swearing in from hospital
summary: Malaysia's Mahathir Mohamad was sworn in as the country's 7th prime minister after Pakatan Harapan's coalition won a majority of parliamentary seats in the general election. Anwar Ibrahim, the jailed leader of Parti Keadilan Rakyat, watched the ceremony from his hospital bed, where he is recovering from surgery. Anwar is expected to become prime minister after Mahathir's term, but is currently disqualified from running for office for five years due to his conviction. Mahathir will hand over the post to Anwar after his release and royal pardon.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon trading at 3,561.69; up 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Friday, with the Straits Times Index advancing 24.1 points, 0.7% up to 3,561.69. Gainers outnumbered losers 199 to 119, with Genting Singapore rising 7.76% and UOB increasing 1.83%. About 994.1 million shares worth S$649.5 million changed hands.

site_title: Singapore retail sales drop 1.5% in March, driven down by slump in car sales
summary: Singapore's retail sales dropped 1.5% in March from a year ago, primarily due to a slump in car sales. Excluding motor vehicles, sales rose 2.6%, driven by growth in department stores, food retailers, and medical goods. Auto sales fell 16.1% year-on-year, while other sectors experienced higher sales growth, except for computer and telecommunications equipment, which declined 8.0%.

site_title: Indonesia central bank says rupiah's level is not reflecting fundamentals
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor Agus Martowardojo stated that the current rupiah exchange rate does not reflect fundamentals and that Bank Indonesia has room to adjust its benchmark policy rate to support the currency. The rupiah strengthened to 14,045 per dollar after the statement, which was seen as a signal that the central bank may lower its key rate. Martowardojo reiterated that the central bank has ample room to adjust its policy rate to ensure stability and sustainability.

site_title: SPH appoints chief technology officer, chief product officer to drive digital media push
summary: SPH appoints Glen Gary Francis as Chief Technology Officer (CTO) and Gaurav Sachdeva as Chief Product Officer (CPO) to drive its digital media push. Francis, with over 20 years of IT experience, will oversee digital capabilities and take over the IT division on August 1. Sachdeva, with 14 years of experience in technology companies, will work with Francis' technology team to develop digital media content and products. The appointments aim to enhance SPH's digital offerings and stay ahead of new technologies and changing needs.

site_title: Philippines' govt sees popularity dip on inflation worries
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's government saw a decline in public satisfaction ratings, with an overall "very good" net satisfaction rating of +58% in the first quarter, down from +70 in December. The drop was largely attributed to low scores on fighting inflation, which reached its highest level in five years. Despite this, the administration received high marks for handling disasters, with 95% of respondents satisfied with its response. The decline in trust ratings mirrors a similar drop in Duterte's personal trust rating.

site_title: Four Singapore startups complete Telstra-backed accelerator programme
summary: Four Singapore startups, CarePod, Idem Hospitality, KNOW, and Vybes, have completed a six-month accelerator program backed by Telstra. The program, part of the third cohort, has seen the startups collectively secure over 100,000 customers, generate S$500,000 in revenue, and raise S$2 million in funding. Each startup received S$75,000 in funding, mentorship, and training, and will continue to foster innovation and entrepreneurism in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Triggers that could end Hong Kong's property boom
summary: Hong Kong's property market is bracing for a potential increase in the prime rate, which could dampen surging housing prices. The city's major banks have held the prime rate at 5% since November 2008, but rising US rates are putting pressure on banks to raise. Analysts predict the next Fed increase could trigger a prime rate hike, potentially ending the bull run on house prices. If the prime rate increases, it could lead to a 15% correction in 2019-2020, according to Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

site_title: Asia: Markets on course to end positive week on a high note
summary: Asian markets are poised to close the week on a high note, driven by a US inflation rate lower than expected, which has dampened expectations for interest rate hikes. The news of a planned US-North Korea summit in June also lifted optimism for peace on the Korean peninsula. Despite ongoing geopolitical tensions, traders are focusing on the potential for cheaper borrowing. The US stock market has also reached new records, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh highs.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks rise, won edges up on soft US inflation
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 14.34 points or 0.58% to 2,478.50, driven by a stronger Korean won against the dollar following weaker-than-expected US inflation. Jin Air Co Ltd rose 9.3% after its co-CEO stepped down amid allegations of bad behavior by his daughter. The US inflation data sparked a retreat in the dollar, contributing to the won's gain.

site_title: Scion of Resources Prima chairman resigns as director for new job
summary: Scion of Resources Prima Group, Gabriel Giovani Sugiono, has resigned as executive director, effective May 31, for another job. He previously held the position since 2014, overseeing investor relations and other key areas. SAC Capital, Resources Prima's sponsor, found no material reasons for his resignation after interviewing him.

site_title: The challenge of space gardening: One giant 'leaf' for mankind
summary: NASA aims to develop space gardening skills for future long-duration missions to the Moon and Mars. The challenges of growing plants in space include seeds floating away, water globs forming, and artificial lighting and fans needing precise replication of Earth's conditions. Despite these difficulties, NASA believes gardening in space will be crucial for sustaining explorers on extended missions, providing a vital source of food and oxygen.

images.alt_text: Using trays rigged with lights that mimic the grow boxes used in space, students must tend to the plants and record data on their progress, which eventually gets shared with NASA.

site_title: Hollywood glitters as 'Star Wars' stages 'Solo' premiere
summary: Hollywood celebrated the premiere of "Solo: A Star Wars Story" on May 11, 2018, with a star-studded event. The film, directed by Ron Howard, tells the coming-of-age story of Han Solo before he became a galaxy's most beloved scoundrel. The movie features an ensemble cast, including Alden Ehrenreich, Woody Harrelson, and Donald Glover, and has been hyped with a sneak peek of a pivotal scene. With a predicted opening weekend domestic box office of around $137 million, the film is expected to bring excitement to fans, despite a bumpy production journey.

site_title: Malaysia king agrees to pardon Anwar immediately: Mahathir
summary: Malaysia's King has agreed to immediately pardon jailed opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim, according to newly installed Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. Anwar, who was jailed on charges of sodomy and abuse of power, was sworn in as a member of the new government. Mahathir has promised to hand the premiership to Anwar, his former nemesis turned ally, and a full pardon will be issued upon Anwar's release. This marks a remarkable reconciliation between Mahathir and Anwar, who had a dramatic falling out in 1998.

site_title: News Corp reports loss on writedowns, weakness in newspapers
summary: News Corp reported a loss of $1.1 billion in the fiscal third quarter, primarily due to a writedown in the value of its Australian television operations and declines in print advertising revenues. Despite a 6% increase in overall revenues to $2.1 billion, the newspaper operations saw mixed results, with revenue growth at The Wall Street Journal offset by a 3% decline in ad revenues. Digital subscriber gains were reported, with 1.49 million digital subscribers at The Wall Street Journal by the end of March.

site_title: Absence of impairment charge sends SingPost to S$24m Q4 profit; to pay 2 S cent dividend
summary: SingPost reported a Q4 profit of S$23.95 million, driven by 13.5% revenue growth in its e-commerce and logistics segments. The absence of impairment charges in Q4 compared to the previous year's S$208.6 million loss allowed for the profit. The company's full-year revenue reached S$1.46 billion, with a final dividend of 2 cents per share recommended. The postal segment's revenue rose 18.2% in Q4, while domestic mail revenue declined 6.6% for the full year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singapore Post, ST Engineering, Vard Holdings, Dasin Retail Trust
summary: Singapore Post swung back into the black in Q4 2018 with a profit of S$23.95 million, driven by 13.5% revenue growth in e-commerce activities. ST Engineering posted an 18% rise in Q1 profit to S$117.7 million. Vard Holdings clarified an error in its financial report, stating it wouldn't have changed the adviser's opinion. Dasin Retail Trust announced a 23% increase in distribution per unit to 1.83 cents, driven by 86% growth in net property income.

site_title: Hot stock: Genting Singapore up 7.8% on positive results, earnings prospects
summary: Genting Singapore's stock surged 7.8% to S$1.25 following the release of its positive first-quarter earnings, with a 3.3% increase in net profit and 15.1% growth in revenue. The casino operator also reported higher VIP gross gaming revenue and lower receivables impairment. Analysts reiterated their "buy" calls, citing growth prospects and a duopoly market, with targets ranging from S$1.40 to S$1.52. Genting expects to bid for a Japan gaming license when regulations fall in place.

site_title: China plans central custody accounts for payment platforms to trim risks: state media
summary: China plans to implement centralised custody accounts for funds from its payment platforms, aiming to reduce financial risks. The People's Bank of China has raised the reserve funds ratio to 50% and is considering a 100% reserve rate. The central bank is planning a trial with 26 payment platforms, where all user funds would be deposited in a centralised account. This move is part of a broader effort to regulate the rapidly growing payment sector, which is backed by tech giants such as Alibaba and Tencent.

site_title: White House cancels Nasa programme on greenhouse gas: report
summary: The White House has canceled a $10-million-per-year NASA program tracking greenhouse gases, citing budget constraints and higher priorities. The Carbon Monitoring System, which monitored carbon and methane emissions, was quietly killed by President Donald Trump's administration. Existing grants will be allowed to finish, but no new research will be supported. The move is seen as part of a broader attack on climate science and jeopardizes efforts to verify national emission cuts agreed to in the Paris climate deal.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by gains on Wall Street despite concerns over US geopolitical risk. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.24% to 22,551.88, while the Topix index gained 0.24% to 1,781.89. This follows a strong performance on US stocks, which edged towards fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: New Zealand manufacturing activity jumps in April: BNZ survey
summary: New Zealand's manufacturing activity surged in April, with the Bank of New Zealand-Business NZ's seasonally adjusted Performance of Manufacturing Index (PMI) reaching 58.9, the largest two-year jump. This marks a reversal of recent slowdowns and indicates an expansion in activity. A reading above 50 signifies growth, while below 50 indicates contraction.

site_title: Singapore shares recover on Friday; STI up 0.49%
summary: Singapore stocks recovered on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.49% or 17.37 points to 3,554.96. The recovery followed a retreat on Thursday in response to Malaysian election results. The STI gained 17.37 points, with gainers outnumbering losers 102 to 39. Stocks such as Genting Singapore, Singapore Post, and Spackman Entertainment were among the most active, with Genting Singapore rising 7.8% and Singapore Post reporting a quarterly profit of S$23.95 million.

site_title: Trump-Kim summit in Singapore a significant step on the path to peace: PM Lee
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korea leader Kim Jong Un will meet in Singapore on June 12, marking a significant step towards peace, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The summit, set to discuss North Korea's nuclear development, will be the first between a sitting US president and a North Korean leader, with Singapore chosen for its neutrality and security. Experts suggest possible locations in Shangri-La Hotel, Marina Bay Sands, and Sentosa, with the event aiming to advance prospects for peace in the Korean Peninsula.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a 13.9% year-on-year increase in net profit, beating expectations. Despite volatile oil prices, analysts remain optimistic about CAO's 2018 performance, citing strong fundamentals and a China civil aviation boom. Fraser and Neave upgraded its "buy" rating to target price S$2.75, driven by Vinamilk's strong earnings growth. PACC Offshore Services Holdings maintained a "hold" rating due to low earnings visibility and technical overhang from a proposed bulk sale.

site_title: Seoul Food
summary: Ryunique, a restaurant in Seoul, stands out for its innovative locavore cuisine, blending international influences with Korean ingredients. Chef Ryu Tae Hwan, schooled in Japanese and French cuisine, developed "Hybrid Cuisine" that combines his international experience with local Korean produce. The restaurant features a map of Korea highlighting suppliers, and its dishes showcase the chef's artistic flair and balance, including unique creations like "fossilised" fish and "hanyakwoo" beef. Despite not yet receiving a Michelin Guide rating, Ryunique is a discovery that reveals the depth of Korean food.

site_title: Europe: Shares weighed by BT, utilities; Italy stocks slide
summary: European shares declined on Thursday, weighed down by BT's 7% drop following a job-cut announcement and weakness in utilities stocks. Italy's stocks slid due to political jitters. However, the banking sector showed resilience, with RBS gaining after a multi-billion dollar deal to settle a US investigation and UniCredit posting a solid update. The pan-European Stoxx 600 ended 0.1% lower.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust's Q1 DPU up 23% to 1.83 S cents
summary: Dasin Retail Trust reported a 23% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.83 Singapore cents for the first quarter, driven by 86% growth in net property income to S$14.9 million and an 85% jump in revenue to S$18.5 million. The trust's acquisition of Shiqi Metro Mall in 2017 contributed to the growth. Major unitholders waived a portion of their entitlements, with the waived amount to be distributed to other unitholders.

site_title: IMF's Lagarde says ready to assist Argentina
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde announced her readiness to assist Argentina with a financing package, following a meeting with economy minister Nicolas Dujovne. The country faces a falling currency, high debt, and soaring inflation, prompting President Mauricio Macri to request IMF help. The IMF is considering a high-access "stand by" financing arrangement, which would provide funds above the normal loan amount, and is expected to finalize talks quickly. US support for the Macri administration's market-oriented reform programme has been reaffirmed by US Treasury Under Secretary David Malpass.

site_title: China's Didi apologises after killing of passenger sparks safety fears
summary: China's ride-sharing giant Didi Chuxing apologized after the killing of a 21-year-old passenger in Zhengzhou city, sparking safety concerns and a debate on Chinese social media. The company, valued at $50 billion, said it was "deeply saddened" and "sorry" about the tragedy, and promised to step up internal supervision. Police are investigating the incident and Didi is offering a reward for information on the suspected driver. The case poses a challenge for Didi as it expands overseas, with many users expressing safety fears on social media.

images.alt_text: Didi was "deeply saddened by and sorry about the tragedy", the company said in a statement, adding that it had apologised to the family of the 21-year-old flight attendant killed en route from the city's airport hotel to downtown.

site_title: Face Time
summary: Newly launched beauty brands MDNA Skin, PIXI Beauty, Chantecaille, Mamonde, and Hera are set to be available at Takashimaya Department Store and Sephora in Singapore. MDNA Skin offers a rejuvenator set, PIXI Beauty features the Glow Tonic, Chantecaille's La Crème à la Rose de Mai, Mamonde's Creamy Tint Color Balm Intense, and Hera's Black Cushion foundation. These products cater to various skin types and concerns, including sensitive skin, immunity, natural glow, and flawless finish.

site_title: Building resilient communities in the age of disinformation
summary: Southeast Asian countries are struggling to combat disinformation due to differing legislative legacies and histories. The region has seen various approaches to combating disinformation, including laws, apps, and public sector initiatives. However, consensus building and a common strategy are proving challenging. To address this, Asean member states could focus on building resilient communities that can adapt to the evolving digital space and share best practices in detecting and responding to disinformation. The upcoming Asean Senior Officials Meeting and Conference of Asean Ministers Responsible for Information provide opportunities for coordinated action and information sharing.

site_title: Starbucks bathrooms now open to all
summary: Starbucks Chairman Howard Schultz announced that the company will open its bathrooms to everyone, regardless of a purchase, following the arrest of two African-American men who asked to use the bathroom at a Philadelphia coffee shop. Schultz stated that Starbucks wants to make everyone feel welcome and give access to the bathroom to anyone, regardless of their worth. This change in policy comes after weeks of controversy and is seen as a step towards inclusivity and equality.

site_title: Apple, Goldman Sachs collaborating on credit card: report
summary: Apple is collaborating with Goldman Sachs on a credit card that would carry the Apple Pay brand, potentially launching early next year. The move aims to diversify Apple's revenue streams and follows a significant rise in the company's services business, including Apple Pay, Apple Music, and other programs, which saw a 31% increase in US$9.2 billion in revenue. The partnership seeks to capitalize on consumer banking operations and align with Apple's focus on online services and content.

images.alt_text: Apple is working with financial giant Goldman Sachs on a credit card that would carry the iPhone maker's digital wallet logo, according to a report on Thursday in the Wall Street Journal.

site_title: Where in the world is Internal Audit in the revised Code?
summary: Singapore's revised Code of Corporate Governance, set to be updated, emphasizes the critical role of internal audit in risk management and internal controls. Despite initial appearances, the revised Code actually enhances internal audit's scrutiny and independence, making it mandatory for listed companies to establish effective internal audit functions. The new structure also focuses on the board's oversight of internal audit's adequacy, effectiveness, and independence, with greater emphasis on the distinction between internal and external auditor independence.

site_title: Singapore businesses unfazed; await new KL government's plans
summary: Singapore businesses remain unfazed by Malaysia's shock victory in the general election, awaiting new government plans. Industry associations, including the Singapore Business Federation and Singapore International Chamber of Commerce, expect "business as usual" despite potential volatility in the financial markets. Analysts, such as UOB economists, believe Malaysia's fundamentals remain strong and risks will be reassessed as clarity emerges. Firms, including Wilmar International and construction companies, also express confidence in the new government's commitment to bilateral ties and stability for mutual benefits.

site_title: US consumer prices rebound 0.2% in April on jump in petrol
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.2% in April, driven by a 3% surge in petrol prices, which recouped March's 4.9% decline. Food and medical services also increased, but cell phone services remained flat. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) is up 2.5% from April 2017, slightly above the Federal Reserve's inflation target. Analysts consider the report benign, reducing odds of aggressive interest rate hikes, and see stabilizing price trends, which should quell inflation concerns.

site_title: Supermarket of the future
summary: Singapore's Cold Storage @ Fusionopolis, a 18,000 sq ft supermarket, has been revamped with high-tech features, including unified payment terminals, cashless payment systems, and a camera weighing scale with visual recognition capabilities. The store also offers a gourmet salad bar, ready-to-eat food options, a wine tasting bar, and two function rooms. The concept is a test bed for the company to engage shoppers and test new retail technology, with plans to share concepts and technology with other outlets. The revamped store aims to provide a unique shopping experience and showcase the future of retail in Singapore.

site_title: SpaceX postpones next-gen rocket launch
summary: SpaceX postponed the launch of its next-gen Falcon 9 Block 5 rocket due to an aborted liftoff just before the scheduled launch. The rocket, designed for more power and reusability, aims to propel the first high-orbit communications satellite for Bangladesh, Bangabandhu Satellite-1. The company plans to launch humans to the International Space Station in December 2018, marking the first time since the US space shuttle programme ended in 2011. The Falcon 9 Block 5 is built to re-fly up to 10 times with minimal refurbishment.

site_title: US: Stocks rally after benign inflation data
summary: US stocks rallied for a second consecutive session on May 10, 2018, after benign inflation data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.8%, the S&P 500 climbed 0.9%, and the Nasdaq Composite also increased 0.9%. The Consumer Price Index rose 0.2% in April, below analysts' expectations. The Federal Reserve is unlikely to accelerate interest rate hikes, with analysts citing the data as "close to the Fed mandate" but not accelerating inflation out of control. Gains were broad-based, with companies like Apple and ExxonMobil among the stronger performers.

site_title: Malaysia elections: Markets' volatility reflect concerns with a dash of hope
summary: Malaysia's 14th general election has resulted in a surprise victory for the opposition coalition Pakatan Harapan (PH) led by Dr. Mahathir Mohamad, marking a significant shift in the country's politics. Analysts expect short-term market volatility, but some see the change as a positive opportunity for Malaysia's economy, which has been doing well, and its financial markets, which have outperformed their emerging market counterparts. The new administration's focus on the economy and finance, combined with its pragmatic leadership, may attract foreign investors and improve the country's economic prospects.

site_title: As flat prices soar in Hong Kong, investors park money down in the lot
summary: In Hong Kong, the value of parking spots in residential complexes has surged, with some selling for over HK$1.6 million, more than doubling in value over the past 18 months. This boom is fueled by a surge in car ownership and a shortage of parking spaces, as well as government measures to cool the property sector. Investors are parking their money in parking spots, which are often sold with high prices per square foot, outpacing the typical price of prime residential flats. Experts predict the market may remain competitive due to the small size of parking spot values compared to the residential sector.

site_title: ST Engineering posts 18% rise in Q1 profit
summary: ST Engineering, a Singapore-based defence and engineering group, reported an 18% rise in Q1 profit to S$117.7 million, driven by increases in revenue and net profit across its aerospace, electronics, land systems, and marine business sectors. Revenue rose 9% to S$1.65 billion, with the marine division's revenue falling 16% due to decreased shipbuilding and repair business. The company secured new contracts worth S$1.35 billion and has an order book of S$13.4 billion, with guidance to deliver S$3.2 billion in the remaining months of 2018.

site_title: RBS clears path to award dividends after US$4.9b deal
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) has reached a deal to pay $4.9 billion to resolve a US mortgage probe, clearing a major hurdle for the UK bank to reduce its stake in the lender. The settlement makes it easier for the UK government to attract buyers for its 70% stake, which was bailed out during the financial crisis. RBS expects to restart dividend payments after a decade, with shares climbing 4.7% following the announcement. The deal cuts second-quarter earnings by $1.44 billion, but analysts say it's an "excellent outcome" for the bank.

site_title: Chinese insurer Anbang's ex-boss jailed 18 years for fraud
summary: Chinese former Anbang Insurance Group CEO Wu Xiaohui was jailed for 18 years for defrauding the company of over $10 billion. The court also ordered the seizure of $10.5 billion worth of his property and suspended his political rights for 4 years. Wu was found guilty of producing false earnings reports, concealing insurance revenue, and deceiving regulators. The government's takeover of Anbang is part of efforts to curb excessive debt and "irrational" investments by conglomerates, with the goal of preventing financial risks and maintaining national stability.

site_title: Non-Stop Action
summary: HBO Asia is hosting a month-long block of blockbuster films, featuring 50 box-office hits from May 10 to June 14. The lineup includes 12 brand-new premieres, such as Wonder Woman, Get Out, and The Mummy, as well as the entire Star Wars franchise and films from DC and Marvel, including Avengers: Age of Ultron and Batman vs Superman.

site_title: Cromwell European Reit posts Q1 DPU above forecast
summary: Cromwell European Reit reported Q1 DPU of 1.45 euro cents, 3.5% above its initial public offering forecast of 1.4 euro cents. The trust's net property income from its light industrial segment increased 6.9% above projections, driven by strong leasing outcomes in France. The company expects the Netherlands office sector to see lower trading volume in 2018, but expects office rents to rise due to strong occupier demand.

site_title: North Korea border town becomes China's new hot property market
summary: North Korea's border town of Dandong has become a hot property market in China after North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's surprise visit to Beijing and subsequent summit with US President Donald Trump. New home sales surged to an eight-year high of 320,000 square meters in March, with prices rising by over 50% in some areas. The city's real estate market is expected to continue to boom due to its strategic location and potential economic benefits from North Korea's newfound rapprochement.

site_title: Design Business Chamber to work with trade bodies
summary: The Design Business Chamber Singapore (DBCS) has signed a Memorandum of Understanding with several trade bodies to promote design thinking and innovation in businesses. The MOU aims to encourage collaboration and leverage expertise to benefit stakeholders. The three areas of collaboration include the Design Kitchen workshop, speed matching, and sharing of speaking platforms. The partnership aims to transform businesses and drive sustainable growth through design-led innovation, with a focus on social, economic, and environmental factors.

site_title: Trump administration taps projects to pilot expanded drone use
summary: The Trump administration has announced partnerships with 10 states, local governments, and tribal governments to pilot expanded drone use across the US. The programme aims to accelerate growth in the sector while addressing security, safety, and privacy concerns. Participating states include Virginia, Kansas, and Nevada, which will work on delivering packages, power-line inspections, and emergency management operations. The programme also includes projects on food delivery, border protection, and autonomous vehicles. Supporters say it will provide on-the-ground insights to inform expanded drone operations, but concerns about security, privacy, and quality of life remain.

site_title: Oil prices expected to fall from present highs as panic subsides
summary: Crude oil prices are expected to decline from their highest levels since November 2014 due to factors such as delayed US sanctions on Iran, hedge fund speculation, and increased production from Saudi Arabia and the US. Despite this, prices could surge if a full-scale Middle East conflict or Iran's renewed nuclear ambitions occur. The International Energy Agency estimates that global demand is slowing, and oil stocks are sufficient for 60 days of OECD nations' consumption.

site_title: Sublime Jazz At Botanic Gardens
summary: The Duke Ellington Orchestra will perform a 75-minute free concert at the Singapore Botanic Gardens on May 12, featuring a repertoire of the legendary jazz composer's best-known pieces. This is the closing show of the Singapore International Festival of Arts. The concert is open to the public and attendees are encouraged to bring a picnic mat and a bottle.

site_title: Wanderlust
summary: Ling Doh Kin, a photographer and editor, is holding his first photo exhibition, "Shine", featuring 30 photographs from less-explored areas of Cuba, Morocco, and other countries. The exhibition, open from May 12-26, will include paired photographs with design collectibles, adding a tactile dimension to storytelling. Limited quantities of the photographs will also be available for sale.

site_title: Keeping things shipshape, in BT Weekend
summary: Singapore's port and shipping sector is a vital maritime centre, with many family businesses ensuring their continuity. Pacific International Lines and Equatorial Marine Fuel are two such torchbearers, now in their second generation. Meanwhile, Philips Asean Pacific has transformed from a consumer electronics company to a healthcare tech leader. The article also explores investing strategies in Singapore and Hong Kong, workplace issues for working mums, and a feature on Taiwanese tennis star Latisha Chan.

site_title: N Korea agrees to warn of activity that poses danger to aviation: UN agency
summary: North Korea has agreed to provide advanced notice for any activities that pose a danger to aviation, a move that could lead to major airlines resuming flights through its airspace. The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) reached the agreement after officials visited North Korea to discuss opening a new air route. This comes as a significant step towards practical reconciliation measures following the historic summit between North and South Korean leaders last month. The assurance could save fuel and time for airlines on routes between Asia, Europe, and North America.

site_title: Singapore businesses unfazed; await new KL government's plans
summary: Singapore businesses remain unaffected by Malaysia's shock election victory, with industry associations expressing confidence in the new government's commitment to bilateral ties. The Singapore Business Federation and other associations expect "business as usual" despite initial market volatility, awaiting clearer policy stances. Experts believe Malaysia's fundamentals remain strong, and long-term impacts on businesses are minimal, with most anticipating a period of stability and continuity.

images.alt_text: Singapore's business community is surprised but unworried by Pakatan Harapan's (PH) shock victory in Malaysia's general election, with industry associations waiting to see what the new government's plans are.

site_title: A taste of old-world Chinese cooking
summary: Circa 1912, a new restaurant in Singapore, offers an authentic taste of old-world Chinese cooking. Chef David Yip aims to revive traditional Cantonese cooking methods, using ancient recipes and techniques such as hand-raising mother yeast and century-old congee. Dishes like char siew pao, century egg congee, and deep-fried superior stock showcase the restaurant's commitment to quality and integrity. However, some dishes, like deep-fried jelly and pan-fried fish roll, may require multiple visits to fully appreciate. The restaurant's authenticity and uncompromising attitude earn it a rating of 7.

site_title: The Last Straw
summary: Banyan Tree Hotels & Resorts has pledged to phase out single-use plastics by Earth Day 2019, including plastic straws, water bottles, and cutlery, in an effort to reduce its environmental impact. The premium hotel operator will also introduce signature Sustainable Itineraries for eco-conscious travelers, raising awareness on climate change and promoting sustainable practices. This move is part of Banyan Tree's broader plan to become a socially responsible business, including planting trees and saving energy across its properties. The initiative aims to contribute to a zero-waste future.

images.alt_text: Banyan Tree Hotels & Resorts.

site_title: UK housing gauge drops to 5½-year low as London slumps
summary: The UK housing market gauge has dropped to a 5½-year low, with London experiencing the largest decline. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) reported a minus-8 gauge, the lowest since November 2012. Analysts expect no near-term pick-up in the market, citing factors such as low stock, low demand, and affordability issues. A survey showed declines in London and the south-east, while prices in Scotland and Northern Ireland rose. The RICS report adds to the uncertainty surrounding the UK property market, which may impact the Bank of England's policy decisions.

site_title: Vard Holdings maintains that valuation error by CIMB 'immaterial', no confusion on its delisting vote
summary: Vard Holdings has responded to concerns over an error in its independent financial adviser's report, stating that a valuation error by CIMB Bank is "immaterial" and would not have changed the adviser's opinion. The company maintained that a recent shareholders' meeting, where a delisting vote was held, was properly carried out despite some shareholders expressing confusion. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) ordered a new EGM to re-vote on the delisting proposal, citing the inaccuracy in the report, but Vard's independent directors confirmed that there was no change to their recommendation.

site_title: US on course for new Middle East policy
summary: US President Donald Trump announced the withdrawal from the 2015 Iran nuclear deal, reimposing all sanctions lifted by former President Barack Obama. The US will use its full economic, diplomatic, and military power to force Iran to give up its nuclear program, including a permanent end to nuclear enrichment and ballistic missile programs. Iran must also end its support for terrorism and regional interventions. The US will work with Israel, Saudi Arabia, and other Arab-Sunni governments to contain Iran's influence in the Middle East.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Haw Par Corporation posted a 15.9% increase in net profit to S$19.3 million in Q1 2018, driven by a 9.1 fold increase in profits from its associated and joint venture companies. Wing Tai Holdings also reported a 9.1 fold increase in net profit to S$68.2 million in Q3 2018. Meanwhile, Noble Group appointed Provenance Capital as an independent financial adviser to review its proposed restructuring plan, amid concerns from substantial shareholder Goldilocks Investment Co.

site_title: Heritage Redefined
summary: A shophouse in Singapore's Blair Road has been redesigned to blend heritage and modern living. The two-and-a-half-storey home features a glass-ceilinged courtyard with a unique wine cellar, a secret garden in the master bathroom, and a balcony-like bedroom. Architect Wu Yen Yen incorporated conservation elements such as Chinese mouldings and bat-shaped windows while introducing modern touches, including a filigree-patterned cabinet and a piece of Chinese calligraphy. The result is a unique and functional home that honors the shophouse's heritage while catering to the couple's modern lifestyle.

site_title: Mum's Not Cooking
summary: Folklore chef Damian D'Silva pays tribute to mothers with a special menu at his restaurant in Beach Road, Singapore. The "An Ode to Mum" menu features dishes his mother used to cook for him during his Basic Military Training, such as Curry Ayam Pekat and Papaya Masak Titek. The menu is available until May 13 and celebrates the love and care mothers show their children.

site_title: Challenging transition ahead for Malaysia
summary: Malaysia's Pakatan Harapan (PH) alliance, led by former Prime Minister Dr Mahathir Mohamad, has won a majority in the elections, marking a significant shift in the country's politics. The new government faces uncertainty, particularly regarding the 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) scandal and relations with China and Singapore. Dr Mahathir has vowed not to pursue "revenge" and has taken a conciliatory tone, but the PH's composition and priorities remain unclear. The transition to the new government is expected to be challenging, with potential for reform and institutional revival, but also risks of racial tensions and instability.

site_title: Rolls-Royce seeks cheaper HQ to cut long-term expenses
summary: Rolls-Royce Holdings plans to relocate its London headquarters to a cheaper location, aiming to cut long-term expenses and address a faulty jet-engine model. The company is considering moving closer to its manufacturing site in Derby, central England, or the area around St Pancras station in London. Chief Operating Officer Simon Kirby will leave the company, and staff will be briefed on options for a move in coming weeks. The restructuring moves follow the appointment of US consultants Alvarez & Marsal to secure £1 billion in free cash flow by 2020.

site_title: Genting Singapore Q1 profit up 3.3% to S$217.2 million
summary: Genting Singapore reported a 3.3% increase in Q1 net profit to S$217.2 million, driven by a 15.1% revenue growth across all business segments. Gaming revenue rose 17% to S$507.4 million, while non-gaming revenue increased 10% to S$167.1 million. Hotel occupancy reached 94%, and net asset value per share edged up to 63.6 Singapore cents. Excluding a one-off gain, net profit after taxation would have increased by 91%.

site_title: Shares ease on Malaysian poll results
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 0.31% to 3,537.59, amid uncertainty over Malaysia's election results, where the opposition coalition Pakatan Harapan won power. Analysts warn of looming ringgit volatility and potential knock-on effects on Singapore's economy, particularly for companies with significant Malaysian exposure. Energy stocks retained some investor goodwill, while some healthcare stocks fell, including IHH Healthcare and Wilmar International.

site_title: Mercedes is bringing its Tesla-killer to Singapore
summary: Mercedes-Benz is set to launch its Concept EQ, a Tesla-killer electric SUV, in Singapore next year. The prototype, showcased at the Paris motor show in 2016, boasts Tesla-rivalling performance and a range of 500km on a single charge. The car will be the first to bear Mercedes' new "EQ" label, complementing its high-performance "AMG" and ultra-luxurious "Maybach" sub-brands. The company aims to put the Concept EQ into showrooms by 2019, with plans to launch 10 pure-electric vehicles within four years, including the road-going version of the Concept EQ.

site_title: China, India should build on existing warm relations
summary: China and India are strengthening their economic ties through the growing popularity of Indian and Chinese films. Indian movies, such as Aamir Khan's "Dangal," have earned significant profits in China, and Chinese films have been well-received in India. This cultural exchange has led to increased investments, with Chinese companies investing over $9.8 billion in India and Indian startups receiving funding from Chinese investors. The two countries are also exploring ways to boost bilateral trade, despite a significant trade deficit between them.

site_title: FDA seeks to shutter two stem-cell firms after patients are blinded
summary: The FDA is seeking to permanently shut down two stem-cell clinics, US Stem Cell Clinic in Florida and Cell Surgical Network in California, after reports of patients being blinded by their treatments. The clinics, which operate hundreds of locations nationwide, have been accused of exploiting patients desperate for cures and causing serious and permanent harm. The FDA claims the clinics have disregarded the law and marketed unapproved products, and Commissioner Scott Gottlieb has stated that the agency will take action against any company putting patients at risk.

site_title: A H-Trust's Q4 DPS increases to 1.72 Singapore cents
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust (A H-Trust) reported a 26.3% increase in Q4 income available for distribution to S$19.5 million, driven by a S$4.1 million fee from divestment of two hotels in Beijing. Gross revenue fell 5.9% to S$49.73 million, while net property income dropped 9% to S$21.96 million. Distribution per stapled security rose to 1.72 Singapore cents, up from 1.37 cents in the previous year.

site_title: Singapore will continue working closely with new Malaysia government: ministers
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong congratulated Mahathir Mohamad on becoming Malaysia's 7th Prime Minister, expressing hope to work closely with the new government to enhance bilateral ties. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing stated it's too early to assess the impact on joint initiatives like the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam welcomed the change in Malaysian government, wishing Malaysia well and hoping for continued cooperation.

site_title: SGX orders Vard to hold new EGM
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has ordered Vard Holdings to hold a new extraordinary general meeting (EGM) after finding inaccuracies in the company's delisting plan. The regulator cited errors in the independent financial adviser's letter, including a historical price-to-net asset value (P/NAV) multiple that was 0.7 times lower than the correct figure. Vard must submit an updated delisting circular and convene a new EGM within a specific timeframe. The new EGM will give minority shareholders a second chance to air their views and potentially seek a different outcome, with the company's delisting remaining conditional.

site_title: Rare victory for minority shareholders at Vard
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has ordered Vard Holdings to hold a new extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to seek approval for its delisting plans, effectively giving power back to minority shareholders. This rare victory comes as a result of minority shareholders' complaints about the company's handling of the delisting proposal. The regulator's intervention is seen as a reassuring move for retail investors, highlighting the importance of shareholder activism and corporate governance in Singapore. The move may also prompt Fincantieri to reconsider its exit offer, potentially leading to improved terms for minority shareholders.

site_title: Uber to offer food delivery by drone in under 30 minutes
summary: Uber plans to deliver food by drone in San Diego, with expected delivery times of 5-30 minutes, as part of a federal government-approved commercial testing program. The company, now the largest food delivery business in the world, aims to use drone delivery to compete with existing services. Uber's CEO, Dara Khosrowshahi, emphasized the company's commitment to mobility beyond cars, while also addressing the company's suspended autonomous-car testing program, which is expected to resume in the next few months.

site_title: Malaysia elections: Mahathir to form next government after being sworn in as PM
summary: Malaysia's King Sultan Muhammad V has sworn in Dr. Mahathir Mohammed as the country's 7th Prime Minister, following his opposition alliance's victory in the general election. Dr. Mahathir led Pakatan Harapan to 113 seats, surpassing the required majority. The King's office refuted allegations of a delay in Dr. Mahathir's appointment, stating that the monarch supports the democratic process and wishes for the nation's betterment. Dr. Mahathir has promised to reverse the goods and services tax, review foreign investments, and investigate the 1MDB graft scandal.

site_title: Upping The Steaks
summary: Korean hanwoo beef, considered the holy grail of beef, has gained attention for its exceptional flavor and tenderness. Unlike other wagyu varieties, hanwoo boasts a 50:50 fat to meat ratio, resulting in a more balanced taste experience. The high-quality beef is challenging to find outside of Korea due to the country's mountainous terrain and limited cattle farming. Restaurants in Seoul offer premium hanwoo experiences, with prices ranging from $74 to $60,000 per 100gm. For those willing to invest, hanwoo offers a superior alternative to wagyu and American beef, making it a must-try for beef connoisseurs.

site_title: Food manufacturing SME proposes integrated dairy hub
summary: SMC Food 21, a Singapore-based food manufacturing company, proposes an integrated dairy hub to cater to the growing demand for dairy products in the region. The hub, which could offer R&D labs, warehousing, and technology transfer services, aims to boost local companies' growth by partnering with multinational dairy companies. The proposed facility is expected to increase production and revenue by three to five times, and Minister Chan Chun Sing supports the initiative, citing Singapore's focus on quality over cost in the food manufacturing sector.

site_title: Modest rate hikes needed even as inflation cools, says Carney
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said the central bank still plans to implement "modest" interest rate hikes despite an unexpected economic slowdown, which derailed an anticipated rate hike in May. The decision was made after inflation was expected to weaken faster than anticipated. The Monetary Policy Committee voted 7-2 to keep the interest rate at 0.5%, with forecasts showing inflation will return to its 2% target in two years. The decision marks a gentle pace of tightening, with a potential interest rate hike in August.

images.alt_text: Mr Carney: "We think the momentum in the economy is going to reassert."

site_title: They came, they saw, they were outbid
summary: The David and Peggy Rockefeller collection, a vast trove of 1,500+ items, was auctioned off in two days, with Day 2 seeing prices soar far beyond estimates. Notable sales included a George III tea caddy sold for $6 times its estimate of $800, and a porcelain dessert service once belonging to Napoleon sold for $1.8 million. The sale attracted top collectors and raised over $600 million on Tuesday, with Day 2's total reaching $12.36 million. The entire collection is expected to bring in over $1 billion for charity by the sale's end.

site_title: Redefining Motherhood
summary: Three Singaporean power women have redefined traditional notions of motherhood by pursuing entrepreneurial and creative passions. Ann Kositchotitana, founder of Sofie & Nate Inc, shifted her focus from fashion to children's products and services after her daughter with Down Syndrome successfully built a Lego instruction kit. Dolores Au, co-founder of Mummyfique, shares her knowledge of raising children through her website and mobile app, while Stephanie Suga Chen, author of 'Travails Of A Trailing Spouse', found success writing a novel about expat wives in Singapore. These women aim to inspire others to retain their identities and pursue passions outside of their parental roles.

site_title: Silent upon a peak
summary: A writer reflects on the experience of drinking a great red wine, likening the moment of savoring its flavors to the poem "On First Looking into Chapman's Homer" by John Keats. The writer expresses gratitude for memories of meeting winemakers, including Egon Muller, and the privilege of experiencing the beauty of wine. They highlight the importance of appreciating the people behind the wines, rather than just the wine itself, and how these memories and connections make the experience even more special.

site_title: China set to trim 2018/19 soyabean imports as trade row boosts prices
summary: China is set to trim its soybean imports for the 2018/19 crop year, the first decline in 15 years, due to a trade row with the US that has boosted prices and reduced demand. The country is expected to import 95.65 million tonnes, a 0.3% decrease from the previous year. This move is expected to negatively impact top exporter Brazil and US farmers, who have seen exports to China dry up amid a trade spat. China's own soybean production is forecast to rise 4.9% to 15.27 million tonnes.

site_title: Ducati Scrambler 1100 review: Classic looks with modern punch
summary: The Ducati Scrambler 1100 has been a successful model since its introduction in 2015, offering a classic look with modern punch. As the least expensive and most beginner-friendly Ducati, it has become a spiritual successor to the original 1962 model. The Scrambler 1100 is a great option for those looking for a luxury motorcycle with a lower price tag, making it an ideal choice for those new to Ducati.

site_title: GM and Seoul agree to US$7 billion bailout for South Korea unit
summary: General Motors (GM) has agreed to a US$7 billion bailout for its South Korean unit, GM Korea, with US$6.4 billion from GM and US$750 million from the Korea Development Bank. The bailout aims to turn around the loss-making unit, which has seen production fall by nearly half in the last decade. GM will invest US$2 billion in facilities and US$1.6 billion on corporate restructuring, with existing loans being converted into preference shares to save on interest. The deal is expected to create jobs and support suppliers, with GM committing to allocate two new models to its Korean plants.

site_title: Margaret Cho
summary: Margaret Cho, a Korean-American comedian, is set to release her new stand-up show "Fresh Off the Bloat" on May 15. The show promises to be a no-holds-barred, confrontational comedy experience tackling socio-political issues and dark topics, including her own life experiences with suicide, sexual abuse, and identity. Cho, 49, has built a successful career by pushing boundaries and finding humor in tragedy, earning her a reputation as a bold and unapologetic comedian.

site_title: Recycling is all the rage in interiors
summary: Recycled textiles are gaining popularity in interior design, with designers incorporating materials such as repurposed denim and cotton into furniture and lighting fixtures. The movement aims to reduce waste and promote sustainability. Exhibitions at the International Furniture Fair in Milan showcased innovative uses of recycled materials, including patchwork fabrics, perforated furniture, and mushroom-inspired designs. The trend also extends to lighting fixtures, with vintage Sputnik chandeliers and modern starburst-style designs proliferating.

site_title: Human-sounding Google Assistant sparks ethics questions
summary: Google has unveiled a new digital assistant, Google Assistant, with "Duplex" technology, allowing it to converse naturally like a real person. The assistant can make phone calls, book appointments, and interact with staff without revealing its artificial intelligence nature. The technology has sparked ethics questions, including concerns over its potential use in robocalls, data collection, and responsibility for mistakes. Google plans to test the assistant in the coming months, while experts warn of the need for proper governance to prevent its misuse.

site_title: Sweating It Out With Kayla Itsines
summary: Kayla Itsines, a 26-year-old Australian fitness star, will headline FitnessFest by AIA 2018 in Singapore on May 19. With 9.5 million Instagram followers, Itsines is known for her 28-minute workout series, Bikini Body Guides (BBG), which focus on high-intensity interval training and resistance training. Her bootcamp and meet-and-greet sessions will be part of the one-day event, which also features various fitness activities, shopping, and health food options.

site_title: Iran nuclear accord crisis warps Opec equation
summary: US President Donald Trump's decision to scrap the Iran nuclear accord and re-impose sanctions on Iran has sparked uncertainty in the oil market, particularly among Opec member states. Saudi Arabia has signaled its intention to increase oil production to mitigate any supply shortages, a move that could potentially lead to higher prices. Analysts predict a cutback in Iranian oil shipments, which could further drain global oil inventories and drive prices higher. The decision may provide an exit strategy for Opec and Russia, which have been working together to eliminate a global oil glut.

site_title: Singapore to host Trump-Kim meeting
summary: US President Donald Trump announced on Twitter that he will meet North Korean leader Kim Jong Un on June 12 in Singapore, marking the first meeting between a sitting US president and a North Korean leader. Singapore, a neutral city-state with strong ties to China, will host the event. Trump hopes to gain an agreement from Kim to give up North Korea's nuclear weapons and ballistic missile programme. The meeting comes after North Korea released three US prisoners held in the country, seen as an early diplomatic concession.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump said on Thursday he will meet North Korean leader Kim Jong Un on June 12 in Singapore.

site_title: Wing Tai Q3 profit up more than ninefold to S$68.2m on increased earnings from associated, JV companies
summary: Wing Tai Holdings reported a net profit of S$68.2 million for the third quarter, a more than ninefold increase from the previous year, driven by increased earnings from associated and joint venture companies. Revenue shrank 4.3% to S$70.3 million, while earnings per share rose to 10.9 Singapore cents. The company's net asset value per share increased to S$4.08.

site_title: Malaysia elections: Markets' volatility reflect concerns with a dash of hope
summary: Malaysia's opposition party, Pakatan Harapan, led by Dr. Mahathir Mohamad, won the country's 14th general election in a surprise victory, ending 61 years of Barisan Nasional's rule. The market's reaction is expected to be short-term, with currency and bond volatility, but analysts see potential positive impact of change. Dr. Mahathir has promised to focus on the economy and finance, and foreign investors may eventually embrace the election outcome as a sign of rising political maturity and respect for democracy. However, key issues such as fiscal reforms and the fate of big projects remain uncertain, and the new administration's ability to deliver on its promises will be closely watched.

site_title: Take-No-Prisoners Theatre
summary: Director Thomas Ostermeier stages Henrik Ibsen's classic "An Enemy Of The People" at the Singapore International Festival of Arts. The play, a gritty celebration of one man's struggle against the system, runs from May 11 to 12 at Esplanade Theatre. Performed in German with English surtitles, it is one of the hottest tickets.

site_title: Million-dollar home values in US gain even as tax deductions shrink
summary: US home prices in high-end markets have defied predictions of a decline despite tax deduction changes, with median home values rising 8% nationally in March. Affluent areas such as San Francisco, San Jose, and the Hamptons saw significant price increases, with some areas rising over 25%. The National Association of Realtors had forecasted price declines, but now predicts a 4% gain in home prices nationwide in 2018. The tax overhaul capped mortgage-interest deductions and set a maximum for state and local tax deductions, but has not deterred buyers, with consistent multiple bidding for $1 million homes.

site_title: OUE C-Reit Q1 DPU falls 9% on enlarged unit base from placement
summary: OUE C-Reit's 1QFY18 distribution per unit (DPU) fell 8.9% to 1.12 Singapore cents due to an enlarged unit base from a private placement in March 2017. Despite a 4.7% increase in available income, revenue declined 1.6% to S$44.1 million due to lower rental income. The portfolio maintained an overall occupancy of 96.9% in Q1FY18, with office rents averaging higher quarter-on-quarter. Asset enhancement works at One Raffles Place shopping mall are expected to commence in mid-2018, while 15% of the portfolio's gross rental income is due for renewal this year.

site_title: Ice Ice Baby
summary: Ice cream vendors in Singapore remain a consistent feature of the city's landscape, with a history dating back to the 1950s. Initially, they sold frozen soda pops from bicycle carts, later introducing wafer ice cream. Today, they offer a variety of flavors, including matcha, durian, and mango, and are licensed by the National Environmental Agency. Despite competition from air-conditioned rivals, ice cream vendors continue to operate, with costs mainly focused on keeping their products cool. This traditional treat remains a popular choice for locals seeking a sweet treat.

site_title: Frasers Property enjoys 74.2% surge in Q2 profit
summary: Frasers Property Limited (FPL) reported a 74.2% surge in Q2 profit to S$124.1 million, driven by overseas acquisitions and development profits in Singapore. Revenue rose 19.3% to S$841.7 million, largely due to sales settlements in China and Australia. The company remains keen to expand its business in Europe and is eyeing capital recycling opportunities, with gearing expected to decrease to around 91% once the recycling of properties is completed.

site_title: Consumer prices rebound 0.2% in April on jump in petrol
summary: US consumer prices rebounded 0.2% in April, driven by a 3% surge in petrol prices and a 0.3% rise in food prices. Medical services prices also increased, while cell phone services remained flat. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) is 2.5% higher than April 2017, surpassing the Federal Reserve's inflation target. Core CPI, excluding food and energy, rose 0.1% and 2.1% year-over-year. Despite weaker-than-expected results, the rebound may calm Wall Street concerns about a potential interest rate hike.

site_title: Let's Talk About Sex
summary: Asia's first sexual wellness festival, SPARK Fest, aims to open candid conversations about sex and relationships through talks, panel discussions, workshops, and art installations. Founded by trained sex and relationship counsellor Erin Chen, the event encourages participants to "love more consciously" and break down taboos. Running parallel to SPARK Fest is the first Sextech Hackathon, which brings together innovators and change-makers to develop solutions for improving sexual wellness. The event aims to empower participants and promote a healthy foundation of sexual wellness, literacy, and inclusivity.

site_title: Marriott wants to beat home-sharing upstarts at their own game
