summary: Marriott International, the world's largest hotel company, is testing home-sharing on its website through a partnership with Hostmaker in London. The service, called Tribute Portfolio Homes, is integrated into Marriott's loyalty program and currently offers about 200 residences. Marriott aims to compete with home-sharing websites like Airbnb by leveraging its expertise in branding and service, and delivering a better product. The company studied the business and is testing it after ensuring compliance with local regulations. Marriott plans to expand its offerings if the test is successful.

site_title: Form And Function
summary: Richard Mille and McLaren unveiled their joint timepiece, the RM 11-03 McLaren Automatic Flyback Chronograph, at the Geneva International Motor Show. The watch features a carbon TPT and orange quartz TPT case, inspired by the McLaren 720S, and is powered by the RMAC3 automatic calibre. Only 500 pieces will be produced, with each edition number matching the caseback number. The watch's design and materials reflect the companies' mutual interest in unique design, new materials, and modern craftsmanship, with a focus on technical challenge and functionality.

site_title: KOP bags Villa D'Este collective sale for S$93m
summary: KOP Limited has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to buy the freehold Villa D'Este in Singapore's District 10 for S$93 million through a collective sale. The property, comprising 12 apartments, will be redeveloped into a high-end condominium. Based on the existing gross floor area, the unit land rate works out to S$1,898 per square foot. Owners of 10 units have signed the collective sale agreement, with gross payouts ranging from S$7.57 million to S$8.07 million.

site_title: Wilmar's Q1 profit down 41% on lower palm oil prices, sugar business woes
summary: Wilmar International reported a 40.6% decline in Q1 net profit to US$203.3 million, attributed to lower palm oil prices and a widening pre-tax loss in its sugar business. Despite these challenges, management focused on the threat of Washington-Beijing trade tensions, citing potential impacts on the market and the company's oilseeds and grains segment. The group's revenue rose 5.7% to US$11.17 billion, driven by stronger oilseeds and grains sales.

site_title: Ford vehicles 'facing hold-ups at China ports' amid trade friction
summary: Ford vehicles are being held up at Chinese ports due to increased customs scrutiny amid a tense trade standoff. Chinese customs officials are requesting extra technical checks on imported Ford cars and US-made German SUVs. This is part of a broader trend of US goods facing increased customs scrutiny in China. The delays are affecting both Ford's premium Lincoln brand and its standard models, highlighting the impact of trade tensions on international trade.

site_title: A Roast For Mother's Day
summary: Atout restaurant in Singapore hosted a Mother's Day brunch featuring Asian roast pork from Uncle G's Handmade, in collaboration with chef-owner Patrick Heuberger. The three-course menu, priced at S$68++ (S$80 with champagne), includes options such as lobster bisque, Angus Beef Ribeye, and Rhubarb Crumble with Chantilly Cream. The event included a complimentary serving of roast pork per table, available for dine-in at 40C Harding Road.

site_title: Hyundai Ioniq Electric review: An affordable EV that's a blast to drive
summary: Hyundai's Ioniq Electric is the first mass-affordable electric vehicle (EV) in Singapore, priced at S$139,888 with COE, making it a more accessible option for the general public. The EV boasts a range of 243km on a full charge, and charging takes 4.5 hours with a wallbox charger. Its handling and ride are comparable to its hybrid sibling, and it delivers instant, punchy torque. However, the lack of public charging stations is a concern, requiring owners to have access to private charging facilities. Despite this, the Ioniq Electric offers a promising alternative to traditional fuel-powered vehicles in the fight against global warming and air pollution.

site_title: Innovation is key to vibrant enterprise: Chun Sing
summary: Singapore aims to boost its economy by focusing on innovation, with the government supporting research and development (R&D) efforts and providing resources for businesses to grow and transform. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing announced plans to position Singapore as a hub for start-ups and innovation, while Minister for Manpower Josephine Teo will provide "selective flexibility" in foreign-manpower policy to support industry transformation. Other ministries, including the Monetary Authority of Singapore and Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat, also unveiled plans to enhance connectivity, infrastructure financing, and research capabilities.

site_title: Young Man, Old Soul
summary: Glen Wee, a 25-year-old Temasek Polytechnic graduate, has been signed by Warner Music Singapore after finishing third in reality singing competition The Final One. His debut single "Send Me An Angel" is a soulful, atmospheric ballad and is available for download and streaming on major platforms. Wee's music is described as a blend of Damien Rice and Sam Cooke, with a sound similar to Bon Iver's work. A debut album is expected later this year.

site_title: There is a need to boost interest in small caps in the Singapore market
summary: Singapore's small-cap stocks underperformed the market, with the FTSE ST Catalist Index losing 8.3% between January and April, compared to the STI's 9.8% gain. The FTSE ST Small Cap Index is down 6% since May last year. Experts suggest making it mandatory for new listings to allocate more shares to the public and improving independent research coverage to boost interest in smaller stocks, which represent the future of the local economy.

site_title: Stereophonics rocks, venue doesn't
summary: Stereophonics performed a 2-hour concert in Singapore, despite a technical fault during their set. The Welsh band played 22 songs, including hits like "Dakota" and "Have a Nice Day," and received a heartfelt response from the crowd. Lead singer Kelly Jones handled the technical issue with composure, and drummer Jamie Morrison stole the show with his energetic drumming. However, the poor venue, Zepp@BIGBOX Singapore, was a disappointment, with limited cash payment options and a lackluster atmosphere, which detracted from the overall experience.

site_title: Trump risks turning trade conflicts into all-out trade wars
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade policies threaten to spark an all-out trade war, risking enormous harm to America's foreign policy and economy. Despite warnings from economists and trade analysts, Trump's protectionism could lead to higher domestic prices, reduced consumer spending, and increased uncertainty for businesses. The potential losses are estimated to be between $400 billion and $1.6 trillion, with some studies suggesting that trade liberalization since World War II has generated gains of up to $2.1 trillion. Trump's approach is seen as a zero-sum game, where he views trade as a competition rather than cooperation, putting his allies at risk of retaliation.

site_title: Johnson & Johnson opens new Asia-Pac HQ; Trimble opens digital training centre
summary: Johnson & Johnson opened its new Asia-Pacific headquarters in Singapore, featuring a Design Lab, Leadership Lab, and Human Performance Institute. The 15,800 sqm regional HQ will lead collaborations and partnerships to create new healthcare ideas and solutions. Trimble also opened a new Integrated Digital Delivery Centre in Singapore, aiming to train a highly-skilled workforce in the latest AECO technologies. Both companies will drive innovation and workforce development in the region.

site_title: Amazon's Jeff Bezos can and should do a lot more with his wealth - for the benefit of current and future generations
summary: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos has amassed a fortune of $131 billion, but instead of using it to benefit humanity, he plans to invest $1 billion annually in his space travel company Blue Origin, citing it as "incredibly important for civilization in the long term." However, experts argue that Bezos has a staggering opportunity to make a significant impact on issues like education, healthcare, and climate change, and that he should consider alternative uses for his wealth, such as funding intensive math tutoring programs or doubling the budgets of global health organizations.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: US President Trump's 50% copper import tariff has been confirmed to cover refined metal, affecting global markets. Oil prices rose over 2% amid market uncertainty and trade tensions. Stocks in Europe declined, with banks and healthcare sectors leading the drop, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times.

site_title: 1,400 people in Singapore could afford a Rolls-Royce Cullinan
summary: Rolls-Royce unveiled the Cullinan, its first Sport Utility Vehicle, named after the Cullinan diamond, the largest diamond ever found. The car follows Bentley's Bentayga and Lamborghini's Urus in the SUV market. With a price tag of around $1.4 million, it's accessible to only 1,400 people in Singapore who can afford it. The Cullinan marks Rolls-Royce's late entry into the SUV market, but its luxurious design and name signify its importance to the brand.

site_title: Bentley Continental GT review: Discovering a new continent
summary: The Bentley Continental GT has undergone significant improvements for its latest model, blending luxurious appointments with driving excitement. The new car boasts a lighter aluminum platform, improved weight distribution, and a 48-volt Dynamic Ride System for precise handling. The Continental GT's W12 engine delivers relentless acceleration, and the "B" mode offers a perfectly nuanced balance of power and chassis pliancy. With its sleek aesthetics and finely executed cabin appointments, the new Continental GT feels decidedly younger-at-heart, making it a strong contender in the luxury Grand Tourer market.

site_title: Euro bounces as US dollar's rally stalls
summary: The US dollar's rally stalled on Thursday as 10-year Treasury yields dropped below 3%, halting its three-week-long advance. The dollar index fell 0.2% against a basket of six major currencies. The euro rose above a 41/2-month low, lifted by a weakened dollar. Tensions between Israel and Iran, and US consumer price data due later, are key drivers of market sentiment. Analysts are divided on whether the US dollar's rally will continue, with some predicting further gains and others seeing it as transient.

site_title: Malaysia elections: Mahathir sworn in as PM
summary: Malaysia's 92-year-old Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad was sworn in after his coalition won a parliamentary majority, ending the ruling coalition's 61-year grip on power. Mahathir will serve as interim prime minister until opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim's release from prison in June, who would need a royal pardon and by-election to take power. Mahathir pledged to work for Anwar's full pardon, stating "there is a lot of work to be done."

site_title: Bloomberg launches index to track 10 cryptocurrencies
summary: Bloomberg has launched the Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index (BGCI) to track the performance of 10 US dollar-traded cryptocurrencies, including bitcoin, ethereum, and ripple. The index, market capitalization-weighted, provides an independent benchmark for investors and will be owned and administered by Bloomberg Index Services. The launch aims to facilitate diversified exposure to cryptocurrencies and follows the growing interest in the market, according to Bloomberg Indices' global product manager Alan Campbell.

site_title: OUE Commercial Reit's Q1 DPU falls 8.9% on enlarged unit base
summary: OUE Commercial Reit's Q1 DPU fell 8.9% to 1.12 Singapore cents due to an enlarged unit base. Revenue edged 1.6% lower to S$44.1 million, while net property income rose 1.8% to S$35.28 million. Occupancy remained robust at 96.9% with all properties achieving higher-than-market office occupancy.

site_title: SBS Transit's Q1 profit up almost 64%
summary: SBS Transit's first-quarter net profit surged 64% to S$16.76 million, driven by 15.8% increase in revenue to S$328.18 million. Higher fees from bus contracting, rail services, and other operating income contributed to the growth. Operating profit rose 58% to S$20.57 million, with earnings per share increasing to 5.39 Singapore cents. The company expects higher revenue from public transport services, while maintaining revenue from other commercial services.

site_title: Renault says its Kangoo ZE can save fleet operators money
summary: Renault has launched the Kangoo ZE, a battery-powered panel van, in Singapore, aiming to save fleet operators both money and the environment. The vehicle can travel 264km on a single charge, costing S$7.33, and has lower servicing costs. According to Wearnes Automotive, running a Kangoo ZE costs 3 Singapore cents per kilometre, saving its operator S$3,171 a year. However, the higher upfront cost of S$25,000 may take over eight years to offset. Experts expect EV prices to decrease by 2025, making them more competitive with combustion vehicles.

site_title: Haw Par posts 15.9% increase in Q1 earnings to S$19.3m
summary: Haw Par Corporation, a Singapore-listed company, reported a 15.9% increase in Q1 earnings to S$19.3m, from S$16.7m in the same period last year. Earnings per share rose to 8.8 cents from 7.6 cents. Revenue slipped 1.4% to S$60m, mainly due to a strong Singapore dollar. The company's net asset value per share edged up to 14.64 cents.

site_title: US consumer prices rebound 0.2% in April on jump in gasoline
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.2% in April, rebounding from a 0.2% decline in March, driven by a 3% jump in gasoline prices. Food and medical services costs also increased, while cell phone services remained flat. The Consumer Price Index is 2.5% higher than last year, slightly above the Federal Reserve's inflation target. Core CPI, excluding food and energy, rose 0.1%. The data may calm Wall Street concerns about a potential interest rate hike.

site_title: China says property control policies will not be changed or loosened
summary: China's housing authority reiterated that property control policies will not be changed or loosened, aiming to stabilize home prices and rents, speed up a residential housing development plan, and increase land supply. Officials emphasized building more small, ordinary homes. Despite efforts to control speculation, home prices continue to rise in most cities, with sales growth slowing. New home prices have risen for 35 consecutive months, with cities supporting demand from first-time buyers.

site_title: Healthway Medical chalks up a profit in Q1
summary: Healthway Medical Corp reported a profit of S$116,000 in Q1, with revenue jumping 24% year-over-year to S$28.66 million. The company's primary healthcare segment and specialist & wellness healthcare segments drove the increase. An independent reviewer, BDO, completed its review of Healthway Medical's loan extensions and is working to finalize the report by June 30. This comes as the company chalks up its first profit in Q1 after reporting losses in the same period last year.

site_title: Japan property information firm LIFULL leads seed round for crowd-investment platform BitOfProperty
summary: Japan's LIFULL Co led a seed round for BitOfProperty, a blockchain-based real estate crowd-investment platform. The funding will help the platform expand and improve technology. BitOfProperty allows small investments into international rental real estate using blockchain technology, providing transparency and liquidity into international investing. The platform has already tested and closed its first investment deal, with plans to introduce new features and investment tools.

site_title: US hopes to narrow wide gap in China talks
summary: US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross expressed hope for progress in narrowing the gap in trade talks with China, where hundreds of billions of dollars are at stake. The US has threatened tariffs targeting $150 billion in imports, while China has warned $50 billion in goods are in the firing line. A high-level Chinese delegation, led by Vice Premier Liu He, will visit Washington next week to discuss the dispute. The US has demanded China reduce the bilateral trade deficit by $200 billion a year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end up for fourth straight day
summary: Hong Kong shares rose for the fourth consecutive day on May 10, 2018, driven by energy firms due to strong oil prices. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.89% to close at 30,809.22. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also rose, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 0.48% and the Shenzhen Composite Index up 0.52%.

site_title: Creative Tech's Q3 loss narrows to US$3.76m
summary: Creative Technology reported a Q3 net loss of US$3.76 million, narrowing from US$4.61 million in the same period last year. Revenue declined 6% year-over-year to US$15.02 million due to challenging market conditions. The company also reported other gains of US$1.1 million. In a warning, Creative Technology cautioned that Q2 revenue may be below target and operating loss similar to the first half.

site_title: Straco Q1 profit falls 60% to S$3.6m due to two-month suspension of the Singapore Flyer ride
summary: Straco Corporation's Q1 profit plummeted 60.1% to S$3.6 million due to a two-month suspension of the Singapore Flyer ride operations. Revenue dropped 31.7% to S$18.8 million. Executive Chairman Wu Hsioh Kwang attributed the decline to the technical issue, but noted a positive outlook for China's tourism sector. The net asset value per share increased to 31.81 Singapore cents, and shares ended 0.6% down at S$0.775.

site_title: Heeton Q1 profit more than doubles to S$6.4m
summary: Heeton Holdings reported a net profit of S$6.4 million for Q1 2018, more than doubling from S$2.8 million in the same period last year. The increase was mainly due to a 44.7% rise in profits from associated companies to S$3.5 million. Revenue fell 23.9% to S$11.8 million due to decreased sales and rental revenue. Net asset value per share edged up to 130.04 Singapore cents.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Malaysia's opposition party won the surprise election, with 92-year-old Mahathir Mohamad as leader, leading to a decline in the Ringgit currency and Malaysia's high-speed rail and Goods and Services Tax (GST) being cited as uncertainties. Noble Group appointed Provenance Capital as an independent adviser for its restructuring plan, while Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust raised S$329 million in a private placement. The Singapore market fell 0.31% due to the Malaysia election outcome, and US tariffs on Vietnam's garment industry were announced. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and the UK economy contracted for the second month.

site_title: Singapore shares close down by 0.31% on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 10.95 points, or 0.31%, to 3,537.59 on Thursday, following Malaysia's overnight election upset. Telcos Singtel and StarHub were among the losers, with Jardine Cycle & Carriage also affected due to its motor interests in Malaysia. The market saw 1.57 billion shares traded for S$1.16 billion, with losers narrowly beating gainers 193 to 189.

site_title: Malaysia elections: 'Now the hard part' as Malaysia awakens to new political dawn
summary: Malaysia's opposition, Pakatan Harapan, won the country's first real government change since independence in 1957, ending the six-decade rule of the United Malays National Organisation (UMNO). 92-year-old Mahathir Mohamad, the coalition's leader, has vowed to bring about lasting change, including rights protections, press freedom, and anti-corruption measures. However, his ability to deliver on these promises remains uncertain, as his authoritarian past and divisive policies pose a challenge to national unity. The historic election victory has sparked hopes for wholesale change in Malaysia.

site_title: Malaysia: Markets closed on Thursday and Friday
summary: Malaysia's markets were closed on Thursday and Friday for public holidays, with trading resuming next Monday. Meanwhile, global markets were affected by US-EU trade tensions, with stocks in Europe and the US experiencing fluctuations. In Asia, traders largely brushed off new Trump threats, and Singapore stocks saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Wilmar Q1 profit falls 41% on lower palm oil prices, loss-making sugar operations
summary: Wilmar International reported a 41% decline in Q1 profit to US$203.28 million, primarily due to lower palm oil prices and losses in its sugar business. Despite higher sales volumes and grain prices, the company's tropical oils segment took a hit, with pre-tax profits down 34.5%. The sugar business saw a 13.1% increase in pre-tax losses. Wilmar attributed the poor performance to seasonal factors, but warned of potential price volatility due to trade tensions, particularly with Chinese import tariffs looming over soya beans.

site_title: SGX RegCo tells Vard to hold new EGM on delisting proposal
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has instructed Vard Holdings to hold a new extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to obtain shareholders' approval on its delisting proposal. The decision follows an inaccuracy found in the company's circular to shareholders, specifically in the historical price-to-net-asset-value (P/NAV) ratio, which was stated as 1.2 times instead of the correct 1.7 times. The regulator also requested an updated independent financial adviser (IFA) letter with the inaccuracies corrected.

site_title: Trump says Kim summit set for June 12 in Singapore
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a historic summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un set for June 12 in Singapore, with the goal of advancing prospects for peace in the Korean Peninsula. The location was confirmed by Singapore's Ministry of Foreign Affairs, following the release of three American prisoners by North Korea earlier in the day. Trump expressed his hope for a "very special moment for World Peace" during the summit, which marks a significant development in the ongoing diplomatic efforts between the two nations.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump on Thursday announced his historic summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un will take place in Singapore on June 12.

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust's Q4 DPS up 25.5% to 1.72 Singapore cents
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust (A H-Trust) reported a 25.5% increase in Q4 distribution per stapled security to 1.72 Singapore cents, driven by a one-time look fee of S$4.1 million from the divestment of two hotels in Beijing. Q4 income available for distribution rose 26.3% to S$19.5 million, while gross revenue fell 5.9% to S$49.7 million. The trust expects healthy demand in Sydney and stable growth in Osaka, but faces increased competition in suburban Sydney and Melbourne.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks snap losing streak; won at near 2-week closing high
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index snapped a five-day losing streak, rising 20.18 points or 0.83% to 2,464.16. The won edged up to a nearly two-week high, closing at 1,073.1 per dollar. The US dollar weakened globally, contributing to the won's gains. Despite a 1.0% decline so far this year, the KOSPI is still up 0.60% compared to the previous day's MSCI Asia-Pacific shares.

site_title: With NYC rents sliding, Queens leads the way on Landlord breaks
summary: In northwest Queens, NYC rents dropped 12% from a year earlier to a median of $2,646/month, excluding landlord giveaways. These giveaways were offered on 65% of new leases signed, a record share since 2016. The decline in rents is attributed to landlord incentives. This trend suggests that Queens is leading the way in NYC in terms of landlord breaks, providing a favorable market for apartment hunters.

site_title: European shares led lower by BT; RBS rallies
summary: European shares fell in early trading on May 10, 2018, led by BT's 6.7% decline after the UK phone company reported disappointing results and announced 13,000 job cuts. However, RBS rallied 5.2% after agreeing to pay $4.9 billion to resolve a US investigation into its bond sales. The pan-European STOXX 600 limit losses to 0.1%, buoyed by solid updates from UniCredit and RBS.

site_title: Philippines GDP grows 6.8% as forecast, inflation 'a spoiler'
summary: The Philippines' economy grew 6.8% in the first quarter, matching expectations and supporting the government's target of 7-8% growth for the year. However, inflation hit a five-year peak, driven by higher fuel prices and tax reforms. Economic Planning Secretary Ernesto Pernia attributed the slower growth to inflation, saying it would have been closer to the government's target if not for it. The government aims to boost growth via infrastructure spending, with a US$180 billion "Build Build Build" programme, and is expected to raise interest rates to combat inflation.

site_title: Frencken's Q1 net profit falls 58.5%, but is up 10.8% excluding one-off gain last year
summary: Frencken Group's Q1 net profit fell 58.5% to S$6.8 million due to a one-off gain last year. Excluding the gain, net profit rose 10.8%. Revenue increased 3.2% to S$138.8 million, driven by a 19.3% jump in mechatronics division turnover. However, IMS division sales fell 29.1% due to the absence of Precico Electronics sales. The company expects growth in its semiconductor and automotive segments in Q2.

site_title: RBS clears path to award dividends after US$4.9b US Department of Justice deal
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland Group reached a tentative deal to pay US$4.9 billion to resolve a US mortgage probe, clearing a major hurdle for the UK to reduce its stake in the lender. The settlement makes it easier for the UK government to attract buyers for its 70% stake in the bank. RBS expects to restart dividend payments after a decade, with shares climbing 4.7% following the announcement. The deal also paves the way for the bank to pass the Bank of England's stress testing exercise, potentially leading to the resumption of ordinary dividend payments.

site_title: Bank Negara Malaysia holds interest rate in aftermath of polls
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia kept its benchmark interest rate at 3.25% on May 10, 2018, following a surprise election victory by Mahathir Mohamad. The decision aims to provide policy stability amid investor concerns. The central bank stated that Malaysia's economic outlook remains positive, with strong fundamentals supporting economic growth. Despite subdued inflation, the trajectory of headline inflation will depend on future global oil prices. The move aims to sustain strong economic growth and manage market risks in the post-election environment.

site_title: Higher expenses lead to 30% dive in marina developer SUTL's Q1 profit
summary: SUTL Enterprise, a marina developer, reported a 30% decline in Q1 profit to S$639,000 due to higher expenses. Revenue grew 4% to S$7.8 million, driven by increased sales. Expenses rose 9% to S$7 million, mainly due to expansion plans, higher headcount, and professional fees. The company's earnings per share fell to 0.74 Singapore cents, and its net asset value per share edged up to 62.71 Singapore cents.

site_title: Australia: Shares end up on oil rally; NZ at record high
summary: Australian shares rose 0.18% to a three-month high, driven by energy and mining companies as commodity prices surged. Metal miners BHP and Woodside Petroleum led the gains, while energy stocks benefited from oil prices reaching multi-year highs. New Zealand shares also reached a record high, driven by telecommunication and consumer staples stocks. The Australian S&P/ASX 200 index rose to 6,118.7, while the NZ S&P/NZX 50 index ended 0.2% higher at 8,637.72.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon trading at 3,543.28, down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading Thursday afternoon at 3,543.28, down 0.1% from the previous day, with the Straits Times Index falling 5.26 points. The market saw a slight edge of gainers over losers, with 898.2 million shares changing hands. Blumont was the most actively traded counter, falling 25% after trading 111.05 million shares. The index was influenced by the decline in DBS Bank and UOB, while DBS Bank and Thomson Medical saw gains.

site_title: Malaysia elections: Pakatan Harapan entitled to form government, says Mahathir
summary: Tun Dr Mahathir Mohamad, former PM of Malaysia, states that Pakatan Harapan (PH) has won a clear majority in the elections and is entitled to form the government. PH secured 121 seats, with 14 from Warisan and a few from smaller parties in Sabah, totaling over 135 MPs. Mahathir emphasized that the rule of law must apply and urged the formation of a government by 5pm on the same day. He expressed confidence that PH will be able to form the government, given the majority support of MPs.

site_title: Noble appoints Provenance as independent adviser on restructuring plan
summary: NOBLE Group appoints Provenance Capital as an independent financial adviser to review its proposed restructuring plan for shareholders. The plan, which would dilute existing shareholders to a 15% stake, is being challenged by Goldilocks Investment Co, a substantial shareholder holding an 8.1% stake. Noble must obtain shareholder approval to avoid an insolvency scenario. The appointment brings the company into compliance with a Singapore Exchange (SGX) requirement. Goldilocks wants the adviser's scope to be substantive and for meaningful engagement and disclosure from Noble management.

site_title: What Malaysia, Turkey and the US have in common
summary: Malaysia's 92-year-old Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad defeated his former protege, Najib Razak, in the country's landmark election, marking a significant shift in the country's politics. This outcome has dealt a blow to emerging-market investors, who had seen Malaysia as a strong growth story due to Najib's "stability rules" and ties with China. The election result has raised concerns about the stability of the region, with investors reevaluating their bets on other countries such as Turkey and Argentina.

site_title: Bloomberg launches index to track ten cryptocurrencies; includes bitcoin, ethereum
summary: Bloomberg and digital asset manager Galaxy Digital Capital Management launched the Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index (BGCI) to track the performance of 10 US dollar-traded cryptocurrencies, including bitcoin and ethereum. The market capitalization-weighted index measures the performance of bitcoin, ethereum, ripple, bitcoin cash, EOS, litecoin, dash, monero, ethereum classic, and zcash. The index aims to provide diversified exposure to cryptocurrencies and an institutional-grade benchmark for investors, using a rules-based methodology and data from trusted sources.

site_title: Why Trump and Kim may pick Singapore for their summit
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un are considering Singapore as the venue for their historic summit, a move seen as a diplomatic coup for the city-state. Singapore's excellent security, hosting of high-level international gatherings, and strong diplomatic ties with the US make it an attractive choice. The city-state has previously hosted high-security events, including a meeting between Chinese President Xi Jinping and Taiwan's Ma Ying-jeou, and has a North Korean embassy and security ties with the US. A venue at the Shangri-La Hotel, which hosts the Shangri-La Dialogue, is also possible.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher amid caution over earnings
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.39% to 22,497.18, driven by a positive lead from Wall Street and gains in petroleum-linked shares following US President Donald Trump's decision to exit the Iran nuclear deal. Petroleum-linked shares such as Inpex and JXTG Holdings jumped 3.35% and 1.38% respectively. Toyota also rallied 2.26% after announcing a record annual net profit, while SoftBank fell 2.33% despite announcing a record operating profit.

site_title: Malaysia elections: PM Lee looks forward to developing equally constructive relationship with next Malaysian govt
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed optimism about developing a constructive relationship with the next Malaysian government after the country's elections. He made the statement as the elections were about to take place. The outcome of the elections would determine the future of Malaysia's government.

site_title: BOJ may debate stimulus exit if inflation nears our goal: Kuroda
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the central bank may debate an exit strategy from its ultra-easy policy if inflation nears its 2% target. Kuroda expressed concerns about market confusion if the exit plan is announced prematurely. The BOJ's policy board could discuss conditions for an exit when the possibility of achieving the target heightens. This indicates a potential shift in the BOJ's policy stance as inflation approaches its goal.

site_title: Cromwell European Reit reports Q1 DPU of 1.45 euro cents, 3.5% above forecast
summary: Cromwell European Reit reported a Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.45 euro cents, 3.5% above forecast, driven by a better-than-expected performance from its light industrial segment. The trust's Q1 income available for distribution and gross revenue were also 3.5% and 0.8% above forecast, respectively. The light industrial portfolio in France benefited from leasing outcomes and rental income, while the Danish portfolio was impacted by a tenant vacating a property.

site_title: Malaysia elections: Najib 'accepts verdict of the people' after shock loss
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Najib Razak accepted the will of the people after his coalition, Barisan Nasional, suffered a shock loss to veteran politician Mahathir Mohamad. Despite acknowledging the verdict, Najib did not make a clear concession, citing the need for the king to decide the next prime minister. Analysts warn Najib may be trying to cling to power by winning defections from other parties, while Mahathir vows to bring him to justice over corruption allegations related to the 1MDB scandal.

site_title: Malaysia elections: Mahathir won't be sworn in as PM on Thursday, says palace spokesman
summary: Mahathir Mohamad, Malaysia's newly elected prime minister, will not be sworn in on Thursday as previously planned, according to a palace spokesman. Mahathir's opposition alliance won the simple majority needed to form a new government, ending six decades of rule by a coalition he once led. Mahathir vowed to restore the rule of law and reverse policies introduced by his predecessor, including a goods and services tax. He must now navigate a fractious alliance and manage the transition to his next prime minister, Anwar Ibrahim.

site_title: Malaysia elections: Singapore will continue to work closely with new government, says Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore will continue to work closely with Malaysia's new government, led by Mahathir Mohamad, to advance bilateral ties. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing stated that it is early days to assess the impact of the election on major projects like the High Speed Railway. Singapore looks forward to the formation of a new Malaysian government and expects the government of the day to continue to advance the relationship to the mutual benefit of both countries. The Singapore government is closely following developments in Malaysia.

site_title: Malaysia elections: Ringgit falls as high-speed rail, GST among analysts' top uncertainties
summary: Malaysia's opposition won the surprise election, sparking uncertainty in the country's markets. The ringgit fell 4.3% against the US dollar, and stocks with Malaysian exposure fell on the Singapore bourse, with Fraser and Neave being the exception. Analysts cite high-speed rail and Goods and Services Tax (GST) as top uncertainties, with Moody's describing the outcome as credit negative for Malaysia's sovereign rating. The new government's fiscal spending plans and potential cancellation of major infrastructure projects, such as the High Speed Rail, are also being closely watched.

site_title: Chinese insurer Anbang's ex-boss jailed 18 years for fraud
summary: A Chinese court sentenced Wu Xiaohui, the former head of Anbang Insurance Group, to 18 years in prison for defrauding the company of over $10 billion. Wu ordered others to produce false earnings reports and conceal insurance revenue to deceive regulators. The court also ordered the seizure of 10.5 billion yuan worth of his property and suspended his political rights for four years. The government's takeover of Anbang marks a significant step in its efforts to regulate large private companies and prevent financial risks.

images.alt_text: Wu Xiaohui was toppled as Anbang's head last year and China's insurance regulator announced an unprecedented takeover of the conglomerate in February, as the government moves to prevent heavily-indebted large private companies from collapsing and posing a risk to the financial system.

site_title: New Silkroutes back in the black for Q3 with US$80,000 profit
summary: New Silkroutes Group reported a US$80,000 profit in Q3, swinging back into the black after a US$294,000 loss in the same period last year. Revenue rose 31% to US$164.4 million, and loss per share narrowed to 0.252 US cents. This marks a significant turnaround for the investment holding company.

site_title: Stocks to watch: HRNetGroup, Japan Foods, Frasers Logistics Trust, Frasers Property, China Aviation Oil
summary: HRNetGroup reported a 46% increase in net profit to S$16.3 million for its first quarter, driven by improved performance from its professional recruitment business. Japan Foods Holding's net profit rose 67.8% to S$938,000 for its fiscal fourth quarter, driven by better sales from its Menya Musashi ramen restaurants and new brands.

site_title: Asia: Markets, energy firms boosted as oil prices press ahead
summary: Crude oil prices surged, boosting Asian energy firms and equity markets, as the US decision to tear up the Iran nuclear deal raises supply concerns. Oil prices rose 3% on Wednesday, with both main contracts reaching highs since November, and are expected to continue rising. Energy firms, such as Woodside Petroleum and CNOOC, saw significant gains, while stock markets in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Tokyo also rose. The decision has added to market uncertainty, with traders monitoring Opec's meeting in Vienna on June 21.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday; STI down 0.1% to 3,543.75
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.1% to 3,543.75 on Thursday, with 52.7 million shares worth S$107.8 million changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 73 to 59. DBS Group Holdings and Singtel were among the active index shares trading higher, while Genting Singapore and Ezion fell. US stocks rose overnight, with energy and banking shares boosted by higher oil prices and interest rate expectations.

site_title: FLT raises S$329m in private placement more than 3.9 times subscribed
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) successfully raised S$329 million in a private placement that was 3.9 times subscribed. The placement saw strong participation from new and existing investors, with Frasers Property Limited and TCCGI allocated 68 million and 19.68 million new units, respectively. FLT's manager, Robert Wallace, expressed confidence in investors' support for the trust's strategy, and the company plans to declare an advanced distribution from April 1, 2018.

site_title: Electronics SMEs urged to embrace South-east Asia as their growth driver
summary: Global electronics manufacturing companies are being urged to shift their focus to Southeast Asia as a growth driver to cushion the impact of a greying home base. Experts predict that companies will tap into the region's value and "Industry 4.0" technology tools to remain competitive. Southeast Asia's intra-regional trade in infocomm technology reflects its close interconnectivity, and the region is seen as a great place to be for businesses, with opportunities for scaling up and generating revenue.

site_title: Singapore likeliest option for Trump-Kim summit: US official
summary: US President Donald Trump's planned summit meeting with North Korea leader Kim Jong Un is likely to take place in Singapore, according to a US official. This announcement comes as the two leaders aim to discuss denuclearization and other key issues. The summit's location and timing have been subject to speculation, but Singapore has emerged as the most probable location for the meeting. Details of the summit are yet to be confirmed, but the event is expected to be a significant development in the US-North Korea diplomatic efforts.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally out of blocks
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for the fourth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.61% to 30,723.55. The rally was driven by gains in energy firms due to rising oil prices. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also rose, with the Shanghai Index increasing 0.31% and the Shenzhen Index adding 0.12%. The gains follow a trend of resilience in Asian markets despite US trade tensions and economic uncertainty.

site_title: Walmart reaches beyond its big-box stores
summary: Walmart has agreed to purchase 77% of Indian e-commerce service Flipkart for $16 billion, marking a significant expansion into the tech-savvy market. This deal follows Walmart's previous purchases of a men's clothing brand and a delivery startup, as part of its strategy to capture a share of the fast-growing e-commerce market. The acquisition is one of the largest and riskiest in Walmart's history, and is part of the company's efforts to stay competitive in the digital age.

site_title: Malaysia elections: Scandal-plagued PM Najib toppled by his mentor
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's administration was toppled in the country's elections, marking a major shift in the political landscape. Najib's administration was marred by allegations of involvement in the 1MDB scandal, described by the US as a "kleptocracy at its worst." The scandal and rising living costs may have been key factors for voters, contributing to a decisive defeat for Najib. The outcome is expected to have significant repercussions for the country.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on May 10, 2018, gaining 0.32% or 70.82 points to 22,479.70, following a positive lead from Wall Street. Investors remained cautious due to US President Donald Trump's withdrawal from the Iran nuclear deal. The broader Topix index was up 0.22%.

site_title: Malaysia elections: Surprise Pakatan Harapan win will not disrupt economic growth
summary: Malaysia's Pakatan Harapan party won the 14th General Election, but experts believe the surprise victory won't disrupt economic growth due to the country's strong fundamentals. The economy's resilience will cushion any potential market reaction. Previous downturns were attributed to external factors, and experts expect a temporary impact on the stock and foreign exchange markets. The government's strong economic stance will likely maintain stability, supporting growth despite the election outcome.

site_title: Human-sounding Google Assistant sparks ethics questions
summary: Google has unveiled a new digital assistant that converses naturally, raising ethics questions about its potential use. The assistant, demonstrated by Google chief Sundar Pichai, made bookings at a hair salon and restaurant without staff realizing it was artificial intelligence. The demonstration sparked concerns about the blurring of lines between humans and AI. As the assistant becomes more human-like, experts are left to ponder the implications for trust, privacy, and accountability. The technology has the potential to revolutionize customer service, but also raises questions about the responsibility that comes with creating increasingly sophisticated AI systems.

images.alt_text: Google chief Sundar Pichai played a recording of the Google Assistant independently calling a hair salon and a restaurant to make bookings - interacting with staff who evidently didn't realise they were dealing with artificial intelligence software, rather than a real customer.

site_title: Boeing CEO champions free trade at Washington event
summary: Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenberg emphasized the importance of free trade agreements at a Washington event, citing his company's significant US job generation and export capabilities. Boeing manufactures 90% of its products in the US and sells 70% globally. Muilenberg's comments come as President Donald Trump's administration scrutinizes free trade deals, highlighting Boeing's reliance on international sales.

site_title: Oil soars after Trump nixes Iran nuclear deal, stocks rally
summary: US President Donald Trump's decision to withdraw from the Iran nuclear deal led to a 3% surge in crude oil prices, with Brent and US crude rising to their highest levels since 2014. The energy sector in equity markets rallied, lifting European stocks and the US market, with Exxon Mobil, Chevron, and Royal Dutch Shell gaining 2.36%, 1.70%, and 3.38% respectively. The decision raises the risk of conflict in the Middle East and casts uncertainty over oil supplies, with US crude rising $2.08 to settle at $71.14 per barrel and Brent up $2.36 to $77.21 per barrel.

site_title: Manchester United confirm Alex Ferguson out of intensive care
summary: Manchester United confirmed Alex Ferguson out of intensive care after emergency surgery on a brain hemorrhage, and will continue rehabilitation as an inpatient. Ferguson, 67, was admitted after a fall at his home near Manchester. Current manager Jose Mourinho expressed positivity about Ferguson's recovery. The legendary manager, known for his success at Manchester United and Aberdeen, has received widespread well-wishes from the football world and beyond.

site_title: Canada's Freeland says Nafta talks centre on autos
summary: Canada's Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland says US, Canadian, and Mexican trade ministers are focusing on new content requirements for autos in the revamped Nafta agreement. The US wants increased parts production in high-wage countries for duty-free access, while Mexico proposes a 10-year phase-in period without a wage-linked requirement. Talks are ongoing, with a May 18 deadline to reach a deal that can be submitted to Congress before the US trade negotiating authority expires.

site_title: Malaysia elections: Outcome shows that a Malay tsunami swept all before it
summary: Malaysia's general election results showed the opposition coalition Pakatan Harapan (PH) significantly ahead of Barisan Nasional (BN), despite odds against it. PH added several states to its current two, giving the opposition majority control of 13 states for the first time. Tun Dr Mahathir Mohamad's leadership played a key role in swinging Malay votes towards PH, dubbed a "Malay tsunami." The BN government's efforts to hobble the opposition, including electoral boundary changes and deregistration of PH, were unsuccessful in preventing the outcome.

site_title: Asean's active role in the greening of growth
summary: Asean countries have made significant steps towards greening their economic development, with the recent Asean Summit endorsing efforts to recognize and develop the complementarities between Asean's movement towards Asean Community Vision 2025 and the UN's 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. Countries such as Thailand, Indonesia, and the Philippines are taking initiatives to ensure sustainability in the palm oil sector and transition to renewable energy. Asean is also shifting towards a pathway of economic development that sets out green targets and rewards "clean and green" practices. However, meeting nationally determined contributions and relying on foreign and private investment will still be a challenge for many Asean member states.

site_title: Ayondo posts deeper loss of 6.3m Swiss francs for Q1 despite revenue surging 67.9%
summary: Ayondo, a European fintech firm, reported a deeper net loss of 6.3 million Swiss francs for Q1 2018, despite a 67.9% surge in revenue to 7.3 million francs. Higher fees, rebates, and finance costs eroded results due to increased rebates and listing costs. The company's net loss per share deepened to 0.04 franc, while net asset value per share rose to 0.07 franc.

site_title: Japan Foods Q4 profit grows 67.8% to S$0.9m as diners slurp up ramen, new brands
summary: Japan Foods Holding reported a 67.8% increase in net profit to S$938,000 for its Q4 fiscal year, driven by better sales from its Menya Musashi ramen restaurants and new brands. Revenue rose 6.5% to S$16.2 million, with additional revenue from new restaurants. The company declared a final cash dividend of 1.30 Singapore cents per share. Full-year net profit grew 24% to S$5.8 million. Japan Foods is cautiously optimistic about its expansion plans in South-east Asia and Japan.

site_title: 'Iron Man' suit worn by Robert Downey Jr. stolen
summary: The iconic Iron Man suit worn by Robert Downey Jr. in the 2008 movie was reported missing from a Los Angeles storage facility. The gold and red suit, valued at US$325,000, vanished between February and April 25, 2023, and police consider the theft high priority. Detectives have no leads so far, but the Los Angeles police are investigating the unusual theft.

site_title: Metal manufacturer Miyoshi seeks to raise S$7m in private placement
summary: Metal manufacturer Miyoshi Limited plans to raise S$7.05 million through a private placement of 115 million new ordinary shares at S$0.0613 apiece. The offering will account for 23.28% of the company's existing share capital. Net proceeds will be used 90% for additional investments in the electric vehicle business and 10% for general working capital. The offering is expected to increase the company's issued and paid-up share capital to 609.07 million ordinary shares.

site_title: European commissioner says Britain's May is 'weak'
summary: European Commission Budget Commissioner Gunther Oettinger criticized British Prime Minister Theresa May as "weak" during a discussion with students, echoing Boris Johnson's comments about her. May's Brexit negotiations remain deadlocked, with the House of Lords handing the government legislative defeats on the issue. The EU expects Britain to present its customs plan by June, ahead of a hoped-for agreement on future trading ties by October. May's leadership is under pressure, with divisions on Brexit causing strain on the government.

site_title: Centurion Q1 profit falls 15% on expiry of facility lease
summary: Centurion Corp reported a 15% fall in Q1 profit to S$9.13 million due to a lease expiry of its Westlite Tuas facility. Revenue fell 17% to S$30.1 million, but gross profit margin increased to 72% without a S$1.2 million amortisation cost. The company's existing portfolio of assets remained strong, and a pipeline of assets under development is on track for completion. New directors Teo Peng Kwang and Tan Poh Hong were appointed.

site_title: Europe: Oil rally drives shares higher as US pulls out of Iran deal
summary: European shares rose 0.6% to fresh three-month highs on Wednesday, driven by an oil rally following the US withdrawal from Iran's nuclear agreement, which boosted crude prices. The oil and gas index surged 2.9% to a three-year high. Shares in oil majors Total, Royal Dutch Shell, and Eni rose between 1.9 and 3.9% as the sector had its best day in a month. However, airline stocks fell 0.8-2.2% due to higher oil prices.

site_title: Pop star Chris Brown named in sex assault lawsuit
summary: A Los Angeles woman, identified as Jane Doe, has filed a lawsuit against singer Chris Brown and rapper Young Lo, alleging she was repeatedly raped and sexually assaulted at Brown's home in February 2017. Doe claims she was lured to Brown's house after a concert, where she was given alcohol and drugs, and then assaulted by Grissom and another unidentified woman, Doe X. The lawsuit alleges the assault was traumatic and Doe has been severely traumatized. Brown's publicist could not be reached for comment, and Los Angeles police said there was no open investigation at the time.

site_title: The pluses of scooter sharing
summary: San Francisco is testing dockless electric scooter sharing, with companies like Bird and Jump operating in the city. Despite concerns over safety and congestion, scooter-sharing can be a convenient and affordable option for short trips, with riders averaging 2.4 km per trip in San Francisco. The city is considering capping the total scooter fleet at 1,250 for six months, citing over-saturation. Scooters may become more attractive to companies like Uber, which has hinted at interest in the electric-scooter market.

site_title: Chinese tech giant may be first victim in a new Cold War
summary: Chinese tech giant ZTE has halted major operations after the US banned the company from using US-made components for seven years. The company's manufacturing plant in Shenzhen has been idle, with workers receiving training sessions every other day. Trading in ZTE's shares has been suspended for weeks, and staff have been instructed to reassure clients without discussing the US technology. This move is seen as the first casualty of the high-tech cold war between the US and China.

site_title: Dutch eye Air France woes, fearing headwinds for KLM
summary: Dutch politicians and unions are watching the Air France crisis with concern, fearing it may impact KLM. Air France-KLM boss Jean-Marc Janaillac resigned after staff rejected a pay deal, sparking anger among KLM staff who feel left out. The crisis highlights cultural differences between the two countries, with Dutch workers favoring compromise and calm discussion. KLM has seen its profits drained by Air France's losses, and the French government has ruled out aiding the carrier. Dutch unions demand a 5.1% wage increase, while the French unions rejected a 7% pay rise over four years.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Ezion Holdings expects a net loss for Q1 2018 due to asset delays and refinancing, but remains operationally cashflow positive. AusGroup plans a consent solicitation for notes and APAC Realty posted a 46.8% increase in net profit. Vicom, Health Management Intl, Aspial Corporation, and Citic Envirotech also reported positive results, with Aspial's revenue surging 50.8% and Citic Envirotech securing a 720 million yuan PPP project.

site_title: Malaysia elections: Mahathir scores shock election win; set to become world's oldest PM
summary: Mahathir Mohamad, a 92-year-old Malaysian veteran, has won the country's general election, defeating the ruling coalition and securing a simple majority. His Pakatan Harapan alliance won 113 of 222 parliament seats, while the Barisan Nasional coalition won 79. Mahathir, who previously served as prime minister from 1981 to 2003, will become the world's oldest elected leader. He has promised to seek a royal pardon for jailed politician Anwar Ibrahim and step aside to allow Anwar to become prime minister.

site_title: Nordstrom Rack says sorry to black customers of St Louis store
summary: Nordstrom Rack's president apologized to three black teenagers falsely accused of stealing at a St Louis store. The teens, who were simply shopping for last-minute prom deals, were followed by employees and reported to police. After cooperating with authorities and showing receipts, the teens were released. The incident highlights racial discrimination in the US retail industry, with the company investigating employee actions and considering changes to training policies.

site_title: Dishing out second chances
summary: HCSA Academy Culinary Training Centre, a six-week program by HCSA Community Services, was officially opened in Singapore, aiming to empower vulnerable individuals with F&B sector skills. The course, based on the Food Services skills framework, offers job placements and WSQ Higher Certificate in Food Services (Culinary Arts) upon completion. The academy incorporates state-of-the-art equipment, online courses, and AR technology, with the goal of boosting learning creatively and effectively. Inaugural trainees, including two former homeless men, expressed gratitude for the program's life-changing impact.

site_title: AIA offers medical case management service
summary: AIA Singapore has launched a personal medical case management service, partnering with Medix Medical Services to help policyholders navigate complex medical care. The service, available to 230,000 AIA Max Essential and A Saver plan holders, aims to improve diagnosis and treatment options. Medix will provide independent, accurate, and objective views on diagnosis and treatment, and facilitate referrals to suitable doctors and hospitals. The service is available for at least three months or a year, depending on the customer's need.

site_title: Producer prices up slightly after recent solid gains
summary: US producer prices rose 0.1% in April, a slight increase after strong gains in the first quarter. This moderation in cost inflation eased concerns about rapidly building inflation pressures. The Labor Department reported a 0.3% increase in March.

site_title: Ford chairman says 'fairly large' changes in store for automaker
summary: Ford Chairman Bill Ford Jr. has stated that the company will undergo "fairly large" changes in the coming year, including cost-cutting measures and investments in electric vehicles. Ford aims to cut costs by $25.5 billion by 2022 and prune its North American sedans and compact cars, while boosting investments in electric vehicles and technology-driven ventures. The company plans to invest $11 billion in new electric vehicles by 2022 and will use cost savings to return cash to shareholders, invest in new technology, and fund restructuring.

images.alt_text: Ford Motor Co shareholders should expect "fairly large" changes in the coming year, executive chairman Bill Ford Jr told Reuters, building on the automaker's moves to discontinue some North American models and boost electric vehicle investment.

site_title: HK Skycity mall deal fuels economic hub dreams
summary: New World Development will invest $2.5 billion to build a retail and entertainment complex near Hong Kong's airport by 2027, with the goal of attracting visitors from the Greater Bay Area. The project, part of Hong Kong's infrastructure initiatives, involves a 55km bridge and a tunnel connecting the airport to mainland China. Financial prospects are modest, but the development could become a day-trip destination, boosting inbound traffic to the region. The project aims to capitalize on the growing population of 60 million in the Pearl River Delta region.

site_title: The international payment system is broken - and it's time Singapore picks a new one
summary: Singapore's current international payment system, dominated by Swift, is vulnerable to hacking and compromised by US access, posing national security risks. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and banks should work together to secure a transparent and workable system, potentially utilizing blockchain technology. Delaying this transition could lead to unregulated systems like Bitcoin gaining market share, exacerbating grey- and black-market activity.

site_title: Frasers Property Q2 profit grows 74% to S$124.1m
summary: Frasers Property Limited reported a 74% increase in Q2 profit to S$124.1m, driven by a 19.3% rise in revenue to S$841.74m. Earnings per share also rose to 3.17 Singapore cents from 1.36 Singapore cents last year. The company's Q2 performance outpaced the same year-ago period.

site_title: Fed returns to centre stage for Asia as US yields near 3%
summary: Asian economies are facing capital outflows and higher borrowing costs due to rising US yields near 3%, testing the decoupling thesis. Countries such as Malaysia, the Philippines, and Indonesia are vulnerable to foreign capital outflows, with the Philippines and Indonesia at risk of a currency crisis. India's rupee is also under pressure due to slowing foreign inflows. Meanwhile, Japan's finance minister expects the yen to weaken against the dollar, and South Korea's central bank has sufficient reserves to prevent disruptions.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher boosted by oil, bank shares
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.8% to 24,542.54, the S&P 500 gaining 1.0% to 2,697.79, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 1.0% to 7,339.91. Energy shares were boosted by higher oil prices, while banking shares advanced on expectations of increased interest rates. The rally was also driven by President Trump's decision to exit the Iran nuclear deal, which lifted shares of ExxonMobil and other energy companies.

site_title: Investment Management Association of Singapore names new chief
summary: The Investment Management Association of Singapore (IMAS) has appointed Carmen Wee as its new chief executive, succeeding Michael Lim who will retire at the end of June 2018. Wee, a veteran of the Singapore investment management industry, previously held roles at Natixis Global Asset Management, Lehman Brothers, and DBS Asset Management. Her appointment follows a rigorous executive search process and aims to build on IMAS's reputation for developing the industry in Singapore. Wee will join IMAS in June to facilitate a smooth transition.

site_title: Mindset shift needed as Singapore's economic strategy evolves: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore's economic strategy is shifting from attracting foreign investment to innovation and enterprise, said Minister for Education Ong Ye Kung. This requires a mindset shift, emphasizing entrepreneurship, collaboration, and risk-taking over competition. The government aims to support local companies venturing abroad, with a focus on innovation and collaboration across industries and sectors. The Singapore International Chamber of Commerce Awards gala dinner highlighted successful industry collaborations, such as a project between Sats and EON Reality. This new approach is expected to drive growth and development in the country.

site_title: IMF not overly worried about forex pressure in Jakarta, Manila
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is not overly concerned about recent selling pressure on assets in Indonesia and the Philippines, as it was not triggered by domestic factors. The currencies' weakness is attributed to tighter global financing conditions and rising oil prices. The IMF notes that Asia has stronger buffers than in the past, and countries have built stronger current accounts and accumulated more reserves. The Fund projects Asia's growth to remain strong at 5.6% this year and next, but warns of vulnerability to sudden tightening in global financial conditions and protectionist policies.

site_title: Motherhood redefined, this Weekend
summary: Motherhood is redefined as entrepreneur Ann Kositchotitana and fellow high-achieving mums discuss the importance of retaining identities outside of parental roles. The article also features Korean-American stand-up comic Margaret Cho and a gift guide for Mother's Day. Additionally, it highlights various lifestyle topics, including fine dining in Seoul and the rise of zero-waste living. The article concludes that mothers need to prioritize their passions and identities beyond the Supermom ideal.

site_title: Electronics SMEs urged to embrace South-east Asia as their growth driver
summary: Singaporean electronics SMEs are advised to expand into South-east Asia as a growth driver, cushioning the impact of a greying home base. Industry experts, including DBS senior economist Irvin Seah, predict that companies will tap into regional value and "Industry 4.0" technology to stay competitive. The intra-regional trade in infocomm technology reflects the close interconnectivity in the region, and SMEs can leverage the strong intellectual property in South-east Asia to take risks and scale up regionally.

site_title: IMF not overly worried about forex pressure in Jakarta, Manila
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is not overly concerned about recent selling pressure on the Indonesian rupiah, Philippine peso, and Indian rupee, which have lost 5-6% from their peaks this year. The currencies' weakness is attributed to tighter global financing conditions and higher oil prices, rather than domestic factors. The IMF notes that Asia has stronger buffers than in the past, allowing for room for interest rate adjustments and a flexible exchange rate system. The region's growth prospects remain strong, with the IMF projecting 5.6% growth for this year and next, but it warns of vulnerabilities to sudden global financial conditions and protectionist policies.

site_title: COE prices mostly higher in latest bidding
summary: COE premiums in Singapore mostly rose in the latest bidding round, with the greatest increase seen in cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp, reaching S$38,501. The premium for motorcycles ended at S$7,204, while the open category closed at S$38,600. Traders note that prices are stabilizing, but caution that a gradual increase could lead to significant price hikes in future rounds. The premium for commercial vehicles decreased by 3%.

site_title: Asean's active role in the greening of growth
summary: Asean nations have taken significant steps towards greening their economic growth, with efforts to recognize and develop sustainability pledges, such as the Asean Community Vision 2025 and the United Nations 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. Countries like Thailand, Indonesia, and Malaysia are implementing measures to ensure sustainability in sectors like palm oil, while Singapore is introducing a carbon tax to promote green growth. Asean can assist its member states in meeting their Nationally Determined Contributions by monitoring implementation, sharing best practices, and encouraging public-private partnerships to reduce financial risks.

images.alt_text: Smoke rising from peat fire in Pekanbaru, Riau province in Indonesia. The country is now looking to reform its land and agrarian rights, which will help ameliorate social and economic inequalities while also shifting to more sustainable development of natural resources.

site_title: Singapore, Brazil ink avoidance of double taxation pact
summary: Singapore and Brazil signed a comprehensive bilateral Avoidance of Double Taxation Agreement (DTA) in Singapore, aiming to facilitate bilateral trade and investment cooperation. The agreement was inked by Foreign Affairs Minister Vivian Balakrishnan and Brazilian counterpart Aloysio Nunes Ferreira during his three-day official visit. The pact will help prevent double taxation and promote economic cooperation between the two countries.

images.alt_text: Dr Balakrishnan (right) and Mr Nunes Ferreira signing the agreement on Monday at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

site_title: No longer a favourite, Woods is just thankful to be on Players turf
summary: Tiger Woods, 42, is a 33/1 betting outsider at the Players Championship, down from being a favourite due to mediocre performances. Despite his struggles, Woods is thankful to be competing and pain-free after a spinal fusion last April. The tournament has a history of unpredictability, with past winners ranging from favourites to outsiders. Woods will need to improve his game to compete against a strong field, including Jason Day, Jordan Spieth, and Rory McIlroy.

site_title: CSE Global's Q1 net profit jumps 90%
summary: CSE Global, a process control and communications network system integrator, reported a 90% increase in Q1 net profit to S$5.7 million, driven by broad-based growth across industry segments. Revenue rose 23.7% to S$92.17 million, with oil and gas revenue up 23.3%. Despite lower new orders, the company ended the quarter with a strong outstanding order book of S$148.6 million, and expects to be profitable in 2018.

site_title: CBA caves to watchdog in rate-rigging case
summary: The Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) has admitted to "unconscionable" rate-rigging and agreed to pay A$25 million after a corporate watchdog case. The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) accused the bank of manipulating interest rates for its own gain. This is the latest scandal to hit CBA, which has faced claims of breaking anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing laws. The bank's actions were deemed "unconscionable" and it will pay the settlement amount.

images.alt_text: CBA has agreed to pay A$25m in penalties, the watchdog's court fees as well as contribute to a consumer protection fund.

site_title: Digital Readiness Blueprint to ensure no one is left behind in Smart Nation plans
summary: Singapore is launching a Digital Readiness Blueprint to ensure all citizens can participate in its Smart Nation plan, which aims to utilize sensors and digital payments. The blueprint will outline strategies for digital access, literacy, and participation. Key projects include the Moments of Life app, a National Digital Identity system, and a Centre of Excellence for Information and Communications. The initiative aims to deepen technical capabilities in the public sector and protect users' privacy.

site_title: Hyflux's loss widens as Tuaspring's woes drag on
summary: Hyflux reported a loss of S$22.21 million in the first quarter ended March 31, 2018, primarily due to the loss-making Tuaspring desalination and power plant. Excluding Tuaspring, the company earned a net profit of S$1.04 million, down 96% from last year. Revenue declined 21% year-on-year to S$72 million, mainly due to lower EPC activities from the TuasOne project. The company is exploring partial divestment of Tuaspring and seeking additional funds to inject growth activities.

site_title: Stockholm, Vancouver see huge plunges in luxury property prices
summary: Vancouver and Stockholm saw significant declines in luxury property prices, with Vancouver plummeting 7.6% and Stockholm falling 9% in the six months to March, according to a Knight Frank survey. This slowdown supports anecdotal evidence of a slowdown in Vancouver's luxury market, attributed to tax hikes and rising interest rates. The decline may bring stability to the local housing market, with Vancouver's mayor calling it a "necessary step."

site_title: Singapore's public service to move from 'Whole-of-Government' to 'Whole-of-Nation'
summary: Singapore's public service is shifting from a "Whole-of-Government" approach to a "Whole-of-Nation" effort, partnering with citizens, businesses, and stakeholders to develop better solutions. Minister-in-charge of Public Service Chan Chun Sing announced the change, aiming to champion innovation, test-bed new ideas, and improve public services. The public sector agencies are developing plans to transform their operations, with a focus on innovation, digital literacy, and data analytics. The government will also maintain a sound and sustainable fiscal system, while driving Singapore's development as an international legal services hub and reviewing its laws to remain progressive and modern.

site_title: China's foreign policy principles under stress
summary: China's foreign policy principles, centered on peaceful coexistence and non-interference, are facing increasing tension with its expanding global involvement. The country's investments and presence in countries like South Sudan, Pakistan, and Myanmar have led to criticism of its role in supporting authoritarian regimes and suppressing minority groups. China's growing economic stakes and nationalist sentiment may prompt it to abandon its commitment to non-interference, potentially leading to a shift in its foreign policy approach, similar to that of other powerful states.

site_title: A united front on North Korea and trade, but sticking points remain
summary: Leaders from Japan, China, and South Korea agreed on a united front on North Korea and free trade, but a joint declaration was delayed due to differing opinions on denuclearisation. They stressed a peaceful and prosperous East Asia, with Japan advocating for strict UN Security Council sanctions and China promoting a resumption of dialogue. The three nations also vowed to uphold free trade and speed up efforts for a trilateral pact, with China set to chair the next summit.

site_title: Facebook undergoes major management overhaul
summary: Facebook has undergone a major management overhaul following a data privacy scandal. Co-founder Mark Zuckerberg remains CEO, with Sheryl Sandberg as his second-in-command. Chris Cox, a longtime member of Zuckerberg's inner circle, now oversees core applications and services. Facebook has reshaped its product and engineering teams into three units, including an emerging technologies division focused on blockchain. David Marcus is stepping down from Messenger and will explore blockchain, while Javier Olivan handles security and ads across various services. No executives are leaving the company.

site_title: Uniqlo targets 1.2b customers with first store in India
summary: Uniqlo, owned by FAST Retailing Co, plans to open its first store in India in autumn 2019, targeting 1.2 billion consumers. This move aims to tap into the large Indian market. The New Delhi store is the company's long-planned entry into the country.

site_title: Japan real wages rise in positive sign for consumption
summary: Japan's inflation-adjusted real wages rose 0.8% in March, marking the first increase in four months, suggesting a gradual increase in salaries that could boost consumer spending. The move is encouraging for the Bank of Japan, which is struggling to achieve its 2% inflation target. However, the jobless rate would need to fall to around 1.5% to see wage growth consistent with the BOJ's goal. A planned sales tax hike in 2019 may dampen domestic demand, potentially slowing wage growth.

site_title: GIC, Canadian pension fund buy Seoul office building for 418b won
summary: GIC and the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPPIB) have entered into a joint venture partnership to buy the Grade A office building Kumho Asiana Main Tower in Seoul for 418 billion Korean won (S$520.1 million). The duo will each own a 50-per-cent stake in the property, located in the centre of Gwanghwamun, a core office and cultural precinct in Seoul's central business district. This investment reflects their confidence in South Korea's continued growth and commitment to identifying attractive opportunities in the market.

site_title: O&G equities up as oil jumps on Trump's ditching of Iran nuclear deal
summary: US President Donald Trump announced the US withdrawal from the Iran nuclear deal and re-imposed sanctions on Iran, causing oil prices to surge 3.1% and Brent crude to reach its highest level in over three years. Oil and gas-related stocks rose, but analysts caution that these gains may be short-lived, with market uncertainty and potential supply disruptions from US sanctions. The market is waiting for clarity on the impact of the sanctions, and analysts predict that significant re-ratings of O&G-related stocks will only occur when Brent oil reaches the $80s.

site_title: China ramps up checks on US pork imports
summary: China has increased inspections of US pork imports, with some trade experts believing Beijing is sending a defiant warning to Washington in response to US trade demands. The checks, which have been applied to China's WH Group Ltd, the world's largest pork company, have significantly lengthened the time the product stays at the port, with some shipments sitting for up to two weeks. The US is one of China's top overseas pork suppliers, with $489 million worth of the meat shipped last year.

site_title: US has duty to enforce Iran nuclear deal, not derail it
summary: US President Donald Trump announced the country's withdrawal from the Iran nuclear deal, a landmark accord signed in 2015, and reinstated sanctions on Tehran. The move is expected to undermine peace and denuclearization efforts, potentially escalating regional tensions and sparking a nuclear arms race in the Middle East. Analysts warn that the US sanctions could severely impact European and Asian countries' trading relationships with Iran, and that a significant deal with North Korea, Trump's upcoming summit, may be more challenging due to North Korea's existing nuclear arsenal.

site_title: China Aviation Oil posts 14% rise in Q1 profit
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a 13.9% increase in Q1 net profit to US$26.9 million, driven by a 23.9% rise in revenue to US$4.1 billion. Earnings per share increased to 3.13 US cents from 2.75 US cents in the previous year. However, gross profit decreased 14.6% to US$13.2 million due to lower profits from trading and optimisation activities. CAO's CEO expressed confidence in the company's financial performance, despite macroeconomic uncertainties, and reiterated its focus on transportation fuels and asset investment strategy.

site_title: Twenty-two apartments at former AA Centre seeking up to S$90 million
summary: Singapore's 336 River Valley Road, a 14-storey freehold residential cum commercial development, has 22 private apartments up for bulk sale by tender with indicative prices ranging from S$86 million to S$90 million. The site, zoned for residential use, offers 49,805 sq ft of potential space for the buyer. Separately, a row of 9 freehold terrace houses along Quemoy Road is also put up for sale with an indicative price of S$23.87 million. Both sales are expected to close on June 6 and June 12, respectively.

site_title: SGX volumes down despite rising prices, latest numbers show
summary: SGX volumes decreased despite rising prices in April, with average daily value of trades increasing 12% to S$1.3 billion and the Straits Times Index gaining 14%. Actual trading activity fell 26% to 1.8 billion shares, while turnover velocity remained unchanged. In contrast, the derivatives market saw a 9% increase in average daily trading volume.

site_title: Put a value on Xiaomi, then subtract some
summary: Xiaomi Corp is set to list in Hong Kong with a valuation between $60 billion and $100 billion, making it the world's biggest float since Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. However, the company's dual-class stock structure gives chairman and CEO Lei Jun and his co-founders majority control, leaving little say for minorities. This structure has raised concerns about corporate governance and investors should be cautious of key-person risk and stretched valuations.

site_title: Oxley to redevelop Dublin city centre site
summary: Oxley Holdings, a Singapore-based developer, will redevelop a 1.96-hectare site in Dublin's city centre as part of an agreement with Córas Iompair Éireann. The site, near Connolly Station, will feature mixed-use properties including residential, commercial, and hotel spaces. Oxley will receive a 300-year ground lease and pay an annual site licence fee of 2 million euros. The project is expected to benefit the developer, government, and local users, with Ching Chiat Kwong stating it will bring long-term income growth for Oxley.
