summary: Singapore's fourth-generation leaders have outlined their priorities for the second half of the government's term, reflecting a shift towards bold policy changes. The key priorities include securing Singapore's place in the world, urban transformation, economic dynamism, and nation building. The younger ministers, who are set to take over the reins within a decade, have emphasized the need for different ideas and strategies to address these ongoing issues in a rapidly changing world. The speech marks a departure from traditional incremental approach, signaling a more forward-thinking approach to governance.

site_title: Fewer women are running funds
summary: Fewer than 10% of US portfolio managers at mutual funds and ETFs are women, according to Morningstar. Despite being underrepresented in the industry, women are more common in other professions such as medicine, law, and accounting. A report by Morningstar and Flowspring found that 25 of the largest US mutual fund companies have a negligible number of female portfolio managers, with some having zero. The lack of women in the industry is a concerning trend, with women being "stuck" at a low percentage, according to Morningstar's head of fund research.

site_title: Oil teeters near US$70 as Trump keeps world guessing on Iran deal
summary: US President Donald Trump's announcement on Tuesday has sent oil prices tumbling as investors weigh the possibility of the US pulling out of the 2015 Iran deal. Oil prices briefly fell below $70, the highest level in 2.5 years, with West Texas Intermediate oil dropping 94 cents to $69.79 a barrel. The uncertainty surrounding Trump's decision has sparked concerns about potential sanctions on OPEC producer Iran, which could impact global oil supply.

site_title: F&N's Q2 earnings quadruple on contributions from associated company
summary: Fraser and Neave's (F&N) Q2 net profit rose to S$15.39 million, quadrupling from S$3.82 million last year, driven by profit contributions from associate company Vinamilk. Revenue increased nearly 5% to S$473.09 million, while earnings per share rose to 1.1 Singapore cents. The company declared an interim dividend of 1.5 Singapore cents per share, unchanged from last year. F&N's directors expect the beverage landscape to remain competitive, but aims to drive growth in core markets and new markets.

site_title: OCBC launches S$20m digital skills training drive
summary: OCBC Bank has launched a S$20 million digital skills training drive to train all 29,000 employees globally over three years, aiming to attain digital competency. The OCBC Future Smart Programme will focus on seven digital domains and four qualification standards, with employees expected to reach minimum competency by the end of the first year. The initiative also includes a "gig" approach, allowing employees to work on consulting jobs with teams running digital projects.

site_title: Xiaomi poised to become a billionaire factory with HK IPO
summary: Xiaomi is set to become a billion-dollar company with a Hong Kong IPO, valuing the firm at $50 billion to $100 billion. This would make Lei Jun, the company's chairman and CEO, and his co-founders billionaires. A $100 billion valuation would create five new billionaires, including Lei Jun, who would also become China's fourth-richest person. The company's IPO is expected to be the largest since 2014, but the market's appetite for tech companies is uncertain, with some analysts questioning whether investors will accept Xiaomi as more than just a cheap phone maker.

images.alt_text: A valuation at the higher end of Xiaomi's expected range depends on investors accepting the company as an Internet darling and not just a maker of cheap phones, says Mo Jia, an analyst at Canalys in Shanghai.

site_title: Surging US dollar back to haunt emerging markets
summary: A resurgent US dollar and higher borrowing costs are negatively impacting emerging markets, particularly Argentina and Turkey, by devaluing their currencies. This shift reverses the three-year trend of declining interest rates, which was fueled by a strong global economy and rising commodity prices. The surge in dollar costs increases the likelihood that the interest rate cutting cycle in emerging markets is ending, and could lead to a bond market downturn.

site_title: Post-industrial capitalism calls for new economic model for Singapore
summary: Singapore's economy, once driven by state-led, export-oriented growth, is facing challenges from global and domestic trends. The US's protectionist policies, EU and China's state-driven industrial policies, and technological disruption from robotics and AI are impacting international trade and investment. Singapore's high-cost location, ageing population, and shrinking manufacturing share are also hindering economic growth. To adapt, Singapore needs a new economic model that focuses on services, regional consumption, and locally-based private entrepreneurship. The state should prioritize privatization, downsizing, and developing local SMEs, while facilitating innovation and entrepreneurship.

site_title: What, why, and when to automate
summary: Automation is poised to have a significant impact on business and personal lives in the next decade. Technologists and consumers are embracing its potential in various industries, from retail to transportation. Many business and IT leaders have already begun to leverage automation in their operations. The rise of AI is also driving innovation, with companies setting up AI-focused innovation hubs and launching new AI-related products and services. As automation continues to evolve, it is expected to bring about changes in various sectors, including education and healthcare.

site_title: ValueAct builds US$1.2b stake in undervalued Citigroup
summary: ValueAct Capital Management has acquired a $1.2 billion stake in Citigroup, arguing the bank is undervalued and poised for success by providing essential services to multinational corporations. The stake was built over the past four months, with the activist fund continuing to add to its position. ValueAct believes the market undervalues Citigroup, contrary to its own assessment.

site_title: Market snaps 3-day losing streak
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) snapped a three-day losing streak, rising 10.31 points, or 0.29%, to 3,543.17. Local banks' Q1 earnings left investors mixed on the potential for interest rate hikes. Analysts from Phillip Securities and OCBC cautioned that geopolitical risks and US President Donald Trump's expected announcement on a disarmament arrangement could support higher crude oil prices. Despite this, analysts maintained a positive outlook on the sector, with DBS and UOB showing gains, while OCBC Bank fell.

site_title: All on board the global reporting standard
summary: Singapore financial institutions are set to report to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore under the Common Reporting Standard (CRS), a global standard for automatic exchange of financial account information. The CRS aims to tackle global tax evasion by exchanging financial information between countries. Correct classification of entities is crucial, as it determines the amount and type of information to be collected and reported. Boutique wealth managers, such as family offices and funds, face particular challenges in classifying and reporting correctly due to the complexity of their structures. Non-compliance can result in severe penalties, including fines and imprisonment, and may also lead to client complaints and legal action.

site_title: Rival ride-hailing ventures rush into Manila gridlock after Grab deal with Uber
summary: Rival ride-hailing ventures, including Hype Transport Systems and Ipara Technologies and Solutions, are entering the Manila market, following Grab's acquisition of Uber's operations in the Philippines. The regulator has approved five new entrants since the deal. These new entrants aim to compete with Grab's dominance in the market, despite the acquisition.

site_title: Malaysia Elections: A guide to the 'do-or-die' election
summary: Malaysia is holding its general election, with 15 million voters choosing 222 parliamentary seats and 505 state seats. The ruling Barisan Nasional (BN) coalition, led by Prime Minister Najib Razak, faces off against the opposition Pakatan Harapan (PH) coalition, led by former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. The election aims to determine control of Parliament and state assemblies, with BN seeking a simple majority in Parliament. Results are expected to start trickling in from 9pm on May 9, with a clearer picture emerging after midnight.

site_title: Global connectivity will boost Singapore's economy, create jobs
summary: Singapore's government plans to enhance its transport network and connectivity to boost the economy and create jobs. The country aims to anchor itself as a world-class air hub and International Maritime Centre, investing in airport and port expansions. Plans also include developing cycling networks, introducing bike-sharing operators, and reviewing licensing frameworks for private-hire cars and e-scooters. Additionally, the government will focus on creating a "smarter, greener and more liveable city" through new regional centres and the deployment of advanced technologies such as autonomous vehicles and smart energy grids.

site_title: Who's who in the Cannes film festival jury
summary: The jury of the 2018 Cannes Film Festival is led by Cate Blanchett, the first majority-female and all-woman jury president, amidst a year marked by the #MeToo movement. The 9-member jury also includes Ava DuVernay, Kristen Stewart, Chang Chen, Khadja Nin, Robert Guediguian, Lea Seydoux, Denis Villeneuve, and Andrei Zvyagintsev, showcasing a diverse range of talent from film, music, and literature.

site_title: Lower palm product prices dent Bumitama Agri's Q1
summary: Bumitama Agri, a palm oil producer, reported a 16.8% decline in its Q1 net profit to 231.77 billion rupiah (S$22.1 million) due to lower sales prices of palm products and increased expenses. The company's higher general and administrative costs, finance costs, and foreign exchange losses also contributed to the decline. The results were released on May 8, 2018.

site_title: Ava Towers to launch en bloc sale bid with reserve price at S$248m
summary: Ava Towers, a freehold condominium in Singapore's Balestier area, is up for tender with a reserve price of S$248 million (S$1,374 psf ppr). The site can be redeveloped up to 180,519 sq ft with a proposed plot ratio of 2.8. The winning developer can retain the existing structure or rebuild with at least 215 units averaging 753 sq ft. The tender opens on May 16 and closes on July 2.

site_title: Ingram Micro ties up with Microsoft to launch cloud platform division
summary: Ingram Micro has partnered with Microsoft to launch CloudBlue, a cloud computing service division powered by Microsoft Azure. The division, resulting from over $500 million in investment, will focus on selling its cloud commerce platform and services to service providers. CloudBlue comprises hundreds of experts in engineering, product management, and sales. The partnership aims to expand Ingram Micro's offerings in the cloud computing market.

site_title: Hong Kong IPO flop a warning for punters in Xiaomi mega deal
summary: Hong Kong's popular investment strategy of borrowing and investing in initial public offerings (IPOs) is failing, with recent flops including Ping An Healthcare & Technology Co's IPO. The strategy, which involves buying stocks before they list, has proven unprofitable, with three-quarters of companies raising funds in the city this year dropping below their listing price. This trend is expected to continue with Xiaomi Corp's upcoming $10 billion IPO, which is expected to be highly anticipated but potentially disappointing for investors.

site_title: Don't overlook the ferry sector
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has committed to reducing greenhouse gas emissions from international shipping, aiming to phase them out as soon as possible in this century. The organization also adjusted the Energy Efficiency Design Index (EEDI) formula for roll-on roll-off (ro-ro) and roll-on/roll-off passenger ferries (ro-pax) after discovering errors in the initial dataset, applying a 20% correction to incentivize newbuild projects. The move is expected to have a positive impact on the ferry sector, which is vital to the global economy and often pioneers new technology.

site_title: Panel expects more women in board roles
summary: A panel discussion in Singapore emphasized the growing importance of women in the digital economy, citing the need for multi-disciplinary skills in the face of digitalization. Panelists, including Singtel's chairman and former GovTech CEO, agreed that women are naturally keener learners and should be given opportunities to take on new roles. They also highlighted the need for women to project confidence and be prepared to take leadership roles, and encouraged businesses to provide equal opportunities and create awareness about the importance of diversity in the digital workforce.

images.alt_text: Members of the discussion panel were (from left) Janet Ang, panel moderator and vice-president of industry solutions and business development in IBM Asia-Pacific; Jacqueline Poh, former chief executive of GovTech; Khai Lin Sng, co-founder and chief financial officer of Fundnel; and Singtel chairman Simon Israel.

site_title: Singapore fintech CCRManager wins backing from ex-Temasek banker
summary: Singapore-based fintech CCRManager has secured Series A funding of US$6.5 million from investors led by ex-Temasek banker Francis Rozario. The company aims to expand its platform in secondary trade loans, worth US$1.7 trillion, and plans to hit US$10 billion in transaction volume by the end of the year. CCRManager has already handled over US$2 billion in transactions, and the new funding will support its growth in the global financial community.

site_title: New digital ad marketplace by SPH and Mediacorp goes live
summary: Singapore Media Exchange (SMX), a digital advertising marketplace between SPH and Mediacorp, launched on May 8, 2018. The platform uses programmatic technology to serve ads on multiple websites, including those of SPH's Business Times and Straits Times, and Mediacorp's Channel NewsAsia and Today Online. With a combined reach of three-fourths of digital consumers in Singapore, SMX aims to deliver a premium, brand-safe alternative for programmatic buyers. The platform has a multi-screening capability and plans to invest in new features and explore tie-ups with other premium publishers.

site_title: Malaysia Elections: Latest polls show tight contest
summary: Malaysia's general election is expected to be a tight contest between Pakatan Harapan, led by Mahathir Mohamad, and Barisan Nasional, led by Najib Razak. According to recent polls, Pakatan Harapan is projected to win 43.4% of the popular vote, while Barisan Nasional is expected to receive 37.3%. The election is seen as a personal test for Najib, who faces corruption allegations and opposition from Mahathir, who backed him to replace his predecessor. A victory for Mahathir would be a significant upset, potentially ending Najib's rule and clearing his name.

site_title: Oxley signs lease deal for Dublin site
summary: OXLEY Holdings has signed a 7-year lease agreement with Córas Iompair Éireann (CIE) for a 1,963-hectare site in Dublin. The site, part of Connolly Station, will be developed in phases, with CIE granting Oxley a 300-year ground lease. Oxley will pay an annual licence fee of 2-3.05 million euros, plus a rent of 3.05 million euros or 10% of gross income, whichever is higher. The development costs will be funded by internal resources and bank borrowings.

site_title: Trek 2000 International reports 56% drop in Q1 profit; independent director resigns
summary: Trek 2000 International reported a 56% drop in Q1 profit to US$552,000, with revenue plummeting 80% to US$8.4 million due to a strategic component supply shortage. The company is diversifying its supplier base to mitigate risks. Earnings per share fell to 0.17 US cent. Independent director Loh Yih resigned due to difficulties in information verification. The Singapore Exchange demanded an extraordinary general meeting to vote on the continued appointment of key executives implicated in a recent forensic review of the company's dealings.

site_title: Perennial Q1 profit falls 86.7% in absence of one-off gain
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings reported an 86.7% decline in Q1 net profit to S$5.14 million due to the absence of a one-off gain from the partial divestment of TripleOne Somerset. Revenue fell 26.1% to S$14.95 million, mainly due to the absence of revenue from TripleOne Somerset. However, revenue from other assets, such as Perennial Qingyang Mall and China retail and office portfolio, showed growth. The company's earnings before interest and tax (EBIT) increased to S$24.4 million, excluding the TripleOne Somerset divestment gain.

site_title: Widening cracks in euro sends US dollar to 2018 highs
summary: The US dollar surged to a 2018 high against its rivals, rising 4.5% in three weeks, as a rout of the euro prompted traders to buy the greenback. The euro fell by half a percent to its lowest levels since December, while sterling also declined due to waning expectations of a Bank of England rate increase. The US dollar's rally was driven by expectations of monetary policy normalization, but underlying caution remained due to investors' focus on US President Trump's decision on an international nuclear agreement with Iran.

site_title: Pacific Star Development's net profit rises 9.5 % to S$2.5m
summary: Pacific Star Development's net profit increased 9.5% to S$2.5 million in its fifth quarter ended March 31. Earnings per share dropped to 0.49 Singapore cents from 0.71 Singapore cents in the previous year due to an enlargement of shares. The company changed its financial year to end in June 30, from December 31, in November 2017.

site_title: Fighting chance to power ahead
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to experience strong growth in 2018, driven by both domestic and external sectors, despite ongoing global uncertainties. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has maintained a cautious tone, tightening its monetary policy to anchor the Singapore dollar. The MAS projects a 3.3% economic growth for 2018, with the services sector expected to contribute to the growth. However, the ongoing global trade tensions pose a significant risk to the economy, and the MAS is unlikely to adopt an overly hawkish stance.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower ahead of Trump Iran decision
summary: US stocks opened lower on May 8, 2018, due to a decline in technology and consumer discretionary stocks. The Dow Jones fell 15.97 points, the S&P 500 dropped 2.37 points, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 9.87 points. Investors awaited President Donald Trump's decision on the Iran nuclear deal, which weighed on market sentiment.

site_title: Standard Life says Lloyds didn't have right to pull US$147b
summary: Standard Life Aberdeen is disputing Lloyds Banking Group's decision to withdraw $197.3 billion in assets, citing the bank's claim that the combined firm is a competitor to its insurance business. The merger aimed to create a $1 trillion asset manager, but the bank's move could reduce assets under management by 20%. Standard Life is seeking arbitration, while Lloyds claims the arrangement is a "pointless exercise" and that the bank should move on. The decision is set to end by mid-2019 unless reversed.

site_title: Jay-Z, accused of dodging SEC subpoenas, due in court
summary: Rapper Jay-Z has been ordered to appear in court after the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) accused him of dodging subpoenas related to an investigation into the sale of his Rocawear clothing line. Jay-Z claims his testimony would hinder his global tour preparations and is not relevant to the investigation. The SEC counters that Jay-Z has been avoiding inquiries for months and should not be given an artificial time limit. Jay-Z sold Rocawear for $204 million in 2007 and the SEC is looking into writedowns totaling that amount.

site_title: F&N posts higher Q2 profit
summary: F&N's second-quarter net profit surged to S$15.39 million, up from S$3.82 million a year ago, driven by higher share of profits from associated companies and broad-based sales growth. Revenue rose 5% to S$473.09 million, and earnings per share increased to 1.1 Singapore cents. The company also reported a 63% profit-before-interest-and-tax jump to S$36.3 million, with a 58% increase in half-year net profit to S$41.48 million.

site_title: PACC Offshore slashes Q1 losses
summary: PACC Offshore Services Holdings (POSH) reported a narrowed Q1 loss of US$7.19 million, up from US$18.57 million in the same period last year, due to increased revenue of US$70.56 million. The company attributed the growth to higher vessel utilisation in its offshore supply vessels, accommodation, and transportation and installation segments. Despite charter rates expected to remain under pressure, POSH noted positive indicators, including increased oil and gas capital expenditure due to firmer oil prices and improved financial performance of oil companies.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: US President Trump's 50% copper import tariff affects refined metal, not raw material. Oil prices rose over 2% due to market uncertainty, tariffs, and sanctions. In the US, stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, with an operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Addvalue Technologies appoints Hong Leong Finance as sponsor for proposed spin-off, listing of unit
summary: Addvalue Technologies has appointed Hong Leong Finance as the full sponsor for the proposed spin-off and listing of its wholly-owned subsidiary, Addvalue Solutions, on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange. The spin-off will reward shareholders proportionately with free AVS shares. The company has also secured new IDRS airtime distribution agreements with Inmarsat and a US-based aerospace company, and inked its first major commercial IDRS contract with a global satellite service provider.

site_title: EU restates support for nuclear deal in talks with Iran
summary: The EU reiterated its support for the Iran nuclear deal in talks with Tehran just hours before US President Donald Trump's announcement on whether to pull out of the accord. EU officials, including Britain, Germany, France, and a senior EU official, met with Iran's deputy foreign minister Abbas Araghchi in Brussels, reaffirming their commitment to the deal's full implementation. The talks aimed to avoid "uncontrolled escalation" after Trump's decision was announced, with a German source emphasizing the importance of continued dialogue in the coming days.

site_title: Ascott forms JV with Huazhu Hotels, CJIA Apartments to grow Citadines in China
summary: Ascott forms a joint venture with Huazhu Hotels and CJIA Apartments to expand its Citadines brand in China, targeting 16,000 units by 2025. The joint venture, with an initial registered capital of 100 million yuan, will focus on manachise, a hybrid of franchise and management contract. The partnership aims to boost Ascott's recurring fee income and expand its presence in first-tier cities such as Shanghai, Beijing, and Shenzhen. This move is expected to more than triple Ascott's existing Citadines portfolio in China.

site_title: Kimly's Q2 profit up 20%
summary: Kimly, a Catalist-listed coffee shop operator, reported a 20% year-on-year rise in net profit to S$5.45 million for Q2 2018, driven by higher other operating income and lower administrative expenses. Revenue increased 4% to S$49.18 million, while earnings per share edged up to 0.47 cent. The company declared an interim dividend of 0.28 cent per share. Net profit for the six-month period remained flat at S$11.2 million, with revenue rising 5.3% to S$99.33 million.

site_title: Trump's fake Nobel nomination to remain a mystery
summary: The Norwegian police closed an investigation into Donald Trump's fake Nobel Peace Prize nomination after failing to identify the person behind it. The nomination, filed earlier this year, was deemed "openly fraudulent" and lacked sufficient information to identify the culprit. Despite this, Trump still has a chance to be nominated next year, with 18 House Republicans nominating him for his work to end the Korean War and bring peace to the region.

images.alt_text: The Norwegian police said Tuesday they had closed an investigation into Donald Trump's fake Nobel Peace Prize nomination after failing to identify the person behind it.

site_title: May backs Johnson after he attacks her 'crazy' Brexit trade plan
summary: Theresa May has expressed confidence in Boris Johnson after he criticized her post-Brexit trade plan as "crazy". The UK foreign secretary's comments came after the proposal was rejected by most of her Cabinet and euroskeptics. May's spokesman stated that good discussions took place last week and the government is working to refine models. Despite the setback, the UK aims to leave the customs union by December 2020.

site_title: Ava Towers in Balestier to launch en bloc sale at reserve price of S$248m
summary: Ava Towers, a 124-unit freehold condominium in Balestier, is up for sale through an en bloc collective sale at a reserve price of S$248 million. The site has a high development baseline, with no development charge payable for redevelopment up to a gross plot ratio of 2.8. The winning developer will have the option to retain the structure or rebuild with a minimum of 215 units averaging 753 sq ft. The tender opens on May 16 and closes on July 2.

site_title: EU plans to shield its companies if Trump ditches Iran deal
summary: The European Union has plans to protect its companies in case US President Donald Trump announces pulling out of the Iran nuclear deal. EU spokeswoman Maja Kocijancic said they are working on plans to shield European companies from potential US sanctions on Iran. The EU has urged the US to preserve the agreement and negotiate side-deals to address concerns. If the US withdraws, the EU may establish procedures to allow companies to trade with Iran, including euro-denominated credit lines and clearing-houses. This move aims to entice Iran to stay in the deal and maintain global security.

site_title: OCBC launches S$20m programme to train all its 29,000 employees in digital skills
summary: OCBC Bank has launched a S$20 million programme to train 29,000 employees globally in digital skills over three years. The OCBC Future Smart Programme focuses on seven digital domains and four qualification levels, aiming for employees to attain minimum competency by the end of the first year. The initiative includes online programmes, workshops, and freelance consulting opportunities, with the goal of creating a strong learning culture and ensuring digital competencies for survival in the industry.

site_title: VW's Audi finds emissions problem with another 60,000 cars
summary: Audi has discovered emissions-related problems with an additional 60,000 cars, primarily A6 and A7 models with a certain type of diesel engine. The issue was identified after a previously unidentified problem with emissions software was found. Audi has halted deliveries of the affected models and will recall 60,000 cars for a software update. This brings the total number of vehicles affected by the "dieselgate" scandal to over 900,000, with Audi's parent company Volkswagen facing further challenges in addressing the emissions issue.

site_title: Market is 'well aligned' with central bank's rate dot plot, says Fed chief
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated that financial markets are "well aligned" with the central bank's interest-rate increase plan. Markets should not be surprised by the Fed's actions if the economy evolves as expected. The gradual pace of tightening has kept financial conditions easy, supporting labor market and economic growth while moving inflation towards the 2% target. Powell warned that investors may not be well-positioned for interest rate rises, and risk sentiment will be closely watched as normalization proceeds globally.

site_title: Riverstone Holdings posts 7.6% fall in Q1 profit
summary: Riverstone Holdings, a manufacturer of cleanroom and healthcare gloves, reported a 7.6% year-on-year decline in Q1 net profit to RM31.08 million, despite a 2% rise in revenue to RM209.82 million. The company attributed the decline to adverse foreign exchange conditions, lower average selling prices, and increased production costs. Despite this, the group plans to expand production capacity in Perak to nine billion gloves by year-end and add another 1.4 billion pieces by 2019.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's stocks closed higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 18.31 points to 1,846.5. Volume reached 2.35 billion shares worth RM2.80 billion, with gainers outnumbering losers 677 to 281.

site_title: China's Xi, North Korea's Kim meet ahead of Trump summit
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un met in China, signaling warming ties ahead of Kim's summit with US President Donald Trump. The meeting comes as Beijing seeks to maintain its central role in the diplomatic shuffle, with Xi expressing support for North Korea's adherence to denuclearization and economic development. The two leaders also discussed the possibility of a US-North Korea summit in Singapore, with Kim expressing hope for "phased and synchronous measures" to achieve denuclearization and peace.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Kim Jong Un met in China for the second time in six weeks on Tuesday, signalling their warming ties ahead of the North Korean leader's expected summit with US President Donald Trump.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore condo resale prices rose 0.6% in April to a 12-month high, while sales volume dipped 1.7%. OCBC Bank launched a US$20m digital skills training program for 29,000 employees. Minister S Iswaran urged countries to stand against anti-globalization sentiment amidst trade tensions. Fintech CCRManager secured US$6.5m funding, while Keppel DC Reit's private placement was oversubscribed. Singapore shares closed up 0.29% on Tuesday, driven by oil price increases.

site_title: CFO, certain directors of Raffles United Holdings interviewed by CAD
summary: Raffles United Holdings' CFO and two directors, Teo Teng Beng and Teo Xian-Hui Amanda Marie, have been interviewed by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) in relation to potential breaches of the Securities and Futures Act. The company also stated that it will continue to cooperate with the CAD's investigation, which will not affect its business operations. Additionally, certain staff and former staff have been interviewed. The company has provided a bond to report back to the CAD on May 17.

site_title: EON confirms 2018 targets after surge in customers
summary: German energy giant EON reported a 38% increase in adjusted net profits to 727 million euros in the first quarter of 2018, driven by a surge in new customers. The company's underlying operating profits rose 24% to 1.3 billion euros. Despite a 11% decline in revenues, EON reaffirmed its 2018 targets, citing a strong start to the year. The company expects to meet its adjusted operating profit and net profit targets of 2.8-3.0 billion euros and 1.3-1.5 billion euros, respectively.

site_title: African growth picks up but debt a concern, says IMF
summary: IMF reports African growth to rise to 3.4% in 2018, with top performers including Benin, Burkina Faso, Ethiopia, and others. However, debt remains a major concern, with 15 of 35 low-income countries at risk of debt distress. The continent's poorest countries face spending constraints and failed efforts to address macroeconomic problems. Average medium-term growth is expected to level off below 4%, far short of Sustainable Development Goals.

site_title: Singapore shares close up by 0.29% on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.29% to 3,543.17 points, driven by a potential return to sanctions on Iran. Oil prices surged, while OCBC Bank fell 0.68% and ComfortDelGro gained 3.65%. Mermaid Maritime also increased by 1.47%. The market saw a mixed performance, with 1.75 billion shares worth S$1.17 billion traded, with losers beating gainers 207-200.

site_title: Beauty products gloss over Zalando earnings squeeze
summary: European online fashion retailer Zalando reported a 22% sales increase to 1.196 billion euros in its first quarter, slightly ahead of analyst forecasts. However, adjusted earnings before interest and taxation fell to 0.4 million euros due to a loss in non-core markets. The company attributed the loss to a delayed spring/summer season and heavy investment in new warehouses and technology. Despite this, Zalando maintained its forecast for 20-25% reported sales growth and an adjusted EBIT of 220-270 million euros. The launch of beauty products in Germany showed promising results.

site_title: Xiaomi poised to become a billionaire factory with Hong Kong IPO
summary: Xiaomi, founded by Lei Jun and seven others in 2010, is set to become a billionaire factory with a Hong Kong IPO valued at $50 billion to $100 billion, creating 3-5 new billionaires. The company, known for affordable smartphones, aims to challenge Apple and Samsung dominance. With a 31.4% stake, Lei Jun could reach a net worth of $28.3 billion, making him China's fourth-richest person. The IPO's success hinges on investor perception of Xiaomi as a tech darling, with analysts warning that market performance has been mixed for Chinese tech companies.

site_title: Europe: London opens higher after break, Shire jumps on Takeda bid
summary: The London stock market opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE 100 index gaining 0.1% to 7,573.15 points. The deal for Shire by Japanese drug giant Takeda boosted shares in the Irish pharmaceutical company, which jumped 4.5%. In contrast, Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 fell 0.2% each.

site_title: Anbang reviewing overseas assets, talking to investment banks
summary: Anbang Insurance Group, a Chinese insurer operating under government control, is reviewing its overseas assets amid reports of imminent divestments. The company is meeting with investment banks as part of the review, reversing previous statements that it wasn't planning any divestments. Anbang's chairman, Wu Xiaohui, was detained in 2016 for leading a $10.4 billion fraud, and the Chinese government has been seeking to sell stakes in companies including Tongyang Life Insurance Co and ABL Life. A review timeline has not been specified.

site_title: Perennial Q1 net profit falls 86.7% in absence of one-off gain
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings reported a 86.7% decline in Q1 net profit to S$5.14 million due to the absence of a one-off gain from the partial divestment of TripleOne Somerset. Revenue fell 26.1% to S$14.95 million, with Perennial Qingyang Mall contributing to a 10.1% increase in revenue. Earnings before interest and tax (EBIT) were S$24.4 million, higher than a year ago excluding the divestment gain. The company has completed the acquisition of Capitol Singapore and is finalizing the hotel operator appointment.

site_title: Armenia's poorest province pins hopes on 'velvet revolution'
summary: In Armenia's poorest province, Shirak, residents express cautious optimism about the country's new prime minister, Nikol Pashinyan, who has promised to tackle widespread poverty and corruption. The province, which has been struggling since a devastating earthquake in 1988, has seen little government support. Pashinyan's "velvet revolution" has transformed Armenian politics, and many hope for change, but the country faces significant economic, political, and security challenges, including high unemployment and a simmering territorial conflict with Azerbaijan.

summary: Swiss-based Nestle has agreed to pay Starbucks Corp US$7.15 billion in cash for exclusive rights to sell the US chain's packaged coffees and teas worldwide. The deal, valued at US$7.15 billion, ties a premium brand to Nestle's global distribution muscle and frees Starbucks to focus on its US cafe business. Starbucks will use the proceeds to increase planned stock buybacks and will receive revenue from product sales and royalties. The alliance is expected to boost Nestle's earnings by 2019 and strengthen its position as the world's largest coffee company.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.35 points to 1,820.85. Losers outnumbered gainers 110 to 50, with volume at 29.33 million lots worth RM14.76 million.

site_title: Melania Trump trolls her husband
summary: Melania Trump unveiled a child-welfare platform, emphasizing the importance of educating children to use their voices wisely and speak with respect. The move is seen as a way to counter her husband's online bullying and extramarital affairs. The first lady's actions have drawn attention to her husband's character flaws, potentially boosting her approval rating. Her ratings have jumped to 57%, surpassing her husband's numbers, as she asserts her power and influence as a figure in the White House. The move is also seen as a way for her to shame her husband without facing direct confrontation.

site_title: US dollar hits strongest level of 2018 as euro falls
summary: The US dollar reached its strongest level of 2018, reaching 92.974 against a basket of currencies, as investors bet on rising interest rates and inflation in the US. Speculators reduced bets on a falling dollar, while analysts warned the dollar's recent bounce may be overdone. The euro fell to a four-month low at $1.1896, while the British pound rose 0.27% to $1.3562, following disappointing economic data in the eurozone and the UK.

site_title: Tokyo stocks open mixed
summary: Tokyo stocks opened mixed on May 8, 2018, as US President Donald Trump's potential departure from the Iran nuclear deal weighed on the market. The Nikkei 225 index edged down 0.06% to 22,453.29, while the Topix index rose 0.11% to 1,775.15.

site_title: US hedge fund Elliott Management offers to buy Athenahealth
summary: US hedge fund Elliott Management has proposed to acquire Athenahealth for $6.9 billion, citing the company's chronic underperformance and reluctance to engage in private talks. Elliott already owns 8.9% of Athenahealth and believes going private is the best option for the company. The proposal was met with a 16.4% surge in Athenahealth shares, and analysts predict high support from shareholders for the offer, which is in cash.

site_title: MAS teams up with EDB, IMDA and IBF to speed up AI adoption in Singapore's financial sector
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has partnered with the Economic Development Board (EDB), Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA), and Institute of Banking and Finance (IBF) to accelerate AI adoption in Singapore's financial sector. The quartet aims to foster a thriving AI ecosystem, develop AI products, and strengthen AI capabilities. The partnership will facilitate research and development, and encourage leading AI solution providers to create new products and services for the financial sector.

site_title: French govt urges Air France to pursue reforms as strikes bite
summary: French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire urged Air France to pursue reforms to become more competitive, warning the airline risks disappearing if it doesn't. Strikes have cost the company 300 million euros, with staff rejecting a pay deal offering a 7% wage increase over four years. Le Maire called the union demands unjustified and stated the French state will not bail out the airline. The carrier's CEO resigned, and the group's board is set to decide on a plan to fill the management vacuum on May 15.

site_title: Xi-Modi summit may point way to new 'Pacific Asian century' - without America
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi met in Wuhan, China, in April 2018 to discuss a "reset" of their Sino-Indian relationship, aiming to become leaders of the "Asian century" in the new era. China views India's democratic governance as chaotic and inefficient, while India sees China's model as more effective. The meeting marked a shift in India's foreign policy, prioritizing cooperation with China over the US. The summit may pave the way for a new era of Asian leadership, potentially leaving the US's traditional influence behind.

site_title: Global rubber prices wallop Halcyon Agri's Q1 earnings
summary: Halcyon Agri Corp reported a significant decline in Q1 earnings due to global rubber price volatility, with net profit from continuing operations plummeting to US$264,000, a 98.3% drop from the year before. Group turnover fell 15.6% to US$429.9 million, and revenue per tonne slid 20.1% year on year. The company attributed the decline to weak rubber prices, despite higher sales volumes from new subsidiaries. Halcyon Agri is cautiously optimistic about an improvement in natural rubber market prices and is reviewing strategic options for restructuring its Thai processing subsidiary.

site_title: HC Surgical dips into IPO proceeds to buy endoscopy practice
summary: HC Surgical Specialists, a medical services group, has reallocated about S$800,000 of its initial public offering (IPO) net proceeds to acquire a 51% equity stake in Jason Lim Endoscopy and Surgery Pte Ltd for S$832,000. The acquisition is subject to conditions, including the appointment of new directors. This deal replaces the group's initial plan to expand its surgical facilities.

site_title: EU said to consider US metal import quotas to avert trade war
summary: The European Union is considering tolerating US metal import quotas to avoid a trade war. EU officials propose that any US limits on steel and aluminium from the bloc be set at 2017 levels, which would impact EU exports worth 6.4 billion euros to the US market. This move highlights the EU's willingness to prioritize short-term economic interests over policy principles to avert a trade war.

site_title: Indonesia's economic growth slower than forecast
summary: Indonesia's economy expanded at 5.06% in the first quarter, slower than forecasted 5.2% growth. The decline was attributed to sluggish consumer spending, but supported by a pick-up in exports last year. The central bank has ruled out further rate cuts due to outflows from emerging markets, raising the prospect of a rate hike. The government forecasts 5.4% growth this year and plans to sustain momentum by assisting low-income groups.

site_title: A star pianist finally lets us see him sweat
summary: Daniil Trifonov's Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall was a resounding triumph, featuring a recital that spanned 20th-century piano works from each decade. Trifonov, known for his effortless playing, was visibly pushed to his limits, sweating heavily during performances of demanding pieces by Rachmaninoff, Liszt, and others. The recital, which included works by Stockhausen, was a testament to Trifonov's mental and physical stamina, and was met with an enthusiastic audience response. The performance showcased Trifonov's impressive range and skill, cementing his reputation as a leading pianist.

site_title: Snap names Amazon's Tim Stone as CFO
summary: Snap Inc. has appointed Tim Stone, a 51-year-old Amazon veteran, as its new Chief Financial Officer, replacing Andrew Vollero. Stone, who led Amazon's Whole Foods acquisition integration, will take charge on May 16. He will have an annual salary of $500,000. Snap's shares rose over 1% after the announcement. CEO Evan Spiegel praised Vollero's contributions to the company's transition to becoming a public company.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: US President Trump has announced a 50% copper import tariff, targeting refined metal. The move comes as investors weigh market outlook and tariffs. Global stock markets are affected, with stocks down in Europe due to bank and healthcare sector concerns, and US stocks edging down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US companies Creative Technology and Wall Street also reported concerns, with Creative warning of below-target revenue and a similar operating loss to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Oil shoots past US$70 as market awaits Trump's call on Iran
summary: Oil prices surged past $70 a barrel for the first time since 2014 as traders await US President Donald Trump's decision on re-imposing sanctions on Iran. The move could stifle Middle East crude exports and tighten the global market balance, potentially supporting higher prices. While Trump has threatened to pull out of the 2015 nuclear deal, he has also signaled openness to negotiation. Oil prices rose 1.4% in New York and London, with West Texas Intermediate oil climbing to $70.69 a barrel.

site_title: Avengers tops box office for 2nd week; fastest to surpass US$1b mark
summary: Avengers: Infinity War has topped the box office for the second consecutive week, earning $112.5 million in the US and Canada. The film has surpassed $1 billion in global ticket sales, becoming the fastest movie to reach this milestone. Its success has turned around the year's box office fortunes, increasing by 5.1% over the same period last year. The film is expected to hold the top spot until the release of Deadpool 2 on May 18, when Disney's Solo: A Star Wars Story is also set to be released.

site_title: Proposed white knights for China Fibretech commit to special audit
summary: China Fibretech, a Singapore-listed company, has secured funding from six new shareholders, including a unit under the Beijing State-Owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission, to conduct a special audit and inject fresh funds. The company plans to issue 50 million new shares, worth S$29.9 million, to improve cash flow and pursue business opportunities. The audit will focus on transactions with three customers and aims to determine if any wrongdoing occurred. The new investors have committed to a special audit to establish accountability and take corrective actions in China.

site_title: Putin sworn in for fourth term as Russian president
summary: Vladimir Putin was sworn in as Russia's president for a fourth term on May 7, 2018, extending his nearly two-decade rule by six years. He won nearly 77% of the vote in March elections, with opposition figure Alexei Navalny banned from running. Putin vowed to revitalize the economy and improve living standards, but faces international disputes and criticism over his rule. The US congratulated him, but emphasized the importance of peaceful assembly and human rights. Putin's term will run until 2024, but he has not yet addressed succession plans.

images.alt_text: Vladimir Putin was sworn in as Russia's president for a fourth term on Monday, extending his almost two-decade rule by another six years at a time of high tension with his Western rivals.

site_title: Residents drawn to cheap rents flee as Hawaii's Kilauea volcano erupts
summary: Residents of Leilani Estates, a Hawaiian neighborhood with cheap rents, are fleeing as the Kilauea volcano erupts, destroying 26 homes and forcing 1,700 to evacuate. The area, with a Zone 1 hazard rating, was once a landing pad for newcomers who couldn't afford Hawaii's high real-estate prices. Geologists predict the eruption could last up to 88 days, similar to 1955's event. Residents, including social worker Jeremy Wilson, are trying to rescue their possessions as the lava flow advances, with some vents expected to close, putting pressure on others.

site_title: Xerox CEO stays in U-turn, setting stage for proxy fight
summary: Xerox CEO Jeff Jacobson and six board members will remain in their positions after a settlement to oust them expired due to a technicality. This setback sets the stage for a proxy fight by activist shareholders Carl Icahn and Darwin Deason, who control over 13% of the company, to improve the terms of a proposed $6.1 billion deal to sell Xerox to Japan's Fujifilm Holdings Corp. The deal, which would see Fujifilm acquire the entire company for a premium, may now be renegotiated, with Icahn and Deason considering legal action against Xerox and Fujifilm.

site_title: Siemens, Idemitsu among suitors drawn to Vietnam energy selloff
summary: Vietnam's state-owned energy companies are attracting interest from international buyers, including Siemens AG and Idemitsu Kosan Co, as the government seeks overseas investment. The companies, which include Vietnam's largest oil and gas firm, are being sold as part of the government's efforts to attract foreign investment. The sale is seen as a key part of Vietnam's efforts to diversify its economy and reduce its dependence on state-owned enterprises.

site_title: Property investment sales could hit S$46b in 2018: Colliers
summary: Singapore's property investment sales market is expected to reach S$46 billion in 2018, a 15% year-on-year growth, beating 2007's record of S$40.187 billion. The first quarter saw a 89% year-on-year increase in total investment sales to S$11 billion, driven by the residential segment, which grew 233% year-on-year to S$9.1 billion. Colliers attributes the growth to collective sales fever and a possible upturn in other segments, with the market expected to grow further in 2019.

site_title: Venezuela inflation hits 13,779%: lawmakers
summary: Venezuela's inflation has reached 13,779% in the past year, according to a study by the opposition-dominated National Assembly, making it the country with the world's highest inflation rate. The government of President Nicolas Maduro has been printing money to address foreign reserve shortages, causing the national currency to become nearly worthless. The International Monetary Fund projects that Venezuela's inflation will top 13,800% this year, and the US Vice-President Mike Pence is expected to announce further sanctions on the country. A new fiscal and exchange rate policy is needed to stabilize the economy.

images.alt_text: The government of President Nicolas Maduro has been printing money as foreign reserves dwindle, and the national currency, the bolivar, has become nearly worthless.

site_title: Nokia acquires US software supplier to expand its base
summary: Nokia has acquired US software supplier SpaceTime Insight, expanding its presence beyond telecoms. SpaceTime provides monitoring and analytics applications to industrial customers, managing millions of devices and assets. The deal, terms of which were not disclosed, marks Nokia's push into the B2B industry. The acquisition will join SpaceTime Insight and its CEO Rob Schilling to Nokia's IoT product unit, with the goal of delivering higher profit margins through software sales. This marks Nokia's latest move to build a standalone software business.

site_title: Overseas expansion is not for all local SMEs
summary: A recent roundtable discussion with four industry leaders highlighted the challenges and strategies for Singaporean SMEs to venture overseas. The top two barriers to expansion are funding and unfamiliarity with foreign markets. To encourage more companies to venture abroad, experts suggest providing assistance in overcoming these hurdles, such as finding the right partners, clarifying funding structures, and analyzing capabilities gaps. Some companies may not be suitable for expansion, and resources should be devoted to transforming local SMEs to enable them to operate effectively in the local environment.

site_title: Boosting infrastructure in Asean with 'patient capital'
summary: Investors are turning to "patient capital" to bridge the infrastructure funding gap in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean), with the region's estimated annual infrastructure spending requirement projected to reach $157 billion between 2016 and 2020. Private sector participation is seen as crucial to bridging the funding gap, with developments including improved political momentum, competition for investments, and the emergence of alternative fundraising solutions such as green bonds. Asean leaders' prioritization of infrastructure development and the growth of renewable energy investments also hold promise, but more work is needed to unlock sustainable investment opportunities.

site_title: Planemakers risk order disruption as Etihad reviews strategy
summary: Etihad Airways, a Middle East carrier, is reviewing its strategy, potentially disrupting dozens of plane orders from Airbus and Boeing. The airline has been struggling financially since 2016, with a nearly $2 billion loss. Etihad is considering options for over 160 aircraft, including swapping models, delaying deliveries, or outright cancellations. The review aims to develop the airline in a sustainable way, according to new CEO Tony Douglas. The airline has 88 Airbus and 78 Boeing jets on order worth tens of billions of dollars, scheduled to start delivery this year.

site_title: Venture snaps back as 'true Valiant' confronts short-sellers
summary: Venture Corp's shares surged 5.36% after a short squeeze following two weeks of panic-selling. The company bought back S$2.26m worth of shares, its first since 2016. An anonymous report, dubbed "Valiant Varriors," claimed Venture derives 30% of revenue from Philip Morris, citing 13.5 million IQOS units sold in 2017. Venture has maintained secrecy about its customer relationships, fueling differing opinions among investors and analysts.

site_title: Singapore to remain 'nation of opportunities', says President
summary: Singaporean President Halimah Yacob emphasized the country's commitment to being a "nation of opportunities" during her maiden address, with four key priorities: renewing the economy, securing Singapore's place in the world, building a well-connected city, and forging a more cohesive society. The government will adapt to changing economic conditions, invest in research and development, and prioritize entrepreneurship and education. President Halimah also highlighted the importance of maintaining good relations with the US and China, as well as regional partners, to ensure peace and security.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit to raise S$303m from private placement to acquire Jurong data centre
summary: Keppel DC Reit is raising S$303.1 million through a private placement to acquire a 99% stake in Jurong data centre, located in Singapore. The acquisition, valued at S$309.6 million, will boost the Reit's footprint in Singapore to nearly 300,000 sq ft of aggregate lettable area. The centre has a 67.7% occupancy rate and will be renamed Keppel DC Singapore 5, with a subsidiary appointed as master lessee and facility manager.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Two Singaporean brokers, RHB Research and DBS Group Research, have released buy recommendations for Japan Foods Holding (JFH) and Singtel. JFH is expected to deliver 10-15% annual earnings growth and is trading at a significant discount to its industry peers. Its dividend yield is the highest amongst SGX-listed peers. DBS Group Research, however, trims its earnings forecast for Singtel due to potential losses from its digital businesses, but notes its core business is undervalued. Both companies are seen as having growth potential, but are subject to risks such as rising labor costs and lower consumer spending.

site_title: STI starts the week on cautious note
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 12.5 points or 0.35% to close at 3,532.86 on Monday, marking the third consecutive day of losses. The decline was attributed to cautious market sentiment ahead of US renegotiation of trade deals with Mexico and Canada, as well as Malaysian elections. Key data releases, including foreign exchange reserves and retail sales, are also expected to impact the market this week.

site_title: Asian buyers paid top dollar for seasonal jet fuel since 2008
summary: Asian buyers are paying record-high premiums for seasonal jet fuel, with a premium of $1.01 per barrel above benchmark quotes in Singapore, the highest since 2008. Strong air-passenger traffic, driven by increasing affluence and better infrastructure, supports demand growth, with Asia's passenger traffic rising 12% in March. Refiners are benefiting from high demand, with the jet fuel crack reaching $15.75 per barrel above benchmark Dubai crude, but airline profits may be threatened by the high fuel prices.

images.alt_text: A technician attaching a jet fuel supply pipe to an outlet in the tarmac at Changi Airport. Analysts are confident Asia will remain the cornerstone for global jet fuel demand expansion in the coming decades. In March alone, Asia's passenger traffic rose by 12% compared to last year.

site_title: Startup aims to take the blues out of retail logistics
summary: Startup blu aims to revolutionize retail logistics by providing end-to-end solutions, including self-service pick-ups, order management, and inventory management. Founded by Prashant Dadlani, blu has 67 automated parcel lockers (bluPorts) and partners with logistics companies like DHL. The company's system, bluPortal, integrates with retailers' e-commerce sites and allows for same-day delivery. With its focus on automation and integration, blu hopes to create new niches, such as temperature-controlled self-collection terminals, and expand into new markets. The startup currently handles thousands of parcels weekly and has the capacity to fulfill up to 200 orders per hour.

site_title: Australia's great wealth divide a sticking point in 2019 polls
summary: Australia is facing a widening wealth divide between baby boomers and younger voters, with the opposition Labor Party targeting this issue in the 2019 election. The country's economic growth has been driven by a mining boom and a surge in house prices, benefiting high-net-worth households. However, this has led to stagnant wage growth and high youth unemployment, particularly in regional areas like Nowra. The government is under pressure to deliver on its promise of a budget surplus by 2020, while Labor has pledged to cut tax benefits for the wealthy and increase spending on education and healthcare.

site_title: SIA flight suffers 'technical fault' after landing at Kolkata airport
summary: A Singapore Airlines flight carrying 241 people encountered a "technical fault" after landing at Kolkata airport in India on Saturday. The Airbus A-330 suffered a hydraulic failure, but all passengers disembarked safely. Engineers will service the aircraft, and the incident occurred after a similar report of an SIA flight experiencing a hydraulic failure at the same airport the day before.

site_title: For sale, must see: Former prison in upstate New York
summary: A former New York prison, Chateaugay Correctional Facility, is up for sale in upstate New York. The 99-acre property, closed in 2014, features 30 buildings and 98,000 square feet of space. The minimum bid is $100,000, with no guarantee of a buyer. The prison's closure was part of a state effort to reduce mass incarceration, but local officials have expressed concerns about the impact on employment. The sale is the latest in a series of state prison closures, with 13 prisons shut since 2011, resulting in a 30% decrease in the state's prison population and estimated annual savings of $162 million.

site_title: Grab's route change meets with scepticism
summary: Grab, a ride-hailing company, has rolled out new services and cut back on discounts for riders and incentives for drivers, sparking skepticism about its strategy. The move aims to differentiate Grab from new competitors, but observers warn it may drive away users and drivers. Grab's acquisition of Uber's South-east Asian operations and its dominance in the market have raised concerns about its ability to retain users and drivers. The company's decision to shift users towards a rewards system and maintain drivers' incomes has been met with criticism, with ComfortDelGro, a rival taxi operator, gaining market share.

site_title: ANZ cuts financial planner bonuses as inquiry reshapes sector
summary: ANZ Banking Group Ltd has cut financial planner bonuses as the country's first major lender to respond to the Royal Commission's inquiry into misconduct in the sector. The move follows a report that 5% of ANZ's financial planning product sales were deemed inappropriate. Other big lenders, such as Commonwealth Bank of Australia and National Australia Bank, are also simplifying their business structures and exiting wealth management. The Royal Commission's findings are expected to reshape the financial services industry, with industry experts predicting significant changes by 2020.

site_title: Vinhomes share sale raises US$1.35b in Vietnam's biggest issue
summary: Vinhomes JSC, Vietnam's residential property development unit, raised approximately US$1.35 billion in its initial equity offering, the country's largest-ever issue. The company is betting on rising home sales to drive its business, following strong economic growth and investor interest in Vietnam. Existing investors sold 10% of the firm's equity capital at 114,700 dong per share, surpassing an indicative range of 110,500-114,700 dong. This sale eclipses a previous offering by Vietnam Technological and Commercial Joint Stock Bank, which raised US$922 million.

site_title: Ensuring fair hiring and firing practices
summary: Singapore's Employment Act salary cap will be removed in April, potentially altering the employment landscape. The revised Act will cover all employees, including professionals and executives, for the first time. However, this change may lead to concerns about wrongful or unfair dismissal, as senior executives could claim compensation for termination. The government aims to strike a balance between employee protection and employer flexibility, introducing clearer guidelines on compensation for wrongful dismissal through the Employment Claims Tribunals. The move is expected to have a significant impact on the country's employment environment and job mobility.

site_title: Are telco tie-ups the way to stay ahead?
summary: Singapore's telcos are forming alliances to stay competitive in a crowded market. Singtel and Razer have partnered for a joint electronic payments system, while StarHub and MyRepublic have signed a network leasing deal. This strategic move aims to tap into new revenue streams and counter the threat of new entrants, such as TPG Telecom. By partnering with companies in the same space, telcos hope to expand their market footprint and offset declining revenue per user.

site_title: S-E Asia SMEs poised for growth
summary: South-east Asian small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are poised for growth, driven by the region's robust growth potential and favourable attributes such as a young population and burgeoning middle class. The digital economy is expected to add an estimated US$1 trillion to the region's GDP by 2025, making it essential for SMEs to seize new opportunities and harness new technologies to drive operational excellence and growth. Many SMEs are already investing in technology solutions, with a focus on software and services, and are exploring enterprise technology solutions to boost productivity, manage finances, and scale up operations.

site_title: Berkshire Hathaway increases stake in Apple by 75 million shares
summary: Berkshire Hathaway, led by Warren Buffett, increased its stake in Apple by 75 million shares, buying nearly 1 in 10 Apple shares traded during the quarter. This move follows a similar purchase by Apple itself, with the two companies collectively buying nearly 1 in 10 Apple shares. The significant increase in Berkshire Hathaway's stake in Apple highlights the confidence investors have in the company's growth prospects.

site_title: ComfortDelGro Taxi expands fleet on revived demand
summary: ComfortDelGro Taxi has ordered 200 new hybrid Hyundai Ioniqs, its first in nearly one-and-a-half years, due to revived demand. The first batch is set to arrive next month and will be leased out to growing taxi hirers. This expansion aims to capitalize on the increasing demand for taxis in Singapore, following a period of reduced orders. The move is expected to support the company's growth strategy in the taxi industry.

site_title: Malaysia poll overtures signal a longer road to reducing deficit
summary: Malaysia's ruling alliance has promised to increase cash handouts ahead of the general election, while the opposition vows to roll back a consumption tax. Economists predict that whoever wins, fiscal reform will be delayed due to the country's strong economic growth of 5.9% in 2017. The election was called earlier than expected, possibly due to the economic surge, which has persuaded Prime Minister Najib Razak to move up the election date.

site_title: Spackman to seek Catalist listing for combined entity of 2 subsidiaries
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group announced it has approved the spinoff of its subsidiaries Novus Mediacorp and Frame Pictures, with plans to list them on the Catalist board as a combined entity. Spackman owns 51% of Novus Mediacorp and fully owns Frame Pictures Co. The proposed listing aims to raise capital and unlock the full potential of the combined entity, which will be financially independent and able to capitalize on growing post-theatrical and camera equipment leasing markets.

site_title: Mending fences: Will China succeed in a charm offensive?
summary: China, under President Xi Jinping, has been increasing its assertiveness, sparking concern among its neighbors. In response, countries such as the US, Japan, India, and Australia have formed the Quadrilateral Security Dialogue, while others like Vietnam, Indonesia, and South Korea have strengthened ties with these nations. China has attempted to mend relations by visiting North Korea, engaging in talks with India and Japan, and hosting state visits. However, its continued assertiveness, including a rising military budget and deployment of missiles, may undermine efforts to improve relations.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Business news for May 7, 2018, includes: 
HIAP Hoe expects a net loss in Q1 due to foreign exchange losses and financial instrument changes. 
Keppel Corp divests 80% stake in a Chinese property project for S$105 million. 
Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust reports a 3.2% increase in second quarter distributable income to A$25.9 million. 
China Everbright Water secures a deal for the construction of a waste water treatment project for S$17.2 million. 
MindChamps PreSchool posts a 50.6% fall in net profit due to increased costs.

site_title: Nestle pays US$7.15b to Starbucks to jump-start its coffee business
summary: Nestle has agreed to pay Starbucks $7.15 billion to sell its coffee products worldwide, aiming to reinvigorate its coffee business. The deal will enable Nestle to expand the Starbucks brand through its global distribution network. Starbucks will use the proceeds to speed up share buybacks and improve its earnings per share. The partnership is part of a consolidation wave in the consumer drinks category, with companies looking to tap into the popularity of coffee among younger customers.

site_title: Australia pledges A$45m plan to help save the koala
summary: Australia has pledged A$45 million to help save its koala population, which is estimated to be as few as 43,000 in the wild. The koala population declined from over 10 million prior to European settlement in 1788. The funding will support conservation efforts, including habitat protection and research. The move aims to bring the koala population back from the brink of extinction.

images.alt_text: Habitat loss, dog attacks, car strikes, climate change and disease have taken their toll on one of Australia's most recognisable animals.

site_title: Cooperation, competition keep the Singapore-London relationship going
summary: The Lord Mayor of the City of London is meeting with Singaporean business and government leaders to discuss cooperation and competition between the two financial hubs. The UK and Singapore have a strong fintech relationship, with the UK's first FinTech Bridge established in 2016, and the Lord Mayor aims to improve cooperation and turn it into a "superhighway." The two cities also collaborate on combating cyber-crime, with UK companies like Darktrace and CyLon expanding their presence in Singapore. Trust and networking are also key considerations in strengthening the relationship, with the UK's Business of Trust programme encouraging businesses to embed principles designed to build trust.

site_title: Singapore banks humming along, but trade woes offer pause
summary: Singapore banks are performing well, with loan growth at a healthy clip and a significant reduction in bad loans. All three banks expect loan growth of around 10% for the full year. However, analysts are concerned about the impact of trade tensions, particularly the US's 50% copper import tariff, which could stymie trade flows and dampen economic growth. The possibility of a sharper-than-expected interest rate hike is also flagged by S&P, posing additional risk to the banking sector.

site_title: CapBridge appoints SGX's Chew Sutat as non-exec director; bags S$5m Series A funding
summary: CapBridge, a Singapore-based startup, appointed Chew Sutat, executive vice-president of SGX, as a non-executive director. The company secured S$5 million in Series A funding, exceeding investor demand. Chew brings capital market experience to guide the company's growth. CapBridge provides venture capital financing and pre-IPO deals for mid- to late-stage growth companies, with investors including SGX and US venture capitalist Tim Draper.

site_title: Delfi Q1 net profit jumps 33.1 per cent
summary: Delfi, a Singapore-based chocolate confectionery company, reported a 33.1% increase in Q1 net profit to US$7.6 million, driven by a 15.1% surge in revenue to US$107.3 million. The company attributed growth to sales of its own brand products in Indonesia and the run-up to Muslim Lebaran festivities. Delfi also acquired the Van Houten brand name in key Asian markets for US$13 million. The company maintains that it has adequate provisions for nine claims related to a divestment in Brazil.

site_title: Perceived level of bribery and corruption low in Singapore: EY
summary: A survey by EY found that Singapore's perceived level of bribery and corruption is low, with 10% of executives believing such practices remain prevalent in business. However, the survey also revealed a mismatch between intentions and behavior, with 28% of Singapore executives willing to justify making cash payments to win or retain business. Companies in Singapore need to improve their compliance programs and protocols to prevent misconduct, and step up on managing third-party agents, according to the report.

site_title: Time to upgrade independent director framework in Singapore
summary: Singapore's regulators and shareholders are calling for greater accountability and expertise from independent directors of listed companies. Recent cases of aggressive accounting and potential fake transactions have raised concerns about the effectiveness of independent directors as a safeguard against impropriety. A proposed amendment to the Code of Corporate Governance aims to improve the neutrality and skills of independent directors, and regulators may step in to support them when wrongdoing is suspected. Upgrading the independent director framework is seen as crucial to maintaining investor trust and confidence in the market.

site_title: Maintaining the human touch while going high-tech
summary: Mohammed Nizzaar Abdul Nazzeer, a 33-year-old former private-hire driver, joined blu as a driver and later moved to a supervisory role, where he maintains automated lockers and computer systems. He credits the human touch for his success, noting that customers and drivers prefer bluPort delivery, which is more secure and convenient than traditional home delivery. As he progressed to a delivery team coordinator role, he demonstrated an eye for efficiency, optimizing routes and suggesting faster alternatives. blu founder Prashant Dadlani emphasizes the importance of the human element in a high-tech firm, highlighting how people-driven processes are essential to the company's business.

site_title: Takeda near deal to buy Shire in its biggest purchase
summary: Takeda Pharmaceutical Co is nearing a deal to buy rival Shire Plc, the largest takeover by the Japanese company. The potential deal, valued at £46 billion (S$83.2 billion), would be announced by Tuesday's deadline set by UK regulators. Shire's board had sought an increase in the cash component of Takeda's offer, which was initially valued at €49 per share. The acquisition aims to replenish Takeda's pipeline of medicines for rare diseases, but may face a credit downgrade due to increased leverage.

site_title: Nobel literature body grants members leave after sex scandal
summary: The Swedish Academy, which awards the Nobel Literature Prize, granted four members leave after a sexual assault scandal. The scandal, sparked by 18 women's testimonies of harassment and assault, led to six members quitting, including the first woman permanent secretary. The four members, Lotta Lotass, Klas Ostergren, Sara Stridsberg, and Kerstin Ekman, were granted leave due to the turmoil within the institution. The scandal prompted the king to change the statutes, allowing members to resign and be replaced, and the Academy has announced plans to award two prizes in 2019.

images.alt_text: The Swedish Academy which awards the Nobel Literature Prize Monday said four members - who are traditionally appointed for life - were granted leave after a sexual assault scandal scuppered this year's award.

site_title: First signs go up for US embassy in Jerusalem
summary: US embassy in Jerusalem signs put up ahead of inauguration, marking a historic move by President Trump to recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital. The embassy, initially occupying part of a US consular building, will be inaugurated on May 14, coinciding with the 70th anniversary of Israel's founding. The move has delighted Israelis but enraged Palestinians, who claim Jerusalem as their future capital. The international community considers the annexation of east Jerusalem illegal, and many countries have yet to relocate their embassies to Jerusalem.

site_title: MindChamps Q1 net profit falls 51% on cost of sales and administrative expenses
summary: MindChamps PreSchool Limited reported a 51% drop in Q1 net profit to S$341,000 due to increased cost of sales and administrative expenses. Revenue rose 35.6% to S$6 million, primarily driven by an increase in school fees after acquiring four Australian preschool centres in 2017. Earnings per share fell to 0.14 Singapore cent, while net asset value per share decreased to 23.32 Singapore cents. The company remains focused on maintaining high-quality curriculum and pedagogy.

site_title: Shareholder activism off to strong start in 2018: JPMorgan report
summary: Shareholder activism in Asia is expected to continue growing, driven by increasing acceptance and the adoption of international best practices in investor engagement and corporate governance. In 2017, 106 activist campaigns were launched in Asia, accounting for 31% of global non-US activism. The number of campaigns in 2018 is on par with 2017, with regulators enacting reforms to encourage more engaged investors and transparent companies. Activism is now seen in all major Asian economies, with Japan and Hong Kong experiencing the most activity, and complex ownership structures being targeted by activists.

site_title: RE&S Q3 net profit slides 55% to S$0.86m
summary: RE&S Holdings Limited, a CATALIST-listed food and beverage operator, reported a 55.3% decline in net profit to S$859,000 for the third quarter, with earnings per share falling to 0.24 Singapore cents. Revenue increased 2% to S$35.3 million, driven by growth in the quick-service restaurants and convenience segments. Despite lower-than-expected results, the company aims to deliver better performance in the remaining fiscal year and derive greater value for shareholders.

site_title: Summit shows Asian geopolitical chessboard is changing
summary: China, Japan, and South Korea will meet on Wednesday for the first trilateral talks since 2015, amid the ongoing Korean reconciliation process and uncertainty over US President Donald Trump's international agenda. The summit comes as North Korea's leader Kim Jong-un prepares to meet with Trump, with the US seeking to negotiate a nuclear deal. China's President Xi Jinping will make a full diplomatic visit to Japan, while the US and Japan have imposed trade tariffs on each other. The meeting highlights the changing geopolitical landscape in the region, with significant downside risks and opportunities in play.

site_title: Scholars have mined Facebook data for years
summary: Researchers have harvested hundreds of millions of Facebook users' data over the past decade using scraper programs and quiz apps, often without proper security measures. The data, which includes user locations, interests, and interactions, was compiled for research purposes and sometimes left unsecured. The practice raises concerns about data leakage and misuse, with some academics warning that the data could be easily copied and sold to marketers or political consulting firms. Facebook has since implemented changes to its policies and given users more control over their privacy settings.

site_title: China Everbright wins deal for building of water treatment plant in Liaoning province
summary: China Everbright Water Limited has secured a deal for the construction of a water treatment plant in Liaoning province, valued at approximately 82 million yuan. The project, which will treat 30,000 cubic meters of wastewater daily, will be built on a 20-year concession basis. Construction is expected to be completed by end-2018, with operations commencing shortly after. The project will primarily process municipal wastewater and a small amount of industrial wastewater in the Pulandian District.

site_title: UE Q1 net profit up 3% to S$9m
summary: United Engineers (UE) posted a net profit of S$9 million for Q1, up 3% from the same period last year, driven by narrowing operating losses from its property development division and tripled operating profit from its engineering and distribution business. Revenue fell 1% to S$105.25 million, with property rental and hospitality revenue down 5% and property development revenue dipping 2%. UE aims to embark on asset enhancement initiatives for its investment properties in Singapore and may make selective acquisitions if opportunities arise.

site_title: HC Surgical taps IPO proceeds for equity stake in endoscopy practice
