images.alt_text: Prices for New Zealand's main commodities rose for the fourth month in a row in April, driven by an increase in dairy prices, ANZ Bank's commodity price index showed on Thursday.

site_title: Fitbit sees weak tracker sales hitting second-quarter revenue
summary: Fitbit Inc forecasted second-quarter revenue below Wall Street estimates due to weak sales of its fitness tracking devices. The company expects further declines in sales, citing competition from larger brands like Apple and Samsung. Fitbit's core wearable fitness trackers business has fallen sharply, but the company expects higher demand for its smartwatches. Revenue is expected to be in a range of $275-295 million, below analyst estimates of $309.9 million. The company's net loss widened to $80.9 million in the first quarter.

site_title: Malaysia's Mahathir being probed for 'fake news'
summary: Malaysian opposition leader Mahathir Mohamad is under investigation for allegedly spreading "fake news" after claiming his plane was sabotaged, just days before a closely-fought election. The investigation follows a new law aimed at combating fake news, which critics say is aimed at silencing criticism of Prime Minister Najib Razak. Mahathir, 92, is seeking to oust Najib and is the opposition's prime ministerial candidate in the general election. A Danish man was the first person punished under the law, receiving a one-week jail term for spreading fake news.

site_title: China's Xiaomi files for mega Hong Kong IPO, lifts lid on financials
summary: Xiaomi, a Chinese smartphone and connected device maker, has filed for a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO), expected to value the company at up to $100 billion. The IPO would be the largest by a Chinese tech company in nearly four years, surpassing Alibaba Group Holding Ltd.'s 2014 listing. Xiaomi reported a 67.5% revenue increase to 114.62 billion yuan in 2017, but also a net loss of 43.89 billion yuan. The company's relatively cheap handsets pose a challenge to market leaders Samsung Electronics and Apple Inc.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed on May 3-4 for public holidays
summary: Japanese markets closed on May 3-4 for public holidays, resuming trading on May 7. Meanwhile, global markets experienced fluctuations, with stocks down in Europe due to bank and healthcare sector drag, and the US-EU trade tensions in focus. Despite this, the US saw its S&P 500 and Nasdaq edge to fresh records. In Asia, Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data, while traders brushed off new Trump threats to extend the rally.

site_title: Urban nomads: Mongolian herders battle new future as many leave the land for the city
summary: Mongolia's nomadic herders, who have traditionally lived on the vast semi-arid grassland, are facing a changing future as climate change, over-grazing, and urbanization threaten their livelihoods. About 68,000 herders have moved to the city since 2001, with the population of Ulaanbaatar doubling in 10 years to 1.4 million, straining city resources and driving pollution. Climate change is also affecting traditional nomadic life, with droughts, harsh winters, and desertification impacting livestock and land. Herders' accounts of climate change are backed by data, and the country is struggling to address the issue, with air pollution estimated to cause over 4,000 deaths a year.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday; STI down 0.9% to 3,583.09
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.9% to 3,583.09 on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index retreating 32.19 points. About 57.8 million shares changed hands, with Ezion leading the decline. The US overnight, Wall Street stocks finished lower due to "resistance" amid trade war and inflation concerns, despite Apple's 4.4% jump in earnings. Japanese markets are closed for public holidays until Monday, May 7.

site_title: Nippecraft gets in-principle nod from SGX to transfer to Catalist
summary: Nippecraft, a paper products maker, received an in-principal approval from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to transfer its listing from the mainboard to the Catalist board. The proposed transfer is subject to conditions, including compliance with listing requirements and shareholders' approval. If successful, Nippecraft will be removed from the SGX financial watch list, which it was placed on four years ago due to consecutive losses and low market capitalization. The company has been granted an extension to meet the watch list removal requirements by July 1, 2018.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 2.81 points lower at 1,849.22 on Thursday, with volume reaching 45.9 million lots worth RM21.88 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 89 to 62.

site_title: Amazon bids for 60% stake in India's Flipkart: report
summary: Amazon has made a formal offer to acquire a 60% stake in Indian e-commerce giant Flipkart, competing with Walmart's bid. Amazon's offer includes a $2 billion breakup fee. The move expands Amazon's competition with Walmart beyond the US, following Amazon's purchase of Whole Food Market last year and Walmart's expansion of its e-commerce mission. The bid is seen as a strategic move to gain a foothold in India's growing retail market.

site_title: Asean growth to remain robust but higher interest rates, trade tensions pose risks: report
summary: Asean growth is expected to remain robust at a mid-5% level, driven by improving global demand, but risks include faster-than-expected interest rate hikes and escalating global trade tensions. The Singapore-based Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office forecasts 5.4% growth this year and 5.2% next year. Rising interest rates could lead to global financial conditions tightening and sharp market reactions, while escalating trade tensions could amplify through global value chains and increase uncertainties. Policymakers are advised to prepare for tighter financial conditions and consider a more active fiscal policy.

site_title: Australia's Commonwealth Bank loses 20 million customer records
summary: Australia's Commonwealth Bank has lost financial records for nearly 20 million customers due to a data storage error, but assured customers there's no need to worry as the lost data didn't include passwords or PIN numbers. The incident was discovered after the bank couldn't find two magnetic data tapes containing customer records from 2000 to 2016. The bank has taken steps to protect customer data and has not found any evidence of customer harm, with ongoing monitoring of the affected accounts continuing.

images.alt_text: Australia's troubled Commonwealth Bank admitted Thursday it has lost financial records for almost 20 million customers in a major security blunder - but insisted there was no need to worry.

site_title: US Reits outperform the broader market in rising rate environment
summary: Rising interest rates are helping US real estate investment trusts (Reits) outperform the broader US equity market. Despite concerns over corporate profit margins, Reits are expected to benefit from growing demand for commercial properties. According to research, Reits have outperformed the S&P 500 index 53% of the time when interest rates are rising. Experts attribute this to increased rents and net operating income from properties, leading to better returns. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates at least twice more this year, potentially benefiting Reits.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks sink at open on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell more than one percent at the open on Thursday, following losses on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index dropped 1.04% to 30,405.48, while the Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.39% to 3,069.08. Energy firms retreated due to declining oil prices. These losses mirrored the US market, where stocks were at record highs despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Crashed US military plane had nine people aboard: official
summary: A US military C-130 transport plane crashed in Georgia, killing all nine people on board, according to an official. The victims included five crew members and four additional passengers. The plane was completely destroyed in the fiery crash, with images confirming the fatalities. Major Paul Dahlen, a Puerto Rico National Guard spokesman, confirmed the details.

site_title: Sembcorp posts 34% fall in Q1 profit; says market environment remains challenging
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 34.1% drop in Q1 net profit to S$76.65 million, driven by a one-off gain absence and lower offshore projects contributions. Revenue rose 30% to S$2.76 billion, with utilities contributing 27% of the net profit. The company expects a challenging market environment in 2018, but remains confident in its ability to benefit from the market's recovery.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse to cut 300 jobs in cost-cutting drive: Handelsblatt
summary: Deutsche Boerse AG plans to cut around 300 jobs as part of a cost-cutting drive to reduce operating costs by 100 million euros ($120 million) by 2020. The move is aimed at lowering costs and is part of new CEO Theodor Weimer's strategy. Older staff may be offered buyouts or early retirement, with few having been offered such deals during Carsten Kengeter's tenure. The job cuts are part of a broader effort to modernize the company and improve its competitiveness.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Sembcorp, OUE Hospitality Trust, AGV
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported a 21% increase in first-quarter net profit to S$978 million, driven by strong growth in net interest income and net fee and commission income. Sembcorp Industries fell 34.1% in net profit to S$76.65 million due to one-off losses from the disposal of Cosco Shipyard Group and lower offshore platform projects. OUE Hospitality Trust's distribution per stapled security decreased to 1.26 Singapore cents, while AGV Group entered into a new memorandum of understanding to develop a regional hot dip galvanising business.

site_title: Oil gains slightly after Federal Reserve sees economy growing at a 'moderate rate'
summary: Oil prices rose slightly ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, with July Brent futures settling up 23 cents at $73.36 a barrel. The Fed expressed confidence in a moderate economic growth rate, which supports oil demand. Despite a surprise build in US crude inventories, oil prices were boosted by strong distillate demand. Iran's oil exports reached a record 2.6 million barrels per day, driven by the lifting of international sanctions. The US may reimpose sanctions on Iran, which could reduce global oil supplies and lead to higher prices.

site_title: UOB earnings up 21% to S$978m for Q1
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported a 21% increase in net profit to S$978 million for the first quarter of 2018, driven by 9% growth in total income. Net interest income rose 13% to S$1.47 billion, while earnings per share increased to 2.28 Singapore cents. The bank did not declare a dividend for the period.

site_title: Spotify narrows losses but disappoints on guidance
summary: Spotify reported narrowed losses in its first quarter, with a loss of 41 million euros (S$65.4 million) compared to 139 million euros in the same quarter last year. The company's earnings filing marked its first as a publicly traded company after listing on the New York Stock Exchange. Despite narrowing losses, Spotify disappointed investors by maintaining its full-year guidance, which remains steady.

images.alt_text: Top music streaming platform Spotify said Wednesday that it narrowed its losses in the first quarter, but it disappointed investors by keeping its full-year guidance steady.

site_title: Australia's NAB to divest wealth management arm
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) announced plans to sell its wealth management arm, MLC, as part of its strategy to simplify its business and achieve cost savings of over A$1.0 billion by 2020. The sale, which will be made via a demerger, initial public offering, or trade sale, comes after the bank posted a 16% slump in cash profit in the six months to March 31. The move is part of NAB's efforts to automate and streamline its business, following the sale of other assets such as Clydesdale and life insurance businesses to Japan's Nippon and Zurich.

site_title: Asean growth to remain robust but higher interest rates, trade tensions pose risks: report
summary: Asean growth is expected to remain robust at mid-5% level, driven by improving global demand, according to a report by the Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office. However, two key risks could derail this outlook: higher interest rates and global trade tensions. The region is forecast to grow 5.4% this year and 5.2% next year. Policymakers are advised to prepare for tighter global financial conditions and consider fiscal policy to support growth, as stronger global growth has built up regional buffers against external shocks.

site_title: China installs cruise missiles on South China Sea outposts: CNBC
summary: China has installed anti-ship cruise missiles and surface-to-air missile systems on three outposts in the South China Sea, according to US intelligence reports. The installations, at Fiery Cross Reef, Subi Reef, and Mischief Reef, are the first known deployments of military assets in the Spratly Islands. Experts say this marks a significant step in China's efforts to dominate the South China Sea, a key global trade route. The move is seen as a threat to regional claimants, including Vietnam and Taiwan, and could potentially challenge US regional presence.

site_title: AGV inks new MOU for regional expansion, ends previous deal
summary: AGV Group has entered into a new memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Hyday (South Pacific) Investment to develop a regional hot dip galvanising business in South-east Asia and China. The agreement includes establishing a facility in Myanmar and AGV will provide "best prices" for galvanising services. The MOU is legally binding for three years and supersedes a previous deal with Myat Mi Ba Co in Myanmar. AGV is terminating the previous deal, which was intended to create a joint venture with Myat Mi Ba.

site_title: Delivering 'care' in health care as the industry moves towards mechanisation
summary: In Asia, particularly Singapore, healthcare is evolving to stay relevant due to an aging population and rising chronic conditions. The industry is embracing technology, with telehealth, elder care robots, and AI-powered robots gaining traction. However, a key concern is that technology may not fully replace human connection, and patients crave personal interaction with their care providers. To strike a balance, healthcare leaders must harness technology thoughtfully, prioritizing patient needs and maintaining the core relationship between doctors and patients.

site_title: Midas could be insolvent soon amid fraud allegations
summary: Midas Holdings, a billion-dollar Singaporean company, is on the brink of insolvency due to alleged fraud and misdeeds in China. The company is facing lawsuits over unauthorized loans and guarantees, and is in serious debt with approximately S$401 million in liabilities. Former chairman Chen Wei Ping is under probe for fraud, and several senior executives have resigned. Trading has been halted, and the company's share price has plummeted to 19.2 cents per share. Shareholders are demanding accountability, and the company's board has promised to try to salvage the situation.

site_title: The Business Times Leaders' Forum explores business opportunities in Asean
summary: The Business Times Leaders' Forum will discuss business opportunities in Asean, a region experiencing impressive growth but facing hurdles. The forum, on May 21, will bring together thought leaders to address challenges such as regulatory and trade barriers, talent acquisition, and infrastructure development. Keynote speakers include Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing and Changi Airport Group's Chairman Liew Mun Leong. The event aims to provide insights on how businesses can overcome these challenges and capitalize on the region's potential, with a focus on Singapore's growth plans and regional expansion strategies.

site_title: Europe: Tech stocks shine after Apple results as shares climb
summary: European shares rose on Wednesday, driven by tech stocks after Apple's earnings exceeded weak expectations. Shares in AMS, STMicroelectronics, Infineon, and ASML jumped 7-8% as Apple's solid iPhone X sales boosted sentiment. The pan-European Stoxx 600 rose 0.7% to its highest level since Feb 5, with mining stocks providing a 2.8% gain. The euro's drop also supported exporter-heavy indices, while Italy's FTSE MIB reached a six-year high. Broadly strong earnings have been the main engine of the European index, with tech, consumer staples, and energy seeing the strongest growth.

site_title: US: Stocks fall, shrugging off strong Apple earnings
summary: US stocks fell 0.7% on Wednesday, despite strong Apple earnings and a Federal Reserve decision not to hike interest rates. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 declined, while the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.4%. Analysts attribute the market's resistance to worries over a trade war, monetary policy, and ongoing political turmoil. Despite Apple's 4.4% gain, the broader market largely ignored the results, with other stocks such as Gilead Sciences and Snap plummeting.

site_title: Federal Reserve leaves key interest rate unchanged, notes rising inflation
summary: The Federal Reserve kept its key interest rate unchanged, as expected, while signaling it's not overly concerned about rising inflation. The Fed's two percent target is considered "symmetric," allowing for some fluctuation above or below the level. Inflation measures, including the Personal Consumption Expenditures price index, have moved close to the target since the last meeting, but the Fed expects inflation to run near the target over the medium term. The decision is seen as a signal that the Fed won't overreact to inflation, and rates are likely to increase at a gradual pace this year.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Corp faces an amended lawsuit complaint, with an additional cause of action alleging aiding and abetting Petrobras' fraud. The Monetary Authority of Singapore will require OTC derivatives to be cleared on central counterparties starting Oct 1. Parkson Retail Asia posted a net loss of S$7.8 million in the third quarter, despite revenue growth. Oxley Holdings agreed to subscribe for shares in Aspen (Group) Holdings, and Addvalue Technologies raised up to S$10 million through a stock placement.

site_title: In corporate banking, a rising tide doesn't lift all boats: study
summary: A McKinsey report reveals that corporate banks' performances are diverging widely within each region, with top-performing banks having a return on equity (ROE) gap of over 15 percentage points from bottom-performers. This shift challenges the traditional notion that success in corporate banking depends on location. The report highlights the importance of cross-selling and loan pricing, with these activities accounting for 60% of revenue margin differential between top and bottom-performing banks. Successful corporate banks can achieve double-digit revenue growth and an ROE gain of 10 percentage points against lagging peers.

site_title: Hi-P Intl Q1 profit up 20% to S$10.1m
summary: Hi-P International, a Singaporean components manufacturer, reported a 20% increase in Q1 net profit to S$10.1 million, driven by a 15.1% revenue growth to S$281.1 million. The company attributed the increase to higher sales volume and efforts to diversify its customer base and market share. Despite a net foreign exchange loss, Hi-P's net asset value per share edged up to 68.12 Singapore cents. The company plans to explore value-driven opportunities for mergers and acquisitions to ensure long-term growth and sustainability.

site_title: Tesla reports narrower than expected losses, shares rise
summary: Tesla reported narrower-than-expected losses of $784.6 million on $3.4 billion in revenue in the first quarter of 2018. The adjusted loss per share was $3.35, beating expectations. Despite this, shares rose less than 1% to $303. The company made progress ramping up Model 3 production, reaching 2,270 vehicles a week, and aims to reach 5,000 vehicles per week in two months. Tesla plans to shut down production to make modifications and could begin showing profit in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Tesla on Wednesday reported that it lost less money than the market expected and said it was making progress ramping up production of Model 3 electric cars.

site_title: Cambridge Analytica to close after Facebook data scandal
summary: Cambridge Analytica, a British marketing firm hired by Donald Trump's presidential campaign, is closing after failing to recover from the Facebook data scandal. The company claimed it was "vilified" by unfounded accusations and had no realistic alternative but to go into administration. It had hired by Trump's campaign and had offices worldwide, but faced intense pressure after allegations emerged that it may have hijacked up to 87 million Facebook users' data. The company's CEO, Alexander Nix, was suspended, and Facebook's market value was wiped billions.

site_title: Opec's reason for sticking with the cuts rests on shaky ground
summary: OPEC and Russia are determined to maintain production cuts despite achieving their initial goal of rebalancing world oil markets. The primary reason for continued cuts is to encourage companies to invest in future supply, but analysts argue this is a pretext to keep oil prices high. Investment in new projects has increased modestly as crude prices rise, with companies operating more efficiently and reducing costs. Industry experts predict global oil production will continue to grow, making OPEC's production cuts unnecessary, with some estimating prices could reach $300 a barrel within a few years if under-investment persists.

site_title: So what's the way forward for the Iran deal?
summary: US President Donald Trump is inclined to abandon the Iran nuclear deal, despite attempts by Merkel and Macron to dissuade him. The Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) limits Iran's nuclear activities for 15 years and imposes sanctions in exchange for compliance. Trump has criticized the deal, calling it "insane" and "worst ever," and has refused to certify Iran's compliance. The deadline for waiving sanctions on Iran is May 12, and there are no indications that the US and Europe can reach an agreement to fix the deal. A US withdrawal would face strong international opposition, and could lead to a regional military conflict.

site_title: Pacific Star Devt partners holiday home blockchain startup
summary: Pacific Star Development (PSD), a Singapore-based developer, has partnered with holiday home blockchain startup Crowdvilla as its exclusive asset manager. Under a non-binding Memorandum of Understanding, PSD will source and evaluate properties for Crowdvilla, which aims to raise up to $50 million in a digital token sale. The partnership will focus on gateway tourist destinations in Asia and Europe, with room rates ranging from $100 to $200 per night. PSD will be paid annual management fees and performance fees, contingent on the successful completion of the token sale by the third quarter of 2018.

site_title: Plunge in Nissan's US car sales should hasten its push into China
summary: Nissan's US car sales plummeted 28% in April, with all models experiencing a decline. The company's aggressive sales strategy in the US has been unsustainable, with 90% of marketing costs coming from incentives. Nissan is shifting focus to China, where it predicts double-digit growth and sees opportunities in green car technology. The company's Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi alliance has also partnered with Didi Chuxing to explore fleet sales in China, marking a strategic pivot away from the US market.

site_title: UK baby boomers facing housing crisis: survey
summary: Almost half a million UK baby boomers (born 1940s-1960s) are struggling to pay rent, with 40% forced to take drastic measures such as borrowing from children or cutting back on essentials. The housing crisis is exacerbating the issue, with rising rents and homelessness. Many over 50s are renting from private landlords without supportive adaptations, and some have had to cut down on food and heating or take out loans. The National Housing Federation calls for more social housing construction and longer, more secure tenancies for those in the private rented sector.

site_title: Iconic wonders in the Weekend magazine
summary: Dr. David Livingstone named Victoria Falls after his visit, describing it as "scenes so lovely must have been gazed upon by angels in their flight." The falls remain a top traveler's destination, immortalized in a photo-essay in Weekend magazine. Meanwhile, German appliance maker Miele unveiled its groundbreaking Dialog oven at Eurocucina, a revolutionary kitchen technology.

site_title: Margate Point, Holland Tower put up for en bloc sale
summary: Singaporean developments Margate Point and Holland Tower have been put up for en bloc sale. Margate Point, a 15-unit apartment development, has a minimum expected price of S$38 million, while Holland Tower, a 19-unit condominium, has a reserve price of S$65 million. Both sites are zoned for residential use and have potential for redevelopment into high-rise buildings with unobstructed views. The sales are expected to bypass the Strata Titles Board application process if final owner consent is obtained, with completion possible within three months.

site_title: China's yuan settings point to concerns about EM currencies
summary: China's central bank has set its yuan mid-point against the dollar lower than expected, with deviations ranging from 37 to 94 pips over the past two weeks. Analysts say this is a deliberate move to slow the yuan's gains against emerging market currencies and maintain its trade-weighted basket stability. The move comes at a sensitive time for Beijing, with a delegation of senior Trump administration officials set to visit for trade talks, amid concerns over currency manipulation.

site_title: Singapore edges out Vietnam as Asia's top stock market
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index surpassed Vietnam's VN Index to become Asia's top-performing stock market this year, with a 6.2% gain in local currency terms. The VN Index plummeted 2% in the first four months, allowing Singapore to edge out Vietnam. This marks a significant shift in the region's equity market performance.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CapitaLand reported Q1 2018 results with revenue and gross profit surging 53.3% and 78.9% year-on-year, respectively. However, profit after tax and minority interest dipped 18.8% due to one-off items. Moya Holdings Asia reported a stellar Q1 2018 with a 560% year-on-year increase in profit after tax. The company is expected to benefit from acquisitions and expansion plans, including a 20,000 litres per second capacity increase, leading to strong organic growth and improved negotiating power.

site_title: Getting businesses to operate sustainably
summary: Women are playing a significant role in promoting sustainability in the corporate world. A 2015 Nielsen report found that 66% of global consumers are willing to pay more for sustainable brands, with 73% of millennials willing to pay extra. Over 200 international firms, including DBS, City Developments Limited, and Singtel, have committed to supporting more transparency on climate-related risks. Women pioneers, such as Gro Harlem Brundtland and Lise Kingo, are driving the sustainability movement. Companies are recognizing the benefits of sustainability, including lower costs, enhanced customer value, and improved productivity. As the sustainability movement gains momentum, the role of women is likely to increase further.

site_title: SPH's Orange Valley partners StarHub, ST Engineering for smart nursing home
summary: Singapore's Orange Valley Nursing Homes has partnered with StarHub and ST Engineering to test aged-care technologies at its new smart nursing home in Balestier. The trials, set to begin in 3-6 months, will focus on enhancing care services. The 4,700 sq m, five-storey facility, officially opened on Wednesday, aims to improve the lives of elderly residents through innovative technologies.

site_title: Mark Zuckerberg has a message: Facebook will keep building
summary: Mark Zuckerberg announced new products and features at Facebook's annual developer conference, including a dating app, group calling feature, and photo filters. Despite scandals over user data and privacy, Zuckerberg emphasized the company's responsibility to "keep building" and move forward. He introduced a new privacy control, Clear History, and promised to refocus on protecting users' information. Facebook also lifted its freeze on approving new apps and is becoming more proactive in fighting false news and taking down fake accounts.

site_title: Dearth of talent still biggest constraint for fintech: MAS
summary: Singapore's fintech sector has seen a self-sustaining growth, with 2,000 jobs created over the last two years, according to Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) managing director Ravi Menon. Despite this, talent remains the biggest constraint, prompting the MAS to update curricula and consider foreign talent. The Singapore Fintech Festival, set for November, aims to connect Asean startups with investors and showcase emerging technologies like AI and quantum computing, while also addressing regulatory and governance issues.

site_title: Strong growth in China and the Americas helps lift Hugo Boss sales
summary: Hugo Boss reported a 5% currency-adjusted increase in first-quarter sales, driven by strong growth in China and the Americas. The company's operating profit rose slightly, confirming its 2018 outlook. Hugo Boss refocused on premium men's clothing and invested in e-commerce and store integration, with online sales rising 43%. The company's sales rose to 650 million euros, slightly below analyst forecasts. Despite a 12% share price increase in the past year, shares were indicated to rise 1.9% in pre-market trade.

site_title: Asia-Pac GDP could add US$387b by 2021 if manufacturing transforms digitally: study
summary: A study by Microsoft in partnership with IDC Asia/Pacific found that if Asia-Pacific's manufacturing sector transforms digitally, its GDP could add US$387 billion by 2021, growing by 1% annually. China is expected to contribute nearly 50% of this growth. Digital transformation is linked to improved productivity, profit margins, and cost reduction, as well as revenue from new products and services. However, barriers to adoption include lack of skills and resources, cybersecurity threats, and a "siloed and resistant culture". A three-pronged strategy is recommended to overcome these challenges.

site_title: Marriott Vacations Worldwide to buy ILG for US$4.7b
summary: Marriott Vacations Worldwide agreed to buy ILG for approximately $4.7 billion in a stock-and-cash deal, creating the largest luxury brand for timeshare vacation resorts. ILG investors will receive $14.75 in cash and 0.165 of Marriott Vacations common stock for each share. The combined firm will have revenue of $2.9 billion and exclusive access to Marriott International and Hyatt Hotels loyalty programmes. The deal is expected to result in $75 million of annual savings within two years and add to earnings per share within the first full year after the transaction closes.

site_title: Uncertain future for SJM as Stanley Ho prepares departure
summary: Stanley Ho, Asia's richest man, is set to retire as chairman of SJM Holdings, Hong Kong's oldest casino company, on June 12, sparking concerns about a potential power struggle. His departure leaves a complicated succession plan, with the chairman's office expanded to four people, including his daughter and fourth wife. Analysts predict a power struggle due to the lack of clear control, as SJM faces declining market share and delayed openings of its new casino resort in Macau's Cotai strip.

site_title: Seven things Wall St wants Musk to talk about
summary: Tesla is set to report its first-quarter earnings, with investors and analysts focusing on production of the Model 3 and the company's path to profitability. The Model 3 is key to Tesla's plan to bring electric vehicles to the masses. Additionally, Elon Musk is expected to discuss the company's robotaxi expansion to California and Arizona, as well as its plans for India. The earnings report comes amid a tumultuous period for the company, with recent weeks seeing significant developments in the automotive and logistics industries. Musk's comments will be closely watched by investors and followers.

site_title: IMF says Saudi Arabia's economic transformation is still an oil story
summary: Saudi Arabia's economic transformation efforts remain oil-dependent, with the IMF forecasting a breakeven price of US$88 per barrel to balance its budget. The country's economy is expected to expand 1.7% in 2018, driven mainly by higher government spending. The reliance on oil revenue remains a concern, with the non-oil balance shortfall expected to rise to 39% of GDP in 2018. The kingdom's efforts to diversify revenue are ongoing, but its economy remains heavily reliant on oil exports.

site_title: SICC charity auction raises S$45,600
summary: The Singapore Island Country Club (SICC) held its annual May Day charity dinner, raising S$45,600 for charity through a charity auction. The top items sold were a Tiger Woods portrait and a Rolex watch, both fetching S$10,000. This brings the club's total charity fundraising to almost S$1 million, with 22 beneficiaries receiving support. The event, themed "Giving from the Heart," has been a long-standing tradition since 1972, raising over S$22 million for worthy causes.

site_title: Sias urges Fincantieri to extend offer period for Vard
summary: Investor advocacy group Securities Investors Association Singapore (Sias) has urged Fincantieri to extend the offer period for Vard Holdings following a contentious extraordinary general meeting (EGM) review by the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The EGM was marred by confusion over the chairman's decision to proceed with voting despite errors in a report. Sias calls for an extension to allow shareholders to evaluate the offer following the SGX's review, which will determine whether shareholders' approval for the delisting resolution was properly obtained. The exit offer is currently open until May 14.

site_title: OUE H-Trust Q1 DPS dips to 1.26 cents
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust reported a 1.9% increase in gross revenue to S$32.68 million for the first quarter, driven by higher contributions from the hospitality segment. However, income available for distribution decreased 2.3% to S$22.9 million, resulting in a distribution per stapled security (DPS) of 1.26 Singapore cents, down from 1.30 cents in the previous year. The trust's net property income grew 3.1% to S$28.3 million. Despite challenges in Singapore's retail scene, the manager expects demand for hotel accommodation to increase due to large biennial events and Singapore's role as Asean chairman this year.

site_title: STI at highest since 2008 amid slow ascent
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) reached its highest level since 2008, closing at 3,615.28, up 1.35 points or 0.04% on Wednesday. The market's slow ascent followed mixed Wall Street directions and tech sector performance ahead of Apple's earnings release, which beat expectations but missed iPhone sales targets. Electronics and semiconductor companies, including Venture Corp, continue to face weak earnings and sentiment. Despite this, some stocks like OCBC Bank, Hongkong Land, and Singapore Airlines rose, with 2.2 billion shares worth S$1.8 billion traded.

site_title: Apple to buy back US$100b in stock; dividend increased 16%
summary: Apple plans to buy back $100 billion in stock, increasing its previous record, and boost its dividend by 16% to 73 cents per share. The move is part of a broader trend of companies using tax windfalls to reward shareholders through share buybacks. Critics argue this can divert funds from investments in hiring and research, exacerbating economic inequality. Despite concerns, investors praise Apple's continued returns to shareholders, citing the company's profitable business and significant investments in hiring and development.

site_title: China manufacturing sector stable in April but exports slow
summary: China's manufacturing sector remained stable in April with a PMI of 51.4, down from 51.5 in March, but weaker exports indicate slower growth ahead. Economists attribute the slowdown to cooling global growth and decreasing foreign demand. This trend is expected to continue, putting pressure on policymakers to address economic growth.

site_title: Singapore has Asia's highest proportion of adults in full-time work
summary: Singapore has the highest proportion of adults in full-time employment in Asia, with 48% of adults in this type of work, surpassing Hong Kong (43%) and Taiwan (42%).

site_title: How's that Trump tax cut working out?
summary: The Trump tax cut, passed in 2017, has failed to deliver on its promised economic growth and wage boosts. Despite initial optimism, most voters have not seen a significant increase in their paychecks, and Republicans are no longer touting the law in their campaigns. Economists argue that a corporate tax cut would require a surge in business investment to yield long-term wage gains, but this has not materialized. The tax cut's effects are now comparable to previous failed tax cuts, with a swollen budget deficit as the only notable outcome.

site_title: Asia sees signs of export weakness before US-China talks
summary: Asia's manufacturing activity remained solid in April, but exports showed weakness, amid heightened US-China trade tensions. High-level talks between US and Chinese officials begin in China, with trade expected to be a top agenda item, as both sides threaten reciprocal tariffs on hundreds of billions of dollars worth of imports. The US has already announced tariffs on Vietnam, and the Asian garment industry is bracing for higher US tariffs, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Banks seeking HK deposits push time-deposit rates as high as 3%
summary: Banks in Hong Kong are increasing time-deposit rates to attract funding as short-term borrowing costs rise, with rates reaching as high as 3% for new savers. The trend is driven by expected Federal Reserve hikes and potential initial public offerings, forcing lenders to seek alternative funding sources. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's efforts to mop up liquidity may lead to a decrease in the city's banking system balance, with HSBC and other lenders offering higher deposit rates to lock up funding.

site_title: Overseas data centre strategy to keep MIT humming
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) has expanded its investment mandate to include US data centres, broadening its portfolio and providing a boost to its distribution per unit. The move is seen as a necessary growth path and a prudent use of resources, leveraging the network of its sponsor Mapletree Investments. MIT's overseas data centres have legs to run, supported by strong debt headroom and a growing demand for data storage. The strategy is expected to ride the tailwinds of exponential data growth, and analysts have welcomed the diversification, although some have raised concerns over valuation.

site_title: Indonesian leader slams oil firm Pertamina, 'convoluted' energy rules
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo criticized state-owned oil firm Pertamina for lacking investment in exploration, while urging the government to simplify energy rules. The country was once a major crude oil producer but became a net importer in 2002 due to a lack of investment. Widodo directed the Energy and Mineral Resources Minister to eliminate regulations hindering investment, aiming to attract more investment. Despite recent efforts to simplify regulations, interest in Indonesia's tenders has been low, with most offshore oil drilling activity concentrated in other countries.

site_title: Chinese fans ponder life without Friends
summary: Chinese fans of the TV sitcom Friends are heartbroken after a video site, Sohu, abruptly stopped broadcasting reruns of the show due to "copyright issues." The move has sparked anguish on social media, with millions calling for Sohu to re-up on its "Friends" rights. Friends gained a significant following in China through pirated DVDs and downloads, and many Chinese youngsters identify with the show, using it to learn American-style English. The show's cancellation has left fans feeling isolated and deprived of a cultural connection.

site_title: Freddie Mac sees strong growth in Q1 net income
summary: Freddie Mac reported a 32% increase in Q1 net income to $2.93 billion, driven by gains on derivatives and growth in its apartments business. The company rebounded from a $5.4 billion net deferred tax asset writedown in the fourth quarter due to the US tax overhaul. Freddie will not make a dividend payment to the US Treasury to build a $3 billion capital cushion. Domestic home sales remained resilient, with existing home sales increasing for a second month in March, and the company's portfolio for guaranteeing apartment or multi-family loans grew 30% in the first quarter.

site_title: US dollar consolidates gains after hitting 3½-mth high
summary: The US dollar consolidated its gains after reaching a 3½-month high on Tuesday, trading flat at 92.39 against a basket of its rivals. Investors await the outcome of the US Federal Reserve policy meeting, expecting a possible interest rate hike next month, despite the Fed keeping rates on hold. The euro received reprieve after posting its biggest weekly loss, and market expectations point to nearly three more rate hikes until January 2019.

site_title: BT Leaders' Forum explores business opportunities in Asean
summary: Singapore's Business Times Leaders' Forum will discuss business opportunities in Asean on May 21, featuring public and private sector leaders. Asean has experienced growth but faces hurdles in integration and talent acquisition. Keynote speakers include MTI Minister Chan Chun Sing and Changi Airport Group Chairman Liew Mun Leong, who will discuss infrastructure and connectivity prospects. The forum aims to address challenges and provide insights for businesses to capitalize on Asean's growth potential.

site_title: Najib likely to win election but opposition could win popular vote
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak is likely to retain power despite opposition leader Mahathir Mohamad's Pakatan Harapan coalition expected to win 43.7% of the popular vote. Najib's Barisan Nasional coalition is projected to win 40.3% of the vote, down from previous forecasts. The opposition's gains are attributed to increased support among majority ethnic Malays, which has shifted away from PAS and towards the opposition alliance. Despite this, Najib's coalition is expected to win the parliamentary seats, retaining power in the general election on May 9.

site_title: US factories showing signs of buckling
summary: US factories are experiencing bottlenecks due to surging demand, supplier delivery time delays, and rising materials prices. The Institute for Supply Management's April manufacturing survey showed production cooling, despite robust orders, and hiring slowing. The Trump administration's tariffs and new trucking regulations are exacerbating the issues, threatening profit margins and potentially blunting the effects of the $1.5 trillion tax cut. Economists warn of a slowdown or recession in late 2019, citing the added costs to companies and inflation in line with the target.

site_title: Greenback surge pares most of Sing dollar's 2018 gains
summary: The Singapore dollar (SGD) has seen its 2018 gains largely erased due to a surge in the US dollar, driven by improved US economic growth and inflation. DBS Bank predicts the SGD will reach 1.38 to the US dollar by year-end, while other strategists expect a recovery to 1.27. This is attributed to the US Federal Reserve's expected rate hikes and the tightening of monetary policy, which may lead to a stronger USD. The SGD's weakness is seen as temporary, with some strategists predicting a recovery to pre-surge levels.

site_title: Korea Summit dodges denuclearisation issue
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un and South Korean President Moon Jae-in held a summit on April 27, focusing on inter-Korean peace rather than denuclearization. The event was marked by symbolic gestures, including a tree-planting ceremony and a review of a full honour guard. Critics argue that the summit trivialized the serious issue of denuclearization, overshadowing the North's nuclear and missile challenges. The summit's lack of denuclearization details has sparked skepticism, with the issue to be addressed in a separate meeting with US President Donald Trump.

site_title: Art leaders ready to 'hit the reset button'
summary: International museum professionals and gallerists are ready to "hit the reset button" on long-standing practices due to significant changes in the American museum world over the last three years. They are rethinking assumptions and embracing technological advancements to reach more diverse audiences. Large galleries are being urged to subsidize smaller ones at art fairs to address the imbalance in market share. Some propose tax on larger stands to redistribute funds to smaller galleries, potentially offering discounts to standholders.

site_title: Fortis Healthcare jumps to two-month high after IHH raises offer
summary: Fortis Healthcare Ltd shares rose 5.3% to a two-month high after IHH Healthcare Bhd, a Malaysian private equity firm, increased its offer to 175 rupees per share, up from 160 rupees previously. The company's shares also gained 24% last month, the best performance since February 2015. Two Indian business families, Munjals and Burmans, also submitted revised proposals to invest 18 billion rupees each, increasing their offers. The move comes after Fortis's founders, Malvinder and Shivinder Singh, resigned from the board amid a dispute over a 5 billion rupee loan.

site_title: US adds 204,000 new jobs in April: ADP survey
summary: The US added 204,000 new jobs in April, according to ADP's survey, below the expected 225,000. This robust job creation is likely to drive down the US unemployment rate further, making qualified labor challenging for employers. The tight labor market may lead to the Federal Reserve raising interest rates more aggressively this year. Skilled talent is becoming increasingly hard to find, particularly in the high-skilled professional and business services industry. The trend suggests the economy is nearing a low unemployment rate of 4%, but this could lead to overheating and inflation concerns.

site_title: EU's Juncker refuses US trade talks 'under threat'
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker stated that the EU will refuse to negotiate US trade talks while under threat from the US. This comes after US President Donald Trump's eleventh-hour decision to spare the EU from punishing steel and aluminum tariffs for 30 days. Juncker described the move as "generous." The EU had been preparing to impose tariffs in response to the US action.

site_title: Disrupting the autocrats with the power of the Internet
summary: Authoritarian regimes have regained control over the flow of information in many parts of the world, often behind a veneer of democracy and elections. In contrast, cryptocurrencies like bitcoin and ethereum offer a decentralized and secure digital record system that can bypass censorship and surveillance. This technology poses a threat to authoritarian regimes, as it allows citizens to make payments and store information without being controlled by the government. While well-organized democracies have little to fear from cryptocurrencies, those whose power is based on controlling information have something new to worry about, potentially leading to a shift towards more open systems and meaningful political competition.

site_title: Softbank's talks over Swiss Re stake said to have stalled
summary: Talks between SoftBank and Swiss Re over SoftBank's stake in Swiss Re have stalled due to disagreements on price and management control. SoftBank, led by billionaire Masayoshi Son, was seeking a 30% stake, but Swiss Re executives have pushed back on selling more than 10%. The talks were limited by issues within SoftBank, including a pending merger and an initial public offering. Swiss Re CEO Christian Mumenthaler stated that a small stake would not allow SoftBank to influence the company's capital position, making a deal unlikely.

site_title: Why we need a self-defending smart city
summary: Smart cities are becoming a reality, with countries like Singapore, Japan, and Hong Kong investing heavily in technology to improve infrastructure and services. These cities aim to operate like living organisms, with digital sensors and AI-powered systems that can detect and respond to threats in real-time. The potential benefits include improved security, efficiency, and awareness, but also raise concerns about cybersecurity risks. As the digital world becomes increasingly integrated with city infrastructures, it is essential to balance the benefits with the risks and ensure a responsible and safe implementation of smart city technologies.

site_title: AusNet to voluntarily delist from SGX
summary: AusNet Services, an Australian energy company, will voluntarily delist from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) after 13 years, citing it as in the best interests of the company. The decision comes after AusNet Services maintained its primary listing on the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) and a secondary listing on the SGX since 2005. The company will continue to list on the ASX, and the delisting is expected to have no impact on its major shareholders, including Singapore Power and State Grid Corporation of China.

site_title: Healthy food packs from the heart
summary: Food from the Heart, a Singapore-based charity, has revamped its School Goodie Bag programme to include healthier food items. The programme, which has been in existence since 2003, provides monthly food packs to 5,600 low-income students and their families. The new additions aim to support healthier eating habits among the beneficiaries. CEO Kwa Eng Kiat stated that the charity has been privileged to serve the community for over a decade through its passion to feed the hungry. The revised packs will contain 16-17 essentials, promoting a healthier and more nutritious food option for the students.

images.alt_text: (Back row, from left) Terence Ng, a deputy director at HPB; Kwa Eng Kiat, CEO, FFTH and Ronald Stride, chairman, FFTH with student beneficiaries of the programme.

site_title: Saudi bank NCB's first-quarter profit up 10.5%, beats forecasts
summary: NCB, Saudi Arabia's largest lender, reported a 10.5% rise in first-quarter net profit to 2.99 billion riyals, beating forecasts. Bad debt charges fell, while fees rose. Deposits dropped 1.5% year-over-year to 309 billion riyals, and loans decreased 0.6%. The bank's profit surpassed analyst estimates of 2.44 billion riyals and 2.66 billion riyals.

site_title: Keppel O&M served with amended complaint in EIG lawsuit
summary: Keppel Offshore and Marine (KOM) has been served with an amended complaint in the lawsuit filed by EIG Management Company LLC. The complaint now includes an additional cause of action for allegedly aiding and abetting Petrobras and Sete Brasil's alleged fraud against EIG. EIG seeks US$221 million in damages and punitive damages. KOM plans to continue defending itself, calling the additional cause of action "without merit". The civil suit concerns KOM's role in a Brazilian bribery scheme related to a failed drill ship venture.

site_title: Close Xi aide to meet US trade delegation in Beijing
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping's top economic adviser, Vice Premier Liu He, will meet a US trade delegation in Beijing this week, amid a dispute over China's joint-venture requirements and intellectual property. US President Donald Trump has threatened tariffs on up to $150 billion worth of Chinese goods, while China has threatened retaliation, including tariffs on US soybeans and aircraft. The talks aim to address Sino-US trade and business ties, but China's resolve to open its economy further is seen as a non-negotiable point.

site_title: Kingboard Copper Q1 profit jumps 30% to HK$5.8m
summary: Kingboard Copper Holdings reported a 30% jump in Q1 profit to HK$5.8m, driven by a HK$30m licence fee and reduced PVB resin sales. Revenue fell 6% to HK$154m, while earnings per share increased to 0.8 Hong Kong cents. Net asset value per share rose to 394.66 Hong Kong cents. The company's shares closed 1.2% higher at S$0.415.

site_title: Far East Group one step closer to selling Lavender Street property
summary: Far East Group, an industrial refrigeration systems distributor, is planning to sell its property at 112 Lavender Street for approximately S$27 million. Chang Hua Construction has paid a S$1.08 million deposit, with the remaining S$26.2 million to be utilized for working capital, business expansion, and future investments.

site_title: StanChart CEO closes in on ROE goal in turnaround sign
summary: Standard Chartered's CEO Bill Winters is closing in on his 8% return on equity (ROE) target, citing a 7.6% Q1 ROE as a step in the right direction. Revenue grew 7% in the first quarter, led by retail banking and wealth management in Hong Kong, and costs rose only 3.8%. Winters believes the target is achievable in the medium term, following a turnaround plan that includes cost cuts, capital raises, and compliance system overhauls. The bank's underlying ROE has increased from 6.3% in Q1 last year.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.35 points to 3,615.28, driven by 2.2 billion shares worth S$1.8 billion traded. Losers outpaced gainers 259 to 192. This marks a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Singapore's manufacturing expands for 20th straight month
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector experienced its 20th consecutive month of expansion in April, with a Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) of 52.9, down from 53 in March. This marks the sixth consecutive month of steady growth, with the PMI fluctuating between 52.6 and 53.1 since October 2017. The steady expansion indicates a stable economic outlook for the country.

site_title: Mahathir under investigation for "fake news" - police
summary: Malaysian opposition leader Mahathir Mohamad is under investigation for allegedly spreading "fake news" about the sabotage of his plane ahead of a general election. The investigation is related to claims made by Mahathir in a campaign speech. The election pits Mahathir against Prime Minister Najib Razak. The anti-fake news law was introduced to curb false information. The investigation is ongoing, with no further details available.

site_title: China Great Land's CEO and independent director resign
summary: China Great Land Holdings Ltd's CEO Ong Peng Kwang Jemme and independent director Lim Boon Kwee have resigned, effective May 2. Jemme is stepping down to pursue personal interests, while Lim is leaving to devote more time to other commitments. Xing Fei, the 36-year-old executive chairman, has been appointed interim CEO. The company is seeking new board members to fill vacancies. Despite recording a loss of 6 million yuan last year, the firm's controlling shareholders have pledged financial support, indicating the company can operate as a going concern.

site_title: Hi-P International Q1 profit up 20% to S$10.1m
summary: Hi-P International reported a 20% increase in net profit to S$10.1 million in Q1, driven by a 15.1% rise in revenue to S$281.1 million. The company attributed the growth to higher sales volume, but also faced a net foreign exchange loss of S$13 million. Despite this, Hi-P's other expenses rose due to weakening currencies. The company's net asset value per share edged up to 68.12 Singapore cents, with shares ending 1.8% up at S$1.69.

site_title: Mastercard profit boosted by card customers traveling abroad
summary: Mastercard's profit increased in the first quarter of 2018, driven by a 32% rise in cross-border transactions on its network, the fastest growth in at least two years. This surge was fueled by a weakening US dollar, allowing customers to spend more on the firm's plastic cards while traveling abroad.

site_title: Razer teams up with Singtel to link their regional e-payment systems
summary: Razer, a gaming tech company, has partnered with Singtel to link their regional e-payment systems, aiming to take a significant share of Singapore's cashless market. The partnership, which includes a US$61 million acquisition of MOL Global, will give each partner access to the other's 1 million merchant points. The joint network, dubbed the "Star Alliance of wallets," aims to provide a unified digital-payments ecosystem in South-east Asia, competing with other players such as Alipay and Grab. The move is seen as a strategic bid to expand Razer's presence in the region, with the company's CEO stating that the market is "incredibly young" and full of opportunities.

site_title: Malaysia PM likely to win election but opposition could win popular vote - survey
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak is expected to retain power despite opposition leader Mahathir Mohamad's Pakatan Harapan coalition gaining 43.7% of the popular vote, surpassing the ruling coalition's 40.3%. The opposition is likely to win the popular vote but Najib's coalition will retain power under Malaysia's first-past-the-post system. The results may raise questions about Najib's leadership, particularly if his coalition performs worse than in the 2013 election.

site_title: Oxley to hold 10% of Malaysian property group Aspen through placement exercise
summary: Oxley Holdings has entered into a placement agreement with Aspen (Group) Holdings, acquiring approximately 10% of the Malaysian-based property group's enlarged share base. Oxley will subscribe to 97 million new shares at S$0.24 each, totaling S$23.3 million. The deal aims to create synergies and grow the business in Malaysian and regional property markets. Aspen has four ongoing projects and four upcoming developments in Penang, with a total of 3,974 residential units. The investment is expected to benefit both parties through joint project development and business opportunities.

site_title: US: Dow opens lower ahead of Fed decision
summary: The US stock market opened lower on Wednesday ahead of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy decision. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.42 points, or 0.01%, to 24,097.63, while the S&P 500 opened 0.56 points lower, or 0.02%, at 2,654.24. However, the Nasdaq Composite gained 7.74 points, or 0.11%, to 7,138.45, driven by Apple's 3.6% jump after its results.

site_title: Singapore Fintech Festival takes Asean focus in third run
summary: The Singapore Fintech Festival will focus on Asean fintech developments and opportunities in its third run, held from Nov 12 to 16. The festival will feature a new segment for deal-making, showcasing next-generation Asean startups and connecting them with investors. Customized research reports will be produced to offer "good-quality information" on participating fintech companies. The festival will also include a fintech conference and exhibition covering nine topics, including AI solutions, blockchain, and cybersecurity. The event aims to promote financial inclusion through innovation and digitalization in the Asean region.

site_title: EU unveils bigger post-Brexit budget
summary: The European Union unveiled a 1.279-trillion euro budget for the seven years after Brexit, featuring a plan to cut funding for countries that fail to respect the rule of law. The proposal, which includes a 1.114% contribution from member states, has faced opposition from several countries, particularly Poland and Hungary, over concerns of "political pressure." The EU aims to spend more on the digital economy, research, and border protection, but the plan's implementation is likely to be contentious, with potential fights over funding and policy changes.

images.alt_text: "We are proposing a new mechanism that will allow for the protection of the budget linked to risks arising from deficiencies in the rule of law." - European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker.

site_title: Broadway Industrial Q1 profit up more than 3.5 times
summary: Broadway Industrial Group, a precision components and form plastics producer, reported a Q1 profit increase of more than 3.5 times to S$0.59 million, driven by higher demand from customers. Earnings per share rose to 0.13 Singapore cents, while revenue increased 2.2% to S$91.4 million. However, net asset value per share slipped to 17.74 cents due to the depreciation of the US dollar versus the Singapore dollar. The company's shares ended 10.4% lower at S$0.103.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end down
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended down on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 0.27% to 30,723.88. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, down 0.07% and 0.05% respectively. The decline occurred as profit-takers chased the market's gains made before a one-day public holiday.

site_title: As social media grows, need for better laws gets stronger
summary: US social media giant Facebook reported a strong earnings result for the quarter ending March 31, with earnings per share (EPS) at US$1.65, exceeding analysts' predictions. The company boasts 1.45 billion daily active users and 2.2 billion monthly active users, making it the world's largest social network. Facebook's messaging platforms, WhatsApp and Messenger, saw 100 billion messages sent daily, a significant increase from the peak of SMS era. The company is exploring monetization opportunities, including advertising on WhatsApp, following the departure of its original founder, Jan Koum.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks edge lower; won falls
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index fell 9.77 points or 0.39% to 2,505.61, with Samsung BioLogics Co Ltd shares down 17.2% after breaching an accounting rule. The won fell 0.75% against the dollar to 1,076.1 per dollar, while US stocks ended with mild gains, influencing the Asia-Pacific region's markets.

site_title: Cityneon bags exclusive global rights to Hunger Games exhibition
summary: Cityneon Holdings secured an exclusive worldwide licence to "The Hunger Games: The Exhibition" for seven years, starting from the exhibition's first public opening date. The agreement also gives Cityneon the right to negotiate the purchase of exhibition materials and intellectual property from Lionsgate. This deal enhances Cityneon's portfolio of international IP property rights, including Marvel's Avengers and Jurassic World. The licensing agreement provides immediate revenue streams and profits for Cityneon, and the company is confident that the affiliation with Universal will continue to enthral audiences globally.

site_title: SHS Holdings bags two modular construction deals in New Zealand worth NZ$30m
summary: SHS Holdings, a Singapore-based company, secured two modular construction contracts in New Zealand worth NZ$30m. The contracts involve the construction of a 79-keys serviced apartment project in Queenstown and the supply of 20 modular units for the refurbishment of the Godley Hotel in Tekapo. The projects are expected to be completed by FY2019 and FY2018, respectively. This marks the company's initial success in the New Zealand market, with SHS group CEO Henry Ng stating that the company's efforts to grow its modular construction business have finally borne fruit.

site_title: UOB inks MOUs with 4 co-working space providers in Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has signed Memoranda of Understanding with four co-working space providers in Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia, offering preferential rental rates of up to 20% off for UOB's startup and SME customers. The partnership provides access to 33 co-working spaces across the region, aiming to address setup costs associated with expanding overseas. The agreement is expected to help businesses drive better performance and tap into local market norms, technology, and innovative ideas.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's stocks closed 18.34 points lower on Wednesday, at 1,852.03, with 2.10 billion shares traded worth RM2.43 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 551-311. This marks the second consecutive day of losses.

site_title: Rising snack demand in Europe, emerging markets fuels Mondelez beat
summary: Mondelez International reported a 14.4% increase in European sales and a 7.6% rise in emerging markets sales in its first-quarter results, beating Wall Street estimates. The company's power brands, including Oreo and Cadbury, saw an 8.2% rise in sales. However, Mondelez warned of pressures on adjusted operating profit margins in the second quarter due to rising commodity and freight expenses. Despite this, the company's shares rose 1.3% after the earnings announcement.

site_title: SGD continues to fall, giving up almost all of this year's gain against USD
summary: The Singapore dollar (SGD) has continued to fall against the US dollar (USD), nearing its loss of this year's gain. The USD surged on Tuesday, with the SGD dropping to 1.3348 from 1.3317. Experts predict the SGD will weaken further, with DBS Bank's Philip Wee forecasting a target of 1.38 for the year. The US dollar's strength is attributed to the Fed's rate hikes, with four expected this year and another four in 2019, according to DBS rates strategist Eugene Leow.

site_title: IHH sweetens Fortis bid amid heated takeover battle
summary: IHH Healthcare, Asia's largest private healthcare operator, has revised its bid for cash-strapped Fortis Healthcare in India, offering an immediate equity infusion of 650 crore rupees (S$130 million) at 175 rupees per share, a 9.4% premium from its previous proposal. This deal comes amid a heated bidding war with four other entities, including TPG-backed-Manipal Hospital and China's Fosun International. The revised terms will be withdrawn if Fortis does not respond by May 15.

site_title: Singtel, Razer ink deal to unite regional payment networks
summary: Singtel and Razer have announced a strategic partnership to link their digital payment systems in the region, creating a seamless integrated network for electronic payments. The partnership will give each firm access to the other's customers and merchants, with Singtel's 50 million users able to pay with Razer's zGold credits and vice versa. The joint system is expected to be implemented after regulatory approvals, and the companies will also explore developing digital media products and services, including electronic sports content and regional gaming events.

site_title: MAS to require central clearing of OTC derivatives from Oct 1
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will require the central clearing of over-the-counter (OTC) derivatives starting October 1, 2018. This rule applies to Singapore-dollar and US-dollar fixed-floating interest rate swaps, the most widely traded interest rate derivatives in Singapore. Central clearing mitigates counterparty credit risks by transferring the risk to a central counterparty.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets diverge at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets diverged on May 2, 2018, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris' CAC 40 experiencing contrasting movements. London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.3% to 7,541.12 points. The divergent performances were attributed to the May Day closures, which affected Frankfurt and Paris. The eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices were flat and fell 0.2% respectively.

site_title: Pacific Star Development unit is asset manager for startup Crowdvilla
summary: Pacific Star Development, a Catalist-listed developer, has signed a non-binding MOU with Crowdvilla, a startup planning to raise up to $50 million for a digital token sale to acquire and operate shared holiday homes. PSD will source, evaluate, and shortlist properties for Crowdvilla, focusing on "casual luxury" segments in Asia and later expanding to Europe, the Middle East, and the US. PSD will receive an annual management fee, acquisition and rental closing fees, and a performance fee, contingent on the successful token sale and definitive agreements.

site_title: Labor walkout trims shift at Cargill Nebraska beef plant
summary: A labor walkout at Cargill's Nebraska beef processing plant has partially disrupted production, diverting some cattle back to area feed lots. First shift employees protested the recently implemented shift differential for second and third shift employees. The plant, which processes 4.5% of the area's cattle, is expected to return to normal operations by Wednesday. The disruption is expected to have minimal impact on overall cattle prices, as the affected cattle were already paid for. The company is working to resolve the issue quickly.

site_title: As Stanley Ho prepares to cash in his chips, an uncertain future for SJM
summary: Macau's SJM Holdings, controlled by Stanley Ho's family, faces uncertainty as its chairman retires in June. The company is playing catch-up with rivals amid a gambling boom in Macau, and a delayed US$4.6 billion casino resort. Analysts predict a potential power struggle after Ho's departure, which could impact the company's future.

site_title: Drugmaker Novo Nordisk beats Q1 profit expectations, nudges up 2018 outlook
summary: Novo Nordisk, the world's largest diabetes drug maker, reported a 8% decrease in operating profit to 12.4 billion Danish crowns in Q1 due to US dollar depreciation. However, the company beat analyst expectations and raised its 2018 sales and profit forecast, with growth of 3-5% and 2-5% respectively. This is driven by new obesity drugs and a once-weekly injection and tablet version of its semaglutide drug, Ozempic, which has received positive feedback and formulary coverage is progressing well.

site_title: Asia-Pacific GDP could add US$387b by 2021 if manufacturing sector digitally transforms: Study
summary: A study by Microsoft in partnership with IDC Asia/Pacific found that if the Asia-Pacific manufacturing sector digitally transforms, its GDP could add US$387 billion by 2021, growing by 1.0% annually. China would contribute nearly 50% to this growth. Digital transformation involves reimagining processes to create value for customers and maintain a competitive advantage. While 44% of respondents track data usage as a key performance indicator, only 44% have an allocated budget for digital transformation, citing barriers such as skills and resources shortages, cybersecurity threats, and a "siloed and resistant culture."

site_title: Inside Theresa May's Brexit war cabinet, where Tory battles rage
summary: Theresa May's Brexit war cabinet, also known as "The SN," is set to meet to discuss the UK's customs arrangements with the EU. The 11-member cabinet is divided on the issue, with pro-Brexit ministers led by Boris Johnson and pro-EU ministers including Chancellor Philip Hammond and Business Secretary Greg Clark. The meeting may not produce a final conclusion, and the decision ultimately rests with May. The cabinet's dynamic has shifted since Amber Rudd's replacement by Sajid Javid, who is closer to the pro-Brexit lobby. The outcome could impact the UK's negotiations with the EU and the potential for a meaningful Brexit deal.

site_title: Mall owners, retailers clash on avalanche of online returns
summary: Mall owners and retailers are clashing over online returns, with retailers deducting returns from sales figures, affecting mall owners' crucial sales per square foot metric. This issue is complicated by the rise of e-commerce, where returns are estimated to be four times the rate for physical-store sales. While returns can drive foot traffic and additional purchases, the lack of standard reporting guidelines is creating tension between landlords and retailers. The problem is expected to worsen as online sales increase, with estimates suggesting online sales will represent 24% of total retail sales by 2027.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore tops Asia in adult full-time employment, with 48% of adults in this type of work. Meanwhile, Singtel and Razer have announced a strategic partnership to link their regional payment systems. In other news, Vietnam reacts to the Trump tariff announcement, the Asian garment industry braces for higher US tariffs, and Malaysia's agency plans to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and Citigroup sets a target for the global equity index by mid-2026.

images.alt_text: Singapore has emerged as the top Asian country in adult full-time employment, excluding those self-employed, with 48 per cent of adults having this type of work.

site_title: Holland Tower offered for en bloc sale with S$65m reserve price
summary: The owners of the 19-unit Holland Tower condominium in Singapore's Holland Village have offered the site for collective sale by tender with a reserve price of S$65 million. The freehold site occupies 21,871 sq ft and is zoned for good-class bungalows, allowing for redevelopment to its current intensity with approval. The tender closes on May 30. The reserve price works out to S$1,489 psf ppr, implying a maximum allowable built-up area of about 43,650 sq ft.

site_title: OUE Hospitality Trust DPS falls to 1.26 cents
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust reported a 2.3% decline in income available for distribution to 1.26 Singapore cents per stapled security for the first quarter, down from 1.30 cents in the previous year. Gross revenue grew 1.9% to S$32.68 million, driven by the hospitality segment, while net property income increased 3.1% to S$28.3 million. The trust's manager expects demand for hotel accommodation to rise due to the return of biennial events and Singapore's Asean chairmanship, but noted challenges in the competitive retail market.

site_title: China prepares tech sector for battle as US trade team arrives
summary: China is preparing its tech sector for a potential trade battle with the US, following the arrival of a US trade delegation in Beijing. China's reliance on foreign semiconductor imports, particularly from the US, is a major concern for Washington. To address this, Beijing has invested around $100 billion in building its semiconductor industry since 2014, with plans to create a second national fund. Despite these efforts, China remains behind in the semiconductor race, with experts warning that it will take many years for these investments to make progress.

site_title: Building boom lifts Lisbon allure and property prices
summary: Lisbon, Portugal, is experiencing a building boom, with scores of construction projects underway, transforming the city's skyline and driving economic growth. The sector has seen a significant surge in activity, with planning permissions and projects increasing after years of urban decline. This has led to a rise in property prices, with many areas experiencing a resurgence in popularity, such as Campo das Cebolas, where renovated apartments are now commanding high prices. Regulatory measures, including the introduction of "golden visas" and preferential tax regimes, have contributed to the boom, making Lisbon an attractive destination for investors and residents.

site_title: Australian shares rise as Qantas surges, banks firm; NZ up too
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% to 6,050.2, driven by Qantas' forecast of a record annual profit, with the airline surging 8.1%. The Australian industrials index climbed 1.5%, while financials extended gains for a fourth consecutive session. Woolworths Group Ltd rose 0.9% and Commonwealth Bank of Australia ticked up 0.4%. New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index firmed 0.7%.

site_title: Hugo Boss sales helped by rebound in China and Americas
summary: German fashion house Hugo Boss reported a 5% currency-adjusted increase in first-quarter sales, driven by strong growth in China and the Americas. The company's operating profit increased slightly, allowing it to confirm its 2018 outlook. Hugo Boss refocused on premium men's clothing with a modern twist, and online sales rose 43% in the quarter. The company's shares were indicated up 1.9% in pre-market trade, following a 12% gain in the past year.

site_title: California leads coalition against new car emissions standards
summary: A coalition of 18 US states, led by California, sued the Trump administration over plans to roll back vehicle emissions standards. The states seek to protect standards set under President Barack Obama, which aim to raise fuel efficiency to 50 miles per gallon by 2025. The lawsuit targets the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and claims the standards, set in 2012, are being achieved ahead of schedule. The move is part of the Trump administration's efforts to reduce environmental regulations, following a pattern of actions seen in other areas.

site_title: Chilly Britain absorbing more gas that would have gone to Europe
summary: Britain is absorbing more natural gas due to cooler weather and North Sea field outages, reducing the need to export to Europe. This has led to higher prices in Britain compared to the continent, making exports unattractive for now. As a result, UK gas exports have reached the lowest levels in at least a decade for this time of year, with Britain keeping more of the fuel for its own use. This trend is expected to continue until warmer weather returns and heating demand subsides.

site_title: Xerox CEO to resign in settlement with top shareholders
summary: Xerox CEO Jeff Jacobson will resign following a US judge's temporary block of the company's takeover by Fujifilm. The decision comes after a settlement between Jacobson and top shareholders, who control 15.2% of Xerox shares and opposed the deal. As part of the agreement, Keith Cozza will become board chairman and John Visentin will take over as CEO, both candidates supported by the shareholders.

site_title: China's HNA sells property developer unit in US$456m deal
summary: China's HNA Group sold a real-estate focused unit to Fusheng Group for 2.9 billion yuan (S$609.1 million), marking a 400 million yuan gain. This sale is part of HNA's efforts to raise funds amid a broader sell-down of assets, following a US$50 billion acquisition spree. The conglomerate has faced issues with regulators and has seen pending deals collapse. Since 2018, HNA has agreed to sell over US$10 billion worth of real estate assets globally.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes flat on Wednesday afternoon at 3,615.7
